question: Were Scott Derrickson and Ed Wood of the same nationality?
pos: Scott Derrickson is an American filmmaker who is famous for directing scary movies like Sinister, The Exorcism of Emily Rose, and Deliver Us From Evil. He also directed the Marvel movie Doctor Strange. He currently lives in Los Angeles, California.
Edward Davis Wood Jr. was an American who worked in the film industry as a filmmaker, actor, writer, producer, and director. He was born on October 10, 1924, and passed away on December 10, 1978.
neg: The movie "Ed Wood" was made in 1994 by Tim Burton and features Johnny Depp as the main character, Ed Wood. It focuses on a specific time in Wood's life when he was making his most famous movies and his friendship with actor Bela Lugosi, played by Martin Landau. The film also stars Sarah Jessica Parker, Patricia Arquette, Jeffrey Jones, Lisa Marie, and Bill Murray in supporting roles.

Woodson is a place in Pulaski County, Arkansas, in the United States. It had 403 people living there in 2010. Woodson is part of the Little Rock–North Little Rock–Conway Metropolitan Statistical Area. The area, including Woodson Lake and Wood Hollow, is named after Ed Wood Sr., who was a well-known plantation owner, trader, and businessman in the early 1900s. Woodson is next to the Wood Plantation, which was the biggest plantation owned by Ed Wood Sr.

Tyler Bates is an American musician who creates music for movies, TV shows, and video games. He is known for his work in action and horror films like Dawn of the Dead, 300, Sucker Punch, and John Wick. Bates has worked with directors such as Zack Snyder, Rob Zombie, and James Gunn. He has scored all of Gunn's films, including Guardians of the Galaxy, which was a huge hit in 2014. Bates is also the lead guitarist for the rock band Marilyn Manson and has produced their albums The Pale Emperor and Heaven Upside Down.

In 2014, a movie called Deliver Us from Evil was made in America. It falls under the supernatural horror genre and was directed by Scott Derrickson and produced by Jerry Bruckheimer. The story is based on a real-life book called Beware the Night, written by Ralph Sarchie and Lisa Collier Cool in 2001. The movie features actors like Eric Bana, Édgar Ramírez, Sean Harris, Olivia Munn, and Joel McHale in the lead roles. It hit theaters on July 2, 2014.

Adam Collis is an American filmmaker and actor. He went to Duke University from 1986 to 1990 and the University of California, Los Angeles from 2007 to 2010. He also studied cinema at the University of Southern California from 1991 to 1997. Collis started his career as an assistant director for Scott Derrickson's short film Love in the Ruins in 1995. In 1998, he portrayed Crankshaft in Eric Koyanagi's film Hundred Percent.

Sinister is a scary movie from 2012 about a writer named Ellison Oswalt, played by Ethan Hawke, who finds some creepy home movies in his attic that threaten his family. It was directed by Scott Derrickson and written by Derrickson and C. Robert Cargill.

Conrad Brooks is an American actor who was born in Baltimore, Maryland on January 3, 1931. He moved to Hollywood, California in 1948 to pursue acting and started his career in movies by appearing in films directed by Ed Wood, such as Plan 9 from Outer Space, Glen or Glenda, and Jail Bait. After taking a break from acting in the 1960s and 1970s, he returned in the 1980s due to the continued interest in Ed Wood's films. Since then, he has been very active in acting and has also written, produced, and directed several films.

Doctor Strange is a 2016 American superhero movie about a character from Marvel Comics. It was made by Marvel Studios and released by Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures. This movie is part of the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), which includes many superhero films. The movie was directed by Scott Derrickson and written by him along with Jon Spaihts and C. Robert Cargill. The main actor, Benedict Cumberbatch, plays the character Stephen Strange, alongside other actors like Chiwetel Ejiofor, Rachel McAdams, and Tilda Swinton. In the movie, Stephen Strange, a surgeon, learns about magic and sorcery after a car accident ends his medical career.

question: What government position was held by the woman who portrayed Corliss Archer in the film Kiss and Tell?
pos: Shirley Temple Black was an American actress, singer, and dancer who was very popular in Hollywood as a child from 1935 to 1938. When she grew up, she became a diplomat and held important roles like being the United States ambassador to Ghana and Czechoslovakia, as well as serving as the Chief of Protocol of the United States.

The movie "Kiss and Tell" is a comedy from 1945 that features Shirley Temple as Corliss Archer, a 17-year-old girl. The story follows two teenage girls who begin showing interest in boys, which worries their parents. The parents argue about which girl is setting a bad example, causing more trouble than they realize.
neg: Corliss Archer was a radio show that aired from 1943 to 1956. It was created to compete with another popular show called A Date with Judy. At one point, it was even broadcast on NBC as a temporary replacement for The Bob Hope Show. The show moved around to different networks but eventually returned to CBS. Surprisingly, despite being on the air for a long time, there are only a few episodes that still exist today.

Janet Marie Waldo was an American actress who was famous for providing the voices of characters in animated shows like Judy Jetson, Nancy in Shazzan, Penelope Pitstop, and Josie in Josie and the Pussycats. She also played the title role in the radio show Meet Corliss Archer.

"Meet Corliss Archer" was a TV show that aired on CBS from July 13, 1951, to August 10, 1951, and later in syndication from April to December 1954 through the Ziv Company. It was based on a radio series with the same name, which in turn was inspired by short stories written by F. Hugh Herbert.

The position of Lord High Treasurer, or Lord Treasurer, has been a part of the British government since 1707. The person in this role is the third-highest-ranking official, after the Lord High Steward and the Lord High Chancellor.

"A Kiss for Corliss" is a comedy movie from 1949 directed by Richard Wallace and written by Howard Dimsdale. It features Shirley Temple in her last leading role and final film appearance. This movie is a sequel to the 1945 film "Kiss and Tell." Before its release, "A Kiss for Corliss" was renamed "Almost a Bride," which is the title shown in the movie's opening credits. The film was distributed by United Artists and came out on November 25, 1949.

The Secretary of State for Constitutional Affairs was a position in the British Government that was established in 2003. Some responsibilities of the Lord Chancellor's Department were moved to this new role. Later on, additional duties were also shifted to the Secretary of State for Constitutional Affairs from the First Secretary of State, who was the Deputy Prime Minister.

In rural areas of the Indian sub-continent, there is a government administrative position called the Village Accountant. This role is known by different names such as Patwari, Talati, Patel, Karnam, Adhikari, Shanbogaru, Patnaik, and others depending on the region. For example, in Telangana, Bengal, North India, and Pakistan, the office and the officeholder are referred to as Patwari, while in Sindh it is called tapedar. In Andhra Pradesh, the position is known as Karnam, in Orissa as Patnaik, and in Tamil Nadu as Adhikari. In Karnataka, Gujarat, and Maharashtra, it is commonly known as Talati. In Northern Karnataka and Maharashtra, it was known as Kulkarni, and in South Karnataka, it was referred to as Shanbogaru.

Charles Craft was a film and television editor who was born in England on May 9, 1902, and later moved to Hollywood in 1927 to work in the film industry. He edited his first film, Painting the Town, in 1927 and went on to edit a total of 90 feature-length films over the next 25 years. In the early 1950s, he transitioned to television editing, starting with the show Racket Squad from 1951 to 1953. Throughout the 1950s, he worked on various series including Meet Corliss Archer, Science Fiction Theatre, and Highway Patrol. In the late 1950s and early 1960s, he was a main editor on Sea Hunt, editing over half of the episodes. His final film project was editing Flipper's New Adventure in 1964, which led to editing the television series based on the film. Craft retired in 1966 and passed away on September 19, 1968, in Los Angeles, California.

question: What science fantasy young adult series, told in first person, has a set of companion books narrating the stories of enslaved worlds and alien species?
pos: The Hork-Bajir Chronicles is a companion book to the Animorphs series, written by K. A. Applegate. It fits into the series before book #23, The Pretender, but the events in the story happen between The Ellimist Chronicles and The Andalite Chronicles. The book is introduced by Tobias, who visits the valley of the free Hork-Bajir. There, Jara Hamee tells him the story of how the Yeerks enslaved the Hork-Bajir. The story follows Aldrea, an Andalite, and her Hork-Bajir companion, Dak Hamee, as they try to save their world from the invasion. Jara Hamee's story is narrated from the perspectives of Aldrea, Dak Hamee, and Esplin 9466, alternating similar to the Megamorphs books.

Animorphs is a series of young adult books written by Katherine Applegate and Michael Grant under the name K. A. Applegate. The books are told from the perspective of six main characters who take turns narrating. The series explores themes like horror, war, morality, and growing up.
neg: The Andre Norton Award is given each year by the Science Fiction and Fantasy Writers of America to the author of the best young adult or middle grade science fiction or fantasy book published in the United States the previous year. It is named after the famous author Andre Norton and was created in 2005 by Catherine Asaro and the SFWA Young Adult Fiction committee. Any young adult or middle grade science fiction or fantasy book, including graphic novels, can be considered for the award, regardless of length. The award is presented alongside the Nebula Awards and follows the same nomination and voting process. Books can be nominated for both the Andre Norton Award and a Nebula Award at the same time.

Victoria Hanley is an American author who writes fantasy novels for young adults. Her first three books, The Seer And The Sword, The Healer's Keep, and The Light Of The Oracle, are related to each other. Her latest book, Indigo Magic, was released in March 2012 as a sequel in a series published by Egmont USA. In addition to her fiction work, she has also written two non-fiction books through Cotton Wood Press: Seize the Story: A Handbook For Teens Who Like To Write, and Wild Ink: A Grownups Guide To Writing Fiction For Teens.

Shadowshaper is a young adult novel written by Daniel José Older in 2015. The story is about Sierra Santiago, a teenager of Afro-Boricua descent living in Brooklyn. Sierra comes from a family of shadowshapers, who are people that connect art with spirits from their ancestors. As their neighborhood faces changes due to gentrification and a dangerous figure threatens their magical abilities, Sierra must embrace her cultural roots and artistic talents to protect her community from harm.

"Left Behind: The Kids" is a series of 40 short novels aimed at young adults, written by Jerry B. Jenkins, Tim LaHaye, and Chris Fabry. The books follow a group of teenagers who go through the rapture and tribulation, based on Bible scriptures and plots from the adult series "Left Behind." The series was published by Tyndale House Publishing between 1997 and 2004 and has sold over 11 million copies globally.

Since 1998, Square Enix has produced many companion books focusing on artwork, developer interviews, and background information about the fictional worlds and characters in its games, rather than gameplay details. The first series, called Perfect Works, was created by Square's subsidiary DigiCube and consisted of three books released between 1998 and 1999. After that, they started the Ultimania series, which is a combination of "ultimate" and "mania," written by Studio BentStuff. This studio had previously made game guides for Square's Final Fantasy VII. The books were initially published by DigiCube until it closed in 2003. Square then merged with Enix on April 1, 2003, forming Square Enix, which continued producing companion books.

The Divide trilogy is a series of fantasy novels for young adults written by Elizabeth Kay. The story is set in a different world from our own. The trilogy consists of three books: The Divide (2002), Back to The Divide (2005), and Jinx on The Divide (2006). The first book was originally published by Chicken House, which is now part of Scholastic. Scholastic later published the other two books and reprinted the first one. The trilogy has been translated into several languages including French, German, Spanish, Finnish, Chinese, Japanese, Portuguese, Italian, Romanian, and Dutch. The illustrations inside the books are done by Ted Dewan.

Science Fantasy was a British magazine that focused on fantasy and science fiction. It was launched in 1950 by Nova Publications as a companion to another magazine called New Worlds. The first editor was Walter Gillings, but he was later replaced by John Carnell to save money. Carnell edited both magazines until Nova went out of business in 1964. The magazine was then acquired by Roberts & Vinter, who hired Kyril Bonfiglioli as the new editor. Bonfiglioli changed the title to Impulse in 1966, but this caused confusion with distributors and sales dropped. The title was changed again to SF Impulse for the last few issues. Unfortunately, Science Fantasy stopped being published the following year when Roberts & Vinter faced financial difficulties due to their printer going bankrupt.

Etiquette & Espionage is a steampunk novel for young adults written by Gail Carriger. It is her first book for young adults and takes place in the same world as her popular Parasol Protectorate series for adults.

question: Are the Laleli Mosque and Esma Sultan Mansion located in the same neighborhood?
pos: The Laleli Mosque, also known as the Tulip Mosque, is a mosque built in the 18th century during the Ottoman Empire. It is situated in Laleli, Fatih, Istanbul, Turkey.

The Esma Sultan Mansion, a historic waterside mansion located in the Ortaköy neighborhood of Istanbul, Turkey, is now a cultural center. It was named after its original owner, Esma Sultan, and has been renovated for its current use.
neg: Esma Sultan was an Ottoman princess, born on March 21, 1873, and passed away on May 7, 1899. She was the daughter of Sultan Abdülaziz and Gevheri Kadın. Gevheri Kadın was the daughter of Salih Bey Svatnba. Esma Sultan was the half-sister of Abdülmecid II, who was the last Caliph of the Muslim world.

The Great Mosque of Algiers, also known as Djama’a al-Kebir, is a historic mosque in Algiers, Algeria, located near Algiers Harbor. The mosque was built in 1097, as indicated by an inscription on the pulpit. It is also called Grand Mosque d'Alger, El Kebir Mosque, and Jami Masjid. This mosque is a rare example of Almoravid architecture and is the oldest mosque in Algiers, second only to the Sidi Okba Mosque in Algeria. The minaret, built in 1332, was constructed by the Ziyyanid Sultan of Tlemcen. The outer gallery of the mosque was added in 1840 during a street reconstruction project by the French.

Küçük Hüseyin Pasha, also called Tayazade Damat Küçük Hüseyin Pasha, was a Turkish leader and naval commander in the Ottoman Empire. He served as the Grand Admiral of the Ottoman Navy from March 11, 1792, until December 7, 1803. He became part of the Ottoman royal family by marrying Esma Sultan, an Ottoman princess.

Esma Sultan was an Ottoman princess who lived from 17 July 1778 to 4 June 1848. She was the daughter of Sultan Abdul Hamid I and the sister of Sultan Mustafa IV and Sultan Mahmud II. She also raised Bezmiâlem Sultan and Rahime Perestu Sultan as her own children.

The Sultan Ahmed Mosque, also known as the Blue Mosque, is a historic mosque in Istanbul, Turkey. It is a popular tourist attraction and is still used as a mosque today. People come to pray on the mosque's beautiful red carpet after the call to prayer. The mosque was built between 1609 and 1616 during the reign of Ahmed I. Inside, you can see hand-painted blue tiles on the walls. At night, the mosque is lit up with blue lights, highlighting its five main domes, six minarets, and eight smaller domes. The mosque is located near the Hagia Sophia, another famous tourist spot.
Esma Sultan is the name of three daughters of three Ottoman Sultans.
Gevheri Kadın was the fifth wife of the 32nd Ottoman Sultan, Abdülaziz. She was the mother of Şehzade Mehmed Seyfeddin and Esma Sultan in the Ottoman Empire.

Esma Sultan was an Ottoman princess who was born on March 14, 1726, and passed away on August 13, 1788. She was the daughter of Sultan Ahmed III and his wife Zeynep Kadın. Esma Sultan was the half-sister of Sultan Mustafa III and Abdul Hamid I.

question: The director of the romantic comedy "Big Stone Gap" is based in what New York city?
pos: Adriana Trigiani is a popular Italian American author who has written sixteen books. She is also a television writer, film director, and entrepreneur who lives in Greenwich Village, New York City. Trigiani has been releasing a new novel every year since 2000.

Big Stone Gap is a romantic comedy movie made in 2014. It was written and directed by Adriana Trigiani and produced by Donna Gigliotti for Altar Identity Studios, which is part of Media Society. The movie is based on Trigiani's popular novel from 2000 with the same title. It takes place in the real town of Big Stone Gap in Virginia during the 1970s. The film first premiered at the Virginia Film Festival on November 6, 2014.
neg: The movie "Just Another Romantic Wrestling Comedy" came out in 2006 and features April Hunter and Joanie Laurer. It premiered in New Jersey and New York City on December 1, 2006, and was later released on DVD in the United States and the United Kingdom on April 17, 2007. Following its DVD release, the film received an Honorable Mention award at the New Jersey International Festival awards. The distribution of the movie is managed by Victory Multimedia.

Dave Eggar's fourth solo album, Kingston Morning, was recorded in Brooklyn, New York; Kingston, Jamaica; and Big Stone Gap, Virginia. It was released by Domo Records. The song "Itsbynne Reel" received a nomination for Best Instrumental Arrangement at the 53rd Grammy Awards.

Nola is a romantic comedy movie made in 2003 by Alan Hruska. The story follows a young woman in New York City as she searches for her biological father. The movie first showed in New York City on July 23, 2004.

Great Eastern Conventions, Inc. was an entertainment company that organized comic book conventions from 1987 to 1996. In New York City, their shows were popular after the Comic Art Convention and Creation Conventions ended in the mid-1980s, and before Michael Carbonaro's Big Apple Comic Con started in 1996. Great Eastern held two shows each year in New York City at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center from 1993 to 1995. They also organized conventions in various other states including New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Oregon, Minnesota, and Texas.

The New York Society of Model Engineers (NYSME) was officially established in 1926 in New York City, but there are records indicating its existence as far back as 1905. Initially, it was a club for gentlemen interested in building models, and it changed locations in Manhattan several times. In 1926, the Society was formally incorporated in New York State to obtain a permit for model motor boat races in Central Park. This was also when they started building their first model railroad, The Union Connecting. Over the next two decades, the Society moved to larger locations twice, expanding their model train layout each time. During World War II, many members were called to serve in the military, leading to the dismantling of the largest layout for the war effort. After the war, the Society found a new home in the Lackawanna Railroad's Passenger Terminal in Hoboken, NJ, where they built the largest model railroad in the world at the time. In the early 1950s, the organization relocated to its current location in Carlstadt, New Jersey.
Clinton is a town in Big Stone County, Minnesota, United States. It was named after New York Governor DeWitt Clinton. In 2010, the population was 449.

Hamish & Andy's Gap Year is a funny TV show that won a Logie Award. It follows two Australian comedians, Hamish Blake and Andy Lee, as they travel to different places around the world. In the first season, they went to America and did ten episodes from New York City. The second season in 2012 was called Hamish & Andy's Euro Gap Year and they did seven episodes from a pub in East London, England. The third season in 2013 was called Hamish and Andy's Gap Year Asia and they filmed from a bar in Bangkok, Thailand, called 'The Raintree'.

"I Love NY" is an Indian romantic comedy movie directed by Radhika Rao and Vinay Sapru. It stars Sunny Deol and Kangana Ranaut in the main roles. The film was produced by Bhushan Kumar and Krishan Kumar under Super Cassettes Industries Ltd. It was filmed in Mumbai, New York City, and Bangkok. The story is inspired by a Russian romantic comedy called "The Irony of Fate" from 1976. After facing many delays, the movie was finally released on July 10, 2015.

question: 2014 S/S is the debut album of a South Korean boy group that was formed by who?
pos: The first album by the South Korean group WINNER is called 2014 S/S. It came out on August 12, 2014, under the group's record label, YG Entertainment. The members wrote the lyrics and made most of the songs on the album.

Winner, also known as WINNER, is a South Korean boy band created by YG Entertainment in 2013 and made their debut in 2014. The group currently has four members: Jinwoo, Seunghoon, Mino, and Seungyoon. Initially, they had five members, including Taehyun, who left the group in November 2016.
neg: South Korean boy group Shinee has won many awards for their music. They were formed by S.M. Entertainment in 2008 and released their first full-length album, The Shinee World, on August 28, 2008. This album won the Newcomer Album of the Year at the 23rd Golden Disk Awards. Their first single, Sanso Gateun Neo (Love Like Oxygen), won first place on M Countdown on September 18, 2008, marking the group's first win on Korean music shows. Their second album, Lucifer (2010), had two hit singles, Lucifer and Hello. The group was nominated for the Best Dance Performance Award at the Mnet Asian Music Awards in 2010 for their impressive choreography. Lucifer also won the Disk Bonsang Award and the Popularity Award at the 25th Golden Disk Awards. In 2012, Shinee released their fourth EP, Sherlock, which won them another Disk Bonsang Award at the 27th Golden Disc Awards and the Bonsang Award at the 22nd Seoul Music Award. The lead single from Sherlock was nominated for Song of the Year at the 2012 Mnet Asian Music Awards due to its success.

Kyuhyun, born on February 3, 1988, is a popular South Korean singer and actor in musical theater. He is famous for being a member of the boy band Super Junior and its sub-groups Super Junior-K.R.Y. and Super Junior-M. He was also part of the ballad group S.M. the Ballad. Kyuhyun is recognized for being one of the first four Korean artists to be featured on Chinese postage stamps.

History was a South Korean boy band created by LOEN Entertainment in 2013. They released their debut song, Dreamer, on April 26, 2013, which included narration by IU, another artist from their label. History was the first boy band under LOEN Entertainment. Unfortunately, they disbanded on May 12, 2017.

Madtown, also known as MADTOWN, is a South Korean boy band that was formed in 2014 by J. Tune Camp. The group includes members Moos, Daewon, Lee Geon, Jota, Heo Jun, Buffy, and H.O. They released their first album, "Mad Town," on October 6, 2014. Before joining Madtown, two of the members, Moos and Buffy, were part of the hip hop duo Pro C in 2013. The group's official fan club is called Mad-people. In December 2016, MADTOWN's contract was transferred to GNI Entertainment after J. Tune Camp shut down.

Ravi is a rapper, songwriter, and producer from South Korea who is signed with Jellyfish Entertainment. He started his career as a rapper in 2012 with the South Korean boy group VIXX. In 2015, he formed VIXX's first sub-unit, VIXX LR, with his bandmate Leo. Ravi began his songwriting career by helping to write VIXX's first single, "Super Hero." By November 2016, he had contributed to writing and composing over 46 songs for VIXX. Ravi is well-known for his role in composing and writing rap parts, as well as lyrics and music, for the group.

SF9 is a South Korean boy group created by FNC Entertainment. They are the first dance boy group from the company. SF9 made their debut on October 5, 2016, with their first single album called Feeling Sensation.
Seventeen is a South Korean boy group formed by Pledis Entertainment in 2015. They have released one album and four EPs.

BTS is a popular boy group from South Korea. They started in June 2013 with their first single album, "2 Cool 4 Skool," which reached number 5 on the South Korean Week 31 Gaon Weekly Chart. In September 2013, they came back with an extended play called "O!RUL8,2?" that reached number 4 on the Week 38 Gaon Weekly Chart. Their second extended play, "Skool Luv Affair," was released in February 2014 and hit number 1 on the Week 18 Gaon Weekly Chart. This was the first time their album made it to international charts like Billboard World Albums and Japan's Oricon Chart. They also released a repackaged version of the album, "Skool Luv Affair Special Addition," in May 2014, which also reached number 1 on the Week 21 Gaon Weekly Chart.

question: Who was known by his stage name Aladin and helped organizations improve their performance as a consultant?
pos: Eenasul Fateh, also known as Aladin, was born on April 3, 1959. He is a cultural practitioner, magician, live artist, and used to work as an international management consultant. He is of Bangladeshi and British descent.

Management consulting is a service that helps organizations perform better by analyzing their problems and creating plans for improvement. Organizations hire management consultants for various reasons, such as getting unbiased advice and tapping into the consultants' specialized knowledge.
neg: James P. Comer, a renowned child psychiatrist, is currently a professor at the Yale Child Study Center and an associate dean at the Yale School of Medicine. He is well-known for his work in improving the academic performance of children from lower-income and minority backgrounds. In 1968, he founded the Comer School Development Program, which has been implemented in over 600 schools across eighty-two school districts. Comer has authored ten books and numerous articles on children's health, development, and race relations. He has also been involved in various organizations and has received 47 honorary degrees for his contributions to the field.

Clifford Smith, who was born on April 1, 1971, is an American rapper, record producer, and actor known by his stage name Method Man. He is part of the Wu-Tang Clan, a famous hip hop group from the East Coast. Method Man is also one half of the hip hop duo Method Man & Redman. He got his stage name from a movie called "Method Man" released in 1979. In 1996, he won a Grammy Award for Best Rap Performance by a Duo or Group for his song "I'll Be There for You/You're All I Need to Get By" with Mary J. Blige, an American R&B singer-songwriter.

Indriati Gerald Bernardina, also known as Indriati Iskak and later as Indri Makki after getting married, was born on June 9, 1942, in Surabaya, Indonesia. She started her career as an actress in Indonesian films and gained fame for her role in the successful movie "Tiga Dara" in 1957. After appearing in several more films and forming her own girl group, she retired from acting in 1963. In 1968, she graduated with a psychology degree from the University of Indonesia and has since taught the subject. She worked at Unilever for twenty-six years and has been a marketing consultant at Makki Makki since 1994.

Mick Batyske, also known as Mick or MICK, is an American DJ and entrepreneur. He is a popular DJ who has played at exclusive parties for famous people like Kanye West, LeBron James, Jay-Z, and Will Smith. Mick has performed at venues all over the world, from New York City to Dubai, Tokyo, Las Vegas, and Los Angeles. As an entrepreneur, he has invested in several start-up companies, including Localeur, where he also serves as an advisor and consultant.

Christopher Nicholas Sarantakos, also known as Criss Angel, is an American magician, illusionist, and musician. He started his career in New York City and later moved to Las Vegas. Angel is famous for his TV show and live performances, such as Criss Angel Mindfreak and Criss Angel Believe. The latter show, in collaboration with Cirque du Soleil at the Luxor casino in Las Vegas, brought in $150 million in tourist revenue in 2010. It was replaced by Mindfreak LIVE in 2016. Angel has also appeared in other TV shows like Criss Angel BeLIEve and Phenomenon, as well as the stage show Criss Angel Magicjam in 2014.

Lanre Dabiri, also known as Eldee, is a Nigerian-American who used to be a rapper, singer, and record producer. He now works as an IT Consultant in the United States. Lanre's full name is Olanrewaju, which means "Wealth is moving forward" in Yoruba. He earned a master's degree in Architecture from the University of Lagos in Nigeria. Lanre was part of the original lineup of the band Trybesmen, which he co-founded in 1998 with rappers KB and Freestyle. He is originally from Lagos Island in Nigeria.

Sylvester Samuels, also known as Lil Ru, is an American rapper from Ridgeway, South Carolina. He is currently signed to Def Jam Recordings. Lil Ru released his first album, "21 & Up," on August 25, 2009. He started his music career at 16, inspired by the Cash Money Crew from New Orleans. Lil Ru began performing at local shows and making his own CDs. His talent and business mindset caught the attention of Angie Stone, a fellow South Carolinian. With her help, he signed a deal with Elektra Records. However, after Elektra Records merged with Atlantic Records, Lil Ru found himself without a label. His debut single, "Will Destroy," was released in 2001, followed by "Shawty What You Doin'" in 2002. Both songs made it to the Billboard R&B/Hip-Hop charts and led him to sign with Capitol Records.

Amaruk Kayshapanta, also known as Amaruk Caizapanta Anchapacxi, is an Ecuadorian artist recognized in Spain and Ecuador for his work supporting immigrant rights. He has received several awards for his cultural contributions, including the Chasqui de Oro and Cultural Ambassador of the Andes-Mushuk Nina. Additionally, he was honored with the 100 Latinos Madrid award for his charitable work benefiting foreign immigrants in Spain. Amaruk is also known for his role as Edgar in the TV series Hospital Central. His philosophy, Amawtica Amarukiana Desestructuration, focuses on bringing the spiritual teachings of the Andean worldview to the modern world to promote collective consciousness.

question: The arena where the Lewiston Maineiacs played their home games can seat how many people?
pos: The Androscoggin Bank Colisée, previously known as the Central Maine Civic Center and Lewiston Colisee, is a multi-purpose arena in Lewiston, Maine. It can hold up to 4,000 people, with 3,677 seats. The arena opened in 1958. In 1965, it hosted the World Heavyweight Title fight, where a famous photo of Muhammed Ali standing over Sonny Liston was taken.

The Lewiston Maineiacs were a junior ice hockey team from Lewiston, Maine, that played in the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League. They played their games at the Androscoggin Bank Colisée. They were the second QMJHL team in the United States and the only one to complete a full season. In 2007, they won the President's Cup.
neg: The Billings Bulls were a junior ice hockey team from Billings, Montana. They played their games at the Centennial Ice Arena, which only had 550 seats. Because the arena was small, the Bulls often had sold-out games. Before that, they played at the Metrapark, which could hold up to 9,000 fans for hockey games. However, a disagreement with arena officials and county commissioners led to the Bulls losing their lease.

The Robins Center is a sports arena in Richmond, Virginia with a seating capacity of 7,201. It opened in 1972 and is where the University of Richmond Spiders basketball team plays their home games. The arena was named after E. Claiborne Robins Sr, a generous supporter of the university. Before the Robins Center was built, the Spider basketball team played in various locations around Richmond. The arena has also hosted events like the ECAC South men's basketball tournament in 1983 and a 1992 Presidential debate.

The 2011-12 QMJHL season was the 43rd season of the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League (QMJHL). It ran from September 2011 to March 2012, with seventeen teams playing 68 games each. This season marked the Blainville-Boisbriand Armada's debut in the league after moving from Verdun, where they were known as the Montreal Junior Hockey Club from 2008 to 2011. The Lewiston Maineiacs, one of the original teams, folded before this season, but the league announced a new team in Sherbrooke for the following season. In the playoffs, the Saint John Sea Dogs made history by winning back-to-back President's Cup championships, becoming the seventh team to do so in the league's history.

Loan modification is when changes are made to a mortgage agreement to help borrowers who are struggling to make payments. These changes can include reducing interest rates, monthly payments, or the amount owed on the loan. Lenders may make these changes to prevent borrowers from facing foreclosure. Loan modifications have been used in the United States since the 2008 housing market crash. They were introduced to assist homeowners who were victims of predatory lending practices and unethical behavior by real estate and mortgage staff. The modifications were created to provide relief to borrowers and prevent further economic destabilization. The modifications aimed to address issues such as inflated fees, fraudulent deeds, and illegal transactions that were harming borrowers. The introduction of loan modifications in 2008, including programs like HAMP and HARP, was a response to the unethical practices in the real estate market. These modifications were designed to protect borrowers and ensure fair treatment in the lending process. The modifications were part of a larger effort to bring justice to consumers and hold institutions accountable for their actions.

Case Gym is a sports arena with 1,800 seats located at Boston University in Boston, Massachusetts. It was built in 1972 as part of the Harold Case Physical Education Center, named after the university's fifth president, Harold C. Case. The gym is known as The Roof because it is situated on the top floor of the building, above Walter Brown Arena. It serves as the home venue for the Boston University Terriers men's and women's basketball teams, as well as the men's wrestling team. While basketball games are sometimes held at Agganis Arena and Walter Brown Arena, the university decided in July 2013 to play all home men's basketball conference games at Agganis Arena and non-conference games at Case Gym after switching from the America East Conference to the Patriot League.

The 2007 MasterCard Memorial Cup took place in May 2007 in Vancouver, British Columbia, at the Pacific Coliseum. This event was the 89th annual Memorial Cup competition, which determines the champion of major junior ice hockey in the Canadian Hockey League (CHL). The tournament featured the WHL champion Medicine Hat Tigers, the OHL champion Plymouth Whalers, the QMJHL champion Lewiston Maineiacs, and the host team Vancouver Giants, who were also the tournament champions. The format was a round-robin with four teams. The Vancouver Giants won their first Memorial Cup by defeating Medicine Hat 3-1 in the final. The tournament set a new attendance record with 121,561 fans, surpassing the previous record of 84,686 set in 2003.

The Robert and Concetta Dwyer Arena at Niagara University in Lewiston, New York, has two ice rinks, each measuring 200 x 85 feet, and a pro shop. The main rink can accommodate up to 1,400 spectators and is where the Niagara Purple Eagles men's ice hockey team plays in the Atlantic Hockey league. The arena used to be the home of the women's ice hockey team, which competed in the College Hockey America league.

In the 2006-07 season, the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League had its 38th season. The regular season lasted from September 14, 2006, to March 18, 2007, with 18 teams playing 70 games each. The Lewiston Maineiacs finished at the top of the regular season standings, winning their first Jean Rougeau Trophy. They also performed well in the playoffs, winning 16 games and losing only one on their way to winning their first President's Cup by defeating the Val-d'Or Foreurs in the finals.

question: Who is older, Annie Morton or Terry Richardson?
pos: Annie Morton, an American model from Pennsylvania, was born on October 8, 1970. She has been featured on the covers of various magazines like British Vogue, ID, and Marie Claire. Renowned photographers such as Helmut Newton, Peter Lindbergh, and Annie Leibovitz have captured her image. Annie has also worked with top fashion brands like Donna Karan, Givenchy, and Chanel, and has appeared in publications like Harper's Bazaar and Sports Illustrated. In addition to her modeling career, Annie is known for her vegetarian lifestyle and support for organic products and natural healthcare. She is a co-founder of Tsi-La Organics, a company that specializes in vegan and organic perfumes and skincare products.

Terrence Uncle Terry Richardson, born on August 14, 1965, is an American photographer known for his work in fashion and portrait photography. He has taken photos for brands like Marc Jacobs, Aldo, Supreme, Sisley, Tom Ford, and Yves Saint Laurent. Additionally, he has contributed to magazines like Rolling Stone, GQ, Vogue, Vanity Fair, Harper's Bazaar, i-D, and Vice.
neg: Madonna is a biography written by English author Andrew Morton that tells the story of American singer Madonna. The book was first published in November 2001 in the United States by St. Martin's Press and in April 2002 in the United Kingdom by Michael O'Mara Books. Morton chose to write about Madonna in 2000 and the book's release was announced in April 2001 by St. Martin's Press. The biography, as described by President and publisher Sally Richardson, delves into Madonna's dreams, her personal relationships, and her way of life.

Lady Gaga and Terry Richardson teamed up to create a photo-book that was released on November 22, 2011. The book contains over 350 photos of Lady Gaga, captured by Richardson over a ten-month period from her performances at The Monster Ball Tour to the 2011 Grammy Awards. It also includes a message from Lady Gaga about her friendship with Richardson. The two artists had worked together on previous projects before working on this book.

PJ Morton, an American singer-songwriter, released his fourth studio album, Gumbo, on April 14, 2017. This album was self-released on Morton Records and followed his previous album, New Orleans, from 2013. Gumbo combines R&B and soul music, with lyrics touching on topics like love, politics, and personal experiences. PJ Morton produced the entire album himself and collaborated with artists like Pell, BJ the Chicago Kid, and The HamilTones, Anthony Hamilton's backing group. The album also includes a cover of the Bee Gees' song "How Deep Is Your Love."

Amanda Lepore is an American transgender model, singer, and performance artist. She has been featured in advertisements for various companies and is a frequent subject in the work of photographers like David LaChapelle, Terry Richardson, and others. Lepore was part of LaChapelle's exhibit in New York City in 2005, where she lived in a life-sized set. She has released several singles, some in collaboration with Cazwell, and in 2011, she released her first studio album, "I... Amanda Lepore," on Peace Bisquit.

"Piano Girl" (Turkish: Deli Deli Olma) is a Turkish comedy-drama film from 2009 directed by Murat Saraçoğlu. It stars Tarık Akan and Şerif Sezer as two elderly characters who are forced to confront their pasts and share their biggest secrets. The film was released nationwide in Turkey on 17, 2009, and premiered at the Sinema Burada Film Festival in İzmir. It has also been shown at various other film festivals, including the 46th Antalya Golden Orange Film Festival, where it received a standing ovation from the audience.

Index Magazine was a well-known publication based in New York City that featured in-depth interviews with important figures in art and culture. It was founded by Peter Halley and Bob Nickas in 1996 and continued until late 2005. The magazine focused on the emerging Indie culture of the 1990s and often collaborated with up-and-coming photographers like Juergen Teller, Terry Richardson, Wolfgang Tillmans, and Ryan McGinley. It also included interviews with well-known personalities such as Björk, Brian Eno, Marc Jacobs, and Scarlett Johansson, covering a wide range of fields like music, film, architecture, fashion, art, and politics. Additionally, the magazine showcased interviews with lesser-known New York personalities like Queen Itchie and Ducky Doolittle.

Snoecks is a large magazine from Belgium that comes out once a year in October. It covers new and exciting international happenings in art, photography, and literature. Recent issues have highlighted artists like Anton Corbijn, Larry Sultan, Matthew Barney, and others.
Kenton Terry Richardson, born on July 26, 1999, is a professional soccer player from England. He plays as a defender for the team Hartlepool United in League Two.

question: Are Local H and For Against both from the United States?
pos: Local H is a rock band from the United States that was started in Zion, Illinois in 1987. The band was formed by Scott Lucas, who sings and plays guitar, along with bassist Matt Garcia, drummer Joe Daniels, and lead guitarist John Sparkman. They all met in high school in 1987 and officially started the band three years later.

For Against is a band from Lincoln, Nebraska that plays post-punk and dream pop music. Since starting in 1984, the band has had different members and taken breaks at times, but they have consistently released music over the years.
neg: Mendocino County, California, was the first place in the United States to say no to genetically modified organisms (GMOs). They made a rule called Measure H in 2004 that banned GMOs from being grown, made, or sold there. The rule was made by a group called GMO Free Mendocino, who were worried about the unknown risks GMOs might have on people and the environment. Some big companies that make GMOs didn't like this rule and tried to stop it. But since then, Mendocino County has become known internationally as a place that doesn't allow GMOs. Other places in the U.S. have also started making rules to stop GMOs from being used.

In 1978, there was a Senate election in Illinois on November 7. The current Republican Senator, Charles H. Percy, was running for a third term. He was up against a Democrat named Alex Seith, who was a lawyer and had held some local government roles. Percy was expected to easily win, but Seith put up a good fight. In a surprising move near the end of the campaign, Percy aired a TV ad where he admitted his mistakes and said he understood the voters' concerns. This helped him win a close race against Seith, securing Percy's third and final term in the Senate.

The William H. Cook Water Tank House is a historic building in Jerome, Idaho, USA, built around 1915 to store water for William H. Cook's farm. Made of lava rock, it has a metal tank inside. The stonework resembles that of local stonemason H. T. Pugh, but the actual builder is unknown.

Amherst is a town in Hampshire County, Massachusetts, United States, located in the Connecticut River valley. It has a population of 37,819 as of the 2010 census, making it the largest town in Hampshire County (even though the county seat is Northampton). Amherst is known for being home to Amherst College, Hampshire College, and the University of Massachusetts Amherst, which are three of the Five Colleges in the area. The town's name is pronounced as "AM-erst," without the "h." This pronunciation has led to a local saying that goes, "only the 'h' is silent," which refers to both how the town's name is said and to the politically active residents of Amherst.

The Wilford H. Fawcett House is a historic house in Breezy Point, Minnesota, USA. It was built by Wilford H. Fawcett, also known as Captain Billy, who created a popular joke book called Captain Billy's Whiz Bang for soldiers during World War I. He started Fawcett Publications in 1919 and later bought land in Breezy Point to build a resort with cottages and a large lodge. Although the lodge has burned down, the Fawcett House still stands on the resort property. Fawcett hired architects to design the house in a Swiss Chateau style, which was a nod to the local logging industry that had declined before the resort was built.

Ophur was a rock band from the Chicago suburbs in DuPage County that performed in the Midwest for seven years. They played alongside well-known bands like The Plain White T's, Sum 41, and Violent Femmes. Their music was a mix of U2, Red Hot Chili Peppers, and Pink Floyd.

Suffrajett is a rock band originally from New York City but now based in Chicago, Illinois. The band consists of singer and violinist Simi Sernaker, guitarist Jason Chasko, bassist Kevin Roberts, and drummer Danny Severson. Suffrajett has toured with bands like Local H, The Last Vegas, and Bob Schneider, and has also opened for the reunited MC5. They released their first album, "Suffrajett," on February 2, 2003, and their most recent album, "Black Glitter," on January 1, 2007. Recently, they went on tour with Juliette and the Licks and Scissors for Lefty.

Local H's seventh studio album, "Hallelujah! I'm A Bum," is a concept album about politics in the United States. The band finished recording the album in spring 2012 but decided to release it in September to coincide with the 2012 presidential election. The album features the sounds of the El Train in Chicago to connect the songs together.

question: What is the name of the fight song of the university whose main campus is in Lawrence, Kansas and whose branch campuses are in the Kansas City metropolitan area?
pos: Kansas Song (We’re From Kansas) is a spirited anthem for the University of Kansas.

The University of Kansas, also known as KU or Kansas, is a public research university located in the state of Kansas in the United States. The main campus is in Lawrence, which is one of the biggest college towns in Kansas and sits on Mount Oread, the highest point in Lawrence. The university also has two branch campuses in the Kansas City area: the Edwards Campus in Overland Park and the medical school and hospital in Kansas City. Additionally, there are educational and research sites in Parsons, Topeka, Garden City, Hays, and Leavenworth, as well as medical school branches in Wichita and Salina. The university is a member of the Association of American Universities, which consists of 62 institutions.
neg: North Kansas City is a separate city in Missouri, near Kansas City. It is part of the Kansas City metropolitan area. In 2010, it had a population of 4,208. Originally, it was a suburb north of Kansas City, Missouri, but now it is mostly surrounded by Kansas City. North Kansas City is also next to the town of Avondale.

The University of Missouri–Kansas City (UMKC) is a public research university in Kansas City, Missouri. It is one of four campuses that make up the University of Missouri. UMKC has multiple locations, with its main campus in the Rockhill neighborhood of Kansas City, near the Country Club Plaza, the Stowers Institute for Medical Research, and the Linda Hall Library. In 2017, UMKC partnered with local healthcare facilities to create the UMKC Health Sciences District on Hospital Hill, aiming to improve health and wellness in the Kansas City area through research, education, and community outreach. The university also announced plans to build a Campus for the Arts downtown near the Kauffman Center for the Performing Arts. UMKC had over 16,600 students enrolled as of 2015.

Kansas City jazz is a style of jazz that developed in Kansas City, Kansas, and Kansas City, Missouri, during the 1930s. It marked a shift from the structured big band style to a more improvisational style known as Bebop. Key figures in this transition were Count Basie and Charlie Parker. Kansas City is recognized as a significant hub for jazz, alongside cities like New Orleans, Chicago, St. Louis, Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, and New York City.

Kansas City Scout is a large electronic traffic management system in the United States. It was started in 2000 through a partnership between the Missouri Department of Transportation and the Kansas Department of Transportation to help manage traffic in the Kansas City Metropolitan Area, which spans both Missouri and Kansas. The project cost $43 million, with most of the funding coming from the Federal Highway Administration. The system uses electronic boards and cameras on highways to provide real-time traffic information and detect issues like accidents or lane closures. While the system covers many highways in the area, there are still more to include. Studies were done to prioritize highways based on accident rates, as it would be too costly to cover all highways in the metro area. The project has grown over time and plans to expand further, including adding coverage to I-635 and enhancing coverage on I-435 and other major city highways. The system is named after the Kansas City Scout Statue in Penn Valley Park.

Downtown Kansas City is the main business area of Kansas City, Missouri and the surrounding metropolitan region. It is located between the Missouri River in the north and 31st Street in the south, and extends from the Kansas-Missouri state line to Bruce R. Watkins Drive. The Downtown Council of Kansas City defines this area, while the 2010 Greater Downtown Area Plan by the City of Kansas City includes North Kansas City and parts of Missouri to the north, the state line to the west, 31st Street to the south, and Woodland Avenue to the east. However, the definition provided by the Downtown Council is the most widely accepted.

The Kansas City metropolitan area is a region that includes 15 counties and is centered around Kansas City, Missouri. It spans across the border of Missouri and Kansas. The area has a population of approximately 2,340,000 people, making it the second largest metropolitan area in Missouri after Greater St. Louis. In addition to Kansas City, the region includes several other cities and suburbs, such as Overland Park, Kansas City, Olathe, and Independence, each with a population of over 100,000. The Mid-America Regional Council (MARC) serves as the governing body and planning organization for the area.

The University of the Incarnate Word (UIW) is a private Catholic university in San Antonio and Alamo Heights, Texas. It was founded in 1881 by the Sisters of Charity of the Incarnate Word and its main campus sits on 154 acres.

The history of the Kansas City metropolitan area began in the 19th century when French settlers from St. Louis, Missouri came up the Missouri River to hunt for furs and trade with Native Americans. The area, located where the Kansas and Missouri Rivers meet and straddling the border between Missouri and Kansas, was important for trade and defense. Kansas City, Missouri was established in 1838 and emerged as the main city west of St. Louis after defeating its rival Westport. This region played a significant role in the expansion of the United States westward, with important trails like the Santa Fe and Oregon passing through it. In 1854, when Kansas was opened for settlement by European Americans, the border between Missouri and Kansas became the first battleground in the American Civil War.

question: What screenwriter with credits for "Evolution" co-wrote a film starring Nicolas Cage and Téa Leoni?
pos: David Weissman is a person who writes scripts and directs movies. Some of the movies he has worked on are The Family Man (2000), Evolution (2001), and When in Rome (2010).

The Family Man is a romantic comedy-drama movie from 2000 directed by Brett Ratner. It was written by David Diamond and David Weissman and stars Nicolas Cage and Téa Leoni. Cage's production company, Saturn Films, also helped make the movie. The story follows a man who gets a glimpse of the life he could have had if he had made a different choice 13 years earlier.
neg: Stabbing Westward released their first album, "Ungod," in 1994 on Columbia Records. The album was recorded in Chiswick, England, over six weeks in 1993 and was officially released on February 15, 1994. The band's success with this album led to a second album, "Wither Blister Burn & Peel," and they toured with Depeche Mode. The guitar riff from the song "Ungod" was later used in Filter's "Hey Man, Nice Shot," after Stuart Zechman, who played guitar for Filter, shared it with Stabbing Westward. The song "Nothing" was featured in the movie "Bad Boys" but did not make it onto the official soundtrack. It was also used in the film "Johnny Mnemonic" along with the song "Lost." Additionally, "Lost," "Lies," and "Can't Happen Here" were featured in the movie "Mortal Kombat," but Stabbing Westward declined to include them in the official soundtrack. The Thread Mix of "Violent Mood Swings" appeared on the Clerks soundtrack.

"Season of the Witch" is a 2011 American movie that mixes history with fantasy and adventure. It features actors Nicolas Cage and Ron Perlman and was directed by Dominic Sena, with some additional scenes directed by Brett Ratner. Cage and Perlman play Teutonic Knights who come back from the Crusades to find their homeland destroyed by the Black Death. They are asked by church leaders to take a girl accused of being a witch to a monastery to remove her curse. The movie takes some inspiration from the 1957 film "The Seventh Seal" and marks a reunion for Sena and Cage, who had previously worked together on "Gone in 60 Seconds."

The movie "Time to Kill" is an Italian drama film from 1989 that stars Nicolas Cage along with Italian actors Ricky Tognazzi and Giancarlo Giannini. Directed by Giuliano Montaldo, the film is set in 1936 during Italy's colonization of Ethiopia and was filmed in Zimbabwe. It is based on a novel of the same name by Ennio Flaiano.

In 1993, Christopher Coppola directed the crime drama film Deadfall. He co-wrote the script with Nick Vallelonga. The movie features actors Michael Biehn, Nicolas Cage, Charlie Sheen, James Coburn, and Peter Fonda. The film inspired the song 'Deadfall' by the American hardcore punk band Snot. A follow-up movie called Arsenal was released in 2017, with Nicolas Cage reprising his role as Eddie King.

Gone in 60 Seconds is a 2000 American action movie about stealing cars. It stars Nicolas Cage, Angelina Jolie, and other actors. The movie was directed by Dominic Sena and written by Scott Rosenberg. It was produced by Jerry Bruckheimer, who also produced other action movies with Nicolas Cage. This movie is a new version of a film from 1974 with the same title.

Drive Angry is a fantasy action film from 2011 that features Nicolas Cage and Amber Heard. It was directed by Patrick Lussier and came out on February 25, 2011. The movie was shot in 3-D and made nearly $29 million at the box office, receiving mixed reviews.

"It Could Happen to You" is a movie from 1994 that features Nicolas Cage and Bridget Fonda. The film tells the story of a New York City police officer (Cage) who wins the lottery and decides to share his winnings with a waitress (Fonda). The idea for the movie was inspired by a true story.

The movie "City of Angels" is a romantic fantasy film from 1998 directed by Brad Silberling. It stars Nicolas Cage and Meg Ryan and is set in Los Angeles, California. The film is a loose remake of a 1987 film called "Wings of Desire" by Wim Wenders, which was set in Berlin. In "City of Angels," the story follows an angel played by Cage who falls in love with a mortal woman played by Ryan. He wants to become human so he can be with her. With the help of a man who has already made the transition from being immortal, the angel learns about human life and experiences.

question: What year did Guns N Roses perform a promo for a movie starring Arnold Schwarzenegger as a former New York Police detective?
pos: Summary: End of Days is a 1999 movie directed by Peter Hyams and featuring Arnold Schwarzenegger, Gabriel Byrne, Robin Tunney, and others. The story revolves around a former detective who saves a banker from an assassin and gets involved in a religious battle to protect a young woman chosen to conceive the Antichrist with Satan.

"Oh My God" is a song by Guns N' Roses that came out in 1999 on the soundtrack for the movie End of Days. The song was sent to radio stations in November 1999 to promote both the soundtrack and the band. Even though it was the band's first new song in almost five years, it was never officially released as a single for purchase by the public.
neg: Arnold Schwarzenegger is an actor who has been in more than 30 movies. He has also tried directing and producing. He started with small parts in movies and TV shows. At first, he used the name Arnold Strong for his acting, but later on, he used his real name. He is known for being in action and comedy movies. Besides acting, he has also been in music videos for AC/DC, Bon Jovi, and Guns N' Roses.

Guns N' Roses is a popular American hard rock band that started in Los Angeles, California in 1985. The band was formed by members of Hollywood Rose and L.A. Guns. They have released a total of six studio albums, two live albums, two compilation albums, two extended plays, seven video albums, eighteen singles, twenty-four music videos, and one video single. Guns N' Roses signed with Geffen Records in 1986, following the release of their EP Live ?! *@ Like a Suicide independently the year before. Their first studio album, Appetite for Destruction, came out in 1987 and topped the Billboard 200 chart. It sold 18 million copies in the United States and around 33 million copies worldwide.

Hammerjacks Concert Hall and Nightclub was a popular music venue in downtown Baltimore during the 1980s and 1990s. It was owned by Louis J. Principio III and hosted a variety of musical acts, from well-known national performers to up-and-coming artists. The club featured a range of music genres, including punk, glam, heavy metal, pop, and alternative rock. The club's unique style attracted a diverse crowd, from hardcore music fans to people with different fashion tastes. Unfortunately, Hammerjacks was demolished in 1997 to make space for a parking lot for M&T Bank Stadium. It was known as the largest nightclub on the east coast.

Steven Adler, an American musician born as Michael Coletti on January 22, 1965, is famous for being the former drummer and co-songwriter of the popular hard rock band Guns N' Roses. He gained worldwide fame with the band in the late 1980s but was later fired in 1990 due to his heroin addiction. After leaving Guns N' Roses, Adler tried to revive his old band Road Crew and briefly joined BulletBoys, but both attempts were unsuccessful. In the 2000s, he formed the band Adler's Appetite and later joined the band Adler in 2012. However, in early 2017, Adler announced that he was leaving the band due to his lack of interest in performing at poorly attended concerts. He also appeared on reality TV shows like Celebrity Rehab with Dr. Drew and its spin-off Sober House. Adler was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2012 as a member of Guns N' Roses.

Faction With Jason Ellis is a radio channel on Sirius XM Satellite Radio that plays uncensored hard rock, punk, hip hop, and heavy metal music. It used to be on channel 41 until mid-July 2017 when it was temporarily replaced by Guns N Roses radio. After August 16, 2017, channel 41 became Turbo, a channel for hard rock from the 1990s and 2000s. Faction then moved to channel 314, which was Turbo's previous channel. You can now listen to Faction on certain Sirius XM radios, Sirius XM streaming, and the Sirius XM smartphone app.

In 1994, a movie called True Lies was released in America. It was written, co-produced, and directed by James Cameron and starred actors like Arnold Schwarzenegger, Jamie Lee Curtis, and Tom Arnold. The story is about a government agent named Harry Tasker who has to juggle his job as a spy with his responsibilities to his family. The movie is a modern version of a French comedy film called La Totale! from 1991.

Summary: Last Action Hero is a 1993 American movie directed by John McTiernan. It pokes fun at action movies and their clichés by including parodies of them within the film. The movie stars Arnold Schwarzenegger as Jack Slater, a detective in a popular action movie series. Another character, played by Austin O'Brien, gets magically transported into Slater's world. Schwarzenegger is also the executive producer and plays himself as the actor portraying Slater, while Charles Dance plays an assassin who crosses over from the movie world into reality.

"Get Christie Love!" is a TV movie and series from 1974 about a female undercover detective named Christie Love, played by Teresa Graves. She is on a mission to take down a drug ring. The story is inspired by Dorothy Uhnak's novel "The Ledger." Originally, the main character was supposed to be a white detective named Christie Opara, but the character was changed to Christie Love for the final production.

question: Are Random House Tower and 888 7th Avenue both used for real estate?
pos: 888 7th Avenue is a tall office skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan that stands at 628 feet (191 meters) with 46 floors. It was built in 1969 by Emery Roth & Sons and is one of the 65th tallest buildings in New York City, sharing this spot with Central Park Place. The building is currently home to the corporate headquarters of Vornado Realty Trust. Originally called the Arlen Building, it was named after the company that built it, Arlen Realty & Development Corporation. The Red Eye Grill, a restaurant, is situated on the street level of the building.

The Random House Tower, also called the Park Imperial Apartments, is a 52-story building in New York City. It serves as the main office for Random House, a book publisher, and also houses luxury apartments. The entrance for the book publisher is on Broadway and goes up to the 27th floor, while the entrance for the apartments is on West 56th Street.
neg: Real estate benchmarking is the way we measure and compare the financial aspects of a real estate investment property. It involves looking at different properties and comparing them based on certain criteria. This helps us understand how well a property is performing financially compared to others.

Hounsfield Heights/Briar Hill is a neighborhood in northwest Calgary, Alberta, Canada. It is situated next to the Hillhurst and West Hillhurst neighborhoods. The boundaries of the area are 16th Avenue N to the north, 14th Street W to the east, a lane north of 7th Avenue N to 19th Street W and 8th Avenue N to the south, and Crowchild Trail, 12th Avenue N, Juniper Road, and 22nd Street W to the west. The community includes the Lions Park C-Train station and is known for its scenic views of downtown and the Rocky Mountains.

Villard, also known as Villard Books, is a publishing brand under Random House, one of the world's biggest publishing companies. It was established in 1983 as an independent brand under Random House and is now a sub-brand of Ballantine Books, which is also under Random House. The name Villard comes from a brownstone mansion on Madison Avenue that was the headquarters of Random House for twenty years.
Pershing Square Capital Management is a hedge fund company based in New York City, founded and led by Bill Ackman.

The Carl B. Stokes Federal Court House Building is a tall building in downtown Cleveland, Ohio. It's also called the Carl B. Stokes Federal Court House Tower, Federal Court House Tower, and the Stokes Tower. This 23-story building is 430 feet tall and sits at the corner of Huron Road and Superior Avenue. It's currently the fourth tallest courthouse in the United States.

Real Estate Technology, also known as RE Tech or Proptech, is an industry that uses technology to streamline real estate transactions. It falls under financial technology because real estate is a major investment. People invest in different types of real estate properties like residential, commercial, and industrial to generate income and capital gains over time. Real estate has been traditionally used for tactical investments or to enhance investment portfolios, but it is now seen as a long-term strategy due to market efficiency and concerns about stock and bond returns. Real estate is valued for its ability to diversify portfolios and protect against inflation.

Loan modification is when changes are made to a mortgage agreement to help borrowers who are struggling to make payments. These changes can include lowering interest rates, reducing monthly payments, or adjusting the principal balance. Lenders may make these changes to prevent borrowers from facing foreclosure. Loan modifications have been common in the United States since the 2008 housing market crash. They were introduced to assist homeowners who were victims of predatory lending practices and unethical behavior by real estate and mortgage staff. The modifications were meant to provide relief to borrowers and prevent further economic instability. Various government agencies and programs, such as HAMP and HARP, were established to address these issues and protect borrowers' rights. It is important for borrowers to be aware of their financial rights and to seek assistance if they are facing difficulties with their mortgage payments.

South Phoenix is a neighborhood in Phoenix, Arizona, bordered by the Gila River Indian Community to the south and west, 48th Street or Interstate-10 to the east, and the Salt River to the north. It includes urban villages like South Mountain Village, Laveen Village, and Ahwatukee Village. Residents often call it the Southside. The area has major streets running east-west, such as Broadway Road, Southern Avenue, and Baseline Road, connecting it to suburbs like Tempe and Chandler. Major streets running north-south include 24th Street, 16th Street, and Central Avenue, connecting South Phoenix to other parts of the city.

question: The football manager who recruited David Beckham managed Manchester United during what timeframe?
pos: In the 1995–96 season, Manchester United played their fourth season in the Premier League and their 21st consecutive season in the top division of English football. They made history by becoming the first English team to win both the league title and the FA Cup twice in the same season. This achievement was even more impressive because their manager, Alex Ferguson, had sold experienced players like Paul Ince, Mark Hughes, and Andrei Kanchelskis before the season began, without bringing in any big-name signings. question: Aside from the Apple Remote, what other device can control the program Apple Remote was originally designed to interact with?
pos: The Apple Remote is a small remote control device made by Apple Inc. It was first introduced in October 2005 and is used with various Apple products that have infrared capabilities. Front Row was a media center software for Apple computers that allowed users to watch videos, view photos, listen to music, and podcasts from their computer or the Internet. It had a user-friendly interface and could be controlled with an Apple Remote or keyboard. The software was first released in October 2005 and received two major updates. However, it was discontinued in Mac OS X 10.7.
neg: A universal remote is a remote control that can be set up to work with different brands of consumer electronics. However, more advanced universal remotes let you add new control codes to operate additional devices. Many remotes that come with electronic devices have universal remote features, allowing them to control other types of devices as well. For instance, a VCR remote can be programmed to work with different brands of TVs.

In electronics, a remote control is a device that lets you operate another electronic device without needing to be right next to it. For example, you can use a remote control to change channels on your TV, play a DVD, or control other home gadgets from a short distance away. Remote controls are designed to make it easier for you to use devices that are not within arm's reach. They are especially handy for situations where you can't physically reach the device, like opening a garage door from outside or adjusting a projector mounted on a high ceiling while standing on the floor.

The Siri Remote is a special remote control that was launched alongside the 4th Generation Apple TV at an Apple event on October 26, 2015. It was introduced by Apple Inc. CEO Tim Cook. NetSupport Manager is a remote control software that works on Windows and other platforms. It allows you to control and manage systems from a Windows or Windows Mobile device. You can transfer files, chat, and keep track of hardware and software on the systems, including updates. The software has more features for Windows compared to Linux and Mac. In 2012, NetSupport added support for remote control from iOS and Android devices, as well as Mac OS. Version 12, released in October 2013, added support for ChromeOS. To use NetSupport Manager, you need to install the software on both the local and remote devices.

The Apple Watch is a smartwatch made by Apple Inc. It can track fitness and health data and works with other Apple products. The first version came in four styles: Sport, Regular, Hermès, and Edition, each with different cases and bands. The watch needs to be connected to an iPhone to make calls and send texts. It works with iPhones from the 5 model onwards and needs iOS 8.2 or later. The first Apple Watch was announced in September 2014 and released in April 2015. It became very popular, selling 4.2 million units in the second quarter of 2015. The second generation, released in September 2016, has two versions: Series 2 and Series 1. MacScan is a tool made by SecureMac for Apple's Mac OS X that helps protect against harmful software. It can remove various types of malware, such as spyware and Trojan horses. Trainmaster Command (TMCC) is an electronic control system created by Lionel for O scale 3-rail model trains and toy trains. It was primarily used from 1994 to 2006. TMCC is similar to Digital Command Control (DCC), which is the standard for HO scale and other 2-rail DC trains. One advantage of TMCC is that trains equipped with TMCC can run alongside trains that do not have TMCC, as well as Lionel Legacy engines, LionChief, and LionChief Plus equipped trains. These other types of trains require their own specific remote controller. 

MTH Corporation's DCS controller can be set up to control TMCC trains, and all four systems (TMCC, Legacy, LionChief/LionChief+, and DCS) can operate on the same track at the same time. Each system needs a constant track voltage of 18 volts. TMCC and Legacy send signals to antennas on the trains, identifying each locomotive by number and issuing commands for speed, direction, sounds, lighting, and other features. DCS works similarly but sends a carrier signal through the rails that is picked up by the train's electrical contacts.

While TMCC/Legacy and DCS use remote controls to send commands to a device that then communicates with the train (Command Base or Track Interface Unit), LionChief and LionChief Plus trains have a different setup. Each LionChief train is paired with its own remote control, and no additional wiring is needed. The control signals are sent directly to the train, similar to how a TV remote or garage door opener works. In 2017, Lionel introduced a universal remote for LionChief+ that can learn addresses for up to three trains at a time, making it easier to operate multiple trains.

Apple Remote Desktop (ARD) is a Mac application made by Apple Inc. It was launched on March 14, 2002, to replace a previous product called Apple Network Assistant. It is designed for computer administrators managing many computers and teachers who need to help students or give group presentations. With Apple Remote Desktop, users can control or watch over other computers on a network from a distance.

question: The 2011–12 VCU Rams men's basketball team, led by third year head coach Shaka Smart, represented Virginia Commonwealth University which was founded in what year?

The 2013–14 VCU Rams men's basketball team played for Virginia Commonwealth University during the 2013–14 NCAA Division I men's basketball season. The VCU Rams finished 6th in the ESPN/USA Today Coaches Poll at the end of the season, the highest ranking in the school's history and the highest among all teams in the CAA. Their performance in the 2011 NCAA tournament is considered one of the greatest Cinderella stories in basketball history. question: Kaiser Ventures corporation was founded by an American industrialist who became known as the father of modern American shipbuilding?
pos: Kaiser Ventures, previously known as Kaiser Steel, is a company based in Ontario, California. It was established by Henry J. Kaiser to supply steel plate for shipbuilding on the Pacific Coast. The company's operations grew during World War II, declined, and then expanded again during the Korean War. One of the shipyards associated with Kaiser was the California Shipbuilding Corporation on Terminal Island, California, which constructed numerous Liberty and Victory ships during World War II. Kaiser Steel was recognized for efficiently using its steelmaking resources and, by the late 1950s, had a significant share of the Pacific Coast steel market along with the U.S. Steel plant in Utah. The company's assets included steelmaking plants in Napa, California (acquired from Basalt Rock Company in 1955), and Fontana, California (now operated by California Steel Industries), as well as an iron ore mine in Eagle Mountain, California. The steel produced by Kaiser was also used in Kaiser Motors.

Henry John Kaiser was an American industrialist known for revolutionizing shipbuilding in the United States. He founded the Kaiser Shipyards, which produced Liberty ships during World War II. Additionally, he started Kaiser Aluminum and Kaiser Steel. Kaiser also created Kaiser Permanente, a healthcare program for his employees and their families. He later ventured into automobile manufacturing with Kaiser-Frazer and Kaiser Motors, focusing on safety in their designs. Kaiser was also involved in construction projects and real estate investments. He used his wealth to establish the Kaiser Family Foundation, a charitable organization.

Kaiser, a shipbuilding tycoon. Kaiser earned degrees from Stanford University and Harvard University. He worked in the White House under Presidents Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard M. Nixon, as well as for U.S. Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel. Kaiser became a Canadian citizen in 1980 and passed away on January 11, 2012.

Neafie & Levy, also known as Neafie, Levy & Co., was a shipbuilding and engineering company in Philadelphia from the mid-1800s to the early 1900s. They were pioneers in the United States for specializing in marine engineering and were one of the first to build iron ships and create steam engines to power them. In their early years, they were the main supplier of screw propellers to other shipbuilders in North America. By the early 1870s, they were the busiest and most well-funded shipbuilder in Philadelphia.

During World War II, the Kaiser Shipyards were seven big shipbuilding yards on the west coast of the United States. They were among the top 20 U.S. companies in terms of the value of contracts for wartime production. These shipyards were owned by the Kaiser Shipbuilding Company, founded by American businessman Henry J. Kaiser in 1939. He started the company to help the United States Maritime Commission build merchant ships as needed during the war.

From 1871 to 1885, the company was the biggest shipbuilding company in the United States. They made more iron ships than their two biggest competitors put together. They also did a lot of work for the U.S. Navy during this time and were one of the biggest employers in the country, second only to the railroads.

Some of its famous ships are the destroyer , the cruiser , the aircraft carrier , the nuclear-powered cargo ship NS Savannah, and four cargo-passenger liners called the Four Aces.

Starfaring is a game set in outer space, created by Ken St. Andre and released by Flying Buffalo in August 1976.

Crank Caverns, located near Crank in St. Helens, Merseyside, is a network of underground tunnels, caverns, and woodland. The quarrying of sandstone in this area began around 1730. Instead of traditional quarrying methods, the stone was mined out following a seam until it was depleted, creating the caves and tunnels we see today. By 1854, the site was listed as a colliery under the ownership of Charles Howarth, also known as Yorkshire Charlie. After being used as a game reserve and later as an ammunition storage facility during World War II, the caverns are now closed to the public due to safety concerns. However, the site remains accessible from a nearby footpath and continues to attract curious locals interested in exploring the area and its many myths and legends.

Crusaders of Khazan is a video game version of the Tunnels and Trolls tabletop role-playing game. It was created by New World Computing in 1990 for various computer systems. You can find the game for purchase from Flying Buffalo and in Fiery Dragon's Tunnels and Trolls 30th Anniversary Edition.

question: When was Poison's album "Shut Up, Make Love" released?

Ahh!," which was certified 5x platinum in the US. Their popularity continued into the 1990s with their third multi-platinum album, "Flesh & Blood."

"Shut Up, Make Love" is a song by the American rock band Poison. It was released in 2000 as the first single from their album "Crack a Smile...and More!" The song also appears on another single called "Be the One." "Crack a Smile" is Poison's fifth studio album, which came out on March 14, 2000, and reached #131 on The Billboard 200 chart.
