"Be the One" is a powerful slow song by the American rock band Poison. It was the second single from their album "Crack a Smile...and More!" released in 2000. "Make Love" is a song by Keri Hilson, an American singer and songwriter. It was written by Jamal Polow da Don Jones, Ester Dean, and Jason Perry, and produced by Polow da Don and Perry for Hilson's first album, "In a Perfect World..." released in 2009. Reviews for the song were mixed, with some critics criticizing its length and Hilson's vocals, while others praised it as one of the standout tracks on the album.

The first album by Australian alternative rock band Cosmic Nomads, titled "Make Love Not War," was released in 2004. Dan Fogelberg's album, Greatest Hits, features a collection of his popular songs. The album also includes two new tracks, "Missing You" and "Make Love Stay," which were released as singles. Both songs performed well on the adult contemporary chart, with "Missing You" reaching #6 and "Make Love Stay" becoming Dan Fogelberg's third #1 hit on that chart.

Chuck Berry on Stage is an album released in 1963 by Chess Records. Despite being advertised as a live album, it actually consists of previously recorded studio tracks, with added audience sounds to create the illusion of a live performance. The album includes five new songs and one track, "Surfin' USA," which is a cover of Berry's own song "Sweet Little Sixteen." This cover was later re-recorded and released on a rare Chess LP in 1975.

Barry White recorded a song called "The Longer We Make Love" for his 1999 album, Staying Power. The song was written by White, Aaron Schroeder, and Marlon Saunders, and produced by White and Jack Perry. There are two versions of the song: one is a duet with Lisa Stansfield and the other is a duet with Chaka Khan. Both versions are in the key of G minor and were well-received by music critics. The CD single was released in some European countries on July 19, 1999, and the song was also promoted in the United States. However, despite positive reviews, the song did not perform well on the charts.

The album "Mind If We Make Love to You" is by the American power pop group Wondermints. It came out in 2002 on Smile Records. The album's title is a playful reference to another album called "Mind If I Make Love to You" from the 1950s, which was in Darian Sahanaja's record collection.

question: Hayden is a singer-songwriter from Canada, but where does Buck-Tick hail from?
pos: Paul Hayden Desser, known as Hayden, is a Canadian singer-songwriter from Thornhill, Ontario. He was born on February 12, 1971.

Buck-Tick is a Japanese rock band that was formed in Fujioka, Gunma in 1983. The band has had the same members - Atsushi Sakurai (lead vocals), Hisashi Imai (guitar), Hidehiko Hoshino (guitar), Yutaka Higuchi (bass), and Toll Yagami (drums) - since 1985. Over their thirty-year career, they have released 20 studio albums, with almost all of them reaching the top ten on the charts. Three of their albums from the late eighties and early nineties even reached number one. Buck-Tick is often recognized as one of the pioneers of the visual kei movement.
neg: Atsushi Sakurai is a Japanese musician and singer-songwriter born on March 7, 1966 in Fujioka, Gunma. He has been the lead singer of the rock band Buck-Tick since 1985, after previously being their drummer from 1983. In 2015, he started a solo project called The Mortal.

The Alberta Hail Project was a research project funded by the Alberta Research Council and Environment Canada. It aimed to study how hailstorms work and find ways to prevent hail damage. The project took place from 1956 to 1985 and used a special weather radar at the Red Deer Industrial Airport in central Alberta, Canada.

Mild and Hazy is a 7-inch vinyl single by Canadian singer-songwriter Hayden. It came out in 1996 on Hayden's label, Hardwood Records, and also on Lunamoth. The cover features a photo of Hayden as a young child. The song "Gouge Away" is a cover of a track by the Pixies from their album Doolittle.

Masami Tsuchiya is a Japanese singer-songwriter and musician who became well-known in the late 1970s as the main singer and guitarist in the band Ippu-Do. He has since released music on his own and worked with various artists, such as the English rock band Japan, Bill Nelson, Ryuichi Sakamoto, the side-project Arcadia of Duran Duran, and the Japanese rock band Buck-Tick.

Hailstorm Alley is a nickname for a region in southern and central Alberta, Canada where hail storms are very common and can cause damage to property. This area extends from High River in the south, through Calgary and Red Deer, up to Lacombe, and then west to Rocky Mountain House. It is known for having some of the most severe hailstorms in the world. While these boundaries are not exact, this area is notorious for hail damage, although damaging hailstorms can happen throughout central and southern Alberta every summer. Calgary is considered the hailstorm capital of Canada.

Dewey Beard, also known as Wasú Máza or Iron Hail, was a Minneconjou Lakota warrior who fought in the Battle of Little Bighorn when he was a teenager. After the defeat of George Armstrong Custer, Iron Hail followed Sitting Bull into exile in Canada and later returned to South Dakota, where he lived on the Cheyenne River Indian Reservation. Historically, Iron Hail is often confused with Chief Iron Tail, another Lakota leader with a similar name. Many biographies mistakenly attribute Chief Iron Tail as a participant in the Battle of Little Bighorn and claim that his family was killed at Wounded Knee in 1890. In reality, it was Chief Iron Hail who experienced this tragic loss.

Kyo is a Japanese musician, poet, and singer-songwriter who is famous for being the lead singer of the metal band Dir en grey. Kyo decided to pursue music after seeing a photo of Buck-Tick vocalist Atsushi Sakurai on a classmate's desk in junior high school. He is known for his wide vocal range, which includes tenor notes.

Hayden, a Canadian singer-songwriter, released his third album, Skyscraper National Park, on various record labels in different countries. The album had two special editions. The first edition, with only 100 copies, was made for Hayden's close circle. The second edition, with 1,500 copies, was sold during Hayden's tour across Canada.

question: Which  French ace pilot and adventurer fly L'Oiseau Blanc
pos: Charles Eugène Jules Marie Nungesser was a famous French pilot known for his skills in air combat during World War I. He was considered one of the top pilots in France, having achieved 43 victories. Nungesser is most remembered for being a competitor of Charles Lindbergh.

In 1927, a French plane called L'Oiseau Blanc, also known as The White Bird, disappeared during an attempt to fly non-stop from Paris to New York City. The goal was to win the Orteig Prize. The plane was piloted by Charles Nungesser and François Coli, who were famous French pilots from World War I. They took off from Paris on May 8, 1927, but were last seen over Ireland. Shortly after, Charles Lindbergh successfully completed the same journey from New York to Paris, winning the prize with his plane, the Spirit of St. Louis.
neg: François Coli, a French pilot and navigator, is most famous for being the one-eyed flying companion of Charles Nungesser during their unsuccessful flight across the Atlantic Ocean in the plane called L'Oiseau Blanc. Coli was born on June 5, 1881, and it is believed he disappeared on or after May 8, 1927.
Georges Félix Madon was a skilled French pilot during World War I, ranking fourth among aces. He had an impressive career with diverse aviation experiences.

William Earl Johns, an English pilot and writer, was born on February 5, 1893, and passed away on June 21, 1968. He wrote adventure stories under the pen name Captain W. E. Johns, with his most famous character being the ace pilot and adventurer Biggles.

Gervais Raoul Victor Lufbery was a skilled fighter pilot in World War I, known for his success in combat. He flew for both the French Air Force and the United States Army Air Service during the war, leading to some confusion about his nationality as either French or American. Despite this, most of his 17 victories in combat were achieved while flying for French units.

L'Oiseau bleu, also known as The Blue Bird, is a famous painting created by the French artist Jean Metzinger in 1912–1913. Metzinger is recognized as one of the founders of Cubism, along with Georges Braque and Pablo Picasso. The painting was first shown in Paris in 1913 and later in Berlin. It is considered one of Metzinger's most important works. The City of Paris acquired L'Oiseau bleu in 1937, and it is now displayed at the Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris.

The Levasseur PL.8 was a modified aircraft made in France in the 1920s. It was originally a carrier-based reconnaissance plane called the Levasseur PL.4. The PL.8 was designed as a long-distance biplane with one engine and two seats. It was built in 1927 for pilots Charles Nungesser and François Coli to attempt a transatlantic flight and win the Orteig Prize. Only two PL.8 planes were made, with the first one named L'Oiseau Blanc (The White Bird), which became famous as Nungesser and Coli's aircraft.

Sergent Paul Joannes Sauvage was a French pilot during World War I. He was known for shooting down eight enemy planes for sure and possibly six more. He started flying for Escadrille 65 in a Nieuport plane and got his first victory on July 16, 1916. By October 2, he became the youngest French ace. Unfortunately, he was killed by anti-aircraft fire on January 7, 1917.

Lieutenant Stanton Hall Wooster and Lieutenant Commander Noel Guy Davis were two American Navy pilots who tried to fly from New York to Paris in 1927. They were attempting to win a $25,000 prize for the first nonstop flight between the two cities. Other competitors for the prize included French pilot Rene Fonck, US Navy Commander Richard Evelyn Byrd, Clarence Chamberlain, and Charles Lindbergh. On the Paris side, their competitors were French pilot Charles Nungesser and his navigator Francois Coli.

question: Are Freakonomics and In the Realm of the Hackers both American documentaries?
pos: "In The Realm of the Hackers" is a 2003 Australian documentary directed by Kevin Anderson. It focuses on the hacker community in Melbourne, Australia during the late 1980s and early 1990s. The documentary follows two Australian teenagers known as Electron and Phoenix, who were part of a skilled hacking group called 'The Realm.' They successfully hacked into highly secure computer networks, such as those of the US Naval Research Laboratory, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, and NASA. The film is 55 minutes long and was based on the book "Underground" by Melbourne writer Suelette Dreyfus.

Freakonomics: The Movie is a documentary released in 2010, based on the book Freakonomics by economist Steven D. Levitt and writer Stephen J. Dubner. It first premiered at the Tribeca Film Festival in April 2010 and was later shown in theaters. The movie received mixed reviews, with a 65% fresh rating on Rotten Tomatoes.
neg: "Hackers" is a 1995 American movie about a group of high school students who are hackers. The film, directed by Iain Softley, stars Jonny Lee Miller, Angelina Jolie, and others. It tells the story of these hackers getting involved in a scheme to extort money from a company. The movie was made in the 1990s when the internet was still new to many people. It reflects the ideas of the Hacker Manifesto, which talks about hackers being curious and not caring about things like race or nationality. "Hackers" has become a cult classic.

Freakonomics Radio is a popular American public radio program that talks about social and economic issues in a way that's easy for everyone to understand. It started as a follow-up to the book Freakonomics in 2005. The show is hosted by journalist Stephen Dubner, and economist Steven Levitt is a frequent guest. You can listen to the show as a podcast, and it's one of the most well-liked shows on iTunes. It began in September 2010 and comes out once a week. Additionally, there are special one-hour episodes that air on public radio stations twice a year.

Heidi Ewing is a filmmaker who co-founded Loki Films with Rachel Grady in 2001. They have worked together on many documentaries. Ewing is well-known for co-directing Jesus Camp, a film that was nominated for an Academy Award in 2006. She also directed 12th & Delaware, which premiered at the 2010 Sundance Film Festival and won a Peabody Award for its exploration of the abortion debate. Detropia, a film about Ewing's hometown, won awards for editing, direction, and score. Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You premiered at the 2016 Sundance Film Festival and aired on PBS American Masters in October 2016. Ewing has also directed other films like The Boys of Baraka, Freakonomics, and The Education of Mohammed Hussein.

Shayne Workman, born on December 5, 1978, is an American author, actor, theatre director, and stage manager. His first book, "A Journey to the Spirit Realm," was published in late 2014 and later included in his collection, "The Spirit Realm: An Anthology of Fables." He also wrote "The Diary Of A Vagabond King," a true story about his challenging experiences over two years, facing tough situations and losses. The proceeds from this book will support the Blue Purity Fund, which helps organizations with programs to assist homeless individuals in reintegrating into society.

Jason Scott Jay Leiderman is an American criminal defense lawyer from Ventura, California. He is known for defending hacker-activists, particularly those associated with Anonymous, who are accused of computer crimes, also known as "Hacktivism." Leiderman is always available on an encrypted chat app to give free legal advice to Anonymous members. He has been referred to as "The Maserati-Driving Deadhead Lawyer Who Stands Between Hackers And Prison" by Buzzfeed, highlighting his reputation as a top defender of hackers in the country.

Peter W. Smith was an American investment banker who worked in Chicago for 40 years managing corporate acquisitions and venture investments. He was also involved in Republican politics. In 1998, he was revealed as a major financial supporter of the Troopergate story, where Arkansas state troopers accused President Bill Clinton of inappropriate behavior. In 2017, Smith admitted to trying to contact computer hackers, including Russians, to get damaging information on Hillary Clinton during the 2016 election. Shortly after speaking to the Wall Street Journal about this, he took his own life in a hotel room, citing poor health.

The Psycho Realm is an American hip hop group that was formed in 1989 by brothers Sick Jacken (Joaquin Gonzalez) and Big Duke (Gustavo Gonzalez) in the Downtown, Pico-Union area of Los Angeles. Their first recorded song, "Scandalous," was featured on the soundtrack of the film Mi Vida Loca in 1994. That same year, B-Real from Cypress Hill saw Psycho Realm performing at Olvera Street during an End Barrio Warfare concert. B-Real was so impressed by their performance that he wanted to join the group. At that time, Cypress Hill was very popular, so anything related to them would receive a lot of publicity.

Robin Goldstein is an American author who writes about food, wine, and economics. He is known for questioning traditional beliefs and prices in the food and wine industries. Goldstein gained attention for exposing issues with Wine Spectator magazine and for his contributions to the Freakonomics blog. He has written popular books like The Wine Trials, which is a bestseller about affordable wines, as well as The Beer Trials. Goldstein is currently working on a new book called A Defense of Fast Food. He was also featured in the book Think Like a Freak by Steven Levitt and Stephen Dubner in 2014. Goldstein resides in Oakland, California.

question: Which band, Letters to Cleo or Screaming Trees, had more members?
pos: Letters to Cleo is a rock band from Boston, Massachusetts. They are famous for their 1994 single "Here & Now" from their first album, "Aurora Gory Alice." The band consists of Kay Hanley, Greg McKenna, Michael Eisenstein, Stacy Jones, Scott Riebling, and later, Tom Polce.

Screaming Trees was a rock band from Ellensburg, Washington that started in 1985. The band members were Mark Lanegan, Gary Lee Conner, Van Conner, and Mark Pickerel. Pickerel was later replaced by Barrett Martin. Even though they were known for grunge music, their style also included elements of hard rock and psychedelia. Throughout their time together, Screaming Trees released seven albums, five EPs, and three compilations.
neg: Truly is an American rock band that was formed after the grunge era. The band included singer-guitarist Robert Roth, bassist Hiro Yamamoto, and drummer Mark Pickerel. Yamamoto and Pickerel were original members of Soundgarden and Screaming Trees. Although not as popular as other bands from Seattle at the time, Truly stayed together for ten years and released two studio albums.

The Screaming Trees released their only album with Sub Pop called "Change Has Come" in 1990. After that, they signed with a major label, Epic Records, and released their next three albums - "Uncle Anesthesia," "Sweet Oblivion," and "Dust," along with the "Something About Today" EP.

Beat Happening's second album, Jamboree, was released in 1988 by K Records/Rough Trade Records. The album features songs produced by Steve Fisk, with some help from Mark Lanegan and Gary Lee Conner of Screaming Trees. One track, Cat Walk, was produced by Patrick Maley, and The This Many Boyfriends Club was recorded live by Rich Jensen. Jamboree showcases a darker side of the band's usual Twee pop sound, with a thicker production and more songs written by Calvin Johnson. Heather Lewis only sings on two tracks, In Between and Ask Me. Calvin Johnson described the album's sound as dark and sexy. Despite this, the band maintained their focus on energy rather than technical skill. In an interview, Bret Lunsford shared a story about recording the opening track, Bewitched, where his guitar string got stuck on a screw, but he kept playing through the song until it became unstuck.

Gary Lee Conner, born on August 22, 1962, in Fort Irwin, California, USA, was the lead guitarist for the rock band Screaming Trees. He played alongside his brother, Van Conner, who was the bassist. Conner joined Screaming Trees in 1985 and stayed with the band until they broke up in 2000. Apart from his work with Screaming Trees, he also released two albums: "The Purple Outside-Mystery Lane" in 1990 and the single "Grasshopper's Daydream/Behind The Smile" in 1999. He collaborated with artists like Josh Homme from Queens of the Stone Age and appeared on tracks by Beat Happening, Mike Watt, and others. After a ten-year break, Conner released a new album in 2010 with his band Microdot Gnome called "4D Sugarcubes." He is currently working on future releases with Microdot Gnome. In August 2016, Conner released his solo album, "Ether Trippers," on Strange Earth Records.

Mad Season was a rock supergroup from Seattle, Washington, formed in 1994 by members of three popular bands from Seattle: Alice in Chains, Pearl Jam, and Screaming Trees. They released one album called "Above" and are most famous for their song "River of Deceit." The band took a break in 1996 because the members had different schedules and the lead singer, Layne Staley, had issues with drugs. They tried to get back together in the late 1990s without Staley, but the band broke up after bassist John Baker Saunders died in 1999. Staley passed away three years later from a drug overdose.

Beat Happening/Screaming Trees is a special collaboration between the bands Beat Happening and Screaming Trees from Washington. It was first released in 1988 and later included in Beat Happening's box set in 2002. Kurt Cobain, in a letter to Mark Lanegan, mentioned that Polly Pereguin was his favorite pop song from the 1980s.

Screaming Trees, a rock band from Ellensburg, Washington, has released seven studio albums, three compilation albums, five EPs, and six singles. This count does not include any music released separately by the band members.

Van Conner, an American rock musician born on March 17, 1967 in Apple Valley, California, helped start the band Screaming Trees in 1984 with his brother Gary Lee Conner and friends Mark Lanegan and Mark Pickerel. The band broke up on June 25, 2000. Conner later formed a band called Gardener, which released its only album in the 1990s under the name New Dawning Time. He also played as a session musician with bands like Queens of the Stone Age and assisted Mark Lanegan on his solo album "I'll Take Care of You."

question: Alexander Kerensky was defeated and destroyed by the Bolsheviks in the course of a civil war that ended when ?
pos: The Socialist Revolutionary Party, also known as the SRs, was a major political party in early 20th century Russia and played a significant role in the Russian Revolution. The party believed in revolutionary socialism with a focus on democracy and agriculture. After the February Revolution of 1917, the SRs shared power with other liberal and democratic socialist groups in the Russian Provisional Government. In November 1917, they won the most votes in Russia's first democratic elections for the Russian Constituent Assembly. However, the Bolsheviks took over in the October Revolution and disbanded the Assembly in January 1918. This led to a split in the SR party between those who supported the Bolsheviks and those who opposed them. The anti-Bolshevik faction, known as the Right SRs, was loyal to Provisional Government leader Alexander Kerensky but was defeated by the Bolsheviks during the Russian Civil War and faced persecution.

The Russian Civil War took place in Russia from November 1917 to October 1922, right after the Russian Revolutions of 1917. It was a conflict involving various groups fighting to shape Russia's future. The main sides were the Red Army, supporting Bolshevik socialism under Vladimir Lenin, and the White Army, a mix of factions favoring different ideologies like monarchism, capitalism, and other forms of socialism. There were also other groups like militant socialists and non-ideological Green armies involved. Several foreign nations, including the Allied Forces and pro-German armies, intervened against the Red Army. The Red Army defeated the White forces in Ukraine and Siberia by 1919, and in Crimea by 1920. The war continued in smaller battles for a couple more years, with minor clashes lasting until 1923. The conflict officially ended in 1923 when the Red Army secured control over the newly formed Soviet Union, although resistance in Central Asia persisted until 1934. The war resulted in an estimated 7-12 million casualties, mostly civilians, and is considered a major tragedy in European history.
neg: Communism in Russia started when Tsar Nicholas II lost his power during the February Revolution. The Provisional Government was set up under Prince Lvov, but the Bolsheviks, led by Vladimir Lenin, did not support this government and rebelled in October 1917, seizing control of Russia. Lenin governed from 1917 to 1924. The Bolsheviks established the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic, sparking the Russian Civil War between the Reds (revolutionaries) and the Whites (counter-revolutionaries). In 1922, the Communist Reds emerged victorious and formed the Soviet Union. After Lenin's death in 1924, a power struggle ensued, and Joseph Stalin took over as the leader of the Communist Party until 1953. Stalin promoted political paranoia and carried out the Great Purge to eliminate his opponents.

Lavr Georgiyevich Kornilov was a military officer and general in the Russian Army during World War I and the Russian Civil War. He is most known for the Kornilov Affair, which took place in August/September 1917. This event was an unsuccessful attempt to support Alexander Kerensky's Provisional Government but instead resulted in Kerensky arresting Kornilov for trying to stage a coup. This incident weakened Kerensky's rule, bolstered the power of the soviets, and helped the Bolshevik party gain influence.

The left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks were rebellions by rival left-wing parties that began shortly after the October Revolution. These uprisings, led by groups like the Socialist Revolutionary Party, Left Socialist Revolutionaries, Mensheviks, and anarchists, lasted from 1918 to around 1924. The Bolsheviks, who initially tried to include these groups in the government, eventually resorted to using force to suppress them during and after the Russian Civil War.

Louise Bryant was an American feminist, political activist, and journalist who gained fame for supporting Russia and the Bolsheviks during the Russian Revolution. She was married to writer John Reed and wrote about various Russian leaders. Her news stories were widely published in newspapers in the United States and Canada after her trips to Petrograd and Moscow. She also published a book called Six Red Months in Russia in 1918. Bryant defended the revolution in front of the Overman Committee in 1919 and later went on a speaking tour to rally public support for the Bolsheviks and oppose U.S. intervention in Russia.

The Battle of Romanovka took place in June 1919 during the Russian Civil War. Russian Bolshevik forces led by Yakov Triapitsyn surprised an American army camp near Vladivostok in Siberia. The Americans successfully defended against the attack. This battle, along with the subsequent Suchan Valley Campaign, marked the last major conflicts involving the United States in the Russian Civil War. Smaller skirmishes between the Americans, Bolsheviks, and Cossacks occurred later, with the Americans consistently emerging as the winners.
The Kerensky-Krasnov uprising was Alexander Kerensky's attempt to regain power in Petrograd after the Bolsheviks had overthrown his Provisional Government.

Timofey Petrovich Samsonov was a Soviet politician and veteran of the Russian Civil War. He served on the Central Committee elected by the 15th, 16th, and 17th Congresses of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks). He held positions as Chief Administrator from 1927 to 1935 and head of the Accounting Department from 1932 to 1934. He passed away in Moscow on October 28, 1955.

Alexander Fyodorovich Kerensky was a Russian lawyer who played a significant role in the Russian Revolution of 1917. He was part of the Russian Provisional Government after the February Revolution, serving as Minister of Justice and later as Minister of War and Minister-Chairman. Kerensky was associated with the moderate-socialist Trudoviks faction of the Socialist Revolutionary Party and was also a vice-chairman of the Petrograd Soviet. However, his government was overthrown by the Bolsheviks led by Lenin in the October Revolution. Kerensky spent the rest of his life in exile in Paris and New York City, where he worked for the Hoover Institution.

question: Seven Brief Lessons on Physics was written by an Italian physicist that has worked in France since what year?
pos: Carlo Rovelli is an Italian theoretical physicist and writer. He has worked in Italy, the United States, and France since 2000. His main focus is on quantum gravity, specifically the loop quantum gravity theory, which he helped create. He also studies the history and philosophy of science. Rovelli often contributes to various Italian newspapers, such as Il Corriere della Sera, Il Sole 24 Ore, and La Repubblica.

Summary: "Seven Brief Lessons on Physics" is a concise book written by Italian physicist Carlo Rovelli. First published in Italian in 2014, the book has been translated into 41 languages and has become a bestseller in Italy, selling over 300,000 copies.
neg: Guido Caldarelli, an Italian physicist specializing in statistical physics, was born in Rome on April 8, 1967. He is currently a full professor of Theoretical Physics at IMT School for Advanced Studies in Lucca. Caldarelli is married, has two children, and resides in Lucca.

Aldo Pontremoli was an Italian physicist who worked as a professor of theoretical physics at the University of Milan. He also started and managed the Institute of Advanced Physics at the same university. Unfortunately, Pontremoli went missing and is believed to have died in May 1928 along with five others when the airship Italia crashed in the Arctic.

Enrico Fermi was an Italian physicist known for creating the world's first nuclear reactor, the Chicago Pile-1. He is often referred to as the architect of the nuclear age and the atomic bomb. Fermi was a rare physicist who excelled in both theory and experimentation. He held patents related to nuclear power and won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1938 for his work on induced radioactivity and the discovery of transuranic elements. Fermi also made important contributions to quantum theory, nuclear and particle physics, and statistical mechanics.

The 12-volume Micropædia is a part of the 15th edition of Encyclopædia Britannica, along with the one-volume Propædia and the 17-volume Macropædia. The term Micropædia was created by Mortimer J. Adler using Greek words that mean small and instruction, which can be translated in English as brief lessons.

Claudio Pellegrini is an Italian physicist who was born in Rome on May 9, 1935. He is well-known for his groundbreaking research on X-ray free electron lasers and how particles behave in high-speed beams. Pellegrini studied at Sapienza University of Rome, where he earned his degree in Physics with top honors in 1958. He later worked at Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati focusing on high-energy and nuclear physics until 1978. In the early 1960s, he was at the Nordic Institute for Theoretical Physics in Copenhagen, exploring a new way to understand general relativity. Pellegrini then moved to the United States in 1978 to work at Brookhaven National Laboratory, where he held leadership roles. In 1989, he joined the University of California at Los Angeles (UCLA) as a physics professor and later became a Distinguished Professor.
Chiara R. Nappi is an Italian physicist who studies mathematical physics, particle physics, and string theory.

Sergio Ferrara, an Italian physicist born on May 2, 1945, is known for his work in theoretical physics and mathematical physics. He is famous for discovering theories that introduced supersymmetry as a symmetry of elementary particles, such as super-Yang–Mills theories with Bruno Zumino, and supergravity, which was the first major extension of Einstein's general relativity. This was based on the idea of local supersymmetry, developed with Daniel Z. Freedman and Peter van Nieuwenhuizen. Ferrara is now a retired staff member at CERN and a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles.

Antonino Lo Surdo was an Italian physicist born in Syracuse on February 4, 1880, and passed away in Rome on June 7, 1949. He became a physics professor at the Istituto di Fisica in Rome in 1919 and later became its director after Orso Mario Corbino's death in 1937. Lo Surdo focused on studying terrestrial physics, particularly seismology and geophysics. The tragic 1908 Messina earthquake, which took the lives of his parents and other relatives, inspired his interest in this field. He played a key role in establishing the Istituto Nazionale di Geofisica with the support of the Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, during Guglielmo Marconi's presidency.

question: The Livesey Hal War Memorial commemorates the fallen of which war, that had over 60 million casualties?
pos: The Livesey Hall War Memorial honors the employees of the South Suburban Gas Company of London who died in World War I and World War II. It also pays tribute to the company's employees who served in the wars. The monument was created by British sculptor Sydney March, from the March family of artists.

World War II was the deadliest war in history, with over 60 million people killed, which was about 3% of the world's population at that time. The number of deaths varied, with estimates ranging from 50 million to over 80 million. The higher figure includes deaths from diseases and famine caused by the war. Civilians accounted for 50 to 55 million of the total deaths, with 19 to 28 million dying from war-related issues. Military deaths from all causes were between 21 to 25 million, including about 5 million prisoners of war who died in captivity.
neg: The Alamein Memorial is a war memorial in Egypt that honors 11,866 members of the Commonwealth forces who died in World War II. It is located in the El Alamein War Cemetery and was designed by Hubert Worthington. The memorial was unveiled by Viscount Montgomery of Alamein on October 24, 1954.
The Rainham War Memorial honors soldiers who died in World Wars I and II, as well as civilians who lost their lives during World War II.

The Portsmouth Naval Memorial, also called Southsea Naval Memorial, is a war memorial in Portsmouth, Hampshire, England. It is located on Southsea Common near Clarence Esplanade, between Clarence Pier and Southsea Castle. The memorial honors about 25,000 British and Commonwealth sailors who died in the World Wars, with around 10,000 in World War I and 15,000 in World War II. It has a central obelisk with bronze plaques displaying the names of the deceased sailors, organized by the year of their death.

The Freetown Memorial is a war memorial in Freetown, Sierra Leone, dedicated to soldiers from Sierra Leone who served in the Royal West African Frontier Force during the First and Second World Wars. It honors 1,109 casualties from the First World War and 247 from the Second World War whose graves are unknown. The memorial is located outside the Secretariate Building and is maintained by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission.

The War Memorial in Hanoi was built in 1993 near the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and Hanoi Citadel. It honors those who gave their lives during the Second Indochina War, also known as the American War in Vietnam. The memorial combines traditional Vietnamese and modern architectural styles. It is often used for official events to remember those who died in the war.

The Tower Hill Memorial in London, England, is a war memorial dedicated to those from the Merchant Navy and fishing fleets who lost their lives in the two world wars and were buried at sea. The memorial was designed by Edwin Lutyens and features sculptures by William Reid Dick. An extension was later added for those who died in the Second World War, designed by Edward Maufe with sculptures by Charles Wheeler.

The Arras Flying Services Memorial is a war memorial in the Faubourg d'Amiens Cemetery in Arras, France. It honors around 1,000 airmen from Commonwealth forces who died during World War I on the Western Front and do not have a known grave. The memorial was created by architect Edwin Lutyens, sculptor William Reid Dick, and was revealed by Hugh Trenchard, 1st Viscount Trenchard, who was a top-ranking officer in the Royal Air Force, on July 31, 1932.

The Masnières Newfoundland Memorial is a war memorial dedicated to the Royal Newfoundland Regiment's actions during World War I. It is located in Masnières, France, and honors the Newfoundlanders' involvement in capturing and defending the town during the First Battle of Cambrai in November and December 1917.

question: Are both Elko Regional Airport and Gerald R. Ford International Airport located in Michigan?
pos: Elko Regional Airport, previously known as Elko Municipal Airport, is located one mile west of downtown Elko in Elko County, Nevada.

Gerald R. Ford International Airport, located about 13 miles southeast of Grand Rapids, Michigan, is a commercial airport in Cascade Township. It is owned by the Kent County Board of Commissioners and run by a separate authority. According to the Federal Aviation Administration's National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems for 2017–2021, it is classified as a small hub primary commercial service airport.
neg: Grantley Adams International Airport (GAIA) is the main airport in Barbados, located in Seawell, Christ Church. It is where people enter and leave the country by plane and serves as a major entry point to the Eastern Caribbean. The airport has flights to the United States, Canada, Central America, and Europe, and is a key hub for the airline LIAT. In 2016, it was the 8th busiest airport in the Caribbean and the third busiest in the Lesser Antilles. GAIA is also important for cruise ship passengers going to and from the Port of Bridgetown, and it is used by the Regional Security System (RSS) and the Regional Police Training Centre in the Caribbean.

Pensacola International Airport, previously known as Pensacola Gulf Coast Regional Airport and Pensacola Regional Airport (Hagler Field), is a public airport located three miles northeast of downtown Pensacola in Escambia County, Florida. The airport is owned by the City of Pensacola. Despite its name, Pensacola International Airport does not have direct flights to other countries. It is one of the five main airports in North Florida, along with Northwest Florida Beaches International Airport, Destin-Fort Walton Beach Airport, Tallahassee International Airport, and Jacksonville International Airport.

In the United States Navy, a pre-commissioning unit (PCU) is a term used for ships that are still being built before they are officially commissioned. For example, before the aircraft carrier Gerald R. Ford (CVN-78) was commissioned, it was referred to as PCU Gerald R. Ford. However, PCU is just a descriptive term and not part of the ship's official name. Until they are commissioned, U.S. Navy ships are officially known by their name and hull number only, without any prefix like Gerald R. Ford (CVN-78).

John Glenn Columbus International Airport is an airport located 6 miles east of downtown Columbus, Ohio. It used to be called Port Columbus International Airport and is now managed by the Columbus Regional Airport Authority. The airport code 'CMH' comes from Columbus Municipal Hangar, which was the airport's original name.

The Raleigh Exec Jetport at Sanford-Lee County, also known as Raleigh Executive Jetport, is a public airport located seven nautical miles northeast of downtown Sanford in Lee County, North Carolina. It is owned by the Sanford-Lee County Regional Airport Authority and was previously called Sanford-Lee County Regional Airport. The airport is considered a reliever airport for Raleigh-Durham International Airport and is part of the National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems for 2011–2015.

Bishop International Airport is an airport in Flint, Michigan that serves both commercial and general aviation flights. It was named after Arthur Giles Bishop, a banker and General Motors board member, who donated 220 acres of his farmland for the airport in 1928. The airport became the third busiest in Michigan in 2002, surpassing MBS International Airport in airline operations. In 2007, over a million passengers used the airport, but by 2011, the number dropped to around 938,000. The airport is classified as a small hub primary commercial service facility by the Federal Aviation Administration. It is served by airlines like Allegiant Air, Southwest Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Delta Connection, United Express, and American Eagle for passenger flights, as well as FedEx for cargo services. The airport also has a fixed-base operator called Av Flight, which manages general aviation and airline operations, and a flight school called American Wings Aviation. Bishop International Airport is located in southwestern Flint, surrounded by Flint Township to the north, east, and west, and Mundy Township to the south.

The Gerald R. Ford Freeway is a series of Interstate Highways named after former President Gerald R. Ford. They are located in Omaha, where he was born, and Michigan, where he grew up and served as a Congressman.

The Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library is at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. It has documents about Gerald Ford, who was the 38th President of the United States. The library is part of the National Archives and Records Administration's system of presidential libraries.

question: Ralph Hefferline was a psychology professor at a university that is located in what city?
pos: Ralph Franklin Hefferline was born on February 15, 1910, in Muncie, Indiana, and passed away on March 16, 1974. He was a psychology professor at Columbia University.

Columbia University, founded in 1754, is a prestigious private research university located in Upper Manhattan, New York City. It is often considered one of the top universities in the world and is a member of the Ivy League.
neg: The Princeton Neuroscience Institute (PNI) is a research center at Princeton University that focuses on studying the brain and nervous system. It was established in 2006 through a collaboration between the university's Psychology and Molecular Biology departments. Professors Jonathan Cohen and David Tank lead the institute together. In 2014, PNI relocated to a new research facility shared with the Department of Psychology. The building, designed by Rafael Moneo, covers 248,000 square feet and is environmentally friendly, aiming for LEED Silver certification.

Stanley Coren, born in 1942, is a psychology professor and researcher who is well-known for his books about dogs' intelligence, abilities, and history. He has gained popularity among dog owners through TV shows and media coverage in Canada, the United States, and abroad. He teaches psychology at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver and writes a regular column for Psychology Today called Canine Corner.

Abraham Harold Maslow was an American psychologist known for creating Maslow's hierarchy of needs, a theory that explains how people can achieve psychological health by meeting their basic needs first and then striving for self-actualization. He taught at several universities and emphasized the importance of recognizing people's strengths rather than just focusing on their problems. In a survey from 2002, Maslow was ranked as the tenth most cited psychologist of the 20th century.

E. Mavis Hetherington, born on November 27, 1926, is a retired psychology professor from the University of Virginia. She is well-known for her research on how divorce affects families and children. Over her career, she has written over 200 articles and edited 13 books. During her time at the University of Virginia, she played a key role in enhancing the psychology department's reputation, leading it to become a top-ranked program nationally. Hetherington also introduced a new way of analyzing observational research and worked to overcome gender discrimination in the field of psychology, paving the way for more women to enter the field.

Kimberly Young is a psychologist who is well-known for her expertise in Internet addiction disorder and online behavior. She established the Center for Internet Addiction in 1995 and taught psychology at the University of Pittsburgh at Bradford. Young holds a PhD in Clinical Psychology and currently works as a professor of management scientists at St. Bonaventure University. She has written many articles and book chapters and has provided expert testimony for the Child Protection Online Act Congressional Committee. Young is a member of various psychological associations and was a founding member of the International Society of Mental Health Online.

"Mathematically Alive: A Story of Fandom" is a documentary from 2007 that won awards. It's about fans of the New York Mets baseball team. The film was made by Katherine Foronjy and Joseph Coburn. It follows different fans during the 2005 and 2006 baseball seasons, including the exciting 7-game series against the St. Louis Cardinals. The film shows how fans can become very attached to their team, feeling either great joy or deep sadness. The filmmakers interviewed many fans, as well as former Mets players and a sports psychology professor who explains why fans feel the way they do. The film focuses on a group of female Mets fans who love former player Mike Piazza. They used to wait for him outside the stadium and even traveled to see him play after he left the team.

Frank L. Schmidt is a retired American psychology professor from the University of Iowa. He is well-known for his research in personnel selection and employment testing. In the 1980s, he had the most publications in the top two psychology journals. In the 1990s, he was the fourth most published researcher in the main journals for industrial-organizational psychology. He also received the first Dunnette Prize, a prestigious lifetime achievement award from the Society for Industrial and Organizational Psychology, for his significant contributions to understanding individual differences through research, development, and application.

David C. Funder is a psychology professor at the University of California, Riverside. He has written many important textbooks and research articles about personality psychology. In the past, he was the editor of the Journal of Research in Personality and also worked as a secondary editor for the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. Funder is well-known for his studies on personality judgment, as well as his research on attribution theory and delay of gratification.

question: Which dog's ancestors include Gordon and Irish Setters: the Manchester Terrier or the Scotch Collie?
pos: The Manchester Terrier is a type of dog that belongs to the smooth-haired terrier breed.

The Scotch Collie is a type of dog that comes from the highlands of Scotland. It includes both the long-haired (Rough) Collie and the short-haired (Smooth) Collie. This breed is thought to have come from different herding dogs that have been around for a long time, possibly since the time of the Romans. These dogs may have been a mix of Roman Cattle Dogs, Native Celtic Dogs, Viking Herding Spitzes, as well as Gordon and Irish Setters.
neg: The Teddy Roosevelt Terrier is a small to medium-sized American hunting dog. It has shorter legs, is more muscular, and has denser bones compared to the American Rat Terrier. The breed has a varied history and is related to the American Rat Terrier, Fox Paulistinha, and Tenterfield Terrier. The Rat Terrier's roots can be traced back to terriers and other dogs brought over by early English and working-class immigrants. The breed was primarily used for farming, hunting, and general utility purposes, so there was not much planned breeding involved. It is believed that the Teddy Roosevelt Terrier has ancestry from various breeds such as Feist, Bull Terrier, Smooth Fox Terrier, Manchester Terrier, Whippet, Italian Greyhound, and others. These dogs were likely crossed with Beagles to enhance their scenting abilities. This mix of breeds has given the modern Teddy Roosevelt Terrier a sharp awareness, strong prey drive, excellent sense of smell, and high intelligence. While they may be reserved with strangers, they are loyal companions who enjoy being close to their owners.

The Feist is a small hunting dog that originated from terriers brought to the United States by English miners and other working class immigrants. These terriers were likely a mix of Smooth Fox Terriers, Manchester Terriers, and the now-extinct English White Terrier. They were used for hunting rats, and their owners enjoyed betting on their ability to catch rats. Some Feists have been bred with Whippets or Italian Greyhounds for speed, and Beagles for hunting skills, expanding their abilities beyond just rat hunting.

The English Setter is a medium-sized dog breed that is part of the Setter family. This family includes red Irish Setters, Irish Red and White Setters, and black-and-tan Gordon Setters. English Setters have a mainly white coat of medium length with long silky fringes on the legs, belly, and tail. Their coat has flecks of color, and the different color variations are known as belton.

The Russian Toy is a very small breed of dog that originated in Russia. It was created by breeding the English Toy Terrier, now known as the Manchester Terrier. This breed has two types of coats: smooth and long. The smooth-coated variety used to be called the Russian Toy Terrier, while the long-coated one was known as the Moscow Long Haired Toy Terrier. In 1988, both varieties were combined under the name Russian Toy Terrier. The word "Terrier" was later removed from the name when the breed was officially recognized by the Fédération Cynologique Internationale in 2006 and registered with the American Kennel Club in 2008. Since 2010, it has been allowed to compete in AKC companion events. The first official breed standard for both coat types was established in 1966 in Russia.

The viol, also known as viola da gamba or gamba, is a type of musical instrument that is bowed, has frets, and strings. It has a hollow wooden body and pegboxes that can adjust the tension on the strings to change the pitch. The frets on the viol are usually made of gut and are tied on the fingerboard around the neck of the instrument. This helps the musician play the strings more precisely. Frets also help to keep the notes in tune and give a tone that matches the open strings. Viols originated in Spain in the 15th century and became popular during the Renaissance and Baroque periods. They have ancestors like the Arabic rebab and the medieval European vielle. More direct ancestors include the Venetian viole and the Spanish vihuela from the 15th and 16th centuries. The vihuela was a plucked instrument with six courses, similar to a lute, and looked like a viol, but was distinct from the guitar of that time.

The collie is a type of herding dog that originated in Scotland and Northern England. They are medium-sized dogs with a pointed snout and many have a white pattern over their shoulders. Collies are known for being active, agile, and having a strong herding instinct. They have spread to different parts of the world, such as Australia and North America, and have developed into various breeds with influences from other types of dogs. Some collies are still used as working dogs for herding livestock, while others are kept as pets, show dogs, or for dog sports. There are distinctions between collies bred for show and those bred for herding or sports, but they all share traits like agility, stamina, trainability, and intelligence.

The Toy Manchester Terrier is a smaller version of the Manchester Terrier, which is a type of terrier dog. In North America, breeders developed the Toy Manchester Terrier by selectively breeding for smaller size. The American Kennel Club and the Canadian Kennel Club classify this breed in the Toy Group, while the Manchester Terrier is classified in the Terrier Group. However, the Fédération Cynologique Internationale and The Kennel Club do not officially recognize the Toy Manchester Terrier as a separate variety of the Manchester Terrier.

Florence Nagle was a successful racehorse trainer and dog breeder who was also known for her advocacy for women's rights. She started breeding Irish Wolfhounds in 1913 and eventually owned or bred twenty-one champions in the United Kingdom. One of her dogs, Sulhamstead Merman, won Best in Show at Crufts in 1960. Nagle also excelled in field trials with Irish Setters from the 1920s to the mid-1960s, producing eighteen Field Trial Champions. Her Irish Setter bloodline played a crucial role in the revival of the Irish Red and White Setter breed in the 1970s.

question: Where is the company that Sachin Warrier worked for as a software engineer headquartered?
pos: Sachin Warrier is a singer and composer in the Malayalam film industry from Kerala. He gained recognition for his song "Muthuchippi Poloru" in the movie Thattathin Marayathu. He started his career with the film Malarvaadi Arts Club after working as a software engineer at Tata Consultancy Services in Kochi. He eventually left his job to focus on his music career. His most recent project is composing music for the film Aanandam.

Tata Consultancy Services Limited (TCS) is a company based in Mumbai, India that provides IT services, consulting, and business solutions. It is part of the Tata Group and has operations in 46 countries around the world.
neg: A lead programmer is a software engineer who oversees one or more software projects. They may also be known by other titles such as development lead, technical lead, lead software engineer, SDE lead, software development manager, software manager, or lead application developer. If they focus on designing high-level enterprise software, they may be called a software architect.

Sachin Bansal, born on August 5, 1981, is an Indian software engineer and internet entrepreneur. He is famous for starting Flipkart, an online shopping platform in India. Sachin is originally from Chandigarh and graduated in engineering from the Indian Institute of Technology Delhi.

William Michael Connolley is a British software engineer, writer, and blogger who specializes in climatology. He used to work as a climate modeller at the British Antarctic Survey until December 2007. Later, he transitioned to a software engineering role at Cambridge Silicon Radio.

Wes McKinney is an American who works with data and technology. He started a company called Datapad and later worked for Cloudera. He is known for creating Pandas, a tool for analyzing data in Python. He also wrote a book called Python for Data Analysis. Currently, he works as a software engineer at Two Sigma Investments.

Muthuchippy Poloru is a Malayalam song from the movie Thattathin Marayathu, composed by Shaan Rahman and written by Anu Elizabeth Jose. It was sung by Sachin Warrier and actress Remya Nambeesan. The song became very popular in 2012 and won multiple awards. It was also used in the Telugu remake of Thattathin Marayathu, called Saheba Subramanyam, with the title Muddu Muddu.

Kanave Kalayathe (Dreams Never Disappear) is an album featuring Sachin Warrier with singers Leon Poulose, Swetha Raj, Akash Thomas, Neethu Krishna VR, Christy Vazhapilly, and Althaf. The music was composed by Abee Joe, produced by Nidhinsha, and distributed by Muzik247. The music video was directed by Deen Shifaz and Ashith Wilson.

Alec David Edward Muffett, born on April 22, 1968, is an internet security expert from both England and America. He is well-known for creating Crack, the first Unix password cracker, and the CrackLib library for testing password strength. He is involved in the Open Source software community and has worked as a Software Engineer at Facebook.

Divya S. Menon is an Indian singer and television anchor from Kerala, born on 14 March 1987. She is known for her work as a playback singer in Malayalam, Tamil, and Telugu films. Divya began her career by hosting musical shows on channels like Asianet Cable Vision, YesIndiavision, and Kairali Channels. She made her film debut in "Ee Pattanathil Bhootham" and gained recognition when Shaan Rahman discovered her during one of her music show hostings. She has also been involved with Blogswara and has sung in various albums. Divya is known for her work in popular movies like "Thattathin Marayathu" and "Bangalore Days," where she sang hit songs composed by Gopi Sunder. Additionally, she has lent her voice to ad jingles in both Malayalam and Tamil.

question: A Japanese manga series based on a 16 year old high school student Ichitaka Seto, is written and illustrated by someone born in what year?
pos: Masakazu Katsura is a Japanese manga artist born on December 10, 1962. He is known for creating popular manga series such as Wing-man, Shadow Lady, DNA², Video Girl Ai, Is, and Zetman. Additionally, he has worked as a character designer for the anime series Tiger & Bunny.

Summary: "I"s is a Japanese manga series about a 16-year-old high school student named Ichitaka Seto who is in love with his classmate Iori Yoshizuki but is too shy to confess his feelings. Every time he tries to tell her, something, usually a misunderstanding, interrupts him. The situation becomes more complex when Ichitaka's childhood friend, Itsuki Akiba, returns to Japan. Itsuki had a crush on Ichitaka before moving to the United States, adding a new layer of complication to the story.
neg: The Manga Bible, also known as Shinyaku Seisho, is a manga series consisting of five volumes that retell stories from the Christian Bible. It was created by a group called Next, made up of people from the manga industry. Originally written in Japanese, each volume is illustrated by a different Japanese manga artist. The adaptation of the Bible into manga format was done by Hidenori Kumai. The first two volumes were illustrated by Kozumi Shinozawa, while the remaining three were done by another artist. The series started with "Manga Messiah" in 2006, which covered the four gospels: Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. Subsequent volumes like "Manga Metamorphosis" (2008) covered events from Acts and Paul's letters, "Manga Mutiny" (2008, 2009) started from Genesis to Exodus, "Manga Melech" (2010) continued from Exodus into the reign of David, and the final book, "Manga Messengers" (2011), covered stories from the reign of King Solomon, major and minor prophets, the Book of Esther, and ended with the anticipation of a messiah.

Neuro: Supernatural Detective, also known as Majin Tantei Nōgami Neuro in Japan, is a manga series created by Yūsei Matsui. It tells the story of Neuro Nōgami, a demon who needs mysteries to survive. After exhausting all the mysteries in the demon world, Neuro comes to the human world to find more. He enlists high school student Yako Katsuragi to help him run a detective agency. Matsui, the creator, made this supernatural manga because he felt he couldn't draw human characters well.

Summary: "Haven't You Heard? I'm Sakamoto" is a Japanese manga series about a high school student named Sakamoto who is known for being the coolest person in school. The manga is written and illustrated by Nami Sano. It has been licensed for an English release by Seven Seas Entertainment. An anime adaptation by Studio Deen aired from April 8, 2016, to July 1, 2016.

Summary: My Bride Is a Mermaid is a Japanese manga series written by Tahiko Kimura. It was published in Monthly Gangan Wing and Monthly Gangan Joker by Square Enix between 2002 and 2010. A drama CD based on the series was released in 2004. An anime adaptation with 26 episodes aired in Japan from April to September 2007, with two additional episodes released later. The English version was distributed in Singapore by Odex as Seto No Hana Yome, and in North America by Funimation Entertainment in 2010 as My Bride Is a Mermaid!

"Clear Skies!" is a Japanese manga series written by Akira Sugano and illustrated by Etsumi Ninomiya. It follows the story of four brothers living together. When one of the brothers' former high school girlfriend shows up and says she's married to their missing older sister, things get complicated. She also brings along her adopted son. The manga was first released in North America on August 28, 2008, under Digital Manga Publishing's Juné imprint.

Summary: "Silver Spoon" is a Japanese manga series by Hiromu Arakawa that follows the story of Yuugo Hachiken, a high school student who attends an agricultural school in Hokkaido to escape his strict father's expectations. Despite initially thinking it would be easy, he realizes the challenges of farm life. While his classmates have clear career goals in agriculture, Yuugo is unsure about his future but admires their determination.

"The Prince Of Tennis" is a Japanese manga series created by Takeshi Konomi about a talented tennis player. It was first published in Japan in July 1999 and ran for 379 chapters across 42 volumes until March 3, 2008. The manga has sold over 40 million copies in Japan. A sequel called "New Prince of Tennis" was announced in December and began serialization on March 4, 2009. Viz Media has the rights to distribute the series in English in North America.

The Kindaichi Case Files is a Japanese manga series about a high school student named Hajime Kindaichi who solves mysteries. The series follows the adventures of Kindaichi, who is believed to be the grandson of the famous fictional detective Kosuke Kindaichi. The manga is written by Yōzaburō Kanari or Seimaru Amagi and illustrated by Fumiya Satō. It first appeared in Weekly Shōnen Magazine in 1992 and is considered one of the earliest mystery manga series. In 1995, the manga won the Kodansha Manga Award for shōnen category.

question: The battle in which Giuseppe Arimondi lost his life secured what for Ethiopia?
pos: The Battle of Adwa took place on March 2, 1896, near the town of Adwa in Ethiopia. It was a significant battle between the Ethiopian Empire and the Kingdom of Italy during the First Italo-Ethiopian War. Ethiopia won the battle, which secured its independence and marked a major defeat for Italy.

Giuseppe Edoardo Arimondi was an Italian general who is best known for his leadership during the First Italo-Ethiopian War. He was one of the few European commanders to defeat the Mahdists at Agordat in 1893 before Kitchener's Expedition. After a successful career in colonial service, he tragically died in combat at Adwa and was later honored with the Gold Medal of Military Valor.
neg: The First Italo-Ethiopian War took place between Italy and Ethiopia from 1895 to 1896. It started because of a disagreement over a treaty that Italy believed made Ethiopia an Italian protectorate. Italy had the support of Germany and Austria, but they were surprised to find that Ethiopian ruler Menelik II had the backing of his traditional enemies. When Italy invaded Ethiopia from Eritrea in 1893, they faced a stronger opposition than expected. Ethiopia also received support from Russia, the United Kingdom, and France to prevent Italy from gaining more colonies. The war began in 1895, with Italy initially doing well until Ethiopian forces fought back and captured the Italian fort of Meqele. The turning point came at the Battle of Adwa, where the Ethiopian army defeated the outnumbered Italians and forced them to retreat to Eritrea.

Ethiopia and Japan have a long history of international relations. They both have a strong historical background of resisting European attempts to take control of their countries. Ethiopia fought off European forces at the Battle of Adwa, while Japan did the same at the Battle of Tsushima. Because of this shared history, both countries saw each other as possible allies before World War II.

Ethiopia is a country in Africa that doesn't have a coastline. It is surrounded by Eritrea, Sudan, South Sudan, Kenya, Somalia, and Djibouti. Ethiopia is one of the oldest countries in the world and has a large population. The area has a significant historical importance as it has some of the oldest traces of human existence. Studies suggest that human migration may have started from the region around present-day Addis Ababa. The country's history dates back to Emperor Menelik I in 1000 BC. The Ethiopian state has a long history, tracing back to the Aksumite Empire and D'mt. After a period of decentralized rule, Ethiopia was reunited in 1855 by Emperor Tewodros II. The country's borders expanded significantly in the 19th century, notably after its victory over the Italians at the Battle of Adwa in 1896. Ethiopia was occupied by Italy from 1936 to 1941 but was eventually liberated by British and Ethiopian forces.

Saint Ephigenia of Ethiopia, also known as Iphigenia of Ethiopia, is a folk saint from the 1st century. Her story, as recounted in the Golden Legend, describes her as a virgin who converted to Christianity and was consecrated to God by St. Matthew the Apostle. St. Matthew was spreading the Gospel in the region of Ethiopia, believed to be situated south of the Caspian Sea, possibly in Mesopotamia (Assyria and Babylon) or Ancient Armenia (Colchis).

Herbert S. Lewis is a retired Anthropology professor from the University of Wisconsin-Madison. He taught there from 1963 to 1998 and has done a lot of research in the field. In Ethiopia, he studied the history of the Oromo Kingdom of Jimma Abba Jifar and the lives of the Oromo people in the late 1950s and mid-1960s. His research focused on political leadership, community organization, and the history and culture of the Oromo people. He wrote a book about the monarchy in Ethiopia and also studied how spirit mediums called k'allu played a role in religious practices, conflict resolution, and providing leadership in rural areas.

P'ent'ay is a term used in Amharic and Tigrinya languages to describe Protestant Christians in Ethiopia and Eritrea. Originally used as a negative term in the late 1960s for churches that believed in the Pentecostal experience, it now refers to local Protestant Christians who are not part of the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo or Eritrean Orthodox Tewahedo churches. The term is a shortened version of Pentecostal and is commonly used to describe all Protestant Christians, regardless of their specific denomination. In other languages, they may be referred to as Evangelicals. The main Evangelical denominations in Ethiopia are Kale Heywet, Mekane Yesus, Mulu Wongel, and Meserete Kristos. While some P'ent'ay communities, like Mekane Yesus, have been influenced by the Orthodox Tewahedo Church, they mostly follow Pentecostal practices in their worship and beliefs.

In late December 1893, there was a battle called the Second Battle of Agordat between Italian colonial troops and Mahdists from Sudan. Emir Ahmed Ali led about 10-12,000 men from Sudan to fight against 2,400 Italians and Eritrean soldiers led by Colonel Arimondi at Agordat, west of Asmara. The fighting was intense, and over 1,000 Mahdists, including the Emir, were killed.

The Treaty of Addis Ababa was signed on October 23, 1896, to end the First Italo-Ethiopian War. It was mostly in favor of Ethiopia. This treaty replaced a secret agreement made between Ethiopia and Italy shortly after the Battle of Adwa in March of the same year. In this battle, Ethiopian forces led by Menelik II defeated the Italians. The key concession from the Italians was canceling the Treaty of Wuchale and acknowledging Ethiopia as an independent nation.

question: Alfred Balk served as the secretary of the Committee on the Employment of Minority Groups in the News Media under which United States Vice President?
pos: Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller was an American businessman and politician. He was the 41st Vice President of the United States from 1974 to 1977 and the 49th Governor of New York from 1959 to 1973. Before that, he worked as Assistant Secretary of State for American Republic Affairs for Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman, and as Under Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare under Dwight D. Eisenhower. Rockefeller was part of the wealthy Rockefeller family and was known for collecting art and managing Rockefeller Center in Manhattan, New York.

Alfred Balk was an American journalist and editor known for his pioneering work on housing segregation, the Nation of Islam, the environment, and Illinois politics. He faced a significant legal battle for protecting a confidential source. Throughout his career, he focused on improving the media industry by contributing to the establishment of the National News Council and advising various foundations. He also worked on promoting diversity in the news media and produced a documentary narrated by Walter Cronkite. Balk authored several books on diverse subjects such as religious organizations, globalization, and radio history.
neg: Cynthia C. Hogan is the Vice President for Public Policy and Government Affairs at Apple. Before joining Apple, she held positions as Senior Vice President of Public Policy and Government Affairs at the National Football League and as Counsel to Vice President Joe Biden during President Barack Obama's administration. She also worked as Chief Counsel to Vice President Biden while he was in the Senate and as Staff Director of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Gerald Ford was an American politician who became the 38th President of the United States in 1974 after Richard Nixon resigned. Before that, he was the Vice President for eight months after Spiro Agnew resigned. He was the first person to be appointed Vice President under the 25th Amendment and the only person to serve as both Vice President and President without being elected. Before his time as Vice President, Ford spent 25 years as a U.S. Representative from Michigan and was the House Minority Leader for the last nine years.

Robert E. Nyce is a former member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives who had a successful career in tax accounting before entering politics. He was involved in various community activities, including serving on the East Allen Township Municipal Authority and the Northampton Area School District Board of Directors. Nyce also ran for PA Auditor General but was not successful. After his political career, he worked as the Executive Director of the Pennsylvania Independent Regulatory Review Commission for eight years. Nyce is now retired and lives in Northampton County. He is a member of several organizations, including the Free and Accepted Masons of PA and the Rajah Shrine. Nyce also served in the U.S. Army, where he achieved the rank of Staff Sergeant and participated in significant events such as President Eisenhower's funeral and President Nixon's Inauguration.

The president pro tempore of the United States Senate is the second-highest-ranking official in the Senate. The Constitution states that the Vice President is the President of the Senate but as they are not a senator, the Senate must choose a president pro tempore to act when the Vice President is not available. Unlike the Vice President, the president pro tempore is a senator who can speak and vote on any issue. Elected by the Senate, the president pro tempore has certain privileges and some powers. When the Vice President is not present, the president pro tempore can lead Senate sessions. However, in reality, neither the Vice President nor the president pro tempore usually presides over sessions. Instead, this duty is rotated among junior senators of the majority party to give them experience in parliamentary procedures.

In 1961, President John F. Kennedy signed Executive Order 10925, which required companies working with the government to actively ensure that job applicants and employees were treated fairly regardless of their race, religion, color, or national origin. This order led to the creation of the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity (PCEEO), chaired by Vice President Lyndon Johnson and managed by Secretary of Labor Arthur Goldberg. The goal of this first Affirmative Action initiative was to provide equal job opportunities for all Americans, rather than giving preferential treatment to those who faced discrimination.

The Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission, also known as the U.S.-Russian Joint Commission on Economic and Technological Cooperation, was created to improve collaboration between the United States and Russia in various areas. It was established by Presidents Bill Clinton of the United States and Boris Yeltsin of Russia during a summit in Vancouver in April 1993. Al Gore, the Vice President of the United States, and Victor Chernomyrdin, the Prime Minister of Russia, were chosen as co-chairmen, hence the name of the commission. Before his role in the Commission, Chernomyrdin managed the Soviet national oil industry as a minister from 1985 to 1989. Following the collapse of the Soviet Union, Chernomyrdin restructured the Soviet oil industry into the Gazprom corporation.

Jim Lentz is the CEO of Toyota North America and also holds leadership positions in other Toyota companies. He oversees Toyota's operations in North America, including Toyota Motor Sales, U.S.A., Toyota Motor Engineering & Manufacturing, North America, and Toyota Motor Manufacturing Canada. Lentz is also the chairman of the North American Executive Committee, which includes top leaders from these companies. Previously, he held various executive roles within Toyota, including overseeing sales, marketing, and logistics activities. Lentz has been recognized for his achievements in the automotive industry and is involved in leadership roles outside of Toyota, such as serving on the board of directors for The Global Automakers and the executive advisory board for the Daniels College of Business at the University of Denver.

Gordon Johndroe is the vice president of Government Operations Communications at The Boeing Company. He started this role in November 2014. His job involves creating and executing communication plans to support the company's products and businesses. He also manages issues and interacts with the media and other groups in Washington, D.C. Before working at Boeing, Johndroe was the Vice President for Worldwide Media Relations at Lockheed Martin from 2013 to 2014. In that role, he was the main spokesperson for the company, advised senior leaders on media interactions, and led media campaigns. Prior to his time at Lockheed Martin, he worked as the Deputy Assistant to President George W. Bush, Deputy Press Secretary, and a spokesperson for the United States National Security Council.

question: A medieval fortress in Dirleton, East Lothian, Scotland borders on the south side of what coastal area?
pos: Yellowcraig, also known as Broad Sands Bay, is a coastal area in East Lothian, Scotland. It has a mix of forests, beaches, and grasslands. Yellowcraig is located in the Firth of Forth Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI). It is surrounded by the Firth of Forth to the north, the village of Dirleton and Dirleton Castle to the south, the North Berwick West Links golf course to the east, and the Archerfield Estate and Links golf courses to the west.

Dirleton Castle is an ancient fortress located in Dirleton, a village in East Lothian, Scotland. It is situated about 2 miles west of North Berwick and 19 miles east of Edinburgh. The castle was built in the 13th century and left empty by the late 17th century.
neg: Lothian and Borders is a region in the southeast of Scotland that includes East Lothian, City of Edinburgh, Midlothian, and West Lothian (known together as Lothian), as well as the Scottish Borders.

The Scottish Borders is one of the 32 council areas in Scotland. It is located next to the City of Edinburgh, Dumfries and Galloway, East Lothian, Midlothian, South Lanarkshire, West Lothian, and Northumberland in England. The main administrative center for this area is Newtown St Boswells.

Dirleton Kirk is located north of the village green in Dirleton, East Lothian, Scotland. The village is on the southern shore of the Firth of Forth, 21 miles east of Edinburgh and two miles west of North Berwick on the A198 road. The church can be found at grid reference [NT512842].

Dirleton, also known as 'Duighreach' in Scottish Gaelic, is a village and parish located in East Lothian, Scotland, about 20 miles east of Edinburgh on the A198 road. The village covers an area of 7500 acres and is surrounded by North Berwick to the east, Gullane to the west, Fenton Barns to the south, and the Yellowcraigs nature reserve, Archerfield Estate, and the Firth of Forth to the north. In 1612, an Act of Parliament merged Gullane parish with Dirleton parish because Gullane was declining while Dirleton was thriving.

The Royal Burgh of Haddington is a town in East Lothian, Scotland. It serves as the main administrative, cultural, and geographical center for the region. In the late 19th century, East Lothian was known as Haddingtonshire from 1889 to 1921 due to Scottish local government reforms. Haddington is located about 20 miles east of Edinburgh. The town's name dates back to the sixth or seventh century AD when it became part of the kingdom of Bernicia. Haddington, along with the rest of the Lothian region, was transferred from King Edgar of England to Scotland in the tenth century. During the reign of David I (1124–1153), Haddington was granted burghal status, making it one of the earliest towns to receive trading rights, which helped it develop into a market town.

Lord Haliburton of Dirleton was a Scottish noble title created around 1450 for Sir Walter de Haliburton, who served as the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland. The title was associated with Dirleton Castle, located in what is now East Lothian.

St. Mary's Priory in North Berwick was a medieval monastery for nuns in East Lothian, Scotland. It was established around 1150 by Donnchad I, Earl of Fife, who owned a lot of land in northern East Lothian. The priory existed for over four hundred years but declined and disappeared after the Scottish Reformation. Initially supported by the Earls of Carrick and Fife, it later became controlled by the Home (or Hume) family, who eventually took over the priory's lands as their own.

John David Home Robertson is a Scottish politician from the Labour party. He served as a Member of Parliament for Berwick and East Lothian and East Lothian from 1978 to 2001. He was also a Member of the Scottish Parliament for East Lothian from 1999 to 2007.

question: Who is the writer of this song that was inspired by words on a tombstone and was the first track on the box set Back to Mono?
pos: "Back to Mono (1958–1969)" is a collection of music by record producer Phil Spector from the 1960s. It was released in 1991 by ABKCO and includes 4 CDs or 5 vinyl records. The first song, "To Know Him Is to Love Him," was released in 1958 by the group the Teddy Bears, which Spector was a part of. The box set originally came in a package the size of a vinyl album and included a booklet with photos, song lyrics, and information about Spector. It also included a red Back to Mono pin.

The song "To Know Him Is to Love Him" was written by Phil Spector, who was inspired by the words on his father's tombstone, which read "To Know Him Was To Love Him." The song was first recorded by the Teddy Bears, a vocal group that Spector was a part of. Their recording of the song reached No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart in 1958 and No. 2 on the UK's New Musical Express chart. Other artists like Peter & Gordon and Bobby Vinton later had hits with the song, changing the title and lyrics to "To Know You Is to Love You." In 1987, Dolly Parton, Linda Ronstadt, and Emmylou Harris released a version of the song as Trio, which became a hit on the U.S. country singles charts. The song is played in 12/8 time.
neg: Trash Box is a collection of 5 CDs featuring garage rock and psychedelic rock music from the mid-1960s, mostly by American bands. It is similar to the Pebbles Box, which was a 5-LP set, and includes almost all the same songs in the same order, along with extra bonus tracks at the end of each CD. The Trash Box gathers the first five volumes of the Pebbles series released by AIP Records. However, the tracks on the CDs in the Trash Box are different from the original Pebbles LPs and later Pebbles CDs, and they do not include the surf rock rarities found in Pebbles, Volume 4. In total, the Trash Box has 109 tracks, compared to 101 songs on the individual CDs and 72 tracks in the Pebbles Box. While most of the songs in the Trash Box were previously released on individual Pebbles albums, some songs are unique to this collection.
