Notably, the hit song "I Fought the Law (but the Law Won)" by the Bobby Fuller Four is included in the Trash Box, replacing the rarer "Wine Wine Wine" by Bobby Fuller from Pebbles, Volume 2.

The box set "Chrome, Smoke & BBQ" by ZZ Top was released in 2003. It was unique because it included the original mixes of all the tracks from the band's first five albums on CD for the first time. This box set and another release called "Rancho Texicano" were the only CDs to have the original mixes from ZZ Top's first three albums, except for a 1977 compilation album. The albums "Tres Hombres" and "Fandango!" were later reissued with their original mixes in 2006. In 2013, Warner Brothers released a CD box set called "The Complete Studio Albums 1970-1990" which includes all ten of ZZ Top's studio albums with their original mixes.

Live in Japan is a collection of live recordings by John Coltrane and his band, which was his final group. The band included Coltrane, his wife Alice on piano, Pharoah Sanders on saxophone and bass clarinet, Jimmy Garrison on bass, and Rashied Ali on drums. The box set consists of four CDs, compiling music from three albums released in the 1970s by Impulse! Records. These albums were Concert In Japan (1973), Coltrane In Japan (1974), and Second Night In Tokyo (1976). The set also includes an interview on the sixth side of the vinyl record from Second Night In Tokyo, which has never been reissued on CD. The US edition of the box set includes both volumes of Live In Japan, which were originally released as two 2-CD sets in Japan.

Nashville Rebel is a collection of music by Waylon Jennings that came out in 2006. It is a comprehensive look at his career, featuring ninety-two songs he recorded from 1958 to 1994. The box set includes tracks from different points in his career, starting with a song produced by Buddy Holly in 1958 and ending with a tune produced by Don Was in 1995. The collection showcases Jennings' work from his time at RCA and Epic Records, but does not include songs from his independent label releases. It features many of his popular songs and collaborations with artists like Willie Nelson and The Highwaymen. One special addition is a previously unreleased duet with Johnny Cash. The box set includes four CDs, a 140-page booklet, and liner notes by Rich Keinzle and Lenny Kaye.

The Radiohead Box Set includes the band's first six studio albums and one live album. It was released on December 10, 2007, and is available in three formats: a seven CD box set, a digital download, and a 4GB USB Stick. The box set reached #95 on the album charts in Canada.

Mono Masters is a collection of songs by the Beatles that were originally created in mono. It was part of The Beatles in Mono box set, which focused on compiling Beatles songs that were specifically mixed for mono release. This set excluded songs that were only released in stereo or had a mono version created by combining the stereo channels. The tracklist of Mono Masters differs from Past Masters, as it includes songs with unreleased mono mixes and excludes songs that were never mixed in mono. Some tracks were intended for a mono EP in 1969 but were ultimately released in stereo. The final Beatles single mixed in mono was "Get Back," released in the UK, while the US release was in stereo. This compilation does not include songs originally released in stereo in the UK.

Led Zeppelin Boxed Set 2 is a collection of music released by Atlantic Records on 21 September 1993. It includes songs by the English rock band Led Zeppelin that were not in their previous box set from 1990. The music has been digitally remastered, and the set even includes a studio track called Baby Come On Home that had never been released before. The release also comes with a 54-page booklet. When you combine this box set with the earlier 4-CD box set, you get every song from Led Zeppelin's nine studio albums, as well as two live recordings from the BBC, a non-album B-side, and a studio outtake.

The Doors: Vinyl Box Set is a collection of records by the rock band The Doors. It includes their original six albums, which have been remastered in stereo from the original tapes. The debut album also has a mono version. The artwork, packaging, and inner sleeves are replicas of the original designs from 1967-1971. The box set was supposed to be released in October 2007 but was delayed until February 2008 due to issues with the vinyl quality and other production problems. The delay was caused by problems with test pressings, issues with the artwork for L.A. Woman, and using poor-quality vinyl initially, which led to a search for better vinyl materials.

question: What type of forum did a former Soviet statesman initiate?
answer: Organizations could come together to address global issues
pos: The World Summit of Nobel Peace Laureates was started by Mikhail Gorbachev in the 1990s. It is a meeting where Nobel Peace Prize winners and organizations can discuss global issues and work together to promote peace and well-being for all people. The summit is organized by a group based in Rome that operates year-round. They have a team of volunteers who help plan the summit and promote the work of the Nobel Peace Prize winners. So far, there have been 16 summits, with the most recent one taking place in February 2017 in Bogota, Colombia. This was the first time the summit was held in Latin America.

Mikhail Gorbachev, born on March 2, 1931, is a former Soviet leader. He was the last General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union from 1985 to 1991 and served as the country's head of state from 1988 to 1991.
neg: Nikolai Viktorovich Podgorny was a Soviet statesman who played important roles during the Cold War. He served as the First Secretary of the Communist Party of Ukraine from 1957 to 1963 and later as the Chairman of the Supreme Soviet from 1965 to 1977. In 1977, he was replaced by Leonid Brezhnev and was also removed from the Political Bureau, leading to his resignation from politics.

Andrei Pavlovich Kirilenko was a Soviet leader during the Cold War. He was born in 1906 in Russia to a working-class Ukrainian family. Kirilenko completed his education in the 1920s and later in the 1930s from the Rybinsk Aviation Technology Institute. He joined the Communist Party in 1930 and worked his way up the Soviet government ranks through the industrial sector. By the 1960s, he held a high position in the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic. After Nikita Khrushchev's resignation, Kirilenko became a key advisor to Leonid Brezhnev.

The MS Excelsior Neptune, previously known as the Feliks Dzerzhinskiy, was a ship owned by the Soviet Union's Black Sea Shipping Company. It was built in 1958 in East Germany and was part of the Mikhail Kalinin series of ships. The ship was named after Felix Dzerzhinsky, a Soviet statesman who founded the Soviet secret police.

Mikhail Suslov was a Soviet leader during the Cold War. He held important positions in the Communist Party of the Soviet Union until he passed away in 1982. Suslov was known for his strong stance against making changes and for his role in maintaining party democracy and power separation within the Communist Party.

Ephraim Markovich Sklyansky was a Soviet statesman who was born on August 12, 1892, and passed away on August 27, 1925. He became involved with the Bolsheviks while studying medicine at Kiev University and graduated in 1916. Sklyansky then served as a doctor in the army and was active in the secret military groups of the Bolsheviks. During the October Revolution, he was part of the Military Revolutionary Committee of the Petrograd Soviet. Leon Trotsky was impressed by Sklyansky's leadership qualities and attention to detail, appointing him as his deputy on the Revolutionary Military Council. Sklyansky played a significant role in improving the Red Army during the Russian Civil War. After his time as Trotsky's deputy, he became the chairman of the Mossukno state textile trust. Sklyansky later traveled to Germany, France, and the United States to gather technical knowledge. Unfortunately, he died in a boating accident on Long Lake in New York on August 27, 1925. There were suspicions that his death was orchestrated by Stalin and carried out by Genrikh Yagoda.

Anastas Ivanovich Mikoyan was a prominent Soviet statesman who served under Lenin, Stalin, Khrushchev, and Brezhnev. He was the only Soviet politician to maintain a high level of power within the Communist Party of the Soviet Union throughout the leadership changes from Lenin to Brezhnev. Mikoyan retired peacefully during the early months of Brezhnev's rule.

David Jonathan Waksberg was born in New York City on December 14, 1956. He was a prominent activist in the Soviet Jewry Movement from the 1980s to the early 1990s. In the 1970s, he joined the Student Struggle for Soviet Jewry. By the early 1980s, he had moved to California and started working for the Bay Area Council for Soviet Jews. Initially, he was an Assistant Director and later became the Executive Director. Waksberg led various public and political initiatives to support Soviet Jews, oversaw their well-being, and coordinated aid for Refuseniks and Prisoners of Conscience in the Soviet Union. He organized protests and vigils to raise awareness about the challenges faced by Jews in the USSR. In 1985, Waksberg became the National Vice-President of the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews. He frequently visited Jewish communities in the Soviet Union and Former Soviet states, providing briefings to American travelers interested in visiting these communities. In 1990, he became the Director of the Center for Jewish Renewal, which aimed to revitalize Jewish life in the USSR and address the rights and resettlement needs of Jews in the Former Soviet Union. The Center set up human rights and emigration offices in major cities across the former Soviet Union. In the mid-1990s, Waksberg served on the Bay Area Council's Board of Directors and worked as the Director of Development and Communication for the UCSJ. Since 2007, Waksberg has been the Executive Director of the Bureau of Jewish Education in San Francisco.

Sergo Anastasi Mikoyan was a prominent historian from the Soviet Union who focused on the foreign relations between the Soviet Union and the United States in Latin America. He was the son of Anastas Mikoyan, a key figure in Soviet politics and an advisor to Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev. Sergo Anastasi Mikoyan was born on June 5, 1929, and passed away on March 7, 2010.

question: Are Ferocactus and Silene both types of plant?
pos: Silene is a type of flowering plant that belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family. With around 700 different species, it is the biggest genus in its family. Some common names for Silene plants are campion and catchfly. These plants are found in many places, especially in the northern hemisphere.

Ferocactus is a type of big, barrel-shaped cactus with large spines and small flowers. There are around 30 different species of Ferocactus, and they can be found in the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico.
neg: The white campion, also known as Silene latifolia, is a plant that produces separate male and female flowers. It belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family and is found in Europe, Western Asia, and Northern Africa. This plant can grow up to 40-80 centimeters tall and is sometimes a short-lived perennial. In the USA, it is also called bladder campion, but it is different from another plant called Silene vulgaris, which is more commonly known as Bladder Campion.

Silene tomentosa, also known as the Gibraltar campion, is a rare flowering plant that belongs to the Silene genus and the Caryophyllaceae family. This plant is a woody-based perennial that grows to about 40cm in height. It has bilobed flowers that come in shades of pink to pale violet and is only found in Gibraltar.

Silene conoidea, also known as weed silene or large sand catchfly, is a type of flowering plant in the pink family. It is originally from Eurasia but is considered a weed in places like western North America. This plant grows as a yearly herb, reaching up to a meter in height, and has a stem covered in hairs and glands. Its leaves are lance-shaped, with the ones near the base being up to 12 centimeters long and smaller as you move up the plant. The flower is surrounded by a puffy, hairy calyx made of fused sepals, which has many veins running through it. At the top of the calyx, you can see five bright pink petals.

Silene stenophylla, also known as narrow-leafed campion, is a type of flowering plant that belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family. This plant species is found in the Arctic tundra of far eastern Siberia and the mountains of Northern Japan. Scientists found frozen samples of this plant that were around 32,000 years old in the same area where current living specimens grow. In 2012, a team of scientists managed to grow a new plant from these ancient samples.

Silene menziesii, also known as Menzies' campion or Menzies' catchfly, is a flowering plant found in western North America, from Alaska to the southwestern United States. It is a common plant that grows in various habitats. It has different forms and subtypes. Typically, it is a perennial herb with stems that can be short or tall, hairy, and sticky. The leaves are lance-shaped and arranged in pairs, with smaller leaves at the top. The flowers can be found at the top of the stem or in the leaf axils, enclosed in a hairy calyx. The petals are white with two lobes. This plant has separate male and female flowers that look similar on the outside but have reduced stamens in females and reduced stigmas in males.

Silene suksdorfii is a type of flowering plant that goes by several common names, including Suksdorf's silene, Suksdorf's catchfly, and Cascade alpine campion. It is found in the Pacific Northwest region of the United States, ranging from Washington and Idaho to northern California. This plant typically grows in high mountain areas, such as rocky slopes, but can also be found in forested subalpine regions below the tree line. It has short stems that grow from a leafy base and can reach heights of 10 to 15 centimeters. The stems are hairy and sticky in some parts. The leaves are clustered around the base, fleshy, and covered in soft hairs. The plant produces solitary flowers on tall stalks. These flowers have purple-veined sepals and white or purple-tinged petals with lobes at the tips.

Silene antirrhina, also called sleepy silene or sleepy catchfly, is a type of flowering plant in the pink family. It is originally from the Americas and can be found all over North America and some parts of South America. In Europe, it is considered a species that was brought in from another place.

Silene is a type of flowering plant that has separate male and female reproductive systems. This is possible because of its sex chromosomes, which are different in males (XY) and females. Silene developed these sex chromosomes about 5-10 million years ago, and they are unique among flowering plants. Scientists study Silene to understand how sex is determined because it is one of only 39 species with sex-determining genes. Silene is valuable for research because it can produce offspring with various reproductive systems. Researchers often find that the Y chromosome plays a key role in determining the sex of the offspring.

question: Which British first-generation jet-powered medium bomber was used in the South West Pacific theatre of World War II?
pos: No. 2 Squadron is a unit of the Royal Australian Air Force based at RAAF Base Williamtown near Newcastle, New South Wales. It was established in 1916 and has operated various types of aircraft such as fighters, bombers, and Airborne Early Warning & Control (AEW&C) planes. During World War I, the squadron flew missions on the Western Front. It was disbanded after the war but re-established in 1922, only to be disbanded again shortly after. The squadron was reformed in 1937 and played a role as a bomber unit in World War II and later in conflicts like the Malayan Emergency and the Vietnam War. It was disbanded in 1982 but re-established in 2000 to operate Boeing 737 AEW&C Wedgetail planes. One of these planes was sent to the Middle East in 2014 as part of Australia's involvement in the military coalition against ISIS.

The English Electric Canberra is a British bomber plane that was made in the 1950s. It was created by English Electric in response to a request from the Air Ministry in 1944 for a new bomber to replace the de Havilland Mosquito. The Canberra was designed to fly at high altitudes and speeds, with the help of new jet engine technology. It became the Royal Air Force's first jet-powered bomber when it started being used by them in May 1951.
neg: During World War II, the South West Pacific theater was a significant battleground where the Allies fought against Japan. It covered countries like the Philippines, the Dutch East Indies (excluding Sumatra), Borneo, Australia, New Guinea (including the Bismarck Archipelago), and part of the Solomon Islands. The Allied forces controlled this region through the South West Pacific Area (SWPA) command.

During World War II, the Asiatic-Pacific Theater was where U.S. forces operated in the Pacific War from 1941 to 1945. From mid-1942 until the end of the war, there were two main U.S. commands in the Pacific. Admiral Chester W. Nimitz led the Pacific Ocean Areas, which were split into the Central, North, and South Pacific Areas. General Douglas MacArthur led the South West Pacific Area. In 1945, the United States also formed the United States Strategic Air Forces in the Pacific, led by General Carl A. Spaatz.

The Savoia-Marchetti SM.79 Sparviero, which means sparrowhawk in Italian, was a three-engined medium bomber made of wood and metal. Originally built as a speedy passenger plane, it broke 26 world records between 1937 and 1939, making it one of the fastest medium bombers at that time. It was first used in the Spanish Civil War and later in various battles of World War II involving Italy. The aircraft gained fame as a torpedo bomber in the Mediterranean region and became one of the most well-known Italian planes of the war. Its crew members affectionately called it "il gobbo maledetto" (damned hunchback) due to its unique dorsal hump design.

During World War II, the South West Pacific Area (SWPA) was the main Allied military command in the South West Pacific region. It was one of four key commands in the Pacific War. SWPA covered areas like the Philippines, Borneo, the Dutch East Indies (except Sumatra), East Timor, Australia, Papua New Guinea, and part of the Solomon Islands. The forces in SWPA were mainly from the United States and Australia, but there were also troops from the Netherlands, the Philippines, the United Kingdom, and other Allied countries.

The Tupolev Tu-12, also known as the Tu-77 during development, was a Soviet bomber that used jet power. It was created as an experiment after World War II by modifying the older Tupolev Tu-2 bomber, which used traditional piston engines. The Tu-12 was meant to help Tupolev and the Soviet Air Force learn about the challenges and benefits of using jet engines in bombers.

No. 12 Squadron was a part of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) and had various roles like general purpose, bomber, and transport duties. It was created in 1939 and took part in battles in the South West Pacific during World War II. Between 1941 and 1943, the squadron mainly did patrols over the waters near northern Australia. From November 1943 to July 1944, it was stationed in Merauke, western New Guinea, before being pulled out of action. After getting new equipment, it worked as a heavy bomber group from February 1945 until the war ended. The squadron kept this role until it was renamed No. 1 Squadron RAAF in February 1948. It was revived in 1973 to handle transport helicopters but was shut down again in 1989.

During World War II, the Coastwatchers were Allied intelligence agents stationed on remote Pacific islands. They were also known as the Coast Watch Organisation, Combined Field Intelligence Service, or Section C of the Allied Intelligence Bureau. Their main job was to watch enemy movements and help rescue Allied personnel in trouble. The Coastwatchers were crucial in the Pacific Ocean and South West Pacific theaters, especially during the Guadalcanal campaign, where they acted as an early warning system.

Edwin A. Doss was an American fighter pilot and commander in the U.S. Air Force during World War II and the Korean War. He flew over 4,500 hours, with 573 of those hours in combat, completing 280 combat missions in the South West Pacific Theatre and Korean War. Doss was recognized for his leadership during World War II with awards like the Distinguished Flying Cross, Legion of Merit, and Air Medal. In the Korean War, he received additional honors for his service as commander of the 49th Fighter Bomber Wing and the 3rd Bomber Wing at Kunsan, Korea. Doss's contributions were crucial in developing long-range fighter tactics in the South West Pacific Theater.

question: In 1991 Euromarché was bought by a chain that operated how any hypermarkets at the end of 2016?
pos: Carrefour S.A. is a big French retail company with its main office in Boulogne Billancourt, France, near Paris. It's one of the biggest hypermarket chains globally, with 1,462 hypermarkets by the end of 2016. Carrefour has stores in over 30 countries across Europe, the Americas, Asia, and Africa. The word "Carrefour" means crossroads and public square in French. The company is listed on the Euro Stoxx 50 stock market index.
Euromarché was a French hypermarket chain that opened its first store in 1968 in Saint-Michel-sur-Orge. In June 1991, its rival Carrefour bought the group for 5.2 billion francs.
neg: Selver is a group of supermarkets and hypermarkets that are located in Estonia. It is a part of Tallinna Kaubamaja. The first Selver store, Punane Selver, opened in Lasnamäe, Tallinn in 1995. The chain expanded outside of Tallinn with the opening of Mai Selver in Pärnu on May 10, 2002. Selver also briefly operated in Latvia from December 18, 2008, but due to the financial crisis in 2009, all six stores in Latvia were closed. As of December 2014, there are 44 Selver stores operating across Estonia.

The Holiday Inn Orlando - Disney Springs Area is a resort hotel located in Lake Buena Vista, Florida, on the property of Walt Disney World Resort. It's close to the Disney Springs district on Hotel Plaza Boulevard. The hotel originally opened in February 1973 as a Howard Johnson's and was later expanded in 1978. It was part of the Howard Johnson's chain until 1994 when it was purchased by Host Marriott Corporation. From 1995 to 2003, it operated as a Courtyard by Marriott hotel. In December 2003, Holiday Inn acquired the resort. The hotel temporarily closed in August 2004 due to damage from Hurricane Charley but reopened in February 2010 after a $35 million renovation. In December 2016, the hotel was sold and is now managed by Interstate Hotels & Resorts under the Holiday Inn brand. The resort features 323 rooms, a heated swimming pool, a hot tub, and offers views of the Disney Springs area and Walt Disney World Resort from certain areas of the hotel.
Tesco Extra is a type of large store located mostly outside city centers, owned and run by the biggest retailer in the United Kingdom, Tesco.
Tazweed Center is a group of hypermarkets that are independently owned and operated. They are located in Syrian refugee camps and the word "tazweed" means resupply.

John A. Brown was a department store chain from Oklahoma that started in 1932 when its founder renamed the chain after himself. When the founder passed away in 1940, his widow took over until she died in 1967, leading to a change in ownership. Dayton-Hudson, another retail company, then took over but kept the chain's name until 1984 when they sold it to Dillard's. Dillard's combined all the Brown stores under its own name. The main store on West Main Street closed in 1974 and was demolished for an urban renewal project that was meant to create a new shopping center called the Galleria. However, the project was never finished, so the Brown chain never returned to downtown.

SavaCentre was a chain of large supermarkets owned by Sainsbury's and BHS. It started in 1977 with 13 hypermarkets and later added seven discount supermarkets. In 1989, Sainsbury's took over full control and renamed the stores as Sainsbury’s SavaCentre. In 2005, the stores were rebranded as regular Sainsbury's supermarkets. The hypermarkets were between 66,000 and 117,000 square feet, while the discount supermarkets were between 31,000 and 70,000 square feet. SavaCentre was the only hypermarket chain in the UK at that time.

Uno-X is a chain of self-service gas stations in Norway and Denmark. It is part of YX Energi and is known for its affordable prices. The chain started in Denmark in the late 1950s as a budget-friendly option. In 1991, Norsk Hydro bought the 330 stations in Denmark, and later acquired the Swedish Uno-X chain from Burmah Oil in 1996.

Lewis's was a British chain of department stores that started in 1856 and closed in 2010. The parent companies of Lewis's faced financial difficulties many times, including in 1991. The first store opened in Liverpool and was the main store in the chain. In 1991, some stores were bought by Owen Owen and kept the Lewis's name for a while. However, after the Manchester store closed in 2002, only the Liverpool store remained as Lewis's. It was eventually sold to Vergo Retail Ltd in 2007 and shut down in 2010.

question: What race track in the midwest hosts a 500 mile race eavery May?
pos: The Indianapolis Motor Speedway is a famous race track in Speedway, Indiana, near Indianapolis. It hosts events like the Indianapolis 500 and the Brickyard 400. It used to host the United States Grand Prix as well. The track is situated at the intersection of 16th Street and Georgetown Road, about 6 miles west of Downtown Indianapolis.

The 41st International 500-Mile Sweepstakes took place at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway on May 30, 1957. It was a part of the 1957 USAC National Championship Trail and was the third race out of eight in the 1957 World Championship of Drivers.
neg: The Subway 400 used to be the second race of the NASCAR Winston Cup Series season until 2004. It took place a week after the Daytona 500 and was a 400-mile (644 km) race sponsored by Subway. The event was held at North Carolina Speedway (The Rock) starting in 1966. Initially, from 1966 to 1995, a longer 500-mile (805-km) race was held under different names like the Peach Blossom 500 (1966), the Carolina 500 (1967–1985), and the Goodwrench 500 (1986–1995). In 1996, the race was shortened to 400 miles and went through various name changes like the Goodwrench Service 400 (1996–1997), the GM Goodwrench Service Plus 400 (1998), the Dura Lube/Big K 400 (1999), the Dura Lube/Kmart 400 (2000), the Dura Lube 400 (2001), and finally the Subway 400 (2002–2004).

The Carolina Dodge Dealers 400 used to be a NASCAR Sprint Cup race that took place every spring at Darlington Raceway in South Carolina, USA. It started as a 100-mile race in 1952 but didn't become a regular event on the NASCAR schedule until 1957 when it became a 300-mile race known as the Rebel 300. Over the years, the race distances changed - in 1966 it became a 400-mile race, and in 1973 it was extended to 500 miles. In 1994, it went back to being a 400-mile race. Due to a lawsuit settlement in 2005, Darlington Raceway had to reduce its races to one per year, with the 500-mile race (Southern 500) moving to Mother's Day weekend. The 400-mile race was discontinued, but Dodge's sponsorship was transferred to the longer race.

The Louis Schwitzer Award is given each year to an engineer or group of engineers who have excelled in creating new and innovative technology for motorsports to be used in the Indianapolis 500 Mile Race. This award recognizes ideas that enhance the performance, safety, and energy efficiency of racing cars, their parts, systems, as well as equipment for drivers and race tracks.

The Lean Horse Ultramarathon takes place in August each year in the Black Hills of South Dakota. It started in 2005 and offers three race options: a 100-mile race, a 50-mile race, and a 50-kilometer race. The majority of the race course follows the George S. Mickelson Trail. This event was the 33rd official 100-mile race in the United States and is considered one of the simplest hundred mile races in the country.

Orange County Fair Speedway is a dirt oval speedway located in Middletown, Orange County, New York. It hosts weekly stock car races and demolition derbies in the summer. Originally built in 1857 for horse racing at the Orange County Fair, the track held its first automobile race on August 16, 1919. The fair, which started as an agricultural exhibit in 1843, found a permanent home in the Wallkill–Middletown area in 1857. The speedway, situated at 239 Wisner Avenue in Middletown, was originally a half-mile horse racing track called the Harry Clay Oval, named after a famous racehorse of that time. Over the years, the track was expanded and lengthened to its current size of five-eighths of a mile.

John Sherman Rutherford III, also known as Lone Star JR, is a retired American race car driver. He is one of only ten drivers to have won the famous Indianapolis 500 race three times, achieving victory in 1974, 1976, and 1980.

The 1964 Armstrong 500 was a car race that took place on 4 October 1964 at the Mount Panorama Circuit near Bathurst in New South Wales, Australia. The race covered a distance of 500 miles and was only for Australian-made production sedans, with 100 cars registered to participate. This event was the fifth of its kind and the second one held at Bathurst, although it is often called the fifth Bathurst 500.

Allison's story started in 1909 when James A. Allison, along with three business partners, played a key role in creating the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. In 1911, the track hosted the first Indianapolis 500-mile race. Jim Allison also supported various race teams and started his own racing team in 1915, where he became known for his expertise in race car technology and automotive innovation.

question: In what city did the "Prince of tenors" star in a film based on an opera by Giacomo Puccini?
pos: Franco Corelli was an Italian opera singer known for his powerful voice and passionate performances. He sang from 1951 to 1976 and was famous for his roles in Italian operas. People loved his strong voice, high notes, clear tone, and emotional singing. He was called the Prince of tenors because of his good looks and captivating stage presence. Corelli sang at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City from 1961 to 1975 and performed at many other opera houses in Europe and North America.

Tosca is an Italian musical film from 1956 directed by Carmine Gallone. The movie stars Franca Duval, Afro Poli, and Franco Corelli, and is based on Giacomo Puccini's opera Tosca. It was filmed at Cinecittà in Rome.
neg: Ron Bottcher was an American opera singer who performed in New York City during the 1960s. He was born in Sandpoint, Idaho, and studied music at the University of Montana and the Curtis Institute of Music. Bottcher debuted at the Santa Fe Opera in 1961, where he played various roles in operas by composers like Richard Strauss, Giacomo Puccini, and Paul Hindemith. He also performed at the New York City Opera and the Metropolitan Opera, where he took on roles in well-known operas like Carmen and Madama Butterfly. Bottcher passed away at the age of 50 due to complications from AIDS at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan.
La movie La bohème, also called La bohème de Puccini, was made in 1988 in Italy and France. It is a film adaptation of an opera by Giacomo Puccini, directed by Luigi Comencini.

Gianni Schicchi is a funny opera written by Giacomo Puccini in 1917-18. The story is based on a part of Dante's Divine Comedy. It is the last part of Puccini's Il trittico (The Triptych), which is a set of three short operas with different themes meant to be performed together. While it used to be performed with the other two operas, Gianni Schicchi is now often staged on its own or with other short operas by different composers. The song "O mio babbino caro" from this opera is one of Puccini's most famous and beloved arias in all of opera.

Summary: "O mio babbino caro" is a soprano aria from the opera Gianni Schicchi by Giacomo Puccini. It is sung by Lauretta, who is in love with Rinuccio, after a conflict between her father Schicchi and Rinuccio's family puts their relationship in jeopardy. The aria conveys a sense of pure love amidst the deceit and discord in the opera's setting of medieval Florence. It is a standout moment in the opera, known for its heartfelt simplicity and emotional depth.

Summary: La fanciulla del West (The Girl of the West) is an opera in three acts by Giacomo Puccini, with an Italian libretto based on a play by American author David Belasco. It followed Puccini's Madama Butterfly and is known for its impressive orchestration and integrated score. The opera shows influences from composers Debussy and Strauss, but is not imitative. Some similarities to Wagner's work have been noted, but the opera is considered quintessentially Italian.

The Festival Puccini, also known as the Puccini Festival, is a summer opera festival that takes place every year in July and August. It showcases the operas composed by the renowned Italian composer Giacomo Puccini.

Cesira Ferrani was an Italian opera singer born on May 8, 1863, in Turin. She is famous for being the first to perform two very important roles in opera history: Mimì in Giacomo Puccini's La bohème in 1896 and the title role in Puccini's Manon Lescaut in its 1893 debut. Ferrani sang a variety of opera pieces, including those by Verdi, Gounod, Wagner, and Debussy, in addition to verismo opera.

Jacopo Puccini, an Italian composer from the 18th century, lived and worked mainly in Lucca, Tuscany. He was the first in a line of five composers, with his great-great-grandson Giacomo Puccini becoming the most well-known for his operas.

question: Ellie Goulding worked with what other writers on her third studio album, Delirium?
answer: Max Martin, Savan Kotecha and Ilya Salmanzadeh
pos: Ellie Goulding's song "On My Mind" is from her album Delirium released in 2015. It was the first single from the album and came out on September 17, 2015. The song was written by Goulding, Max Martin, Savan Kotecha, and Ilya Salmanzadeh. "On My Mind" is a mix of electropop and R&B with scratchy guitars, trap drums, and electronica beats. The lyrics tell a story of a one-night stand with someone the singer knows they shouldn't be with, showing a conflict between emotions and logic. Some critics thought the song was a response to Ed Sheeran's "Don't," although Goulding denied this.

Ellie Goulding's third studio album, "Delirium," was released on November 6, 2015 by Polydor Records. Music critics mostly liked the album's production quality, but some were unsure about how unique it was. It entered the UK Albums Chart and the US Billboard 200 at number three, becoming Goulding's highest-charting album in the US and achieving her best first-week sales in both countries. The album included three singles: "On My Mind," "Army," and "Something in the Way You Move."

She also worked with artists such as Tinie Tempah and Calvin Harris on the album.

It was released on January 7, 2015, as the second single from the movie's soundtrack and was also included on Goulding's album Delirium.

Summary: "Outside" is a song by Calvin Harris featuring Ellie Goulding, released in 2014 as part of Harris's album Motion. It is their second collaboration, following their previous single "I Need Your Love." The song is also included in the deluxe edition of Goulding's album Delirium.
Ellie Goulding, an English singer and songwriter, released a song called "Army" from her third album, Delirium, in 2015. The song was released as the second single from the album on January 9, 2016.

Ellie Goulding's Delirium World Tour is her third major concert tour to support her third studio album, Delirium, released in 2015. The tour is divided into four parts: European, North American, Summer Festivals, and Oceanic. It includes a total of 89 shows in 88 different cities. The tour began on January 21, 2016, in Hamburg, Germany, and ended on May 12, 2017, in Rabat, Morocco, as part of the Mawazine Festival.

Flashlight is a song by Ellie Goulding, a singer from England. It was produced by DJ Fresh and released as the fourth single from Fresh's upcoming fourth album. The song was first released on September 28, 2014, in the UK as a single, even though it was already on Goulding's 2013 album. It is also included on Goulding's Halcyon Days album, which is a reissue of her second album, Halcyon. The song was written with the help of The Invisible Men.

Something in the Way You Move is a song by Ellie Goulding, an English singer and songwriter. It is from her third album, Delirium, released in 2015. The song was released to radio in the United States on January 19, 2016, as the second single from the album in North America and the third single overall. It reached number 51 on the UK Singles Chart and number 43 on the US Billboard Hot 100.

English singer Ellie Goulding has recorded songs for three albums and made guest appearances. She signed with Polydor Records in July 2009 and started working on her first album, "Lights," which came out in February 2010. The first single, "Under the Sheets," was a collaboration with Starsmith, who also co-wrote four other songs and produced most of the album. Goulding worked with Jonny Lattimer on singles like "Starry Eyed" and "The Writer," and with Fraser T Smith on "Your Biggest Mistake." In November 2010, she re-released "Lights" as "Bright Lights," adding new songs. She worked with Richard Stannard and Ash Howes on "Lights" and covered Elton John's "Your Song." Goulding also featured on Tinie Tempah's song "Wonderman" from his debut album "Disc-Overy" in 2010.

question: Which Australian city founded in 1838 contains a boarding school opened by a Prime Minister of Australia and named after a school in London of the same name.
pos: Marion is a neighborhood located in the City of Marion, which is about 10 km southwest of downtown Adelaide. It started as a small village in 1838 near the Sturt River, where the soil was fertile, leading to a quick increase in population. Colonel William Light, who also planned the layout of Adelaide, designed the village of Marion.

Westminster School is a coeducational day and boarding school located in Marion, South Australia, about 12 km south of Adelaide. It was established in 1961 as a Methodist school for boys and was inaugurated by Prime Minister Robert Menzies. The school, named after Westminster School in London, became coeducational in 1978 and currently has approximately 1150 students enrolled.
neg: The Sainik School Balachadi in Jamnagar, Gujarat, is considered one of the top Sainik Schools out of the 26 in India. Established in July 1961 by then-Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri, it is a prestigious English medium boarding school for boys that follows the Central Board of Secondary Education curriculum up to the 10+2 stage. The school aims to provide high-quality education with a focus on military training. Situated about 32 km from Jamnagar city, the campus overlooks the Gulf of Kutch and is surrounded by historical landmarks like the former residence of Maharaja Jam Shaheb Digvijaysinhji Ranjitsinhji and a ship breaking yard.

The PNG solution is an Australian government policy that says any asylum seeker who arrives in Australia by boat without a visa will not be allowed to stay in Australia. Instead, they will be sent to Papua New Guinea if they are considered to be real refugees. This policy involves making the immigration detention center on Manus Island bigger, where refugees will go to be checked before moving to Papua New Guinea. If they are not considered real refugees, they may be sent back to their home country, to a different country, or kept in detention. The policy was introduced on July 19, 2013, by Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd and Papua New Guinean Prime Minister Peter O'Neill because there were too many asylum seekers arriving by boat. At first, Opposition Leader Tony Abbott supported the policy, but Greens leader Christine Milne and some human rights groups did not like it and organized protests in major Australian cities.

Cotter High School in Winona, Minnesota, is the only Roman Catholic high school in the area and one of the oldest in the state. It was founded in 1911 as a boys' school named after Bishop Joseph Bernard Cotter. Originally run by the Christian Brothers, it later became co-educational in 1952 by merging with Cathedral Girls High School. The school moved to its current location in 1992 with the help of the Hiawatha Education Foundation, allowing it to include a boarding school.

Princeton High School was established in 1867 and had its first graduating class in 1869. Initially, it was a boarding school that taught subjects like English, math, history, and science. The school expanded in 1894 and 1908 to accommodate more students. Unfortunately, a fire destroyed the school on December 15, 1924. While plans were made to build a new school, classes were temporarily held in various locations in Princeton. The new school opened on September 27, 1926, featuring a large building with classrooms, an auditorium, a library, science labs, and a gym. Today, the school is still in use, but it has undergone several renovations and additions over the years.

Concho Indian Boarding School, also known as the Cheyenne-Arapaho Boarding School, was a school for Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribe members that later accepted other Native American students. It operated from 1909 to 1983 in central Oklahoma, about 1 mile south of Concho, Oklahoma, and 4 miles north of El Reno, Oklahoma. The school was named after the Indian agent, Charles E. Shell, and the town's name comes from the Spanish word for shell.

Grace Church School is a private school in New York City. It was founded in 1894 by Grace Church and originally located on Fourth Avenue. The school started as a choir boarding school and later became a private day school in 1934. In 2012, the High School Division was opened at a different location on Cooper Square. In the 2015-16 school year, the school expanded to offer classes from Junior Kindergarten to 12th grade.

Vishwajyoti Higher Secondary School was first established in 1994 in Nawalparasi, Nepal by a group of experienced education professionals. It started as Nawal English Boarding School in 1982 and later merged with Vishwa Jyoti English Boarding School in 2000. In 2007, the school upgraded to offer classes in science and management at the Higher Secondary Level, affiliated with the Higher Secondary Education Board.

Grennaskolan Boarding School is a Swedish boarding school in Gränna, Jönköping County. It was established in 1963 by Stockholm University and currently has around 200 students. Half of the students live on campus, while the other half are from different countries.

question: D1NZ is a series based on what oversteering technique?
pos: Drifting is a driving technique where the driver intentionally makes the car slide sideways through a turn by turning the wheels in the opposite direction. This is done by causing the rear wheels to lose traction while still keeping control of the car.

D1NZ is a drifting competition for production cars in New Zealand. It is considered the top series in the country since there is no official drifting championship in New Zealand. The competition started in 2003 with a few drifting teams from across the country. It is now a professional event with sponsored drivers and two championships: Pro and Pro-sport. New drivers usually start in the Pro-sport championship before moving up to the Pro championship. The goal of the organizers is to promote and educate people about drifting in a safe environment. Despite having a similar name, D1NZ is not connected to the Japanese D1 Grand Prix series. It is known as the oldest drifting series in the world.
neg: Raimund Harmstorf was a German actor born on October 7, 1939, in Hamburg. He is best known for his role in a popular German TV series called "The Sea-Wolf," based on a book by Jack London. Rising Star is a French music competition TV show that is inspired by the Israeli show HaKokhav HaBa. In this show, the viewers at home are the main judges, with a small influence from a panel of experts. The French channel M6 bought the rights to air the show.

Iron Man: The Animated Series is a cartoon show about the superhero Iron Man from Marvel Comics. It aired on TV from 1994 to 1996 as part of The Marvel Action Hour. The show included episodes of Iron Man and another Marvel show, the Fantastic Four, airing one after the other. The show also had a toy line with different Iron Man suits.

Raaz Pichhle Janm Ka is an Indian reality TV series that explores past life regression. The show airs on NDTV Imagine and is hosted by actor Ravi Kishan. Mumbai-based psychologist Trupti Jayin conducts the past life regression sessions. The first season premiered on December 7, 2009, with a planned 20-episode run from Monday to Friday at 9:30 pm. Due to its popularity, the season was extended by 20 episodes and concluded on January 15, 2010. The second season began on October 23, 2010, with actor Chunky Pandey as a guest.

The Office is a TV show that is a parody of a documentary style. It mixes traditional comedy scenes with fake interviews with the characters. The show lets viewers hear the characters' thoughts and sometimes shows what other characters are thinking too.

Night School is a British web series that is adapted from the Night School books written by CJ Daugherty. It is the first web series to be based on a British young adult book. The show debuted on YouTube on December 12, 2014, and was written and created by CJ Daugherty and Jack Jewers.

Ripley's Believe It or Not! is the name of a few TV shows that were inspired by a newspaper column. The first show was on NBC from 1949 to 1950 and was hosted by Robert L. Ripley. After he passed away, other hosts took over. The show came back on ABC in the 1980s with Jack Palance as the main host. It was revived again on TBS in 2000 with Dean Cain as the host. A Filipino version hosted by Chris Tiu began in 2008. There was also an animated series based on Ripley's stories.

"Katri, Girl of the Meadows" is an anime series based on a Finnish novel called "Paimen, piika ja emäntä" by Auni Nuolivaara. This series, also known as Meisaku, produced many animated shows based on children's novels from around the world. "Katri, Girl of the Meadows" was popular in Europe, airing in countries like Spain, Italy, France, and Germany. Surprisingly, the show has never been shown or released in Finland, where it remains largely unknown.

question: who is younger Keith Bostic or Jerry Glanville ?
pos: Jerry Michael Glanville is a retired American football player and coach, as well as a former NASCAR driver and team owner. He was the head coach for the Houston Oilers from 1986 to 1990 and the Atlanta Falcons from 1990 to 1994, with a total NFL record of 63 wins and 73 losses. He later coached the Portland State University football team from 2007 to 2009, where he won 9 games and lost 24. Glanville has also worked as a sports analyst on various TV shows and has competed in races on the Automobile Racing Club of America circuit. In 2011, he briefly worked as a consultant for the United Football League.

William Keith Bostic, born on January 17, 1961, is a retired professional American football player who played as a safety in the National Football League (NFL) for seven seasons. He played for the Houston Oilers and the Cleveland Browns. Bostic was the defensive captain for the Oilers under Jerry Glanville. He was selected for the Pro Bowl once and narrowly missed another selection due to a tiebreaker. During his Pro Bowl season, he led the American Football Conference in interceptions.
neg: Ken Herock, a former football player, was born in Pittsburgh on July 16, 1941. He played as a tight end in college at West Virginia and professionally in the American Football League. question: Are both Cypress and Ajuga genera?
pos: Ajuga, also called bugleweed, ground pine, carpet bugle, or just bugle, is a type of plant that belongs to the mint family Lamiaceae. There are around 40 species of Ajuga, which are both annual and perennial herbaceous flowering plants. Most of these species are found in Europe, Asia, and Africa, although there are also two species in southeastern Australia. Ajuga plants typically grow between 5 and 50 cm tall and have leaves that grow opposite each other.

neg: Fokienia is a type of conifer tree that is part of the cypress family. It shares traits with both Chamaecyparis and Calocedrus, but it is genetically more similar to Chamaecyparis. Some researchers do not consider Fokienia to be its own distinct genus. There is only one living species in this genus, called Fokienia hodginsii or Fujian cypress, and one fossil species named Fokienia ravenscragensis.

The Frenchman Formation is a layer of rock from the Late Cretaceous period found in the Western Canada Sedimentary Basin. It can be seen in southern Saskatchewan and the Cypress Hills area of southeastern Alberta. This formation was identified by G.M. Furnival in 1942 after studying rocks along the Frenchman River, near Ravenscrag and Highway 37. It holds the remains of some of the most recently living dinosaur species, similar to the Hell Creek Formation in the United States.

The Cupressus genus is a group of cypress trees that belong to the Cupressaceae family. The name "cypress" is used for several genera within this family. Cupressus is part of the Cupressoideae subfamily and is known to have diverse origins. The common name "cypress" comes from the Old French word "cipres," which is derived from the Latin word "cyparissus," itself a Latinized version of the Greek word "κυπάρισσος" (kypárissos).

Cedrol is a type of alcohol found in the essential oil of certain conifer trees like cedar, cypress, and juniper. It is also present in a plant called Origanum onites, which is similar to oregano. Cedrol is commonly used in creating fragrances. In cedarwood oil from Texas, it makes up around 19% of the composition, while in cedarwood oil from Virginia, it accounts for about 15.8%.

Libocedrus is a type of conifer tree that belongs to the cypress family Cupressaceae. There are five species of Libocedrus trees found in New Zealand and New Caledonia. Libocedrus is closely related to other tree genera like Pilgerodendron and Austrocedrus from South America, as well as Papuacedrus from New Guinea. Some botanists group these genera together under Libocedrus. These trees are similar to Calocedrus and Thuja found in the Northern Hemisphere. In the past, Calocedrus was sometimes considered part of Libocedrus. Recent studies have confirmed that they are not as closely related as previously thought. The name "Libocedrus" means teardrop cedar, possibly referring to the resin drops produced by these trees.

Pilgerodendron is a type of conifer tree that belongs to the cypress family Cupressaceae. It is unique because it only has one species, called Pilgerodendron uviferum. This tree is found in the Valdivian temperate rainforests and Magellanic subpolar forests in southern Chile and southwestern Argentina. It grows in the region between 40 and 55 degrees south latitude in Tierra del Fuego, making it the southernmost conifer in the world. Pilgerodendron is part of a group called subfamily Callitroideae, which includes several distinct genera from the southern hemisphere that are connected to the Antarctic flora.
Cypress-pine is the name given to three closely related types of conifer trees that belong to the cypress family Cupressaceae.

question: Who was born earlier, Emma Bull or Virginia Woolf?
pos: Emma Bull, an American author born on December 13, 1954, writes science fiction and fantasy novels. neg: The Mark on the Wall is Virginia Woolf's first published story. It was first published in 1917 in a collection of short stories by Virginia and her husband, Leonard Woolf, called Two Stories. Later, it was included in another collection called Monday or Tuesday, published in New York in 1921.

"Orlando: A Biography" is a novel written by Virginia Woolf and was first published on October 11, 1928. The story is a lively and humorous tale inspired by the dramatic family history of Woolf's close friend and lover, the poet and novelist Vita Sackville-West. It is considered one of Woolf's most popular novels and is a satirical look at the history of English literature. The book follows the adventures of a poet who changes gender from male to female and lives for centuries, interacting with important figures from English literary history. Regarded as a feminist classic, the novel has been extensively analyzed by scholars in the fields of women's writing, gender studies, and transgender studies.

Rev Dr Jane de Gay is a British academic and lecturer known for her expertise on Virginia Woolf. Her contributions have been acknowledged by the Virginia Woolf Society of Great Britain. Additionally, she has co-edited four books on gender and theatre, such as Languages of Theatre Shaped by Women with Lizbeth Goodman.

Freshwater is a chamber opera with two acts composed by Andy Vores. It is based on a 1929 comic play by Virginia Woolf. Quentin Bell, Woolf's nephew and executor, helped Vores create the opera by sharing an earlier version of the text that inspired parts of the libretto.

Summary: "The Duchess and the Jeweller" is a short story by Virginia Woolf that delves into the inner thoughts and actions of a greedy jeweller. Woolf highlights how corrupt individuals often act selfishly without remorse. The story was first published in British Harper's Bazaar Magazine in April 1938 and later included in the collection A Haunted House and Other Short Stories in 1944 after Woolf's death.

Moments of Being is a book of personal essays written by Virginia Woolf that were published after her death. The essays were discovered in her husband's papers and used by Quentin Bell in his biography of Woolf in 1972. Jeanne Schulkind edited the essays for publication in 1976, with a second edition released in 1985. The original writings are now kept at Sussex University and the British Library in London.

Jane Marcus was a feminist literary scholar who studied women writers from the Modernist era, like Virginia Woolf, Rebecca West, and Nancy Cunard. She focused on the social and political aspects of their work, especially highlighting feminist, pacifist, and socialist themes that had been overlooked by previous critics. Marcus's interpretations of Woolf's writing challenged traditional views and are now widely accepted in the academic community, despite facing criticism and opposition when she first presented them.

A diplomatic mission, also known as a foreign mission, is a group of people representing one country or organization in another country. A diplomatic bag, also called a diplomatic pouch, is a special container that is legally protected and used to carry official letters or items between a diplomatic mission and its home government or other official entities. The key point is that a diplomatic bag is immune from being searched or taken away as long as it is clearly marked as diplomatic, as stated in the 1961 Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations. It can only hold items for official use and is often accompanied by a diplomatic courier, who also has immunity from being arrested or detained.
