Dover is the county seat of Strafford County and is known for being home to Wentworth-Douglass Hospital, the Woodman Institute Museum, and the Children's Museum of New Hampshire.

Woodsville is a small community in Grafton County, New Hampshire, located where the Connecticut River meets the Ammonoosuc River. In 2010, it had a population of 1,126. Even though the official county seat is now North Haverhill, the county courthouse used to be in Woodsville, so it was considered the county seat. Now, the county buildings are located between Woodsville and North Haverhill.

Hampden County is a county in Massachusetts, USA. It is not run by the government and is located in the Pioneer Valley. In 2010, it had a population of 463,490 people. The main city in the county is Springfield, which is also the largest city in the Connecticut River Valley and serves as its economic and cultural center. Hampden County was created in 1812 when it split from Hampshire County. This happened because Springfield was growing faster than Northampton, which was the traditional county seat of Hampshire County. The county was named after John Hampden. Hampshire County is to the north, Berkshire County is to the west, Worcester County is to the east, and Litchfield County, Hartford County, and Tolland County in Connecticut are to the south.

Carroll County is a county in New Hampshire, USA. It has a population of 47,818, making it the third least populated county in the state. The county seat is Ossipee. It was established in 1840, with towns taken from Strafford County. The county is named after Charles Carroll of Carrollton, the last signer of the Declaration of Independence, who passed away in 1832.

The Gardnerville Branch Jail is an old jail located at 1440 Courthouse St. in Gardnerville, Nevada. It was built in 1910 and was the only jail in Douglas County from 1910 to 1915. Before 1910, the county's jail was in Genoa, the county seat. But because Gardnerville was far from Genoa, they had to keep prisoners in the local judge's granary, which was not suitable for holding them. The community asked the county to build a new jail. However, leaders in Minden, who wanted to move the county seat to their town, opposed the idea, thinking Gardnerville was trying to become the county seat. Despite this, the county agreed to build the new jail. The first prisoners were housed there even before construction was complete because the Genoa jail had burned down. One prisoner had to be chained to a post briefly until the new jail was ready for him. The jail was used until 1915 when Minden became the county seat and opened its own jail.

Lempster is a town in New Hampshire, USA, located in Sullivan County. It had a population of 1,154 people according to the 2010 census. The town has two main areas: the town center known as Lempster village, and the village of East Lempster.

question: The Album Against the Wind was the 11th Album of a Rock singer Robert C Seger born may 6 1945. What was the Rock singers stage name ?
pos: Robert Clark Seger, born on May 6, 1945, is an American musician who sings, writes songs, plays the guitar, and piano. He started his career in the 1960s in Detroit, performing with different bands like Bob Seger and the Last Heard and Bob Seger System. In the early 1970s, he changed his band name to just Bob Seger and later formed the Silver Bullet Band in 1973 with musicians from Detroit. His big breakthrough came in 1976 with the album "Live Bullet," recorded live in Detroit. Seger's most successful studio album, "Night Moves," was released the same year. He often collaborated with the Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section from Alabama on his popular songs and albums.

Against the Wind is Bob Seger's eleventh album, and his fourth with the Silver Bullet Band. It came out in February 1980 and is his only album to reach number one on the Billboard Top LPs chart. It stayed at the top for six weeks, surpassing Pink Floyd's The Wall.
neg: Bob Seger released his seventeenth studio album, Ride Out, on October 14, 2014. He had initially said it might be his last album, but he surprised fans by announcing a new album called I Knew You When, which will be released on November 17, 2017.

Despina Vandi released an album called 10 H.M. (Short for 10 Hronia Mazi, Greek: 10 Χρόνια Μαζί; English: 10 Years Together) on December 6, 2007. This album marks her 12th release since the start of her career and her 10th collaboration with Phoebus. It is her first album with new songs since Stin Avli Tou Paradisou in 2004. The album celebrates her 10-year partnership with Phoebus and includes a title track dedicated to this milestone. It consists of three CDs: the first CD features pop/rock songs, the second CD contains Modern Laika songs, and the third CD offers remixes of her older songs. Phoebus wrote and produced all the songs on the album, which was released by Heaven Music and sponsored by WIND Hellas.

Gary Cherone is an American rock singer and songwriter born on July 26, 1961. He is famous for being the lead singer of the band Extreme and briefly fronting Van Halen for their 11th album and tour. He has also released music as a solo artist. In 2007, he got back together with Extreme.

Mark Britten, also known as The Chinaman, is an American comedian from Arlington, Texas. He has been performing stand-up comedy for ten years, using material from his own background to poke fun at ethnic stereotypes. Born to a Chinese-American mother and a Caucasian father, he incorporates his dysfunctional upbringing into his act. Known for his voice impersonations, rock singer parodies, and humorous stories about cultural stereotypes, Britten has been described by the Austin Chronicle as a comic with the charisma of a rock star. He is a member of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

Freudiana was supposed to be the 11th album by The Alan Parsons Project. However, during its creation, Eric Woolfson disagreed with Alan Parsons on the direction of the album. Woolfson then decided to transform it into a rock opera and released it as Freudiana. This album is often seen as the unofficial 11th album of The Alan Parsons Project by their fans. After this, Alan Parsons pursued a solo career and released his own album Try Anything Once in 1993, which carried on musically from his previous work on 1987's Gaudi.

Anggun has released a total of ten studio albums, two soundtrack albums, three greatest hits albums, seven single compilations, thirty-eight singles, and twenty music videos throughout her career. She started performing at the age of seven and recorded a children's album two years later. Her first studio album, Dunia Aku Punya, was released in 1986 but did not do well commercially. Anggun gained popularity with the success of her single Mimpi, which was later recognized as one of the top 150 Indonesian songs. She continued to release more singles and albums like Anak Putih Abu Abu, Nocturno, and Anggun C. Sasmi... Lah!!!, establishing herself as a successful rock singer in Indonesia during the early 1990s. In 1993, at the age of nineteen, she became the youngest Indonesian singer to start her own record company, Bali Cipta Records. Anggun had sold over four million albums in Indonesia by that time.

Bob Seger's album "Stranger in Town" was released in May 1978. It was his second album with the Silver Bullet Band. Half of the songs were backed by the Silver Bullet Band, while the other half were backed by the Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section.

"Heaven Knows" is a rock song by English singer Robert Plant. It was the first single from his 1988 album "Now and Zen." The song reached number 33 on the UK singles chart and number 1 on the Billboard Album Rock Tracks chart. This was Plant's third rock song to reach number one, after "Other Arms" in 1983 and "Little by Little" in 1985.

question: Rostker v. Goldberg held that the practice of what way of filling armed forces vacancies was consitutional?
pos: In the case of Rostker v. Goldberg in 1981, the United States Supreme Court ruled that it was okay for only men to be required to sign up for the draft. The decision came after a lot of discussions and debates in Congress, where the law was made to apply only to men. Some lawyers, like Robert L. Goldberg, argued that this was unfair and unconstitutional. However, the Supreme Court, in a 6-3 decision, said that the law was not breaking any rules about equal rights and that it would stay the same for men only.

The draft, also known as conscription, has been used by the U.S. government in four major conflicts: the American Civil War, World War I, World War II, and the Cold War (including the Korean and Vietnam Wars). The draft was first introduced in 1940 during peacetime through the Selective Training and Service Act. It continued until 1973, where men were drafted to serve in the military when there weren't enough volunteers. The draft was later replaced by an all-volunteer military, but the Selective Service System still exists as a backup plan. All male civilians aged 18 to 25 must register in case the draft is needed again in the future.
neg: The 2010 Kiev Victory Day Parade took place on May 9, 2010 in Kiev to celebrate the 65th anniversary of the Soviet Union's victory in the Great Patriotic War. General of the Army Ivan Svyda oversaw the parade, while Colonel General Gennady Vorobyov led it. President of Ukraine Viktor Yanukovych gave a speech at the event. The parade included 2,500 troops from the Ukrainian Armed Forces, as well as participants from Russia and Belarus. Additionally, 17 military orchestras, directed by Major General Volodymyr Derkach, performed during the parade.

One Rank One Pension (OROP) is a demand from Indian armed forces and veterans for equal pensions for individuals of the same rank and length of service, regardless of when they retired. This demand stems from a decision made by the Indian National Congress government in 1973 to reduce armed forces pensions by 20-40% and increase civilian pensions by 20%, without consulting the armed forces. This decision was made shortly after the retirement of Field Marshal SHFJ Manekshaw and the victory in the 1971 Bangladesh war.

The Chief of the Defence Staff (CDS) is the second highest-ranking member of the Canadian Armed Forces, after the commander-in-chief. They lead the Armed Forces Council and are in charge of commanding, controlling, and managing the forces, as well as developing military strategies, plans, and needs. The CDS is a senior member from one of the three main branches of the Canadian Armed Forces. Jonathan Vance has been serving as the CDS since July 17, 2015.

The military parade on September 16th in Mexico City is a yearly event that celebrates Mexican Independence Day. It has been a tradition since the late 19th century when the Mexican Armed Forces became more professional in the 20th century. The parade is held in the Zócalo and is the largest of all the parades that take place across Mexico on this day. The President of Mexico leads the parade as the Supreme Commander of the Armed Forces, and it is also attended by government officials, military personnel, police officers, veterans, and members of the public. The event is broadcast on TV, the Internet, and radio, making it one of the most significant events of the year. Participants include members of the Mexican Armed Forces and the Federal Police.

Fernando Tapias Stahelin was a retired General in the Colombian Armed Forces. He held various important positions during his career, including Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff for four years (1998-2002) under President Andres Pastrana. He later served as Colombia's ambassador to the Dominican Republic from 2002 to 2004 and as Deputy Minister of Defense from 2009 to 2010 under President Alvaro Uribe. Stahelin spent 41 years in the military, rising through the ranks to become the General Commander of the Colombian Armed Forces.

The Military Covenant, also known as the Armed Forces Covenant, is a concept introduced in 2000 in the UK to describe the shared responsibilities between the country and its Armed Forces. It is not a legally binding agreement but is highly respected within the military. The term is used to assess if the government and society have fulfilled their duty to support military personnel.

Armed Forces Day in Poland is celebrated on 15 August each year to honor the victory over Soviet Russia in the Battle of Warsaw in 1920. This day also coincides with the Day of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary. The celebration includes military parades, equipment displays, and tributes by all branches of the Polish Armed Forces nationwide. The main event takes place in Warsaw, where a large military parade is held. The holiday was initially celebrated in the Second Republic but was stopped during the communist era and later reinstated in 1992.

In June 1941, President Roosevelt created the Fair Employment Practice Committee (FEPC) through Executive Order 8802. This was a significant step in supporting the rights of African-Americans, marking the most important federal action for their rights between Reconstruction and the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The order stated that the federal government would not discriminate in hiring based on race, color, creed, or national origin. The FEPC enforced this by prohibiting discriminatory hiring in the federal government and in companies with federal contracts. As a result, many African-Americans and women gained access to better jobs and higher pay. The issue of racial equality became more prominent during World War II, with the Army and Navy being segregated since the Civil War. Despite the order, some branches like the Marine Corps found ways to avoid integration until 1942. African-American leaders, including A. Philip Randolph, pushed for full integration into the armed forces, including combat roles and service in the Navy, Marine Corps, and Army Air Forces. Although Roosevelt agreed to this demand, he did not take action to implement it, leaving the task to his successor, Harry S. Truman, who eventually desegregated the armed forces.

question: Handi-Snacks are a snack food product line sold by what American multinational confectionery, food, and beverage company that is based in Illinois?
pos: Handi-Snacks are a type of snack made by Mondelez International. They come in a two-compartment package with one side for spread and the other for crackers. The package also includes a red plastic spreader for the spread.

Mondelez International, Inc., also known as Mondelēz, is a big American company that makes candy, food, and drinks. It is located in Illinois and has about 107,000 employees worldwide. The company includes all the snack and food brands that used to belong to Kraft Foods Inc before they separated in October 2012. The name "Mondelez" was chosen in 2012 and comes from the words "mundus" (which means "world" in Latin) and "delez" (a stand-in for "delicious").
neg: Canyon Creek Food Company is a food processing company located in Edmonton, Alberta. They offer fresh soups and other prepared food products for health-conscious consumers. The company supplies its fresh food products to grocery stores, restaurants, and various food service establishments across Canada.

Robert's American Gourmet Food is a snack food company in the United States. It was started by businessman Robert Ehrlich in 1986. The company is famous for its snack called Pirate's Booty, which is sold in most supermarkets in the United States. Robert's American Gourmet focused on making snacks for people who care about their health.

Rewrapped is a cooking show on Food Network that started in 2014. Hosted by Joey Fatone, the show has three chefs who compete in challenges. First, they have to recreate a popular snack, and then they have to come up with a new dish using that snack as the main ingredient. The show is inspired by another show called Unwrapped, and its host, Marc Summers, is the Head Judge. Each episode also has a judge from the company that makes the snack, as well as a third judge from the food industry, like a chef or food critic.

PepsiCo is a big American company that makes food, snacks, and drinks. It is based in Purchase, New York. PepsiCo started in 1965 when Pepsi-Cola and Frito-Lay joined together. Over the years, PepsiCo has grown and now sells many different food and drink brands. Some of the famous brands it owns are Tropicana and Gatorade.

Snackbox Food Holdings Co, Ltd is a Korean company that specializes in making lunch snacks. It was founded in 2004 and is located in Mokdong-Ri Gyoha-Eup Paju Gyeonggi-do, Korea. The company provides various snack food options for home parties, such as fruit lunch packs, salads, yogurt, and sandwiches. As of January 2006, Snack Box has around 25 employees.

Snack Foods Limited is an Australian company that makes snack foods. It was created on November 25, 1999, and was owned by Arnott's Biscuits Holdings Pty Ltd., which is a part of the American Campbell Soup Company. Snack Foods Limited owns Snack Brands Australia, one of the biggest salted snack food companies in Australia. In April 2008, Campbell Arnott's sold Arnott’s Snackfoods to The Real McCoy Snackfood Co, and now the company is called Snack Brands Australia.

Deep Fried Peanuts are a snack made by frying peanuts in oil. You can eat the whole snack, including the shell and nut. Frying the peanuts doesn't affect the taste or texture of the nut inside, but it does change the flavor and texture of the shell, especially if seasonings are added to make it tastier.

Twisties are a popular cheese curl snack made from corn, mainly found in Australia and other countries like Papua New Guinea, New Caledonia, Vanuatu, Fiji, Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore, Brunei, and Mauritius. They were first introduced in 1950 by the General Foods Corporation and are now owned by The Smith's Snackfood Company. Smith's was bought by Frito-Lay in 1998, which is a part of the American company PepsiCo. In Malaysia, Twisties are made by Mondelēz International, and in Thailand, they are produced by Lay's, also owned by PepsiCo. In some countries like New Zealand, Malta, and Italy, Twisties are sold under different brand names.

question: What was the name of a woman from the book titled "Their Lives: The Women Targeted by the Clinton Machine " and was also a former white house intern?
pos: "Their Lives: The Women Targeted by the Clinton Machine" is a book written by Candice E. Jackson. It was published by conservative publisher World Ahead Publishing on May 31, 2005. The book tells the stories of seven women who had encounters with Bill Clinton: Monica Lewinsky, Paula Jones, Gennifer Flowers, Kathleen Willey, Elizabeth Gracen, Juanita Broaddrick, and Sally Perdue.
Monica Samille Lewinsky, born on July 23, 1973, is an American activist, TV personality, fashion designer, and a former intern at the White House.
neg: Sheila Cavanagh is a sociology professor at York University. She focuses on gender and sexuality, particularly queer, cultural, and psychoanalytic theories. Cavanagh is involved in various projects, such as editing a special issue on transgender and psychoanalysis for Transgender Studies Quarterly and completing her third book on transgender topics. She has also co-edited books on skin, culture, and psychoanalysis. Cavanagh has received recognition for her books on school sex scandals and queer pedagogies, as well as on gender, sexuality, and hygiene. She has also written and performed a play called Queer Bathroom Monologues. Cavanagh has published in many international journals and given keynote speeches at conferences. She teaches courses on gender sociology, sexuality studies, feminist theory, and queer theory. Additionally, she has been featured in documentaries about education and queer science.

Gregory Bestor Greg Craig, born on March 4, 1945, is an American lawyer who worked as the White House Counsel for President Barack Obama from 2009 to 2010. Before that, he was a lawyer at the law firm Williams & Connolly in Washington, D.C., where he represented many important clients. Craig also worked in the White House under President Bill Clinton, helping to defend Clinton during his impeachment proceedings. Additionally, he advised Senator Edward Kennedy and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright.

"The White House Doctor: My Patients Were Presidents – A Memoir" is a book written by Connie Mariano. She was the first female military physician to serve as the President's doctor, the first woman to lead the White House medical unit, and the first Filipino-American rear admiral in the US Navy. The book, with an introduction by Bill Clinton, shares insights into the personal lives of three Presidents (George H.W. Bush, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush) and three First Ladies (Barbara Bush, Hillary Clinton, and Laura Bush) she cared for during her time as a White House physician. It provides a unique glimpse into the private lives of these political figures at the White House.

In February 2012, former White House intern Mimi Alford published a book called "Once Upon a Secret: My Affair with President John F. Kennedy and Its Aftermath." The book tells the story of her secret relationship with President Kennedy from June 1962 to July 1963. Alford kept this affair hidden for almost 50 years until some information was revealed in a 2003 biography of Kennedy by Robert Dallek.

Eric Schultz is a senior advisor to former President Barack Obama and the founder of Schultz Group. He previously worked as a White House Principal Deputy Press Secretary and special assistant to President Obama. Schultz is known for being the go-to strategist during crises for White House officials. He joined the White House in 2011 to handle Congressional oversight investigations and later became the White House Deputy Press Secretary. In this role, Schultz is known for diffusing tensions with humor and being persistent in delivering his message. Former White House Communications Director Jen Psaki likened Schultz to fictional crisis manager Olivia Pope, emphasizing his reliability during crises. Former White House Senior Advisor Valerie Jarrett praised Schultz for his wise counsel and the President's trust in his judgment.
William H. Ginsburg, who was an American lawyer, became famous for his role in representing Monica Lewinsky during the scandal involving her relationship with President Bill Clinton in 1998.

Mark D. Fabiani is an American political strategist who has worked in various high-profile roles. He has served as a crisis management expert, Deputy Mayor of Los Angeles, and chief of staff to Mayor Tom Bradley. Fabiani has also worked as a White House lawyer and spokesman, notably as special counsel to President Bill Clinton and as a legal spokesperson for the Clinton White House. In addition, he was the head of communications for the Gore presidential campaign in 2000 and held senior positions at the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Department of Justice.

The Lewinsky scandal was a situation in American politics where President Bill Clinton, who was 49 years old at the time, had a sexual relationship with a 22-year-old White House intern named Monica Lewinsky. This affair happened between 1995 and 1996 but became public in 1998. President Clinton initially denied the relationship during a televised speech. However, after further investigation, he faced charges of lying under oath and was impeached by the U.S. House of Representatives in 1998. After a 21-day Senate trial, he was found not guilty of perjury and obstruction of justice. Additionally, a judge found him in contempt of court for giving misleading testimony in another case and fined him $90,000. As a result, his law license was suspended in Arkansas for five years, and he was later disbarred from presenting cases in front of the United States Supreme Court.

question: When was the American lawyer, lobbyist and political consultant who was a senior member of the presidential campaign of Donald Trump born?
pos: Paul John Manafort Jr. is an American lawyer, lobbyist, and political consultant. He worked for various Republican presidential campaigns before joining Donald Trump's team in 2016. Manafort co-founded a lobbying firm in Washington, D.C. in 1980 with Charles R. Black Jr. and Roger J. Stone, and later added Peter G. Kelly to the team.

On June 9, 2016, a meeting took place at Trump Tower in New York City. It involved three key members of Donald Trump's presidential campaign - Donald Trump Jr., Jared Kushner, and Paul Manafort - along with at least five other individuals, including Russian lawyer Natalia Veselnitskaya. The meeting was set up by Rob Goldstone, a publicist and friend of Trump, on behalf of his client, singer-songwriter Emin Agalarov. This meeting was later revealed to U.S. government officials when Kushner updated his security clearance form.
neg: Donald Trump is a segment from the HBO news satire show Last Week Tonight with John Oliver. It aired on February 28, 2016, during the third season when Trump was a leading candidate for the Republican Party's presidential nomination. In this 22-minute segment, comedian John Oliver talks about Trump's 2016 campaign, his business background, his different political stances, and his unsuccessful business endeavors. Oliver also mentions that the Trump family name was once Drumpf before being changed.

Brad Parscale is an American digital media and political strategist who worked on Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign. He started by creating websites and managing digital media strategies for the Trump Organization in 2011. Trump later hired Parscale to work on his campaign website, and eventually, Parscale became the digital media director for the campaign. He was in charge of online fundraising, digital media strategy, and traditional media placements like radio and TV. In 2017, Parscale helped launch America First Policies, a non-profit supporting Trump's agenda.

Donald Trump in music refers to songs, albums, and bands that mention or are inspired by Donald Trump and his various business ventures like Trump Tower, his TV show, hotel chain, and casinos. Before his successful presidential campaign in 2016, over 200 songs referenced Trump between 1989 and 2013. Since becoming president, Trump's influence in hip-hop music has been compared to Ronald Reagan's impact on hardcore punk in the 1980s.

Protests against Donald Trump, known as anti-Trump protests, have been happening in the United States and other countries since he started his presidential campaign in 2016. These protests show disagreement with Trump's campaign messages, his election victory, his inauguration, and some of his presidential decisions. The protests have taken different forms, like walk-outs, closing businesses, signing petitions, and holding rallies, demonstrations, or marches, especially after Trump became president. While many protests have been peaceful, there have been instances where protesters have damaged property and harmed Trump supporters.

Donald Trump, a real estate magnate from New York, decided to run for president in 2000 as a member of the Reform Party. Even though he had never been in an elected position before, he was well-known for his business ventures and public statements. Trump had thought about running for president in 1988 as a Republican but decided against it. In 2000, Minnesota Governor Jesse Ventura convinced Trump to run for the Reform Party nomination. The Reform Party was facing internal issues despite having been successful in the 1996 election with Ross Perot. Trump's campaign coincided with that of Pat Buchanan, a conservative commentator, whom Trump criticized during the campaign.

Anthony Fabrizio, an American Republican pollster and strategist born in 1960, is the main figure in the company Fabrizio, Lee & Associates. He has worked as a pollster for various political campaigns, including Donald Trump's 2016 Presidential campaign, Bob Dole's 1996 Presidential campaign, Rand Paul's U.S. Senate and 2016 Presidential campaign, and Rick Perry's 2012 Presidential campaign. Additionally, he provided polling services for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce during the 2014 midterm elections.

David Urban is an American lobbyist, political operative, and commentator known for his work on Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign. He played a key role in organizing the 2016 Republican National Convention and was a senior advisor in the campaign's successful push to win Pennsylvania. There were reports in November 2016 that Urban was being considered for positions such as chair of the Republican National Committee and White House Deputy Chief of Staff. In May 2017, it was reported that Trump was thinking about appointing Urban as the new White House Chief of Staff, replacing Reince Priebus.

During his presidential campaign, Donald Trump made illegal immigration a major focus. He promised to build a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border and proposed various changes to immigration policies. Trump wanted to limit legal immigration and guest-worker visas, including pausing green card approvals to reduce high immigration levels. He also had varying stances on H-1B visas, ultimately seeming to oppose them by July 2016. Additionally, Trump disputed the official estimate of 11-12 million illegal immigrants in the U.S., claiming the actual number was much higher, around 30-34 million.

question: In what year was the novel that Lourenço Mutarelli based "Nina" on based first published?
pos: Crime and Punishment is a novel written by the Russian author Fyodor Dostoyevsky. It was first published in 1866 in a literary journal called The Russian Messenger, released in monthly parts before being published as a complete book. This novel is one of Dostoyevsky's major works, written after he returned from a five-year exile in Siberia. It is often seen as the first significant novel of his later writing career.

In addition to comic books, Mutarelli has also created plays, books, and illustrated and animated sequences for the 2004 movie Nina. The movie was based on the novel Crime and Punishment by Dostoyevsky.
neg: The Golden Hour is a children's book written by Maiya Williams. It was published in 2004 and is the first book in a series about time travel called the Golden Hour series. The story follows Rowan Popplewell and his sister, Nina, who are dealing with their mother's death. They end up traveling back in time to the French Revolution.

"Quando Eu Era Vivo" (English: When I Was Alive) is a Brazilian drama-thriller movie from 2014 directed by Marco Dutra. It is based on the novel "A Arte de Produzir Efeito Sem Causa" by Lourenço Mutarelli.

"Spirit of the Border" is a historical novel by Zane Grey, published in 1906. It is set in the late 18th century in the Ohio River Valley and follows the adventures of Lewis Wetzel, who fought against Native Americans to protect white settlements. The story also involves Moravian Church missionaries trying to convert Native Americans, and how two brothers' lives change when they reach the border. This novel is part of a trilogy, with "Betty Zane" being the first book and "The Last Trail" focusing on the life of Jonathan Zane, who was Grey's ancestor.

"Before We Say Goodbye," originally titled "Prima di Lasciarsi," is a novel by Gabriella Ambrosio published in 2004. The story is inspired by the 2002 Kiryat HaYovel supermarket bombing and follows the last moments of both the suicide bomber and her victims. Initially released in Italy by Nutrimenti, the book was later translated into English and published by Walker Books on August 2, 2010. It has also been translated into other languages like Arabic and Hebrew and has received support from Amnesty International.

"4 a.m." is the first novel written by Scottish author Nina de la Mer. It was released in the UK on August 26, 2011, by Myriad Editions, a publishing house located in Brighton. The book is based on the author's own experiences and research, exploring the rave culture of the 90s and the everyday life of British Army soldiers during peacetime.

The novel "Three Comrades" was written by the German author Erich Maria Remarque and first published in 1936. It is narrated by Robert Lohkamp, a character who has a cynical view of life due to his traumatic experiences during World War I. The story follows Robert and his friends Otto Köster and Gottfried Lenz as they run an auto-repair shop in Berlin in the late 1920s. Remarque wrote the novel while in exile, and it was first published in Dutch and then translated into English in 1937. The German edition was not published until 1951.

Summary: "Drained" (Portuguese: O Cheiro do Ralo) is a 2006 Brazilian dark comedy film adapted from a novel by Lourenço Mutarelli. Directed by Heitor Dhalia and starring Selton Mello, the film was produced by Geração Conteúdo, Primo Filmes, and RT Features.
"The Birds on the Trees" is a novel written by Nina Bawden in 1970. It tells the story of a middle-class English family whose 19-year-old son disappoints his parents.

question: Where are Teide National Park and Garajonay National Park located?
pos: Garajonay National Park is situated in the central and northern parts of La Gomera, one of the Canary Islands in Spain. Established as a national park in 1981, it was later recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1986. Covering an area of 40 square kilometers (15 square miles), the park spans across all six municipalities on the island.
Teide National Park is a protected area in Tenerife, which is one of the Canary Islands in Spain.
neg: Hermigua is a town in the northeastern part of La Gomera, which is one of the Canary Islands in Spain. It is situated 12 km northwest of the island's capital, San Sebastián de la Gomera. The southern part of the town is covered by the Garajonay National Park.

Crater Lake National Park is a park in southern Oregon that became a national park in 1902. It is the fifth-oldest national park in the United States and the only one in Oregon. The park includes the crater of Crater Lake, which was formed by the collapse of the volcano Mount Mazama, as well as the nearby hills and forests.

The Glacier National Park Fund was established in 1999 to raise money for Glacier National Park in West Glacier, Montana. The organization supports park projects in four main areas: preserving the park experience, providing educational programs, researching the park ecosystem, and preparing for the park's 2010 Centennial year. The fund has supported various studies, including one in 2007 on human and bear aversion techniques and another in 2009 to learn more about the Bighorn Sheep in the park. The fund's official mascot is named Billy Bowman.

The Roque Cinchado is a famous rock formation on the island of Tenerife in Spain. It is located in the Teide National Park, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The rock is near the volcano called Teide, right in the center of the island. The Roque Cinchado is one of the tallest rock formations in the world because the park itself is over 2000 meters high.

Adenocarpus viscosus is a shrubby plant that produces flowers and belongs to the legume family Fabaceae. It is native to the Canary Islands and is commonly called Codeso del Pico there. This plant grows at elevations above 1800 meters on two of the islands, La Palma and Tenerife. In Tenerife, it is a prominent shrub in Teide National Park and can also be found in parts of Corona Forestal Nature Park and Reserva Especial de las Palomas.

The Atma-energy Release Training Center, also called the Atman Foundation, was a new religious group that operated primarily in Tenerife and Germany. It started as a small offshoot of the Brahma Kumaris. The group gained attention when there were concerns raised by the police and media about a possible ritual suicide attempt in Teide National Park in Tenerife. Despite believing in an apocalyptic event, experts like religious studies scholar Georg Schmid and sociologist Massimo Introvigne clarified that the group did not plan to engage in mass suicide.

The Alpine National Park is a large park in Victoria, Australia, situated in the Central Highlands and Alpine regions. It covers an area of 646,000 hectares and is located northeast of Melbourne. This park is the biggest in Victoria and includes the higher parts of the Great Dividing Range, such as Mount Bogong, which is the highest point in Victoria at 1986 meters. The park also features subalpine woodland and grassland on the Bogong High Plains. Its northeastern boundary runs along the border with New South Wales, where it meets the Kosciuszko National Park. In 2008, the Alpine National Park was recognized as part of the Australian Alps National Parks and Reserves on the Australian National Heritage List.

North Cascades National Park is a large park in Washington state that is part of the North Cascades National Park Service Complex. It is surrounded by national wilderness areas and parks in British Columbia. The park is known for its rugged mountain peaks and it helps preserve parts of the North Cascades range.

question: How many copies of Roald Dahl's variation on a popular anecdote sold?

The Roald Dahl Children's Gallery is located on Church Street in Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire, England. This museum, dedicated to Roald Dahl, opened on November 23, 1996. Roald Dahl's short stories bibliography is a detailed list of all the short stories he wrote, with additional notes and explanations.

Roald Dahl Plass is a public area in Cardiff Bay, Wales, named after the author Roald Dahl. It is situated by the coast in the southern part of the city center. The Roald Dahl Treasury is a collection of stories by the children's author Roald Dahl. It was first published in the United Kingdom in 1997 by Puffin Books.

Roald Dahl's Willy Wonka is a musical that mixes parts of Roald Dahl's book Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and the 1971 movie Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory with new content. question: What occupation do Chris Menges and Aram Avakian share?

Second Best is a British film from 1994 that was produced by Sarah Radclyffe and directed by Chris Menges. The movie is based on a novel from 1991 with the same title by David Cook, who also wrote the screenplay for the film.

The movie "11 Harrowhouse" is a British film from 1974 directed by Aram Avakian. It was adapted by Charles Grodin from a novel by Gerald A. Browne, with the screenplay written by Jeffrey Bloom. The movie "End of the Road" was made in 1970. It was directed, co-written, and edited by Aram Avakian. The story is based on a novel by John Barth from 1958. The main actors in the film are Stacy Keach, James Earl Jones, and Harris Yulin.

A World Apart is a movie made in 1988 that speaks out against Apartheid. It was written by Shawn Slovo and directed by Chris Menges. The movie "Cops and Robbers" was made in 1973. It is a crime comedy film directed by Aram Avakian and written by Donald E. Westlake. Westlake later turned the story into a novel. The main actors are Cliff Gorman, who plays Tom, and Joseph Bologna, who plays Joe.

"Made in Britain" is a British TV play from 1982 written by David Leland and directed by Alan Clarke. It follows a 16-year-old racist skinhead named Trevor as he clashes with authority figures. The play was first shown on ITV on July 10, 1983, as part of a series by Leland called Tales Out of School. The aim was to realistically portray English working-class life without complicated plots or moral lessons. The play includes strong language, violence, racism, and a rebellious attitude. The use of the Steadicam by cinematographer Chris Menges helped create a fluid and gritty atmosphere in the play.

CrissCross is a drama movie from 1992. It was directed by Chris Menges and written by Scott Sommer, who also wrote the book the movie is based on. The movie features actors like Goldie Hawn, Arliss Howard, Keith Carradine, Steve Buscemi, and David Arnott.

question: Andrew Jaspan was the co-founder of what not-for-profit media outlet?
pos: Andrew Jaspan is a British-Australian journalist born on April 20, 1952. He is the co-founder of The Conversation, a non-profit website that provides analysis and news from universities and research institutions. Jaspan served as the Editor-in-Chief of The Conversation from its launch in March 2011 until March 2017.

The Conversation is a non-profit media organization that shares content from academics and researchers. It started in Australia in March 2011 and has since grown to include editions in the UK, US, Africa, France, and globally. The organization publishes all its content under a Creative Commons license. As of May 2017, it had 5.2 million monthly users on its website and reached 35 million people through republication of its content.
neg: Chicago Public Media is a non-profit media company in Chicago that is the main National Public Radio member organization for the city. It owns three educational FM broadcast stations and one FM translator. The company produces popular programs like Wait Wait... Don't Tell Me! for NPR stations, This American Life (distributed through PRX), and Sound Opinions (also distributed through PRX). Chicago Public Media is located at Navy Pier in Chicago.

State media, also known as state-owned media, refers to mass communication channels that are financially and editorially controlled by the government. These news outlets can be the only source of media or can coexist with privately-owned media companies.

An advice column is a section in a magazine or newspaper where readers can write in with their problems or questions, and an advice columnist provides answers or advice. This format can also be found online or on TV. The person giving advice is often called an agony aunt or agony uncle in British English. Originally, the advice columnist was seen as a wise and comforting older woman, which is why they were called an aunt.

990WBOB is a digital media and radio station located in Providence, Rhode Island. It was established in 2007 and has become a major player in the New England media market. This independent outlet has won the Providence Phoenix Best Blog Award twice and offers the latest news, sports, politics, and weather through its digital print and radio platform. With over 80,000 listeners in Rhode Island and access to over 200,000 homes across the country, 990WBOB is a popular choice for staying informed.

AMI is a non-profit media company that provides entertainment, information, and empowerment to Canadians who are blind or partially sighted. They run three broadcast services: AMI-tv and AMI-audio in English, and AMI-télé in French. AMI's goal is to create a platform for Canadians with disabilities to have their voices heard and their interests represented in the media.

14ymedio is the first independent online news source in Cuba. It was created on May 21, 2014, by Cuban blogger and activist Yoani Sánchez and journalist Reinaldo Escobar. They began with a team of 12 reporters aiming to provide a variety of news content. The publication covers news about Cuba and global events, including national and international politics, economics, culture, society, science and technology, and sports. It also features editorials, opinion pieces, and interviews.

The Vatileaks scandal involved leaked Vatican documents that revealed possible corruption and blackmail of homosexual clergy by people outside the Church. Italian journalist Gianluigi Nuzzi published letters from Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò, who was worried about being moved to a different position after exposing corruption that led to higher contract prices for the Holy See. The scandal's name, VatiLeaks, is a reference to WikiLeaks, a media organization that aims to share important news and information with the public.

EvidenceNetwork.ca makes media content about public policy topics for mainstream media. They connect journalists with policy experts to give them access to unbiased, evidence-based information. Since 2011, they have published hundreds of original articles in major Canadian media outlets each year. Their content has been reprinted over 3700 times across various media outlets. All of their content is licensed under Creative Commons.

question: Which American film director hosted the 18th Independent Spirit Awards in 2002?

Since 2006, the trophy has been redesigned to show a bird with spread wings perched on a pole, with the shoestrings from the old design wrapped around it.
The Independent Spirit Award for Best Cinematography is a prize given out each year by the Independent Spirit Awards, a non-profit group that supports independent films and filmmakers.

Silent Light is a 2007 film written and directed by Carlos Reygadas. It is set in a Mennonite colony near Cuauhtémoc, Chihuahua State, Northern Mexico. The movie follows the story of a married Mennonite man who falls in love with another woman, which puts his standing in the conservative community at risk. The characters speak in Plautdietsch, the Low German dialect of the Mennonites. The film was Mexico's submission for the Best Foreign Language Oscar at the 80th Academy Awards, but it didn't make the final list. It was also nominated for Best Foreign Film at the 24th Independent Spirit Awards and received nine nominations, including in major categories, at the Ariel Awards, Mexico's national film awards.

The nominees for the 32nd Independent Spirit Awards in 2017 were revealed by Film Independent, the organization that puts on the event, on November 22, 2016. Additionally, Sundance Now streamed the Spirit Awards online at the same time as the TV broadcast, and an on-demand version was later available on Sundance Now.

In 2012, the Independent Spirit Awards celebrated its 28th annual event. The nominees were revealed on November 27, 2012, and the winners were announced on February 23, 2013, at a ceremony hosted by Andy Samberg.
The Independent Spirit Award for Best Editing is a yearly award presented by the Independent Spirit Awards, a non-profit group that supports independent films and filmmakers.

The Independent Spirit Award for Best First Feature is a yearly award given out as part of the Independent Spirit Awards. It is typically presented to the director(s) and producer(s) of a film. The award is specifically for the director's first feature film, not the producer's. As a result, producers can receive multiple nominations for the award.

Mihai Mălaimare Jr. is a Romanian cinematographer born in 1975. He is the son of a Romanian actor and former politician. Mălaimare Jr. has worked as a cinematographer on films by directors such as Francis Ford Coppola and Paul Thomas Anderson. In 2008, he was nominated for Best Cinematography at the 24th Independent Spirit Awards for his work on the film Youth Without Youth.

question: Where does the hotel and casino located in which Bill Cosby's third album was recorded?

Disco Bill (1977) is an album by Bill Cosby that pokes fun at the disco trend of the late 1970s. It was his fifth and final musical comedy album. Like his previous work, Cosby mentioned that he came up with a lot of the content on the spot.

The theme song for The Bill Cosby Show, called "Hikky Burr," was released as a popular single in 1969. It was written and performed by Quincy Jones and Bill Cosby and is known for its silly lyrics. Bill Cosby released an album called "At Last Bill Cosby Really Sings," which is his fifth music album. It was released on Partee Records, distributed by Stax Records. Bill Cosby's first album, "Bill Cosby is a Very Funny Fellow...Right!" was recorded live at The Bitter End nightclub in New York City's Greenwich Village in early 1963. The album features three sketches about Noah.

Bill Cosby released his 17th comedy album titled "Bill's Best Friend." Some of the jokes from this album were also used in the movie and album called "Himself." Bill Cosby co-wrote and released a funny song called "Yes, Yes, Yes" in 1976. It was part of his album, Bill Cosby Is Not Himself These Days.

question: Do the drinks Gibson and Zurracapote both contain gin?
pos: The Gibson is a cocktail made with gin, vermouth, and a pickled onion garnish. The first known recipe for the Gibson was published in 1908 in a book called The World's Drinks And How To Mix Them by William Boothby.

Zurracapote, also known as zurra, is a well-liked Spanish mixed drink that is similar to sangría. It is made by mixing red wine with fruits like peaches and lemons, along with sugar and cinnamon. The mixture is typically left to sit for a few days, but some variations include adding other alcoholic drinks, juices, and fruit extracts. The end product is a mildly alcoholic beverage, reminiscent of sangría.
neg: Phillips Distilling Company, founded in 1912 in Minneapolis, Minnesota, is a well-known distillery that produces a variety of liquors. Some of their popular brands include UV Vodka and Prairie Vodka, which are gaining popularity nationwide. In addition to vodka, gin, rum, Canadian whisky, brandy, and various flavors of schnapps, Phillips has also introduced specialty drinks like Revel Stoke Spiced Whisky, Gin-Ka, Phillips Union Whiskey, and a series of 100 proof schnapps. They also offer handcrafted and organic Prairie Vodka, and an herbal liqueur called Black 100, known for its high alcohol content and dark color.

Flaming drinks are cocktails or mixed drinks that have strong alcohol in them, which can catch fire when lit before drinking. The alcohol can be mixed in the drink or poured on top to create a fiery effect. The flames are mostly for show, but they can also change the taste of the drink by enhancing certain flavors or adding a toasted taste to it.

Energy shots are a type of energy drink that have a small amount of caffeine in a concentrated liquid form. Unlike regular energy drinks that come in cans or bottles, energy shots are typically sold in small 50ml bottles. They can have the same amount of caffeine, vitamins, and other ingredients as larger energy drinks, making them a more potent and concentrated option. There are also micro shot energy drinks available, which contain even less liquid, usually only 1-5 teaspoons.

CytoSport is an American company that makes sports nutrition products in Benicia, California. They offer a variety of protein-enhanced powders, shakes, and bars. One of their popular products is Muscle Milk, a protein supplement that comes in a ready-to-drink form. Muscle Milk is a non-dairy beverage that is free of trans fats, lactose, and high fructose corn syrup. It is also shelf-stable. Muscle Milk focuses on taste, offering flavors like banana, milk chocolate, and vanilla that remind consumers of milkshakes. The product comes in different sizes and formats, including powders, and can be found in convenience stores next to regular energy and sports drinks.

Here is a list of soft drinks based on where the brand comes from. Soft drinks are beverages that usually have water, sweeteners, and flavors. The sweetener can be sugar, high-fructose corn syrup, fruit juice, sugar substitutes (in diet drinks), or a mix of these. They may also have caffeine, colors, preservatives, and other additives.

A soft drink is a fizzy drink made with carbonated water, sugar or other sweeteners, and flavorings. It can also have caffeine, colors, preservatives, and other additives. Sugar substitutes are used in diet versions of soft drinks.

Rubicon Drinks Ltd, previously known as Rubicon Products Ltd, is a company in Milton Keynes, UK that makes exotic soft drinks. They offer a range of flavors, some with sugar or artificial sweeteners, available in both still and sparkling versions. In the UK, A.G. Barr plc bottles and distributes their drinks.

The gin pennant, also known as the gin flag or drinking pennant, is a flag used at sea. When it is raised on a ship, it signals to other ships' officers that they are welcome to come aboard for drinks.

question: In what month is the annual documentary film festival, that is presented by the fortnightly published British journal of literary essays, held?
pos: The London International Documentary Festival, also known as LIDF, happens every year in March and April. It is organized in partnership with the London Review of Books.
The London Review of Books (LRB) is a British magazine that publishes literary essays every two weeks.
neg: The International Documentary Film Festival Docville is a yearly event that takes place in Leuven, Belgium and showcases documentary films.

The Chagrin Documentary Film Festival is held every year in Chagrin Falls, Ohio. It started in 2010 with 93 films shown in different places around the village, and 1,800 people attended. In 2015, the festival had almost 7,000 attendees but fewer films, less than 70 in total.

The British Journal was an English newspaper that was published from September 22, 1722, to January 13, 1728. It was later known as the British Journal or The Censor from January 20, 1728, to November 23, 1730, and then as the British Journal or The Traveller from November 30, 1730, to March 20, 1731.

FreedomFilmFest, also called The KOMAS Freedom Film Festival (FFF), is Malaysia's first yearly documentary film festival. It was started in 2003 and focuses on the principles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR). The festival introduced a competition for documentary films in Malaysia, encouraging new filmmakers to create films based on their winning ideas.

Doc NYC is a yearly documentary film festival held in New York City. It was co-founded by Thom Powers and his wife Raphaela Neihausen. The festival is the largest of its kind in the country, featuring over 300 films and events with 200 special guests. It takes place over eight days in November at the IFC Center in the West Village, as well as the Cinépolis and SVA Theater in Chelsea.

The British Journal of Social Psychology is an academic journal that is reviewed by experts in the field before publication. It is published by Wiley-Blackwell on behalf of the British Psychological Society. The journal features research articles on various topics related to how people think and behave in social situations. These topics include social cognition, attitudes, group dynamics, social influence, relationships between different groups, self-perception, nonverbal communication, emotions, and how language affects social interactions. The journal was originally called the British Journal of Social and Clinical Psychology when it started in 1962, but changed its name to the current one in 1981. In 2010, it had an impact factor of 2.056, which is a measure of how influential the journal's articles are in the academic community.

Thomas Gordon was a Scottish writer who, along with John Trenchard, published a weekly periodical called The Independent Whig. They wrote a series of 144 essays known as Cato's Letters from 1720 to 1723, criticizing corruption and immorality in the British political system and warning against tyranny. These essays were later published as Essays on Liberty, Civil and Religious in the London Journal and the British Journal. Their writings greatly influenced the Commonwealth man tradition and the ideas of the Country Party. Gordon's ideas were significant in shaping republicanism in Britain and the American colonies leading up to the American Revolution. John Trenchard and Thomas Gordon, writing under the pseudonym Cato, are credited with creating a new form of republicanism in the early 18th century.

The New Haven Documentary Film Festival, also known as NHdocs, is an annual event that takes place in New Haven, Connecticut, usually over a weekend in June. The festival screens documentary films at locations like Yale University’s Whitney Humanities Center Auditorium and the New Haven Free Public Library. NHdocs focuses on showcasing documentaries made by filmmakers from the New Haven area and beyond. The festival was started in 2014 by co-founders Charles Musser, Gorman Bechard, Jacob Bricca, and Lisa Molomot, who wanted to create a sense of community among documentary filmmakers in the region. In its inaugural year, the festival featured documentaries by the four co-founders, three of which had recently been shown at the Big Sky Documentary Film Festival.

question: Tysons Galleria is located in what county?
pos: Tysons Galleria is a large shopping mall in Tysons Corner, McLean, Virginia. It has three levels and is owned by General Growth Properties. The mall is located at 2001 International Drive and is one of the biggest malls in the Washington metropolitan area.

McLean is a town in Northern Virginia, close to Washington, D.C. and the Central Intelligence Agency. It is a popular area for diplomats, businessmen, members of Congress, and government officials. McLean is known for its luxury homes and upscale shopping centers like Tysons Corner Center and Tysons Galleria. The town has historical significance, being the former home of Ethel Kennedy and Light-Horse Harry Lee. In 2015, McLean had a population of around 53,673 people. It is situated between the Potomac River and Vienna, with two of its zip codes, 22101 and 22102, being among the most expensive in Virginia and the U.S.
neg: Scott's Run Nature Preserve is a protected area in Fairfax County, Virginia, USA. It is located in McLean and is surrounded by Virginia State Route 193 to the south, Interstate 495 to the east, and the Potomac River to the north. The preserve covers 336 acres of woodland with Scott's Run stream running through its western side. The stream starts in Tysons Corner and flows into the Potomac River on the preserve's northwest side. The area is known for its eastern hemlocks, which are not commonly found in this region. Scott's Run Nature Preserve is a popular spot for outdoor activities like hiking and is managed by the Fairfax County Park Authority.

The Poughkeepsie Galleria, also known as The Galleria, is a fancy shopping center in Poughkeepsie, New York. It is situated on U.S. 9, just north of Wappingers Falls, and is the biggest shopping center in Dutchess County. The Galleria is massive, covering 1,100,000 square feet with two floors that house 140 shops, 14 restaurants, and a 16-screen Regal Cinemas theater with stadium seating.

Tysons, previously known as "Tysons Corner," is a community in Fairfax County, Virginia, United States. It is situated in Northern Virginia between McLean and Vienna, along the Capital Beltway (I-495), within the Washington Metropolitan Area. Tysons is known for its two large shopping malls, Tysons Corner Center and Tysons Galleria, as well as being the headquarters for several major companies including Intelsat, Gannett, Hilton Worldwide, Freddie Mac, Capital One, and Booz Allen Hamilton. Tysons serves as the central business district for Fairfax County and is a key commercial hub in the region. With a population of 19,627 as of the 2010 census, Tysons is often described as a prime example of an edge city.

Tysons Corner Center is a shopping mall in Fairfax County, Virginia, United States. It opened in 1968 and was one of the first malls in the Washington, D.C. area to be fully enclosed and climate-controlled. It is located between McLean and Vienna, Virginia.

The Cobb Galleria Centre is a large building in Cobb County, near Atlanta, Georgia, that serves as both a meeting place and a shopping center. It is surrounded by office buildings, the Cumberland Mall, and the Cobb Energy Performing Arts Centre. The venue has hosted over 15,000 events and millions of guests. It is managed by the Cobb-Marietta Coliseum and Exhibit Hall Authority and is conveniently located at the intersection of three major highways: Interstate 75, Interstate 285, and Cobb Parkway (U.S. 41). Downstairs, there is the Galleria Specialty Mall, while upstairs are the meeting halls.

West McLean is a small community in Fairfax County, Virginia, USA. It is situated in the western part of the McLean area and covers a large portion of the Tysons Corner region. West McLean has its own post office with the ZIP code 22103, mainly for PO Boxes. The rest of West McLean uses ZIP code 22102.

McLean, also known as Tysons East or Tysons-McLean, is a Washington Metro station in Fairfax County, Virginia. It is on the Silver Line and is situated in Tysons Corner with a postal address in McLean. The station started operating on July 26, 2014.

Spring Hill is a Washington Metro station in Fairfax County, Virginia, on the Silver Line. It is located in Tysons Corner and started operating on July 26, 2014. The station is situated in the middle of Leesburg Pike (SR 7) just to the west of Spring Hill Road.

question: Bordan Tkachuk was the CEO of a company that provides what sort of products?

neg: Cardinal Health, Inc. is a big healthcare company in Dublin, Ohio that is part of the Fortune 500 list. Cardinal Health supplies medical goods to most hospitals in the U.S. In 2013, they joined forces with CVS Caremark to create the largest source for generic drugs in the U.S., called Red Oak Sourcing, which started operating in July 2014.

Terren Scott Peizer, known as the "Zelig of Wall Street," is currently the Chairman of Acuitas Group Holdings (AGH), an investment company based in Los Angeles. AGH owns 100% of Crede Capital Group (CCG), which invests in public companies and provides growth capital to small and medium-sized enterprises. Since its start in June 2009, CCG has provided over $1.2 billion in capital commitments and funding to various companies. In addition to owning Crede Capital, Acuitas Group also owns 72% of Catasys, Inc., a company that offers behavioral health management services using big data analytics, and 100% of NeurMedix, Inc., a biotech company focused on developing treatments for neurodegenerative diseases. Peizer is the Founder and Chairman of the Acuitas companies, as well as the CEO of Catasys, Inc. and Crede Capital Group. BankUnited, Inc. is a bank holding company that owns BankUnited, a national bank based in Miami Lakes, Florida. BankUnited offers a variety of banking services to individuals and businesses through its 94 branches in Florida and 6 branches in the New York metropolitan area. The bank also offers commercial lending and deposit products nationwide. BankUnited aims to provide personalized customer service and a wide range of traditional banking products to both commercial and retail customers through its experienced lending and relationship banking teams.

Compass Minerals also makes consumer deicing and water conditioning products, culinary salt for consumers and businesses, and other mineral-based products for various uses. Additionally, the company offers records management services to businesses in the UK.

Owens & Minor is a large company based in Mechanicsville, Virginia, near Richmond. They specialize in managing healthcare products for hospitals. Their tagline is "Connecting the World of Medical Products to the Point of Care." The Navy discovered a trail near Jupiter Inlet and sent seventy-five men to locate the nearby Seminole camp led by Sam Jones, Ar-pi-uck-i, the spiritual and war chief of the Miccosukee and Seminole people. The officers were outnumbered and ambushed by the Seminoles. After a prolonged battle, the US forces retreated with five men killed and around twenty others wounded, including Lt. Powell.

question: Since 2 June 2017, The Leader of Fine Gael had been held by which Irish Fine Gael politician who has served as Taoiseach and Minister for Defence?

question: Which airplane was this Major test-flying after whom the base, that 514th Flight Test Squadron is stated at, is named?
pos: The 514th Flight Test Squadron (514 FLTS) is a part of the United States Air Force. It operates under the Ogden Air Logistics Center (OO-ALC), which is part of the Air Force Materiel Command. The squadron is based at Hill Air Force Base in Utah.

Hill Air Force Base, abbreviated as HIF, is a significant U.S. Air Force facility situated in northern Utah, just south of Ogden. It's close to several towns like Clearfield, Riverdale, Roy, Sunset, and Layton, and approximately 30 miles north of Salt Lake City. The base got its name from Major Ployer Peter Hill, a pilot who tragically lost his life while test-flying a B-17 Flying Fortress prototype. Even today, in this decade, Hill AFB remains one of Utah's top employers, ranking sixth overall and third if excluding state government and higher education institutions.
neg: The 413th Flight Test Squadron, located at Duke Field, Eglin Air Force Base in Florida, is a unit within the 96th Test Wing. Their job is to test-fly various aircraft like the C-130 Hercules, CV-22 Osprey, MH-53 Pave Low, UH-1 Iroquois, and HH-60 Pave Hawk.

The 486th Flight Test Squadron, based at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida, is a unit with a secretive nature despite its somewhat misleading name. It is associated with the United States Department of State Foreign Emergency Support Team activities. The squadron's motto, "Non semper ea sunt quae videntur," translates to "Not always what they seem." Initially assigned to the 227th Special Operations Flight, later renamed the 150th Special Operations Squadron at McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey, it is currently under the 46th Test Wing at Eglin. The squadron operates a pair of Boeing C-32B or Boeing 757-23A aircraft, which are on stand-by alert for special operations and intelligence missions worldwide. It's important to note that operations are officially under the jurisdiction of the Air Force Special Operations Command.

The 415th Flight Test Flight is a squadron in the United States Air Force Reserve. It belongs to the 413th Flight Test Group of the Air Force Reserve Command, and it's based at Randolph Field, which is part of Joint Base San Antonio in Texas.

The 10th Flight Test Squadron, which is part of the 413th Flight Test Group under Air Force Materiel Command, is located at Tinker Air Force Base in Oklahoma. Their main job is to test refurbished aircraft like the Rockwell B-1 Lancer, Boeing B-52 Stratofortress, Boeing E-3 Sentry, and Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker before they're sent back to their respective units.

The 419th Flight Test Squadron is a part of the United States Air Force. It operates under the 412th Operations Group, which is part of the Air Force Materiel Command, and is based at Edwards Air Force Base in California.
The 370th Flight Test Squadron is a part of the United States Air Force. It's based at Edwards Air Force Base in California and falls under the command of the 413th Flight Test Group.

The 417th Flight Test Squadron, previously known as the 6517th Test Squadron, was originally activated in 1989. It conducted flight tests for the McDonnell Douglas C-17 Globemaster III until its inactivation in 1995, after which it was reactivated as the 417th Test Squadron in 2006. The squadron operated under the 412th Operations Group at Edwards Air Force Base, California, until its final inactivation on 14 February 2012. During its second activation, it performed ground and flight tests on the Boeing YAL-1A until its eventual inactivation in 2012.

The 339th Flight Test Squadron, stationed at Robins Air Force Base in Georgia, is part of the Warner Robins Air Logistics Center. Their job is to make sure aircraft are safe and ready to fly again. They do this by testing planes like the Lockheed C-130 Hercules, the Lockheed C-5 Galaxy, and the McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle after they've been serviced.

question: Over how many centuries were the "dwelling place of the dead" built?
pos: Flaming Feather is a colorful Western movie from 1952, directed by Ray Enright and featuring Sterling Hayden. It was filmed in scenic locations like Oak Creek Canyon near Sedona, AZ, and Montezuma Castle National Monument. During filming, the Yavapai Indians, who were hired as extras, wouldn't go into the cliff-dwellings because they considered them sacred. This caused a delay until Navajos from a reservation 137 miles away were brought in as replacements.

Montezuma Castle National Monument safeguards ancient homes near Camp Verde, Arizona, crafted by the Sinagua people, who lived there from about 1100 to 1425 AD. The main building, with five floors and twenty rooms, took three centuries to construct.
neg: Château de Druyes is an old castle in Druyes-les-Belles-Fontaines, France. It was constructed in the 12th century by the Counts of Nevers and was owned by them until the 18th century. The castle served both as a home for nobles and as a fortress. In the 13th century, it was often visited by Peter II of Courtenay, who was the Emperor of Constantinople at the time, and his daughter Matilda, who held titles such as Countess of Nevers, Auxerre, and Tonnerre.

In Hebrew, "Shamayim" means heaven, but it actually refers to multiple heavens. This concept is part of a three-part cosmos, with "erets" meaning earth and "sheol" meaning the underworld. "Shamayim" is where God and other heavenly beings live, "erets" is where the living reside, and "sheol" is where the dead go, including in later texts like the Christian New Testament where it's seen as the place for righteous souls.

In Norse mythology, Andlang, also known as Andlàngr or Öndlangr, is the second heavenly realm located between two others: the first, where the gods' halls are, and the third, called Vídbláin. According to Snorri, there are nine heavens in total. Andlang is where the souls of the dead will find shelter and live during and after Ragnarök, the end of the world.

The Tabernacle was like a portable home for God among the Israelites after they left Egypt and as they settled in Canaan. It was made of curtains, boards covered in gold, and various valuable materials, all according to instructions from God given to Moses. The Israelites carried it with them during their travels in the wilderness and while they took over the Promised Land. Eventually, Solomon's Temple in Jerusalem replaced it as God's dwelling place about 300 years later.

In zoology, an inquiline is an animal that lives together with another species in its nest, burrow, or home without causing harm. For instance, some insects may live in gophers' homes and feed on debris, fungi, roots, etc. Inquilines are often found in social insects' nests, like ants and termites, with a single colony supporting many inquiline species. While inquilines share similarities with parasites, they don't harm the host species, unlike parasites which have a negative impact.
In Norse mythology, Víðbláinn is the third heaven, according to Snorri's Gylfaginning. It's above Andlang and Asgard and will be where souls go during and after Ragnarök.

Determining the oldest synagogue in the United Kingdom isn't straightforward. There are synagogues found by archaeologists or historians that existed before Jews were expelled from England. Then, there are synagogues built after Jews legally returned in the 17th century. Some old synagogues were destroyed and rebuilt, so while the site is ancient, the building is modern. Others were repurposed for different uses like churches, mosques, residences, or schools. Finally, some ancient synagogues have been in constant use for centuries.

Determining the oldest synagogue in the world isn't straightforward. Lots of ancient synagogues have been found through archaeological digs. Some have been rebuilt over time, so while the location or community might be ancient, the actual building might be newer. Others have been repurposed as churches, mosques, or for different uses. Yet, some ancient synagogues have been used continuously as synagogues for many centuries.

question: When was the British author who wrote the novel on which "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush" was based born?
pos: Edward Hunter Davies, OBE, born on January 7, 1936, is a British writer, journalist, and broadcaster. He's known for writing several books, notably the officially approved biography of the Beatles.

The movie "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush" is a British film from 1967, adapted from Hunter Davies' novel of the same name. It was supposed to be shown at the 1968 Cannes Film Festival, but the festival got called off because of the events in France in May 1968.
neg: The phrase "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush" can refer to different things, and this page helps clarify those meanings.

"The Wheels on the Bus" is an old American song, likely from 1939, written by Verna Hills. Kids in the UK, US, Australia, and Canada love singing it on bus rides. It's super repetitive, like "99 Bottles of Beer," so everyone can join in. It's inspired by another British song called "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush." Sometimes, people sing it to the tune of "Buffalo Gals," like Raffi's version.

Roy Holder, born on June 15, 1946, is an English TV actor known for his roles in shows like Ace of Wands, Z-Cars, Spearhead, and Doctor Who's The Caves of Androzani, as well as the movie Sorry! His acting career began with the 1961 film Whistle Down the Wind, followed by appearances in various films like The Taming of the Shrew (1967), Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush (1967), Romeo and Juliet (1968), The Virgin Soldiers (1969), Loot (1970), Psychomania (1973), The Land That Time Forgot (1975), Trial by Combat (1976), and Jesus of Nazareth (1977). In more recent years, he played Mr. Hill in Pride & Prejudice (2005) and Gaffer Tom in Robin Hood (2010).

The song "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush" (also known as "Mulberry Bush" or "This is the Way") is a popular nursery rhyme and game in English. It's identified by the Roud Folk Song Index number 7882. Interestingly, the melody is shared with other songs like "Lazy Mary, Will You Get Up?" and a slightly different version is used for "The Wheels on the Bus."

"Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush" is a song by Traffic, also the title track of the movie with the same name. All four members of Traffic sing together, though Steve Winwood sings alone in some parts. The single released in late 1967 made it into the UK Top 10. The Beatles considered including footage of the band performing the song in their film Magical Mystery Tour, but it didn't make the final cut. However, it's now included as a special feature in the 2012 DVD/Blu-ray release of the film.

Michael Finnegan is a never-ending song often sung by schoolchildren. It's a favorite around campfires and during scouting gatherings. No one knows where it came from, but it sounds a bit like "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush." The earliest mention of it is in The Hackney Scout Song Book from 1921 and later in The Oxford Song Book from 1927.

Clive Stanley Donner (21 January 1926 – 6 September 2010) was a British film director known for his contribution to the British New Wave. Some of his notable films include The Caretaker, Nothing But the Best, Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush, and What's New Pussycat?. He also worked on television movies and commercials until the mid-1990s.

Christopher Mitchell (May 21, 1947 – February 22, 2001) was a British actor known for playing Gunner Nigel 'Parky' Parkin in the BBC sitcom It Ain't Half Hot Mum. He also appeared in movies like Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush (1967), This, That and the Other (1969), The Sex Thief (1973), and What's Up Superdoc! (1978).

question: Who died first, George Archainbaud or Ralph Murphy?
pos: George Archainbaud was a film and television director. He was born in France on May 7, 1890, and passed away in the United States on February 20, 1959.

Ralph Murphy, born on May 1, 1895, in Rockville, Connecticut, was an American film director who worked in both movies and television from 1931 to 1962. He was briefly married to Gloria Dickson from 1941 to 1944, during which time he directed her in the film "I Want a Divorce."
neg: The Big Brain is a movie made in 1933 before the strict censorship rules of the time, directed by George Archainbaud and written by Sy Bartlett and Warren Duff. It features actors like George E. Stone, Phillips Holmes, Fay Wray, Minna Gombell, and Lilian Bond. The movie was released on August 5, 1933, by RKO Pictures.

In the 1943 Western film "Hoppy Serves a Writ," directed by George Archainbaud and starring William Boyd as Hopalong Cassidy, there's a notable cast including Andy Clyde, Victor Jory, and George Reeves. It's also worth mentioning that this film marked one of the early appearances (his 3rd) of Robert Mitchum, who, like Clark Gable in "The Painted Desert," received a lot of fan mail for his role, despite playing a similar unshaven character.

"Criminal Lawyer" is a 1937 American drama movie directed by Christy Cabanne. It was written by G. V. Atwater and Thomas Lennon, based on a story by Louis Stevens. The main actors are Lee Tracy, Margot Grahame, and Eduardo Cianelli. RKO made the movie and showed it for the first time on January 26, 1937, in New York City. It was released nationally a few days later on January 29. This wasn't the first time Stevens' story had been made into a movie; it had previously been used for "State's Attorney" in 1932, starring John Barrymore and Helen Twelvetrees. That film was also produced and released by RKO and directed by George Archainbaud.

"Flying with Music" is a musical movie made in 1942, directed by George Archainbaud and written by Louis S. Kaye and M. Coates Webster. It features actors like Marjorie Woodworth, George Givot, William Marshall, Edward Gargan, Jerry Bergen, and Norma Varden. The film came out on May 22, 1942, under the United Artists banner.

"Thrill of a Lifetime" is a comedy movie from 1937, directed by George Archainbaud and written by Seena Owen, Grant Garett, and Paul Girard Smith. The cast includes James V. Kern, Charles Adler, George Kelly, and Billy Mann, who were known as the Yacht Club Boys at the time. Other actors in the film are Judy Canova, Ben Blue, and Eleanore Whitney.

Alias French Gertie is a crime movie from before the enforcement of the Motion Picture Production Code in America. It was directed by George Archainbaud and written by Wallace Smith, adapted from a play called The Chatterbox by Bayard Veiller. The film features Bebe Daniels and Ben Lyon in their debut on-screen collaboration. A preserved copy of the film is held in the Library of Congress.

Arthur Roberts, also known as Arthur E. Roberts, was an American film editor. He edited over 100 films in his nearly 30-year career, starting around the end of the silent film era. His first film was "The College Hero" in 1927, directed by Walter Lang, and his last was "Lay That Rifle Down" in 1955. After that, he briefly edited the TV series "Lassie" before retiring in 1956. Throughout his career, he collaborated with famous directors like Frank Capra, Lowell Sherman, William Seiter, and others on various films.
Campus Confessions is a movie made in 1938, directed by George Archainbaud. It stars Betty Grable in her first big role and Hank Luisetti, an American basketball player, in his only movie role.

question: Which component of shellite has the formula (ON)CHOH?
pos: Shellite, also called Tridite in the US, is a type of explosive made by mixing Picric acid with either Dinitrophenol or Hexanitrodiphenylamine, usually in a 70/30 ratio. It was commonly used to fill armor-piercing shells for the Royal Navy in the early 1900s.

Picric acid, also known as 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), is an organic compound represented by the formula (ON)CHOH. Its name "picric" comes from the Greek word "pikros," meaning bitter, because it has a bitter taste. It's very acidic, like other phenols.
