Originally, it was mainly used as an explosive due to its highly nitrated nature. However, it has also found applications in medicine, such as antiseptics and burn treatments, as well as in dye production.
neg: Isopropyl alcohol, also known as propan-2-ol, is a clear, flammable liquid with a strong odor. It's often mistakenly called isopropanol. Its chemical formula can be written as CHO, CHOH, or CHCHOHCH (sometimes noted as i-PrOH). This compound is the simplest type of secondary alcohol, featuring a propyl group attached to a hydroxyl group. This means the alcohol carbon atom is linked to two other carbon atoms, sometimes depicted as (CH)CHOH. Isopropyl alcohol is structurally similar to 1-propanol. It's widely used in both industrial and household products, including antiseptics, disinfectants, and detergents.

Alcohol refers to any organic compound containing a hydroxyl group (-OH) attached to a carbon atom, often linked to other carbon or hydrogen atoms. The most common type is ethanol (CHOH), which is what you find in alcoholic drinks. When people talk about "alcohol," they usually mean ethanol. Some articles related to alcohol include:
Tetrakis(hydroxymethyl)phosphonium chloride (THPC) is a type of chemical compound made up of phosphorus, hydrogen, carbon, and oxygen. It's often used in making fire-resistant materials.

Here's a simpler version:

1-Hexanol is a type of alcohol made from six carbon atoms. It's clear and can mix with substances like diethyl ether and ethanol. There are two similar versions called 2-hexanol and 3-hexanol, which differ by where the hydroxyl group is located. Lots of alcohols with a similar formula are used in perfumes.

1-Pentanol, also known as n-pentanol or pentan-1-ol, is a type of alcohol composed of five carbon atoms and the molecular formula CHOH. It exists as a colorless liquid with a disagreeable smell. This compound is the linear version of amyl alcohol and is one of eight isomers sharing the same formula.

An aldonic acid is a type of sugar acid made by changing the aldehyde part of a sugar to a carboxylic acid. Their basic formula is HOOC-(CHOH)-CHOH. If you oxidize the last hydroxyl group, you get a uronic acid, and if you oxidize both ends, you get an aldaric acid.

Xylitol is a type of sweetener made from wood, hence its name which comes from Greek roots. It's often grouped with sugar alcohols and has a chemical formula similar to a specific type of pentol. Studies using electron microscopy show that xylitol can help rebuild enamel, and there's some evidence that using xylitol products like gum or nasal spray can lower the risk of ear infections in kids.

In a mix of a substance that doesn't conduct electricity well (dielectric) and a metal, when the metal part reaches a certain level, something important happens. The ability of the mix to conduct electricity and its dielectric properties start changing a lot. This change happens smoothly, and we can describe it using two important numbers, called critical exponents. Also, the dielectric properties go crazy as we get closer to this level from either side. To understand this better, we use a model that includes how the mix behaves at different frequencies, called a resistor-capacitor model (R-C model).

question: The Argentine PGA Championship record holder has won how many tournaments worldwide?
pos: The Argentine PGA Championship is a golf tournament that has been held in Argentina since 1920. It has been well-regarded among Argentine golfers, with champions like Eduardo Romero (8 wins), José Jurado (7 wins), Vicente Fernández (5 wins), José Cóceres (2 wins), and Ángel Cabrera. The most successful player in the tournament's history is Roberto De Vicenzo, a former British Open champion, who won an impressive 16 times between 1944 and 1985.

Roberto De Vicenzo, born on April 14, 1923, and passed away on June 1, 2017, was a skilled golfer from Argentina. Throughout his career, he achieved over 230 tournament victories globally, which included eight wins on the PGA Tour. One of his most notable victories was at the 1967 Open Championship.
neg: The 1939 PGA Championship took place from July 9 to 15 at Pomonok Country Club in Queens, New York. Back then, it was a match play event. Henry Picard won his first and only PGA Championship by defeating Byron Nelson with a birdie on the 37th hole. This victory was Picard's second major win, following his Masters triumph in 1938. Nelson, who had won the U.S. Open a few months earlier, would go on to win the next PGA Championship in 1940. From 1939 onward, Nelson reached the finals in five out of six PGA Championships, ultimately clinching his second title in 1945.

The Middle Atlantic PGA Championship is a golf tournament that crowns the champion of the Middle Atlantic section of the PGA of America. It's been held every year since 1932 in Virginia, Maryland, or Washington, DC. Fred Funk, who won eight times on the PGA Tour, holds the record with six victories in this championship. Other notable winners include Chandler Harper, Bobby Cruickshank, Lew Worsham, and George Fazio, all of whom have also succeeded on the PGA Tour.

The 2000 PGA Championship took place at the Valhalla Golf Club in Louisville, Kentucky, from August 17 to 20. Tiger Woods secured his second consecutive PGA Championship victory and his fifth major overall by defeating Bob May in a three-hole playoff. They both finished the tournament at 18 under par, setting a new record for the PGA Championship, which Tiger Woods later matched in 2006. This win marked the first successful defense of a PGA Championship title since 1937 and the first time it happened in a stroke play event. Woods and May were well ahead of the third-place finisher, Thomas Bjørn, by five shots.

The Northern California PGA Championship is a golf tournament that represents the championship of the Northern California section of the PGA of America. Mark Fry, a long-time professional at Sequoyah Country Club in Oakland, California, holds the record for the most victories, with 10 wins. Tony Lema, the winner of the British Open in 1964 and a 12-time PGA Tour winner, achieved a notable feat by winning three consecutive Northern California PGA championships from 1962 to 1964. Other notable winners who have triumphed in both the Northern California PGA Championship and the PGA Tour include Bob Lunn, a six-time PGA Tour winner, Dick Lotz, a three-time PGA Tour winner, Bruce Summerhays, a three-time PGA Tour winner, Bob Wynn, and John McMullin.

In 2006, the PGA Championship was held at Medinah Country Club in Illinois, near Chicago. Tiger Woods won his third PGA Championship, beating Shaun Micheel by five shots. It was Woods' 12th major win. The course, No. 3, was the longest ever for a major tournament. Medinah had hosted the championship before in 1999, when Woods won his first PGA Championship. The total prize money was $6.8 million, and the winner received $1.224 million.

The 2018 PGA Championship, which marks the 100th anniversary, is happening from August 9th to 12th at Bellerive Country Club in Town and Country, Missouri. It's the second time this club hosts the championship. Also, it's the last time it'll be held in August; starting from 2019, it'll be in May, as announced before the 2017 tournament.

In 1977, the PGA Championship took place at Pebble Beach Golf Links in California from August 11 to 14. Lanny Wadkins, aged 27, won his first major title by defeating Gene Littler in a sudden-death playoff. This playoff was significant because it hadn't happened at the PGA Championship in a decade and marked the first sudden-death playoff in a stroke-play major championship. The previous instance of such a playoff occurred 36 years earlier at the 1941 PGA Championship, extending a final match to two extra holes.

The 1940 PGA Championship took place from August 26 to September 2 at Hershey Country Club in Hershey, Pennsylvania, near Harrisburg. Byron Nelson won his first PGA Championship by beating Sam Snead 1 up in the 36-hole final. This victory was Nelson's third major title out of five, and he went on to win the PGA Championship again in 1945. During the years 1939 to 1945, Nelson reached the final match five times out of six, only skipping the event in 1942 (as it wasn't held in 1943).

question: Suicide's 1977 released album features a song based on what brand's comic character?
pos: "Ghost Rider" is a song by the protopunk band Suicide, featured on their first album. The song is inspired by the Marvel Comics character of the same name.

Suicide's first album, also called "Suicide," marked the beginning of the American rock band's journey. Released in 1977 on Red Star Records, the album was created under the production of Craig Leon and Marty Thau. They recorded the album in just four days at Ultima Sound Studios in New York. The music is characterized by Martin Rev's simple electronic sounds and Alan Vega's gritty singing style, which often portrayed city life themes.
neg: "A Week of Garfield" is a video game released in 1989 for the Family Computer console in Japan. It features the popular comic character Garfield. Despite its popularity, the game faced licensing issues and was only made available in Japan. This game marked the third attempt to adapt Jim Davis' Garfield Comics into a video game.

Patty Griffin's fifth album, "Impossible Dream," came out on April 20, 2004. One cool surprise on the album is an unlisted song where Griffin's parents sing "The Impossible Dream" at the end of the track "Top of the World."

"Nagaram Marupakkam" is a 2010 Indian Tamil action film directed by Sundar C., who also stars in it. His wife Kushboo co-produced the film, which also features Anuya Bhagvath and Vadivelu. It's Sundar's first directorial project in five years and was released on November 19, 2010. The movie is inspired by the 1993 American film "Carlito's Way" and is famous for its comedy scenes, particularly Vadivelu's portrayal of Style Pandi.

The album "Levolution" is the second one by the Australian rock band Juke Kartel, and it's their first album released in America. It came out in Australia on August 20, 2010, through Carved Records, and then in the United States on September 28, 2010. Produced by Brian Virtue and Rick Parashar, it features some new tracks along with some remixes of songs from their 2009 Australian album "Nowhere Left to Hide." According to the vocalist and lyricist Toby Rand, "Levolution" focuses on personal growth and life's journey, showcasing strong hooks, diverse instrumentals, and passionate vocals.

The second studio album by Mucky Pup, titled "A Boy in a Man's World," was released in 1989 through Torrid Records and Roadrunner Records. It includes a re-recorded version of their song "U-Stink-But-I-♥-U," which they had won a Bloom County songwriting contest with previously. Additionally, the band shot their first music video for this song. The album also includes a track called "Batman," inspired by an urban legend and featuring a snippet of the title theme from the 1966 Batman TV show.

"Deceit" is a book by Peter Darvill-Evans, inspired by the popular British sci-fi show Doctor Who. It stars the Seventh Doctor, along with Ace and Bernice. The novel also introduces Abslom Daak from the Doctor Who Magazine comics, marking his first appearance outside the magazine. Before the novel's release, a prelude written by Darvill-Evans was published in Doctor Who Magazine #198.

Carly Rae Jepsen's second album, "Kiss," came out on September 14, 2012, under 604, Schoolboy, and Interscope Records. Unlike her first album, "Tug of War," which was only successful in Canada, "Kiss" was her first album to be released worldwide. It includes songs in genres like nu-disco, dance-pop, and teen pop, influenced by artists such as The Cars, Madonna, and Robyn. The album was produced by various producers like Dallas Austin, Josh Ramsay, and Redfoo, and it even features a track with Justin Bieber's vocals.

"In My Country There Is Problem," also called "Throw the Jew Down the Well" because of its prominent line, is a song created by British comedian Sacha Baron Cohen for his character Borat Sagdiyev. It's part of the 'Country Music' segment in Borat's Guide to the USA (Part 2), highlighting the surprising reactions of patrons in an Arizona country and western bar to the song's antisemitic lyrics.

question: What other political position did the person who introduced the DISCLOSE Act hold?
pos: The DISCLOSE Act, also called H.R. 5175 (S.3628-Senate), was a bill introduced in the U.S. House of Representatives by Chris Van Hollen (D-Maryland) on April 29, 2010, and in the U.S. Senate by Charles Schumer (D-New York) on July 21, 2010. It aimed to increase transparency in election spending.

Christopher Van Hollen Jr., born on January 10, 1959, is currently the junior Senator representing Maryland in the United States. He started serving in this role on January 3, 2017. Before that, from 2003 to 2017, he was the U.S. Representative for Maryland's 8th congressional district. He belongs to the Democratic Party.
neg: In Norway, a State Secretary is a political role within the government's executive branch. Unlike the Secretary of State in other countries, the Norwegian State Secretary doesn't lead their Ministry; instead, they're second in command to a Minister. They're sort of like a vice minister, but they can't attend a Council of State meeting or fill in for a Minister who's sick or on leave.

The Vice President of Panama is the second most important political role in the Panamanian government. Since 2009, only one person has held this position. Before that, there were two positions: First Vice President and Second Vice President, also called First Designate to Presidency and Second Designate. According to the current constitution, Vice Presidents are elected alongside the President. However, the role of Second Vice President was removed in 2009.

Hannah Annie Elizabeth Rolinson Gale, born on December 29, 1876, and passed away on August 7, 1970, was a Canadian politician originally from Britain. She made history by becoming the first woman in Canada to win an elected political office.

In Nazi Germany, the Abteilungsleiter, which means "section leader" in German, was like a department head in charge of specific areas. They were usually mid-level administrators who were also part of the Nazi Party. This title wasn't an official political rank within the party but more of an additional role for party members. It started in 1933 after the Nazis took control of Germany.

Pub.L. 113–167, also known as the Interstate Land Sales Full Disclosure Act amendment, aims to clarify how the Act applies to condominiums in the United States. This law, originally passed in 1968, was created to protect consumers from scams related to land sales across state lines. Sellers must provide detailed information about the property they're selling in a Property Report. While initially overseen by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, it's now managed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. H.R. 2600 proposes changes specifically concerning condominiums under this law.

Attorney misconduct refers to unethical or illegal behavior by a lawyer, which can take various forms such as conflicts of interest, overcharging clients, refusing representation for personal or political reasons, making false statements, withholding evidence, abandoning clients, not sharing all important facts, selectively presenting legal arguments without mentioning opposing laws, and in extreme cases, engaging in sexual relationships with clients.

The Modernization of Investigative Techniques Act, Bill C-74, was proposed in the Canadian House of Commons on November 15, 2005, as part of a group of laws called "lawful access" proposals. This bill aimed to make telephone and internet service providers create systems for intercepting communications and give law enforcement access to subscriber information without needing a warrant. However, it didn't become law because Parliament ended before it could be passed. Similar legislation, named Bill C-13, was reintroduced by Stephen Harper's Conservative government on November 20, 2013, and it passed into law on December 9, 2014, under the title Protecting Canadians from Online Crime Act.

Campaign finance regulation in the United States saw its modern inception with the Federal Election Campaign Act (FECA) of 1971, followed by significant amendments in 1974. The 1971 FECA required candidates to disclose their campaign contributions and spending. In 1974, the amendments revamped the Act, introducing limits on individual contributions for the first time and establishing the Federal Election Commission (FEC) to enforce these rules independently. These changes also expanded disclosure requirements and imposed spending limits on both candidates and citizens advocating for political causes. Despite attempts to restrict the influence of wealthy donors by capping individual and PAC donations, the Supreme Court's 1976 decision in Buckley v. Valeo deemed certain expenditure limitations unconstitutional.

question: Were the bands Skin Yard and Ostava from the U.S.?
pos: Ostava is a Bulgarian alternative rock band that started in 1991. However, they didn't release a full-length album until 2000, which gained them critical acclaim.

Skin Yard, a grunge band from Seattle, Washington, operated between 1985 and 1993. Although they didn't become widely popular, they influenced other grunge bands like Soundgarden, Screaming Trees, The Melvins, and Green River.
neg: Matthew David Cameron, born on November 28, 1962, is an American musician known for playing the drums in the rock bands Pearl Jam and Soundgarden. He started his music career with bands like Bam Bam and Skin Yard in Seattle, Washington. Cameron gained recognition as the drummer for Soundgarden from 1986 to 1997. After Soundgarden disbanded, he joined Pearl Jam for their U.S. Yield Tour in 1998 and became a permanent member. Soundgarden reunited in 2010 for a tour and released the album "King Animal" on November 13, 2012.

Chris Hanzsek is an American music engineer and producer who lives in Snohomish, Washington. Back in 1984, he co-founded C/Z Records and Reciprocal Recording studio with Tina Casale. During the mid-1980s, he worked with bands like The Melvins, Soundgarden, The U-Men, Malfunkshun, Skin Yard, and Green River, who are considered pioneers of Seattle's "grunge" music scene. You can find some of their work on C/Z Records' notable compilation album, "Deep Six".
Skin Yard, the debut album by the band Skin Yard, was released in January 1987. They pressed 1400 copies of the album on vinyl, which had a translucent skin-tone appearance.

Mark Arm, whose real name is Mark Thomas McLaughlin and was born on February 21, 1962, is the lead singer of the grunge band Mudhoney. Before Mudhoney, he was part of a band called Green River, which is considered one of the pioneering grunge bands, alongside others like Malfunkshun, Soundgarden, Skin Yard, and the U-Men. Additionally, Mark has experience managing the Sub Pop warehouse and has worked at Fantagraphics Books in the past.

Jack Endino (born 1964) is a music producer and musician from Seattle, USA. He's well-known for his work with the Seattle label Sub Pop and the grunge scene. He's worked on important albums for bands like Mudhoney, Soundgarden, and Nirvana. Endino also played guitar for the Seattle band Skin Yard from 1985 to 1992. Nowadays, he runs a recording studio in Seattle called Soundhouse Recording.

Gruntruck is a rock band from Seattle, formed in 1989 by vocalist Ben McMillan and drummer Norman Scott, who were part of the early Grunge scene with Skin Yard. Norman also briefly played with Soundgarden and teamed up with Chris Cornell in another band called Bass Truck. Lead guitarist Tommy Niemeyer came from The Accüsed, known for metal thrash, and bassist Tim Paul from Final Warning, a hardcore punk band from PDX. Their music is often labeled as Grunge with a heavier emphasis on metal.

Cat Butt was a rock band from Seattle, Washington, that started in 1987. They went on a quick tour along the west coast and then made their first full-length album, "Journey to the Center Of," with Jack Endino from Skin Yard producing it. To get the word out about the album, the band toured extensively across the United States before breaking up in late 1990. While they didn't reach the same level of fame as some other Sub Pop bands, they still had a dedicated fan base in the Pacific Northwest.

Daniel House, born on August 8, 1961, is known for his role in the Seattle "grunge" music scene during the 1980s and '90s. He co-founded and played bass for Skin Yard, a band active from 1985 to 1992. Additionally, he was the President and owner of C/Z Records, an independent record label based in Seattle. C/Z Records released music by various bands such as 7 Year Bitch, Built to Spill, Coffin Break, Engine Kid, The Gits, Hammerbox, Love Battery, The Melvins, The Presidents of the United States of America, Silkworm, and Skin Yard. In 2003, he relocated from Seattle to Los Angeles, where he managed the development of the now-defunct website www.DownloadPunk.com and the music-focused online dating platform, RocknRollDating.com.

question: Are Daryl Hall and Gerry Marsden both musicians?
pos: Daryl Franklin Hohl, born on October 11, 1946, goes by the name Daryl Hall in his music career. He's an American singer, songwriter, and producer, famous for co-founding Hall & Oates alongside guitarist John Oates.

Gerard Marsden MBE, born on September 24, 1942, is a well-known English musician and TV personality. He's most famous for being the frontman of the British band Gerry and the Pacemakers, which was part of the Merseybeat music scene.
neg: "Did It in a Minute" is a song by the American duo Hall & Oates. It was written by Daryl Hall along with Sara and Janna Allen. The song was released in March 1982 as the third single from their album "Private Eyes." Daryl Hall sings the lead vocals, with John Oates providing backing harmony vocals.

"One on One" is a song by the American musical duo Hall & Oates. It was written by Daryl Hall and released as the second single from their album "H2O" on January 29, 1983. The song has a simple production with synthesizers and uses sports metaphors to talk about seduction. Daryl Hall sings the main part, and John Oates sings backup vocals.

Janna Allen, born on May 12, 1957, and passing away on August 25, 1993, was a renowned American songwriter. She gained fame for co-writing many of the major hits performed by Daryl Hall & John Oates. She often collaborated with Daryl Hall, John Oates, and her sister Sara Allen. Sara Allen, who was Hall's long-term partner, inspired the duo's famous song "Sara Smile."

"Daryl's House," also known as "Live from Daryl's House" or LFDH, is an online series that began in fall 2007. Hosted by singer-songwriter Daryl Hall, the show takes place at his home in Millerton, New York, where he performs with his band and various guest artists. It offers a unique performance space for artists outside of traditional concerts and studio sessions, allowing them to have fun and be spontaneous creatively. Many episodes also feature Hall and the guest artist cooking food from different cuisines, often sourced from local restaurants. Despite later expanding to broadcast TV, the essence of the show remained unchanged, with Hall emphasizing that it's still an internet show being aired on television. The show initially aired in 95 markets in 2011 and later transitioned to filming at Hall's club, Daryl's House, in Pawling, New York, starting with its 66th episode.

"Don't Let the Sun Catch You Crying" is a song by the British beat group Gerry and the Pacemakers. It was written by Gerry Marsden along with other band members Freddie Marsden, Les Chadwick, and Les Maguire. The song was initially recorded by Louise Cordet before the band recorded their version in early 1964.

"Ferry Cross the Mersey," a song by Gerry Marsden, was first recorded by his band Gerry and the Pacemakers in late 1964 in the UK and in 1965 in the United States. It became popular on both sides of the Atlantic, reaching number six in the US and number eight in the UK. The song is featured in the film of the same name and was included on its soundtrack album. In the mid-1990s, a musical theatre production, also titled "Ferry Cross the Mersey," depicted Gerry Marsden's Merseybeat days. It premiered in Liverpool and was later performed in the UK, Australia, and Canada.

Jonathan Wolfson, born on December 1, 1970, is an American TV executive and publicist. He's recognized for managing Daryl Hall & John Oates and Loverboy. Previously, he handled publicity for Suge Knight via Wolfson Public Relations. Also, he's been the executive producer for Daryl Hall's TV programs like "Daryl's Restoration Over-Hall" and "Live From Daryl’s House."

Daryl Hall and John Oates, known as Hall & Oates, are a music duo from Philadelphia, USA. Daryl Hall usually sings lead, while John Oates plays electric guitar and sings backup. They mostly write their own songs, either alone or together. Their biggest success was in the late 1970s to the mid-1980s, blending rock and roll with rhythm and blues.

question: What major truck road is located in Backford Cross?
pos: Backford Cross, a village in Cheshire, England, sits on the Wirral Peninsula. It's close to Ellesmere Port and falls under Cheshire West and Chester. Positioned near the A41/A5117 junction, south of Great Sutton, and about 1.5 miles north of Backford village near Chester, Backford Cross mainly consists of homes built since 1990. People here often commute to Ellesmere Port and Chester, although they don't feel strongly connected to either place. The village is divided between postcode districts, with some areas in Great Sutton, Ellesmere Port (CH66), and others in Backford, Chester (CH1).

The A41 is a significant road in England connecting London to Birkenhead. Although some sections have been replaced by motorways, it still goes through or near several towns and cities like Watford, Kings Langley, Hemel Hempstead, Aylesbury, Solihull, Birmingham, West Bromwich, Wolverhampton, Newport, Whitchurch, Chester, and Ellesmere Port.
neg: Pureland Industrial Complex is a huge industrial area spanning 3000 acres in Logan Township, Gloucester County, New Jersey, USA. It sits next to the Delaware River and Raccoon Creek, just 12 miles south of the ports of Camden and Philadelphia. Highways like Interstate 295, U.S. Route 322, and U.S. Route 130 pass through it, linking it to major truck routes. Additionally, SMS Rail Lines connect it to Penns Grove Secondary and the national rail network. Established in 1975, it's the biggest industrial park in New Jersey and one of the largest globally.

The Portland and Southwestern Railroad Tunnel, also called the Nehalem Divide Railroad Tunnel, is an old railway tunnel near Scappoose, Oregon, USA. It's special because it's on the National Register of Historic Places. The tunnel was made by the Portland and Southwestern Railroad, which mainly moved logs. Unlike most railways for logging, this one had tunnels. They built a 1712 ft tunnel to get to the other side of the Nehalem divide in the Northern Oregon Coast Range. Construction began in 1918 and finished in 1919, although some work started earlier in 1910. Since the tunnel wasn't through solid rock, they lined it with timber. It was used until 1945 when a road for trucks was built over the divide.
Param is a village located in the Rampur district of the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. It's situated 3 kilometers away from Ram Ganga and 8 kilometers from the Grand Truck Road.

Al Haj FAW Motors is the only company in Pakistan that distributes and puts together FAW vehicles. It's part of the Al Haj group and has a plant in Karachi, which opened in 2013. They make cars for regular use, small trucks, and big commercial trucks. Over the years, they've become a top choice for many transport and logistics companies in Pakistan when it comes to buying trucks.

The A5117 is a road in Cheshire, England, stretching from Shotwick to Helsby. It links the A550 at Woodbank to the M56, serving as a bypass to Chester in the north and offering a quicker path between the North West and North Wales compared to the A55. West of the M56, the road has two lanes. Near the M56's western end, there's a roundabout with the A540. East of this roundabout, the road becomes a single lane and passes through a roundabout at Backford Cross, crossing the A41. The A5117 meets the M53 at Junction 10, just east of Cheshire Oaks Designer Outlet. It then runs parallel to the M56, intersecting it again at Junction 14, where a motorway service area is located. Finally, the road heads southeast and ends at its junction with the A56 in Helsby.

U.S. Route 287 runs from north to south across the United States, spanning 2,882 kilometers. It's a crucial route for trucking, connecting Fort Worth to Amarillo in Texas, and Fort Collins in Colorado to Laramie in Wyoming. Yellowstone National Park divides the highway into two parts, but there's a road within the park that links them together.

US 19 Truck is a special road for trucks in Western Pennsylvania near Pittsburgh. It's like a circle that goes around US 19. One end is in Mt. Lebanon, and the other is in McCandless Township. It connects to US 19 at both ends. One interesting part is where it meets the Penn–Lincoln Parkway near the Fort Pitt Tunnel. There, it joins the Parkway and goes in some strange directions, even going the wrong way at times. North of Pittsburgh, it's called McKnight Road, and south of Pittsburgh, it's called West Liberty Avenue and Washington Road.
Strawberry Park and Strawberry Fields are neighborhoods in Ellesmere Port, which is part of Cheshire West and Chester. They're situated south of Hope Farm and west of Backford Cross.

question: In which role did Caroline Carver played in a 1999 Hallmark Entertainment made-for-TV fantasy movie?
pos: The Magical Legend of the Leprechauns is a fantasy movie made for TV in 1999 by Hallmark Entertainment. It features actors like Randy Quaid, Colm Meaney, Kieran Culkin, Roger Daltrey, Caroline Carver, and Whoopi Goldberg. The movie tells two main stories that eventually connect: one about an American businessman encountering magical leprechauns during a visit to Ireland, and the other about a fairy and a leprechaun, who are in love despite being from opposing sides in a magical war. The film draws parallels to Romeo and Juliet, with themes of poisoned love and feuding families.

Caroline Carver, born in 1976, is a British actress, screenwriter, and producer. She's famous for playing Princess Jessica in the TV movie "The Magical Legend of the Leprechauns" (1999), Ingrid in "The Aryan Couple" (2004), and Sandy in "My First Wedding" (2006).
neg: Donald J. Hall Jr. is the President and CEO of Hallmark Cards. He also serves on the board of directors for Crown Media Holdings and Hallmark Entertainment Holdings, as well as Business Men's Assurance Company of America. He's the son of Donald J. Hall Sr., who is the chairman and main shareholder of Hallmark Cards.

Silver Bells is a TV drama from 2005 featuring Anne Heche and Tate Donovan. It was made by Hallmark Entertainment for their Hallmark Hall of Fame series, adapted from Luanne Rice's novel of the same name.

The TV movie "La Femme Musketeer" was made by Hallmark Entertainment and Larry Levinson Productions. It was filmed in Croatia on Draguć island. The movie first aired on June 20, 2004, on the Hallmark Channel.

"The Boys Next Door" is a TV movie from 1996, adapted from Tom Griffin's play. The play was first titled "Damaged Hearts, Broken Flowers" in 1983, then renamed "The Boys Next Door" in 1988. Hallmark Entertainment produced the film as part of their Hallmark Hall of Fame series.

Snow White: The Fairest of Them All is a TV movie from 2001. It's a fantasy adventure directed by Caroline Thompson and produced by Hallmark Entertainment. It premiered in Europe first and later aired in the US on ABC as part of The Wonderful World of Disney series on March 17, 2002.

"Released in 2008, 'You Me and Captain Longbridge' is a 15-minute short film helmed by director Kenny Doughty and crafted by writer-producer Caroline Carver. It features Callum Williams portraying 11-year-old Luke, Chris Larkin as Captain Longbridge, and Joseph Fiennes lending his voice to Luke as an adult. The film screened at 12 International Film Festivals and garnered 3 awards."

The Snow Queen is a 2002 television film produced by Hallmark Entertainment. Directed by David Wu, it's based on Hans Christian Andersen's story of the same name. Bridget Fonda stars as the Snow Queen, with Chelsea Hobbs playing Gerda, her rival and the story's heroine. Originally airing on the Hallmark Channel as a two-part miniseries, it has since been released as a full-length film on DVD in the United States. The DVD was released on November 9, 2009, in the United Kingdom, and on September 2, 2011, in Australia. Notably, this film marks Bridget Fonda's last acting role to date.

Family Plan is a TV movie shot in Los Angeles by Mat IV Productions, along with Alpine Media and Larry Levinson Productions, and brought to you by Hallmark Entertainment. It first aired on February 12, 2005, on the Hallmark Channel as part of their Valentine's Day lineup. It marks Chloë Grace Moretz's first appearance in a feature film.

question: What's the name of the fantasy film starring Sarah Bolger, featuring a New England family who discover magical creatures around their estate?
pos: Sarah Lee Bolger, born on February 28, 1991, is an Irish actress famous for her roles in movies like "In America," "Stormbreaker," and "The Spiderwick Chronicles." She also gained acclaim for portraying Lady Mary Tudor in the TV show "The Tudors" and appeared as Princess Aurora in "Once Upon a Time."

"The Spiderwick Chronicles" is a movie released in 2008, adapted from a popular book series by Holly Black and Tony DiTerlizzi. Directed by Mark Waters, it features actors like Freddie Highmore, Sarah Bolger, and Seth Rogen. The story is set in the Spiderwick Estate in New England and revolves around Jared Grace and his family finding a guide to faeries, encountering goblins, mole trolls, and other magical beings.
neg: In the Harry Potter series by J.K. Rowling, magic is portrayed as a supernatural power that can defy natural laws. The series features various magical creatures, and even ordinary beings can display magical abilities. Objects can also be enchanted with magical properties. Those who can use magic are called witches and wizards, while non-magical people are known as muggles.

In the movie "Sinbad of the Seven Seas," made in 1989, Sinbad, the main character, goes on a quest to find five magical stones. He needs these stones to break an evil spell that a wizard has cast on the city of Basra. Along the way, Sinbad travels to strange islands and fights magical creatures to save the world.

"As Cool as I Am" is a movie adapted from Pete Fromm's novel, featuring Claire Danes, Sarah Bolger, and James Marsden as the Diamond family. It's directed by Max Mayer, known for directing "Adam." Filming started in New Mexico in May 2011, and the movie hit theaters in the United States on June 21, 2013, distributed by IFC Films.

Barbie and the Secret Door is a movie released in 2014. It's a computer-animated musical fantasy film and is the 28th installment in the Barbie film series. Directed by Karen Lloyd and produced by Mattel Entertainment and Rainmaker Entertainment, the movie was released by Universal Studios Home Entertainment. Kelly Sheridan provides the voice for Princess Alexa, the main character. The story revolves around Princess Alexa, who is initially shy but becomes adventurous when she finds a secret door in her kingdom. Through this door, she enters a magical land full of enchanting creatures.

Identity Films, founded by Anthony Mastromauro in 2006, has produced several notable films. Some of their recent productions include the independent coming-of-age drama "As Cool As I Am," directed by Max Mayer and featuring James Marsden, Claire Danes, and Sarah Bolger. They've also produced "Moonlight Serenade," directed by Giancarlo Tallarico and starring Amy Adams, Alec Newman, and Harriet Sansom Harris, as well as "Artie Lange's Beer League," directed by Frank Sebastiano and co-starring Lange and Ralph Macchio.

Stormbreaker, also known as Alex Rider: Operation Stormbreaker in the US, is a 2006 action spy movie directed by Geoffrey Sax. It's based on a book of the same name by Anthony Horowitz, which is the first book in the Alex Rider series. The main actor is Alex Pettyfer playing Alex Rider, alongside other notable actors like Mickey Rourke, Bill Nighy, Sophie Okenedo, Alicia Silverstone, Sarah Bolger, Stephen Fry, and Ewan McGregor. Stormbreaker was made with collaboration from companies and investors in the UK, the US, and Germany.

John Ridge, also known as Skah-tle-loh-skee or Yellow Bird, was born around 1802 and came from a well-known Cherokee family in Georgia. He went to study at the Foreign Mission School in Cornwall, Connecticut, where he met and married Sarah Bird Northup, who was from a New England family. After they returned to New Echota in 1825, Ridge became a leader in the Cherokee tribe, serving on the Cherokee National Council.

The Moth Diaries is a horror film from 2011, directed by Mary Harron. It's based on a novel of the same name by Rachel Klein, published in 2002. The movie features Lily Cole, Sarah Gadon, Sarah Bolger, Judy Parfitt, and Scott Speedman.

question: Maxeda has been owned since 2004 by which American multinational equity firm?
pos: Maxeda, previously known as Vendex KBB, is a Dutch retail company running DIY stores in Belgium and the Netherlands. It was formed by combining Koninklijke Bijenkorf Beheer (KBB) and Vendex. In the past, it also had big department stores in the Netherlands. Since 2004, Maxeda has been owned by a group of investors, mainly led by the American private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

KKR & Co. L.P., previously called Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., is a big American company that deals with buying other companies using borrowed money. It's based in New York City. They handle investment funds and have done deals worth more than $400 billion since they started.
neg: Lincolnshire Management is a company that invests in and buys middle-sized businesses in various industries. They were recognized as one of the top ten performing private equity firms by Private Equity News in 2010 and ranked fifth by CNN Money/Fortune Magazine in 2011.

HGGC is a private equity company in Palo Alto, California. They've invested over $4.25 billion since they started in 2007. They've done a lot of deals worth over $12 billion, involving more than 60 different investments and employing over 46,000 people. In 2014, they were recognized as the M&A Mid-Market Private Equity Firm of the Year by Mergers & Acquisitions magazine.

Leeds Equity Partners is a private equity firm that specializes in investing in industries related to knowledge. They're currently investing their fifth private equity fund, Leeds Equity Partners V, L.P., which is the biggest fund dedicated solely to this sector. Their investors come from various backgrounds, including top institutions, pension plans, endowments, foundations, financial institutions, family offices, and wealthy individuals.

Manischewitz, a well-known brand in the United States, specializes in kosher products, notably matzo and kosher wine. Established in 1888, it transitioned to public ownership in 1923 before being acquired by a private equity firm in 1990. Later, on April 7, 2014, Sankaty Advisors, a branch of Bain Capital, purchased the company from a consortium including Harbinger investment firm. Manischewitz holds the title of the world's largest matzo maker and is among the prominent kosher brands in America.

Polycom is a big American company that makes technology for people to work together using video, voice, and sharing content. They have around 3,800 employees and made about $1.4 billion in 2013. They're the biggest company in their field that focuses only on collaboration tools. They also sell licenses for different types of technology like video codecs, high-definition cameras and displays, audio coding, and tools to improve the quality of video calls. In 2016, it was announced that the company was going to become private, meaning it wouldn't be publicly traded anymore, by a company called Siris Capital Group.

Avenue Capital Group is a worldwide investment company that specializes in buying assets that are in trouble or struggling, and also in investing in private companies. They have teams in different regions like the United States, Europe, and Asia. The company does two main things: it invests in private companies like a regular investment company, and it also operates like a hedge fund. Their main focus is on buying debt and stocks of companies that are struggling, but they also manage funds that invest in different things like real estate and financial products called collateralized debt obligations. They handle about $12 billion worth of assets. The company was started by people who used to work for Amroc Investments, which was connected to the Robert M. Bass Group.

Court Square Capital Partners is a company that invests in buying out other companies using borrowed money. It started as part of Citigroup, called Citigroup Venture Capital Equity Partners. The people at Court Square have put over $4.5 billion into more than 150 deals, and those deals have made $14 billion so far.

Mekong Capital is a company in Vietnam that invests in other businesses. They've been in Vietnam since 2001 and have invested in about 30 companies using four funds. They have around 25 employees and offices in Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi. Initially, they focused on manufacturing companies but changed to consumer-driven businesses in 2006. Mekong Capital is recognized for putting effort into building a strong corporate culture within its own company and the companies it invests in, which has attracted attention from researchers and resulted in case studies.

question: The youngest daughter of Lady Mary-Gaye Curzon stars with Douglas Smith and Lucien Laviscount  in what 2017 film?
pos: "The Bye Bye Man" is a spooky movie from 2017 directed by Stacy Title and written by Jonathan Penner. It's based on a chapter from Robert Damon Schneck's book, "The President's Vampire." The cast includes Douglas Smith, Lucien Laviscount, Cressida Bonas, Doug Jones, Carrie-Anne Moss, Faye Dunaway, and Jenna Kanell.

Cressida Curzon Bonas, born on February 18, 1989, is an English actress, dancer, and model. She is the youngest daughter of Lady Mary-Gaye Curzon and entrepreneur Jeffrey Bonas, and her grandfather is Edward Curzon, who held the title of 6th Earl Howe.
neg: The movie "Love Beats Rhymes," previously called "Coco," is a musical drama directed by RZA. It follows a 25-year-old female rapper from Brooklyn, New York, played by Azealia Banks, who dreams of making it big in the music industry. The cast includes Lorraine Toussaint, Jill Scott, Lucien Laviscount, MC Jin, Hana Mae Lee, and Common. It's set for release by CodeBlack Films and Lionsgate.

Princess Olga of Hanover and Cumberland (1884–1958) was the youngest daughter of Ernest Augustus, Crown Prince of Hanover, and Princess Thyra of Denmark. Thyra was the youngest daughter of Christian IX of Denmark and Louise of Hesse-Kassel. Olga was a descendant of George III of the United Kingdom and Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz.

Sian Powers is a character in the British TV show Coronation Street, played by Sacha Parkinson. She first appeared in January 2009 as Sophie Webster's love interest. Sian, along with Ben Richardson, joined the show as Sophie's schoolmates. They, along with Ryan Connor, formed a new teenage group. Sian and Sophie became the show's first lesbian couple. Sacha Parkinson left the show on May 29, 2011, with her final appearance on screen on December 30, 2011.

One Night in Istanbul, also called One Night in Istanbul: The Movie, is a British film that blends comedy and drama. James Marquand directs it, and Nicky Allt both produces and writes it. The cast includes Steven Waddington, Paul Barber, Lucien Laviscount, Samantha Womack, and Ingvar Eggert Sigurðsson. The movie is adapted from Nicky Allt's play of the same title.

Lady Alexandra Naldera Curzon, born on either March or April 20, 1904, and passing away on August 7, 1995, was the third daughter of George Curzon, who was the 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston and served as Viceroy of India. Her mother was Mary Victoria Curzon, originally Mary Leiter, an American heiress. Lady Alexandra was named after Queen Alexandra, her godmother, and the place of her conception, Naldehra, India. Anne de Courcy wrote about Lady Alexandra and her two older sisters in a book titled "The Viceroy's Daughters: The Lives of the Curzon Sisters."

Gelston Castle, situated in Dumfries and Galloway, Great Britain, was originally built for Sir William Douglas of Castle Douglas, who obtained the Gelston lands in 1799. When Sir William died in 1809 without children, his property was split among various nieces and nephews. Gelston went to the youngest daughter of his brother James, Mathilda Douglas. In 1813, Mathilda married William Maitland, and their family managed the estate for most of the 19th Century. Later, Gelston was owned by the Galliers-Pratts, who mainly used it for pheasant shooting. During World War II, the castle was taken over for military purposes and housed handicapped boys from Glasgow. After this, the roof was removed.
"Bottom of the World" is a drama movie from 2017. Directed by Richard Sears, it features Jena Malone, Douglas Smith, and Ted Levine, with Brian Gottlieb as the writer.

Chainsaw is the third episode of the show Scream Queens, a mix of horror and comedy. It first aired on Fox on September 29, 2015. The episode was both directed and written by Ian Brennan. In this episode, the Red Devil continues to cause chaos on campus with a chainsaw. Chanel (played by Emma Roberts) takes on a new project involving Hester (played by Lea Michele), while Dean Munsch (played by Jamie Lee Curtis) assigns a new mascot for Wallace University. Meanwhile, Dean Munsch tries to break up the budding relationship between Gigi (played by Nasim Pedrad) and Wes (played by Oliver Hudson). Chad (played by Glen Powell) and Earl Grey (played by Lucien Laviscount) lead their fraternity in a hunt for the Red Devil.

question: Mummulgum is a stop on the Bruxner Highway before reaching the town on the banks of which river?
pos: Casino, located in the Northern Rivers region of New South Wales, Australia, had a population of 9,629 people in 2011. It sits beside the Richmond River, where the Bruxner Highway and the Summerland Way meet.

Mummulgum is a quaint countryside village in New South Wales, Australia, about 740 kilometers away from Sydney. Situated on Shannon Brook between Tenterfield and Casino, it lies along the Bruxner Highway (Highway 44), around 58 kilometers southwest of Kyogle. The village, along with its surrounding area, is under the local administration of Kyogle Council. The closest major town is Casino, located about 27 kilometers to the east of Mummulgum.
neg: Richmond Valley Council (RVC) is a local government area in the Northern Rivers region of northeastern New South Wales, Australia. It covers 3051 km2 and is named after the Richmond River, which flows through much of the area. The council manages an area located next to the Bruxner Highway, Pacific Highway, and the North Coast railway line.

Wollongbar, with a population of 2,396 as of 2011, is a town situated in the Northern Rivers area of New South Wales, Australia. It sits along the Bruxner Highway, positioned between the towns of Lismore and Alstonville.

Tabulam, a small countryside village in the northeastern part of New South Wales, Australia, sits about 800 kilometers away from the state's main city, Sydney. Positioned along the Bruxner Highway (Highway 44) between Tenterfield and Casino, Tabulam rests by the Clarence River. As of the 2006 Census, Tabulam had a population of 573 residents. The village falls under the jurisdiction of the Kyogle Council.

The Bruxner Highway is a 420 km road in New South Wales, Australia. It runs from the Northern Rivers coast to the Northern Tablelands in the northern part of the state, near the border with Queensland, going from east to west.

Alstonville, with a population of 5,648 in 2011, is a town located in northern New South Wales, Australia. It's situated in the Northern Rivers region and can be found on the Bruxner Highway. Specifically, it lies between Ballina, 13 km to the east, and Lismore, 19 km to the west. Additionally, the village of Wollongbar is just 4 km west of Alstonville. This town serves as the main hub for the Alstonville Plateau area.

Tenterfield, a town in New South Wales, Australia, sits at the crossroads of the New England and Bruxner Highways in the New England region. It's about a three-hour drive from Brisbane, Queensland, and Byron Bay, New South Wales, two hours from Armidale, New South Wales, and eight hours from Sydney. Tucked into a valley on the northwest side of the Northern Tableland plateau, it's bordered by the Great Dividing Range and overlooked by Mount MacKenzie, which stands at 1,287 meters tall. According to the 2015 census, Tenterfield had a population of 6,986.

Bonshaw, a village in New South Wales, Australia, sits about 783 km north of Sydney. In 2006, the village was home to 171 people. Positioned near the northern border of the state, it's close to Texas, Queensland, with the Dumaresq River acting as the boundary between the two states. Bonshaw falls within the Inverell Shire and Arrawatta County and is situated along the Bruxner Highway, linking Tenterfield and Goondiwindi. Primarily, it serves the agricultural community in the region.
Goonellabah, located in New South Wales, Australia, is an eastern suburb of Lismore, situated along the Bruxner Highway. As of the 2006 census, it had a population of 12,527 residents.

question: Which American audio engineer and clandestine chemist, who was a key figure in the San Francisco Bay Area hippie movement during the 1960s recorded the album "Old and in the Way?"
pos: Old and in the Way released their first album, "Old and in the Way," which was recorded on October 8, 1973, at the Boarding House in San Francisco by Owsley Stanley and Vickie Babcock using eight microphones (four per channel). The live recording was mixed directly onto a stereo Nagra tape recorder. The album cover features a caricature illustration by Greg Irons. Initially, it held the record for the best-selling bluegrass album until it was surpassed by the soundtrack album for "O Brother, Where Art Thou?"

Owsley Stanley, also known as Bear, was an important figure in the 1960s hippie movement in the San Francisco Bay Area. He was the sound engineer for the Grateful Dead, a role he took on after meeting them at a party. Stanley not only recorded their live performances and designed their logo but also created their massive Wall of Sound system, which was one of the biggest mobile speaker setups ever made.
neg: Jory Prum (January 31, 1975 – April 22, 2016), also called Jory K. Prum, was an American sound expert famous for his contributions to movies and video games. He owned a recording studio in the San Francisco Bay Area.

Oakland, California, is the biggest city in Alameda County and a significant port city on the West Coast. It's part of the East Bay region in the San Francisco Bay Area and is the third-largest city in that area, the eighth-largest in California, and the 45th largest in the entire United States. With a population of around 419,267 as of 2015, it's a bustling trade hub, home to the Port of Oakland, which is the busiest port in the San Francisco Bay, Northern California, and the fifth busiest in the entire USA. The city was established in 1852.

The Ragazzi Boys Chorus, based in the San Francisco Bay Area, gained recognition by winning a Grammy Award in 2000 for their involvement in Perséphone with the San Francisco Symphony. Established in 1987 with just six boys, the chorus has grown to over 170 singers from 86 schools across 26 Bay Area communities, including San Mateo, Santa Clara, and Santa Cruz counties. They have achieved high rankings in international competitions and consistently send the most singers to national or state American Choral Directors Association honor choirs annually.

Codornices Creek, sometimes spelled and pronounced Cordonices, is a creek that runs for about 2.0 miles. It originates in the Berkeley Hills in the East Bay area of California's San Francisco Bay Area. In its upper part, it flows entirely within Berkeley's city limits and forms the boundary with Albany in its lower section. Before Europeans settled in the area, Codornices Creek likely didn't connect directly to San Francisco Bay. It used to meander through grassland, eventually joining a larger marsh and waterway system with other creeks like Marin Creek and Schoolhouse Creek. However, in the 19th Century, a channel was dug, diverting Codornices Creek's flow directly to San Francisco Bay via a narrow slough next to the Golden Gate Fields racetrack.

The Association of Bay Area Governments (ABAG) is a planning agency for the San Francisco Bay Area in California, bringing together local governments from nine counties surrounding the Bay: Alameda, Contra Costa, Marin, Napa, San Francisco, San Mateo, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Solano, and Sonoma. ABAG sets goals for housing and transportation to prevent urban sprawl by requiring housing near workplaces. It addresses land use, housing, environmental quality, and economic development and accepts both non-profit and governmental members. All 101 cities within the Bay Area, along with the nine counties, can voluntarily join ABAG.

The San Francisco Bay Area Water Trail is a network of launch and landing sites designed for people using small, non-motorized boats like kayaks, canoes, and paddleboards to explore the San Francisco Bay safely. It connects communities to the bay and links existing shoreline open spaces and regional trails. Additionally, it focuses on educating users about personal and navigational safety and proper behavior near wildlife and habitats. This initiative is led by the California Coastal Conservancy, working closely with other organizations like the Association of Bay Area Governments, the San Francisco Bay Conservation and Development Commission, and the California Department of Boating and Waterways.

The Key System, also known as the Key Route, was a private transportation company that operated in several cities in the eastern San Francisco Bay Area from 1903 to 1960. It provided local streetcar and bus services in Oakland, Berkeley, Alameda, Emeryville, Piedmont, San Leandro, Richmond, Albany, and El Cerrito. Additionally, it offered commuter rail and bus routes connecting these areas to San Francisco via a ferry pier on San Francisco Bay, later using the lower deck of the Bay Bridge. At its peak in the 1940s, the Key System had more than 66 miles of track. However, local streetcar services were stopped in 1948, and commuter trains to San Francisco were discontinued in 1958. Today, the areas once served by the Key System are covered by BART and AC Transit bus services.

Gary Edson Arlington (October 7, 1938 – January 16, 2014) was an American who played a big role in the underground comix scene of the 1960s and 1970s. He owned the first comic book store in the US, called the San Francisco Comic Book Company, which was in the Mission District of San Francisco. This store became important for underground artists in the Bay Area. Arlington also published comics under the names San Francisco Comic Book Company and Eric Fromm. Cartoonist Robert Crumb has said that Gary made a big cultural impact in San Francisco from the late 1960s through the 1990s.

question: When was the palace founded at which Columba de Dunbar died in 1435?
pos: Columba de Dunbar, born in 1386 and passing away in 1435, served as the Bishop of Moray from 1422 until he died at Spynie Palace near Elgin, sometime before November 7, 1435.

Spynie Palace, previously called Spynie Castle, served as the fortified residence for the Bishops of Moray for roughly 500 years. It was established in the late 12th Century and is located around 500 meters from the site of the initial Cathedral Church of the Diocese of Moray, which is now known as Spynie Churchyard. Although it wasn't commonly referred to as a palace throughout its history, the term first appeared in official documents, like the Registry of Moray, in 1524.
neg: The Earl of Dunbar, also known as the Earl of Lothian or Earl of March, was the leader of an area in southeastern Scotland from the early 12th century to the early 15th century. Gospatric II was the first to hold this title, followed by George de Dunbar, who lost his titles and land in 1435. His son, Patrick, held onto a barony in Fife.

George de Dunbar, the 11th Earl of Dunbar & March, and also the Lord of Annandale and the Isle of Man, lived around 1370 to after 1457. He was the final member of his family to possess these noble titles.

Haripur Barabari, located in the Horipur Union of Nasirnagar Upazila in the Brahmanbaria district of Bangladesh (formerly East Bengal), is a palace established by Jamindar Krishna Prasad Roy Choudhury in the 18th century.

Gospatric, also known as Cospatric, was a powerful figure in medieval Northumbria and later controlled large estates near Dunbar. Although we're not exactly sure about his family background, his descendants ruled over Dunbar as Earls until 1435, when it became known as the Earldom of March in southeast Scotland.
Patrick IV, Earl of March (1242 – 10 October 1308), also known as Patrick de Dunbar, was a prominent figure in the border regions of Scotland and a key contender for the Scottish Crown.

George de Dunbar, the 10th Earl of Dunbar and March (1338–1420), held significant influence in Scotland during his era, and he often clashed with the Douglases, another powerful noble family. He also held titles such as the 12th Lord of Annandale and Lord of the Isle of Man.

Mike Dunbar was an American coach in football and baseball. He coached football at Central Washington University from 1983 to 1991 and at the University of Northern Iowa from 1997 to 2000. He also coached baseball at Central Washington in 1983. He graduated from the University of Washington in 1972 and Pacific Lutheran University in 1979. Dunbar passed away from cancer in 2013 at the age of 64 in Dupont, Washington.

Bishop Dunbar's Hospital, founded in 1531 by Bishop Gavin Dunbar, was supported by his endowment just before he died. King James V of Scotland approved its establishment, as recorded in the charter signed on 24 February 1531. The hospital, also known as St. Mary's Hospital, provided for bedesmen, who were residents supported by a charitable foundation. They were named after the word "bede," meaning prayer, as they said prayers in a cycle of Divine Office. The Bede House in Old Aberdeen served the bedesmen from 1789 until the late nineteenth century. Today, only a perimeter wall in Seaton Park, Old Aberdeen, remains of the original 1531 building. The last bedesman passed away in 1988, and the management of the hospital became the Bishop Dunbar Hospital Trust, which ceased operation in 2012.

question: Where is the Bubblegum Alley, that is similar to Gum Wall, located in California?
pos: San Luis Obispo, often abbreviated as SLO, is a city in California, USA. It sits about halfway between Los Angeles and San Francisco on the Central Coast. As of the 2010 census, the city had a population of 45,119, while San Luis Obispo County had a population of 269,637.

The Market Theater Gum Wall in downtown Seattle is a brick wall covered in used chewing gum. You can find it in Post Alley, right under Pike Place Market. It's like the Bubblegum Alley in San Luis Obispo, California, and it's a famous spot for locals. Some parts of this wall have layers of gum that are several inches thick and it stretches 15 feet high and 50 feet long.
neg: The Old US 67 Rest Area in rural Clark County, Arkansas, is a historic spot along the west side of U.S. Route 67. It's situated between Curtis and Gum Springs, marked by a semicircular fieldstone retaining wall with six pillars. You'll find a concrete bench facing a fieldstone well here. Constructed five years after US 67 was paved in 1931, it was a project of the National Youth Administration, a New Deal agency, in collaboration with the state highway department.

The Philadelphia Baseball Wall of Fame is a display of plaques honoring important figures from the history of the Philadelphia Phillies. It's located in Ashburn Alley at Citizens Bank Park. From 1978 to 2003, the Phillies and the Philadelphia Athletics (A's) would each annually select a notable person from their history to be honored, except in 1983 when the Phillies celebrated their Centennial Team. When Veterans Stadium closed in 2003, the Phillies' plaques were moved to Citizens Bank Park, but they stopped inducting notable Athletics players. Each plaque features the honoree's face, their role and years with the team, and a summary of their contributions. In 2004, the Athletics' plaques were moved to the Philadelphia Athletics Historical Society, and a single plaque listing all the A's inductees was placed on a statue of Connie Mack near Citizens Bank Park.

Ouch! is a sugar-free bubble gum produced by the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company under the Hubba Bubba brand. In the 1990s, it came in grape, watermelon, and strawberry flavors. The gum sticks were wrapped in paper resembling bandages and packed in metallic containers resembling bandage boxes. In October 2009, the gum was redesigned with new packaging and bubblegum flavor added. Each pack may contain one of twenty collectible games.

Hollywood Star Lanes was a bowling alley with 32 lanes on Santa Monica Boulevard in Los Angeles, California. It operated from 1960 to 2002 and appeared in movies like The Big Lebowski and The Big Empty. The Los Angeles Unified School District took over the land in 2002 to build an elementary school, closing the alley.

The Digital Media Factory is a place in Santa Cruz, California, where Marty Collins, Ginny Mitchell, Ned Hearn, and Brian Critchlow work together on multimedia projects. It used to be the Wrigley Gum factory on Mission Street.

The Up Your Alley Fair, also known as Dore Alley Fair or simply Dore Alley, is an event in San Francisco, California. It happens on the last Sunday of July on Folsom Street between 9th and 10th Streets, as well as on Dore Street from Howard Street to just a bit southeast of Folsom Street. You'll find lots of vendors' booths along the streets, and there's a dance stage at the end of Folsom Street near 10th Street.

Lower Louviers and Chicken Alley, also known as Louviers and Duck Street, are historic homes near Wilmington in New Castle County, Delaware. Built in 1811, Lower Louviers is a two- to three-story house made of stuccoed stone, featuring five bays. The middle three bays stick out slightly from the main structure. In 1935, a kitchen wing, a gated wall, and a garage were added to the house. It was owned by the Du Pont family. Additionally, Chicken Alley on the property is a well-preserved example of 19th-century workers' row houses.

Bubblegum Alley, located in downtown San Luis Obispo, California, is a popular spot where people stick their chewed bubble gum on the walls of an alley. The alley is about 15 feet tall and 70 feet long, spanning around 20 meters in the 700 block of Higuera Street.

question: At what venue was the January 2, 2012 game featured the University of Louisville team?
pos: In 2013, on January 2nd, there was a college football game called the Allstate Sugar Bowl. It happened at the Mercedes-Benz Superdome in New Orleans, Louisiana. The teams playing were the Florida Gators and the Louisville Cardinals. The game was shown live on ESPN at 8:30 PM Eastern Time. Louisville got to play in their first Sugar Bowl after having a 10-2 season and sharing the Big East title. Florida was chosen to play against them because they had an 11–1 season.

In 2012, the Louisville Cardinals football team, representing the University of Louisville, played in the NCAA Division I FBS football season. Coached by Charlie Strong for the third year, they played home games at Papa John's Cardinal Stadium and were part of the Big East Conference. They ended the season with an 11–2 record, including 5–2 in Big East matches, resulting in a tie for the conference championship with three other teams. Being the highest-ranked team among the Big East champions in the final BCS poll, they earned the conference's automatic bid to a BCS game, specifically the Sugar Bowl, where they defeated Florida.
neg: Parkway Field was a baseball stadium in Louisville, Kentucky, used by various teams from the 1920s to the late 1990s. It hosted the Louisville Colonels, the Louisville Buckeyes, and the University of Louisville team. The university team, led by Coach Gene Baker, had a reputation for hitting many home runs, particularly in the early 1990s. Players like Richie Hawks, Rob Newman, Greg Gooding, Dan Kopriva, Charlie Allen, and Darren Oppel were known for their power hitting. The team led the NCAA Division I in home runs in 1991 and 1992 and also excelled in batting average and slugging percentage in 1992. Despite their success, the stadium was eventually abandoned in 1998 when the university moved to Cardinal Stadium.

Dead or Alive 5 Plus, often written as DOA5+, is a fighting game part of the Dead or Alive series. It was made for the PlayStation Vita in March 2013 by Team Ninja with help from Sega AM2 and published by Tecmo Koei. It's basically a bigger version of the 2012 game Dead or Alive 5, but for handheld devices. People liked it more than the original game, giving it better reviews.

In the 1989 Sunkist Fiesta Bowl on January 2, 1989, the Notre Dame Fighting Irish played against the West Virginia Mountaineers. Both teams were unbeaten, making this bowl game a big deal, as it determined the National Championship for the second time in three years. Just like in 1987, the Fiesta Bowl showcased two independent schools vying for the national title. However, it wasn't a match between the #1 and #2 teams because the second-ranked Miami Hurricanes, who were also independent like Notre Dame and West Virginia, decided to play in the Orange Bowl instead.

In March 1956, the NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament took place at the Municipal Auditorium in Kansas City, Missouri. It was the 19th edition of the tournament, where 32 teams competed in a knockout format. This year marked the end of unseeded teams participating. The championship game saw McNeese State University (Louisiana) facing off against Texas Southern University. It was McNeese State's first and only appearance in the NAIA tournament, and they won against Texas Southern with a score of 60 to 55. In the third place match, Pittsburg State University (Kansas) defeated Wheaton College (Illinois) with a score of 77 to 70. Notably, six all-time leading scorers participated in this tournament.

The 2008 Tostitos Fiesta Bowl was a college football game that took place on January 2, 2008, at the University of Phoenix Stadium in Glendale, Arizona. It was part of the 2007–2008 Bowl Championship Series (BCS) during the 2007 NCAA Division I FBS football season. The game, which had been played annually since 1971, used to be held at Sun Devil Stadium on the campus of Arizona State University in Tempe, Arizona until 2006. It started at 8 p.m. EST. The match-up was between the fourth-ranked team (BCS), the Oklahoma Sooners, who were the Big 12 champions, and the ninth-ranked team (BCS), the West Virginia Mountaineers, who were the Big East champions. West Virginia won the game, beating Oklahoma 48–28, and it was broadcasted on Fox.

The NBL Canada All-Star Game happens once a year, featuring players from the Central and Atlantic Divisions. Each division picks ten players—five starters and five reserves—from their teams. These players are selected by coaches to showcase their skills at the All-Star Weekend. While no player has participated in three or more All-Star Games, ten have competed multiple times. In 2012, Joey Haywood and Eddie Smith served as captains, and players were grouped into teams without considering their division.

The 1989 Mobil Cotton Bowl Classic was a college football game held on January 2, 1989, at the Cotton Bowl in Dallas, Texas. It was scheduled for January 2 because New Year's Day was on a Sunday. The teams playing were the Arkansas Razorbacks from the Southwest Conference and the UCLA Bruins from the Pacific-10 Conference. The game was shown on CBS in the United States. Troy Aikman, UCLA's quarterback, and LaSalle Harper, an Arkansas linebacker, were chosen as the game's Most Valuable Players.

In March 1943, the 7th NAIA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament took place at the Municipal Auditorium in Kansas City, Missouri. The tournament included 32 teams competing in a single-elimination format. In the championship game, Southeast Missouri State University beat Northwest Missouri State University with a score of 34 to 32. This was the first time in the tournament's history that two teams from the same state, Missouri, played against each other in Missouri for the championship. Additionally, the 3rd place game saw the first overtime in NAIA Final Four history, with North Texas State University defeating Murray State College 59 to 55.

question: Which film was Oscar nominated, LaLee's Kin: The Legacy of Cotton or Gimme Shelter, the 1970 Rolling Stones documentary?
answer: LaLee's Kin: The Legacy of Cotton
pos: LaLee's Kin: The Legacy of Cotton is a documentary movie made in 2001 by directors Deborah Dickson, Susan Frömke, and Albert Maysles. It was up for an Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature at the 74th Academy Awards.

"Gimme Shelter" is a documentary made in 1970 by directors Albert and David Maysles, along with Charlotte Zwerin. It follows The Rolling Stones during the final weeks of their 1969 US tour, leading up to the chaotic Altamont Free Concert. The movie takes its name from the song "Gimme Shelter," which is the main track on the band's 1969 album "Let It Bleed." Although the film was shown at the 1971 Cannes Film Festival, it wasn't included in the main competition.
neg: "Gimme Shelter" is a track performed by The Rolling Stones.

Merry Clayton, born in 1948, is an American singer known for her work in soul and gospel music, as well as acting. She sang backup for many big artists in the 1960s, famously teaming up with Mick Jagger for the Rolling Stones hit "Gimme Shelter." Her story is featured in the award-winning documentary "20 Feet from Stardom," highlighting the role of background singers in music. In 2013, she put out "The Best of Merry Clayton," a collection of her top tracks.
"Gimme Shelter" is a collection of songs by The Rolling Stones, released on Decca Records in 1971. It peaked at number 19 on the U.K. charts.

Wenzell Baird Bryant, born on December 12, 1927, in Columbus, Indiana, and passing away on November 13, 2008, in Hemet, California, was an American filmmaker. He gained recognition for his work as a cameraman in the Albert Maysles documentary "Gimme Shelter." Bryant was the one who filmed the tragic moment when Meredith Hunter, a concertgoer at the Rolling Stones' performance, was fatally stabbed by a member of the Hells Angels, Alan Passaro, during the Altamont Free Concert in December 1969.

Stanton Hill is an American producer who works in broadcast and also lends his voice to characters. He's behind the creation of TV ads for big names like Pepsi, Activision, Nissan, Budweiser, McDonald's, Energizer, Jimmy Dean, and Visa. Back in 2007, he made a short film called "Stars," which won awards. It starred Kevin Durand and was directed by Jason Eli Lewis. Then in 2011, Hill was the brains behind the launch commercial for Call of Duty: Black Ops. It featured Kobe Bryant and used the Rolling Stones song "Gimme Shelter."

Alamont Diary is the first album by the Melbourne electronica band Black Cab. It came out in 2004 and tells the story of the infamous 1969 free concert at Altamont Speedway in California, which was headlined by the Rolling Stones. The music style of the album is a mix of psychedelic and country sounds. It includes recordings of Sam Cutler, the former tour manager of the Rolling Stones, taken from the 1970 documentary film Gimme Shelter.

Keith Richards, born on December 18, 1943, is an English musician famous for his roles as a guitarist, singer, songwriter, and author. He is best recognized as a founding member of the iconic rock band, the Rolling Stones. Rolling Stone magazine has praised Richards for his outstanding guitar riffs, ranking him 4th on its list of the 100 best guitarists. He has co-written fourteen songs with Mick Jagger, the lead vocalist of the Rolling Stones, which have been included in Rolling Stone magazine's list of the 500 Greatest Songs of All Time. Throughout the band's history, Richards has been known for his guitar interplay, alternating between rhythm and lead with other band members like Brian Jones, Mick Taylor, and Ronnie Wood. Despite this collaborative style, Richards is the sole guitarist on several of the band's most famous tracks, such as "Paint It Black," "Ruby Tuesday," "Sympathy for the Devil," and "Gimme Shelter."

"Gimme Shelter" kicks off the 1969 album "Let It Bleed" by the Rolling Stones. While it was spelled "Gimmie" on that album, later recordings by the band and other artists adopted "Gimme" as the standard spelling. In a review for Rolling Stone magazine, Greil Marcus hailed the song as the band's finest work up to that point.

question: Which board game was published most recently, Pirate's Cove or Catan?
pos: Pirate's Cove, also known as Piratenbucht in German, is a board game created by Paul Randles and Daniel Stahl. It was first released in Germany in 2002 by Amigo Spiele, featuring illustrations by Markus Wagner and Swen Papenbrock. In 2003, Days of Wonder reissued the game with updated graphics by Julien Delval and Cyrille Daujean. In this game, players take on the role of pirate captains, aiming to collect treasure from islands and gain reputation by outsmarting other pirates in battles at sea.

The board game Settlers of Catan, often just called Catan, was created by Klaus Teuber and first released in 1995 in Germany. In the game, players act as settlers, trying to build and grow their settlements by trading and gathering resources. Points are earned as settlements expand, and the first player to reach a certain number, usually 10, wins. The game, along with its expansions, is published by several companies including Mayfair Games, Filosofia, Capcom, 999 Games, Κάισσα, and Devir.
neg: Catan Histories: Struggle for Rome is a board game released in 2006, inspired by Settlers of Catan. It's designed by Klaus Teuber, the creator of Settlers, and is published by Kosmos in German and Mayfair Games in English. The game focuses on the decline of the Western Roman Empire. It's part of the Catan Histories series and, like many multi-language releases, may have slight rule variations between versions.

The Kids of Catan is a board game from Germany meant for children, based on The Settlers of Catan theme. It's made by Klaus Teuber and sold by Kosmos in German and Mayfair Games in English, like other Catan games.

The Rivals for Catan is a card game version of The Settlers of Catan released in 2010. It's designed for two players and is part of the Catan series, published by Kosmos in German and Mayfair Games in English. The game is based on the Rebecca Gablé novel inspired by the original board game.

Catan: Seafarers, also known as Seafarers of Catan in older versions, is an expansion of the popular board game The Settlers of Catan designed for three to four players (though with extensions, five to six players can also play). This expansion introduces ships, gold rivers, and a pirate, enabling gameplay between multiple islands. It offers various scenarios, some with unique rules, all of which are mostly compatible with the base game and its expansions.

The Catan Card Game, once known as The Settlers of Catan: The Card Game, is a card-based version of The Settlers of Catan board game. It's part of the Catan series, published by Kosmos in German and Mayfair Games in English. While designed for two players, you can adjust the rules to share a set or have each player use their own. Additionally, there have been seven expansions released for the game.

Catan: Cities & Knights is an expansion for The Settlers of Catan board game, designed for three to four players (but can accommodate five to six players with extra extensions). It focuses on developing cities and using knights for both attacking opponents and defending against common enemies. You can mix Cities & Knights with other expansions or scenarios, though playing with five to six players requires the appropriate extensions.

The Catan Dice Game, created by Klaus Teuber in 2007, is a board game inspired by his famous Settlers of Catan. It's published by Catan GmbH and its partners, Kosmos in Germany and Mayfair Games in English-speaking regions. You can play it with any number of players, but it's best with up to four. There's also a version called Catan Dice Game Plus, which you can find for free on the Catan website, and it's more similar to the original Settlers game.

Elasund: The First City, a board game by Klaus Teuber, is part of the Catan Adventures series, following the success of The Settlers of Catan. Published by Kosmos in German and Mayfair Games in English, Elasund shares a theme with Settlers but has entirely different gameplay mechanics.

question: Alice David is the voice of Lara Croft in a video game developed by which company ?
pos: Tomb Raider is a video game where you play as Lara Croft, developed by Crystal Dynamics and published by Square Enix. It's the tenth game in the series but serves as a fresh start, telling Lara's backstory. It first came out on March 5, 2013, for Windows, PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360. Later, it was released for OS X on January 23, 2014, and for Linux on April 27, 2016.

Alice David, born on March 22, 1987, is a French actress famous for her roles in the TV show "Bref" (2011) and the movie "Babysitting" (2014). She also lends her voice to the French version of Lara Croft in the video game "Tomb Raider."
neg: Tomb Raider is a popular series that includes video games, comics, books, movies, and even theme park attractions. It follows the adventures of Lara Croft, a fictional British archaeologist. Since the first game came out in 1996, it has become a big franchise, with Lara Croft becoming a well-known figure in the video game world. Lara Croft even holds a Guinness World Record for being the Most Successful Human Videogame Heroine, recognized in 2006. The series was initially developed by Core Design, but Crystal Dynamics took over for the latest four games.
