Eidos Interactive first published all the games, but they are now part of Square Enix, which owns the rights to Tomb Raider. Angelina Jolie starred as Lara Croft in two movies, with a reboot announced in 2016.

Tomb Raider, originally called Lara Croft: Tomb Raider from 2001 to 2007, is a popular series created by a British company called Core Design. It's about a fictional archaeologist named Lara Croft who travels the globe looking for ancient treasures in dangerous places. The games usually involve exploring, solving puzzles, dodging traps, and fighting enemies. The series has also inspired movies, comics, and books.

Lara Croft Go, released in 2015, is a puzzle video game set in the Tomb Raider series. Players control Lara Croft through levels like moving a puzzle piece on a game board, avoiding obstacles and changing the environment. The game simplifies key elements of the series, like running from rolling boulders, to fit its turn-based style. Developed by Square Enix Montreal, it follows the style of their 2014 game Hitman Go. Lara Croft Go initially launched for Android, iOS, Windows, and Windows Phone in August 2015, with a PlayStation 4 and PlayStation Vita version following in November 2016.

"Tomb Raider III: Adventures of Lara Croft" is a video game made by Core Design and published by Eidos Interactive in 1998 for PlayStation and Windows. It's the third game in the series, following Tomb Raider II. In the game, Lara Croft searches for four meteorite pieces worldwide. Players explore five places—India, South Pacific, London, Nevada, and Antarctica—solving puzzles, jumping obstacles, and battling enemies to progress.

"Lara Croft and the Temple of Osiris" is a game where you control Lara Croft, developed by Crystal Dynamics and published by Square Enix. It's available on PC, PS4, and Xbox One. This game is the follow-up to "Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light" from 2010 and is part of a spin-off series within the Tomb Raider franchise. The announcement for "Temple of Osiris" was made at E3 2014. In the game, Lara Croft, voiced by Keeley Hawes, is the main character exploring the Temple of Osiris.

"Lara Croft: Tomb Raider" is a movie from 2001, based on the video game series about Lara Croft, played by Angelina Jolie. It was made with the help of multiple countries, including the US, UK, Japan, and Germany. The story follows Lara as she battles the Illuminati to get valuable ancient artifacts.

Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light is a game where you play as Lara Croft or a Mayan warrior named Totec. It's different from other Tomb Raider games because it focuses a lot on playing with friends. You can play on different devices like computers, PlayStation, Xbox, Android, and iOS. In the game, you and your friend need to team up to defeat a bad spirit named Xolotl and get back the Mirror of Smoke. There's also a mode where you can play alone without any computer-controlled characters helping you.

Lara Croft, the lead character in the Tomb Raider video game series by Square Enix (formerly Eidos Interactive), is depicted as a smart, athletic, and attractive British archaeologist who explores dangerous ancient tombs and ruins worldwide. Created in 1996 by a team at Core Design in the UK, she has since appeared in sequels, comics, animated shorts, and movies (played by Angelina Jolie and later by Alicia Vikander), as well as various merchandise. Lara Croft has been heavily marketed, appearing on numerous magazine covers and being featured in promotions like clothing lines, action figures, and advertisements.

question: Which Eminem album included vocals from a singer who had an album titled "Unapologetic"?
pos: "The Monster" is a song by Eminem, featuring Rihanna, from his album "The Marshall Mathers LP 2" released in 2013. It's their fourth collaboration together. Eminem, Jon Bellion, and Bebe Rexha wrote the song, and Frequency handled production. It was released as the album's fourth single on October 29, 2013. The lyrics delve into Rihanna facing her inner struggles, while Eminem reflects on the downsides of his fame.

"Numb" is a song by Rihanna from her album "Unapologetic" released in 2012. The song includes vocals from Eminem, marking their third collaboration since "Love the Way You Lie." After the album came out, "Numb" made it onto various charts globally, including in Canada, the United Kingdom, and the United States.
neg: "Better Off Alone" is a song by Alice Deejay, which is a trance music project created by Dutch producer Jürgen Rijkers, also known as DJ Jurgen, along with Sebastiaan Molijn and Eelke Kalberg, who go by the name Pronti & Kalmani. Originally released as an instrumental track by DJ Jurgen in 1998 on Violent Records, it later included vocals by Judith Pronk, who became an important member of the Alice Deejay project.

Rabid Neurosis (RNS) was a group that shared pirated MP3 music files. They started in 1996, following another group called Compress 'Da Audio (CDA). By 1999, they claimed to release over 6,000 titles each year. They often used the slogan "Rabid Neurosis - Spread The Epidemic." RNS was famous for leaking albums by hip hop, pop, rock, and dance artists before their official release dates. They played a significant role in the MP3 scene. After their mention in an MTV News article about the early leak of Eminem's album "Encore," RNS stopped using their initials in filenames and ID3 tags.

"Dropping the World" is a track by Lil Wayne, with Eminem as a featured artist, from Lil Wayne's album "Rebirth." It was released on iTunes in December 2009 and later performed by Lil Wayne, Eminem, and Travis Barker at the 52nd Grammy Awards in 2010. The song received quadruple platinum certification from the RIAA on April 10, 2014. Additionally, it's also known as "Eminem x Lil Wayne - Drop the World" on Eminem's Detroit King hidden video album.

"You and Me" is the second single by the UK group Uniting Nations, released right after their successful remake of Hall and Oates' "Out of Touch." The song is also featured on their album "One World" and introduces Craig Powell as a new member of the band. Vocals on the track are provided by studio session artist Jinian Wilde.

Encore, also stylized as ƎNCORE and occasionally referred to as Curtains Down, is a song performed by Eminem, 50 Cent, and Dr. Dre. It was released in 2004 as a vinyl single in the U.S. and served as the title track for Eminem's album of the same name, which was also released that year. The song, which marks the third single and final track from the album, features all three artists collaborating together.

On February 11, 2014, it was confirmed that the album's production team included producers like Stu Bangas, C-Lance, Leaf Dog, Panik, and Apathy from Army of the Pharaohs, along with some new faces. To promote "In Death Reborn," Vinnie Paz dropped "The Flawless Victory" mixtape on March 2, 2014. Reef the Lost Cauze also released a collaborative album called "Fast Way" with producer Emyd on March 9, 2014. Doap Nixon only appeared on one song due to personal reasons but promised more involvement in the LP set to release in November. King Syze released his fourth studio album, "Union Terminology," a month before "In Death Reborn." Apathy delayed his album "Connecticut Casual" from April to June to focus on "In Death Reborn." Zilla announced his fourth studio album, "Martyr Musick," set to release in June 2014, just before "In Death Reborn" dropped. The group followed up with their second album of the year, "Heavy Lies the Crown," on October 21, 2014, six months after "In Death Reborn."

Linkin Park, a rock band from the United States, has made music for seven albums. Their latest one, "One More Light," came out in 2017, with the song "Heavy" as a global release. The band started in Los Angeles in 1996 with three friends from high school: Mike Shinoda, Rob Bourdon, and Brad Delson. They later added Joe Hahn, Dave Phoenix Farrell, and Mark Wakefield to become a six-piece group. Chester Bennington replaced Mark Wakefield as the lead vocalist. Linkin Park struggled to get noticed by big record labels until Jeff Blue, who was then the vice president of Warner Bros. Records, helped them sign in 1999. Their breakthrough came with the album "Hybrid Theory" in 2000, featuring hit singles like "One Step Closer," "Crawling," "Papercut," and "In the End." They followed up with a remix album called "Reanimation" in 2002, which reached the second spot on the Billboard 200 chart and sold nearly 270,000 copies in its first week.

Barbara Higbie, born in 1958, is a talented musician known for her piano, violin, and singing skills. She's been recognized with Grammy and Bammy awards. With over 65 CDs under her belt, including contributions to Carlos Santana's recent album, she's made her mark in the music world. Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, she's been part of various record labels and is admired for her folk, jazz, pop, and fusion music styles. Since the 1980s, she's been touring globally, collaborating with other artists and releasing solo albums. Notably, she co-founded the group Montreux and recorded acclaimed albums with singer Teresa Trull in the '80s and '90s. Her music is praised for its melodic and soulful qualities.

question: This American crime film set in South Los Angeles was written and directed by the same director and writer of screenwriter of "Street Kings", "End of Watch", "Sabotage", "Fury" and what other film?
pos: David Ayer, born on January 18, 1968, is an American filmmaker who has worked as a director, producer, and screenwriter. He gained recognition for writing "Training Day" (2001) and for directing and writing films like "Harsh Times" (2005), "Street Kings" (2008), "End of Watch" (2012), "Sabotage" (2014), "Fury" (2014), and "Suicide Squad" (2016).

Harsh Times is a crime movie from 2005, taking place in South Los Angeles. It features actors like Christian Bale and Freddy Rodriguez, and it was both written and directed by David Ayer, known for his work on Training Day. The movie reflects Ayer's experiences and the people he encountered while living in South Central.
neg: West Athens is a neighborhood in Los Angeles County, California, United States. It had a population of 8,729 people in 2010, which decreased from 9,101 in 2000. It's not officially part of any city, falling under the 2nd Supervisorial District of Los Angeles County. Policing is handled by the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department. West Athens is roughly bordered by 87th Street to the north, Vermont Avenue to the east, El Segundo Boulevard to the south, and approximately Western Avenue to Van Ness Avenue to the west. It's mostly residential, with some shops along the main streets. Los Angeles Southwest Community College is located there too.

Central Avenue is a big road that goes north to south in the middle of Los Angeles. It starts near the eastern part of downtown LA and goes south until it reaches Del Amo Boulevard in Carson. Along the way, it goes through Downtown LA, South LA, Compton, and Carson, passing by California State University, Dominguez Hills.

"End of Watch" is a crime drama movie from 2012, created by David Ayer. It features Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Peña as Brian Taylor and Miguel Zavala, LAPD officers stationed in South Los Angeles. The movie follows their daily work routines, interactions with a specific gang, their bond as friends, and their personal lives.

Bonsallo Avenue is a street in South Los Angeles with two parts around four miles apart. The northern part, in historic West Adams near downtown, has six Los Angeles Historic-Cultural Monuments. The southern part is close to Slauson Avenue, situated between Los Angeles' Mt Carmel and Hoover-Gage parks.

The DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel Los Angeles Downtown is in Los Angeles, California, USA. It's managed by Rim Hospitality Inc. and sits in the Little Tokyo area of downtown Los Angeles at 120 South Los Angeles Street.

"South of 8" is a 2016 American crime movie about a series of bank robberies in the near future. It's directed by Tony Olmos, who wrote the screenplay alongside Rosewood Five Productions. The film premiered on September 26, 2016, at the Downtown Los Angeles Film Festival, where it won the jury award for Best Dramatic Screenplay. Before its premiere, it also won 'Best Trailer' at the San Diego Film Awards and was a finalist for Audience Choice #TrailerChallenge at DTLAFF via Indi.com. Additionally, it screened at San Diego Film Week on February 11, 2017, and won the award for Best Horror/SciFi/Thriller Feature.

"Street Kings 2: Motor City" is a crime movie made in 2011. It features Ray Liotta and was directed by Chris Fisher. This movie follows up on "Street Kings," which came out in 2008 with Keanu Reeves. "Street Kings 2: Motor City" was released straight to DVD in the United States on April 19, 2011.

Barriox13, also known as B13, is a street gang in South Los Angeles with more than 200 members, although many are not currently active. The gang is split into two factions: West Side Barriox13 and East Side Barriox13, but all members remain loyal to the main Barriox13 group. The gang was formed in the early 1980s near El Segundo Boulevard and Main St in South Los Angeles, California, initially as a means of self-defense for its original members. Barriox13 is aligned with Hispanic prison gangs and identifies as a South Side (Sureno) gang.

question: SuperMansion starred the actress who had a recurring role as whom on Workaholics?
pos: SuperMansion is a funny TV show made with stop-motion animation in America. It was created by Matthew Senreich and Zeb Wells. The main actors are Bryan Cranston, Heidi Gardner, Tucker Gilmore, Keegan-Michael Key, Tom Root, Yvette Nicole Brown, Zeb Wells, and Jillian Bell. It first aired on Crackle on October 8, 2015.

Jillian Leigh Bell, born on April 25, 1984, is an American comedian, actress, and screenwriter. You might recognize her from shows like Workaholics, where she played Jillian Belk, or from the last season of Eastbound & Down, where she portrayed Dixie. She's also appeared in movies like 22 Jump Street and Fist Fight (2017).
neg: Helen Modern, born on February 16, 1983, is an English actress known for her roles in the British sitcom "Respectable" on Five, where she played the character Naomi. She also appeared in the eighth series of the ITV1 drama "Bad Girls" in 2006 as Stella Gough, the daughter of Governing Governor Joy Masterton. Apart from these shows, Helen has appeared in BBC One's daytime soap opera "Doctors" in 2005 as Diane Bishop, and she has had various roles in other series like "No Angels," "Wire in the Blood," "The Chase," and "Messiah - The Harrowing" alongside actors Ken Stott and Maxine Peake.

Mitch Pileggi, born April 5, 1952, is an American actor famous for playing Walter Skinner in The X-Files. He also appeared regularly as Colonel Steven Caldwell in Stargate Atlantis and had roles in the 2008 film Flash of Genius and the TV series Sons of Anarchy as Ernest Darby. From 2012 to 2014, he starred as Harris Ryland in the TNT reboot of Dallas.

John Amos Jr. is an American actor best known for playing James Evans, Sr. on the TV show Good Times. He's also been in The Mary Tyler Moore Show, Roots, and The West Wing. You might remember him as Lisa Wilkes' dad on The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air or as Coach Sam Wilson on In the House. He's played other roles too, like Sgt. Strawn on Martin and Edward Boynton on Two and a Half Men. Plus, he was in Die Hard 2 as Major Grant. He's been in Broadway shows and lots of movies over the years, and he's been nominated for awards like the Primetime Emmy and NAACP Image Award.

Hilarie Ross Burton, an American actress and producer born on July 1, 1982, is known for several roles in TV shows and movies. She used to host MTV's Total Request Live and played Peyton Sawyer on the show One Tree Hill for six seasons (2003–09). Burton became more widely known for her roles in movies like Our Very Own, Solstice, and The List. She also appeared as Sara Ellis in the crime drama White Collar (2010–13) and as Dr. Lauren Boswell in Grey's Anatomy in 2013. In 2014, she was in the ABC drama Forever as Molly Dawes and had a recurring part in the CBS sci-fi drama Extant as Anna Schaefer in 2015. Then, in 2016, Burton took on a recurring role as DEA Agent Karen Palmer in the Fox action dramedy Lethal Weapon.

Jo Marie Payton, born on August 3, 1950, is an American actress and singer known for her roles in television. She played Harriette Winslow, the mother figure in the Winslow family, in the sitcom "Family Matters" aired on ABC/CBS. Additionally, she had a recurring role in the show's parent series "Perfect Strangers." From 2001 to 2005, Payton voiced the character Suga Mama Proud in Bruce W. Smith's "The Proud Family" on the Disney Channel, which earned her a nomination for an NAACP Image Award in 2005. She also appeared in a recurring role as the personal assistant to Gregory Hines' character, Ben Doucette, during the second season of "Will & Grace" (1999–2000).

Jenna Dewan Tatum, born Jenna Lee Dewan on December 3, 1980, is an American actress and dancer. She started out as a backup dancer for Janet Jackson and later worked with artists like Pink, Missy Elliott, and Christina Aguilera. Her notable role was Nora Clark in the 2006 movie Step Up. Jenna also appeared in the short-lived NBC show The Playboy Club and had a recurring role in the FX series American Horror Story. On Lifetime, she played Freya Beauchamp in Witches of East End, and starting in 2016, she had a recurring role as Lucy Lane in Supergirl.

John Pappas, born on November 11, 1951, is an American actor, playwright, and former comic. He's been in TV and movies since the 1970s. Pappas is most famous for playing Pappas on the TV show "Hardball" (NBC 1989-1990) and Leo Sullivan on "Days of Our Lives" (NBC 1994). He came back to "Days of Our Lives" in 2001 as a character named Buddy. Pappas has won awards for acting, including a Best Actor award from L.A. Weekly in 1990 for his role in "BAD COUNTRY" by Gilbert Girion, and two Drama-Logue awards in 1988 and 1989.

Jeff Hephner, an American actor born on June 22, 1975, is known for his roles in various TV shows. He played Matt Ramsey in the third season of "The O.C." and Morgan Stanley Buffkin in "Easy Money." Additionally, he appeared as football coach Red Raymond in "Hellcats" and as Ben Zajac in "Boss" alongside Kelsey Grammer. He starred as John Case in "Agent X" and had a recurring role as Jeff Clarke in NBC's "Chicago Fire" and its spin-off "Chicago Med."

question: The 1974 Texas Tech Raiders football team represented what public research university in Lubbock, Texas?
pos: Texas Tech University, also known as Texas Tech or TTU, is a public research university located in Lubbock, Texas. It was founded on October 10, 1923, originally named Texas Technological College. It's the main school within the Texas Tech University System. As of Fall 2014, it has the sixth-largest student population in Texas. The campus also includes the Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center, making it unique in Texas for housing an undergraduate university, law school, and medical school all in one place.

In 1974, the Texas Tech Red Raiders football team played for Texas Tech University in the Southwest Conference during the NCAA Division I football season. Coached by Jim Carlen for the fifth and final season, the team had a 6–4–2 record, ranking sixth in the conference. They scored 193 points while allowing 158. Notable players were Tommy Duniven, who passed for 552 yards, Larry Isaac, who rushed for 671 yards, and Lawrence Williams, who had 477 receiving yards. They played their home games at Clifford B. & Audrey Jones Stadium.
neg: In 2013, the Texas Tech Red Raiders football team played in the NCAA Division I FBS football season as part of the Big 12 Conference. Kliff Kingsbury was their head coach for the first time, and they played their home games at Jones AT&T Stadium in Lubbock, Texas.

In 2015, the Texas Tech Red Raiders football team played in the NCAA Division I FBS football season as part of the Big 12 Conference. Kliff Kingsbury was the head coach for his third season. They played their home games at Jones AT&T Stadium in Lubbock, Texas. The team ended the season with 7 wins and 6 losses, ranking 7th in the conference with a 4-5 record. They were selected to play in the Texas Bowl but lost to LSU.

In 2009, the Texas Tech Red Raiders football team, led by coach Mike Leach for most of the regular season and interim head coach Ruffin McNeill for the Valero Alamo Bowl, played their home games at Jones AT&T Stadium in Lubbock, Texas. They competed in the NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision, finishing the season with a 9–4 record, 5–3 in Big 12 games, and won the Valero Alamo Bowl against Michigan State with a score of 41–31.

The 1986 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team, led by head coach David McWilliams for one season, competed in the Southwest Conference during the 1986 NCAA Division I-A football season. They achieved a 7–4 record in the regular season (5–3 against SWC opponents), tying for fourth place in the conference. The team participated in the 1986 Independence Bowl but lost to Ole Miss with a score of 20 to 17, with Spike Dykes as the coach for that game. Throughout the season, they scored a total of 271 points while allowing 268 points from opponents. Home games were played at Clifford B. and Audrey Jones Stadium in Lubbock, Texas.

The 2012 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team played in the 2012 NCAA Division I FBS football season as part of the Big 12 Conference. Their coach, Tommy Tuberville, led the team in his third season. They played their home games at Jones AT&T Stadium in Lubbock, Texas. The team ended the season with an 8–5 record, 4–5 in Big 12 games, tying for fifth place with three other teams. They were invited to the Meineke Car Care Bowl of Texas and won against Minnesota.

The 2014 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team played in the 2014 NCAA Division I FBS football season as part of the Big 12 Conference. Their coach, Kliff Kingsbury, led the team for his second season. They played their home games at Jones AT&T Stadium in Lubbock, Texas. The season ended with the Red Raiders achieving a 4–8 overall record, finishing 2–7 in Big 12 games, and landing in eighth place.

The Texas A&M–Texas Tech football rivalry was a matchup between the football teams of Texas A&M University and Texas Tech University. It all started back in 1927. From 1957, when they both joined the same conference, this rivalry went on without a break. Currently, Texas A&M is ahead in the series, winning 37 games to Texas Tech's 32, with one tie. Texas A&M initially dominated from 1927 to 1955 when they weren't in the same conference, leading 12 wins to 3. Then, during Texas Tech's early years in the Southwest Conference (1957–59), they won 2 out of 3 games. The series was pretty close during the Southwest Conference years (1960–1995), with Texas A&M slightly ahead at 18 wins to 17. When the teams were in the Big 12 Conference (1996–2011), Texas Tech led with 10 wins to 6. Both teams have had their good streaks; Texas Tech once won 6 games in a row from 1968 to 1973, while Texas A&M had a nonconsecutive winning streak of 6 games in 1927, 1932, and 1942 through 1945. Right now, Texas A&M has won the last three games, but since they left the Big 12 in 2012, it's unclear if this rivalry will continue.

In 2016, the Texas Tech Red Raiders football team played in the NCAA Division I FBS as part of the Big 12 Conference. Kliff Kingsbury served as head coach for his fourth season. The team played their home games at Jones AT&T Stadium in Lubbock, Texas, finishing the season with a 5–7 record overall and 3–6 in Big 12 matches.

question: During Siege of Bharatpur, which Commander-in-Chief of Ireland and Commander-in-Chief of India contributed to the storming of the castle?
pos: Field Marshal Stapleton Cotton, 1st Viscount Combermere (14 November 1773 – 21 February 1865), was a British Army officer, diplomat, and politician. He served in various military campaigns, including the Flanders Campaign, the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War, and the suppression of Robert Emmet's insurrection in 1803. Later, he led a cavalry brigade under Sir Arthur Wellesley's command during the Peninsular War and eventually took charge of all cavalry forces in the later stages of the conflict. He also held positions as Commander-in-Chief in Ireland and India. Notably, he successfully led the storming of Bharatpur, a previously thought impregnable fort, during his time in India.

The Siege of Bharatpore happened in December 1825 and January 1826 in the Indian princely state of Bharatpur, which is now part of Rajasthan. British troops led by Lord Combermere surrounded the capital and eventually stormed and captured its fortress on January 18, 1826.
neg: Maharaja Surajmal Brij University, previously known as Brij University, is a public university in Bharatpur, Rajasthan, India. It was established in 2012 by the Rajasthan government under the Brij University, Bharatpur Act, 2012. In 2014, it was renamed Maharaja Surajmal Brij University, Bharatpur, in honor of Maharaja Surajmal, through the Brij University, Bharatpur (Change of Name) Act, 2014. Ashwini Kumar Bansal became the Vice Chancellor of the university in February 2017.

Bharatpur District, located in western India, Rajasthan state, is often referred to as the Jat Kingdom. The district's administrative center is the town of Bharatpur. It's also included in the National Capital Region (NCR).

Field Marshal Sir Claude Auchinleck was a British Army leader in World War II. He spent much of his military career in India, eventually becoming Commander-in-Chief of the Indian Army by early 1941. In July 1941, he took charge of the Middle East theater but was relieved of duty in 1942 during the Alamein campaign when the North African war turned against the British. He was then appointed Commander-in-Chief India again in June 1943, where he played a crucial role in supporting Slim's Fourteenth Army through supply, maintenance, and training. He continued in this role until Partition in 1947, when he became the Supreme Commander of all British forces in India and Pakistan until late 1948.

Vishvendra Singh, born on June 23, 1962, at Moti Mahal in Bharatpur, Rajasthan, is a member of the Legislative Assembly representing the Deeg-Kumher Constituency. He is the son of the former ruler of Bharatpur. Following the 26th amendment to the Indian Constitution in 1971, the Indian government got rid of all official symbols associated with princely states, such as titles, privileges, and financial allowances (privy purses).

Bharatpur is a city in the Indian state of Rajasthan that recently became a municipal corporation. It's in the Braj region and was once known for being very strong and difficult to conquer. The city is about 180 km south of New Delhi, 178 km from Jaipur, the capital of Rajasthan, 55 km west of Agra, and 34 km from Mathura, where Lord Krishna was born. It's the main hub for Bharatpur District and Bharatpur Division of Rajasthan. The Royal House of Bharatpur has a history dating back to the 11th century, and Bharatpur is also part of the National Capital Region (NCR).

Lohagarh Fort, also known as the Iron Fort, is located in Bharatpur, Rajasthan, India. It was built by the Bharatpur Jat rulers, particularly Maharaja Suraj Mal, who dedicated his resources to constructing forts and palaces throughout his kingdom. Lohagarh Fort stands out as one of the most formidable forts in Indian history. During the British siege in 1805, led by Lord Lake, the virtually impenetrable fort withstood attacks for over six weeks. It features two gates: the Ashtdhaatu Gate to the north, made of eight metals, and the Chowburja Gate to the south, with four pillars.

During the British Raj, the Commander-in-Chief, India, was the top leader of the British Indian Army. They were stationed at General Headquarters, India, and worked closely with the civilian Governor-General of India. After India's partition in 1947, the role was eliminated and briefly replaced by the Supreme Commander of India and Pakistan until November 1948. Later on, the duties of the Commander-in-Chief were integrated into the roles of the Governors-General and eventually into the offices of the Presidents of India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh.

The Siege of Bharatpur happened from January 2 to February 22, 1805, in what is now part of Rajasthan, India, during the Second Anglo-Maratha War. The British East India Company, led by General Gerard Lake, tried four times to take over the fortress but failed each time. Bharatpur, with support from the Maratha Empire, won the battle, which was a humiliating loss for the British.

question: For what type of work is the production company for The Year Without a Santa Claus best known?
answer: seasonal television specials, particularly its work in stop motion animation
pos: Rankin/Bass Productions, Inc. originally known as Videocraft International, Ltd., was an American company famous for its holiday TV specials, especially its stop-motion animation work. Universal Studios (through DreamWorks Animation/DreamWorks Classics) owns the library of works made before 1974, while Warner Bros. owns those made after 1973. Rankin/Bass stop-motion films are known for their distinctive style featuring doll-like characters with round body parts, and they used a technique called Animagic. They often overlaid traditional animated scenes of falling snow onto their animations to create the effect of snowfall.

The Year Without a Santa Claus is a Christmas TV special made in 1974 by Rankin/Bass Productions. It's based on Phyllis McGinley's book from 1956, with pictures by Kurt Werth. It first aired on ABC on December 10, 1974.
neg: Santa's Workshop is a fun park located in Cascade, Colorado, near Colorado Springs, at the foot of Pikes Peak. It was inspired by a similar place in Lake Placid, New York. The park has a cute North Pole village with shops selling toys, Christmas decorations, and sweets. Kids can meet Santa and Mrs. Claus anytime. The staff, including Santa's elves, are all dressed up for the holiday season and can be found at the entrance and in various shops.

Larry Wilson is an American who makes movies and writes scripts. He's famous for writing the scripts for Beetlejuice (1988) and The Addams Family (1991). He also helped write The Little Vampire (2001) and The Year Without a Santa Claus (2006). In addition to writing, he directed some episodes of the Tales from the Crypt TV show between 1991 and 1996.

Jonathan Meath, born in 1955, is an American TV producer known for making children's TV shows. He worked on Where in the World is Carmen Sandiego? and produced Zoom (1999) and The Wubbulous World of Dr. Seuss. He also co-founded a production company called Andanzura. Besides his TV work, he's known for being a professional Santa Claus, appearing on shows like ABC's Good Morning America and at events like New York's Radio City Music Hall with The Rockettes. He even graced the cover of Boston Magazine as Santa. National Public Radio and Time Magazine recognized him as a top Santa, and he even starred in a Delta Airline's in-flight safety video. You might also remember him as Santa from Coca-Cola's 2016 holiday campaign titled "A Coke for Christmas."

"Santa Claus: The Movie," also known as "Santa Claus," is a Christmas film from 1985 featuring actors like Dudley Moore, John Lithgow, and David Huddleston. It was one of the last big fantasy films made by a father-and-son team based in Paris, Alexander and Ilya Salkind. Directed by Jeannot Szwarc, it premiered in North America on November 27, 1985, under TriStar Pictures. The DVD came out in 2005 under Anchor Bay Entertainment, now called Starz Home Entertainment, with rights from StudioCanal. A 25th-anniversary edition, including Blu-ray, was released by Lionsgate Home Entertainment, again under StudioCanal's permission.

The song "Santa Claus Is a Black Man" was created by record producer and songwriter Teddy Vann. It features his daughter, Akim Vann, singing and was released in 1973 by the Teddy Vann Production Company. It's a playful twist on the classic "I Saw Mommy Kissing Santa Claus" and has become a beloved favorite, often played during the holiday season.

"A Miser Brothers' Christmas" is a one-hour stop motion special that spins off characters from the 1974 Rankin-Bass special "The Year Without a Santa Claus." It was made by Warner Bros. Animation and Cuppa Coffee Studios, airing on ABC Family on December 13, 2008, as part of their Christmas programming. The voices of Santa Claus and Heat Miser were reprised by Mickey Rooney (age 88) and George S. Irving (age 86), respectively. Snow Miser, originally voiced by Dick Shawn who passed away in 1987, was voiced by Juan Chioran, and Mrs. Claus, originally voiced by Shirley Booth who died in 1992, was portrayed by Catherine Disher. The special aimed to capture the animation style of Rankin/Bass. Notably, this marked the final time Mickey Rooney voiced Santa Claus, as he passed away in 2014, and George Irving voiced Heat Miser, as he passed away in 2016.

Movies about Santa Claus are quite popular and form their own category within Christmas movies. Early ones usually show Santa visiting kids on Christmas Eve. In 1897, a short film called "Santa Claus Filling Stockings" just showed Santa filling stockings with toys. Another one, "Santa Claus and the Children," came out in 1898. Then, in 1899, there was "Santa Claus" (or "The Visit from Santa Claus" in the UK), where Santa comes in through the fireplace, decorates the tree, fills stockings, and disappears back up the chimney. "Santa Claus' Visit" in 1900 shows him entering through the chimney, leaving gifts, and magically creating a Christmas tree. In 1909, "A Trap for Santa Claus" by D. W. Griffith tells the story of kids trying to catch Santa but capturing their burglar father instead. In 1925, Frank E. Kleinschmidt made a 29-minute silent film called "Santa Claus," showing Santa in his workshop, visiting Eskimos, and caring for his reindeer. In 1926, there was another movie called "Santa Claus" with sound. Many actors have played Santa over the years, including Monty Woolley, Dan Aykroyd, and Ed Asner. Later films about Santa Claus cover various themes.

The Year Without a Santa Claus is a 2006 movie that's a remake of the Rankin-Bass classic with the same name. It's a live-action film that aired on NBC on December 11, 2006, and was later released on widescreen DVD on December 12, 2006.

question: What year was the film that starred the composer for "The Naked Brothers Band"?
pos: "The Fault in Our Stars" is a movie released in 2014. It's about a teenage girl named Hazel Grace Lancaster, who has cancer. Her parents make her go to a support group, where she meets and falls in love with another cancer patient named Augustus Waters. The movie stars Shailene Woodley, Ansel Elgort, and Nat Wolff, with Laura Dern, Sam Trammell, and Willem Dafoe in supporting roles.

Nathaniel Marvin "Nat" Wolff, born on December 17, 1994, is an American actor, singer-songwriter, and musician. He became known for creating music for The Naked Brothers Band (2007–09), a TV show on Nickelodeon where he starred alongside his younger brother Alex. The show was created by their mom, Polly Draper, who is an actress. Their dad, Michael Wolff, a jazz pianist, helped produce the show's soundtrack albums. One of the albums, "The Naked Brothers Band" (2007), even reached the 23rd spot on the Billboard 200 charts.
neg: Alexander Alex Draper Wolff, born on November 1, 1997, is an American actor, musician, and composer. He became known for his role alongside his older brother Nat in the Nickelodeon show "The Naked Brothers Band" (2007–09), a musical comedy created by their mother Polly Draper. Together, they released two soundtrack albums for the show, "The Naked Brothers Band" and "I Don't Want to Go to School," with their father Michael Wolff co-producing them.

"Operation Mojo" is a mix of documentary and musical comedy within the TEENick series called The Naked Brothers Band. It's the sixth TV movie of the band series and the second of season 3. The movie premiered on Nickelodeon on November 22, 2008.

Nat and Alex Wolff are a musical duo from New York, USA. They're brothers known for their roles in the TV show "The Naked Brothers Band" on Nickelodeon. The show, created by their mom Polly Draper, was based on a mockumentary film she made. The brothers started as a teen pop band also called "The Naked Brothers Band," which was featured in the TV series from 2007 to 2009. They've released four albums and received award nominations.

"Mystery Girl" is a comedic musical movie that parodies the rockumentary genre. It's actually the first and second episode of Season 3 of "The Naked Brothers Band" TV show, which aired on Nickelodeon. The movie premiered on October 18, 2008, and was a big hit, becoming the highest-rated episode of "The Naked Brothers Band" with over 4 million viewers.

"I Don't Want To Go To School" is the second soundtrack album by The Naked Brothers Band, serving as the soundtrack for their second season. The album, released as a deluxe fanpack, includes a poster, lyrics, and two bonus tracks.

The Naked Brothers Band: Music from the Movie is a soundtrack EP by The Naked Brothers Band. It came as a bonus disc with The Naked Brothers Band Movie DVD but was only available for a limited time. Now, it's only sold on Amazon and hasn't been officially released separately or on iTunes. The song "Crazy Car" from the EP reached No. 83 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart in 2007.

"The Naked Brothers Band" album is the soundtrack for Season 1 of the TV series of the same name. It's available as a regular album or as a deluxe fanpack, which comes with a poster, lyrics, and two extra tracks.

The Premiere is the eighth TV movie in The Naked Brothers Band series, a mix of documentary and musical comedy created by Polly Draper. It aired on Saturday, April 11, 2009, and follows the premiere of The Naked Brothers Band Musical Mystery Movie. It also includes appearances by Victoria Justice from Zoey 101.

question: The author of Sexual Politics attended which British University?
pos: Katherine Murray Millett was an influential American feminist, writer, educator, artist, and activist. She was the first American woman to earn a first-class honors degree from Oxford University, studying at St Hilda's College. Her book Sexual Politics, based on her doctoral dissertation at Columbia University, is well-known and considered a pivotal work in second-wave feminism. Journalist Liza Featherstone credits Millett with contributing to advancements like legal abortion, professional equality, and sexual freedom.
"Sexual Politics" is a book written by Kate Millett in 1970, which originated from her doctoral dissertation.
neg: "Contract With the World" is a book from 1980 by Canadian writer Jane Rule. It's set in Vancouver, British Columbia, during the mid-1970s and is split into six parts, each told from a different character's point of view. The book explores themes like why people create art, finding happiness, and issues around sex and power.

Carol J. Adams, born in 1951, is an American writer, feminist, and supporter of animal rights. She's known for books like The Sexual Politics of Meat (1990) and The Pornography of Meat (2004), where she explores connections between the mistreatment of women and animals.

The British University Hurling Championship is a yearly competition for universities in Great Britain, organized by the BUGAA, a branch of the Higher Education GAA committee, which oversees Gaelic Games in universities. Unlike the British University Gaelic Football Championship, this event isn't managed by the British Universities Sports Association yet. Outstanding players are selected annually for an all-star team to compete against the Scottish Universities Shinty Team. The championship trophies honor students who introduced Gaelic Games at British Universities. The Michael O'Leary Cup, awarded to the winner of the British University Hurling Championship, was donated by The Friary, Dundee, in memory of a founding member of the University of Glasgow hurling club who passed away in 2001.

The Au Pairs were a British post-punk band from Birmingham, active between 1978 and 1983. They released two albums and three singles. Their music was known for challenging typical views on sex and politics, drawing comparisons to bands like Gang of Four and Young Marble Giants. Lesley Woods, the band's leader, was often praised for her distinctive presence in the British rock scene.

C. V. Balakrishnan is a writer from Kerala, India, who writes in Malayalam. He's known for his novels, short stories, essays, and screenplays. His writing deals with themes like societal issues, relationships, and religion. He's written over 40 books, including the famous novel "Ayussinte Pusthakam." Balakrishnan has won awards like the Kerala Sahitya Akademi Award and the Kerala State Film Award.

Susannah "Susie" Bright, also called Susie Sexpert, is an American who wears many hats: feminist, writer, journalist, critic, editor, publisher, producer, and performer. She's well-known for talking and writing about sexual politics and sexuality.

Shannon Bell, born on July 5, 1955, is a Canadian philosopher known for her unique approach called philosophy-in-action, which blends philosophy with real-life experiences. She works as a professor and directs the graduate program in the Political Science Department at York University in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Her teaching covers a range of topics including postmodern theory, fast feminism, sexual politics, cyber politics, identity politics, and violent philosophy.

Harris George Mirkin (24 August 1936 – 30 May 2013) was a political science professor. He caused controversy by writing an essay called "The Pattern of Sexual Politics," which was published in the Journal of Homosexuality. Because of this essay, the Missouri legislature decided to cut the university's budget by the same amount as Mirkin's salary, as a way of showing they didn't support his work.

question: Who had the best singles ranking, Roberta Vinci or Jorge Lozano?
pos: Roberta Vinci, born on February 18, 1983, is a tennis player from Italy. She was ranked as the top doubles player until April 6, 2015, and achieved her highest singles ranking of 7th in the world in May 2016. Alongside Flavia Pennetta, Francesca Schiavone, and Sara Errani, she is one of the four Italian women to reach the top 10 in singles. At 33 years and 4 days old, she became the oldest player to enter the Top 10 for the first time.

Jorge Lozano, a retired tennis player from Mexico, achieved his highest doubles ranking of World No. 4 in August 1988 and his highest singles ranking of World No. 51 the following month. Throughout his career, he won two mixed doubles titles at the French Open in 1990 and 1988. He also reached the round of 16 in singles at the 1988 US Open and the doubles semifinal that same year. Lozano won nine doubles titles but no singles titles, earning a total prize money of $739,424. He played in the Davis Cup for Mexico for 15 years from 1981 to 1995, with a 20–23 win/loss record. Currently residing in Guadalajara, Mexico, Lozano runs a tennis academy for kids and coaches the men and women's tennis teams at the University Tec de Monterrey, while serving as the captain of the Mexican Davis Cup Team.
neg: Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci, who were the previous winners, decided not to play together. Errani paired with Flavia Pennetta but got knocked out in the quarterfinals by Bethanie Mattek-Sands and Lucie Šafářová. Meanwhile, Vinci partnered with Jelena Janković but was eliminated in the first round by Garbiñe Muguruza and Carla Suárez Navarro.

Morbo was a Mexican music group led by Juan Carlos Lozano, who was also a founding member of Moenia. Moenia's debut album in 1997, with Lozano as the lead vocalist, and its remix album in 1998, were well-received. However, due to creative differences with other Moenia members, Lozano left the band and formed Morbo in 2001, which focused more on synth and guitar music compared to Moenia's style.
Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci were the champions from last time, but Roberta Vinci decided not to keep playing before reaching the quarterfinals.
Horacio de la Peña and Jorge Lozano, who were the champions last time, didn't compete this year.

Flavia Pennetta, born on February 25, 1982, is a former professional tennis player from Italy who won Grand Slam titles in both singles and doubles. On August 17, 2009, she became the first Italian woman to rank in the top 10 in singles, and on February 28, 2011, she became the first Italian to be ranked world No. 1 in doubles. In 2015, she made history by winning the US Open singles title, defeating her childhood friend Roberta Vinci in the tournament's first all-Italian final.

Marta Domachowska, born on January 16, 1986, in Warsaw, is a former professional tennis player from Poland. She reached her highest singles ranking of World No. 37 and doubles ranking of World No. 62 in 2006. Some of her notable achievements include reaching the fourth round of the 2008 Australian Open in singles and winning the 2006 Canberra International doubles title with Roberta Vinci. Domachowska also reached the finals of three WTA Tour singles events: the 2004 Hansol Korea Open, the 2005 Internationaux de Strasbourg, and the 2006 U.S. National Indoor Tennis Championships. In addition, she was the runner-up in the girls' singles event at the 2003 Australian Open. Domachowska represented Poland at the 2008 Summer Olympics and was part of the Poland Fed Cup team. She held the title of the best female Polish tennis player until Agnieszka Radwańska's rise, following Magdalena Grzybowska's retirement.
Jorge Lozano and Todd Witsken won the final match with a score of 6-3, 7-6 against Pieter Aldrich and Danie Visser.

Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci, who were last year's winners, didn't defend their title this time. Instead, Vinci teamed up with Karin Knapp, but they got knocked out in the third round by Casey Dellacqua and Yaroslava Shvedova.

question: Both Truth in Science and Discovery embrace what campaign?
pos: "Truth in Science" is a UK-based group that supports teaching intelligent design alongside evolution in schools through the Discovery Institute's Teach the Controversy campaign. They argue there's scientific debate about evolution's validity, contrary to views held by prestigious scientific bodies like the UK's Royal Society and over 50 Academies of Science worldwide. The group aligns with the Discovery Institute, a key player in the intelligent design movement, and shares its materials and strategies.

The Discovery Institute (DI) is a conservative non-profit organization in Seattle, Washington. They're famous for promoting intelligent design (ID), which is seen as a pseudoscientific idea. Their Teach the Controversy campaign wants to allow teaching both evolution and intelligent design in public high school science classes. They argue that there's a scientific debate about these topics.
neg: Every Voice is a nonprofit organization in the U.S. that wants to change how political campaigns are funded. They merged with other groups in 2014. They have a Super PAC called Every Voice Action, which works to reform campaign finance by supporting public funding for campaigns and restricting big donations. The president, David Donnelly, acknowledges the irony of using a Super PAC to oppose Super PAC influence.

"The Last Embrace" is Spirit Caravan's final album, released in 2003 by Meteor City Records on both CD and vinyl. It includes 19 songs from their albums "Jug Fulla Sun" and "Elusive Truth," as well as tracks from their debut 7-inch record released under the name Shine. Additionally, it features songs from their final 7-inch record as Spirit Caravan, their contribution to a split 7-inch with Sixty Watt Shaman, and a track from the Rise 13 compilation on Rise Above Records. The album also includes the last three songs Spirit Caravan recorded: "The Last Embrace," "Brainwashed," and "Dove-Tongued Aggressor."

The Discovery Museum and Planetarium in Bridgeport, Connecticut, is a fun science museum that attracts tourists and helps schools teach. It offers interactive STEM activities to spark curiosity and encourage visitors, especially kids, to ask questions, solve problems, and prepare for the future.

Truth Initiative, formerly known as the American Legacy Foundation or Legacy, is a non-profit organization focused on reducing tobacco use among youth and young adults. It was founded in March 1999 following the Master Settlement Agreement involving 46 states, the District of Columbia, five US territories, and the tobacco industry. Truth Initiative is renowned for its efforts in preventing youth smoking through various campaigns. Additionally, the organization conducts research on tobacco control, develops policies, engages communities and youth, and creates digital products for tobacco cessation and prevention, often with revenue-generating models. In 2015, it changed its name to Truth Initiative to align with its Truth campaign. As of 2016, the organization held assets exceeding $957 million and employed 133 staff primarily in Washington, D.C.

In 1986, a band called Extrema was formed in Milan with guitarist Tommy Massara, vocalist/guitarist Andrea Boria, bassist Luca Varisco, and drummer Stefano Bullegas. They were one of Italy's first thrash metal bands. Their debut EP, "We F**kin' Care," released in 1987, gained popularity solely through word of mouth and sold 3,000 copies. Despite this, Italian heavy metal fans weren't quite ready to support local bands, so for the next four years, Extrema underwent significant changes with Massara bringing in new members Gianluca Perotti on vocals, Mattia Bigi on bass, and Chris Dalla Pellegrina on drums. They mainly opened for international acts like Slayer, D.R.I., and Corrosion of Conformity during this period. Realizing they needed outside recognition, Extrema aggressively promoted their demos to international heavy metal critics and even performed in New York City. This strategy paid off as their 1991 demo gained attention from major international publications, leading to a record deal with Contempo Records. Their album "Tension at the Seams" in 1993 propelled them to perform at stadiums with Italian rock star Vasco Rossi and participate in a notable metal festival in Turin alongside bands like Megadeth, The Cult, Suicidal Tendencies, and Metallica. The album's success also led to a music video for their song "Child O' Boogaow," which received heavy rotation on Italy's MTV affiliate, Videomusic.

The truth campaign, run by the American Legacy Foundation, is a nationwide effort to reduce smoking among young people in the United States. It started in 1999 after an agreement between tobacco companies and several states. Using TV and online content, the campaign spreads messages against smoking. In 2014, they introduced "Finish It," a new phase urging young people to be the ones who stop smoking for good.

In a small Texas town called Promise, tough times with scorching heat, dry land, and economic collapse have made life bleak. For a decade, the town has suffered one setback after another, leaving its people feeling hopeless. When a couple discovers a boy walking alone along a dusty road with just a mat, they take him in, hoping to lend a hand. Little do they know, he's actually there to assist them and the town. Mystery surrounds the boy's origin, with some seeing him as an answer to prayers while others doubt his intentions. Despite skepticism, he insists he's there to help, leaving the town sheriff, Brody, determined to uncover the truth. Amidst a series of miraculous events, the townsfolk warm up to the boy. However, when the town doctor passes away, the boy feels compelled to reveal his true identity, urging Brody and the community to believe in his intentions to help, not harm. Finally, with no other options, the boy reveals who he really is.

Discovery Networks Benelux manages TV channels like Discovery, Animal Planet, and TLC in the Netherlands and Belgium. They handle everything from local advertising to programming, often using the local language through dubbing or subtitles. Additionally, they utilize services from Discovery Networks International, such as Discovery Science and Discovery World.

question: Josey Scott and Ian Watkins were both promising musicians. Which of these talented men was incarcerated, impacting his career with a rock band?
answer: Lostprophets disbanded in 2013 after Watkins was charged with sexual offences in late 2012.
pos: Ian David Karslake Watkins, born on July 30, 1977, is a Welsh singer, musician, and a person convicted of sexual offenses. He gained fame as a founding member, lead singer, and songwriter of the rock band Lostprophets. The band broke up in 2013 after Watkins faced charges of sexual offenses in late 2012. In November 2013, he admitted guilt to 13 charges, including attempting rape and sexually assaulting a child under 13. These crimes were committed against infants of two women who were also convicted. He was then sentenced to 29 years in prison with an additional six years on probation.

Josey Scott, originally named Joseph Scott Sappington, was the main singer in the rock group Saliva. Besides his work with Saliva, he collaborated with Chad Kroeger from Nickelback to write and perform "Hero," featured as one of the theme songs in the 2002 movie Spider-Man.
neg: Where We Belong is a song by the Welsh band Lostprophets from their album The Betrayed. It came out on January 4, 2010, as the album's second single. Ian Watkins, the singer, told Kerrang! that although the song might seem cheerful, the lyrics suggest feeling like they belong in hell. It reached No. 32 on the Official UK top 40 on January 10, 2010. The band wrote it as a tribute to coming back home to Wales after recording in Los Angeles.

"Shinobi vs. Dragon Ninja" is a song by the Welsh rock band Lostprophets. It was written by the band's frontman, Ian Watkins, and released in 2001 as the first single from their debut album, "The Fake Sound of Progress." It was the only song from the album to chart on the Billboard charts. The band continued to perform it on tour until they broke up in 2013.

"Family Reunion" is the debut track from Saliva's sixth album, "Cinco Diablo." Lead singer Josey Scott explained that the song is all about connecting with their fans while touring. It reached its highest position at #14 on Billboard's Mainstream Rock Tracks chart in 2008.

Lostprophets were a rock band from Pontypridd, Wales, started in 1997 by lead singer Ian Watkins, bassist (later guitarist) Mike Lewis, drummer Mike Chiplin, and guitarist Lee Gaze. Originally, they began as a side project to the hardcore punk band Public Disturbance and were active in the Cardiff music scene.

"Under Your Skin" is the seventh album by the American rock band Saliva. It's the last one with singer Josey Scott, who left in 2012. The album came out on March 22, 2011, but before that, it had different names like "Take That Society" and "Skin Deep."

The song "We Bring an Arsenal" was meant to be the second single from the album "Weapons" by the band Lostprophets. It was scheduled for release on June 4, 2012, but it only hit rock radio in the United States by that date. However, it never officially came out in the UK, mainly because Ian Watkins, a member of the band, was imprisoned in 2013. The band played it live for the first time on February 25, 2012, in Brisbane, Australia.

In It to Win It is the eighth album by the American rock band Saliva. It's their first album with singer Bobby Amaru, who joined after Josey Scott's departure in 2012. Initially released on September 3, 2013, via Rum Bum Records, it's no longer for sale because the band reissued it as Rise Up, which includes all the songs except Animal, Flesh, and I.D.N.A.E.

The song "Always" is the opening track from the album "Back into Your System" by the rock band Saliva, featuring lead vocalist Josey Scott. It reached the number 1 spot on the Modern Rock Tracks chart for one week in February 2003. It's Saliva's most successful song, hitting #51 on the Hot 100 chart.

question: The movies Queen of Blood and Battle Beyond the Sun both contained scenes from what 1959 Soviet feature?
pos: Battle Beyond the Sun is an American version of a 1959 Soviet sci-fi movie called Nebo Zovyot. It's about two countries in the future racing to be the first to land a spaceship on Mars.

Queen of Blood is a 1966 sci-fi horror movie inspired by the Soviet film Mechte Navstrechu. It was made by George Edwards and Samuel Z. Arkoff, directed by Curtis Harrington, and features actors like John Saxon, Basil Rathbone, Dennis Hopper, and Judi Meredith. The film was released by American International Pictures alongside Blood Bath. Director Harrington incorporated special effects scenes from the Soviet films Mechte Navstrechu and Nebo Zovyot.
neg: The movie "I Was a Satellite of the Sun" is a Soviet science-fiction film from 1959 that includes animation.
Tracker, also known as Филёр in Russian, is a Soviet drama film directed by Roman Balayan. It was filmed in 1987 in Kaluga.

"Girl Seeks Father" is a Soviet drama film from 1959. Produced by Yuri Bulychyov at Belarusfilm and directed by Lev Golub, it features Anna Kamenkova, Vladimir Guskov, and Nikolai Barmin. The screenplay was written by Konstantin Gubarevich and Yevgeny Ryss. In 1959, it ranked fifth in the Soviet Union box office, with over 35 million viewers, making it the third most-watched Belarusian film ever.

Battle Beyond the Stars, a 1980 American space opera film, is like a futuristic version of The Magnificent Seven, set in outer space. Directed by Jimmy T. Murakami and produced by Roger Corman, it features a cast including Richard Thomas, Robert Vaughn, George Peppard, John Saxon, Sybil Danning, and Darlanne Fluegel. John Sayles penned the screenplay, James Horner composed the score, and James Cameron handled the special effects.

Rewrite: "All Costs Paid" is a Soviet TV miniseries created by Studio Ekran. Directed by Aleksei Saltykov, known for his work on "The Chairman" with acclaimed Russian actor Mikhail Ulyanov, the series is notable for being one of the first Soviet productions to depict the war in Afghanistan. It offers a candid perspective on this chapter of Soviet history and the conflict in Afghanistan.

The Scarlet Flower is a Soviet animated film from 1952, directed by Lev Atamanov. It was made at the Soyuzmultfilm studio in Moscow and adapted from Sergei Aksakov's story. The popular chamber singer Victoria Ivanova sang Nastenka's song "During this time in a darling party/В эту пору в родимой сторонушке" in the film.
The Key, also known as "Ключ" (Klyuch) in Russian, is a Soviet animated film from 1961 directed by Lev Atamanov. It was made at the Soyuzmultfilm studio in Moscow.
"Older Sister" is a Soviet movie made in 1966, based on Alexander Volodin's play "My Older Sister," directed by Georgy Natanson.

question: Who was born first, Erika Jayne or Marco Da Silva
pos: Erika Girardi, also known as Erika Jayne, is an American singer, actress, and TV personality. She gained fame with her first single "Roller Coaster," which became a hit in 2007, reaching the number one spot on the US Billboard Dance Club Songs chart. This song was part of her first album, "Pretty Mess," released in 2009. By 2016, Jayne had achieved nine number-one hits on the Dance Club Songs chart, with her latest being "How Many Fucks." She's recognized as the 42nd greatest Dance Club Artist of All Time by Billboard.

Marco Da Silva, born on May 30th, 1977, is a Portuguese dancer and choreographer who hails from a Portuguese family in Bremen, Germany. He has an extensive background in dance, having performed on numerous tours with artists like Kylie Minogue and Britney Spears, as well as appearing in TV commercials for Coca Cola, movies like "The Muppets – The Musical Movie," and music videos for various artists including Mariah Carey and George Michael.
neg: Emilio Ribeiro Neves da Silva, also called Emílio da Silva, was born on April 5, 1982, in Dili, Timor Timur, Indonesia. He's a football player from East Timor and has been with AD Esperança since 2004. Before that, he played for FC Zebra for two years, where he also spent his youth career from 2000 to 2002.

Marco da Silva Ignácio, also known as Marquinhos, was born on June 15, 1989. He's a Brazilian football player currently on the roster for Santos. While he typically plays as an attacking midfielder, he's also skilled as a wing back.

The Viscount of Cardoso da Silva is a noble title from Portugal. It was given by Carlos I of Portugal in the 1800s to Oliver William Lewis Cardoso da Silva de León, who currently resides in London, England.

Marisa Letícia Lula da Silva, the second wife of former Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, served as First Lady of Brazil from 2003 to 2010. Before marrying Lula, Marisa was previously married to Marcos Cláudio da Silva, who passed away in 1971. Tragically, Lula's first wife, Maria de Lourdes da Silva, died during childbirth when he was in his twenties. Marisa Letícia suffered a stroke on January 24, 2017, and passed away on February 3 at the age of 66. Her death prompted three days of official mourning declared by President Michel Temer. She was cremated the following day, and her ashes were laid to rest at Cemitério Jardim da Colina in her hometown of São Bernardo do Campo, São Paulo.

The Fortaleza Metro, also known as Metrofor, is a rail system in Fortaleza, Brazil. It runs on a 43 km track and is managed by Companhia Cearense Metropolitan Transport, established on May 2, 1997. The system, overseen by the state government, started operating on June 15, 2012, with the South Line being the first completed route. Planned expansions include lines to the South, East, West, Mucuripe, and Maranguape, connecting major terminals like Parangaba and Papicu, as well as the Mucuripe port and Pinto Martins international airport.

José Graziano da Silva is a Brazilian American agronomist and writer who has written books about agricultural issues in Brazil. He served as Extraordinary Minister for Food Security from 2003 to 2004 in Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva's cabinet, where he implemented the Zero Hunger program. This program lifted 28 million people out of poverty during Lula's presidency. In 2011, Graziano was elected as the director-general of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), becoming the first Latin American to hold this position. He was re-elected for a second term from August 2015 to July 2019 during FAO's 39th Conference.

Café, also known as Edson Aparecido da Silva or simply Edson da Silva, is a musician from Villa Maria, São Paulo, Brazil. He's a percussionist, singer, composer, and music producer. He relocated to the United States in 1985.

Marco da Silva, born on April 10, 1992, is a French footballer who currently plays for Valenciennes in Ligue 1. He's a midfielder and attended the Clairefontaine academy. After that, he joined Valenciennes and moved up to the reserve team after two years in the youth academy. He helped the team get promoted to the Championnat de France amateur in the 2010–11 season and is now the team's captain. Da Silva made his professional debut for Valenciennes on August 31, 2011, playing against Dijon in the Coupe de la Ligue. He started the match but was substituted after 73 minutes, and Valenciennes lost 3–2.

question: When did the English local newspaper, featuring the sculpture and war memorial in the Forbury gardens, change names?
pos: The Maiwand Lion is a statue and war memorial in Forbury Gardens, a public park in Reading, Berkshire, England. It was built in 1884 to honor the 329 soldiers from the 66th (Berkshire) Regiment of Foot who died during the Second Anglo-Afghan War between 1878 and 1880, specifically at the Battle of Maiwand. Locally, it's also called the Forbury Lion.

The Reading Post, formerly known as the Reading Evening Post until 2009, was a newspaper in England that focused on news from Reading, Berkshire, and nearby areas. Its front page often showed a picture of the Maiwand Lion, a well-known statue in Forbury Gardens. The newspaper was last published by Surrey & Berkshire Media Ltd., which is part of Trinity Mirror plc.
neg: The Kargil War Memorial, also called Vijaypath, is a tribute to the Indian Army soldiers who died during the 1999 conflict with Pakistan. It's situated in Dras, near Tololing Hill, about 5 km from the city center across Tiger Hill, on the Srinagar-Leh National Highway 1D. The memorial features a large epitaph with the names of all the fallen soldiers. Every year on July 26th, Kargil Vijay Diwas is observed here, and the Prime Minister of India pays respects at the Amar Jawan Jyothi in New Delhi. The memorial's highlight is a Sandstone wall bearing the names of the fallen soldiers, along with a souvenir shop. Visitors can also view some of the peaks reclaimed by the Indian army from Pakistan. Additionally, a large national flag, weighing 15 kg, was raised at the memorial to mark the 13th anniversary of India's victory in the war.

The Devon County War Memorial is a tribute to those who served in World War I, created by architect Sir Edwin Lutyens. It's located on the cathedral green in Exeter, Devon's main city in southwest England. Lutyens designed fifteen War Crosses, including this one, as civic memorials. Originally, there was a plan to build a cloister at Exeter Cathedral dedicated to Devon's war dead, but it fell through due to funding issues. Eventually, the Devon County War Memorial Committee decided on a War Cross instead, placing it on the cathedral green after considering various locations. Meanwhile, Exeter was also planning its own memorial, resulting in two separate ones—the county memorial by the cathedral and the Exeter City War Memorial in Northernhay Gardens.

The Manchester Cenotaph, designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens, is a memorial for the First World War, later expanded to honor other conflicts. It's located in St Peter's Square, Manchester, England. Despite being late to commission the memorial, the city council raised £10,000 swiftly. However, deciding on a location was tricky. The first choice, Albert Square, faced opposition from the artistic community due to the need to relocate statues. Piccadilly Gardens was another option, but for efficiency, St Peter's Square was chosen, despite already having a memorial cross. Attempts to move the cross failed, so the war memorial was built alongside it.

The York City War Memorial, designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens, honors those who died in World War I and is located in York, England. Initially, there was debate over whether it should serve a practical purpose or be a traditional monument. After discussions, it was decided to go with a monument. Lutyens was chosen to design it after presenting his plans. However, there was controversy regarding its design and location, as some felt it didn't fit with the city's architecture. Eventually, due to public opposition, the site was changed to Leeman Road, and the design was simplified due to budget constraints.

The Spalding War Memorial, located in the gardens of Ayscoughfee Hall in Spalding, England, honors those who served in World War I. Designed by architect Sir Edwin Lutyens, it was initially suggested by Barbara McLaren, whose husband, Francis McLaren, a member of Parliament for Spalding, died in a flying accident during the war. McLaren, through family ties, enlisted Lutyens to create a plan featuring a cloister surrounding a pond with a central cross. The memorial was to be placed in Ayscoughfee Hall's formal gardens, owned by the local council. McLaren's proposal sparked community debate, leading to alternative ideas. Eventually, a scaled-down version of McLaren's plan, along with a clock on the town's corn exchange building, was chosen after a public meeting and vote in 1919.
The Forbury Hotel, once known as Shire Hall, is a historic hotel located in Reading, Berkshire, England. It stands on the south side of Forbury Gardens, a park in the town center.
St. James's Church is a Catholic church in downtown Reading, Berkshire, England. It's right next to the old ruins of Reading Abbey, between Forbury Gardens and Reading Gaol.

Forbury Gardens is a park in Reading, Berkshire, England, located where the outer court of Reading Abbey used to be, just in front of the Abbey Church. It was once called The Forbury, and one of the roads around the park is still called The Forbury. In the past, fairs were held here three times a year until the 19th century.

question: What is the name of the Isles who were led by Aonghus Mór and covered a total land area of over 8300 km2?
pos: Aonghus Mór mac Domhnaill, who died around 1293, was an important figure in the kingdoms of the Isles and Scotland in the 13th century. He was the son of Domhnall mac Raghnaill, who led the Clann Domhnaill family, part of Clann Somhairle. Aonghus Mór likely took over from his father in the mid-1200s. During this time, the rulers of the Isles were separate from the Scottish Crown and nominally loyal to the Norwegian Crown. Aonghus Mór is first mentioned in history when he supported Irish groups against Anglo-Irish authority in northwest Ireland. This cooperation might have been part of Clann Domhnaill's efforts to form Irish alliances against Scottish influence.

The Kingdom of the Isles existed from the 9th to the 13th centuries AD and included the Hebrides, the islands of the Firth of Clyde, and the Isle of Man. These islands were called the Suðreyjar by the Norse, meaning Southern Isles, to distinguish them from the Northern Isles like Orkney and Shetland. The historical records are incomplete, and the kingdom wasn't always a unified entity during this time. Sometimes the rulers were independent, but often they had overlords from Norway, Ireland, England, Scotland, or Orkney. The islands covered an area of over 8300 km2 and stretched for more than 500 km from north to south. They are sometimes referred to as the Kingdom of Mann and the Isles, but not all rulers claimed this title. There were also competing claims over the territory at different times.
neg: The title "Lord of Islay" was held by the leaders of the Clann Domhnaill in the 13th and 14th centuries, before they started calling themselves the "Lord of the Isles" in the late 14th century. The first person known to have called themselves "Lord of Islay" was Aonghus Mór, the son of the clan's ancestor, Domhnall mac Raghnaill. The term "Islay" was commonly used by these leaders and later members of the clan.

Forest cover in Himachal Pradesh spans nearly 37,691 square kilometers, accounting for about 38.3% of the state's total land area. Originally seen as a primary income source, many forests were extensively cleared. Now, the focus has shifted towards conservation efforts. The state government aims to raise forest coverage to 50% of the total land area, implementing projects like establishing protected areas such as National Parks to safeguard and enlarge the forests.

The Ashanti Region is in southern Ghana and is the third largest of the country's 10 regions. It covers about 10.2% of Ghana's total land area, which is about 24,389 square kilometers. Even though it's not the biggest in size, it has the most people, with a population of 4,780,380 according to the 2010 census. That's about 19.4% of Ghana's entire population. The Ashanti Region is famous for producing a lot of gold bars and cocoa. The biggest city and capital of the region is Kumasi.
