The music scene in Pristina includes composers who have made significant contributions to various genres, influenced by Kosovan folklore. To ensure a comprehensive view, we highlight each composer's work across different genres, acknowledging the diverse influences and developments over the years.

The Take 21 event, formerly known as the Toronto Student Film Festival or TSFF, is held every year for young people to display their skills in different types of short films. Filmmakers from various countries participate, and prizes include opportunities for industry experience, scholarships for filmmaking programs, cash, and film gear.
A parody film is a type of comedy that makes fun of other movie genres or specific films by imitating their style or combining elements from various movies.
The movie "Three are Three" (Spanish: Tres eran tres) is a Spanish comedy film from 1955, directed by Eduardo García Maroto. It makes fun of various film styles in three different parts.

"Poetical Refugee," also known as "La Faute à Voltaire," is a French drama film from 2000. It's directed by Abdellatif Kechiche and stars Sami Bouajila, Élodie Bouchez, and Bruno Lochet. This movie marked Kechiche's first feature film and received the Golden Lion award at the Venice Film Festival for best debut film. In total, it won seven awards at various film festivals.

The buddy film is a type of movie where two (or sometimes more) characters, usually men, team up. They often have contrasting personalities, which adds a unique dynamic compared to pairs of opposite genders. Sometimes, their differences are highlighted by their ethnic backgrounds. Buddy films are popular in American cinema and have remained popular throughout the 20th century, featuring various duos and themes.

Jacqueline Lourdes Blanco-Davao, born on February 11, 1964, is a Filipina actress and aerobics instructor with Filipino roots. In the 1980s and 1990s, she starred in various types of movies like "Hihintayin Kita sa Langit" (1991), "Si Aida, Si Lorna, o Si Fe" (1989), "Misis mo, Misis ko" (1988), and "Palabra de honor" (1983).

question: Tefik Selim Mborja was a part of a party that held power in Albania until what year?
pos: The Albanian Fascist Party (PFSh) was a Fascist group in Albania during World War II. It gained control when Italy took over Albania in 1939, but when Italy surrendered to the Allies in 1943, Albania came under German control. Then, the PFSh was replaced by the Guard of Greater Albania.
Tefik Selim Mborja (1888-1954) was an Albanian politician and lawyer who held the position of general secretary in the Albanian Fascist Party during World War II.
neg: In the 1982 general elections in Sweden, the Social Democratic Party won, bringing them back into power after being out of office for six years. This was the longest time they had been out of power since the 1910s. Before the election, the center-right coalition led by Thorbjörn Fälldin lost support due to disagreements over tax policies, leading to the government breaking up in 1981. Olof Palme, a socialist leader who had previously been Prime Minister from 1969 to 1976, regained power and remained Prime Minister until he was assassinated in 1986.

Bal'arab bin Himyar was an Imam who played a significant role in the civil wars of Oman in the late years of the Yaruba dynasty. He first became Imam in 1728, controlling the interior regions of Oman while his cousin, Saif bin Sultan II, controlled the coastal areas. However, he later relinquished his claim in 1737 after being defeated by Saif's Persian allies. In 1743, Bal'arab was elected Imam again during another Persian invasion. He once more governed the interior regions, while Ahmad bin Said al-Busaidi was accepted as the ruler by the coastal inhabitants. Bal'arab died in battle against Ahmad bin Said in 1749, leading to Ahmad's uncontested rule over the country.

The Confederation of Mexican Workers (CTM) is Mexico's largest labor union group. It used to be closely linked with the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI), which ran Mexico for over seventy years. However, starting in the late 1980s, the CTM's influence within the PRI declined as technocrats gained more control. When the PRI lost the 2000 general election, the CTM had to adjust to a new political landscape, which significantly weakened its political power.

The United Bermuda Party (UBP) was a political group in Bermuda. It saw itself as a centrist party with moderate views on social and financial issues. The party was in charge of Bermuda's House of Assembly from 1968 to 1998. After 47 years, it stopped operating on June 30, 2011, when most of its members joined the One Bermuda Alliance.

In Australia, there was a federal election on December 2, 1972. The Australian Labor Party, led by Gough Whitlam, won the election. They secured 67 out of 125 seats, defeating the Liberal Party, led by Prime Minister William McMahon, and their Coalition partner, the Country Party, led by Doug Anthony. This election marked the end of 23 years of consecutive Coalition government rule, which had been in power since 1949.

Albania, officially known as the People's Socialist Republic of Albania, was a socialist country led by Enver Hoxha and the Party of Labour of Albania from 1946 until its collapse in 1992. It went through various name changes during this time. Under its strict regime, travel in and out of Albania was highly restricted, making it one of the hardest countries to visit. In 1967, it became the world's first atheist state. Unlike other Warsaw Pact members, Albania formally left the alliance in 1968 due to the invasion of Czechoslovakia. The country transitioned to a multi-party system in 1991, with the first parliamentary elections held in 1992. The People's Socialist Republic ceased to exist officially on November 28, 1998, with the adoption of a new constitution.

In February 1967, the fourth legislative assembly election of Madras State (now Tamil Nadu) took place. The Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK), led by C.N. Annadurai, won the election, defeating the Indian National Congress. Key issues included protests against the imposition of Hindi, high prices of essential goods, and a shortage of rice. K. Kamaraj's resignation as Chief Minister in 1963, amidst corruption rumors, weakened the Congress Government. This marked the second instance in India, after the Communist Party of India's victory in Kerala in 1957, where a non-Congress party gained majority in a state. It also signaled the end of Congress's rule in Tamil Nadu. This election saw the first formation of a non-Congress government with a clear majority, initiating Dravidian dominance in Tamil Nadu politics. Annadurai, the first non-Congress Chief Minister of post-independence Tamil Nadu, passed away in 1969, and V.R. Nedunchezhiyan assumed the role of acting Chief Minister.

The Communist Party in Hungary, initially known as the Party of Communists, later renamed the Hungarian Communist Party, was established on November 24, 1918. It briefly held power in Hungary from March to August 1919 under Béla Kun during the Hungarian Soviet Republic. The Romanian Army ousted the communist government, forcing the party underground. After World War II, under Mátyás Rákosi's leadership, the party regained power in 1945. In 1948, it merged with the Social Democrats to form the Hungarian Working People's Party. The Communist Party of Hungary was affiliated with the Communist International.

question: Joe Walker played for which team that ends their regular season with the Civil War rivalry game?
pos: The Oregon Ducks football team represents the University of Oregon in college football. They compete in the FBS division of NCAA Division I and are part of the Pac-12 Conference. Initially known as the Webfoots, they changed their name to the Ducks in the mid-1960s. Their football history dates back to 1894. The team plays their home games at Autzen Stadium in Eugene, which can seat 54,000 people. Their primary rivals are the Oregon State Beavers and the Washington Huskies, and they traditionally face the Beavers in the Civil War rivalry game at the end of each regular season in late November.
Joe Walker, born on December 11, 1992, is a linebacker for the Philadelphia Eagles in the NFL. He used to play football for Oregon in college.
neg: The Civil War is a popular college football game that happens every year in Oregon. It's between the Ducks from the University of Oregon in Eugene and the Beavers from Oregon State University in Corvallis. It started in 1894 and is one of the top five most played college football rivalries in the NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision. Both teams are part of the North Division of the Pac-12 Conference.

The Textile Bowl is an annual college football game between Clemson University and North Carolina State University. It's been called the Textile Bowl since 1981. Both schools are in the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) and compete in the Atlantic Division. The name comes from both universities having major textile schools and the textile industry's historical significance in South Carolina and North Carolina.

The Rivalry is a big American college football game between Lafayette College's team, the Leopards, and Lehigh University's team, the Mountain Hawks. It's the most played football rivalry in the country and has happened every year since 1884, except for one break in 1896. They used to play twice a year, except for in 1891 when they played three times, and in 1896 when they didn't play at all. The schools are close, just seventeen miles apart, in eastern Pennsylvania. The Rivalry isn't just about football; it's also about their competitions in other sports and activities.

The 1983 Oregon State vs. Oregon football game was held on November 19, 1983, at Autzen Stadium in Eugene, Oregon. It was the 87th match in the ongoing Civil War rivalry between the two teams. Interestingly, the game ended in a tie with no points scored by either team. It's worth noting that since overtime rules were introduced to NCAA Division I games in 1996, this particular game is likely to remain the last one to end in a tie.

The LSU–Ole Miss football rivalry, called the Magnolia Bowl since 2008, is a yearly game between LSU Tigers and Ole Miss Rebels. They play for the Magnolia Bowl Trophy. Starting in 1894, they've regularly faced off in the SEC, playing each year since 1945. The rivalry peaked in the 1950s and 1960s when both teams were strong and claimed national championships. It slowed down from the 1970s to the 1990s because Ole Miss wasn't as competitive and LSU had new rivals like Alabama and Auburn. Despite less national attention lately, it's still a big deal in Oxford and Baton Rouge.

The Battle of the Blue is a yearly college football game between the University of Delaware's Fightin' Blue Hens and Villanova University's Wildcats. It started in 1895, paused when Villanova stopped football from 1964 to 1980, then resumed in 1988 when Villanova brought back football. Since 2007, it's been called the Battle of the Blue. The winner keeps a trophy until the next game, which has a football with both team logos and colors. Scores are engraved on its base. Villanova had it for the first four years, then Delaware won it in 2011.

The Army–Navy Game is a big college football matchup between the Army team from West Point, New York, and the Navy team from Annapolis, Maryland. It's a historic rivalry between two military academies. This game is the climax of the college football season and the last match in the Commander-in-Chief's Trophy series, which also involves the Air Force Academy from Colorado.

The Battle for the Bell is a college football rivalry between Marshall University's Thundering Herd and Ohio University's Bobcats. Their campuses are about 80 miles apart, and the winner gets a bell trophy. After Marshall switched conferences in 2005, the rivalry paused but resumed unexpectedly in 2009 during the Little Caesars Pizza Bowl, which Marshall won 21–17. They then signed a six-year contract in 2010. Ohio currently leads the series with 33 wins to Marshall's 20, with 6 ties.

question: What station broadcast the episode "Marry Me a Little, Marry Me a Little More" , of the series created by Max Mutchnick and David Kohan?
pos: Will & Grace, an American sitcom by Max Mutchnick and David Kohan, revolves around the friendship of Will Truman, a gay lawyer, and Grace Adler, a straight interior designer, set in New York City. Originally airing from September 21, 1998, to May 18, 2006, for eight seasons, the show returned on NBC on September 28, 2017. It gained fame for featuring gay lead characters, making it one of the most successful TV series of its kind during its original run.

"Marry Me a Little, Marry Me a Little More" is a special two-part episode from the fifth season of the TV show "Will & Grace". It was written by Jeff Greenstein and Bill Wrubel and directed by James Burrows. The episode first aired on NBC on November 21, 2002, and features guest appearances by Harry Connick Jr., Katie Couric, Judith Ivey, and Debbie Reynolds.
neg: Boston Common was a TV sitcom made by David Kohan and Max Mutchnick. It aired on NBC from 1996 to 1997. In its first season, it was one of the top 10 highest-rated shows, ranking 8th with a household rating of 15.6. However, when it moved to Sundays for its second season, its ranking plummeted from 8th to 52nd place.

David Sanford Kohan, born on April 16, 1964, is an American TV producer and writer. He worked on shows like The Wonder Years and The Dennis Miller Show before co-creating and producing series like Will & Grace, Boston Common, Good Morning, Miami, Twins, and Four Kings with Max Mutchnick. Kohan has won an Emmy and a People's Choice Award and has also been nominated for a Golden Globe. Alongside his business partner Max Mutchnick, he collaborated on a comedy series called Partners for CBS.

James Carroll, born in America and later a Canadian citizen, was an actor and radio personality. He's most famous for his role as Max Sutton on the CBC Television series "Wind at My Back," which aired from 1996 to 2001. Later in life, Carroll transitioned into community radio in Huntsville, Ontario. Starting in 2010, he hosted various shows on Hunters Bay Radio (CKAR-FM), including a local afternoon show, a Top 20 countdown, Motown Mondays, and a local talent showcase. His efforts helped the station grow from a small online operation in a basement to a full-fledged FM radio station with 60 employees by 2016.

The Stones is a sitcom about the Stone family, who are divorced but still live together. It aired on CBS starting March 17, 2004, but unfortunately, it was canceled after just three episodes because not enough people were watching. Originally planned for 2003, the show was delayed. David Kohan, Max Mutchnick, and Jenji Kohan produced it.

The first episode of the TV show Will & Grace, also known as Pilot or Love and Marriage, aired on September 21, 1998, on NBC. In this episode, Grace Adler gets a surprise marriage proposal from her boyfriend. Her best friend, Will Truman, who is gay, wants to be supportive but ultimately tells her she's making a mistake, risking their friendship. Things get even more complicated when Grace's assistant, Karen Walker, and Will's friend, Jack McFarland, get involved.

Partners is a comedy show that aired on CBS in 2012, on Monday nights right after How I Met Your Mother. It was created by Max Mutchnick and David Kohan, who also produced it, and it stars Michael Urie, David Krumholtz, Sophia Bush, and Brandon Routh.

"Four Kings" was an American sitcom that premiered during NBC's winter 2006 lineup but got axed before the season finale. It aired on Thursdays at 8:30pm and featured Seth Green, Josh Cooke, Shane McRae, and Todd Grinnell. The show was brought to life by David Kohan and Max Mutchnick, known for their work on "Will & Grace."

"Good Morning, Miami" was a TV comedy that aired on NBC from 2002 to 2004. It was created by David Kohan and Max Mutchnick. The show followed Jake, the executive producer of a poorly performing morning show in Miami, and delved into his personal and work experiences.

question: Georges-Henri Bousquet translated the work of a historian who is of what heritage?
pos: Georges-Henri Bousquet, born in 1900 and passed away in 1978, was a French scholar who focused on law, economics, and the study of Islam. He taught at the University of Algiers, specializing in the sociology of North Africa, particularly the Berbers and Islam. Bousquet was renowned for translating works by prominent Muslim thinkers like Al-Ghazali and Ibn Khaldun. He was also known for his proficiency in multiple languages, both European (including Dutch, English, German, Italian, Spanish, Danish, Norwegian) and Eastern (such as Arabic and Malay).
Ibn Khaldun, born on May 27, 1332, and passed away on March 17, 1406, was a historian from North Africa.
neg: Sally Gibson, an author, archivist, and heritage consultant based in Toronto, has written three books about the city's history. She holds a Master of Urban Studies from Yale University, and earned a Master of Library Science and a Ph.D. in Urban Geography from the University of Toronto. Originally from New Jersey, she attended Vassar College before moving to Toronto in 1969. Her first book, "More than an Island: A History of the Toronto Island," was praised by urban thinker Jane Jacobs. "Inside Toronto: Urban Interiors 1880s to 1920s," her second book, was a finalist for the City of Toronto Book Award and won a Heritage Toronto Book Award of Excellence in 2007. Her third book, "Toronto’s Distillery District: History by the Lake," stemmed from her role as the Distillery District's site historian and won a Heritage Toronto Book Award of Merit in 2009.

Jean Portante, born in Differdange, Luxembourg, and now living in Paris, is a versatile writer who has penned novels, stories, plays, journalism, and poetry. His works have been translated into multiple languages, including English. Not only does he write, but he also translates poetry from Spanish, Italian, English, and German into French. Among his notable works are "Mrs Haroy ou la mémoire de la baleine" and the biography "Allen Ginsberg: L'autre Amérique." Portante's poetry collection "L’Etrange langue" earned him prestigious awards, including the Mallarmé award in France. He has been recognized for his lifetime contribution to poetry, receiving the Grand Prix d’Automne de la Société des Gens de Lettres. Additionally, he is a member of the Académie Mallarmé and co-founded the French poetry magazine "Inuits dans la jungle." In Luxembourg, he leads the literary magazine "Transkrit." Portante's accolades include Luxembourg’s Batty Weber National Prize. His recent publications include "En réalité," "La réinvention de l'oubli," "Conceptions," and "Après le tremblement."

Professor Ghulam Nabi Firaq, born on July 15, 1927, and passing away on December 17, 2016, was a Kashmiri poet, writer, and educator. He dedicated fifty years to writing poetry and prose, exploring various poetic forms like blank verse, free verse, sonnets, quatrains, metric poems, and lyrics, alongside translating numerous English poems into Kashmiri. His efforts greatly enhanced the language's expressiveness, aligning it with modern sensibilities. He also authored essays and articles in Kashmiri, his mother tongue, since the early 1950s, advocating for its significance in literary expression. As a critic and historian, he sought to evaluate and elevate Kashmiri poetry over the past five centuries, earning recognition such as the Sahitya Akademi Award for his contributions to Kashmiri literature. Firaq is esteemed for his endeavors in preserving Kashmir's rich cultural heritage and language.

The Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park, managed by the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation, is a 1000-acre park in Massachusetts. It highlights the importance of canals in moving goods between growing industrial areas. Located in Uxbridge, it's a key part of the Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor. This area played a crucial role in America's industrial revolution. The park includes the historic Stanley Woolen Mill, undergoing redevelopment for commercial and tourism purposes. The Native American name for the village here was Wacentug, meaning bend in the river.

Don Bousquet, born in 1948, is a cartoonist from Rhode Island. He's known for his cartoons appearing in The Providence Journal, Rhode Island Monthly, and the South County Independent, as well as other publications like Yankee Magazine. Many of his popular works were published by Covered Bridge Press. On March 29, 2014, he retired from his Sunday spot in The Providence Journal and began to wind down his drawing career.

Armando Mook, also known as Armando Moock Bousquet (born in Santiago in 1894 and died in Buenos Aires in 1942), was a writer and playwright from Chile. He is best known for his play "Arm in Arm Down the Street," which was made into movies in 1956 and 1966. Some of his other notable works include "Los demonios" (1917) and "La Serpiente" (1919), with "La Serpiente" being considered his most acclaimed work. He lived during the same time as Germán Luco Cruchaga.
Latresne is a town in the Gironde region of southwestern France. It's where Georges-Henri Bousquet, a French legal expert and scholar of Islam who lived in the 20th century, passed away.

John Bradley Hirst (9 July 1942 – 3 February 2016) was an Australian historian and commentator known for his teaching, research, and writing. He was born in Adelaide, attended Unley High School, and studied at the University of Adelaide. Instead of pursuing his early aspiration to become a Methodist Minister, he became a lecturer at La Trobe University in Melbourne in 1968, where he spent his entire career. He married Christine, his fellow student, and they had two children. Hirst held various roles at La Trobe, including head of department and Reader in History, until his retirement in 2006. Even after retirement, he continued as an Emeritus Scholar until his passing. Hirst was recognized for his innovative teaching methods, particularly in Australian history and European cultural heritage. His notable work, "The Shortest History of Europe," was translated into nine languages. He also served as editor of Historical Studies, a prominent Australian historical journal, from 1977 to 1980. In his retirement, he volunteered his time to mentor post-graduate students in Sydney on thesis writing.

question: In which city are the headquarters of the American research and scientific development company where Ravi Sethi worked as computer scientist located?
pos: Ravi Sethi, born in 1947, is an Indian computer scientist who used to work at Bell Labs and now leads Avaya Labs Research. He's also on the advisory committee for the National Science Foundation's Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE). Sethi is famous for co-authoring the popular computer science textbook often referred to as the Dragon Book, along with two others.

Nokia Bell Labs, previously known as AT&T Bell Laboratories, Bell Telephone Laboratories, and Bell Labs, is a research and development company based in the United States. It is owned by the Finnish company Nokia and has its main headquarters in Murray Hill, New Jersey. Additionally, it has laboratories in various locations across the United States and in other countries as well.
neg: Nuria Oliver, a computer scientist, currently holds positions as the Director of Data Science Research at Vodafone and the Chief Data Scientist at DataPop Alliance. Previously, she served as the Scientific Director at Telefónica and worked as a researcher at Microsoft Research. With a PhD from MIT's Media Lab and recognition as an IEEE Fellow, she's highly regarded. Known for her expertise in computational models of human behavior, human-computer interaction, mobile computing, and leveraging big data for social impact, she's among Spain's most cited female computer scientists, with her research cited in over 11,800 publications.

Pharma Medica Research Inc. is a company in the United States that conducts research and development for pharmaceutical and biotechnology firms. It's located in Toronto, Canada, with its main office in Mississauga, Ontario. Additionally, it has offices in Scarborough, Ontario, and St. Charles, Missouri.
In computer science, the Sethi–Ullman algorithm, named after its inventors Ravi Sethi and Jeffrey D. Ullman, helps convert abstract syntax trees into machine code using the fewest registers possible.

Annie J. Easley, born in 1933 and passing away in 2011, was a remarkable African-American woman who excelled in computer science, mathematics, and rocket science. She contributed significantly to the development of software for the Centaur rocket stage while working at NASA's Lewis Research Center, which is now called the Glenn Research Center. Easley was also among the first African-Americans to work as a computer scientist at NASA, paving the way for others in her field.

David Harold Bailey (born 1948) is a mathematician and computer scientist. He got his bachelor's degree in math from Brigham Young University in 1972 and his doctorate from Stanford University in 1976. He spent 14 years as a computer scientist at NASA Ames Research Center before joining the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in 1998. Although he's retired officially, he still conducts research actively. Additionally, he serves as a Research Associate in the Department of Computer Science at the University of California, Davis.

The book "Compilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools" written by Alfred V. Aho, Monica S. Lam, Ravi Sethi, and Jeffrey D. Ullman, is a well-known computer science textbook that explains how to build compilers. It was first published in 1986 and is considered the go-to book for learning about compiler technology.

Franz Josef Och, born on November 2, 1971, is a German computer scientist. He currently holds the position of Head of Data Science at Grail, which is a company owned by Illumina. Before joining Grail, he served as the Chief Data Scientist at Human Longevity Inc. Prior to that, he worked at Google as a Distinguished Research Scientist and headed the machine translation division at Google's headquarters in Mountain View, California, just south of San Francisco.

The University of Berat is a private, secular institution offering higher education programs at state-regulated fees. Established in 2009, it initially had two faculties: Social Sciences and Economics. Over time, it expanded its offerings to include programs in various fields such as education, language, nursing, engineering, computer science, and information technology. By the 2010-2011 academic year, it had added faculties of Medical Sciences and Architecture. The university emphasizes academic excellence, research, and intellectual growth, striving to enhance the quality of education through projects and initiatives.

question: What is the full name of the viral respiratory disease in which Yi Guan's research helped to prevent the outbreak of?
pos: Here's a simpler version: Below is a timeline showing what happened during the SARS outbreak from 2002 to 2004.

Yi Guan, a Chinese virologist, was ranked 11th globally in microbiology by Thomson Reuters (now Clarivate Analytics) in 2014. He played a crucial role in preventing the 2004 outbreak of SARS in China through his research on the disease. Currently, he serves as the Director (China affairs) of the State Key Laboratory for Emerging Infectious Diseases at the University of Hong Kong. In 2017, Guan issued a warning about the H7N9 influenza virus, stating that it presents a significant threat to humanity, perhaps the most serious in the past century.
neg: Pulmonary rehabilitation, also called respiratory rehab, is crucial for managing and maintaining the health of people with chronic respiratory diseases who still have symptoms or reduced function despite regular medical treatment. It's a broad approach that involves various therapies recommended by medical experts to help patients with chronic respiratory issues feel better and do more in their daily lives. This can include different services provided to patients and their families to enhance the patient's quality of life. Pulmonary rehab can happen in different places, depending on what the patient needs, and it might involve medication or not.

The Journal of Thoracic Disease is a medical journal focused on lung health that anyone can read. It started in December 2009 and comes out every month thanks to AME Publishing Company. It's backed by some big names in respiratory health like the State Key Laboratory of Respiratory Disease and the Guangzhou Institute of Respiratory Disease. The boss in charge is Zhong Nanshan from the Guangzhou Institute of Respiratory Diseases. According to the Journal Citation Reports, in 2016, it had an impact factor of 2.365.

The Irish Thoracic Society (ITS) is the main group for healthcare professionals who work with people having long-term or sudden breathing issues in Ireland. Members include doctors specializing in respiratory health, pediatricians, surgeons, general practitioners, nurses, physiotherapists, pharmacists, dietitians, therapists focusing on lung function, scientists, and other healthcare providers interested in respiratory care across Ireland, both in the North and the South.

SARS, a type of severe respiratory illness, is caused by a virus called the SARS coronavirus. From November 2002 to July 2003, there was an outbreak of SARS in southern China. It resulted in 8,098 cases and 774 deaths across 37 countries, with most cases occurring in Hong Kong. The World Health Organization reported a fatality rate of 9.6% in Hong Kong. Since 2004, there haven't been any reported cases of SARS worldwide.

Chronic Respiratory Disease is a medical journal published four times a year. It focuses on research about respiratory diseases like chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, respiratory failure, and obstructive sleep apnea. The journal's editors-in-chief are Mike Morgan from Glenfield Hospital, Carolyn Rochester from Yale University, and Sally Singh also from Glenfield Hospital. Chronic Respiratory Disease was started in 2004 and is published by SAGE Publications.
SARS, short for severe acute respiratory syndrome, is a viral respiratory illness that comes from animals and is caused by the SARS coronavirus.

Feline viral rhinotracheitis (FVR) is a respiratory infection in cats caused by a virus called feline herpesvirus 1. It's sometimes called feline influenza or feline pneumonia, but those terms actually refer to different illnesses. FVR is widespread and can be severe, especially in places like catteries and kennels. It's one of the most common respiratory diseases in cats, along with another virus called feline calicivirus.

Chronic infections like Mycoplasma pneumonia and Chlamydia pneumonia can trigger and worsen asthma by causing ongoing inflammation, blocking the clearance of mucus, and increasing mucus production in the airways. Additionally, children who have severe viral infections early in life, mainly from respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and human rhinovirus (HRV), are more likely to develop asthma later on. While RSV infections raise asthma risk in young children, this link weakens as they get older. HRV, however, is closely tied to bronchiolitis and asthma development. For people with existing asthma, viral infections like HRV, especially in the upper respiratory tract, can lead to sudden asthma flare-ups. In summary, these microbes—Chlamydia pneumoniae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and human rhinoviruses—play a significant role in non-allergic asthma.

question: Which Kentucky Writers Hall of Fame author has had works published by Dim Gray Bar Press?
pos: Dim Gray Bar Press, an independent publisher, produced limited edition books using letterpress printing at The Center for Book Arts in New York City. It was founded by Barry Magid in 1989. Their first book, "Dialogue About A Hidden God," translated by Thomas Merton, was a work of Nicholas of Cusa. They printed subsequent works in small editions, usually fewer than 100 copies, featuring authors like Martine Bellen, Wendell Berry, and others. Magid also edited "Father Louie: Photographs of Thomas Merton" by Ralph Eugene Meatyard. The press stopped operating in 2000. Barry Magid is also known as a psychoanalyst and a Dharma heir to Charlotte Joko Beck in the Ordinary Mind Zen School.

Wendell Erdman Berry, born on August 5, 1934, is an American writer known for his novels, poems, essays, and activism. He's received numerous awards including The National Humanities Medal and the Jefferson Lecturer for 2012. In 2013, he was named a Fellow of The American Academy of Arts and Sciences and received the Richard C. Holbrooke Distinguished Achievement Award. He made history on January 28, 2015, by becoming the first living writer to be inducted into the Kentucky Writers Hall of Fame.
neg: The Nebula Award for Best Novel is given every year by the Science Fiction and Fantasy Writers of America (SFWA) for science fiction or fantasy novels. A novel, according to the organization, is a work of fiction that is at least 40,000 words long. They also give awards for shorter works like short stories, novelettes, and novellas. To be eligible for the Nebula Award, a novel must be published in English in the United States. However, novels published in English outside the US are also eligible if they're available on a website or as an electronic edition. This award has been given annually since 1966. Novels that are expanded versions of previously published short stories can be considered, as well as novellas published separately if the author requests them to be considered as a novel. The Nebula Award is considered one of the most important in American science fiction, similar to the Emmy Awards for science fiction and fantasy.

Melissa Fay Greene, born on December 30, 1952, is an American writer known for her nonfiction books. She graduated from Oberlin College in 1975 and has written six nonfiction books. She was a finalist for the National Book Award twice and was inducted into the Georgia Writers Hall of Fame in 2011. Her books have been translated into 15 languages.

The New York State Writers Hall of Fame, also known as NYS Writers Hall of Fame, started in 2010 by the Empire State Center for the Book and the Empire State Book Festival. It's based at the New York State Library in Albany, New York, and aims to showcase the state's literary history and honor exceptional writers from New York.

Judith Ortiz Cofer was a renowned Puerto Rican American author who wrote poetry, short stories, autobiographies, essays, and young-adult fiction. She taught creative writing at the University of Georgia for 26 years and received accolades like being inducted into the Georgia Writers Hall of Fame in 2010 and winning the University's 2014 Southeastern Conference Faculty Achievement Award in 2013.

Jay Cronley, born in 1943 and passing away in 2017, was an American newspaper columnist for the Tulsa World. He wrote several funny fiction books like Fall Guy, Good Vibes, Quick Change, and Funny Farm. However, most of his books are no longer in print. In 2002, he was honored by being inducted into the Oklahoma Writers Hall of Fame.

Claude Sheetz Blinkey Horn (1885–1937) was an American sportswriter in the early 20th century, famous for his contributions to the Nashville Tennessean. He was honored as a founding member of the Tennessee Sports Hall of Fame in 1966 and was also inducted into the Tennessee Sports Writers Hall of Fame.

Win Blevins, born in 1938, is a popular American author known for writing historical fiction, non-fiction, fantasy, and various other forms of literature like short stories and articles. He's particularly famous for his books about mountain trappers in the American West and is praised for his deep knowledge of western culture. Some of his well-known works include "Stone Song," "So Wild a Dream," and "Dictionary of the American West," which is available in 728 libraries worldwide. Blevins has received several prestigious awards throughout his career, including the Owen Wister Award for Lifetime Achievement in western literature, induction into the Western Writers Hall of Fame, and winning two Spur Awards for his western novels. He's also been honored as 'Writer of the Year' twice by the Wordcraft Circle of Native Writers.

Franci Cerar is a Slovenian sci-fi writer whose stories appeared in several issues of the Croatian sci-fi magazine Sirius. One of his well-known pieces is a short story called "Umor targumskega diplomata," featured in issue 6 of MINI YU SIRIUS. Other works of his in Sirius include "Izumi skromnega mladeniča," "Drugo rojstvo," and "Ubogi človek." These stories were all translated from Slovenian to Croatian by Krunoslav Poljak.

question: What director worked with Vikram Bhatt on a film starring actors Rajneesh Duggal and Adah Sharma?
pos: 1920 is an Indian horror film from 2008, written and directed by Vikram Bhatt. It's about a married couple who move into a haunted house in 1920. The film stars newcomers Rajneesh Duggal and Adah Sharma as the couple, with Indraneil Sengupta in a special role. It's the first movie in the 1920 series, which did well both critically and financially. It was also dubbed into Telugu as 1920 Gayathri. A sequel came out in 2012, receiving mixed reviews but still making money. The film takes inspiration from the 1973 horror classic, The Exorcist.

1920 is a series of Indian horror films directed by Vikram Bhatt, Bhushan Patel, and Tinu Suresh Desai, with Vikram Bhatt also writing the story for all three films. The first film came out in 2008, directed by Vikram Bhatt, followed by one in 2012 by Bhushan Patel, and the third, directed by Tinu Suresh Desai, is set for release in 2016. Both of the first two films were hits at the box office.
neg: Anhoniyon Ka Andhera was an Indian TV horror series that started on February 26, 2011, on Colors channel. It aired every Saturday at 11 PM IST and ended on July 9, 2011. The show, produced by Bollywood's Vikram Bhatt, tells stories about Anahita Malik, a girl with supernatural abilities. Additionally, on April 30, 2011, actors Mahaakshay Chakraborty and Tia Bajpai appeared on the show to promote their film "Haunted 3D," which was also produced by Vikram Bhatt.

The Bollywood movie "Be Careful" came out in late October 2011. It was directed by Chandrakant Singh and featured actors like Rajneesh Duggal, Tanisha Mukherjee, Kiran Rathod, Zaid Hameed, and Shillpi Sharma. Other cast members included Rajpal Yadav, Asrani, Shakti Kapoor, Sanjay Mishra, and Tiku Talsania.

Spark is a movie from India. V. K. Singh wrote and directed it, and Rekha Yadav and Naresh Gupta produced it. The main actors are Rajneesh Duggal and Subhasree Ganguly, with Govind Namdeo, Ashutosh Rana, Rohit Raj, and Rati Agnihotri in supporting roles. It came out on October 2, 2014.

Inteha is a Bollywood movie that came out on October 24, 2003. Produced by Mukesh Bhatt and directed by Vikram Bhatt, it features actors like Ashmit Patel, Vidya Malvade, and Nauheed Cyrusi. The story draws inspiration from the Hollywood film Fear. This movie also served as Ashmit Patel's debut. Just three months later, Vikram Bhatt directed another film called Aetbaar, also based on the Hollywood movie Fear.

The movie "Phhir" is an Indian romance and thriller featuring actors Rajneesh Duggal, Adah Sharma, and Roshni Chopra. It was made by ASA Productions and Enterprises Pvt. Ltd. and came out on August 12, 2011.

Rajneesh Duggal, an Indian actor and former model, clinched the Grasim Mr. India title in 2003 and was a runner-up in Mr. International. He also snagged the Kingfisher Model of the Year award in 2005. In May 2014, he emerged victorious in a reality stunt show. His Bollywood journey kicked off with a leading role in Vikram Bhatt's successful horror thriller "1920." Now, he's making his television debut in the series "Aarambh."

Udanchhoo is a new Hindi movie starring Rajneesh Duggal and Sayyeshaa. It's a mix of comedy, romance, and thrills. Directed by Vipin Parashar and produced by Sandeep Chandrra, the movie takes a humorous look at how spiritual leaders become commercialized in Mumbai. It's being made by R Vision India.

Ankahee, also known as Untold, is an Indian movie directed by Vikram Bhatt. It features actors like Aftab Shivdasani, Ameesha Patel, and Esha Deol. Initially named Aakhir, the film draws inspiration from the life of former Miss Universe Sushmita Sen, who was romantically linked with director Vikram Bhatt. Though the director later denied the connection, the movie revolves around a similar storyline.

question: Robert Smith founded the multinational company headquartered in what city?
pos: Robert Smith (1802-1867) was a politician from Illinois and a relative of Jeremiah Smith and Samuel Smith from New Hampshire. He established General Mills in 1856.

General Mills, Inc. is a big American company that makes and sells popular food brands in stores. They're based in Golden Valley, Minnesota, near Minneapolis. You've probably heard of some of their brands like Annie's Homegrown, Betty Crocker, Yoplait, and others. They have over 89 famous brands in the U.S. and are also popular worldwide.
neg: Namsung is a big company from South Korea with its main office in Seoul. It was started by Yoon Bong-Soo in 1965, making electronic products for other companies. Namsung has other smaller companies under it like Namsung Telecom, Nasco, Dreamer, Namsung International, and Namsung America.

Teleperformance, a French-based multinational company, specializes in handling various customer services for businesses globally. They offer services like customer support, technical assistance, and debt collection through their extensive network of 340 contact centers spread across 74 countries. With a workforce of 217,000 employees, Teleperformance caters to over 160 markets, including countries like France, the United States, India, and many others.

Stevanato Group is a big Italian company based in Piombino Dese, Padua, Italy. It started in 1949 and focuses on making sure that injectable medicines are safe and reliable by developing systems, processes, and services for them.

RetailMeNot, Inc. (previously known as Whaleshark Media) is a big American company based in Austin. They run several coupon websites, including RetailMeNot.com and VoucherCodes.co.uk, which are the biggest ones in the US and UK. Cotter Cunningham founded the company. They also buy other coupon sites and software from other companies.

Henkel AG & Company, KGaA, is a German company based in Düsseldorf, Germany, that makes chemicals and consumer products. It operates worldwide in both household and industrial markets. Established in 1876, it has three main divisions: laundry & home care, beauty care, and adhesive technologies. Henkel is famous for brands like Loctite, Persil, and Fa.

Hyrum W. Smith started Franklin Quest Company in 1981. They made the Franklin Planner and held seminars on productivity using concepts like the belief window. In 1997, Franklin Quest joined Covey Leadership Center, becoming Franklin Covey. Smith wrote "10 Natural Laws of Successful Time and Life Management" (1994) and "What Matters Most" (2001) and made other audio tapes.

Equinix, Inc. is a big company based in Redwood City, California. They're experts in helping organizations connect with each other, as well as with their employees, customers, partners, data, and clouds all around the world. They're the top provider of colocation data centers worldwide, with over 175 centers in 44 big cities across 22 countries on five continents.

Corey Smith, born in 1977, is a multi-talented American artist who paints, sculpts, takes photos, and designs snowboards. He used to work as an art director at COMUNE and founded the Drop City artist collective (although he's no longer involved). He also contributed art to CAPiTA Snowboards and started his own snowboard company called Spring Break Snowboards.

question: What amount was the settlement that the character from the Son of al Quada got in 2017?
pos: Omar Ahmed Sayid Khadr, a Canadian citizen, was held in Guantanamo Bay by the United States for ten years starting from when he was 16. During his time there, he admitted to killing U.S. Army Sergeant 1st Class Christopher Speer and faced other charges. He later said he only pleaded guilty to get back to Canada. Khadr sued the Canadian government, claiming they violated his rights under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. In 2017, the government settled the lawsuit by paying him $10.5 million (USD 8 million) and issuing an apology.

"Son of al Qaeda" is a documentary about Abdurahman Khadr, a Canadian whose father was linked to Osama bin Laden. It was made by Terence McKenna and Nazim Baksh. Abdurahman's brother, Omar Khadr, was also held at Guantanamo.
neg: The Fraley, et al. v. Facebook, Inc., et al. lawsuit was filed in California. It claimed that Facebook used users' names and faces in ads called Sponsored Stories without permission. The case ended with a settlement, and class members received $15.00 checks starting from November 17, 2016.

A liability insurance company has a responsibility called the duty to settle. This means they're expected to try their best to quickly and fairly settle claims where the policyholder is liable. Interestingly, most liability insurance policies don't specifically promise to settle. In California, if an insurer unreasonably refuses a fair settlement within the policy's limits, they can be held responsible for the full amount of the judgment against the insured, even if it's more than the policy covers. This duty exists because when there's an offer to settle a claim within the policy limits but for more than the policy amount, there's a conflict between the insurance company and the insured. If an insurer denies coverage, they do it at their own risk. Their belief about coverage shouldn't affect whether the settlement offer is reasonable. It's also their job to keep the insured informed about settlement offers. An insurer can also be held responsible for pressuring the insured to contribute to a settlement fund in an unreasonable way.

Mana Al Otaiba, born on May 15, 1946, in Abu Dhabi, UAE, was the former Minister of Petroleum and Mineral Resources under Sheikh Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan's presidency. After Sheikh Zayed's passing, he served as a Personal Advisor to Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan. Additionally, he was a member of the Royal Moroccan Academy under King Hassan II. His son is Yousef Al Otaiba.

Damian Wayne, also known as Damian al Ghul, is a made-up hero (sometimes seen as a bad guy) in American comic books from DC Comics, often seen alongside Batman. He's Batman's son with Talia al Ghul, making him the grandson of Ra's al Ghul, another villain in the Batman series. Damian first showed up as a baby in a story from 1987, but that story wasn't part of the main storyline. After that, different stories from alternate universes explored Damian's life with different names. In 2006, Grant Morrison created the character Damian Wayne, who became part of the main Batman story in Batman #655, starting the "Batman and Son" storyline. Damian Wayne is the fifth person to be Robin, Batman's crime-fighting partner.

Here's a simpler version of the paragraph:

This list shows the 20 biggest agreements between the US Department of Justice and drug companies from 1991 to 2012, ranked by settlement size. Settlements include both civil fines (under the False Claims Act) and criminal fines. Glaxo's $3 billion settlement is the largest civil one ever, while Pfizer's $2.3 billion includes a $1.3 billion criminal fine, a record. Legal issues against drug companies have been diverse, covering things like Medicare and Medicaid fraud, promoting drugs for unapproved uses, and poor manufacturing practices. For instance, the court ruled promoting drugs for unapproved uses broke the False Claims Act in Franklin v. Parke-Davis, resulting in a $430 million settlement.

Al Utouriya is a town in Qatar, which used to be in the Al Jemailiya municipality before that municipality became part of Al Rayyan. In 2014, Al Utouriya became part of the newly formed Al-Shahaniya Municipality.

Kasia Al Thani, originally from Kraków, Poland, became the third wife of Abdelaziz bin Khalifa Al Thani, who is the son of Khalifa bin Hamad Al Thani. She grew up in Los Angeles, USA, and admires Barack Obama. They met in Paris while Abdelaziz was living in exile there since 1992. It's said that she converted to Islam but doesn't wear a hijab. They got married, and together they have three daughters: Sheikha Malak, Sheika Yasmin, and Sheikha Reem. In 2007/2008, she started a luxury gift shopping website called Savoir-Faire.com. She found fraudulent activity on her husband's Barclays Bank account in Marbella, leading her to lead a €50m/£40m legal action against the bank. Barclays settled in 2009 for an undisclosed amount, after which she filed for divorce. She lives in Paris, France, rarely visiting the Middle East, and doesn't identify as Qatari. In 2012, she suggested to her close friend Baptiste Giabiconi that he should date Katy Perry.

Tell El Sakan was an important ancient Egyptian port town during the early Bronze Age. It was located at the mouth of wadi Ghazzeh, making it a vital hub for trade routes to Arabia, the Egyptian empire to the south, and the Canaan region to the north. The site, dating between 3500-2350 BCE, seems to have preceded the Tell al-'Ajjul settlement, which was affected by changes in the estuary. Tell El Sakan predates Egyptian military control of the Levant. Pottery findings at Tell El Sakan and Tell al-'Ajjul suggest a strong connection to ancient Egypt, while the Bronze Age settlement at Taur Ikhbeineh indicates local pottery production with interaction between Egyptians and Canaanites.

question: Considered the strongest recorded tropical cyclone, which cyclone had a film made about it in 2007?
pos: In 1999, a really powerful cyclone hit Odisha, a state in India, causing a lot of damage. It started as a small storm in the Andaman Sea and got stronger as it moved towards Odisha. The storm became extremely powerful with winds up to 260 km/h and hit Odisha on October 29th. It weakened after hitting land and eventually disappeared by November 1st.
Kathantara, also known as "Another Story" in English, is a 2007 Indian film in the Oriya language. Directed by Himansu Khatua, it portrays the challenges faced during the 1999 Odisha cyclone.
neg: Severe Tropical Cyclone Donna was the strongest tropical cyclone to hit the South Pacific off-season in May. It was the twenty-first tropical disturbance, the third named storm, and the second severe tropical cyclone of the annual cyclone season. Donna formed from a patch of bad weather first spotted west-northwest of Fiji on May 1, 2017. Initially called Tropical Depression 21F on May 2, it quickly intensified into a Category 1 cyclone and was named Tropical Cyclone Donna as it moved west and then south. By May 6, it peaked as a Category 4 cyclone but weakened due to wind shear and upwelling. However, it regained strength, reaching Category 5 status on May 8. As it encountered strong westerly winds, it rapidly lost power and eventually became a tropical low on May 10. By May 16, Donna had completely dissipated.

Severe Tropical Cyclone Anne was one of the strongest storms in the South Pacific during the 1980s. It started as a weak storm on January 5, 1988, northeast of Tuvalu. Over the following days, it got stronger and moved southwest. It became a tropical cyclone and was named Anne on January 8. By January 11, it was a Category 5 storm, the most severe category, and it hit Vanuatu and then New Caledonia. After interacting with another cyclone, it weakened and dissipated on January 14 southeast of New Caledonia.

Intense Tropical Cyclone Hondo (also known as 16S) was the strongest and longest-lasting cyclone of the 2007–08 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season. It formed from a tropical disturbance in early February, about 1,020 km east-southeast of Diego Garcia. The disturbance quickly grew stronger, becoming a moderate tropical storm on February 4 and a severe tropical storm the next day. Hondo then intensified rapidly into an intense tropical cyclone, reaching its peak intensity with winds of 215 km/h on February 7. It weakened over the next few days due to faster movement and cooler sea temperatures, degenerating into a remnant low-pressure area on February 12. The remnants moved west-northwest for about a week with no significant development. On February 20, over 2,780 km northeast of its last advisory point, the storm started to reform. The following day, it was reclassified as Tropical Disturbance Ex-Hondo, briefly becoming a tropical depression. Despite this, according to the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, Hondo continued strengthening and reached winds of 95 km/h before passing over Réunion, which caused it to weaken again. Finally, the storm dissipated on February 29 after completing a counterclockwise loop.

The 2002–03 cyclone season in the Australian region saw Cyclone Inigo, which matched the intensity of Cyclone Gwenda in 1999, making it the most powerful cyclone ever recorded in the Australian basin. This season lasted from November 1, 2002, to April 30, 2003. In this region, the cyclone year, which typically runs from July 1, 2002, to June 30, 2003, is distinct from the cyclone season. Most cyclones form in this region between these dates, located in the southern hemisphere between 90°E and 180°E. The season had ten tropical depressions, with the first one, named Tropical Cyclone 07S, appearing on December 27, 2002. The final system, Cyclone Epi, faded away on June 6, 2003. Monitoring of tropical cyclones in this area was handled by four Tropical Cyclone Warning Centres: the Australian Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) in Perth, Darwin, and Brisbane, along with one in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea.

Super Cyclonic Storm Gonu, also known as Cyclone Gonu, was the most powerful tropical cyclone ever recorded in the Arabian Sea and the strongest named cyclone in the northern Indian Ocean. It formed from a persistent stormy area in the eastern Arabian Sea on June 1, 2007, becoming the second named tropical cyclone of the 2007 North Indian Ocean cyclone season. With ideal upper-level conditions and warm sea temperatures, Gonu rapidly grew stronger, reaching peak winds of 235 km/h (145 mph) on June 4, according to the India Meteorological Department. However, it weakened due to dry air and cooler waters, and on June 6, it struck the easternmost tip of Oman, marking the strongest tropical cyclone to hit the Arabian Peninsula. Afterward, it moved northward into the Gulf of Oman, and on June 7, it dissipated after hitting southern Iran, making it the first time a cyclone had made landfall in Iran since 1898.

Tropical Cyclone Kesiny was the first recorded tropical cyclone in May 2002 to hit the south-west Indian Ocean. It formed on May 2 from a weather disturbance near the equator. Its formation was influenced by an increase in the Madden–Julian oscillation, which also caused other storms in the region. Kesiny initially moved southeast but later changed direction to the southwest due to a strengthening ridge. On May 6, it became a tropical cyclone, weakened, but unexpectedly regained strength with an eye forming on May 9. It peaked with winds of 130 km/h before hitting Madagascar, weakened while crossing the country, then hit again before fading away on May 11.

In February and March 1992, Severe Tropical Cyclone Esau hit New Caledonia, making it the strongest cyclone on record there. It started as a weak tropical depression near Vanuatu, then gradually intensified as it moved southwest. After passing over several islands, it formed into a cyclone and looped around before heading towards Australia. Esau peaked as a Category 4 cyclone before turning towards Vanuatu and New Caledonia. It hit New Caledonia as a Category 3 cyclone and weakened into an extratropical cyclone before reaching New Zealand.

The 2011–12 South Pacific cyclone season was not very active, with only three cyclones happening. It lasted from November 1, 2011, to April 30, 2012, but any cyclones forming before June 30, 2012, counted for that season. The strongest cyclone was Severe Tropical Cyclone Jasmine, which came from outside the South Pacific basin. The Regional Specialized Meteorological Center (RSMC) in Nadi, Fiji, and the Tropical Cyclone Warning Center (TCWC) in Wellington, New Zealand, monitored cyclones in the region. RSMC Nadi gives an F designation to disturbances in or moving into the South Pacific. The United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) provides unofficial warnings for the South Pacific, using a number and a P suffix for storms equal to or stronger than a tropical storm. RSMC Nadi and TCWC Wellington use the Australian Tropical Cyclone Intensity Scale, measuring winds over ten minutes, while the JTWC uses the Saffir–Simpson Hurricane Scale, measuring winds over one minute.

question: At the 71st Golden Globe Awards for television in 2013, what achievement did Breaking Bad, police sitcom Brooklyn Nine-Nine and American Hustle attain?

DeMille Award for his lifetime achievements, with Diane Keaton accepting it on his behalf. question: Which actor does American Beauty and American Beauty have in common?

question: Are Hot Rod and The Memory of Our People both magazines?
pos: Hot Rod is a magazine in the US that comes out every month and focuses on hot rodding, drag racing, and muscle cars. They talk about how people make cars faster and look cooler.
The Memory of Our People is a magazine from Rosario, Argentina, started in 2004. In Spanish, it's called La Memoria de Nuestro Pueblo.
neg: The National Hot Rod Reunion brings together people who love nostalgic drag racing, custom car building, and cars in general, inspired by the California Hot Rod Reunion. The Fender Hot Rod DeVille is a type of guitar amplifier made by Fender. It's been around since 1996 as part of their Hot Rod amplifier series. It comes in two versions: one with two 12-inch speakers (called the 212) and another with four 10-inch speakers (called the 410). It's similar to another Fender amp called the Hot Rod Deluxe.

The California Hot Rod Reunion is a yearly gathering of drag racers, hot rod enthusiasts, and street rodders that takes place in Bakersfield, California. It was started by Steve Gibbs, who was the vice-president of the National Hot Rod Association, back in October 1992. Originally intended as a one-time event to bring together veteran drag racers, it has now become an annual tradition held in early October at the Auto Club Famoso Raceway just outside Bakersfield. The success of this event has led to the creation of similar gatherings, like the National Hot Rod Reunion in Bowling Green, Kentucky. Each year, the reunion honors individuals who have made significant contributions to the world of drag racing and hot rodding. The upcoming 25th annual event, sponsored by AAA and Good Vibrations Motorsports, is scheduled for October 21-23, 2016.

The Volvo T6, showcased at SEMA in 2005, was a unique concept car. Only one was ever made, but there was talk of making a few more. Interestingly, the engine sits behind the driver. Inspired by hot rod cars, it even won Hot Rod Magazine's 2004 Hot Rod of the Year award. Designed by Per Gyllenspetz from Labyrint studio and built by Leif Tufvesson, many see its shape and style as reminiscent of the Plymouth Prowler, aiming to give a modern twist to the classic hot rod look.

A rat rod is a type of hot rod or customized car that typically copies or amplifies the look of early hot rods from the 1940s, 1950s, and early 1960s. It's different from traditional hot rods, which aim to faithfully recreate or restore hot rods from that same time period.

The Fender Hot Rod Deluxe is a guitar amplifier made by Fender Musical Instruments Corporation. It came out in 1995 as part of the Hot Rod series and has been made ever since. ('Fender American Tube') amps, but this changed in 2002 when production moved from Corona, CA to Fender's Baja-Ensenada, Mexico facility.

Ala Kart is a special custom car, originally crafted in 1957 from a 1929 Ford Model A roadster pickup by George Barris, Richard Peters, and Mike Blackie Gejeian. Hot Rod Lincoln, a song by Charlie Ryan, came out in 1955. It was written as a response to Arkie Shibley's Hot Rod Race from 1951. question: Who was Chamberlain and Colonel of the military staff of The Merrie Monarch?
pos: Colonel Charles Hastings Judd (1835–1890) was an American businessman, rancher, courtier, and politician in the Kingdom of Hawaii. He held positions as Chamberlain and Colonel of King Kalākaua's military staff, accompanying the king on his global tour in 1881.

Kalākaua, also known as The Merrie Monarch, was the final king of the Kingdom of Hawai'i, ruling from February 12, 1874, until his death on January 20, 1891, in San Francisco, California. He was known for his lively personality and love for entertaining guests with his singing and ukulele skills. He played a significant role in reviving Hawaiian cultural practices, like the hula, which had been previously banned from public celebration.
neg: James Alexander Sandy Winnefeld Jr., born on April 24, 1956, is a retired United States Navy admiral who held several important roles. He served as the ninth Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff from August 4, 2011, to July 31, 2015. Before that, he was the fourth Commander of U.S. Northern Command (USNORTHCOM) and the 21st Commander of North American Aerospace Defense Command (NORAD) from May 19, 2010, to August 3, 2011. Earlier in his career, Winnefeld was the Director for Strategic Plans and Policy at The Joint Staff and also represented the U.S. on the U.N. Military Staff Committee. He also commanded the U.S. Sixth Fleet and served as the Commander of Allied Joint Command Lisbon. As the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Winnefeld was the second-highest-ranking officer in the U.S. Armed Forces, after the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He retired from the Navy in 2015 after more than 37 years of service, including a special mission in Afghanistan.

The Merrie Monarch Festival happens every year in Hilo, Hawaii, lasting for a week after Easter. It celebrates King David Kalākaua, known as the Merrie Monarch for supporting the arts and reviving Hawaiian cultural practices like the hula. Various hula schools, including some from the mainland U.S. and other countries, come to take part in performances and competitions. It's highly regarded as the top hula contest globally.

The muumuu, also known as muʻumuʻu, is a loose dress originally from Hawaii that drapes from the shoulder. Similar to aloha shirts, muumuus often feature vibrant colors and floral patterns inspired by Polynesian designs. Locally in Hawaii, muumuus for residents tend to have more understated colors. While not as commonly worn for work as aloha shirts nowadays, muumuus remain a popular choice for formal events like weddings and festivals such as the Merrie Monarch hula competition. Additionally, muumuus are favored as maternity wear due to their non-restrictive waistline.

George Walter Hunter Macfarlane (March 1, 1849 – February 20, 1921) was a British businessman, courtier, and politician in the Kingdom of Hawaii. He held various roles, including Colonel of the military staff for King Kalākaua, accompanying him on his 1881 world tour. Macfarlane also served as the king's final chamberlain and was with him at his death in 1891.
The Corps of Military Staff Clerks was a group in the Canadian Army that handled administrative tasks. It was set up in 1905, with its headquarters established at that time.

The Ottoman Military College, also known as the Imperial Military Staff College or Ottoman Army War College, was a two-year school in Istanbul, Turkey. Its main goal was to train staff officers for the Ottoman Army.

A military staff, also known as general staff, army staff, navy staff, or air staff depending on the branch, is a team of officers, enlisted personnel, and civilians who handle the administrative, operational, and logistical tasks for their unit. They manage communication between the commanding officer and other military units, while also sorting through information to ensure the commander gets what they need and filters out what isn't necessary.

Fabianne Pomaialoha Wong Dalire, also known as Aloha Dalire, was a renowned Hawaiian kumu hula, or master hula teacher. She achieved fame by winning the inaugural Miss Aloha Hula title in 1971 under the name Aloha Wong, coinciding with the establishment of the Merrie Monarch Festival that year. This title is considered the highest honor for solo women hula dancers.

question: Who has written more than 300 papers, Semyon Aranovich Gershgorin or Pavel Alexandrov?
pos: Pavel Sergeyevich Alexandrov, also known as Paul Alexandroff or Aleksandrov (7 May 1896 – 16 November 1982), was a mathematician from the Soviet Union. He wrote around 300 papers and made significant contributions to set theory and topology.

Semyon Aronovich Gershgorin (1901–1933) was a Soviet mathematician born in Pruzhany, Belarus, Russian Empire. He started studying at the Petrograd Technological Institute in 1923, became a Professor in 1930, and also worked at the Leningrad Mechanical Engineering Institute in that same year. One of his notable contributions is the Gershgorin circle theorem.
neg: In topology, the nerve of an open covering is a way to create a structured network from a bunch of overlapping open sets that cover a space X. This network helps us understand the space's important features in a simpler, more organized manner. It was first proposed by Pavel Alexandrov and has since been expanded into various forms, like the Čech nerve and hypercoverings, each offering different insights into the space's topology.

Pavel Urysohn, a Soviet mathematician of Jewish descent, is famous for his work in dimension theory, particularly for creating Urysohn's Metrization Theorem and Urysohn's Lemma, which are key ideas in topology. His name is honored in concepts like Urysohn universal space, Fréchet–Urysohn space, Menger–Urysohn dimension, and Urysohn integral equation. In 1923, he and Pavel Alexandrov updated the definition of compactness.
In the math area called topology, the Alexandroff extension is a method to make a noncompact space compact by adding just one point. It's named after the Russian mathematician Pavel Alexandrov.

Semyon Davidovich Aranovich, born on July 23, 1934, in Derazhnya, Ukraine, Soviet Union, and passed away on September 8, 1996, in Hamburg, Germany, was a film director from the Soviet Union and Russia.
Rafferty, also known as "Рафферти" in Russian, is a drama TV film from 1980 made in the Soviet Union. It was directed by Semyon Aranovich and adapted from a novel by American author Lionel White.
"Confrontation," also known as "Противостояние" (Protivostoyanie), is a six-part Soviet television film from 1985. It was directed by Semyon Aranovich and adapted from the novel by Yulian Semyonov.

The Year of the Dog is a Russian drama movie from 1994, directed by Semyon Aranovich. It was shown at the 44th Berlin International Film Festival and won the Silver Bear award for its excellent artistic contribution.

In math, the Gershgorin circle theorem helps us figure out a range for the numbers in a square matrix. This theorem was introduced by the Soviet mathematician Semyon Aronovich Gershgorin back in 1931. The spelling of his name can be found in different versions like Geršgorin, Gerschgorin, Gershgorin, Hershhorn, and Hirschhorn.

question: Which post DC Extended Universe actress will also play a role in what is intended to be the fifth installment of the DC Extended Universe?

Gal Gadot-Varsano, born on April 30, 1985, is an Israeli actress and model famous for portraying Wonder Woman in the DC Extended Universe. The DC Extended Universe is a collection of superhero movies made by Warner Bros. It features characters from DC Comics and all the movies are set in the same fictional world.

Suicide Squad, released in 2016, is an American superhero movie about a group of antiheroes from DC Comics. It's part of the DC Extended Universe. Aquaman is a new superhero movie from Warner Bros., part of the DC Extended Universe. It's directed by James Wan and features actors like Jason Momoa, Amber Heard, and Nicole Kidman.

Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice is a 2016 movie about Batman and Superman, two popular characters from DC Comics. Directed by Zack Snyder and released by Warner Bros. Pictures, it's part of the DC Extended Universe, which started with the movie Man of Steel in 2013. The screenplay was written by Chris Terrio and David S. Goyer. The movie stars Ben Affleck, Henry Cavill, Amy Adams, Jesse Eisenberg, Diane Lane, Laurence Fishburne, Jeremy Irons, Holly Hunter, and Gal Gadot. It's the first time Batman and Superman appear together in a live-action film, and it also introduces live-action versions of Wonder Woman, Aquaman, Flash, and Cyborg. "Man of Steel" is a 2013 superhero movie about Superman from DC Comics. It's a joint project between British and American companies and is the first movie in the DC Extended Universe. Directed by Zack Snyder, it stars Henry Cavill, Amy Adams, and others. The movie retells Superman's origin story, where Clark Kent discovers he's an alien with superpowers and becomes Superman to protect Earth. He faces General Zod, who wants to destroy humanity.

Wonder Woman, released in 2017, is an American superhero film based on the DC Comics character of the same name. Distributed by Warner Bros. Pictures, it is the fourth installment in the DC Extended Universe (DCEU). question: Who was the captain of the only battleship to provide gunfire support during the Vietnam War?
pos: The USS New Jersey (BB-62), also known as Big J or Black Dragon, is a battleship of the Iowa-class. It was named after the state of New Jersey and was the second ship in the US Navy to bear this name. Among the completed Iowa-class battleships, New Jersey earned the most battle stars for its combat actions. It was also the only US battleship to provide gunfire support during the Vietnam War.

Rear Admiral J. Edward Snyder, USN (Ret.) (October 23, 1924 – November 4, 2007), gained recognition as the captain of the battleship USS New Jersey during its deployment to the Vietnam War in 1968. He was admired by the crew for his approachable leadership style and ability to inspire them with his relaxed rules onboard the ship.
neg: Operation Market Time, launched in 1965 during the Vietnam War, was a joint initiative between the United States Navy, South Vietnam, and the United States Coast Guard Squadrons One and Three. Its goal was to block the movement of troops, weapons, and supplies from North Vietnam to certain areas of South Vietnam via sea routes and rivers. The Coast Guard contributed armed patrol boats and cutters, equipped with cannons for combat and gunfire support.

USS Trippe (FF-1075) was a type of ship called a frigate in the US Navy. It was built in Westwego, Louisiana, and became active in September 1970. After some training and a mission near Haiti in 1971, it went to a shipyard in Boston for upgrades. These upgrades included a new missile system called the Basic Point Defense Missile System, which was designed to protect against air and missile attacks. Trippe was the first ship of its kind to get this system. In 1972, after testing its new weapons, Trippe went to Southeast Asia to support aircraft carriers and provide naval gunfire support during the Vietnam War. Later, it visited ports in the Indian Ocean and the Persian Gulf. It returned to the US in December 1972 after a trip around the world.

The ongoing debate in the United States involves the Navy, Marine Corps, Congress, and groups like the United States Naval Gunfire Support Association discussing the role of naval gunfire support and naval surface fire support (NSFS) in the navy. They're trying to figure out how best to use naval artillery to support troops during operations like amphibious assaults.

Naval gunfire support (NGFS), also called shore bombardment, refers to using naval artillery to help troops, especially during amphibious assaults. It's part of Naval Fires, which includes various naval support disciplines. Today, it's a key part of supporting amphibious warfare alongside aircraft and ship-launched missiles. Naval guns have been used against shore defenses since ancient times.

During the Vietnam War, the United States Seventh Fleet, humorously nicknamed the "Tonkin Gulf Yacht Club," actively fought against enemy forces. They conducted various combat operations, including air strikes from attack carriers, naval gunfire support, amphibious missions, patrols, reconnaissance, and mine warfare.

In the late 1800s, the Italian Royal Navy started making new battleships. At first, these ships were smaller, had lighter armor, and were faster than those from other countries. The first batch of these ships, called the Ammiraglio di Saint Bon class, were limited in size because of money issues set by the government. Admiral Simone de Pacoret Saint Bon ordered two ships of this class, but the design was also influenced by Benedetto Brin, who took over as naval minister after Saint Bon died. Brin then designed the next set of battleships, the Regina Margherita class, which were bigger and meant to rival the battleships being built by Austria-Hungary. Brin passed away while these ships were being built. The next class of smaller battleships, the Regina Elena class, was designed by Vittorio Cuniberti and were the fastest in the world when completed. These ships all fought in the Italo-Turkish War of 1911–12, where they mainly supported Italian ground troops with naval gunfire because the Ottoman Navy stayed mostly in port.

Kirov was a Soviet Navy cruiser that served in various conflicts, including the Winter War and World War II. It tried to attack Finnish coastal defenses during the Winter War but had to retreat due to damage from near misses. In 1941, it led the evacuation of Tallinn and later provided gunfire support during the Siege of Leningrad. In 1944, it bombarded Finnish positions but didn't have any other significant roles in the war. Eventually, it was reclassified as a training cruiser in 1961 and sold for scrap in 1974.

Jean Bart was the second ship in a class of battleships called Courbet, which were the first of their kind for the French Navy. She was finished before World War I as part of a naval program in 1910. During the war, she was in the Mediterranean and helped sink the Austro-Hungarian cruiser Zenta on August 16, 1914. For most of the rest of 1914, she supported the Montenegrin Army with gunfire until she was hit by a torpedo from the submarine U-12 on December 21. Despite having three flooded compartments, she managed to sail to Malta for repairs, which took three and a half months. After repairs, she spent the rest of the war involved in the Otranto Barrage in the Adriatic Sea.

question: The Polar Bears featuring the voice of Armie Hammer, is also the same voice actor for which character in Cars 3?
pos: Armand Douglas Hammer, born on August 28, 1986, is an American actor known for various roles. The Polar Bears is a short 3D animated film from 2012 made by The Coca-Cola Company. It was produced by Ridley Scott, written by David Reynolds, and directed by John Stevenson. The movie stars Lin-Manuel Miranda, Armie Hammer, Jonathan Adams, and Megyn Price. It's about Coca-Cola's famous polar bears and was first shown on the company's website and YouTube on December 31, 2012.
neg: The Kermode bear, also called the spirit bear, is a rare type of black bear found in British Columbia, Canada. It's the official provincial mammal there. What makes it unique is that about one-tenth of these bears have white or cream-colored coats because of a special gene. Despite their color, they're not albino and aren't more related to polar bears or other blond bears than other black bears. Occasionally, a black bear mother can have a white cub.

Wapusk National Park, Canada's 37th national park, was established in 1996. It's situated in the Hudson Plains ecozone, about 45 km south of Churchill in northeastern Manitoba, Canada, along Hudson Bay. Getting to the park is tricky because it's far away and efforts are made to protect it. Its name, "Wapusk," comes from the Cree word for polar bear. The park is famous for Cape Churchill, known as the top spot globally to see and take pictures of wild polar bears. You can only reach Cape Churchill by helicopter or Tundra Buggy.

Richard Anthony Cheech Marin, born on July 13, 1946, is an American entertainer known for his work as a stand-up comedian, actor, voice actor, writer, and activist. Joe Dominguez, partnered with Don Johnson on the TV show Nash Bridges. Beatitude is the first album by Ric Ocasek, the main singer and songwriter of The Cars. It came out in 1982 under Geffen Records. The album includes Greg Hawkes from The Cars on keyboards, along with Jules Shear and Stephen Hague from Jules and the Polar Bears.

Nagesh Bhosle, an acclaimed Indian actor in films, television, and theater, recently starred in the Hollywood movie 'Hotel Mumbai' alongside Jason Isaacs, Armie Hammer, and Dev Patel. With over a hundred Indian film appearances and numerous TV show episodes, he has also delved into directing and producing, successfully creating six films. His debut film, 'Goshta Choti Dongraevadhi' (A story as small as a mountain), earned praise in 2009. Known for addressing contemporary Indian issues, his film 'Panhala' received critical acclaim, multiple awards, and was featured at various international film festivals.
