It has also been selected for prominent film festivals such as the Pune International Film Festival, Bodhisattva International Film Festival, and Orange City International Film Festival.

Cars 3, released in 2017, is an American 3D computer-animated film produced by Pixar and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures. Directed by Brian Fee, the screenplay was written by Kiel Murray, Bob Peterson, and Mike Rich. It serves as both a sequel to Cars and a standalone sequel to Cars 2. The movie features returning voices such as Owen Wilson, Bonnie Hunt, and Larry the Cable Guy, along with new voices including Cristela Alonzo, Chris Cooper, Armie Hammer, Nathan Fillion, Kerry Washington, and Lea DeLaria, as well as several NASCAR personalities. The storyline follows Lightning McQueen as he sets out to prove his racing prowess to a new generation of high-tech race cars.

Ian Grote Stirling, born on September 26, 1941, is a retired research scientist from Environment and Climate Change Canada. He also serves as an adjunct professor at the University of Alberta in the Department of Biological Sciences. His research mainly centers around Arctic and Antarctic zoology and ecology, with a specialization in polar bears. Stirling is highly regarded as one of the leading experts on polar bears globally. He has authored five books and over 150 articles published in respected scientific journals. Additionally, he has actively communicated the risks that global warming poses to polar bears through both his writing and speaking engagements.

The Lone Ranger is a 2013 movie set in the American Old West. Directed by Gore Verbinski and written by Justin Haythe, Ted Elliott, and Terry Rossio, it stars Johnny Depp as Tonto and Armie Hammer as John Reid, the Lone Ranger. The story follows Tonto's recollections of their early attempts to fight crime and bring justice to the Wild West. The film also features William Fichtner, Barry Pepper, Ruth Wilson, James Badge Dale, Tom Wilkinson, and Helena Bonham Carter in supporting roles. This movie marks the return of the Lone Ranger and Tonto characters to the big screen after a hiatus of more than 32 years.

question: Which tower is taller, 712 Fifth Avenue or Manhattan Life Insurance Building?
pos: The Manhattan Life Insurance Building, a 348-foot tower located at 64-66 Broadway in New York City, was completed in 1894 by the architects Kimball & Thompson. It was later extended north in 1904, with its new address becoming 64-70 Broadway. This building was a significant milestone as it was the first skyscraper in Manhattan to exceed 100 meters in height.

712 5th Avenue is a tall building located on the corner of 56th Street and Fifth Avenue in Midtown Manhattan, New York City. It stands at 650 feet tall and was built between 1990 and 1991. Despite its height, it ranks as the 53rd tallest building in New York City. The design of the tower had to consider the historical facades of the Coty and Rizzoli Buildings situated at its base. In 2007, the Bannister Trust bought the building through a Private Treaty and included it in Property Fund #1 managed by JP Morgan. Some people also know this building as the Henri Bendel building.
neg: Whole life insurance, also known as whole of life assurance in some countries, is a type of life insurance that lasts for the entire life of the insured person, as long as they keep paying the premiums. It's a contract between the insured and the insurer, ensuring that when the insured person dies, the insurer will pay a death benefit to the beneficiaries. Premiums for whole life insurance are usually higher compared to term life insurance because they stay the same throughout the insured person's life and build cash value over time. The insured typically pays premiums until death, but there are options for limited pay policies that can be fully paid in 10, 20 years, or at a certain age. Whole life insurance falls under the cash value category of life insurance, alongside universal life, variable life, and endowment policies.

Manhattan Life Insurance Company was founded on May 29, 1850. It's a life insurance company based in New York, but it's actually owned by Manhattan Life Group, which is headquartered in Houston, Texas.
The New York Life Insurance Building is the headquarters of the New York Life Insurance Company. It's situated at 51 Madison Avenue in Manhattan, New York City, right across from Madison Square Park.

The Supreme Life Building, situated at 3501 S. Dr. Martin Luther King Drive in Chicago, Illinois, is a significant landmark. It was constructed in 1921 as the headquarters of the Supreme Life Insurance Company, which was established just two years earlier. Originally named the Liberty Life Insurance Company, it was the first insurance company owned by African-Americans in the northern United States. This was crucial because other insurance companies often refused to provide life insurance to black customers. The Supreme Life Insurance Company played a vital role in ensuring that African-Americans in Chicago had access to life insurance. Over time, it grew to become the largest African-American owned business in the northern states and was a symbol of economic prosperity in the predominantly black Bronzeville neighborhood from the 1920s to the 1950s.

The Montreal New York Life Insurance Building, also called the Quebec Bank Building, is an office building located at Place d'Armes in Old Montreal. It was built between 1887 and 1889 and was the tallest commercial building in Montreal at the time. The first eight floors were meant for retail office space, which quickly attracted top lawyers and financiers from the city. Later, when the clock tower was finished, the owner added a ninth and tenth floor, creating the largest legal library in the country as a gift to the tenants. The building sits adjacent to another historic office tower, the Aldred Building.

Francis Hatch Kimball (1845–1919) was an architect from New York City, famous for designing tall buildings in downtown Manhattan and adding decorative terra-cotta elements. He partnered with the firm Kimball & Thompson and contributed to notable projects like the Empire Building, Manhattan Life Insurance Building, and the Casino Theatre on Broadway. Most of Kimball's projects were located in the United States.

The Flatiron Building, originally called the Fuller Building, is a famous triangular landmark in Manhattan, New York City. It's a 22-story steel-framed skyscraper located at 175 Fifth Avenue. Built in 1902, it was one of the tallest buildings in the city with 20 floors, and it stood out as one of the only two skyscrapers above 14th Street at the time. The building is situated on a triangular block created by Fifth Avenue, Broadway, and East 22nd Street, with 23rd Street touching the top corner. Its name comes from its shape, resembling a flatiron used for ironing clothes.

Physicians Mutual is an insurance company based in Omaha, Nebraska, USA. It started in 1902, initially offering health insurance to doctors. By 1962, it began offering policies to the general public and later expanded into life insurance in 1970 with the creation of Physicians Life Insurance Company. Today, it provides various insurance products, annuities, and services like Medicare, Medigap, Medicare Supplement, Term Life Insurance, Whole Life Insurance, Cancer coverage, and funeral pre-planning. The company has assets worth over US$3 billion and employs over a thousand people. Robert A. Reed serves as the CEO and president.

question: Who was born first, Arthur Conan Doyle or Penelope Lively?
pos: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, born on May 22, 1859, and passing away on July 7, 1930, was a British writer famous for creating Sherlock Holmes, the detective character. Although he started as a doctor, he gained recognition as an author when he released "A Study in Scarlet" in 1887, which was the first of four novels about Holmes and Dr. Watson. Doyle also wrote more than fifty short stories starring the iconic detective.

Dame Penelope Margaret Lively is a British author who writes fiction for both kids and adults. She's won prestigious awards like the Booker Prize for her book "Moon Tiger" in 1987 and the Carnegie Medal for children's literature for "The Ghost of Thomas Kempe" in 1973.
neg: Dead Man's Land is a World War I novel written by Robert Ryan, featuring Dr. Watson from the Sherlock Holmes series created by Arthur Conan Doyle. It's officially approved by the Conan Doyle Estate Ltd., and the book was written with permission from the literary estate of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.

The Adventure of the Empty House is a Sherlock Holmes story written by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. It's part of a collection called The Return of Sherlock Holmes, which includes 13 stories. After public demand, Conan Doyle revived Holmes, explaining how he survived a deadly encounter with Professor Moriarty. Conan Doyle considered The Adventure of the Empty House one of his top twelve favorite Holmes stories, ranking it sixth.

The movie "The Return of Sherlock Holmes" is a mystery film made in 1929 in the United States before the movie industry's stricter regulations. It was directed by Basil Dean and written by Arthur Conan Doyle, Basil Dean, and Garrett Fort. The film's title is inspired by the third volume of Sherlock Holmes stories, also called "The Return of Sherlock Holmes" by Arthur Conan Doyle. It features actors like Clive Brook, H. Reeves-Smith, Betty Lawford, Charles Hay, and Phillips Holmes. The movie premiered on October 29, 1929, through Paramount Pictures and is preserved in the Library of Congress.

The movie "Sherlock Holmes" is a silent film made in 1916 in America. It features William Gillette playing the role of Sherlock Holmes, based on Arthur Conan Doyle's character. Directed by Arthur Berthelet and produced by Essanay Studios in Chicago, the film is an adaptation of a 1899 stage play with the same title. The play itself was inspired by Conan Doyle's stories "A Scandal in Bohemia," "The Final Problem," and "A Study in Scarlet."

Grant Duff Douglas Ainslie (1865–27 March 1948) was a Scottish poet, translator, critic, and diplomat. He was born in Paris, France, and studied at Eton College and Oxford. Ainslie became friends with Oscar Wilde at Oxford when he was twenty-one. He was also associated with other notable figures like Aubrey Beardsley, Walter Pater, and Marcel Proust. Ainslie translated the works of Italian philosopher Benedetto Croce into English and taught about Hegel. He received twelve letters from Arthur Conan Doyle in 1895 - 1896, which were sold at auction in 2004.

The movie "Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes," released in 2010, blends elements of steampunk and mystery. Directed by Rachel Lee Goldenberg and produced by The Asylum, an American film studio, it draws inspiration from Doyle's famous characters but presents a new storyline. The plot follows detective Sherlock Holmes and his partner Dr. Watson as they unravel a mystery involving monster attacks and a threat to London. Gareth David-Lloyd portrays Dr. Watson, while Ben Syder, in his film debut, takes on the role of Sherlock Holmes.

The Lost World TV series, inspired by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's 1912 novel, aired in the U.S. starting in 1999, running for three seasons until 2002 when it was abruptly cancelled due to funding issues, leaving a cliffhanger ending. The unresolved storyline still intrigues fans, and the entire series was released on DVD in 2004.

Adrian Malcolm Conan Doyle (November 19, 1910 - June 3, 1970) was the youngest child of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and his second wife, Jean, also known as Lady Conan Doyle. He had two full siblings, a sister named Jean and a brother named Denis, and also two half-siblings, a sister named Mary and a brother named Kingsley.

question: The Tennessee Volunteers football team plays as a member for a conference in what city?

It competes in NCAA Division I, and for football, it's in the Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS), which used to be called Division I-A.

In 1984, the Tennessee Volunteers football team, also known as UT or the Vols, played in the NCAA Division I-A. Coached by Johnny Majors for his eighth year, they competed in the Southeastern Conference (SEC) and played home games at Neyland Stadium in Knoxville, Tennessee. They ended the season with a 7-4-1 record, winning 7 games, losing 4, and tying 1. Unfortunately, they lost to Maryland in the Sun Bowl. Their offense scored 327 points, while their defense allowed 276 points.
neg: The 1899 Tennessee Volunteers football team played for the University of Tennessee in the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association season. This was the first time UT had a head coach, J. A. Pierce, who led the team in 1899 and 1900. They won six games and lost two that season.

The 1983 Tennessee Volunteers football team, also known as Tennessee or the Vols, represented the University of Tennessee in the NCAA Division I-A football season. Coached by Johnny Majors in his seventh year, the team played at Neyland Stadium in Knoxville, Tennessee. The 1985 Tennessee Volunteers football team, also known as Tennessee or the Vols, played for the University of Tennessee in the 1985 NCAA Division I-A football season. The 1891 Tennessee Volunteers football team was the very first one for the University of Tennessee. They played their first game on Thanksgiving Day in Chattanooga, Tennessee against Sewanee. Unlike modern teams, they didn't have a head coach and were mostly made up of intramural players.

In 1896, the University of Tennessee had its first official football team in three years, called the Tennessee Volunteers. They played in the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association (SIAA) for the first time. The team had a perfect record of 4-0, marking their first-ever winning season. The 1938 Tennessee Volunteers football team, led by head coach Robert Neyland, played for the University of Tennessee that year. It was Neyland's third team at Tennessee after serving in the US Army. The 1930 Tennessee Volunteers football team, also known as Tennessee, UT, or the Vols, represented the University of Tennessee in college football. Tennessee and Vanderbilt were the only teams to score against Alabama that year. Overall, the 1930 Volunteers outscored their opponents 209 to 31 and achieved seven shutout victories.

question: Ernest Foot was the best friend of the fighter pilot who had how many victories?
pos: Major Ernest Leslie Foot, born on 19 May 1895 and passing away on 23 June 1923, was an English World War I flying ace. Credited with five aerial victories, he was also known as the best friend of Albert Ball.

Albert Ball, a decorated English fighter pilot in World War I, was the UK's top flying ace when he died in 1917. He had 44 victories, making him the fourth highest-scoring ace in the country, behind Edward Mannock, James McCudden, and George McElroy.
neg: Lydia Vladimirovna Litvyak, also known as Lilya, was a Soviet Air Force fighter pilot during World War II. She made history as the first woman to shoot down an enemy plane and one of two female fighter pilots to become a fighter ace. Over the course of approximately two years and 66 combat missions, she achieved twelve solo victories and four shared kills. Sadly, she was shot down near Orel during the Battle of Kursk while attacking a group of German planes.

Eino Ilmari Juutilainen, born on February 21, 1914, and passing away on February 21, 1999, was a fighter pilot in the Finnish Air Force. He holds the record for the highest number of confirmed kills among non-German fighter pilots. During World War II, he led all Finnish pilots in shooting down Soviet aircraft, with 94 confirmed victories out of 437 missions. He personally claimed 126 victories, with 34 of them achieved while flying the Brewster Buffalo fighter plane.

Manfred Meurer, born on September 8, 1919, and passed away on January 22, 1944, was a German fighter pilot in World War II. He became known as a flying ace for shooting down 65 enemy aircraft, ranking him as the fifth most successful night fighter pilot in history. He achieved all of his victories while defending the Western Front against the Royal Air Force's Bomber Command during missions for the Defense of the Reich.

Paul Anton Guido Zorner, originally named Paul Zloch, was a German pilot who flew night missions for the Luftwaffe during World War II. He's known for achieving 59 victories during 272 missions, with 110 of those specifically as a night fighter. Zorner ranked as the ninth most successful pilot in the Luftwaffe and in the history of aerial combat.

The IMAX movie "Fighter Pilot: Operation Red Flag" follows USAF F-15 Eagle pilot Captain John Stratton as he aims for success in his career. It focuses on his participation in USAF Red Flag training at Nellis AFB, where pilots simulate combat situations. Directed by Stephen Low and sponsored by Boeing, the film shows how airmen train for war scenarios without actual casualties, including training for firemen, ordnance crews, refueling operations, and cockpit perspectives. It was released in December 2004.

Ashley Rolfe is a female fighter pilot in the United States Air Force. She flies the McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle and is a member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard. On August 18, 2016, she became the first female fighter pilot in the 70-year history of the 104th Fighter Wing. Initially stationed at Kadena, she was the only female F-15 pilot in the 67th Fighter Squadron. In 2010, she was the sole female fighter pilot participating in Exercise Commando Sling, which was featured on Air Force TV News.

Flight Lieutenant Ayesha Farooq, born on August 24, 1987, is a Pakistani fighter pilot hailing from Bahawalpur. She made history by becoming the first female fighter pilot in the Pakistan Air Force. Achieving this milestone in 2013, she topped the final exams, making her the first and only Pakistani and South Asian female fighter pilot. Currently, she flies missions in a Chengdu J-7 fighter jet, made in China, alongside her 24 male colleagues in Squadron 20.

Egon Mayer, born on August 19, 1917, and passing away on March 2, 1944, was a German fighter pilot in World War II. He successfully shot down 102 enemy aircraft in 353 combat missions, all over the Western Front. Mayer holds the distinction of being the first pilot to achieve 100 victories solely on the Western Front.

question: From March 631 to April 631, Farrukhzad Khosrau V was the king of an empire that succeeded which empire?
pos: Farrukhzad Khosrau V, the son of Khosrau II, served as king of the Sasanian Empire for a short period, just from March to April 631.

The Sasanian Empire, also called the Sassanian or Neo-Persian Empire, was the last era of the Persian Empire before Islam took hold. It was ruled by the House of Sasan from 224 to 651 AD and was known as Ērānshahr to its people. Following the Parthian Empire, the Sasanians were a major global power for over 400 years, often rivaling the Roman-Byzantine Empire.
neg: The Duchy of Thuringia began around 631 when King Dagobert I of the Merovingian kingdom of Austrasia set it up as a border area in the east. This happened after his army lost to the Slavic confederation of Samo at the Battle of Wogastisburg. Later, during the Carolingian Empire, the duchy was recreated, and the kings appointed dukes to rule it until 908 when it was taken over by the Saxon dukes. Eventually, from about 1111/12, the Landgraves of Thuringia governed the territory as Princes of the Holy Roman Empire.

Khosrow IV briefly ruled as a usurper in 631 during a period of turmoil in the Sasanian Empire. He was the son of Mah-Adhur Gushnasp and Kahar-dukht. His reign, shrouded in mystery, likely only extended over a specific region rather than the entire empire, as there were other claimants to the throne at the time, like Hormizd VI. Khosrow IV's rule was short-lived, ending in his death after just a few days.

Samo created the first known political alliance of Slavic tribes, called Samo's Empire, which existed from 623 to 658 and spanned from Silesia to present-day Slovenia. He was originally a Frankish merchant and became a leader by uniting various Slavic tribes to fend off raids from nearby Avars. He showed remarkable bravery and leadership in battles, leading to his election as the Slavic king. In 631, he successfully defended his territory against the Frankish Kingdom in the Battle of Wogastisburg, which lasted three days.

Chach, born around 631 CE, was a Brahmin who became the ruler of Sindh in the middle of the 7th century. He used to be the prime minister for King Rai Sahasi II, and after the king's death, Chach married his widow to become the new king. During his reign, Chach expanded the kingdom of Sindh by conquering neighboring regions and groups, creating an empire that stretched across the Indus valley and beyond. His achievements were documented in a historical text called the Chach Nama.
Ashur-etil-ilani ruled as king of Assyria around 631 BC to 627 BC after his father, Ashurbanipal.

Suintila, also known as Swinthila or Svinthila, ruled as the Visigothic King of Hispania, Septimania, and Galicia from around 621 to 631. During his reign, he achieved peace in the Visigothic Kingdom, which enabled him to reclaim territories from the Byzantine Empire by 624. Suintila was the son of Reccared I and his wife Bado, and he had a brother named Geila who served as a general.
Samo's Empire refers to a Slavic tribal union led by King Samo from 631 to 658 A.D. Its main hub was probably in Moravia, and it encompassed regions like Silesia, Bohemia, Lusatia, and Carantania.

Hormizd VI was a ruler of some areas in Persia from 630 to 631. He emerged as a contender for power following the death of Khosrau II in 628. Hormizd VI held onto his position for around two years, mainly in the Nisibis region. He was Khosrau II's grandson.

question: Which suburb is a soap opera featuring a character named Beverly Marshall set in?

The show mainly focuses on the people who live on Ramsay Street, named after Max Ramsay's grandfather. Beverly Marshall is a character in the Australian soap opera Neighbours. Lisa Armytage originally played her, making her debut on July 6, 1987. Roger Howarth, born on September 13, 1968, is an American actor known for playing Todd Manning on the soap opera One Life to Live (OLTL). He won a Daytime Emmy Award for this role in 1994. "The Greatest Gift" was a popular American TV soap opera from the 1950s. It starred actors like Ward Costello, Anne Meara, and Jack Klugman, who played the character Jim Hanson.

John Black is a character on the TV show "Days of Our Lives." Actor Drake Hogestyn has played him since 1986, with a break from January 2009 to September 2011. Alamo Heights SA is a thrilling soap opera set in San Antonio, Texas. It has made history in multiple ways.

Victor Newman is a character on the TV show "The Young and the Restless," played by Eric Braeden since 1980. Originally meant to appear briefly, Victor became a central figure in the soap opera. Initially portrayed as a villainous and abusive husband, the character was supposed to be killed off but was kept due to Braeden's performance. Despite initial reluctance, Braeden signed a long-term contract and has stayed on the show for 37 years. Victor is known for his ruthless nature and has been involved in many controversial storylines and relationships.

Philip James Mitchell, often known as Phil Mitchell, is a character on the BBC soap opera EastEnders, portrayed by Steve McFadden. He first appeared on the show on February 20, 1990, along with his brother Grant (played by Ross Kemp), sister Sam (played by either Danniella Westbrook or Kim Medcalf), and mother Peggy (played by either Jo Warne or Barbara Windsor). Phil was initially portrayed as the more level-headed of the two. His character remained popular through the 2000s and 2010s. Katie Landers is a made-up person in the Australian soap opera Neighbours. Sally Jensen played her. She showed up on screen for the first time on February 15, 1988. question: Which country did the Falkland Islands beat in the 2010 Commonwealth games that has eleven administrative divisions?
pos: Gerald Reive, born on March 10, 1937, is a Falkland Islands athlete based in New Zealand. He competed in Lawn Bowls alongside George Paice at the 2010 Commonwealth Games in New Delhi, India, winning matches against Samoa and Guernsey. Reive also had the honor of being the flag bearer for the Falkland Islands at the closing ceremony. Currently, he plays lawn bowls at the Papatoetoe Hunters Corner Bowling Club in Auckland. Samoa, previously called Western Samoa until 1997, is a country in the Pacific known for its two main islands, Savai'i and Upolu, along with four smaller ones. The 2010 Commonwealth Games, also called the XIX Commonwealth Games, took place in Delhi, India from October 3 to 14, 2010. Archery is a sport that's sometimes included in the Commonwealth Games, which happen every four years. It first appeared in 1982 and then again in 2010. However, it's not guaranteed to be part of every Games since it's optional. The decision to include it is up to the host country.

KTV Ltd. is a television and radio service provider based in Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands, and also operates in some parts of the Camp. The Falkland Islands participated in the 2010 Commonwealth Games that took place in Delhi.

George Paice, born in 1941 in Fox Bay, Falkland Islands, is a lawn bowler from New Zealand. During the games, they won two matches against Guernsey and Samoa. Paice now plays at the Papatoetoe Hunters Corner Bowling Club in Auckland, New Zealand.

The 2010 Commonwealth Games, also called the XIX Commonwealth Games, took place in Delhi, India, from October 3 to 14. Over 6,000 athletes from 71 Commonwealth countries participated in 21 sports and 272 events, making it the largest Commonwealth Games ever. It was also the biggest international multi-sport event ever held in Delhi and India, surpassing the Asian Games held in 1951 and 1982. The opening and closing ceremonies were held at the Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium. These were the first Commonwealth Games held in India and the second in Asia after Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia in 1998. Additionally, it was the first time a Commonwealth Republic hosted the games, and the second time they were held in a country not currently led by the British monarch, the first being Malaysia in 1998. Shera was the official mascot, and the official song, "Jiyo Utho Bado Jeeto," was composed by renowned Indian musician A.R. Rahman.

question: Which Netflix series "Unbreakable" character is Elizabeth Claire Kemper known for playing?

Elizabeth Claire Liddell, a Scottish pianist and composer, was born in Glasgow on May 24th. She received her education at the Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama in Glasgow, as well as at the Royal College of Music in London under the tutelage of Andrew Lloyd Webber.

"Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt" is a TV comedy made by Tina Fey and Robert Carlock, starring Ellie Kemper. It's been on Netflix since March 6, 2015. Originally planned for 13 episodes on NBC in spring 2015, Netflix bought it and ordered two seasons instead.

Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt is a comedy TV show made by Tina Fey and Robert Carlock. It stars Ellie Kemper and has been on Netflix since March 6, 2015. It was supposed to air on NBC in spring 2015 for 13 episodes, but Netflix bought it and ordered two seasons instead.

The Wet Hot American Summer series is a comedy movie and two Netflix shows created by David Wain and Michael Showalter. It stars a bunch of actors like Janeane Garofalo, Paul Rudd, and Amy Poehler. Azie Mira Dungey is an American actress, comedian, and writer known for her work in the comedic web series Ask a Slave, where she wrote and starred in the lead role. Sam Means is a funny guy from America. He got three big awards called Emmys for making people laugh on The Daily Show with Jon Stewart. question: Which television series featured an actor who also performed in "The Young Ones"?
pos: Adrian Edmondson, born in 1957, is a well-known English comedian, actor, writer, musician, TV presenter, and director. He gained fame in the early 1980s during the rise of alternative comedy. He's most recognized for his funny roles in TV shows like "The Young Ones" (1982–84) and "Bottom" (1991–95), which he co-wrote with his longtime partner Rik Mayall. Edmondson also starred in various films as part of "The Comic Strip Presents..." series from the 1980s to the 1990s. In one episode, he created a parody heavy metal band called Bad News, and in another, he portrayed his character Eddie Monsoon, a provocative South African TV personality.

Bad News was a parody heavy metal band from England, formed for the TV show "The Comic Strip Presents..." The band consisted of Vim Fuego (real name: Alan Metcalfe) on vocals and lead guitar (played by Ade Edmondson), Den Dennis on rhythm guitar (Nigel Planer), Colin Grigson on bass (Rik Mayall), and Spider Eight-Legs Webb on drums (Peter Richardson).
neg: The Young Ones video game is inspired by the British comedy TV show of the same name.

Roland Rat is a British TV puppet character created and performed by David Claridge. "Oh, No! Not THEM!" is a TV series from 1990 in America, which is a remake of a British show called "The Young Ones."

Carole Gray, born in 1940 in Bulawayo, Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe), was a British dancer and actress known for her roles in 1960s West End musicals. She also appeared in TV shows like The Avengers and made her film debut as Cliff Richard's girlfriend, Toni, in The Young Ones (1961). Later on, she became known for her roles in horror films like Curse of the Fly, Devils of Darkness, and Island of Terror, earning her the nickname "the Scream Queen." She was married to Douglas Cullinan, a diamond heir.

Ben Elton, born on May 3, 1959, is a multi-talented English entertainer known for his work in comedy, writing, acting, and directing. He was active in London's alternative comedy scene during the 1980s and contributed as a writer to popular TV series like The Young Ones and Blackadder. Elton's comedic style at that time focused on left-wing political satire. Over the years, he has authored 15 novels spanning dystopian, satire, and crime genres. Additionally, he's behind the creation of musicals such as We Will Rock You (2002) and Love Never Dies (2010), the sequel to The Phantom of the Opera.

"Filthy Rich & Catflap" is a BBC sitcom from 1986, aired in 1987. It starred Nigel Planer, Rik Mayall, and Adrian Edmondson from "The Young Ones." Ben Elton wrote it (with some help from Mayall), Paul Jackson directed it (he also directed "The Young Ones"), and Ed Bye directed the film sequences. The music was by Peter Brewis. It ran for one series with six half-hour episodes.

David Mirkin, born in 1955, is an American filmmaker and TV creator. He initially wanted to be an electrical engineer but switched to film studies at Loyola Marymount University. He started as a stand-up comedian and then transitioned to writing for TV shows like Three's Company, It's Garry Shandling's Show, and The Larry Sanders Show. He also ran the series Newhart. In 1990, he made Get a Life, featuring Chris Elliott, which lasted two seasons despite facing resistance from Fox executives due to its unconventional humor. Later, he made The Edge with actress Julie Brown.

The Young Ones was a British sitcom that aired in the UK from 1982 to 1984 across two six-part series on BBC2. It brought a unique, rebellious humor to TV in the 1980s and helped popularize alternative comedy. It gained further recognition when it aired on MTV in 1985, marking one of the first non-music shows on the channel. In 2004, it ranked 31st in the BBC's list of Britain's Best Sitcoms. The show's title is inspired by the song "The Young Ones" by Sid Tepper and Roy C. Bennett, sung by Cliff Richard and The Shadows, which was a chart-topping hit in the UK.

question: Are both Dafeng District and Dazhou located in the same province?
pos: Dazhou is a city in the northeast part of Sichuan province, China. It's next to Shaanxi in the north and Chongqing in the east and south. In 2002, its population was 384,525.

Dafeng, a district in Yancheng, Jiangsu province, China, sits on the Jiangsu North Plain and boasts a 112 km coastline. It was once a major salt-making area in China but is now renowned for its pristine ecosystem and several national conservation parks. Notably, it houses the largest national nature reserve for Père David's Deer, also known as Milu in Chinese. Dafeng shares its border with Taizhou to the southwest.
neg: The Sichuan–Shanghai gas pipeline is a really long natural gas pipeline in China, stretching about 1702 km. Yandu District is one of three districts in Yancheng, Jiangsu province, China. The other two districts are Tinghu District and Dafeng District.
Tinghu District is one of Yancheng's three districts in Jiangsu province, China, alongside Yandu District and Dafeng District. Before 2004, it was known as the Urban District of Yancheng.

question: In what century did this Native warrior and chief, whose brother Tenskwatawa led the Tippecanoe order of battle, become the primary leader of a large, multi tribal confederacy?
pos: The U.S. Army and Indiana state militia, commanded by Governor William Henry Harrison, battled against Native American fighters from Tecumseh's group, led by Chief Tecumseh's brother, Tenskwatawa The Prophet, at the Battle of Tippecanoe on November 7, 1811.

Tecumseh was a Shawnee warrior and chief, known for leading a multi-tribal confederacy in the early 19th century. He was born in present-day Ohio, during the American Revolutionary War and the Northwest Indian War, experiencing warfare early on. Tecumseh aimed to create an independent Indian nation east of the Mississippi River, under British protection. He sought to expand his tribal confederacy by recruiting members from the southern United States.
neg: The Kasi, also known as Kansi, are a Pashtun supertribe belonging to the Sarban tribal confederacy. They are mainly found in Pakistan and Afghanistan. Many Kasi people reside in Quetta, Balochistan, Pakistan. Another significant group, called Shinwari, lives in the eastern valleys of Nangarhar Province, Afghanistan, and around Landi Kotal in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas, as well as Kohat District in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan.

Tenskwatawa, also known as the Prophet, was a Shawnee leader alongside his brother Tecumseh. He initially went by Lalawethika, meaning "He Makes a Loud Noise," but later changed his name. Around 1805, he transformed from a troubled youth into a powerful spiritual figure. Tenskwatawa criticized Americans, labeling them as descendants of the Evil Spirit. He led a purification movement advocating unity among Native Americans, resisting assimilation into American culture, and promoting traditional customs.

Tecumseh's Confederacy was a coalition of Native American tribes in the Old Northwest that began forming in the early 19th century under the teachings of Tenskwatawa, also known as The Prophet. Over time, the confederation grew to include several thousand warriors. Tecumseh, a Shawnee leader and the brother of The Prophet, emerged as the group's leader around 1808. Viewed as a threat by the United States, a preemptive strike was launched against the confederation, leading to the 1811 Battle of Tippecanoe. Under Tecumseh's guidance, the confederation engaged in conflicts with the United States during Tecumseh's War and the War of 1812. After Tecumseh's death in 1813, the confederation dissolved.
Ziri ibn Atiyya, also known as Ziri ibn Atiyya, was the initial leader of the Berber Maghrawa tribal group and kingdom. He passed away in 1001.

The Battle of Tippecanoe occurred on November 7, 1811, near Battle Ground, Indiana. It pitted American forces, led by Governor William Henry Harrison, against Native American warriors aligned with Shawnee leader Tecumseh. Tecumseh and his brother, Tenskwatawa (The Prophet), led a coalition of Native American tribes opposing US expansion into their territory. Governor Harrison marched with around 1,000 men to break up the confederacy's base at Prophetstown, located where the Tippecanoe and Wabash Rivers meet, as tensions and conflicts escalated.

Prophetstown State Park in Indiana, USA, honors Tenskwatawa, also known as The Prophet, who was a spiritual leader and the younger brother of Shawnee chief Tecumseh. Situated close to Battle Ground, Indiana, it's just a mile east of where the Battle of Tippecanoe took place. Opened in 2004, it's Indiana's most recent state park. Within the park, you'll find the Museum at Prophetstown, which features reconstructions of a Native American village and a 1920s-era farm.

The Battle of Fallen Timbers marked the end of the Northwest Indian War, a conflict between Native American tribes and the United States over land in the Northwest Territory. This area, located north of the Ohio River and east of the Mississippi River, had been given to the US in the Treaty of Paris (1783), but Native Americans, not part of the treaty, resisted giving up control. With British support, they held onto the land, leading to a US offensive. The US won the battle, leading to the withdrawal of British and Native American forces from the territory after the Treaty of Greenville. This peace didn't last long, as conflicts resumed in Tecumseh's War and the Battle of Tippecanoe in 1811.

Zafar, also known as Dhafar, is an ancient site located in Yemen, about 130 km south-southeast of the current capital, Sana'a. It's an important Himyarite site mentioned in ancient texts and sits in the Yemenite highlands at an elevation of around 2800 meters. Despite some confusion with a namesake site in Oman, Zafar in Yemen is older. It used to be the capital of the Himyarites from 110 BCE to 525 CE, and at its peak, it ruled over much of Arabia. The Himyarites were not a single tribe but a confederacy, and their territory extended from Riyadh to the north and the Euphrates to the northeast for about 250 years, until they were conquered by the Aksumites.

question: What film was written and directed by Joby Harold with music written by Samuel Sim?
pos: "Awake" is a thriller movie from 2007, made by Joby Harold. It features actors like Hayden Christensen, Jessica Alba, Terrence Howard, and Lena Olin. The movie came out in the United States and Canada on November 30, 2007.

Samuel Sim is a composer known for his work in film and TV. He became famous for his amazing score in the BBC series Dunkirk. After that, he has composed music for many other movies and shows, like the film Awake for The Weinstein Company and the BBC/HBO series House of Saddam. One of his latest achievements is the soundtrack for Home Fires, which was released by Sony Classical Records on May 6, 2016.
neg: Here's a famous song from 1954, with music by Harold Grant and lyrics by Dorcas Cochran. Although most sources credit both for both music and lyrics, it's worth noting that Cochran wrote the lyrics while Grant composed the music. The melody was borrowed from an operatic aria called "Caro nome" from Giuseppe Verdi's opera, Rigoletto.

The documentary Beautiful Young Minds premiered at the BRITDOC Festival on July 26, 2007, and aired on BBC 2 on October 14, 2007. It follows the journey of the U.K. team preparing for the 2006 International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) and their competition in Slovenia. Many of the young mathematicians highlighted in the film have autism, which the documentary suggests may be connected to their mathematical talent. The team wins several medals at the IMO, including four silver and one bronze. Directed by Morgan Matthews, edited by Joby Gee, and featuring music by Sam Hooper, the documentary was also shown at the Bath Film Festival in October 2007. It later inspired the 2014 film X+Y, directed by Morgan Matthews and based on IMO participant Daniel Lightwing.

Joby Talbot, born on August 25, 1971, is a British composer known for his diverse range of compositions. His work spans instrumental and vocal concert pieces, film and TV scores, pop arrangements, and dance performances. This means he's recognized by various audiences for his different kinds of music.

The movie "Robin Hood" is a new action-packed adventure directed by Otto Bathurst. It's based on the classic tale of Robin Hood and is written by Joby Harold, Peter Craig, and David James Kelly. The film features actors like Taron Egerton, Jamie Foxx, Eve Hewson, Ben Mendelsohn, Jamie Dornan, Tim Minchin, Björn Bengtsson, and Paul Anderson. You can catch it in IMAX theaters everywhere starting September 21, 2018, distributed by Lionsgate's Summit Entertainment.

"King Arthur: Legend of the Sword," released in 2017, is a fantasy movie directed by Guy Ritchie. It tells a story inspired by the legends of King Arthur. The main character, played by Charlie Hunnam, is accompanied by a cast including Jude Law, Àstrid Bergès-Frisbey, Djimon Hounsou, Aidan Gillen, and Eric Bana.
Blog Wars is a documentary from 2006 that explores how political blogging affected the 2006 Connecticut senate election. The film features music composed by Samuel Sim.

"Gidget Goes to Rome" is a colorful movie from 1963, produced by Columbia Pictures. It stars Cindy Carol as Gidget, a popular character from the 1959 film "Gidget," originally played by Sandra Dee. Directed by Paul Wendkos, it's the third installment in the Gidget series, focusing on Gidget's relationship with her boyfriend Moondoggie. The screenplay, by Ruth Brooks Flippen, builds on the characters created by Frederick Kohner. Familiar faces from previous Gidget films, like James Darren as Moondoggie, make appearances alongside newcomers like Joby Baker. You can find the film on VHS and DVD.
The song "By the Beautiful Sea" was published in 1914, featuring music by Harry Carroll and lyrics by Harold R. Atteridge. It was published by Shapiro, Bernstein & Co.

question: What is the name of the ethnic group who settled in Canada in the 17th century that participated in a conflict with Irish Catholic immigrants in the Shiners' War?
pos: The Shiners' War was a clash between Irish Catholic immigrants and French Canadians in Bytown from 1835 to 1845. It began when Peter Aylen, a prominent Irish timber operator, gathered a group of Irishmen to target rival timber operations. These attackers, called the Shiners, went after French Canadian timber rafts and engaged in street fights with the French Canadians in Bytown.

French Canadians are people whose ancestors came from France and settled in Canada starting in the 17th century. Today, they make up about 22% of Canada's population and are the largest group of French speakers in the country.
neg: The Oku people, also called Oku Mohammedans in Sierra Leone and Aku Marabou or Oku Marabou in the Gambia, are a distinct ethnic group in both countries. They are descendants of freed Africans from Yoruba descent in Nigeria, who settled in Sierra Leone in the mid-19th century. They're mostly Muslims and known for their conservative beliefs. While the British recognized them as a separate community, the Sierra Leone government categorized them as Creoles, though many locals see them as a unique ethnic group.

The Ancient Order of Hibernians (AOH) is a fraternal organization for Irish Catholics. To join, you need to be Catholic and either born in Ireland or have Irish ancestry. It started in New York City in 1836 and is now mostly based in the United States. Originally, it formed to protect Catholic churches from anti-Catholic groups in the 19th century and to support Irish Catholic immigrants, especially those facing discrimination or tough conditions in industries like coal mining. Many members in places like Pennsylvania were connected to the Molly Maguires. Over time, it also became a hub for Irish American political engagement.

The Pinpu tribe, also known as the Pepo or Plains tribes, lived in western Taiwan. They were farmers before many Han Chinese immigrants arrived. Over the centuries, they encountered pressure from outside groups like the Dutch, Spanish, and later Han Chinese, and eventually lost their unique identity. By the late 19th century, most Pingpu tribes had adopted Han Chinese culture and language, becoming invisible in a society dominated by the Han. Japanese scholars studied them during the Japanese rule, leading to the current classification of the Plains tribes.

African Bermudians, or Bermudians with African roots, are people from Bermuda whose ancestors came from Africa. They are descendants of Black Africans who were brought to Bermuda as slaves. Some Black Bermudians were Free Blacks who came to the island as indentured servants in the 17th century. By the 19th century, the Black population became larger than the White population, making them the largest ethnic group in Bermuda. Initially, they were grouped with other non-white ethnicities as Coloured. However, in the 20th century, Black Bermudians became officially recognized as an ethnic group, and they remain the largest ethnic group in Bermuda today.

The Irish are the largest ethnic group in Philadelphia and the surrounding areas. They've been part of the city since before the American Revolution, even joining in pro-Revolutionary activities. As European immigrants flooded in during the 19th century, Philadelphia, once dominated by Quakers, changed. The first big wave of Irish migration happened in 1844 due to the Irish Famine. Despite initial tensions, the city's commitment to religious tolerance allowed Irish Catholics and Protestants, among others, to coexist. With Philadelphia becoming a major industrial hub, many Irish found work in factories. However, they faced discrimination, leading to riots in the 1840s and 1850s. Over time, though, the Irish community gained economic and social standing, establishing their own institutions in the latter half of the 19th century.

Americo-Liberians, also known as the Congo people in Liberian English, are a group in Liberia with roots in African-American, Afro-Caribbean, and liberated African backgrounds. They share ancestry and culture with the Sierra Leone Creole people. Americo-Liberians' ancestors were free-born or once enslaved African Americans who came to Liberia in the 19th century and played a key role in its founding. The terms "Americo-Liberian" and "Congo" were used differently in the past but now refer to the same ethnic group descended from various free and formerly enslaved African Americans, Caribbeans, Recaptives, and Sierra Leone Creoles who settled in Liberia starting in 1822.

Irish people make up the largest group of people with a shared heritage in Boston, Massachusetts. Boston was originally mostly inhabited by Puritans, but in the 19th century, it changed a lot because of European immigrants. The Irish were the main group of newcomers during this time, especially after the Great Irish Famine. Their arrival made Boston less of a city dominated by Anglo-Saxons and Protestants and more diverse. Although the native Bostonians hired Irish people to work for them, there wasn't much social mixing. In the 1840s and 50s, a group called the Know-Nothings, who were against Catholics and immigrants, targeted Irish Catholics in Boston. During the 1860s, many Irish immigrants fought for the Union in the American Civil War, and this helped reduce some of the prejudice against them.

Czechs settled in Ukraine, often called Volhynian Czechs, are Czech ethnic people or their descendants who arrived mainly in the Volhynia region of Ukraine during the latter half of the 19th century. Between 1868 and 1880, around 16,000 Czechs left Austria-Hungary for Tsarist Russia, attracted by the challenging living conditions in the Czech lands and the perceived opportunities in Russia, which had abundant unused agricultural land. The local government in Russia offered various incentives to attract new immigrants, including the right to purchase land at low prices, support for starting businesses, access to education, self-government, and religious freedom. Immigrants were also exempt from taxes for 20 years and military service. Most Czechs settled in regions like Volhynia, Zhytomyr, Lutsk, and other areas, with some villages established in flat meadows and others near existing Ukrainian villages. These settlements often adopted names combining the original village name with "Czech" (e.g., České Noviny, Český Malín, Český Boratín, Český Straklov). Besides agriculture, Czech immigrants also engaged in industries like engineering, breweries, mills, and cement plants. They established schools, churches, and libraries, fostering a vibrant cultural and social life that significantly contributed to the economic and cultural development of their communities.

question: The author of The Thing of It Is... is what Nationality?
pos: "The Thing of It Is..." is a book from 1967 by William Goldman. It's about Amos McCracken, a 31-year-old who wrote a hit song and is facing problems in his marriage.

William Goldman, born on August 12, 1931, is an American writer known for his work as a novelist, playwright, and screenwriter. He gained fame in the 1950s as a novelist and later shifted his focus to writing for movies. He has received two Academy Awards for his screenplays, one for "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" (1969) and another for "All the President's Men" (1976), which is about journalists uncovering the Watergate scandal during Richard Nixon's presidency. Both films featured Robert Redford as a lead actor.
neg: Australian Property Law governs the rights, interests, and responsibilities individuals have regarding property. Property can be tangible, like land, or intangible, like intellectual property. This area of law determines who has priority over a property and what can be classified as property, sparking philosophical debates in legal scholarship.

Joshua D. Zimmerman is a history professor at Yeshiva University, specializing in Holocaust studies. He's written several books, including "The Polish Underground and the Jews, 1939-1945" and "Contested Memories: Poles and Jews during the Holocaust and Its Aftermath." He earned his BA in History from the University of California, Santa Cruz, in 1989, followed by an MA from UCLA in 1993 and a PhD from Brandeis University in Comparative History in 1998. Zimmerman speaks Yiddish, Polish, Hebrew, Russian, and French.

Creationism, a literary movement started by Chilean poet Vicente Huidobro circa 1912, revolves around the concept of a poem being a wholly original creation by the author, existing for its own sake rather than to praise something else, satisfy the reader, or even be fully understood by the author themselves.

The Man Booker International Prize is an international literary award held in the United Kingdom. It was introduced in June 2004 to complement the Man Booker Prize. Sponsored by the Man Group, it was initially given every two years to a living author from any country for their body of work published in English or available in English translation. The prize recognized an author's ongoing creativity, development, and overall impact on global fiction, focusing on their entire body of work rather than individual titles. Each year, the judges created their own lists of authors, and submissions were not requested.

The Viola Concerto by William Walton was composed in 1929 for violist Lionel Tertis, suggested by Sir Thomas Beecham. It's dedicated to Christabel McLaren, Lady Aberconway. However, Tertis initially declined the manuscript, leading composer Paul Hindemith to perform it first. The concerto was well-received, propelling Walton to prominence in British classical music. Eric Blom of The Manchester Guardian praised it highly, calling Walton a natural talent and suggesting the concerto might be one of the best recent compositions regardless of nationality. Tertis later changed his mind and embraced the piece.

"The Most Incredible Thing" is a fairy tale written by Hans Christian Andersen, a Danish poet and author who lived from 1805 to 1875. It tells the story of a competition to find the most amazing thing, and what happens when the winner is announced. The tale was first published in English by Horace Scudder, an American friend of Andersen's, in the United States in September 1870, and later in Danish in Denmark in October 1870. Interestingly, it was also the first of Andersen's tales to be published in Denmark during World War II. Andersen himself considered it one of his finest works.

"A Thing of Beauty" is a book by A. J. Cronin, first released in 1956 under the title "Crusader's Tomb." It follows the journey of Stephen Desmonde, an English painter striving for acknowledgment in a traditional society, giving up everything for his love of art. The title is inspired by John Keats' poem "Endymion," which starts with the line "A thing of beauty is a joy forever."

"Who Goes There?" is a science fiction story collection by author John W. Campbell, Jr., published in 1948 by Shasta Publishers. There were 3,000 copies in the first edition, with 200 signed by Campbell. The 1951 film "The Thing from Another World" and the 1982 version "The Thing" by John Carpenter are based on the title story. These stories first appeared in the magazine Astounding, under Campbell's pseudonym Don A. Stuart.

question: How long is the bridge in the Öresund Region that connect Copenhagen, Denmark and Malmo, Sweden?
pos: The Øresund or Öresund Region is a big area in northern Europe that includes Copenhagen, Denmark, and Malmö, Sweden. It's centered around the Øresund strait. This area is linked by the Øresund Bridge in the south and the HH Ferry route between Elsinore, Denmark (called Helsingør in Danish), and Helsingborg, Sweden, which is the narrowest part of the strait.

The Øresund/Öresund/Oresund Bridge is a bridge that combines both railway and motorway functions, spanning the Øresund strait between Sweden and Denmark. It stretches almost 8 km from the Swedish coast to an artificial island called Peberholm located in the middle of the strait. To complete the crossing, there is also a 4 km long Drogden Tunnel connecting Peberholm to the Danish island of Amager.
neg: The Bjarkøy Fixed Link is a planned connection between three islands—Bjarkøya, Sandsøya, and Grytøya—in Harstad, Norway. It involves building a 3.25 km underwater tunnel to link Grytøya and Bjarkøya and constructing a bridge to connect Grytøya and Sandsøya. The bridge to Grytøya will be 300 m long, with an additional 900 m causeway. The project also includes constructing 3 km of road on Grytøya to join existing roads with the new underwater tunnel. The tunnel will become part of Norwegian County Road 867, while the bridge will be part of Norwegian County Road 124.

Malmö Harbour Heliport (IATA: JMM, ICAO: ESHM) is a heliport in Malmö, Sweden. Before the Öresund Bridge opened in 2000 and Sweden joined the Schengen Area in 2001, there were passport and customs checks at Malmö Harbour Heliport and port. Helicopter and speedboat services provided direct connections to Copenhagen Airport's transfer area.

The Øresund, also known as the Sound, is a strait that acts as the border between Denmark and Sweden. It separates the Danish island of Sjælland from the Swedish region of Skåne. The strait is 118 km long and ranges in width from 4 km to 28 km. At its narrowest point, it's only 4 km wide, located between Helsingør in Denmark and Helsingborg in Sweden.

Sweden, officially known as the Kingdom of Sweden, is a country in Northern Europe, part of Scandinavia. It shares borders with Norway to the west and north, Finland to the east, and connects to Denmark in the southwest through a bridge-tunnel across the Öresund. With an area of 450,295 square kilometers, Sweden is the third-largest country in the European Union. It has a population of 10.0 million, with 2.3 million having a foreign background. Sweden has a relatively low population density of 22 people per square kilometer, with the highest concentration found in the southern half of the country. About 85% of the population resides in urban areas.

The E47 highway stretches from Lübeck, Germany, through Copenhagen, Denmark, to Helsingborg, Sweden, known as Vogelfluglinie and Sydmotorvejen. Except for a 28 km stretch in Germany and a 6 km city street in Helsingør, the road meets motorway standards. There are two ferry connections along the route, with plans for a fixed link by 2020. The Danish parliament opted for a tunnel over a bridge across the Fehmarn Strait for safety and environmental reasons. Another ferry connects Helsingør, Denmark, and Helsingborg, Sweden, despite the presence of a bridge-tunnel combination further south.

The City Tunnel in Malmö, Sweden, is a 17-kilometer railway connecting Malmö Central Station to the Öresund Line, with six kilometers passing under Malmö's city center in a tunnel. It was built to increase the capacity of the Scanian network by allowing trains to pass through Malmö Central Station instead of terminating there. The project was expected to cost 9.45 billion SEK. Construction started in March 2005, and the tunnel was officially opened by King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden on December 4, 2010, with regular train services starting on December 12, 2010.

The Öresund Committee was an organization that aimed to facilitate political collaboration in the Öresund region. This area includes Skåne, the southernmost province of Sweden, as well as the Danish islands of Zealand, Lolland, Falster, and Bornholm. Together, these areas are home to a total of 3.7 million people.

CMP manages the ports in Copenhagen, Denmark, and Malmö, Sweden, situated on either side of the Øresund strait. This area, known as the Øresund Region, is the biggest metropolitan area in the Nordic countries by population. It's linked by the Øresund Bridge in the south and the HH Ferry route between Helsingør, Denmark, and Helsingborg, Sweden.

question: Martin Patterson "Pat" Hingle was a close friend of an actor who achieved success in what Western TV series?
pos: Clinton Eastwood Jr., born on May 31, 1930, is an American actor, filmmaker, musician, and politician. He became famous for his roles in the Western TV series Rawhide and later gained international recognition for playing the Man with No Name in Sergio Leone's Spaghetti Western trilogy during the 1960s. He also portrayed the tough cop Harry Callahan in the Dirty Harry films during the 1970s and 1980s. These roles have solidified Eastwood as a lasting symbol of masculinity in popular culture.

Martin Patterson Hingle, born in 1924 and passed away in 2009, was a prolific American actor known for his roles in numerous TV shows and movies. He kicked off his film career with "On the Waterfront" in 1954, typically portraying strong, authoritative characters. He shared a close friendship with Clint Eastwood and acted alongside him in several films like "Hang 'em High," "The Gauntlet," and "Sudden Impact."
neg: The Longhorn Ballroom in Dallas, Texas, started out as Bob Wills' Ranch House in the 1950s. It was built by O.L. Nelms, a wealthy Dallas resident, for his friend, the famous western swing bandleader Bob Wills. After Wills departed, Nelms leased the venue to Jack Ruby, who gained notoriety for killing Lee Harvey Oswald, the accused assassin of President John F. Kennedy. Eventually, Nelms sold the property to his business partner Dewey Groom.

In 1950, A.C. Trilogchander started as a junior assistant on the sets of the film Manthiri Kumari and became friends with M.G. Ramachandran during the shoot. Producer A.V. Meiyappan recognized his talent and gave him his first directorial break in the 1962 film Veerathirumagan. After the success of his debut, he directed another film for AVM, titled Main Bhi Ladki Hoon in Hindi and Nannum Oru Penn in Tamil, which won awards. He continued directing for AVM, including the popular film Anbe Vaa in 1966. Trilogchander directed various genres, from social dramas like Babu (1971) to romantic comedies like Anbe Vaa. He also directed bilingual films and worked with notable actors like Sivaji Ganesan, Jayalalitha, and Rajesh Khanna. Known for his attention to detail, he coordinated actors' outfits with the film sets' color schemes.

Alison Ann Ward wears many hats – she's a writer, painter, American TV actress, and co-hosted the 2013 Cooking Channel travel-food series, "Tripping Out with Alie & Georgia." She's also a correspondent for the CBS show "Innovation Nation" and has written for L.A. Weekly and the Los Angeles Times. You might recognize her from appearances on shows like "Nash Bridges." Ward gained fame through her online videos and TV gigs with her friend Georgia Hardstark, where they share quirky recipes like the McNuggetini.

The song "Diras que estoy loco" is from Miguel Ángel Muñoz, a Spanish singer and actor. It was the main single from his album "MAM" and came out in Spain in 2004 and later in other countries in June 2006. Originally, he performed the song as the character Roberto Arenales in the TV show "Un Paso Adelante." In 2004, it topped the charts in Spain for eleven weeks straight, selling over 180,000 copies. Two years later, a new version of the music video helped it become a hit in France, Spain, and Italy, reaching the top three in those countries.

Virginia Foster Durr was born in Birmingham, Alabama in 1903. She was a white American who actively supported civil rights and lobbied for change. She married lawyer Clifford Durr at 22 and had five children, one of whom passed away as an infant. Durr had influential friendships with Rosa Parks, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Supreme Court Justice Hugo Black, who presided over significant civil rights cases. She was also connected to Alger Hiss. In 2006, she was honored by being inducted into the Alabama Women's Hall of Fame.

The TV show "Dr. Kildare" aired on NBC from 1961 to 1966, with a total of 191 episodes over five seasons. It was based on characters from stories by Max Brand and starred Richard Chamberlain. The show became popular quickly and influenced many other medical dramas on TV.

Kyle Craig, a character in James Patterson's novels about Washington, D.C. detective Alex Cross, starts off as Cross's friend and helps him with important cases. However, in "Roses Are Red," it's revealed that Craig is actually a criminal mastermind known as The Mastermind, responsible for violent bank robberies and murders. Cross eventually catches him, but Craig remains a major adversary in later books. In the movie adaptations "Kiss the Girls" and "Along Came a Spider," Craig is portrayed by Jay O. Sanders.

Damon Dark is a TV and web series from Australia centered around an investigator who delves into UFO sightings and other odd occurrences. Created by Adrian Sherlock, the series follows Damon James Dark, who became fascinated with aliens after a close encounter in his teens. He's linked to both secret agents and friendly extraterrestrials, like Vincent Kosmos, an alien time traveler, and Trans-Dimensional Control, an alien police force. The show has aired on Community TV 31 in Melbourne, spawned a self-published novel called "Biodome," and has a long-running web series on YouTube. It's also led to spin-offs like "Young Damon Dark" and "Vincent Kosmos." The character of Damon Dark has been portrayed by various actors, including Adrian Sherlock, Bruce Hughes, Aiden Sherlock, and Jack Knoll. Damon Dark, a loner who dresses in black, is known for his extensive knowledge of aliens and their tech, as well as his intelligence, idealistic morals, and dry humor. His loyal friend Gary Sutton, played by Robert Trott, often accompanies him on his adventures. The series began in 1999 on Community TV 31 in Melbourne, following a pilot shot in 1996 and years of development. It later transitioned to a YouTube web series, inspiring spin-offs like "Young Damon Dark Adventures" and "Vincent Kosmos," created by Chris Heaven, an Italian actor and musician, focusing on a rebellious alien friend of Damon's.

question: Is the Marsilea or the Brabejum the genus of more individual species of plants?
pos: Marsilea is a group of about 65 types of water ferns in the Marsileaceae family. It's named after the Italian naturalist Luigi Ferdinando Marsili (1656–1730).

Brabejum is a type of tree found only in South Africa's Western Cape Province. It's known by different names like wild almond or bitter almond. This tree stands out because it's the only one of its kind in Africa's large grevilleoid subfamily. It's not very tall and has many stems growing from the ground. Its leaves are narrow, about 6 inches long, and are grouped in sets of six along the branches. In the summer, it blooms with dense clusters of white flowers, and in the autumn, it produces small almond-like fruits that are too bitter to eat raw. However, in the past, people used to boil, roast, and grind these nuts to make a coffee-like drink.
neg: Sinocyclocheilus is a type of freshwater fish found only in China, specifically in Guangxi, Guizhou, and Yunnan. Most of these fish live in caves or near them and have features common among cavefish, like no scales, no coloration, and small or absent eyes (some are completely blind). Some of them have a distinctive hunched back, and a few even sport a horn on their head, though its purpose isn't clear. However, Sinocyclocheilus species living aboveground or in some caves don't show these cave-related traits. They're typically small, around 23 cm long, and because they have small ranges and populations, many species are considered threatened. Many species still need to be evaluated for their conservation status.

Myiodynastes is a type of bird group in the Tyrannidae family. It was named by Charles Lucien Bonaparte in 1857 and includes five species known as sulphur-bellied flycatchers. The name Myiodynastes comes from two Greek words: "muia," meaning fly, and "dunastẽs," meaning ruler.

Leptospermum plants, also called tea trees, are shrubs and small trees in the myrtle family. They're mainly found in Australia, especially in the southern part, but some also grow in places like New Zealand and Southeast Asia. These plants have five petals and five groups of stamens around a central style, with woody capsules as fruit. The genus was first formally described in 1776, but it took until 1979 to clearly define each species. Tea trees thrive in various habitats, often preferring moist, low-nutrient soils. They're valued in gardening, honey production, and floral arrangements.

Araripesuchus is an extinct type of crocodile that lived during the Cretaceous Period in areas that are now Western Africa and South America. There are at least five different species of Araripesuchus. One species, Araripesuchus wegeneri, is particularly debated among scientists. It was a small crocodile with long limbs, walked upright, and had different types of teeth. Based on its teeth and the way they were worn, it might have eaten both plants and animals. Its slender limbs and the way they were positioned suggest it lived on land. These characteristics set Araripesuchus wegeneri apart from modern crocodiles and alligators.

The Marsileaceae is a small family of ferns that live in or near water. They don't look like typical ferns. People call them the pepperwort or water-clover family because their leaves look a bit like four-leaf clovers. Sometimes, people use these fern leaves instead of clover leaves on Saint Patrick's Day. There are three genera and around 50 to 80 species in this family, with most of them being in the genus Marsilea.

The Be'er Sheva fringe-fingered lizard is a type of lizard found in the Lacertidae family. It belongs to the subgenus Lacertinae and the tribe Acanthodactylus, which are known as spiny footed lizards. This lizard is classified as a separate species due to differences in its appearance and its isolated habitat. Although it shares a lot of its genetic makeup with another lizard called Acanthodactylus pardalis, it has distinct physical characteristics, especially in terms of coloration. Like other lizards in the Acanthodactylus genus, the Be'er Sheva fringe-fingered lizard lays eggs, usually between three to seven at a time. Adult lizards typically measure between 17 to 20 centimeters in length, but they can grow even larger. This lizard is only found in the loess scrublands of the Negev desert in Israel and the Palestinian Territories, which is an area known for its rich biodiversity.

A fen is a type of wetland, like marshes, swamps, and bogs. Fens, along with bogs, are considered a kind of mire. They're mineral-rich peatlands, usually getting their water from mineral-rich surface water or groundwater. Fens have a unique water chemistry, being either pH neutral or alkaline, with high mineral levels but few other plant nutrients. They're mainly filled with grasses, sedges, and brown mosses like Scorpidium or Drepanocladus, along with other plants like carnivorous Pinguicula. Fens can be found near lakes and rivers where water levels change seasonally, keeping the soil wet with few woody plants. The distribution of fen plants often depends on water levels and nutrient concentrations.

Marsilea minuta, also known as dwarf waterclover, is a type of aquatic fern in the Marsileaceae family. It's important not to mix it up with Marsilea minuta, which is another name for Marsilea vestita. Some other names for it include gelid waterklawer, small water clover, airy pepperwort, and pepperwort, but be aware that "pepperwort" can also refer to plants in the genus Lepidium. In French, it's called...

question: What building is opposite the ceremonial meeting place of the Accession Council in the United Kingdom?
pos: Mark Masons' Hall in London is where The Grand Lodge of Mark Master Masons of England and Wales, overseeing the Royal Ark Mariner degree, is based. It's situated at 86 St James's Street, across from St James's Palace in central London. Unlike Freemasons' Hall, which serves as the headquarters for the United Grand Lodge of England and the Supreme Grand Chapter of Royal Arch Masons of England, Mark Masons' Hall is the hub for various other significant branches of Freemasonry in England and Wales.

St. James's Palace, situated in the City of Westminster, is the oldest royal palace in the UK. While it's no longer where the main monarch lives, it's still used for important events like the Accession Council meetings. Plus, it's where some royal family members stay when they're in London.
neg: Warriparinga, which means "Windy Place" in the local Kaurna language, is a nature reserve covering 3.5 hectares in the Bedford Park area of Adelaide, South Australia. It's important for its historical, cultural, and environmental significance. It was a traditional meeting place for the Kaurna people and was also settled by Europeans early on. Sometimes referred to as Fairford, Laffer's Triangle, or the Sturt Triangle, Warriparinga is bordered by Marion Road, Sturt Road, and South Road. The Sturt River flows through it, starting from Sturt Gorge and heading west across the Adelaide Plains.

In Canada's government, the President of The Queen's Privy Council for Canada oversees the Privy Council Office. They also have the symbolic role of leading meetings of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada, which meets only for significant events like when there's a new monarch or when a royal marriage occurs. The last time this role was active was in 1981 for Prince Charles' engagement to Lady Diana Spencer. This position is similar to the Lord President of the Council in the United Kingdom.

The Great Hall of the People, found on the western side of Tiananmen Square in Beijing, is a significant government building in China. It's used for both important meetings and ceremonies by the government and the Communist Party of China. It's where the Chinese parliament, known as the National People's Congress (NPC), gathers each March, alongside the national session of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), which is an advisory group. Additionally, it hosts the National Congress of the Communist Party of China, which happens every five years since 1982.

In the UK, the Accession Council is a group that meets at St James's Palace when a monarch dies to officially announce the next person taking the throne. According to the Act of Settlement 1701, the new monarch takes over automatically. The announcement confirms the name of the new heir.

The Grange Hall in Somerset Township, Jackson County, Illinois, is where the local chapter of The Grange meets. It was built in 1912, replacing the first hall that burned down in 1909. The building, made of red brick in the Commercial style, was constructed by contractor W. A. Pitman. It was used for farmer meetings to discuss agriculture and suggest farm policies to lawmakers. Until 1914, the Somerset Grange Hall was home to the National Farmers Union's newspaper, the Union Farmer. Additionally, it was a hub for social gatherings, township elections, club meetings, and community events. In 1988, the hall underwent rehabilitation and continues to serve as a polling place for the township.

Crowther Masonic Hall, also known as Freemasons' Hall, located in Kollam, is affiliated with the Grand Lodge of India. It has served as a gathering spot for various Masonic Lodges in the Quilon area since 1806. Situated near Kochupilamoodu in Kollam city, it holds historical significance as a landmark of Freemasonry in the ancient Travancore region.

The Pollokshields Burgh Hall is located next to Maxwell Park in Glasgow, Scotland. It was designed by Henry Edward Clifford and built in the 17th-century Scottish Baronial style. Sir John Stirling Maxwell opened it in 1890 for both Masonic meetings and community events. However, it only served Pollokshields independently for a year before the growing city absorbed the area. The hall housed council offices and a courtroom. Today, it still hosts Masonic meetings, evident in the many Masonic symbols found in the carvings and stained-glass windows, especially at the rear of the building.

The Blackman-Bosworth Store, also known as Bosworth Store Building, has a long history in Beverly, Randolph County, West Virginia, USA. Originally built around 1828, it's made of brick on a stone foundation, with an extra section added in 1894. Over the years, it served various purposes including as a general store, a courthouse, a post office, and a meeting spot. In 1973, the Randolph County Historical Society bought it, and now it's the Randolph County Museum and a meeting spot for locals.

question: What material did a hairdresser from Yorkshire, England invent that was named by his granddaughter?
pos: Maurice Ward, an English inventor, gained fame for creating Starlite, a heat-resistant material. Originally a hairdresser from Yorkshire, England, Ward insisted on keeping 51% ownership of the Starlite formula, believing it was worth billions. However, this stance hindered its commercial success.

Starlite is a special material that's said to be really good at handling super hot temperatures and keeping things safe. It was created by Maurice Ward, who was a chemist and also worked as a hairdresser. He came up with it back in the '70s and '80s, but it got famous in 1993 after being featured on a TV show called Tomorrow's World. Ward's granddaughter Kimberly came up with the name "Starlite" for it.
neg: William Levett, around 1200 to about 1270, was in charge of the South Yorkshire village called Hooton Levitt, named after his family. He gained control of Roche Abbey by marrying the granddaughter of Richard FitzTurgis, one of its founders. FitzTurgis was a Norman baron who, along with the great-nephew of Roger de Busli, another influential Norman baron, established Roche Abbey.

The Nidderdale Museum is located in a building that used to be a workhouse in Pateley Bridge, North Yorkshire, England. It showcases various aspects of rural life through exhibits like a cobbler's workshop, a schoolroom, a Victorian parlour, a general store, a 1930s hairdresser's shop, and a kitchen. The museum also features displays of historic costumes, agricultural tools and equipment, local industries, and transportation vehicles.

The West Yorkshire Association Football League is a soccer league in Yorkshire, England. It used to be called the Leeds League until 1939 when it got its current name. Even though it's called the West Yorkshire League, teams from Harrogate and York in North Yorkshire also compete in it.

The University of Leeds, located in Leeds, West Yorkshire, England, has been part of the prestigious Russell Group since its establishment in 1831. Initially known as the Yorkshire College of Science, it later merged with the Leeds School of Medicine and joined the federal Victoria University, alongside institutions that would later become the University of Manchester and the University of Liverpool. In 1904, it received a royal charter from King Edward VII, formalizing its status as the University of Leeds.

Bedale is a market town in North Yorkshire, England. It's about 34 miles north of Leeds, 26 miles southwest of Middlesbrough, and 7 miles southwest of Northallerton. Historically, it was part of the North Riding of Yorkshire and was initially in Richmondshire. It's listed in the Domesday Book as part of Catterick wapentake, also known as Hangshire. Bedale Beck flows into the River Swale, which is part of the Yorkshire Dales. The town relies heavily on agriculture and traditional trades, but tourism is becoming more significant.

The East Riding of Yorkshire is an administrative area in England. It's named after a historical region called the East Riding of Yorkshire, which was part of a larger administrative area along with the North Riding and West Riding until 1974. Between 1974 and 1996, the modern East Riding of Yorkshire was in the northern part of a larger area called Humberside.

Bradley is a village in North Yorkshire, England, located between Skipton and Keighley. It's about half a mile from the A629 and two miles from Skipton. The village is split into two parts: High Bradley and Low Bradley, often called Bradleys Both, though it was previously known as Bradley Ambo. Despite being in North Yorkshire and under its council, it uses a West Yorkshire postal town and dialling code.

Norman Walter Dransfield Yardley (March 19, 1915 – October 3, 1989) was a cricketer from England. He played for Cambridge University, Yorkshire County Cricket Club, and the England national team. He was a right-handed batsman and occasionally bowled. Even though he was an amateur player, he led Yorkshire from 1948 to 1955 and captained England in fourteen matches from 1947 to 1950. During his captaincy, England won four Tests, lost seven, and drew three. Yardley was honored as Wisden Cricketer of the Year in 1948 and was regarded as Yorkshire's finest amateur player since Stanley Jackson in his obituary in Wisden Cricketers' Almanack.

question: One Raffles Place is one of the tallest skyscrapers in the city of Singapore and tallest in the wolrd outside North America until it was succeeded by a Building in city?
pos: The BOC Tower is a well-known skyscraper in Central, Hong Kong, serving as the headquarters for the Bank of China (Hong Kong) Limited. It stands at 1 Garden Road in the Central and Western District on Hong Kong Island.
