One Raffles Place, previously known as the Overseas Union Bank Centre or OUB Centre, stands as one of Singapore's tallest skyscrapers. It used to hold this title alongside UOB Plaza and Republic Plaza until the Tanjong Pagar Centre was built in 2016. When it was finished in 1986, it reached a height of 280 meters, making it the tallest building outside North America at the time, overtaking South Korea's 63 Building, completed a year prior. However, it was later surpassed by the Bank of China Tower. The building is located in the heart of Raffles Place.
neg: São Paulo, Brazil's biggest city, has a stunning skyline with 6,467 buildings. It's ranked 3rd globally in terms of the number of buildings, after New York City and Hong Kong. Within the city and its surrounding area, there are 193 buildings over 100 meters tall, mainly clustered in downtown and the Brooklin neighborhood. The Martinelli Building, once the tallest in Latin America at 130 meters, opened in 1929. The Mirante do Vale, São Paulo's tallest building at 170 meters, was completed in 1960. Nowadays, the city mainly has low-rise buildings, mostly residential, with strict laws limiting skyscraper construction. Skyscrapers are scattered across three main areas, as the financial center has shifted. São Paulo ranks 10th globally for buildings over 90 meters tall, after cities like Hong Kong, New York City, and Tokyo.

One Raffles Link is an office building in Marina Centre, Singapore. It has six floors and a basement and is managed by Hongkong Land. It was designed by famous architects Kohn Pedersen Fox and Aedas LPT Architects and was completed in 2000 at a cost of S$340 million. It's a top-notch office building, with major tenants like VISA, Credit Suisse, Goldman Sachs, and Citibank. It's built on a narrow strip of land and offers the largest open floor spaces in the city. Additionally, it's connected to CityLink Mall, Singapore's first underground mall, which links it to City Hall MRT Station, Raffles City, Marina Square, Suntec City, and the Esplanade.

CapitaGreen, also called Market Street Tower, is a tall office building situated in Raffles Place, Singapore. It was designed by Toyo Ito and finished in 2014. Standing at 242 meters tall, it ranks among the tallest skyscrapers in Singapore.

Chevron House, previously known as Caltex House, is a tall building situated in Singapore's central business district. You can find it at 30 Raffles Place, right in the financial hub of Raffles Place. It's surrounded by other buildings and notable spots like Singapore Land Tower, Hitachi Tower, Change Alley, and The Arcade, all within a stone's throw, less than 100 meters away. Plus, it's conveniently connected underground to the Raffles Place MRT Station. Interestingly, Hitachi Tower is its close neighbor and even shares a four-level retail area with Chevron House.

Raffles Place MRT Station (NS26/EW14) is a subway station in Downtown Core, Singapore, where two major subway lines, the North South Line and the East West Line, intersect. It's right under the financial hub of Raffles Place, south of the Singapore River. As a crucial interchange station in the heart of the city, it sees heavy traffic. The station has many entrances, with the main ones facing Raffles Gardens. The station building resembles the historic John Little building.

Republic Plaza is one of the tallest skyscrapers in Singapore, standing at the Southern end of Raffles Place in the Downtown Core, the city's central business district. It's as tall as the OUB Centre and UOB Plaza One. Completed in 1995, it reaches 280 meters (919 feet) high and even has earthquake-proof features, although Singapore isn't prone to earthquakes.

One Marina Boulevard, also known as NTUC Centre, is a tall building standing at 32 stories high and reaching 110 meters in height. It's located at 1 Marina Boulevard, in the bustling area of Raffles Place and Marina Bay, right in Singapore's central business district. The building sits close to other tall buildings like One Raffles Quay, The Sail @ Marina Bay, and Ocean Building, all within about 100 meters. Additionally, it's conveniently connected to Raffles Place MRT Station through an underground mall with air conditioning.

Raffles Place sits at the heart of Singapore's Financial District, positioned to the south of where the Singapore River meets the sea. Originally called Commercial Square in the 1820s, it was meant to be the main spot for business in Singapore according to Raffles Town Plan. Renamed Raffles Place in 1858, it's now home to many big banks. Found in the Downtown Core of the Central Area, it boasts some of Singapore's tallest buildings and notable landmarks.

question: Which case came first, Craig v. Boren or United States v. Paramount Pictures, Inc.?
pos: In 1948, the United States Supreme Court made a big decision in the case known as United States v. Paramount Pictures, Inc. It dealt with whether movie studios could own theaters and control where their films were shown. The Court ruled that the way movies were being distributed broke antitrust laws, which forbid certain types of exclusive agreements. This changed how movies were made, sent out, and shown in Hollywood.

Craig v. Boren, a landmark case in 1976, marked the first time the majority of the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that laws or rules classifying people by sex had to be carefully reviewed under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
neg: Block booking was a method used by Hollywood's major studios from the 1930s until it was banned by the U.S. Supreme Court in 1948. It involved selling multiple films to theaters as a package deal. Independent theater owners were required to buy a bunch of movies without knowing what they were getting. This allowed studios to sell both their top-quality films and less popular ones together, making their business more efficient. The part of this system where theaters bought movies without seeing them is called blind bidding.

In the case of Baker v. Nelson, the Minnesota Supreme Court decided that a law allowing only opposite-sex couples to marry didn't break the U.S. Constitution. Baker appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court, but they declined to hear it, which meant their decision stood as precedent. Later, in 2013, Minnesota legalized same-sex marriage, and in 2015, the U.S. Supreme Court made it legal nationwide in Obergefell v. Hodges, overturning the Baker decision.

In the case of R v Van der Peet, [1996] 2 S.C.R. 507, the Supreme Court examined Aboriginal rights outlined in section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982. They concluded that while Aboriginal people have fishing rights, these rights do not include selling fish commercially. This case introduced the Van der Peet test, a method for determining the existence of Aboriginal rights. It's the first of three cases, collectively known as the Van der Peet trilogy, which also includes R v NTC Smokehouse Ltd and R v Gladstone.

In the case of United States v. Binion from 2005, the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals used two new decisions from the U.S. Supreme Court (United States v. Booker and United States v. Fanfan) to check a sentencing decision made by the trial court. This decision had been approved by the Federal District Court for the Eastern District, and the Appeals Court agreed with it.

In 1999, there was a significant case in Hong Kong called Lau Kong Yung v. Director of Immigration. This case followed closely after another important decision, Ng Ka Ling v. Director of Immigration. Before Lau's case reached the Court of Final Appeal (CFA), the National People's Congress Standing Committee (NPCSC) of China issued an interpretation of the Basic Law, which impacted Lau and others' rights. This made Lau's case the first to consider an NPCSC interpretation while applying the Basic Law in the CFA.

In 2006, the Ohio Supreme Court heard the case of Norwood, Ohio v. Horney 110 Ohio St.3d 353. This case followed the Kelo v. City of New London decision by the US Supreme Court, which allowed eminent domain for commercial development. However, Norwood's case focused on the limitations set by the Ohio State Constitution, rather than the broader scope of the US Constitution like in Kelo.

During Morrison Waite's time as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court from 1874 to 1888, the Court handled a remarkably high number of criminal cases. In just fourteen years, they tackled 106 criminal cases, nearly matching the total number of cases heard by the Court from its establishment up to Waite's appointment as Chief Justice. Some notable cases during this period include United States v. Cruikshank (1875), United States v. Reese (1875), Reynolds v. United States (1878), Wilkerson v. Utah (1879), the Trade-Mark Cases (1879), Strauder v. West Virginia (1880), Pace v. Alabama (1883), United States v. Harris (1883), Ex parte Crow Dog (1883), Hurtado v. California (1884), Clawson v. United States (1885), Yick Wo v. Hopkins (1886), United States v. Kagama (1886), Ker v. Illinois (1886), and Mugler v. Kansas (1887).

During its tenure from 1801 to 1835, the Marshall Court dealt with forty-one criminal law cases, averaging slightly more than one case per year. Some notable cases include United States v. Simms (1803), United States v. More (1805), Ex parte Bollman (1807), United States v. Hudson (1812), Cohens v. Virginia (1821), United States v. Perez (1824), Worcester v. Georgia (1832), and United States v. Wilson (1833).

question: What is the nickname of the city where Darling's Waterfront Pavilion is located?
pos: The Darling's Waterfront Pavilion, initially called the Bangor Waterfront Pavilion, is an outdoor amphitheater situated in Waterfront Park, Bangor, Maine. It's a seasonal venue set up next to the Penobscot River, usually open from July to October.

Bangor, located along the Penobscot River in Maine, has a population of 33,039 in the city itself, with a larger metropolitan area population of 153,746. It's often referred to as the Queen City of Maine.
neg: Silver Line Way is a bus station for the MBTA Silver Line, situated on Silver Line Way near Pumphouse Road, between Massport Haul Road (also known as Trilling Street) and D Street, close to the South Boston Waterfront area. It's just one block away from the Boston Fish Pier and provides access to destinations like the Boston Renaissance Waterfront Hotel and the Blue Hills Bank Pavilion.

The Kertha Gosa pavilion is a Balinese architectural gem situated in Bali, Indonesia, specifically in Klungkung city. Built in the early 18th century by Dewa Agung Gusti Sideman, it initially served as a court of law starting in 1945. Over the years, it underwent repainting in the 1920s and again in the 1960s. The discovery of the pavilion revealed its rich history, known mainly through writings shared outside Bali. Adorning the pavilion's ceiling is the depiction of the Bhima Swarga story from the Hindu epic Mahabharata, offering visitors a glimpse into this specific narrative within the larger epic.

The Oleson Park Music Pavilion, also called the Karl King Bandshell, stands in Fort Dodge, Iowa, USA. It's linked to Karl King, a renowned composer for concert and military bands, who pushed for its construction. Designed by Henry L. Kamphoefner, an architect from Sioux City, it resembles the Grandview Park Music Pavilion he previously designed. It was a project funded mostly by the Works Progress Administration (WPA), with 85% of the cost covered by them and the rest by Fort Dodge city. This concrete structure, built in a Modernist style with Art Deco influences, reaches 36 ft in height and is recognized for its great acoustics. It replaced a bandstand in the city square from the 1920s. In 1976, it was dedicated to King and in 2003, it was listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

The Concord Pavilion, once called Sleep Train Pavilion and Chronicle Pavilion, is an outdoor venue in Concord, California. It belongs to the city and is managed by Live Nation. Built in 1975, it can hold up to 12,500 people. People gather there for concerts, community gatherings like jazz festivals, and even high school graduations.

Paulus Hook is a neighborhood in Jersey City, New Jersey, situated by the Hudson River, just a mile away from Manhattan. The name "Hook" comes from the Dutch word "hoeck," meaning a point of land. This area, bounded by Montgomery, Hudson, Dudley, and Van Vorst Streets, is elevated. Its main street is Washington Street, running north and south. Along the Morris Canal basin in a park connected to Liberty State Park, you'll find the waterfront of Paulus Hook. The Hudson-Bergen Light Rail stops at Essex Street, and there's also the Liberty Water Taxi stop at Warren Street. With the introduction of the light rail and the development of office buildings along the Hudson Waterfront, more businesses, including restaurants with outdoor seating and small shops, have opened up on Morris Street.

A sala, also known as a sala Thai, is like an open pavilion used for meetings and to shield people from the weather. They're often open on all sides and are common in Thailand, usually found in Buddhist temple areas called wats. Building one earns religious merit, especially if it's at a temple, where it's called a salawat. Some temples have big salas where people can listen to sermons or get religious teachings. In government settings, they're called sala wa kan or sala klang changwat.

Corus Quay, formerly known as First Waterfront Place, is an eight-story office building situated on a 2.5-acre piece of land along the waterfront in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. It cost $160 million to construct and is the first major development in the East Bayfront area. Located at the bottom of Jarvis Street, it serves as the new headquarters for Corus Entertainment, bringing together its 1,200 employees from 10 different locations. The project was overseen by the Toronto Economic Development Corporation (TEDCO), with funding coming from TEDCO's own funds, city loans, and a $12.5 million contribution from Waterfront Toronto.

The Grandview Park Music Pavilion is an old building found in Sioux City, Iowa, USA. Back in 1930, the Monahan Post Band collected money to construct a small music stage in the park. However, construction faced a setback when neighbors didn't like the original design. The band paused the project, gathered more funds, and looked for a better design. When President Franklin D. Roosevelt established the Civil Works Administration (CWA) in 1933, the city applied to include the new music stage in its projects. An architect named Henry L. Kamphoefner, who was not well-known at the time, created the plans. Sculptural plaques on the pavilion's front were designed by Herschel Elarth. The CWA approved the project in February 1934, and construction used 52 tons of steel, 4,200 bags of Portland cement, and 300 bags of white cement, finishing on October 17, 1934. The pavilion, seating 5,000 in its natural amphitheater, was built with $47,436 from Federal Relief funds and $3,800 in city materials. It was dedicated in spring 1935. The Monahan Post Band played there until 1948 when they became the Sioux City Municipal Band, carrying on the tradition in the summer. In 2011, the music pavilion was added to the National Register of Historic Places.

question: The Kansas City Wizards have had three home venues in Kansas City in their time.  Which was their first?
pos: Children's Mercy Park, previously called Sporting Park and Livestrong Sporting Park, is a stadium in Kansas City, Kansas, USA. It's where Sporting Kansas City plays soccer. It opened in 2011 during the Major League Soccer season, with a game against the Chicago Fire. The stadium can hold 18,467 people for regular events, but it can fit up to 25,000 for concerts. Sporting Kansas City games usually bring in around 21,000 fans. Before this stadium, Sporting Kansas City played at Arrowhead Stadium from 1996 to 2007 and at CommunityAmerica Ballpark from 2008 to 2010. In 2013, the stadium hosted the MLS All-Star Game, the United States men's national soccer team, and the MLS Cup, making it the only stadium to host all three events in the same year.

CommunityAmerica Ballpark is a baseball stadium situated in Kansas City, Kansas, specifically in the Piper neighborhood. It's where the Kansas City T-Bones, an independent American Association team, play their home games. Previously, it was also home to the Kansas City Wizards, now known as Sporting Kansas City, from Major League Soccer. Found in the Village West area at 1800 Village West Parkway, the ballpark hosts various events, including the Butch Foster Memorial Baseball Classic for local high school teams like Bonner Springs High School and serves as the home venue for the Kansas City Kansas Community College Blue Devils. Additionally, it's occasionally used for concerts and other community gatherings.
neg: Shawnee Mission District Stadium is a sports stadium in Overland Park, Kansas, that's used by several local high schools like Shawnee Mission North, Shawnee Mission Northwest, and Shawnee Mission East. It's also home to FC Kansas City from the National Women's Soccer League. In the past, Sporting Kansas City, known as the Kansas City Wizards at the time, had a match against the Colorado Rapids here during the 2008 Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup.

In 1997, the Kansas City Wizards played their second season in MLS at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Missouri. MLS didn't allow matches to end in ties, so shootouts were used to break draws. The statistics provided don't include shootout goals, and although the team's actual point total in the regular season was 49, it appears as 63 below because shootout wins were counted as 2 points and shootout losses as 0 points.

In 1999, the Kansas City Wizards played their season at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Missouri. During that time, Major League Soccer (MLS) didn't permit matches to end in ties, so shootouts were used to break draws. The statistics provided exclude shootout goals scored. The team's actual point total for the regular season was 20, even though it's listed as 24 below. In the scoring system, a shootout win earned 2 points, while a shootout loss earned 0 points. Additionally, Ron Newman, the team's first manager, was replaced by Bob Gansler.

In the 2004 MLS Cup, D.C. United faced off against the Kansas City Wizards to determine the season's champion. The game happened at The Home Depot Center in Carson, California, on November 14, 2004. D.C. United won 3-2, with one of the goals scored by Wizards defender, Alex Zotinca, accidentally in their own net. This victory marked D.C. United's fourth MLS Cup win and their first since MLS Cup '99.

This list includes every player who has played in a league match for Sporting Kansas City (previously called Kansas City Wiz and Kansas City Wizards) since the team joined Major League Soccer in 1996. Players who were on the roster but never played in a first-team game are not listed. Additionally, players who participated in other competitions like the US Open Cup or CONCACAF Champions League but didn't make an MLS appearance are mentioned separately at the bottom of the page.
The 2008 season for the Kansas City Wizards was the first time they played at the temporary location, Community America Ballpark, in Kansas City, Kansas.

Curt Johnson is currently the President of North Carolina FC in the NASL (North American Soccer League) and the North Carolina Courage in the NWSL. He has previously worked as the General Manager for the Richmond Kickers in the A-League/Division 2 and the Kansas City Wizards in Major League Soccer (now called Sporting Kansas City).

In 1998, the Kansas City Wizards had their third season in Major League Soccer (MLS), playing at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Missouri. During that season, MLS didn't permit ties, so shootouts were used to break them. The statistics provided don't count goals scored in shootouts. Despite showing 36 points below, the team's actual total in the regular season was 32. In MLS, a shootout win earned 1 point, while a shootout loss earned 0 points.

question: Henry Hall is known for fighting in the Revolutionary War, and for being the first to successfully cultivate this food found in what type of bogs?
pos: Cranberries are small evergreen plants that grow as low shrubs or vines. In Britain, "cranberry" usually means Vaccinium oxycoccos, while in North America, it usually refers to Vaccinium macrocarpon. Vaccinium oxycoccos is grown in central and northern Europe, and Vaccinium macrocarpon is grown in the northern United States, Canada, and Chile. Some classifications consider Oxycoccus to be its own genus. Cranberries typically thrive in acidic bogs in cooler parts of the northern hemisphere.
Captain Henry Hall, an American hailing from Dennis, Massachusetts, fought in the American Revolutionary War and went on to become the first person to successfully grow cranberries.
neg: Vice-Admiral Robert Plampin (1762 – 14 February 1834) was a British naval officer in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. He served in various wars, including the American Revolutionary War, the French Revolutionary Wars, and the Napoleonic Wars. He's most famous for leading the British colony of Saint Helena, where Napoleon Bonaparte was imprisoned. Plampin came from a Navy family and started his naval career at 13, fighting mainly in the Caribbean during the American Revolutionary War. During the French Revolutionary Wars, he served on different ships with mixed success, even experiencing a shipwreck and participating in sieges on land. After a period of peace, he commanded the ship HMS Powerful, operating successfully in the Atlantic and Indian Ocean. In 1816, after Napoleon's defeat, he was put in charge of the squadron at the Cape of Good Hope, responsible for Saint Helena, where he often visited and conversed with Napoleon.

Historic Camden Revolutionary War Site is a national historic area and outdoor museum in Camden, Kershaw County, South Carolina. It's roughly 40 minutes from Columbia, the state capital, and is one of the biggest tourist attractions in the state. Covering 107 acres, it's also referred to as Historic Camden Revolutionary War Restoration and British Revolutionary War Fortifications. Camden features preserved buildings and grounds that reflect the Southern aspect of the American Revolutionary War. The site is overseen by a group of private donors and local governments and is associated with the National Park Service.

Blanket bog, also called featherbed bog, forms in areas with lots of rain and little evaporation, allowing peat to build up not just in wet hollows but across large, uneven ground. The thick layer of peat covering the ground is why it's called "blanket" bog. These bogs are common in the northern hemisphere, with well-known ones in Ireland and Britain, as well as in large parts of the Russian and North American tundra.

Carnival Cravings, also called Carnival Cravings with Anthony Anderson, is a TV show on the Food Network. It's all about the special food you can find at American carnivals. The host, Anthony Anderson, tries out these unique dishes that you can only get at carnivals, fairs, and festivals across the USA. The show first aired on August 12, 2015, and you can catch it on Wednesdays at 10:00 p.m. EDT.

Karachi cuisine is the food you'll find in Karachi, Pakistan. It's heavily influenced by the Urdu-speaking Muslims, also called Muhajirs, who migrated from northern India after Pakistan gained independence in 1947. Since many Muhajirs settled in Karachi, the city's cuisine reflects their tastes, with a mix of traditional dishes and beverages from their cultural heritage.

John Adlum (April 29, 1759 – March 14, 1836) was an important figure in American grape growing. He introduced the Catawba grape to cultivation and is often called the father of American viticulture. Adlum had a diverse career; he fought in the American Revolutionary War, worked as a respected surveyor, served as one of the initial associate judges in Lycoming County, Pennsylvania, and also contributed to the United States Army during the War of 1812.

This list shows fossils called consumulites, which are fossils containing preserved food remains eaten by the animal while alive. Consumulites fall under the broader category of bromalites, which includes fossilized materials consumed by animals, such as waste like feces (coprolites) and vomit (regurgitalites). Consumulites are categorized into food found in the animal's mouth at death (oralites), in its throat (esophagolites), partially digested stomach contents (gastrolites, different from gastroliths), and food in the intestinal tract (cololites).

Boortsog, also known as bauyrsaq, baursak, or boorsoq in different regions, is a popular fried dough dish enjoyed in Central Asia, Idel-Ural, Mongolia, and the Middle East. It's typically shaped into triangles or spheres and made from a mixture of flour, yeast, milk, eggs, margarine, salt, sugar, and fat. In Tajikistan, boortsog is often embellished with a criss-cross pattern before frying, achieved by pressing the bottom of a small strainer onto the dough.

question: A scam involving a male calling small town fast-food restaurants and pretending to be a police officer to have them strip search employees was turned into a movie of what name?
pos: Compliance is a thriller movie released in 2012, directed and written by Craig Zobel. It stars Ann Dowd, Dreama Walker, and Pat Healy. The story revolves around a prank caller pretending to be a police officer, who manipulates the manager of a fast food restaurant into conducting invasive and illegal actions on an employee. The movie is inspired by a real-life incident known as the strip search prank call scam, which occurred at a McDonald's in Mount Washington, Kentucky, located in Bullit County. Ann Dowd's portrayal of Sandra, the manager, earned her the National Board of Review Award for Best Supporting Actress.

The strip search phone call scam lasted for about ten years until an arrest in 2004. During this time, a man would make prank calls to restaurants or grocery stores, pretending to be a police officer. He would convince managers to conduct strip searches on female employees and perform other strange tasks in the name of police authority. These calls usually targeted fast-food joints in small, rural towns across the United States.
neg: Devyani Khobragade, an Indian Foreign Service officer, gained worldwide attention while working as Indian Deputy Consul General in New York. She was arrested by US law enforcement for lying on a visa application for her maid and paying her below the legal wage. The arrest happened after she dropped off her daughters at school. She was searched and brought before a judge, sparking a diplomatic crisis between India and the US. In 2016, she ventured into fiction with her book, "The White Sari."

A&W Restaurants is a fast-food chain known for its draft root beer and root beer floats. It all started when Roy W. Allen opened a small root beer stand in Lodi, California, in 1919. Later, his employee Frank Wright joined forces with him and they opened the first A&W restaurant in Sacramento, California, in 1923. The name "A&W" comes from their last names, Allen and Wright. The company gained fame in the United States for serving root beer in frosty mugs kept in freezers before being served to customers.

Ringer Hut is a Japanese fast-food chain that specializes in Nagasaki dishes like Champon and Sara udon. It was founded in 1974 by Hamakatsu Co. in Nagasaki. The company got its name from a former tourist attraction called Ringer House, which Nagasaki City had purchased in 1966. The word "hut" in its name might have been inspired by Pizza Hut. Ringer Hut has more than 550 restaurants across Japan, Taiwan, and San Jose, California, and also owns 100 Hamakatsu Restaurants, which are known for their tonkatsu dishes. The company has two headquarters, located in Fukuoka and Tokyo.

Police perjury, also known as "testilying" among police in the United States, refers to when a police officer lies while giving testimony. This often happens during criminal trials to strengthen the case against a defendant whom the police believe is guilty, especially if issues during the suspect's arrest or search could lead to the defendant being acquitted. However, police perjury can involve more than just false testimony—it can also include providing inaccurate information to secure convictions against those believed to be guilty, or even fabricating evidence to incriminate innocent individuals. In simpler terms, it's when a police officer lies under oath, typically to help secure a conviction.

Jacob D. Robida, a teenager from Massachusetts, caused harm at a gay bar in New Bedford on February 2, 2006. He then left the state, taking Jennifer Rena Dunlap Bailey with him, and headed towards Charleston, West Virginia. While in Arkansas, he got stopped by Police Officer James W. Sell for a traffic issue and shot him dead before fleeing again. During the chase, he fired at Sgt. Van Nowlin but got stopped by deputies using a spike strip, which caused his car to crash in Norfork, Arkansas. There, he fatally shot Bailey and then himself after being fired upon by the police.

In Japan, there's a trend called "part-time job terrorism," where part-time workers do pranks like squeezing into ice cream freezers or lying flat on fast-food counters (known as 'planking') to get attention on social media. This often happens among people who are unhappy with their jobs, which the media often links to low pay and long hours. While these pranks might not be a big deal elsewhere, they're seen as disrespectful in Japanese culture.

Coronado, a coastal city and resort, sits just an hour away from Panama City. It's a popular vacation spot drawing in thousands of tourists every year, both from within the country and beyond. Being Panama's initial resort project, Coronado has a head start over neighboring beach towns. It boasts amenities like supermarkets, pharmacies, a variety of restaurants from budget-friendly to beachfront bistros, medical services, banking facilities, shops, outdoor markets, and even a shopping plaza and mall.

A body cavity search, sometimes just called a cavity search, is when authorities visually or physically inspect certain body openings like the nostrils, ears, mouth, belly button, genitals, or rectum to find hidden illegal items like drugs, money, jewelry, or weapons. It's much more intrusive than a regular strip search done when someone is arrested or detained, like in a jail, prison, or psychiatric facility. Sometimes they do it again when the person leaves.

question: What airport serviced by American Airlines Shuttle, is also the largest airport in the New England region and 17th busiest in the U.S?
pos: Logan International Airport, also known as General Edward Lawrence Logan International Airport, is situated in the East Boston neighborhood of Boston, Massachusetts, United States. It spans 2384 acres, has six runways, four passenger terminals, and employs around 16,000 people. As the largest airport in New England and the 17th busiest in the United States, it served 33.5 million passengers in 2015. Named after General Edward Lawrence Logan, it saw a significant increase in passenger traffic, reaching approximately 36.3 million passengers in 2016, according to Massport.

American Airlines Shuttle is a service that flies every hour between Logan International Airport in Boston, LaGuardia Airport in New York City, and Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport in Washington, D.C.
neg: Kazan International Airport, situated about 25 km southeast of Kazan in Tatarstan, Russia, is the largest airport in the region and ranks as the 15th busiest airport in Russia. It served nearly 3.8 million people from the area.

Pitt Meadows Airport (ICAO: CYPK) is a small airport for private planes in Pitt Meadows, British Columbia, Canada. It sits in the southwest part of the town. In 2016, it ranked as the 17th busiest airport in Canada, with 109,188 flights. It's also the 4th busiest airport in the Lower Mainland area.

Charlotte Douglas International Airport, identified by its IATA code CLT, is a significant airport in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA, serving both civilian and military purposes. Originally named Charlotte Municipal Airport in 1935, it was later renamed Douglas Municipal Airport in honor of former mayor Ben Elbert Douglas, Sr., before adopting its current name in 1982. By September 2017, it became American Airlines' second-largest hub, offering flights to 161 destinations domestically and internationally. In 2016, it ranked as the fifth busiest airport in the USA in terms of passenger traffic and aircraft movements and was the seventh busiest globally in terms of aircraft movements alone. Notably, it lacks direct flights to Asia but serves as a vital connection hub for the Caribbean Islands. Spanning over 5,558 acres of land, CLT is one of the largest airports in the country.

Coimbatore International Airport (IATA: CJB, ICAO: VOCB) is the main airport for Coimbatore city in Tamil Nadu, India. It's located in Peelamedu, about 13 km from the city center. Formerly called Peelamedu Civil Aerodrome, it ranks 19th busiest in India for passengers, 16th for total aircraft movement, and 14th for cargo. It's the second largest airport in Tamil Nadu after Chennai International Airport. The airport is served by five domestic and three international airlines and is becoming a significant hub for cargo transport.

Townsville Airport, also referred to as Townsville International Airport or Garbutt Airport due to its location in the Townsville suburb of Garbutt, is a significant regional airport in Australia serving the city of Townsville. It is served by major domestic and regional airlines, and in the fiscal year 2011/12, it accommodated 1.7 million passengers, ranking as the 11th busiest airport in Australia.

Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport (IATA: DLC, ICAO: ZYTL) serves Dalian city in Liaoning Province, China. It's in Ganjingzi District, about 10 km northwest of the city center. In 2014, it handled 17,203,640 passengers, making it Northeast China's busiest airport and the 16th busiest nationwide. It's the main hub for Dalian Airlines and a focus city for China Southern Airlines and Hainan Airlines. Because Zhoushuizi Airport is too crowded, a new airport called Dalian Jinzhouwan International Airport is being built on reclaimed land to replace it.

Denver International Airport (DEN) is located in Denver, Colorado, United States. It's the largest airport in the country in terms of land area, covering about 33,531 acres or 52.4 square miles. One of its runways, 16R/34L, is the longest public use runway in the United States, stretching over 16,000 feet. In 2016, DEN ranked as the 18th busiest airport globally and the sixth busiest in the U.S. in terms of passenger traffic, serving over 58 million passengers. It also boasts the third largest domestic connection network in the U.S. As of 2017, the airport has 135 gates across three separate but connected concourses labeled A, B, and C.

Eastern Air Lines Shuttle, also known as Eastern Air Shuttle, was a flight service operated by Eastern Air Lines. It started on April 30, 1961, and was later bought by Donald Trump in 1989, after which it became known as the Trump Shuttle. In April 1992, it was renamed the USAir Shuttle, which is now known as the American Airlines Shuttle. The shuttle initially flew between New York City, Boston, Washington, D.C., and Newark. Its slogan was "Imagine life without us."

question: What arcade game is named after the only player in major league history to have a 0.300 batting average for 7 consecutive seasons?
pos: Frank Thomas' Big Hurt is a pinball machine created by Bill Parker and launched by Gottlieb in 1995. It's all about baseball and takes its name from the famous player Frank Thomas.

Frank Thomas Jr., also known as The Big Hurt, played as a first baseman in Major League Baseball from 1990 to 2008. He mainly played for the Chicago White Sox, except for his last three years. Thomas was known for his exceptional hitting skills, being the only player in MLB history to achieve seven consecutive seasons with a .300 batting average, 100 runs batted in (RBI), 100 runs scored, 100 walks, and 20 home runs from 1991 to 1997. He had impressive stats during this time, batting .330 with an average of 36 home runs and 118 RBI per year. Thomas won the AL's Most Valuable Player award in 1993 and 1994, leading the White Sox to division titles. Despite facing some challenges in the following years, he continued to perform well and earned recognition, including the AL Comeback Player of the Year award in 2000.
neg: John Paul Jack Fox was a professional baseball player who played for 11 seasons, including one in Major League Baseball with the Philadelphia Athletics in 1908. In his MLB career, he had a batting average of .200, scoring two runs, six hits, and two stolen bases in nine games. Additionally, he played in various minor league teams such as the Poughkeepsie Colts, Albany Senators, Jersey City Skeeters, Memphis Egyptians, Wilkes-Barre Barons, Troy Trojans, Lincoln Railsplitters, Harrisburg Senators, Bradford Drillers, and Scranton Miners. He started as an outfielder but later became a pitcher, achieving a career minor league batting average of .251 with 670 hits in 694 games, and a pitching record of 90 wins and 63 losses in 185 games. He was right-handed in both batting and throwing.

Ronald Samuel Herbel (1938–2000) was a Major League Baseball pitcher known for his poor batting skills. He holds the record for the lowest batting average in Major League history among players with at least 100 at-bats, with a career average of .029.

Howard Richard "Dick" Kauffman (June 22, 1888 – April 16, 1948) was a baseball player. He played for 11 seasons, two of which were in Major League Baseball (MLB) with the St. Louis Browns (1914–15). Kauffman mainly played as a first baseman. In his MLB career, he had a batting average of .259 with 10 runs, 36 hits, nine doubles, two triples, and 16 RBIs in 44 games. He started his professional career in 1911 with the York White Roses in the minor leagues, then joined MLB in 1914 and 1915 before returning to the minors. Throughout his minor league career, he played for various teams including the York White Roses (1911–12), Elmira Colonels (1913–14), Atlanta Crackers (1915, 1920–21), and Nashville Volunteers (1916–19). Before going pro, Kauffman attended Bucknell University and Susquehanna University. He was born in East Lewisburg, Pennsylvania.

Francis Patrick Frank Crossin, Sr. was a baseball player who played professionally for seven seasons. He spent three seasons with the St. Louis Browns in Major League Baseball from 1912 to 1914 as a catcher. In his MLB career, he had a batting average of .147 with eight runs, 17 hits, one double, one triple, and seven RBIs in 55 games. He started with the Binghamton Bingoes in the minor leagues in 1912 before his MLB debut on September 24, 1912. After two seasons in the majors, he went back to the minors in 1915, where he had a batting average of .261 with 303 hits in 381 games. He was right-handed, standing at 5 feet tall and weighing 160 pounds.

Germán Barranca Costales, born on October 19, 1956, in Veracruz de Ignacio de la Llave, Mexico, used to play as a second baseman in Major League Baseball. He started his career with the Kansas City Royals after being acquired from the Mexico City Reds on August 26, 1974. Standing at 6 feet tall and weighing 160 pounds, Germán debuted in the major leagues on September 2, 1979, at 22 years old, playing against the New York Yankees. He played a total of 5 games that year and 7 games in 1980, achieving a batting average of .600. Later, on January 21, he was traded to the Cincinnati Reds for Cesar Geronimo. He played for the Reds in 1981 with a batting average of .333 and in 1982 with a batting average of .255. Germán's final MLB game was on July 11, 1982, against CHC at the age of 25. Before the all-star break, he was batting .250 and leading the National League in triples but was then sent to Indianapolis, the AAA team of the Cincinnati Reds. Subsequently, on September 7, 1982, he was sent to the Detroit Tigers as part of a conditional deal. Germán played a total of 67 games in the MLB, 12 in the American League, and 55 in the National League, with stats including 62 at-bats, 19 runs, 18 hits, 2 doubles, 3 triples, 5 stolen bases, a fielding percentage of .893, and a batting average of .290.

In 1921, the Detroit Tigers didn't do well in the American League, landing sixth and trailing the Yankees by 27 games with a 71–82 record. However, they made history with 1,724 hits and a .316 batting average as a team, the highest ever in the league. Notably, Harry Heilmann and Ty Cobb ranked first and second in the league's batting race with .394 and .389 averages, respectively, while all three Detroit outfielders were among the league's top hitters. Despite their strong hitting, the team struggled due to poor pitching, evident in their high ERA of 4.40, allowing nine or more runs in 28 games, and only one pitcher, Dutch Leonard, having an ERA below 4.24.

Charles Henry Chick Shorten was an American baseball player who played professionally as an outfielder for 18 years, from 1911 to 1928. During his career, he played for teams like the Boston Red Sox, Detroit Tigers, St. Louis Browns, and Cincinnati Reds. Shorten was part of the 1916 Red Sox team that won the World Series, where he achieved an impressive .571 batting average. Throughout his eight major league seasons, he played in 527 games, primarily as an outfielder, and ended with a career batting average of .275.

In baseball, batting average (AVG) shows how often a batter gets a hit during their turn at bat. In Major League Baseball (MLB), it's found by dividing the number of hits by the number of at bats (AB). Each season, the player with the highest AVG in each league wins the batting title. The American League (AL) winner is called the Rod Carew American League Batting Champion, and the National League (NL) leader is named the Tony Gwynn National League Batting Champion. To qualify for the title, a player needs to have 3.1 plate appearances (PA) per team game (totaling 502 over the 162-game season). But if a player's lead in AVG is big enough, and they add enough hitless at bats to meet the requirement, they still win the title if they would still have the highest AVG. For instance, Tony Gwynn in 1996 had 159 hits in 451 ABs, making a .353 average, but only 498 PAs. Adding four hitless ABs to reach 502 PAs would drop his average to .349, but it would still be higher than the next-highest eligible player's average (.344), so he won the 1996 NL batting title.

question: What american actress/singer born in 1956 recorded the song Something there for beauty and the beast?
pos: Donna Paige Helmintoller, also known as Paige O'Hara, is an American actress, singer, and painter. She started her career on Broadway in 1983, playing Ellie May Chipley in the musical Showboat. In 1991, she made her film debut in Disney's Beauty and the Beast, where she voiced Belle. Because of the success of Beauty and the Beast, she continued to voice Belle in two direct-to-video sequels: Belle's Magical World.

"Something There" is a song from Disney's Beauty and the Beast (1991), written by Howard Ashman and Alan Menken. It's sung by most of the main cast, including Paige O'Hara as Belle and Robby Benson as the Beast. Other actors, like Jerry Orbach, Angela Lansbury, and David Ogden Stiers, voice characters like Lumiere, Mrs. Potts, and Cogsworth. This is the only song where the Beast sings, and it plays during a scene where Belle and the Beast start realizing their feelings for each other.
neg: Robin David Segal, also known as Robby Benson, was born on January 21, 1956. He's an American actor, director, singer, and educator. You might recognize him as the voice of The Beast in Disney's Beauty and the Beast and its follow-up movies. He's also directed episodes of the hit TV show Friends.
Marissa Perry, born on May 5, 1985, is an American actress and singer from Waterbury, Connecticut.

"Be Our Guest" is a lively song from Disney's Beauty and the Beast, written by Howard Ashman and Alan Menken. It's performed by Lumiere and Mrs. Potts, voiced by Jerry Orbach and Angela Lansbury. The song is a big Broadway-style production, where the enchanted objects in the castle try to welcome Belle. Originally, Menken planned to replace the melody, but he couldn't find a better one. The song was initially meant for Belle's father, Maurice, but it was rewritten to keep the focus on Belle as the story developed.

Belle is a song from Disney's Beauty and the Beast movie. It was written by Alan Menken and Howard Ashman and performed by Paige O'Hara and Richard White. The song mixes French and classical music styles with Broadway flair. It's the first song in the movie and sets the scene, introducing Belle as a girl who loves books and doesn't fit in with her village. It also introduces Gaston, the guy who wants to marry her, even though she's not interested.

Belle is a made-up character from Disney's movie "Beauty and the Beast" released in 1991. She's voiced by Paige O'Hara. Belle is different from the people in her village and dreams of having exciting adventures. When her dad, Maurice, gets captured by a mean beast, Belle offers herself instead, to set him free. Over time, she grows to love the Beast, even though he looks scary on the outside.
Anna Simpson, born on March 23,

"Evermore" is a song from the 2017 movie Beauty and the Beast, written by Alan Menken and Tim Rice. It was first sung by actor Dan Stevens, who played the Beast in the movie. Later, singer Josh Groban released his own version of the song as a single on March 3, 2017. Stevens' version was included in the movie's soundtrack released on March 10, 2017, while Groban's version plays during the closing credits.

"Beauty and the Beast" is a song from the Disney movie of the same name, written by Howard Ashman and Alan Menken. It's a ballad that talks about Belle and the Beast's relationship, highlighting how they accept each other's differences and grow because of it. Angela Lansbury, as Mrs. Potts, sings it in the movie during the iconic ballroom scene. The song emphasizes that love is timeless, which is shown throughout the film. Later, Celine Dion and Peabo Bryson recorded a pop version, released as the movie's main single in 1991.

question: Which professional baseball player and National 1993 Baseball Hall of Fame inductee is featured in the Greatest Sports Legends anthology?
pos: "Greatest Sports Legends" is a TV show that talks about famous athletes' lives and careers. It started in 1972 and aired 10 new episodes each year along with reruns. There were 207 episodes in total, featuring athlete hosts like Michael Jordan, Tom Seaver, and others. The show also had celebrity hosts like George Plimpton and Jayne Kennedy. It won one Emmy award out of three nominations.

Reggie Jackson, born on May 18, 1946, is a retired American baseball player. He spent 21 seasons playing for teams like the Kansas City/Oakland Athletics, Baltimore Orioles, New York Yankees, and California Angels in Major League Baseball (MLB). Jackson was honored with induction into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 1993.
neg: Wilburn Edward Eddy Furniss III, born on September 18, 1975, is a former American baseball player who mainly played as a first baseman and designated hitter. He gained recognition for his exceptional performance during his college years at Louisiana State University (LSU). Furniss has received honors for his achievements, including inductions into the College Baseball Hall of Fame, the LSU Athletic Hall of Fame, and the Louisiana Sports Hall of Fame.

Charles Clyde Teague (1924-), an American professional baseball player, primarily played as a second baseman in the minor leagues. During his college years at Wake Forest University, he achieved All-American status for three consecutive seasons. In recognition of his achievements, he was honored with induction into the National College Baseball Hall of Fame in 2010.

Jay Hanna Dizzy Dean, born on January 16, 1910, and passed away on July 17, 1974, was a well-known American baseball player. He played as a pitcher for teams like the St. Louis Cardinals, Chicago Cubs, and the St. Louis Browns. Dean was famous for his bold and lively personality and holds the record as the last National League pitcher to win 30 games in a single season. After retiring from baseball, he became a popular sports commentator on television. In 1953, he was honored with induction into the Baseball Hall of Fame. Additionally, when the Cardinals reopened their team Hall of Fame in 2014, Dean was among the first class of inductees.

Timothy Scott Jorgensen, born on November 30, 1972, used to play pro baseball and coach high school baseball. While at the University of Wisconsin–Oshkosh, he smashed Division III records for most home runs in a season and overall. His baseball career lasted until 1999, and he earned a spot in the National College Baseball Hall of Fame.

Babe Ruth, born on February 6, 1895, and died on August 16, 1948, was a famous American baseball player. He played for 22 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1914 to 1935. Starting with the Boston Red Sox as a talented left-handed pitcher, he gained more recognition playing as an outfielder for the New York Yankees. Ruth set numerous MLB records in hitting and pitching, including career home runs (714), runs batted in (2,213), bases on balls (2,062), slugging percentage (.690), and on-base plus slugging (OPS) (1.164). Many people consider him the greatest baseball player ever. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1936 as one of its first five members.

Robin Ventura, born on July 14, 1967, is a former American professional baseball player and manager. He spent 16 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB) playing for teams like the Chicago White Sox, New York Mets, New York Yankees, and Los Angeles Dodgers. Ventura also managed the White Sox for five seasons. He was picked by the White Sox as the tenth overall draft choice in 1988 from Oklahoma State University (OSU). Ventura achieved notable accolades including six Rawlings Gold Glove awards, two MLB All-Star selections, and induction into the National College Baseball Hall of Fame.

Emma Elizabeth Carney, born on July 29, 1971, is an Australian professional triathlete who has won the World Triathlon Championship twice. She's been honored with inductions into the Sport Australia Hall of Fame in 2016, the World Triathlon International Triathlon Union Hall of Fame in 2014, and the Triathlon Australia Hall of Fame in 2012. Emma stands out as one of the few triathletes worldwide to have achieved two ITU world titles. Dominating the sport, she held the top ranking by ITU from 1995 to 1997 and claimed victory in 19 World Cup events, a record unmatched by any other triathlete. Additionally, her seven wins in 1996 set the record for the most ITU World Series victories in a single season.

Mickey Mantle, known as "The Commerce Comet" and "The Mick," was a famous American baseball player who spent his whole career with the New York Yankees from 1951 to 1968. He played as both a center fielder and first baseman and was praised for his powerful hitting from both sides of the plate. He's widely considered one of the best switch hitters ever. Mantle was honored with induction into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 1974 and was chosen for the Major League Baseball All-Century Team in 1999.

question: Salisbury Woodland Gardens links a zoo with a park designed and built under the watchful eye of who?
pos: Stanley Park is a big park in Blackpool, England, by the coast. It's the main park in town and it's about 104 hectares. It has sports areas, pretty gardens, a lake for boating, and some woods. It was made in the 1920s by a guy named Thomas Mawson.

Salisbury Woodland Gardens is a green area in the east part of Blackpool, situated between East Park Drive and Woodside Drive, connecting Blackpool Zoo and Stanley Park. Locals often refer to it as the 'Woodland Gardens'. The area was bought by Blackpool Corporation in 1924 and initially used as a protective barrier for Stanley Park Golf Course. In the 1940s, it was turned into an arboretum and public space. In 1967, Peter Perry and his team, known as the 'Flying Squad', renovated it. Although once a popular spot for wedding photos, the site declined in the 1990s. Since September 2006, the Council's Ranger Service has been managing and preserving the gardens, including funding and restoring the woodland.
neg: "Conférencier" is the term used for the master of ceremonies in European cabarets. It originated in the 1920s and referred to individuals who not only hosted cabaret shows but also provided political and social commentary. They became controversial during the Nazi regime, which banned their commentary and closely monitored their activities.

Toby Peter Sibbick, born on May 23, 1999, is an English footballer currently playing for AFC Wimbledon. He honed his football skills during his time at St Lawrence R C Primary School in Feltham, West London, where he was coached by Rory McCormack, the Headteacher and football team coach. Starting as an attacking player, Toby became the top goalscorer for the school and helped win the championship. Later, he attended Gunnersbury Boys' School, where he continued to excel in various sports, with football being his primary focus.

Patan Minara, an ancient Buddhist monastery, is located about eight kilometers from Rahim Yar Khan city in Pakistan and is believed to be around 5000 years old. It was constructed during the Hakrra valley civilization in the Mauryan period around 250 BC. At one point, it served as the capital of a Hindu kingdom around 10 AD, according to Colonel Toy. Some researchers suggest that Alexander the Great may have built the structure during his expedition to India, setting up a military camp with a Greek governor and watchtower to monitor the local tribes. Legend has it that there was hidden treasure within the building, and when it was demolished in the 18th century, a brick with Sanskrit writing was discovered, adding to the mystery.

The Thick of It is a British comedy TV show that first aired in 2005 on BBC Four. It makes fun of how the British government operates today. The show mainly revolves around a made-up Department of Social Affairs and Citizenship. Each episode usually centers on the current minister of that department and a group of advisors and civil servants. They're all closely monitored by Malcolm Tucker, who works for Number 10. Other characters include government officials, opposition members, and media personalities.

Double Trouble was a sitcom on NBC from April 4, 1984, to March 30, 1985, starring identical twins Jean and Liz Sagal as Kate and Allison Foster. They play teenagers looked after by their widowed father. The show was like a modern version of other twin mischief stories seen in movies like The Parent Trap or the Patty Duke Show from the 1960s. The Sagal sisters credited Norman Lear, their family's godfather, for shaping the show's idea.

Kiyoshi Daniel Kohatsu, also known as Daniel Kiyoshi, is an animation director and producer. He was born in Lince, Lima, Peru, in March 1971. With Japanese heritage, Kiyoshi went to La Union School for both primary and secondary education before attending the Faculty of Arts at the Catholic University of Peru. Not satisfied with the academic approach to art, Kiyoshi left the university and moved to Tokyo and later Vancouver, Canada, to pursue studies in cinema. He eventually graduated from Vancouver Film School as an animation artist. Under the mentorship of Marv Newland, the animator and director of International Rocketship, Kiyoshi embarked on a career dedicated to animation production. As a freelancer, Kohatsu contributed to various projects for companies like Dreamworks, Warner Bros., MTV, Nickelodeon, and Disney.

Charles de Lorme, also known as Delorme, d'lorm, or De l'Orme, was a medical doctor born on January 1, 1584, and passed away on December 31, 1678. His father, Jean Delorme, served as a professor at Montpellier University and was the primary physician to Marie de' Medici. Charles followed in his father's footsteps, pursuing a medical career after graduating from the University of Montpellier in 1607 at the age of 23. Initially, he practiced medicine in Paris under his father's guidance before establishing his independent practice. Although little is known about his marital life, records indicate that he married for the third time at the age of 78, with his third wife passing away within a year.

"Sasquatched! The Musical" is a comedy musical written by Phil Darg in 2012. It tells the story of Bigfoot, referred to as Arthur the Sasquatch, who arrives in Columbia National Park. Throughout the play, Arthur interacts with eccentric locals, trying to show them that he is intelligent and deserving of their respect. Meanwhile, he also deals with media attention and stereotypes about Bigfoot. The musical features a pop-rock soundtrack.

question: What class of instrument does Apatim Majumdar play?
pos: Apratim Majumdar, born in 1978 in Kolkata, India, is a renowned Indian classical musician known for his mastery of the Sarod instrument. He follows the Dhrupadee Veenkar style of the Seni Veenkar Gharana, pioneered by Ustad Alauddin Khan. His music is characterized by a blend of intricate melodies and technical prowess, reminiscent of the great legends of the Gharana. Additionally, he is highly regarded as an instructor of classical Indian music worldwide.

The sarod, a stringed instrument from India, is widely used in Indian classical music, alongside the sitar. While the sitar has a sweet, overtone-rich sound, the sarod produces a deep, introspective tone. It has sympathetic strings that enhance its resonant quality. Being fretless, the sarod allows for smooth slides between notes, called meend, which are crucial in Indian music.
neg: Chander Bari, a 2007 Bengali film directed by Tarun Majumdar, follows the story of a middle-class joint family. It's based on a Bengali tale by Pracheta Gupta and features Rabindra Sangeet songs by Majumdar.

The sousaphone is a brass instrument, related to the tuba, and was invented around 1893 by J.W. Pepper under the direction of American bandleader John Philip Sousa, after whom it was named. It was designed to be easier to play while standing or marching compared to the tuba, and to project its sound above the heads of the band. Like the tuba, it produces sound by buzzing the lips into a large mouthpiece. However, unlike the tuba, it is bent in a circle to fit around the musician's body and has a bell that points forward, directing the sound ahead. It's commonly used in marching bands and various music styles. Originally made of brass, it later began to be made of lighter materials like fiberglass, which are still popular today.

A bukkehorn, also known as a bockhorn in Swedish or "Billy Goat Horn" in English, is an ancient Scandinavian musical instrument made from the horn of a ram or a goat. Typically crafted from a horn harvested 5 to 7 years prior, it was traditionally used by shepherds and milkmaids in mountainous summer dairy farms. Initially employed as a signaling or scaring instrument, it later evolved to allow playing melodies with finger holes. The instrument employs two blowing techniques: the trumpet-principle being the most common, although the clarinet-principle is also utilized.

An experimental musical instrument is a unique or custom-made device that changes, adds to, or invents a new type of musical tool. Some are made by adjusting existing instruments, like putting metal objects between piano strings. Others are crafted from everyday items, like using bathtub plugs as mutes for brass instruments. Some even combine electronic parts with acoustic instruments.

Udaka Vadya is an Indian musical instrument that resembles Jal tarang or something similar. It falls under the category of Ghan Vadya, which includes percussion instruments where sound is produced by striking a surface. This instrument is mentioned in Vatsyayana's Kamasutra and also in the Sangeeta Parijata from the 17th century. Learning to play this instrument was considered one of the essential 64 skills for women.

The keyboard glockenspiel, also known as jeu de timbre or organ glockenspiel, is a musical instrument that combines a glockenspiel with a piano keyboard. It was first used by George Frideric Handel in 1739 in his oratorio Saul. Later, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart used a similar instrument in The Magic Flute in 1791. Maurice Ravel favored the keyboard version for its ability to produce a strong sound in orchestral climaxes. In the late 20th century, Bergerault began making a three-octave mallet instrument with a foot pedal damping mechanism to meet the demands of modern scores.

An asset class refers to a group of financial instruments that share similar characteristics and tend to behave alike in the market. These instruments are typically categorized as either real assets or financial assets. While assets within the same class often face similar regulations, this isn't always the case. For example, futures contracts are usually grouped in the same class as the assets they're based on, but they are subject to different regulations.

Accompaniment in music refers to the supporting musical parts that enhance the melody or main themes of a song or piece. It comes in various styles across different music genres. In simpler terms, in popular music, a clear vocal melody is backed by chords. The accompaniment sets the beat and chord progression, often played on instruments like piano, guitar, or organ. While any instrument can accompany, keyboards and guitars are common due to their ability to play chords and basslines simultaneously. For instance, a solo singer can accompany themselves by playing guitar or piano while singing. Sometimes, a singer can even accompany themselves solely using their voice and body, as demonstrated by artists like Bobby McFerrin.

question: Jamie Harris is best known for his role as The Hook-Handed Man in a movie directed by who ?
pos: Jamie Harris, a British actor born on May 15, 1963, is famous for playing The Hook-Handed Man in Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events, Rodney in Rise of the Planet of the Apes, and Gordon in Marvel's Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.

"Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events" is a movie from 2004, directed by Brad Silberling. It's based on the books by Lemony Snicket, specifically the first three: "The Bad Beginning," "The Reptile Room," and "The Wide Window." The cast includes Jim Carrey, Liam Aiken, Emily Browning, and others, with Jude Law voicing Lemony Snicket.
neg: Usman Ally is an actor known for his work in American films, stage plays, and television shows. In 2015, he received an Obie Award for his performance in The Invisible Hand. He has been in many stage productions like The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity, The Jungle Book, and Around the World in 80 Days. On TV, he's recognized for playing Vincent in Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. and the hook-handed man in A Series of Unfortunate Events.

Rewrite: "Badla Jatti Da" is a Punjabi action film from 1991, directed by Ravinder Ravi and featuring Gugu Gill and Yograj Singh in prominent roles. Yograj Singh's portrayal of the antagonist is highly praised, and the movie was a huge success in Punjab, becoming a blockbuster hit.

"Song to the Sun," also known as "Taiyō no Uta" in Japan, is a film directed by Norihiro Koizumi featuring Japanese artist and singer Yui. The story follows Kaoru Amane, played by Yui, a 16-year-old girl with xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), a condition that makes sunlight harmful to her. The character is partially inspired by Yui herself, who is a singer and guitarist. Yui performs three of her songs in the movie: "It's Happy Line," "Good-bye Days," and "Skyline." The film has inspired various adaptations, including a 2006 Japanese TV drama, a manga by Bandō Kenji and Minatsuki Tsunami, a 2015 Vietnamese/Japanese drama, and a 2017 American remake.

Maurice Walsh, born on April 23, 1879, and passed away on February 18, 1964, was an Irish novelist. He gained fame for his short story "The Quiet Man," which was adapted into a successful movie directed by John Ford and featuring John Wayne and Maureen O'Hara. During the 1930s, he was among Ireland's top-selling authors.

Estelle Hemsley was a well-known African American actress in the early days of stage and screen. She was recognized for her performances in various productions, such as "Take a Giant Step," both on stage and in the movie adaptation directed by Philip Leacock, which earned her a Golden Globe nomination. Additionally, she played memorable roles like Grandmother Topouzoglou in Elia Kazan's "America, America," Cla-Cla in Mel Ferrer's "Green Mansions," and Catherine in Robert Mulligan's "Baby the Rain Must Fall." She also portrayed Ruby Dee's mother in "Edge of the City" in 1957.

Jalam is a Malayalam-language movie released in 2016, directed by M. Padmakumar and starring Priyanka Nair. It's notable as the world's first charity movie, produced by the Aries Group and directed by M. Padmakumar, with Sohan Roy as the producer. Several songs from the film, like 'Bhoomiyilenganumundo', 'Kooduvaykkam', 'Yaathra Manoradhamerum', and 'Pakalppathichari', are being considered for nominations in the Original Song Category at the 88th Academy Awards. Additionally, the movie is hoping for nominations in the Best Picture Category at the Oscars.

The 1988 NBC TV movie "Man Against the Mob" is directed by Steven Hilliard Stern and features actors George Peppard, Kathryn Harrold, and Max Gail. It's also known as "Trouble in the City of Angels." The movie is about a special LAPD unit formed after World War II to fight organized crime in Los Angeles. It's similar to the 2013 movie "Gangster Squad" and might have been influenced by the 1987 film "The Untouchables," which also portrays law enforcement fighting mobsters. George Peppard plays a tough LA cop in the late 1940s. There's a sequel called "Man Against the Mob: The Chinatown Murders," released in 1989 and starring Peppard as well. The first movie was supposed to kick off a series called "City of Angels" but ended with just these two TV movies when George Peppard passed away in 1994.

"The Dragon, The Hero" is a Hong Kong martial arts film directed by Godfrey Ho and featuring actors like Philip Ko, Dragon Lee, Tino Wong Cheung, and Liu Chung-Liang. It's regarded as one of Ho's top martial arts films beyond just martial arts enthusiasts. The movie is also sometimes referred to as "Dragon on Fire."

question: How many laps did Harry Prowell run during the 10,000 metres race at the 1967 Pan American Games?
pos: The 10,000 meters, also known as the 10K run, is a popular long-distance track event often seen at the Olympics and World Championships. Runners circle the track 25 times, covering a distance of 10,000 meters. While it's a staple at major championships, it's not as common at regular track meets due to its lengthy duration. This event is specifically labeled in meters, unlike the similar 10K run held on roads, which is measured in kilometers.

Harry Prowell was a Guyanese long-distance runner who competed in the Marathon at the 1968 Summer Olympics in Mexico City. He set Guyana's national record that year and remains one of their best marathon runners. He's the only Guyanese to have ever competed in the Marathon at the Summer Olympics and was a prominent Indo-Caribbean long-distance runner. Additionally, he took part in the 10,000 meters at the 1967 Pan American Games in Canada and represented Guyana at the 1970 British Commonwealth Games in Scotland.
neg: Ross MacKenzie, a Canadian sprinter born on July 18, 1946, participated in the 1968 Summer Olympics in the men's 400 meters race. He also took part in the 1967 Pan American Games, where he came in second in the 4x400 meters relay with teammates Brian MacLaren, Bill Crothers, and Robert McLaren, and finished fifth in the 400 meters event. Additionally, MacKenzie won a silver medal in the 1966 British Empire and Commonwealth Games as part of the 4x440 yards relay team alongside Don Domansky, Brian MacLaren, and Bill Crothers.

The European 10,000m Cup is a yearly race spanning 10,000 meters, specifically for European athletes. It started in 1997 and is managed by the European Athletics Association. Initially, it was called the European 10000 Metres Challenge when it was removed from the European Cup program. The competition's origins trace back to the Iberian 10,000 Metres Championships, a contest between Spanish and Portuguese athletes from 1991 to 1996. The first five editions of the European 10000 Metres Challenge were held in the Iberian Peninsula. In 2005, it adopted its current name.

The Toronto 2015 Pan American Games, also called the XVII Pan American Games, were a big sports event that happened from July 10 to 26, 2015, in Toronto, Canada. This event was part of the Pan American Games tradition and was overseen by the Pan American Sports Organization (PASO). It was the third time Canada hosted the Pan American Games and the first time in the province of Ontario. The games took place in Toronto and seventeen other nearby communities. They were organized by the Toronto Organizing Committee for the 2015 Pan and Parapan American Games (TO2015).

Kavita Tungar, born as Raut on May 5, 1985, is an Indian long-distance runner from Nashik, Maharashtra. She's set national records in 10 km road running, completing it in 34 minutes and 32 seconds, and in the half marathon with a time of 1 hour, 12 minutes, and 50 seconds. Notably, she won a bronze medal in the 10,000 meters race at the 2010 Commonwealth Games, marking the first individual track medal won by an Indian woman athlete at the Commonwealth Games. Additionally, she secured a silver medal in the 10,000 meters race at the 2010 Asian Games.

Brian MacLaren, born on December 21, 1943, is a Canadian sprinter known for his participation in various athletic competitions. He represented Canada in the men's 400 meters at the 1972 Summer Olympics. Notably, he achieved second place in the 4 × 400 meters relay at the 1967 Pan American Games alongside teammates Bill Crothers, Ross MacKenzie, and Robert McLaren. Additionally, he secured third place in the 800 meters at the same event. In the 1966 British Empire and Commonwealth Games, he clinched a silver medal in the 4 x 440 yards relay, competing with Don Domansky, Ross MacKenzie, and Bill Crothers.

David Bailey, born in Toronto, Ontario on March 17, 1945, is a retired track and field athlete who represented Canada at the 1968 Summer Olympics in the men's 1,500 meters. He achieved several milestones in his career, including being the first Canadian to run a mile in under 4 minutes, accomplishing this feat in San Diego, CA on June 11, 1966, and later in Toronto on July 22, 1967. Throughout his career, he won bronze at the 1967 Pan American Games and silver at the 1968 World University Games. Bailey was recognized as the Canadian Universities Track and Field Athlete of the Year in 1965 and 1967 and was inducted into the University of Toronto Sports Hall of Fame in 1998 and 2003. He represented Canada in various international competitions, including the Commonwealth Games, Pan American Games, and Olympic Games.

Nora Leticia Rocha de la Cruz, born on December 18, 1967, in Monclova, Coahuila, Mexico, is a former track and field athlete. She competed in the 5000 and 10,000 meters events. In 1999, she won the gold medal in the women's 10,000 meters at the Pan American Games held in Winnipeg, Canada.

In 2011, the XVI Pan American Games took place from October 14–30 in Guadalajara, Jalisco, Mexico. Some events also occurred in nearby cities like Ciudad Guzmán, Puerto Vallarta, Lagos de Moreno, and Tapalpa. It was the biggest multi-sport event of the year, with around 6,000 athletes from 42 countries participating in 36 sports. The games were organized by the Guadalajara 2011 Organizing Committee (COPAG). This was Mexico's third time hosting the Pan American Games, and the first time in Jalisco. Mexico had previously hosted the 1955 and 1975 Pan American Games, both in Mexico City. The 2011 Parapan American Games followed 20 days after the Pan American Games ended.

question: Are  Chrysalis and Look both women's magazines?
pos: Look is a trendy magazine for young women that covers fashion, shopping tips, celebrity styles and news, and real-life stories. It's published by Time Inc. UK and edited by Ali Hall.

Chrysalis: A Magazine of Women's Culture was a feminist publication that ran from 1977 to 1980. It was founded by Kirsten Grimstad and Susan Rennie in Los Angeles. The magazine stemmed from their work on self-help books, The New Woman's Survival Catalog and The New Woman's Survival Sourcebook. What set Chrysalis apart was its blend of politics, literature, cultural studies, and art, all done through a collective process inspired by feminist consciousness-raising. Despite covering a wide range of topics, the magazine maintained high quality. It featured contributions from notable figures such as Audre Lorde, Robin Morgan, Adrienne Rich, Marge Percy, Judy Chicago, Joanna Russ, Lucy Lippard, Mary Daly, Dolores Hayden, Andrea Dworkin, Marilyn Hacker, Arlene Raven, and Elizabeth Janeway. Despite its acclaim, financial difficulties led to its closure in 1981 after ten issues.
neg: The first women's magazine in Malaysia came out in 1932. By the 2000s, there were almost fifty local magazines aimed at women, some with an Islamic angle. Malaysia also sees international women's magazines like Elle Malaysia (since March 2014) and Women’s Health (since April 2015). Comic and film magazines are popular too.

The magazine industry in Austria is heavily influenced by Germany, especially in women's and fashion magazines, although this influence has decreased since the late 1990s. However, business magazines remain unaffected by this dominance. Austrian magazines mainly focus on news, popular science, and special interest topics. Magazines play a significant role in Austria's press market, which is split between magazines and newspapers.

The Transition House Association of Nova Scotia (THANS), also known as TRANS, is an organization based in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada, that operates women's shelters. Pamela Harrison serves as the executive director of THANS and also acts as the provincial coordinator. Rhonda Fraser, who heads Chrysalis House, is a member of THANS. Every year, THANS holds a purple ribbon awareness campaign to honor the victims of the École Polytechnique massacre. Established in 1989, THANS conducted interviews with 34 women who experienced physical abuse and sought resolution through family law mediation. In 2000, THANS released a report based on these interviews, revealing that most of the women did not recommend legal mediation to other abuse victims. In 2008, THANS backed Bill 81, aiming to establish the Domestic Violence Elimination Act, but Minister of Justice Cecil Clarke did not advance the bill to a third reading. In 2009, Darrell Dexter, from the New Democratic Party, pledged to increase government funding for halfway houses in Nova Scotia, including support for THANS. In 2012, THANS collaborated with organizations like the World YWCA, Family SOS, Silent Witness Nova Scotia, and Leave Out Violence to host the Atlantic Ballet Theatre of Canada's performance of "Ghosts of Violence," a ballet addressing domestic violence, in Halifax.
Lifestyle magazines cover various topics like fashion, health, travel, and culture, targeting both men and women. They focus on a particular style or vibe in their content.

A customer magazine is a publication created by a business to communicate with its customers. It's similar in appearance to regular magazines but is funded either partly or entirely by the business. Instead of focusing on sales and ads, the main goal is to achieve specific business objectives like increasing sales, improving brand perception, or fostering loyalty. For example, airlines were among the first to have customer magazines, and now, many supermarkets in the UK have them too, featuring recipes and food content to promote their products. Even digitally-native companies like WebMD and Net-À-Portér have their own customer magazines. Some of these magazines include advertisements, which can help cover costs and make the publication seem more like a traditional magazine.

Rick Wilber, an American writer, has written over thirty-five short stories for various magazines like Aboriginal SF, Analog, and Asimov's Science Fiction, among others. His works have also appeared in anthologies such as Alien Sex and Chrysalis. Apart from short stories, he has authored novels like Rum Point, The Cold Road, and Alien Morning, along with a memoir titled My Father's Game: Life, Death, Baseball. Additionally, Wilber has penned textbooks including Modern Media Writing and Magazine Feature Writing.
In Portugal, most magazines focus on topics like women's interests, society, and TV. Back in 1994, there were around 984 magazines available in the country.

Surfer hair is a messy hairstyle that became popular with surfers starting in the 1950s. It's typically long, thick, and naturally lightened by the sun and saltwater. In the late 1960s and 1970s, this relaxed, long-haired style was associated with hippie culture. Nowadays, hair product companies sell gels, shampoos, and waxes to help people achieve the surfer look, even though today's styles are often shorter and require more grooming to get that windswept appearance. Fashion magazines often praise the sun-kissed surfer hair look for women, despite the fact that real surfer hair is often damaged from exposure to the elements.

question: Which author has won more Pulitzer Prizes, Thomas Friedman or Henri Bergson?
pos: Henri-Louis Bergson (1859-1941) was a French philosopher who had a big impact in the early 20th century and continued to be influential in continental philosophy after World War II.
Thomas Loren Friedman, born on July 20, 1953, is an American journalist and author who has won the Pulitzer Prize three times.
neg: "Introduction to Metaphysics" by Henri Bergson, written in 1903, delves into the idea of reality. Bergson proposes that reality is not fixed but rather a dynamic process, akin to concepts found in process philosophy and Heraclitus' teachings. He argues against the idea that reality can be fully comprehended through breaking it down into parts, suggesting that this approach only gives us relative perspectives. Instead, Bergson advocates for understanding reality through intuition, which he describes as immersing oneself into the object to grasp its essence completely.

Henri Bergson proposed the concept of "duration" as a theory of time and consciousness, aiming to address what he saw as flaws in Herbert Spencer's philosophy. Bergson believed Spencer's lack of understanding of mechanics led to a misconception that time could be fully understood through mathematics and science.
