Notable founders of the college include three future signers of the Declaration of Independence and three future signers of the United States Constitution. The university was founded to promote liberal education and is one of the oldest in the nation.

Wolfson College, part of the University of Cambridge in Cambridge, England, mainly caters to postgraduate students. However, it also accepts mature undergraduates (aged 21 and older), constituting about 15% of its student body. Established in 1965 as University College, it became Wolfson College in 1973, named after the Wolfson Foundation, a major benefactor. Situated west of Cambridge city center, close to the University Library, Wolfson holds the distinction of being the first college at the university to admit both men and women as students and Fellows.

Trinity Hall Boat Club (THBC) is the rowing club of Trinity Hall, one of the colleges at the University of Cambridge. Established in 1827, it's one of the oldest college boat clubs in Cambridge, England. Over the years, it has been very successful at the Henley Royal Regatta, winning numerous events, including dominating in 1887 when it won all but one event.

Campbell Field, also known as Marv Kay Stadium at Harry D. Campbell Field, is a historic American college football stadium situated in Golden, Colorado. It's where the Colorado Mines Orediggers football team plays their home games. Campbell Field stands out as one of the oldest football fields in the country, being the oldest west of the Mississippi River and within NCAA Division II. Originally, it was a dirt surface within a clay pit, fitting for the Orediggers. The first athletic event held here was on May 20, 1893, featuring various contests between local universities. The first football game took place on October 7, 1893, resulting in a 6-0 victory for the Orediggers over the University of Denver. Since then, Campbell Field has been the Orediggers' home, with a few renovations over the years. Initially named Athletic Park, it was later renamed Brooks Field and finally Campbell Field in honor of a benefactor and former team member. Today, it stands as the oldest football field in the west and among the oldest in the nation.

The Doehling–Heselton Memorial Trophy is given each year to the winning team of the Division III college football match between Ripon College Red Hawks and the Lawrence University Vikings. This game is part of the oldest college football rivalry in Wisconsin, which started in 1893. It's also the 14th oldest college football rivalry in the country. Ripon currently leads the series with 56 wins, 46 losses, and 7 ties.

Ismail Yusuf College, known as IY College, is the fourth oldest college in Mumbai, India, managed by the Government of Maharashtra. It's also the oldest college in North Mumbai, established in 1930 with a significant donation from Sir Mohammed Yusuf Ismail. The foundation stone was laid by Sir Leslie Orme Wilson, the Governor of Bombay, in 1924. The college was envisioned as a grand temple of learning in a Persian architectural style, featuring spacious corridors and surrounded by lush greenery, including large banyan and palm trees.

The College of Natural Resources (CNR) at the University of California, Berkeley, is the oldest college in the UC system and boasts several top-ranked programs internationally. It's highly regarded in Agricultural Economics, topping multiple rankings such as those by the Journal of Agricultural and Applied Economics, the Chronicle of Higher Education, Perry for its Ph.D. programs and in International Trade, the National Research Council in Agricultural & Resource Economics, and U.S. News in Environmental/Environmental Health. Additionally, UC Berkeley is recognized as the top university worldwide for Environmental Studies by QS World Rankings and U.S. News ranks it as the best global university for environment and ecology. A study on AJAE authors and their affiliations found CNR to have the highest number of pages per research faculty member.

question: In what 1997 American mystery crime film did Johnny Galecki start in?
pos: John Mark Galecki, born on April 30, 1975, is an American actor recognized for his roles as David Healy in the ABC sitcom Roseanne from 1992 to 1997 and as Dr. Leonard Hofstadter in the CBS sitcom The Big Bang Theory since 2007. He has also been in movies like National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation (1989), Prancer (1989), Suicide Kings (1997), I Know What You Did Last Summer (1997), Bookies (2003), and In Time (2011).

"Suicide Kings" is a movie from 1997 about a group of criminals who kidnap a Mafia leader. It's based on a short story by Don Stanford called "The Hostage" and directed by Peter O'Fallon. The main actors include Christopher Walken, Denis Leary, Sean Patrick Flanery, Johnny Galecki, Jay Mohr, Jeremy Sisto, and Henry Thomas. Despite mixed reviews, it earned $1.7 million in the US and has a 34% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes.
neg: Herbert Brean was an American journalist and crime fiction writer, famous for his characters William Deacon and Reynold Frame. He was involved in the Mystery Writers of America as a director and former executive vice president, and he taught a mystery writing class for the group. In addition to his seven mystery novels, he wrote non-fiction books, articles, and short stories for mystery magazines. Alfred Hitchcock adapted one of Brean's Life magazine articles, "A Case of Identity" (1953), into the film "The Wrong Man" (1957).

"The Mystery of the Yellow Room" is a 1919 American crime drama film produced by the Mayflower Photoplay Company and distributed by Realart Pictures Corporation. It's based on the novel "Le mystère de la chambre jaune" by Gaston Leroux, a French writer. The film was directed by Emile Chautard, a French actor, director, and producer, who was 55 years old at the time of its release. Leroux's novel, serialized in the magazine L'Illustration from September to November 1907 before being published as a book in 1908, is considered one of the earliest examples of locked room mystery crime fiction.

Penny is a made-up character in the TV show "The Big Bang Theory" on CBS. She's played by Kaley Cuoco and is the main female character. She becomes friends with her neighbors Leonard Hofstadter and Sheldon Cooper, who are scientists at Caltech. Penny doesn't have a fancy education like the guys but is friendly and practical, which is very different from them. She and Leonard start a relationship in the third season, break up, then get back together in the fifth season. They eventually get engaged in the seventh season and married in the ninth season. Penny is unique because her last name is never mentioned until after her wedding, when she's sometimes called Penny Hofstadter.
"The Law & Harry McGraw" is a mystery crime show that aired on CBS from September 27, 1987, to February 10, 1988. It's a spin-off of "Murder, She Wrote."
The Renegades is a TV show about a street gang who join the police undercover to dodge going to jail. Patrick Swayze plays Bandit, the gang's leader.

Kingston: Confidential was a TV show in the US that aired on NBC for 13 episodes in the spring of 1977. It came after a successful TV movie called "Kingston" in 1976. The show was made by R.B. Productions, Inc. and Groverton Productions, Inc., working with Universal Television.

Morgan's Ferry is a crime drama movie made in 2001. It features actors like Billy Zane, Henry Rollins, Kelly McGillis, Roscoe Lee Browne, Johnny Galecki, and Muse Watson. The film was directed by Sam Pillsbury.

Mystic River, a movie from 2003, is an American mystery crime drama directed by Clint Eastwood and featuring Sean Penn, Tim Robbins, Kevin Bacon, Laurence Fishburne, Marcia Gay Harden, and Laura Linney. The screenplay was written by Brian Helgeland, adapted from Dennis Lehane's novel of the same name. Clint Eastwood, along with Robert Lorenz and Judie G. Hoyt, produced the film, marking Eastwood's first credit as a composer for the score.

question: Which came to market first, "Hey Pa! There's a Goat on the Roof" or "Poleconomy"
answer: Hey Pa! There's a Goat on the Roof
pos: "Hey Dad! 'There's a Goat on the Roof' was a board game for kids released by Parker Brothers in 1966."

Poleconomy is a board game created by Bruce E. Hatherley from New Zealand in 1980. It's like Monopoly, but instead of properties, the board features companies. Players compete to buy these companies and make investments through economic and political actions. The game's duration is agreed upon by all players, usually around 2 hours, and the winner is the one with the most money from cash, companies, insurance, or other assets. The game can also end when there are no more companies, ads in the bank, or bonds in the treasury. Besides entertainment, the game aims to teach players about economics and the relationship between the economy and government. Different versions of the game were released for various countries, and its name comes from a blend of "politics" and "economy."
neg: Pashmina is a luxurious type of cashmere wool originally woven in Kashmir, India. The name originates from Persian and translates to "Soft Gold" in Kashmiri. Pashmina shawls are so delicate that they can pass through a small ring. In the West, it's known as 'cashmere' because Europeans first discovered it in Kashmir. The wool comes from four types of Cashmere goats, including those from Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, and Nepal. These shawls are hand-spun and woven in Kashmir and Nepal using fine cashmere fibers.

"Verão Vermelho" is a song by Santana from the album "Festival." Carlos Santana honors Brazilian singer Elis Regina in this track. The song features beautiful acoustic guitar melodies and backing vocals by The Waters Family (Julia, Oren, and Maxine Willard Waters), who sing the repetitive words, "Badadup, badadup, badadup, ba pa pa ba pa pa." It's driven by a marching drum beat and maracas. Santana showcases a flamenco guitar solo at the beginning and end of the song, which is a first for him. The solo at the end is accompanied by a keyboard flourish by Tom Coster.

The Ford flathead V8, also known as the Ford flathead or flatty in hot-rodding circles, is a type of V8 engine designed by Ford Motor Company and produced by Ford and its licensees. Initially, it was referred to as the Ford V-8 due to the rarity of overhead-valve engines at the time. The Model 18 was the first car to feature this engine, often called the Ford V-8 as well. While V8 engines were not new, Ford's introduction made an 8-cylinder engine affordable for the mass market, marking a significant development. This engine, Ford's first independently designed and mass-produced V8, was a major success and remained in production until 1953, longer than the Model T engine. It was highly regarded, making Ward's list of the top 10 engines of the 20th century and remaining popular among hot rodders and classic car enthusiasts.

Friendship Hall, situated in East New Market, Dorchester County, Maryland, is a historical residence designed in the Georgian architectural style, characterized by its brick construction. The main building, erected around 1790, features a spacious two-story main section with five bays, alongside a two-bay single-story passage and a kitchen wing with a lower, 1 ½-story structure. Additionally, the property includes a tall smokehouse made of wood panels and a steeply pitched roof. This property has ties to the well-known Sulivane family, who settled in Maryland in 1695.

Veti-gel is a type of gel used for animals, made from plants and injected into wounds to stop bleeding fast, both on the outside and inside of the body. It's named after a gel in the video game Mass Effect called Medi-Gel. The gel contains a plant-based material that forms a mesh to seal the wound. Suneris Inc, an American biotech company, makes it. They're also working on similar products for humans, aiming to launch them as early as 2016. The company plans to release a version for military and emergency use first, and then for surgical use once it gets FDA approval.

The Rove is a type of goat that was first tamed in France. It used to be at risk of disappearing, but now, as of 2003, there are over 5000 registered Rove goats on farms in France. Initially, people bred this goat for its meat. However, since the demand for goat meat in France isn't great anymore, farmers have started using the Rove for producing dairy products instead.

Chatta Bazaar, also known as the "Under Roof Market," is situated in Hyderabad, India. It's one of the city's oldest markets and was the first to have shops set up under a roof to store goods more efficiently.

VELUX is a Danish company known for making roof windows and skylights. It all started over 75 years ago when the founder, Villum Kann Rasmussen, installed the first VELUX roof window in a Danish school. Since then, the company has grown steadily. In 1952, VELUX partnered with Ernst Günter Albers to enter the German market, and later, the sons of the founders, Lars Kann-Rasmussen and Peter Albers, continued to expand the business.

question: What record did the Super Bowl XXXIV champions finish the regular-season with in 1999?
pos: In 1999, the St. Louis Rams had their 62nd season in the National Football League and their fifth season in St. Louis, Missouri. They did well, winning 13 games and losing only 3 during the regular season. They also won the NFC West Championship.

The 2000 season for the Tennessee Titans was their 41st overall and 31st in the National Football League (NFL). This was the second season the team went by the name Titans. They started the season after narrowly losing Super Bowl XXXIV to the St. Louis Rams as the defending AFC Champions.
neg: Thomas E. Ted Plumb, born on August 20, 1939, is a former American football player and coach. His football career ended due to a neck injury during training camp when he was a promising young receiver for the Buffalo Bills from Baylor University. Despite this setback, he transitioned into a successful coaching career at various levels, including high school, college, and the NFL. Notably, he coached for two legendary Super Bowl-winning teams: the 1985 Chicago Bears and the 2000 St. Louis Rams. With the Bears, he was the Wide Receivers Coach, and with the Rams, he served as the Director of Pro Scouting. Plumb retired after the 2000 season and returned to his home in Alba, Texas.

Super Bowl XXXVII was a football game between the Oakland Raiders and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to determine the NFL champion for the 2002 season. The Buccaneers won 48–21, marking their first Super Bowl victory. It was held on January 26, 2003, at Qualcomm Stadium in San Diego, California. This game was notable for being the last Super Bowl played in January, as subsequent ones have been held in February since 2004. Additionally, it was the final Super Bowl in California until Super Bowl 50.

Richard Scott Proehl, born on March 7, 1968, used to play professional American football as a wide receiver in the NFL. Over 17 seasons, he was part of various teams like the Phoenix/Arizona Cardinals, Seattle Seahawks, Chicago Bears, St. Louis Rams, Carolina Panthers, and Indianapolis Colts. He participated in four Super Bowls, winning two of them: Super Bowl XXXIV with the Rams and Super Bowl XLI with the Colts.

Donald André Dré Bly, born on May 22, 1977, is a former American football player who played as a cornerback in the NFL for eleven seasons. He started his career playing college football at the University of North Carolina (UNC), where he received All-American honors twice. Drafted by the St. Louis Rams in 1999, he spent four seasons with them, winning a Super Bowl in XXXIV. He later played for the Detroit Lions, earning two Pro Bowl selections during his four years there, and also had stints with the Denver Broncos and San Francisco 49ers.

Super Bowl LIII, also known as the 53rd Super Bowl, is the championship game of the National Football League (NFL) for the 2018 season. It will happen on February 3, 2019, at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta, Georgia. This marks Atlanta's third time hosting the Super Bowl, following the events in 1994 and 2000. CBS will broadcast the game nationwide.

Bill Leavy, pronounced LEE-vee, is a former American football official in the NFL from 1995 to 2014. He wore uniform number 127 and served as a police officer and firefighter in San Jose, California, for 27 years. During his time as an NFL official, he worked in fifteen playoff games, including two Super Bowls. In 2000, he was a back judge for Super Bowl XXXIV, and in 2006, he served as the referee for Super Bowl XL.

Super Bowl XXXIV was a football game in which the St. Louis Rams played against the Tennessee Titans to determine the champion of the 1999 NFL season. The Rams won 23-16, marking their first Super Bowl victory and NFL championship since 1951. The game took place on January 30, 2000, at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta, making it the fourth Super Bowl held a week after the conference championship games. The last time this occurred was during Super Bowl XXVIII, which also happened to be played on January 30 at the Georgia Dome.

This is a timeline of the seasons played by the Tennessee Titans, a team in the NFL (National Football League). It shows how well the Titans did each year, including playoffs and any awards their players or coaches received. Originally called the Houston Oilers, they started in 1960 in a league called the AFL (American Football League). In 1997, they moved to Tennessee, first playing in Memphis before settling in Nashville. After the 1998 season, they changed their name to the Titans. Although they haven't won a Super Bowl yet, they did win two championships when they were in the AFL. Since moving to Tennessee, they've beaten every other NFL team at least once, and they've never lost to the Detroit Lions, with a record of 5 wins and 0 losses against them.

question: What is the population of the town at the intersection of Interstate Highways 77 and  the longest Interstate highway within the borders of Virginia?
pos: Wytheville is a town in Wythe County, Virginia, USA. It's named after George Wythe, who signed the Declaration of Independence and was Thomas Jefferson's mentor. The population was 8,211 in 2010. Positioned at the meeting point of Interstate Highways 77 and 81, Wytheville has historically been a busy junction for travelers. During the Civil War, it was strategically important and faced attacks in 1863 (Toland's Raid) and 1865 (Stoneman's 1865 Raid). Additionally, it's where Edith Bolling Wilson, wife of President Woodrow Wilson, was born.

Interstate 81 (I-81) is a highway that spans 855 miles. In Virginia, it covers 324.92 miles, making it the longest stretch of I-81 in any state and the longest Interstate highway in Virginia. It runs from the Tennessee state line near Bristol to the West Virginia state line near Winchester.
neg: Interstate 40 (I-40) is a big highway in the USA. It goes from Barstow, California to Wilmington, North Carolina. In North Carolina, it starts at the Pigeon River Gorge near Tennessee and goes all the way across the state, passing through cities like Asheville, Winston-Salem, Greensboro, Durham, and Raleigh. It ends in Wilmington. Along the way, it goes through different landscapes like mountains, suburban areas, cities, and farmland. It's the longest interstate in North Carolina, covering 423.55 miles. In North Carolina, there are also other highways related to I-40, and there's a business loop in Winston-Salem. Even though it's called east-west, the part in eastern North Carolina actually goes more north-south.

In New York, there are 32 Interstate Highways, with 9 main routes and 23 auxiliary routes. The New York State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) mostly takes care of these highways, except for a few cases. Unlike in some other states, NYSDOT doesn't refer directly to Interstate Highways by their numbers. Instead, they add the letter "I" to the route number on markers and internal documents. This might seem confusing because some Interstate Highways share numbers with state routes, like I-86 and NY 86. However, adding the "I" suffix to Interstate Highway numbers allows both the Interstate Highway and the state route to exist without conflict (86I versus 86, respectively).

Illinois's Interstate Highways are parts of the national Interstate Highway System, maintained by the state's Department of Transportation (IDOT). There are 13 main highways and 11 smaller ones, totaling 2,248.93 miles. Interstate 57 is the longest in Illinois at 358.57 miles, while Interstate 41 is the shortest at just 0.90 miles.

Maryland has 16 Interstate Highways. Six are main routes, and ten are smaller routes connected to the main ones. The longest main route is Interstate 95 (I-95) at 110.01 miles, and the shortest is I-81 at 12.08 miles. I-97 is both the shortest main route, at 17.62 miles, and the shortest route within Maryland only, meaning it doesn't cross state lines. It's also the only main route entirely within one county and doesn't link to other main routes. The longest smaller route is I-695 at 51.48 miles, and the shortest is I-295 at 0.80 miles. Most Interstates in Maryland are looked after by the Maryland State Highway Administration, except for a few sections. There's one Interstate, I-595, that's not labeled but is part of US Route 50 and US 301. Additionally, there's one former Interstate, I-170, marked in dark gray on the list.

When the Interstate Highway System routes were designated in Utah, the state legislature also made some changes to the Utah State Route system. Most of these changes weren't noticeable to the public and only involved assigning route numbers within the legislature. They mainly focused on assigning numbers 1 through 5 for future Interstate Highway corridors. Some adjustments were made to unsigned highways for state parks and institutions, while other routes were shortened, reorganized, or divided to streamline the Interstate Highway numbering. These changes aimed to support future construction, as the Interstate Highway System was still in its early stages in Utah in 1962. Many of the changes made then weren't implemented until years later, and most of them are no longer in effect today. Further changes to route designations occurred in 1977, which included eliminating unsigned legislative routes and concurrences.

The auxiliary Interstate Highways, also known as three-digit Interstate Highways, are extra freeways in the United States Interstate Highway System. Like the main highways, they follow the same rules, get most of their funding from the federal government (usually 90%), and meet federal standards.

In Texas, the Interstate Highways are taken care of by the Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT). They manage the day-to-day upkeep and running of these roads. There are 12 main routes, 7 secondary ones, and Interstate 35 (I-35) splits into I-35E and I-35W, connecting Fort Worth and Dallas. The longest stretch is I-10 at 878.6 miles, and the shortest is I-110 at 0.9 miles.

Interstate 85 (I-85) is a highway that stretches from Montgomery, Alabama to Petersburg, Virginia. In Virginia, it covers a distance of about 68.64 miles, starting from the North Carolina border near Bracey and ending at I-95 in Petersburg. As it travels through Southside Virginia, I-85 runs alongside US Route 1, passing through areas like Petersburg and South Hill, where it connects with other major roads like US 460 and US 58. This highway is vital for linking the Richmond–Petersburg area with places like the Research Triangle in North Carolina. And just like other mainline Interstate Highways, I-85 in Virginia is part of the National Highway System.

question: What was the nickname of the hitman hired by an Italian American Criminal Organization?
answer: The Crowned Prince of the Philadelphia Mob
pos: Salvatore Salvie Testa, also known as The Crowned Prince of the Philadelphia Mob, was a gangster in Philadelphia from March 31, 1956, to September 14, 1984. He worked as a hitman for the Philadelphia crime family during a time when there was a lot of fighting within the gang. Testa, the son of the former Philadelphia boss Philip, was considered a promising member of the mob until he was murdered following orders from Nicky Scarfo Sr.

The Philadelphia crime family, also called the Philadelphia Mafia or Philly Mob, is an Italian American criminal group in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. They're based in South Philadelphia but operate in many parts of the Philadelphia area, Delaware Valley, Southeastern Pennsylvania, and South Jersey. Known for their violent history, they've had many aggressive leaders and been involved in numerous mob conflicts.
neg: The Los Angeles crime family, part of the American Mafia, is an Italian American criminal group in California. It started in the early 1900s and expanded across Southern California. Like other Mafia groups in the US, it got stronger during Prohibition by selling illegal alcohol. Its heyday was in the 1940s and 1950s under Jack Dragna, a member of The Commission. However, it was never as big as the New York or Chicago families. After Dragna's death, the family has been slowly losing power, with the Chicago Outfit now speaking for them on The Commission.

Joseph Baldie LoPiccolo (1918–1999) was an American criminal associated with the New York Gambino crime family and worked as a capo in Santo Trafficante, Jr.'s criminal organization. He was known for his involvement in narcotics trafficking.

The Italian American One Voice Coalition is a group across the nation that fights against prejudice towards Italian American heritage. They work through sharing knowledge, educating others, pushing for laws, and speaking up for their community. Their aim is to stand together against any unfair treatment, discrimination, or harmful stereotypes about Italian American culture and history. They're the only national organization like this for Italian Americans.

Operation Power Outage was a police operation aimed at catching and charging members of the Armenian American criminal group called Armenian Power in the US. This group is accused of doing illegal activities like racketeering, bank fraud, kidnappings, and selling drugs. Armenian Power, also known as AP-13, started 20 years ago in East Hollywood as a small street gang but has grown into a large criminal organization with over 200 members, operating internationally.

"The Sopranos" is a TV show about Tony Soprano, an Italian American mobster living in New Jersey. It focuses on his struggles to juggle his family life with his criminal activities. Throughout the series, we see Tony dealing with these challenges, often discussing them with his therapist, Dr. Melfi. The show also delves into the lives of Tony's family, mafia associates, and enemies, with characters like his wife Carmela and protege Christopher playing significant roles.

The Mexican Mafia, also known as La eMe, is a highly organized criminal group in the United States, formed by Mexican Americans. Despite its name, it didn't start in Mexico and operates solely within the U.S. prison system. Some gangs like MS-13 and Florencia 13 use the number 13 to show loyalty to the Mexican Mafia, as "M" is the 13th letter of the alphabet. Law enforcement considers La eMe the most influential gang in California's prisons. Currently, there are 155–300 official members of the Mexican Mafia, with around 990 associates aiding them in illegal activities, hoping to become full members.

The National Italian American Sports Hall of Fame is a nonprofit organization that celebrates outstanding American athletes with Italian heritage. It was established in 1977 by George Randazzo, who initially started the Italian American Boxing Hall of Fame to support local Catholic youth programs. Following a successful fundraising event honoring 23 former Italian American boxing champions, Randazzo expanded the concept into the National Italian American Sports Hall of Fame. It was originally located in Elmwood Park, Illinois. The inaugural induction ceremony in 1978 honored notable figures such as Lou Ambers, Eddie Arcaro, Charley Trippi, Gino Marchetti, Dom DiMaggio, Joe DiMaggio, and Vince Lombardi. Since then, over 230 Italian Americans have been inducted into this prestigious hall of fame.

The Barrow Gang, operating from 1932 to 1934, was a notorious American criminal group. They gained widespread notoriety as outlaws, robbers, and criminals during the Great Depression, traveling across the Central United States. Their actions were widely covered in the media during the "public enemy era." While they were known for bank robberies, they typically targeted small stores or gas stations. The gang was responsible for the deaths of at least nine police officers, along with other murders.

question: What was the position of Jean Baptiste Androuet du Cerceau under the man who was King of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth from 1573 to 1575?
pos: Jean Baptiste Androuet du Cerceau (1544/47–1590) was a French architect known for designing the Pont Neuf (1579), a bridge over the Seine River in Paris. He also served as the overseer of construction projects for kings Henri III and Henri IV, including work on the Louvre. Among his notable works are several mansions, such as the Hôtel d'Angoulême, the Hôtel de Lamoignon (1584), which now houses the Historical Library of the City of Paris, and the Hôtel de Mayenne located on rue St-Antoine in the Marais district. The Hôtel de Mayenne features distinct dormer windows arranged in a pattern on its steep roof and decorative elements like pediments above its main windows.

Henry III, born Alexandre Édouard de France, also known as Henryk Walezy in Polish and Henrikas Valua in Lithuanian, ruled as King of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth from 1573 to 1575 and as King of France from 1574 until he passed away in 1589. He belonged to the House of Valois, marking the end of their rule in France.
neg: Jean Androuet du Cerceau (circa 1585–1650) was a French architect, known as the son of Jean Baptiste Androuet du Cerceau, who was a prominent architect in Paris during his time.

Salomon de Brosse (1571 – 9 December 1626) was a significant French architect in the early 17th century. He had a big impact on François Mansart. Salomon was born in Verneuil-en-Halatte, Oise, to a well-known Huguenot family. His mother was the granddaughter of the designer Jacques I Androuet du Cerceau, and his father was the architect Jean de Brosse. Salomon started his architectural career in Paris in 1598 and later became the court architect in 1608.
Jacques Androuet du Cerceau, born in 1550 and passing away on September 16, 1614, was a French architect.

The Warsaw Confederation, signed on January 28, 1573, in Warsaw by the Polish national assembly, was a significant event in Poland and Lithuania's history. It was the first European document to grant religious freedoms, extending tolerance to nobles and free people within the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth. This marked the formal start of religious freedom in the region. Though it didn't eliminate all religious conflicts, it made the Commonwealth safer and more tolerant compared to other parts of Europe at the time, especially during the Thirty Years' War that followed.
Androuet du Cerceau was a French family known for their work as architects and designers during the 16th and early 17th centuries.

Jean Baptiste Assenede, also known as Jan Baptist Assenede or by his nickname Lantaren, was a Flemish painter during the Baroque period. He lived in Italy during the mid-17th century, having been born in Tournai in the early 1600s. Assenede was part of a group called the Bentvueghels, which included Dutch and Flemish artists working in Rome. Despite his membership in this group, none of his artworks are known to have survived to the present day.

Paul Androuet du Cerceau (1623–1710) was a French goldsmith and engraver who worked in Paris around 1610. It was once thought that he was the son of architect Jean Baptiste Androuet du Cerceau, known for building the Pont Neuf in Paris, but recent research suggests that Paul was actually the grandson of Jacques II Androuet du Cerceau.

Jacques I Androuet du Cerceau, also known as Du Cerceau, was a famous French designer during the 16th century. He worked on various designs like architecture, furniture, and metalwork, and he's credited with bringing Renaissance architecture to France. He collaborated with Pierre Lescot, Philibert Delorme, and Jean Bullant. Despite being called an architect and even appointed as the king's architect, he's best remembered for his series of engravings, which he started producing in 1549 from his printshop in Orléans.

question: Which American music star appeared as a guest in a Will & Grace episode called "Back Up, Dancer"?
pos: Janet Jackson, born on May 16, 1966, is an American singer, songwriter, dancer, and actress. She is recognized for her groundbreaking music, socially aware lyrics, and bold performances. With a career spanning over 30 years, Jackson has remained a significant influencer in popular culture.

"Back Up, Dancer" is the second episode of season seven of the TV show Will & Grace. It was written by Tracy Poust and Jon Kinnally and directed by James Burrows. The episode aired on NBC on September 23, 2004, and features guest stars Will Arnett, Bobby Cannavale, and Janet Jackson.
neg: The sixth season of It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia, an American comedy TV show, premiered on September 16, 2010, on FX. It had 14 episodes and ended on December 9, 2010, with a Christmas special that was initially meant for season 5 but aired in season 6. There was also an extra episode called "The Gang Gets Successful" (production code IP06004) made for this season, but it didn't air despite being featured in season 6 promotions. Later, scenes from it were used in a different episode for season 7 called "How Mac Got Fat."

"Glee: The Music, The Power of Madonna" is the first extended play (EP) by the cast of the TV show Glee. It features eight songs from the season one episode "The Power of Madonna," which pays tribute to Madonna. In 2009, Madonna granted Glee the rights to her music catalog. The show's producers created the episode, which included cover versions of Madonna's songs performed by the cast. The EP, released alongside the episode, shares the same name as the show: "Glee: The Music, The Power of Madonna."

The Surreal Life: Fame Games is a reality TV series on VH1, a spin-off of The Surreal Life. It brings together ten former contestants from the original show to compete in Las Vegas over ten weeks for a $100,000 prize from Golden Palace.net. Hosted by Robin Leach, the contestants face elimination in a game show called Back to Reality. In the first three weeks, losers move to the B-List area of the mansion, while winners stay in the A-List section. Later, teams compete, and the losing team sends three members to compete in Back to Reality, eliminating one from the competition.

"My Generation," hosted by Leeza Gibbons, is a vibrant lifestyle show that discusses topics ranging from health and finances to relationships and the joys of life. The show also features remarkable individuals who contribute positively to society by giving back. In a notable episode titled "Quiet Heroes," which was nominated for an Emmy Award, the program showcases stories about a running club established to assist homeless men in rebuilding their lives and African American Giving Circles.

Joey Miyashima, born on November 18, 1957, is a Japanese American actor known for his roles in television and film. He portrayed Oki Doki, Pee-wee Herman's Japanese pen pal, in an episode of Pee-Wee's Playhouse called "Accidental Playhouse." He also appeared in an episode of The Tracey Ullman Show titled "9 Minutes and 52 Seconds Over Tokyo" and its spin-off, The Simpsons, voicing Toshiro, the apprentice chef, in the episode "One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish." Miyashima played Principal Dave Matsui in the Disney Channel Original Movie "High School Musical" in 2006 and reprised the role in 2008. Additionally, he made a cameo appearance as a police officer in the 2009 Disney Channel Original Movie "Dadnapped."

"Let That Be Your Last Battlefield" is the fifteenth episode of the original American science fiction TV series. It aired on January 10, 1969, on NBC and was repeated on August 12, 1969. The episode was written by Oliver Crawford, based on a story by Gene L. Coon (writing as Lee Cronin) and directed by Jud Taylor. It started as an idea by Barry Trivers for the first season but was accepted for the third season due to budget cuts. The episode features guest stars Lou Antonio and Frank Gorshin, famous for his role as The Riddler in the Batman TV series.

Emily Bowker is a British actress known for her roles in TV shows like Neighbours, High School Musical: The TV Show, Upstairs Downstairs, Shameless, Torchwood, Holby City, Wire in the Blood, and The Bill. She has also performed in theater productions at various venues including The Birmingham Rep, West Yorkshire Playhouse, and Bristol Old Vic, among others. Additionally, she has appeared in BBC Radio 4 plays and the independent British film City Rats. Notably, in Torchwood, she played Ellie Johnson in an episode titled "Countrycide" in 2006. There's speculation that she may reunite with her co-star Vanessa Hudgens for romantic roles in the future.

Randy Travis's third studio album, "Old 8×10," came out on July 12, 1988, under Warner Bros. Records Nashville. The album featured hit singles like "Honky Tonk Moon," "Deeper Than the Holler," "Is It Still Over," and "Promises." Most of these singles, except "Promises," topped the Hot Country Songs charts in the late 1980s. The German version of the album included a bonus track called "Forever and Ever, Amen," marking Travis's first release in Germany. In January 1990, "Old 8×10" bagged Travis three American Music Awards for 'Favorite Country Male Artist,' 'Favorite Country Album,' and 'Favorite Country Single' for "Deeper Than the Holler."

question: What army did the namesake of the ship launched as the München in 1930 fight in during the American Revolutionary War?
pos: Friedrich Wilhelm August Heinrich Ferdinand Steuben, also known as Baron von Steuben, was a Prussian and American military officer. He played a significant role during the American Revolutionary War, serving as inspector general and major general of the Continental Army. Steuben is recognized for teaching the Continental Army essential military drills, tactics, and discipline, earning him the title of one of the fathers of the Continental Army. He authored "Regulations for the Order and Discipline of the Troops of the United States," which became the standard drill manual until the American Civil War. Additionally, he served as General George Washington's chief of staff in the war's later stages.

SS General von Steuben was a German ship used for carrying passengers, and later it was equipped with weapons by the Nazi German navy during World War II. The ship, originally named München but later changed to General von Steuben in honor of a famous German officer from the American Revolutionary War, was eventually renamed Steuben in 1938.
neg: HMS Swan was the first ship in a series of sloops called the Swan class, built with 14 guns in the 1760s and 1770s. Launched on November 21, 1767, she was later renamed HMS Explosion from 1779 to 1783 when she was used as a fireship. She saw action in both the American Revolutionary War and the French Revolutionary War before being decommissioned in 1801 and eventually sold off in 1814.

Vice-Admiral Robert Plampin (1762 – 14 February 1834) was a British Royal Navy officer in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. He served in various wars, including the American Revolutionary War, the French Revolutionary Wars, and the Napoleonic Wars. Plampin is most famous for leading the British colony of Saint Helena in the South Atlantic, where Napoleon Bonaparte was imprisoned. He came from a family with a Navy background and started his naval career at age 13 during the American Revolutionary War, mainly in the Caribbean. During the French Revolutionary Wars, he served on different ships with mixed success, experiencing a shipwreck and serving on land during sieges. After the Peace of Amiens, he commanded the ship HMS Powerful, operating successfully in the Atlantic and Indian Ocean. In 1816, after Napoleon's defeat and capture, Plampin was appointed to lead the squadron at the Cape of Good Hope, which also managed Saint Helena. He frequently visited the island and had several conversations with Napoleon.

HMS Vulture was a ship with 14 to 16 guns, part of the Swan class, and was launched for the Royal Navy on March 18, 1776. It played roles in the American Revolutionary War and the French Revolutionary War until the Navy sold it in 1802. Vulture gained notoriety when Benedict Arnold fled on it in 1780 after his failed attempt to betray the Continental Army's fortress at West Point, New York, to the British.

The USS Zeilin (APA-3) was originally named Silver State and was launched on March 19, 1921, in Newport News, Virginia. It was built for the United States Shipping Board (USSB). Later, it was renamed President Jackson and operated by commercial lines before being bought and used commercially again until it was parked in the late 1930s.

HMT Empire Windrush, originally known as MV Monte Rosa, started as a passenger and cruise ship launched in Germany in 1930. In the 1930s, she operated as a German cruise ship named Monte Rosa. During World War II, the German navy used her as a troopship. After the war, the United Kingdom acquired her as a prize of war and renamed her Empire Windrush. She served mainly as a troopship until March 1954 when a fire broke out, causing the ship to sink in the Mediterranean Sea and resulting in the loss of four crew members.

Tobago was a ship built in 1790. It was acquired by the British in 1793, likely as a prize during the French Revolutionary Wars. After trading with Tobago for some time, new owners bought it for whaling. Tobago completed two whaling trips to the East Coast of Africa before being sold again. It later served on two voyages as a slave ship and was last recorded in Lloyd's Register in 1806.

The USS Proton, initially called USS LST-1078, was a tank landing ship built by the U.S. Navy near the end of World War II. It played various roles, including transporting troops and cargo, and supplying electronic parts to the U.S. Pacific Fleet. After the Korean War, it was taken out of service.

The USA Army is the biggest part of the US Armed Forces and deals with operations on land. It's one of the seven uniformed services of the US, as stated in the US Constitution and Code. The modern USA Army traces its roots back to the Continental Army, formed in 1775 for the Revolutionary War. After that war, the US Army was created in 1784 to replace the Continental Army. The USA Army sees itself as continuing the legacy of the Continental Army since its inception in 1775.

question: The Church of the Guanche People was founded in the city that is on the most populated island of what larger area?
pos: Tenerife is the biggest and most crowded island among the seven Canary Islands. It's also the most populous island in Spain, covering an area of 2034.38 km2 with 898,680 people, making up 43 percent of the total population of the Canary Islands. Tenerife holds the title for being the largest and most densely populated island in the Macaronesia region.

The Church of the Guanche People, established in 2001 in San Cristóbal de La Laguna, Tenerife, aims to keep alive and share the traditional religion of the ancient Guanche people, who lived in the Canary Islands.
neg: Mactan, also known as Maktan, is a crowded island near Cebu Island in the Philippines, just a short distance away. It's part of Cebu Province and divided into two areas: Lapu-Lapu City and the municipality of Cordova. The island is separated from Cebu by the Mactan Channel, which you can cross using two bridges: the Marcelo Fernan Bridge and the Mactan-Mandaue Bridge. Mactan Island is about 65 square kilometers in size and home to around 470,000 people, making it the most densely populated island in the country. Together with the Olango Island Group, these areas are managed as one city and a municipality covering 75.25 square kilometers.

Bear Island, also known as Bjørnøya, is an inhabited island in Haram Municipality, located in Møre og Romsdal county, Norway. It's linked to the mainland by a man-made causeway, with the closest larger village being Søvik. To the east of Bear Island, between it and Søvik, is Terøya. These two islands are divided by the Bjørnøysundet strait. Historically, Bear Island was under the jurisdiction of Borgund municipality until it became part of Haram in 1965.

Loppa Church is a small white wooden church in the village of Loppa on the island of Loppa, which is not very populated. It was built in 1953 and can accommodate around 150 people. However, it's not used much because there are only a few residents on the island.

Vilsandi Island, located in the Baltic Sea off the coast of Estonia, is about 9 square kilometers in size and is the westernmost inhabited island in Estonia. The surrounding waters are shallow and rocky, posing dangers to passing ships. You can reach Vilsandi Island by boat, truck (if it has enough clearance), or by wading from Saaremaa. Most of the island is now part of Vilsandi National Park, established in 1910 as a bird reserve. It's an important nesting and breeding ground for migratory birds, so hunting is strictly prohibited. The park is a popular tourist spot, attracting not only Estonians but also increasing numbers of visitors from Finland.

Pung Island, also known as Pungdo in Korean, is a small island in the Yellow Sea. It's part of Ansan city in Gyeonggi Province, South Korea. It's about 74 km southwest of Seoul, the capital, and 24 km south of the bigger Daebudo island.

Guanche mummies are the dried-out bodies of the indigenous Guanche people from the Canary Islands. They were mostly made before the Spanish arrived in the 15th century. They used techniques like the Ancient Egyptians, but fewer mummies survive because many were stolen or destroyed.

Karlsøy Church, situated on Karlsøya island in Troms county, Norway, is a historic parish church built in 1854. Although it can accommodate around 570 people, it's no longer used regularly because the island it's on has become less populated. However, special services, like an annual summer service, are still held there occasionally.

Wheeling Island, located in the Ohio River and part of Wheeling city in Ohio County, West Virginia, is the most populated island in the area. According to the 2000 census, it had 3,142 residents, covering a land area of 1.514 km² (374 acres). In comparison, Neville Island in Pennsylvania is larger, spanning 3.4 km², but has a smaller population of 1,232 people.

question: What officially ended the first phase of the military conflict between the British Raj and the Emirate of Afghanistan from 1878 to 1880?
pos: The Treaty of Gandamak marked the end of the initial stage of the Second Anglo-Afghan War. Mohammad Yaqub Khan agreed to give certain border regions to Britain but kept control over Afghanistan itself.

During the Second Anglo–Afghan War from 1878 to 1880, the British Raj fought against Afghanistan when it was ruled by Sher Ali Khan. This was the second time Britain invaded Afghanistan. The war ended with Britain winning, and Afghanistan agreed to let Britain achieve its goals outlined in the Treaty of Gandamak. Most British and Indian soldiers left Afghanistan. Afghan tribes could keep their local customs but had to let Britain handle foreign relations. This helped create a buffer zone between the British Raj and the Russian Empire.
neg: The Emirate of Afghanistan was a country located between Central Asia and South Asia, which is now known as the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan. It came about after the Durrani Empire, with Dost Mohammed Khan establishing the Barakzai dynasty in Kabul. During this time, there was intense rivalry known as 'the Great Game' between the Russian Empire and the United Kingdom for control in Central Asia, while European colonial interests expanded in South Asia. Afghanistan also had conflicts with the Sikh Empire. British-led Indian forces invaded Afghanistan in 1842, resulting in heavy losses for the Afghans, but the invaders didn't achieve their initial goals. In the Second Anglo-Afghan War, the British defeated the Afghans again, temporarily taking control of Afghanistan's foreign affairs until Emir Amanullah Khan regained them with the signing of the Anglo-Afghan Treaty of 1919 after the Third Anglo-Afghan War.

Line 2 is the main north-south route of Suzhou Rail Transit. It is 26.557 kilometers long, with 6.57 kilometers being elevated, 19.146 kilometers underground, and 0.67 kilometers at ground level. The first phase of the line runs from Suzhou North Railway Station to Baodaiqiao South Station near Baodai Bridge, passing through five districts of Suzhou and serving 22 stations (17 underground and 5 elevated). The first phase of Line 2 began operating on December 28, 2013.

The Edict of Amboise, also called the Edict of Pacification, was signed on March 19, 1563, at the Château of Amboise. Catherine de' Medici, acting as regent for her son Charles IX of France, signed it. This treaty marked the end of the initial part of the French Wars of Religion and brought peace to France by ensuring religious rights and freedoms for the Huguenots.

The Working Group on Internet Governance (WGIG) was created by the United Nations after the 2003 World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) couldn't decide how to manage the Internet. The WSIS's first phase agreed to keep talking about Internet governance in a document they approved in December 2003. They wanted to make a decision about it at the second phase of the WSIS in Tunis in November 2005. So, during the first phase of the Summit, they asked the United Nations Secretary-General to set up the WGIG.

In the summer of 2010, there were really intense heat waves in many places like the United States, Kazakhstan, Mongolia, China, Hong Kong, North Africa, Europe, Canada, Russia, Indochina, South Korea, and Japan. These heat waves happened between May and August 2010. The first part of the heat waves, from April to June 2010, was caused by a mild El Niño. Even though it wasn't super extreme, it still broke temperature records in most of those places. The second part, from June to October 2010, was the worst. It was caused by a strong La Niña, which is a weather phenomenon. This La Niña was one of the strongest ever recorded. It also caused serious problems in Australia. These heat waves started in April 2010 when there were strong high-pressure systems over a lot of the affected areas in the Northern Hemisphere. They finally stopped in October 2010 when those high-pressure systems went away.

The Shagai Plateau, also known as Shagai Heights, is a flat area near the Khyber Pass with Fort Al Creator nearby. The path up to the Shagai Plateau starts near the entrance to the Khyber Pass from the southeast, close to Peshawar in modern-day Pakistan. During the Second Anglo-Afghan War that began in November 1878, the British set up a camp there because they were worried about Russian influence in Afghanistan. The initial part of the war ended in May 1879 with the Treaty of Gandamak, where the Afghans could govern internally but had to let the British control their foreign affairs. Fighting started again in September 1879 due to an uprising in Kabul against the British, and it ended decisively in September 1880 with the Battle of Kandahar.

The Afghan Civil War from 1996 to 2001 was part of the larger War in Afghanistan that started in 1978. In 1996, the Taliban took control of Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, and set up the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan. However, the internationally recognized government of Afghanistan was still the Islamic State of Afghanistan. Only Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, and the United Arab Emirates recognized the Taliban's Emirate. Ahmad Shah Massoud, the defense minister of the Islamic State of Afghanistan, formed the United Front (Northern Alliance) to oppose the Taliban. This alliance included various Afghan ethnic groups such as Tajiks, Uzbeks, Hazaras, Turkmens, some Pashtuns, and others. During the conflict, Pakistan provided military support to the Taliban, while Saudi Arabia offered financial assistance. Pakistan also sent its Frontier Corps and Army to fight against the United Front. Additionally, Al Qaeda supported the Taliban by sending fighters from Pakistan, Arab countries, and Central Asia.

In 1920, there was a battle called the Bukhara operation. It involved the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic and the Young Bukharians fighting against the Emirate of Bukhara. The conflict happened from August 28 to September 2, resulting in the defeat of the Bukhara Emirate. Afterward, the RSFSR took control, forming the Bukharan PSR.

question: The mass killing that took place at Oakland, California on April 2, 2012 was less deadly than the one that took place on October 1, 2015 in which state?
pos: The Oikos University shooting happened on April 2, 2012, when a person shot at people inside Oikos University, a Korean Christian college in Oakland, California, United States. Seven people died, and the shooter, One L. Goh, a former student, was arrested. It was one of the deadliest university shootings in U.S. history, ranking fourth after the Virginia Tech massacre, the University of Texas Clock Tower shooting, and the Umpqua Community College shooting. It's also the deadliest mass killing in Oakland's history.

On October 1, 2015, a tragic shooting took place at Umpqua Community College near Roseburg, Oregon, USA. Chris Harper-Mercer, a 26-year-old student at the college, fatally shot a professor and eight students in a classroom. Several others were also injured. When the police arrived, there was a brief exchange of gunfire, and Harper-Mercer ended his own life by shooting himself in the head after being wounded. This incident was the deadliest mass shooting in modern Oregon history.
neg: The Tezno massacre, which occurred near Maribor after World War II in Yugoslavia, involved the mass killing of prisoners of war from the Independent State of Croatia (NDH). Yugoslav Partisan units were responsible for these killings in May 1945, following the Bleiburg repatriations. The executions started on May 19 when the first prisoners arrived in the Tezno forest from nearby prison camps and lasted until May 26. The bodies were mostly buried in a long antitank trench spanning several kilometers, which the Yugoslav authorities later hid and kept secret.

The 1972 American League Championship Series happened from October 7 to 12, 1972. The Oakland Athletics, who had won 93 games and lost 62 during the season, faced off against the Detroit Tigers, who had a season record of 86 wins and 70 losses. They were competing for a spot in the 1972 World Series, and the A's won the series 3-2 after five games. The first two games were played at the Oakland Coliseum, while the remaining three were held at Tiger Stadium.

In 2007, a terrible event called the Mosul massacre happened in northern Iraq. On April 23rd, attackers hijacked a bus carrying workers from the Mosul Textile Factory. They separated Muslims and Christians from others on the bus based on their identity cards. Then, they took the remaining passengers, all Yazidis, to eastern Mosul. There, they forced them to lie down in front of a wall and shot them.

Established in 2012 by a group including Scott Cross and Sean Cross, the Los Cabos International Film Festival is an annual event held in mid-November in Los Cabos, Mexico. It was formerly known as the Baja International Film Festival. Subsequent editions took place in Cabo San Lucas in 2013 and back in Los Cabos in 2014, 2015, and 2016. The 2017 festival is scheduled for November 8-12. This festival, set in a top Mexican resort spot, attracts attendees and filmmakers globally.

In 2008, Robinson Ekspeditionen (also known as Robinson: Fans vs. Paradise) was the eleventh season of the Danish version of the show Expedition Robinson, which is like the Swedish version. It aired from September 1 to November 24, 2008. This season had a twist: contestants were either fans of Robinson or former contestants from Paradise Hotel. The fan tribe was called Tenga, and the Paradise tribe was called Sembilang. Throughout the season, there were several twists, like elimination challenges and tribe swaps. In the end, Daniela Hansen from Paradise Hotel 2006 won the season over Robinson fan Hilde Austad after a tiebreaking cointoss, as the jury vote ended in a 4-4 tie.

Gymnastics events happened during the 2002 Asian Games in Busan, South Korea. Artistic gymnastics were held from October 1 to October 5, while rhythmic gymnastics took place on October 8 and 9. Everything went down at Sajik Gymnasium.

The Račak massacre, also known as the Račak operation, occurred in January 1999 in the village of Račak in Kosovo. It involved the killing of 45 Kosovo Albanians by Serbian security forces. Despite calls for investigation, the Serbian government denied access to a war crimes prosecutor and claimed that all casualties were members of the Kosovo Liberation Army killed during combat with state security forces.

In early April of 1957, a series of tornadoes swept through the Southern United States from April 2nd to the 5th, causing significant damage and loss of life. At least 21 people were killed across three states, with over 72 tornadoes reported from Texas to Virginia. One particularly devastating tornado struck the densely populated Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area, claiming 10 lives and injuring over 200. This tornado was highly visible and extensively documented, making it one of the most observed tornadoes in history at the time. The footage of this tornado, captured by hundreds of people, still stands out today for its remarkable quality considering the technology of the 1950s. Damage from the Dallas tornado alone amounted to approximately $4 million in 1957. Additionally, other deadly tornadoes hit parts of Mississippi, Texas, and Oklahoma, including two F4 tornadoes in southern Oklahoma that killed five people on April 2nd. On April 4th, an F3 tornado struck rural Mississippi, claiming another life. There were also reports of possible tornado activity in Kentucky and Louisiana, causing damage and generating loud roaring noises.

question: When did the rock band that sang "All Join Hands" rise to prominence?
pos: "All Join Hands" is a song by the British rock band Slade. It came out in 1984 as the main single from their twelfth album, "Rogues Gallery." The band's lead singer, Noddy Holder, and bassist, Jim Lea, wrote the song. John Punter produced it. It reached No. 15 on the UK charts and stayed there for ten weeks.

Slade is a glam rock band from Wolverhampton, England. They became really popular in the early 1970s with 17 hits in the top 20 and six songs reaching number one on the UK Singles Chart. They're considered the most successful British group of the 1970s in terms of singles sales. They were also the first to have three songs debut at number one. All six of their chart-toppers were written by Noddy Holder and Jim Lea. By 2006, they had sold over 6.5 million singles in the UK, with their best-selling single, "Merry Xmas Everybody," selling over a million copies.
neg: "Join Hands" is the second album by the English post-punk band Siouxsie and the Banshees. It came out in September 1979 on Polydor Records. British music critics, such as those from Melody Maker, Sounds, NME, and Record Mirror, praised the album when it was released.

"The Joys of Living 2008–2010" is a collection of songs by the British rock band Sharks, released on April 5, 2011. It brings together tracks recorded during the band's first two years, including those from their Shallow Waters EP (2008), Common Grounds single (2009), and Show of Hands EP (2010), along with two new tracks, "Sweet Harness" and "The Joys of Living." This album marks the band's debut in the United States, where their previous releases were only available as imports. It was released through the band's label Velvet Scene, in collaboration with Rise Records. To promote the album, the band toured the United States with Social Distortion and Chuck Ragan in April and May 2011, and also performed at the 2011 Warped Tour.

Playground Twist is a song by the English post-punk band Siouxsie and the Banshees. It was released in 1979 by the record label Polydor as the only single from the band's second album, Join Hands, which was released in the same year.

Tom Morello is a Grammy-winning American rock guitarist known for his work with bands like Rage Against the Machine, Audioslave, Street Sweeper Social Club, and his folk alter-ego, The Nightwatchman. He began playing guitar in the mid-80s with the band Electric Sheep alongside future Tool guitarist Adam Jones. After graduating from Harvard University in 1986 with a degree in political science, he moved to Los Angeles and briefly worked as an aide to Senator Alan Cranston. Later, Jones also moved to L.A., where Morello introduced him and Maynard James Keenan to Danny Carey, forming Tool. In the late 80s, Morello replaced Mike Livingston in the band Lock Up, releasing their only album "Something Bitchin' This Way Comes" in 1986. In 1991, Morello left Lock Up to start a new band. Impressed by Zack de la Rocha's freestyle rapping, Morello invited him to join, along with Brad Wilk, who had previously auditioned as a drummer for Lock Up. After Zack persuaded his childhood friend Tim Commerford to join as the bass player, the lineup was complete.

"Rise Above" is an album by the indie rock band Dirty Projectors, which came out on September 11, 2007. It's led by Dave Longstreth, who took inspiration from Black Flag's album "Damaged" after not hearing it for 15 years. The album includes Longstreth on guitar and vocals, Amber Coffman on vocals and guitar, Brian McOmber on drums, Nat Baldwin on bass, and Susanna Waiche on vocals. Angel Deradoorian later joined the band, contributing on bass and vocals for the Rise Above tour. This album marks Dirty Projectors' transition from being solely Longstreth's project to a fully-fledged band.

The song "You're Gonna Go Far, Kid" by the Offspring, from their album "Rise and Fall, Rage and Grace" released in 2008, was a big hit. It was the second single from the album, following its radio debut on August 12, 2008, and official release on September 4, 2008. This track topped the Hot Modern Rock Tracks chart for 11 weeks, marking the band's third No.1 single on that chart, following "Come Out and Play" and "Hit That." It's also certified Gold by the RIAA, but oddly, the album itself wasn't certified by the RIAA. Additionally, it reached the No. 1 spot on KROQ's Top 106.7 songs of 2008 list. Overall, it's considered one of the Offspring's most successful songs of the 2000s. In the album, it's the third track, following "Trust in You."

The Rats were a punk band from Portland, Oregon, led by Fred Cole, who used to be in another band called The Lollipop Shoppe. Fred played guitar and sang, his wife Toody played bass and sang, and initially, Rod Rat was the drummer. Their music was a mix of punk rock with some country influences. Their first album, titled "The Rats," came out in 1980 on Fred's label, Whizeagle. After that, Rod Rat left the band and sadly died by suicide, but not before contributing to their second album in 1981. Sam Henry then joined as the drummer for a while before moving on to another band. Louis Samora took over drumming duties for their 1983 album, "In a Desperate Red." The band eventually split up, but they reunited briefly in 1984 to release a single under the name The Desperate Edge. Fred later formed a country band called Western Front, and he and Toody reunited in a band called Dead Moon. The Rats' albums have become rare and expensive, but in 2008, Mississippi Records reissued their first album on vinyl.

"Crackers – The Christmas Party Album" is a collection of songs by the British rock band Slade. It came out on November 18, 1985, and made it to No. 34 in the UK charts. In the same month, it got certified Gold by the BPI. Bassist Jim Lea produced most of the album, except for tracks like "All Join Hands," "Do You Believe in Miracles," "My Oh My," and "Run Runaway," which were handled by John Punter. The album features a mix of the band's previous hits, some re-recorded songs, and a few cover tracks.

question: Where is the company that owns thanKing Horse pub restaurant chain based ?
pos: Hungry Horse is a group of 225 pub-restaurants spread across England, Wales, and Scotland, which are owned by Greene King Brewery. Established in 1995, it focuses on providing affordable meals suitable for families and large gatherings.

Greene King is the biggest company in the UK that sells beer and runs pubs. They are located in Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk, England. Besides pubs, they also own restaurants and hotels. You can buy their stocks on the London Stock Exchange, and they are part of the FTSE 250 Index.
neg: Klenger Burger is a restaurant chain from Indonesia, headquartered in Jakarta, and managed by PT Kinarya Anak Negeri. They specialize in halal hamburgers tailored to Indonesian tastes. Their menu features a range of burgers, like the Raja Klenger (King Klenger), a massive 25 cm burger meant for seven people. Additionally, they offer pizza, grilled and fried duck and chicken, along with Indonesian snacks like rempeyek and emping.

VIP's, also known as Vip's, was a restaurant chain in the Western United States that operated from 1968 to the late 1980s. It was headquartered in Salem, Oregon, and had over 50 locations, making it the largest restaurant chain in Oregon at the time. VIP's was similar to Denny's, offering what was then called a "coffee shop" experience, now more commonly known as casual dining. Most of its restaurants were situated near highways and stayed open 24/7. At its peak, VIP's had branches in Oregon, Washington, Idaho, Nevada, and northern California.

Fazoli's is a fast casual restaurant chain that serves Italian-American food. It started in 1988 in Lexington, Kentucky, and is now owned by Seed Restaurant Group, Inc. They have over 200 locations across the US and want to open more in other countries. The restaurant focuses on Italian dishes, and Carl Howard is the president and CEO.

Todai is a restaurant chain with locations mainly in the United States. In 2016, it had 19 restaurants in the US, 7 in South Korea, and single locations in Hong Kong, Canada, Indonesia, Singapore, and Malaysia.

Chefette Restaurants is the biggest fast food chain in Barbados, with 14 locations across the island. They're famous for their broasted chicken meals and a local wrap called a roti, similar to a European Gyro. Chefette was started by Assad John Haloute, who moved from Trinidad to Barbados in 1971 and opened the first restaurant in 1972. Over the years, the chain expanded, and its trademark colors are yellow and purple.
The Works is a Canadian restaurant chain founded by Brad Fennema in Ottawa, Ontario, in 2001. Since then, it has expanded to include 27 locations throughout southern Ontario.
Piccadilly Pub was a group of laid-back eateries based in Massachusetts, USA. It all started in 1973 when William C. Martin opened the very first Piccadilly Pub in Westborough, Massachusetts.

The Chessels is a part of Bedminster, Bristol, stretching from the middle of Luckwell Rd to the old White Horse pub on West Street, with Chessel Street being the main road. The name "Chessel" comes from a field mentioned as far back as 1350. The White Horse pub was turned into apartments by 2013, but it was famously featured as the Nags Head pub in the BBC TV show Only Fools and Horses.

question: What is the uppermost age range for the sort of fiction written by Alexander Gordon Smith?
pos: Alexander Gordon Smith, born on February 27, 1979, in Norwich, England, writes books for kids and teenagers.

Young adult fiction, also known as YA literature, is books made for young readers. The exact age group can vary; some say it's for ages 12 to 18, while others, especially authors and readers of books for teens, see it as aimed at those from about 15 to their early 20s. It includes novels referred to as young adult novels, juvenile novels, teenage fiction, and more.
neg: "The Inventors" is a kids' book written by Alexander Gordon Smith and his brother Jamie Webb. It's about Nate and Cat, two young inventors who win a scholarship to work at Saint Solutions, a big skyscraper. They get to invent whatever they want under the supervision of Ebenezer Saint, the world's top inventor. But things go wrong when Saint won't let them leave, turning their dream opportunity into a struggle for survival and the fate of the world.

A Junior school is where kids aged 8 to 13 go for their primary education, after attending an Infant school from ages 5 to 7. Usually, both Infant and Junior schools are housed together in what's called a Primary school.

While Celtic Irish epics were written in prose, not verse, many believe that Irish fiction as we know it started in the 18th century. Still, elements of Early Irish prose, like exaggeration for humor, a fondness for lists, and a keen sense of satire, seem to have influenced later Irish novels. This article focuses on the history of Irish fiction in English. For Irish fiction written in Irish, check out Modern literature in Irish. For a broader look at Irish writing across all genres, see Irish literature.

Sugardaddyforme.com is a website where older individuals, called sugar daddies, meet younger ones, known as sugar babies, for dating. In 2013, it had over 4 million members and added around 2,000 new profiles each day. The site attracts about 1.5 million new visitors monthly. Women on the site are mostly between 18 and 45 years old, while men are typically aged between 25 and 60.

James Ogilvie was a Scottish church leader who lived in the late medieval period and died in 1518. When the Bishop of Aberdeen, William Elphinstone, passed away in 1514, his position became available. John Stewart, the Duke of Albany, suggested Ogilvy for the role. However, the Pope appointed Robert Forman to the position instead. Meanwhile, the canons of Aberdeen chose Alexander Gordon, possibly influenced by his cousin, Alexander Gordon, the 3rd Earl of Huntly.

George Gordon, who lived in the 16th century, was a Scottish church leader. His father was Alexander Gordon, who was a bishop in Galloway, and his brother John also held the same position. He was related to the earls of Huntly as a cousin, through his great-grandfather Alexander Gordon, who was the 3rd Earl of Huntly.

Grant Gordon Smith, born on May 5, 1980, in Irvine, is a Scottish midfielder in football. He's the son of Gordon Smith, who used to play for Rangers and Brighton & Hove Albion and was also the former chief executive of the Scottish Football Association.

Escape from Furnace is a series of novels by Alexander Gordon Smith. In the United States, it's called Escape from Furnace, while in the United Kingdom, it's simply called Furnace. The story follows a teenager named Alex Sawyer, who is imprisoned in the fictional London prison called Furnace Penitentiary. The series includes Lockdown, Solitary, Death Sentence, Fugitives, and Execution. Smith also wrote a novella called The Night Children, which explores the backstory of Warden Cross, a character from the series, and his encounter with Alfred Furnace, the mysterious founder of the prison, during World War II in the Belgian woods.

question: What is the birthday of the actress who was the Duchess in "The Revengers Tragedy"?
pos: Revengers Tragedy is a movie based on the play The Revenger's Tragedy from 1606, commonly attributed to Thomas Middleton. Directed by Alex Cox and written for the screen by Frank Cottrell Boyce, both from Liverpool. The film features Christopher Eccleston as Vindice, who seeks revenge, Derek Jacobi as the villainous Duke, Eddie Izzard as his lustful son Lussurioso, Diana Quick as the Duchess, Andrew Schofield as Vindice's brother Carlo (similar to the play's Hippolito), Carla Henry as his virtuous sister Castiza, and Marc Warren and Justin Salinger as the Duchess's sons Supervacuo and Ambitioso.
Diana Marilyn Quick, born on November 23, 1946, is an actress from England.
neg: Emily Jewell, an English actress, studied at the Central School of Speech and Drama. She has acted in plays like Look Back in Anger (as Alison) and The Duchess of Malfi (as the Duchess) with the Twister Theatre Company, and she's been in the movie The Duchess too.

Appius and Virginia is a tragic play written by John Webster, possibly with contributions from Thomas Heywood, in the early 17th century. It's not as well-known as Webster's other tragedies, like The White Devil and The Duchess of Malfi.

The Grand Duke's Official Birthday, also called Luxembourgish National Day, is the yearly celebration of Luxembourg's national holiday. It happens on June 23rd, even though it's not the real birthday of any Luxembourg ruler. If the ruler is a woman, it's called the Grand Duchess' Official Birthday.

"The Duchess of Padua" is a play written by Oscar Wilde. It's a five-act melodramatic tragedy set in Padua, written in blank verse. Oscar Wilde originally penned it for the actress Mary Anderson in early 1883 while in Paris, but she declined the role. It wasn't until January 26, 1891, that the play premiered at the Broadway Theatre in New York City, under the title "Guido Ferranti." Despite its initial run of three weeks, it hasn't been frequently performed or analyzed since then.

"The Revengers' Comedies" is a play written by Alan Ayckbourn. It's a long piece, lasting over five hours, meant to be shown in two parts. The title is a nod to "The Revenger's Tragedy." Ayckbourn drew inspiration from his passion for movies, especially Alfred Hitchcock's "Strangers on a Train," which is referenced in the play.

Grace Mae Brown, a skirt factory worker from America, was murdered in 1906, sparking national interest. Her life story influenced the character Roberta Alden in Theodore Dreiser's 1925 novel, "An American Tragedy," and Jennifer Donnelly's 2003 novel, "A Northern Light." The murder is detailed in two non-fiction books from 1986: "Adirondack Tragedy: The Gillette Murder Case of 1906" by Joseph W. Brownell and Patricia A. Wawrzaszek, and "Murder in the Adirondacks: An American Tragedy Revisited" by Craig Brandon. Shelley Winters received an Academy Award nomination for portraying a character inspired by Grace Brown, renamed 'Alice Tripp,' in the 1951 film "A Place in the Sun," which was loosely based on Dreiser's novel.
Revengers Tragedy is a soundtrack album released in 2003 by Chumbawamba for the movie based on the 1606 play The Revenger's Tragedy.

Revengers Tragedy is a song by the British anarcho-punk band Chumbawamba. They made it in 2003 as the soundtrack for Alex Cox's movie, also called Revengers Tragedy. They released it as a single on their own label, MUTT Records.

question: Which film starring Patrick Tatten is based on a book written by Steve Lopez?
pos: Patrick James Bolger Tatten, born on January 21, 1981, is a well-known American actor and producer. He has starred in popular films like "Dirty Deeds," "The Good German," and "The Soloist," as well as appearing in the TV series "Boystown" on OutTV.

"The Soloist" is a movie from 2009 directed by Joe Wright. It stars Jamie Foxx and Robert Downey Jr. The film tells the true story of Nathaniel Ayers, a musician who suffered from schizophrenia and ended up homeless. The script, written by Susannah Grant, is adapted from the book "The Soloist" by Steve Lopez.
neg: "Njan Steve Lopez" is a Malayalam movie from 2014, directed by Rajeev Ravi and produced by Jar Pictures, M.R Filmworks, and Media Mill. The story takes place in Thiruvananthapuram city and features Farhaan Faasil and newcomer Ahaana Krishna. It premiered on August 8, 2014.

Alencier Ley Lopez is an actor from India who primarily works in Malayalam movies and theater. He started his acting career with the Malayalam film "Daya" in 1998. He gained fame for his roles in movies like "Annayum Rasoolum" (2013), "Njan Steve Lopez" (2013), and "Maheshinte Prathikaaram" (2016).

Can't Buy Me Love is a movie from 1987 about a high school nerd in Tucson, Arizona, who pays a cheerleader $1,000 to be his girlfriend for a month. It stars Patrick Dempsey and Amanda Peterson and was directed by Steve Rash. The title is inspired by a Beatles song.

"The Fear Merchants" is the second episode of the fifth series of the 1960s British TV show "The Avengers." It stars Patrick Macnee and Diana Rigg, with guest appearances by Patrick Cargill, Brian Wilde, Annette Carell, and Garfield Morgan. The episode aired on ABC on January 21, 1967, and was directed by Gordon Flemyng, with the script written by Philip Levene.

Farhaan Faasil is an actor in Indian movies, mainly in Malayalam films. He started his acting career in 2014 with the movie Njan Steve Lopez, which was directed by Rajeev Ravi. He is also known as the younger brother of actor Fahadh Faasil.

"The Three Lives of Thomasina" is a British fantasy movie from 1963. It's about a cat that impacts a family's life. The main actors include Patrick McGoohan, Susan Hampshire, Matthew Garber, and Karen Dotrice. The story is based on a novel called "Thomasina, the Cat Who Thought She Was God," written by Paul Gallico in 1957. The movie was directed by Don Chaffey and filmed in Scotland and England. It's been shown on TV and is available on VHS and DVD.

Jennifer Lopez, the American entertainer, penned the book "True Love" (in Spanish, "Amor Verdadero"). It was released as a hardcover edition in both English and Spanish on November 4, 2014, by Celebra, a branch of the Penguin Group. Part of the sales proceeds from "True Love" support the Lopez Family Foundation, a nonprofit co-founded by Lopez, aiming to enhance the health and welfare of women and children.

Third and Indiana is a novel by Steve Lopez that delves into the lives of people linked to 14-year-old Gabriel Santoro. Set in the crime-ridden streets of Philadelphia's Badlands, it sheds light on the challenges faced in this area. The book brought attention to the real intersection of Third Street and Indiana Avenue, notorious for its drug trade. With an initial print run of 50,000 copies in 1994, it marked Lopez's debut as a novelist.

question: Are Skeptical Inquirer and The Progressive Populist both tabloid-style magazines?
pos: The Progressive Populist is a tabloid-style magazine that comes out twice a month. It started in 1995 and is headquartered in Storm Lake, Iowa, with editorial offices in Manchaca, Texas. James M. Cullen is the editor, Art Cullen is the managing editor, and John Cullen is the publisher.

Skeptical Inquirer is an American magazine released every two months by the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry (CSI) with the tagline: The Magazine for Science and Reason.
