The EAFF E-1 Football Championship is a soccer tournament in East Asia for national teams from the East Asian Football Federation (EAFF). Both men's and women's national teams compete in this event at the same time.

The EAFF E-1 Football Championship, previously called the East Asian Football Championship and the EAFF East Asian Cup for certain years, is a soccer tournament for men in East Asia. It's organized by the East Asian Football Federation (EAFF). Before the EAFF was established in 2002, there was the Dynasty Cup, which was kind of like a precursor to this championship. It involved the top four teams from East Asia. Both men and women have their own separate competitions, with the men's tournament starting in 2003 and the women's in 2005. In 2005, there was also a combined points system where the scores of both the men's and women's teams were added together, excluding qualifiers.

Geraldine Geri Donnelly, born on November 30, 1965, is a retired soccer player from Canada. She played as a midfielder and competed for Canada in the FIFA Women's World Cup in 1995 and 1999. She was honored as the Canadian Player of the Year in 1996 and 1999. Donnelly was also on the Canadian team that won the CONCACAF Women's Championship in 1998. In recognition of her achievements, she was inducted into the Canadian Soccer Hall of Fame in 2014.

The 1929-30 British Home Championship was a football tournament played among the UK nations. In 1930, it faced competition from the newly established FIFA World Cup held in Uruguay. The UK teams weren't part of FIFA due to disagreements over professionalism in other regions. They chose not to participate in the World Cup, believing the foreign teams weren't strong enough. It's interesting to consider what might have happened if they had joined, especially as global football was evolving. The England team, dominant in the 1930 championship, had suffered their first loss to a foreign team (Spain) the previous year. Scotland, usually strong in the championship, was also unprepared, having played few international games outside the UK and facing heavy defeats against Austria and Italy in 1931.

The 2016 L'Alcúdia International Football Tournament, held in July and August of that year, was unique because it was the first time it only included youth teams from different countries. In the past, the tournament included both national teams and club teams.

The Togo women's national football team, also known as the Équipe du Togo féminine de football in French, has been representing Togo in international women's football since 2006. They are overseen by the Fédération Togolaise de Football (FTF), which is the organization in charge of football in Togo. The team has only participated in five FIFA-recognized matches, all of which took place in 2006. Currently, the team is led by manager Paul Zoungbede, and their home stadium is the Stade de Kégué, located in Lomé.

The Women's Nordic Football Championship was a yearly international football tournament where women's national teams from Nordic countries competed. It ran from 1974 to 1982. Finland, Denmark, and Sweden were the initial competitors, with Norway joining in 1978. However, Iceland and the Faroe Islands didn't participate in the competition.

question: Rock Springs is a collection of short stories by an author born in what year?
pos: Richard Ford, an American author born on February 16, 1944, is famous for writing novels like "The Sportswriter" and its follow-ups "Independence Day," "The Lay of the Land," and "Let Me Be Frank With You." He's also known for his collection of short stories titled "Rock Springs," which includes many stories often featured in anthologies.
"Rock Springs," written by Richard Ford and published in 1987, is a book of short stories. It mostly focuses on how troubled parents influence the lives of young male characters.
neg: Vacuum Diagrams is a collection of sci-fi short stories by British author Stephen Baxter. It's part of the Xeelee Sequence novels and explores humanity's history within this universe. The stories, while standalone, are linked through a framework story called "Eve," where a character named Jack Raoul witnesses events guided by a god-like being. "Eve" introduces each section, with interludes between eras, and concludes its own plot. The collection won the Philip K. Dick Award in 1999.

Mai Al-Nakib wrote The Hidden Light of Objects, a collection of connected short stories released by Bloomsbury in 2014. This collection was the first of its kind to win the Edinburgh International Book Festival's 2014 First Book Award. Her short stories have been featured in Ninth Letter, The First Line, and the anthology Novel of the World. Additionally, two of her stories received honorable mentions in Glimmer Train competitions. The Hidden Light of Objects marks her debut collection of short stories.

The Rest of the Robots is a book by Isaac Asimov, first published in 1964. It contains eight short stories and two full-length novels about robots with positronic brains. These stories are part of the Robot series and mostly occur in the Foundation universe. Asimov titled the collection "The Rest of the Robots" because another book, "I, Robot," which also featured robot stories, was re-released the year before. None of the short stories in this collection were in "I, Robot," but they were later included in another book called "The Complete Robot." The two novels about Elijah Baley were also released separately.

"Ambulance" is a book of short stories by Norwegian writer Johan Harstad, released in 2002. It includes eleven interconnected tales where characters from one story reappear in others, sometimes from different perspectives. The common thread is an ambulance navigating through an unnamed city.

J. J. Syvrud, born on May 10, 1977, used to play football as a linebacker for the New York Jets in the NFL. He was chosen by the Jets in the seventh round of the 1999 NFL Draft. Before that, he played college football at Jamestown College and went to Rock Springs High School in Wyoming.

Richard Marsh, born as Richard Bernard Heldmann, was an English author known for his popular works during the late 19th century and the Edwardian period. His most famous work, "The Beetle," a supernatural thriller novel, was published in 1897, the same year as Bram Stoker's "Dracula," and initially gained even more popularity. "The Beetle" remained in print until 1960. Marsh wrote nearly 80 fiction books and many short stories across various genres including horror, crime, romance, and humor. Recently, some of his works, starting with "The Beetle" in 2004, have been republished. Marsh's grandson, Robert Aickman, was also a notable writer of strange short stories.

Richard Henderson Honaker, born in 1951, is a lawyer from Rock Springs, Wyoming. He was chosen by U.S. President George W. Bush on March 19, 2007, to be one of three U.S. District Judges for the District of Wyoming. He received a top rating from the American Bar Association. Honaker was recommended to Bush by U.S. Senator Craig L. Thomas of Wyoming, who passed away three months later. Despite not receiving a Senate confirmation vote, he would have replaced Judge Clarence A. Brimmer in Cheyenne if he had been confirmed. However, the inauguration of Barack Obama ended his nomination, and Nancy D. Freudenthal was later confirmed for the position.

Summary: "A Good Man Is Hard to Find and Other Stories," also known as "The Artificial Nigger and Other Tales" in England, is a collection of short stories by Flannery O'Connor, published in 1955. The stories cover various themes, including baptism, serial killers, and human greed. Many stories feature violent scenes prompting characters to undergo spiritual changes, often with Catholic themes surrounding life and death. For example, in "A Good Man Is Hard To Find," a character suggests that constant threat would have made someone a better person.

question: Folie à Deux is a studio album by the American rock band formed in which city?
pos: "Folie à Deux," which means "A Madness Shared by Two" in French, is the fourth album by Fall Out Boy. Produced by Neal Avron, it was recorded from July to September 2008 in Hollywood, California. It came out on December 16, 2008, on Island Records, after being postponed from November 4 to avoid clashing with the US presidential election. Lead vocalist and guitarist Patrick Stump composed the music, while bassist Pete Wentz wrote the lyrics. The band saw this album as their most collaborative effort yet.

Fall Out Boy is a rock band from Illinois, formed in 2001. The band includes lead vocalist Patrick Stump, bassist Pete Wentz, guitarist Joe Trohman, and drummer Andy Hurley. They started in Chicago's punk scene and formed as a side project of their hardcore bands. They went through a few drummers before settling on Hurley and released their first album, "Take This to Your Grave," in 2003. The album gained them a dedicated fanbase and influenced pop punk music in the 2000s.
neg: Fall Out Boy's song "What a Catch, Donnie" is from their album Folie à Deux (2008). It was released on iTunes on October 14, 2008, before the album came out, and it did well on charts in the US and Canada. The song has guest appearances from other musicians who sing lines from previous Fall Out Boy songs. Pete Wentz, the bassist and lyricist, wrote it as a reminder of Patrick Stump, the vocalist and guitarist. It's one of their rare slow songs. They performed it live on Late Night with Jimmy Fallon.

Daughtry, the first album by the American rock band Daughtry, led by Chris Daughtry from American Idol's fifth season, came out on November 21, 2006, under RCA Records. It holds the record for the quickest-selling debut rock album in Soundscan history and remains the band's top-selling record.

The Steve Miller Band, formed in 1966 in San Francisco, California, is led by Steve Miller on guitar and vocals. They're famous for their 1970s hits often heard on classic rock radio and earlier acid rock albums. Miller moved to San Francisco from his first band to start the Steve Miller Blues Band, which later became the Steve Miller Band. They signed with Capitol Records in 1967 and released their debut album, "Children of the Future," in February 1968. Their album "Greatest Hits 1974–78," released in 1978, sold over 13 million copies. They've continued to make albums and toured with Journey in 2014. In 2016, Steve Miller was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as a solo artist.

The song "Headfirst Slide into Cooperstown on a Bad Bet" is by the American rock band Fall Out Boy from their fourth studio album, Folie à Deux (2008). It was first released as a digital single on iTunes on October 7, 2008, as part of the lead-up to the album's release. The song then hit modern rock radio in the United States on June 15, 2009.

Here's a simpler version:

"Welcome to the New Administration" was a popular campaign and mixtape by Pete Wentz, the bass guitarist of Fall Out Boy. He launched it on August 18, 2008, to promote the band's fourth album, Folie à Deux. The mixtape, released on November 4, 2008, featured songs and demos from Fall Out Boy and other artists from Decaydance.

The Believers Never Die Tour Part Deux was a two-month concert tour led by Fall Out Boy in 2009 to support their album Folie à Deux. It ran from April 3 to May 17 and featured opening acts like Cobra Starship, All Time Low, Metro Station, and Hey Monday. Some dates included 50 Cent instead of Metro Station. The tour's name was inspired by Fall Out Boy's 2004 Believers Never Die tour. It marked their last headlining tour before a hiatus in late 2009, and they later released the Believers Never Die - Greatest Hits album with the same name.

"I Don't Care" is a popular song by the American rock band Fall Out Boy, released as the lead single from their fourth studio album "Folie à Deux" in 2008. It premiered on the band's website and mozes.com on September 3, 2008, and hit the radio waves on September 16. The song quickly gained popularity and was certified platinum by the RIAA, indicating sales of over one million units, with 500,000 copies sold in just four months. While it reached No. 21 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart in the United States, it didn't match the success of the band's previous single "This Ain't a Scene, It's an Arms Race," which reached No. 2 on the charts in 2007. "I Don't Care" also performed well on Modern Rock and Pop radio stations, reaching No. 21 on Billboard's Hot Modern Rock Tracks and No. 22 on Pop Songs.

"America's Suitehearts" is a song by Fall Out Boy, released as the second single from their fourth album, "Folie à Deux" (2008). It was first available on iTunes before the album's release and then sent to radio on January 20, 2009. The band included a demo/snippet of the song titled "America's Sweethearts" on their mixtape, "Welcome to the New Administration," as part of their promotional campaign. The music video premiered on January 1, 2009, on The N channel. Bassist and lyricist Pete Wentz explained that the song explores society's obsession with celebrities, while vocalist/guitarist Patrick Stump composed the music.

question: This work of literature _______ , known by its Greek title Oedipus Tyrannus was argued by Sigmund Freud to be one of the greatest works of world literature in his 1928 article.
pos: Sigmund Freud wrote an article called "Dostoevsky and Parricide" for a book about Fyodor Dostoyevsky's novel The Brothers Karamazov, published in 1928. Freud suggests that it's not random that many famous stories, like Oedipus Rex, Hamlet, and The Brothers Karamazov, focus on killing one's father. He connects Dostoevsky's interest in this theme to his epilepsy.

Oedipus Rex, also known as Oedipus the King, is a tragic play by Sophocles, performed in Athens around 429 BC. Originally, the Greeks just called it Oedipus, as mentioned by Aristotle. The title was later changed to Oedipus Tyrannus to tell it apart from another play called Oedipus at Colonus. Back then, "tyrant" meant a ruler, without necessarily being negative.
neg: Summary: "The Interpretation of Dreams" is a book by Sigmund Freud from 1899 where he talks about how dreams can reveal the unconscious mind and introduces the idea of the Oedipus complex. Freud revised the book multiple times, adding more detail about dream symbolism in later editions. He once said that achieving such insight is rare in one's lifetime.

"Freud: A Life for Our Time" is a biography of Sigmund Freud, written by historian Peter Gay in 1988. Gay incorporated new information that had surfaced since the release of Ernest Jones' biography in 1953. While some people have praised the book, others, particularly those skeptical of psychoanalysis, have criticized it.

Since it debuted in the early 1600s, Hamlet has been Shakespeare's most famous and widely studied play. The main character, Hamlet, was crucial in Sigmund Freud's theory about the Oedipus complex, impacting modern psychology. Its influence extends beyond psychology to literature, as noted by Foakes, who highlights how Hamlet's name has become synonymous with a particular outlook on life, a rare occurrence in literature.

"Freud and Philosophy: An Essay on Interpretation" is a book by philosopher Paul Ricœur from 1965, discussing Sigmund Freud's ideas. It's sometimes compared to other works like Jürgen Habermas's "Knowledge and Human Interests" from 1968. While some people have praised "Freud and Philosophy," others disagree with Ricœur's interpretation of Freud's theories.

"The Assault on Truth: Freud's Suppression of the Seduction Theory" is a book by Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson. In it, Masson argues that Sigmund Freud intentionally hid his early idea, called the seduction theory, which suggested that sexual abuse in infancy causes hysteria. Masson believes Freud did this because he couldn't accept the idea that children suffer sexual abuse within their own families. Masson came to this conclusion while working at the Sigmund Freud Archives and had access to Freud's unpublished letters. The book was first published in 1984 and has seen multiple revised editions since then.

"Why Freud Was Wrong" by Richard Webster is a book that criticizes Sigmund Freud and psychoanalysis. Webster argues that Freud was revered like a Messiah and that psychoanalysis is not a genuine science but rather a continuation of religious traditions. He supports Gilbert Ryle's views against mentalist philosophies and critiques other authors' treatment of Freud. While some praise the book as brilliant and definitive, others criticize its scholarship and arguments. This work contributed to the ongoing debate known as the Freud wars.

Peter J. Swales, born in 1948, is a Welsh historian who focuses on psychoanalysis and has previously worked as an assistant to the Rolling Stones. He's known for his writings about Sigmund Freud, where he's uncovered the real identities of some of Freud's early patients who were only known by their fake names. His work was praised in a 1998 article in The New Republic for its investigative depth over the past 25 years. Swales is also mentioned in the book "In The Freud Archives" alongside Freud Archives director Kurt R. Eissler and psychoanalyst Jeffrey Masson, detailing their actions discussed in two New Yorker articles from 1984, which led Masson to sue the magazine and its writer Janet Malcolm for libel, though unsuccessfully.

"The Life and Work of Sigmund Freud" is a biography by Ernest Jones, covering the life and impact of Sigmund Freud. Originally released in three volumes in the 1950s, it was condensed into one volume in 1961. Despite initial success, some criticize Jones for portraying Freud too positively, though the biography remains a classic.

question: Katherine Waterston and Chrisann Brennan has what in common?
pos: Chrisann Brennan, an American painter and writer born on September 29, 1954, wrote a book called "The Bite in the Apple" about her time with Steve Jobs, the co-founder of Apple. She is also the mother of Lisa Brennan-Jobs.

Katherine Waterston, born on March 3, 1980, is an American actress known for her roles in various films. She started her career with a debut in "Michael Clayton" in 2007 and went on to appear in supporting roles in movies like "Robot & Frank," "Being Flynn" (both in 2012), and "The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Her" (2013). One of her notable roles was as Shasta Fay Hepworth in Paul Thomas Anderson's "Inherent Vice" in 2014. In 2015, she portrayed Chrisann Brennan in "Steve Jobs." Waterston gained more attention for her starring roles in "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them" (2016) and its sequel, which serves as a prequel to Ridley Scott's 1979 film "Alien."
neg: "Manhattan Romance" is a romantic comedy movie made in 2015. It was directed and written by Tom O'Brien. The film features actors like Gaby Hoffmann, Katherine Waterston, Zach Grenier, Caitlin FitzGerald, and Louis Cancelmi.

Inherent Vice is a movie from 2014 directed by Paul Thomas Anderson. It's a mix of noir, comedy, and drama. The story, based on a book by Thomas Pynchon, follows a hippie private investigator named Larry Doc Sportello in 1970s Los Angeles. He gets caught up in the city's criminal scene while looking into three connected cases tied to the disappearance of his ex-girlfriend and her rich boyfriend. The film stars Joaquin Phoenix, Josh Brolin, Owen Wilson, and other notable actors.

Lisa Nicole Brennan-Jobs, an American writer, is the daughter of Apple co-founder Steve Jobs and Chrisann Brennan. Initially, there was uncertainty about her paternity, leading to a legal dispute and media coverage during Apple's early years. However, they later resolved their differences, and Brennan-Jobs pursued a career in journalism and magazine writing.

Alien: Covenant, released in 2017, is a science fiction horror film directed by Ridley Scott. It's a sequel to Prometheus (2012) and the sixth movie in the Alien series. Michael Fassbender, Katherine Waterston, Billy Crudup, Danny McBride, and Demián Bichir star in the film, which follows the crew of a colony ship as they land on a mysterious planet and encounter something horrifying.

Logan Lucky is a 2017 American heist comedy film directed by Steven Soderbergh. It's about the Logan family, who are down on their luck and decide to rob the Charlotte Motor Speedway. The movie stars Channing Tatum, Adam Driver, and others. Soderbergh, who had retired, returned to direct the film and released it independently through his company, Fingerprint Releasing.

The Current War is a 2017 film directed by Alfonso Gomez-Rejon and written by Michael Mitnick. It stars Benedict Cumberbatch, Michael Shannon, Nicholas Hoult, Tom Holland, Katherine Waterston, and Tuppence Middleton. The film portrays the rivalry between Thomas Edison and George Westinghouse known as the War of Currents.

In 2016, director David Yates brought us "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them," a fantasy film that serves as a prequel to the Harry Potter series. J.K. Rowling, in her first venture into screenwriting, produced and wrote the film, drawing inspiration from her book of the same name published in 2001. The movie stars Eddie Redmayne as Newt Scamander, alongside a supporting cast including Katherine Waterston, Dan Fogler, Alison Sudol, Ezra Miller, Samantha Morton, Jon Voight, Carmen Ejogo, Ron Perlman, and Colin Farrell. This film marks the beginning of the Fantastic Beasts series and is the ninth installment in J.K. Rowling's broader Wizarding World franchise, which originated with the Harry Potter films.

The book "The Bite in the Apple: A Memoir of My Life with Steve Jobs" is written by Chrisann Brennan. She's an American painter who dated Steve Jobs in high school, worked at Apple Inc. before it became a big company, and is the mother of Jobs' first child, Lisa Brennan-Jobs. It came out on October 29, 2013.

question: The voice of Homer Simpson also voices what alien character in the television series "The Simpsons"?
pos: Daniel Louis Castellaneta, born on October 29, 1957, is an American actor known for his work as Homer Simpson on the TV show The Simpsons. He's also a voice actor, comedian, and screenwriter, lending his voice to various other characters on the show like Grampa Simpson, Barney Gumble, and Krusty the Clown, among others.

Kang and Kodos are two fictional characters from The Simpsons. Kang is voiced by Harry Shearer, and Kodos by Dan Castellaneta. They're aliens from a made-up planet called Rigel VII and usually show up in the Treehouse of Horror episodes. They've been in every one of those episodes, either as the main story or just making a quick appearance. They're always up to no good, trying to take over Earth and make humans their slaves.
neg: Damon Dark is an Australian TV and web series centered around a brave investigator who delves into UFO sightings and other mysterious events. Created by Australian filmmaker Adrian Sherlock, the series follows Damon Dark, who became fascinated with aliens after a close encounter in his youth. He collaborates with both secret agents and friendly extraterrestrials, notably Vincent Kosmos, an alien time traveler, and Trans-Dimensional Control, an alien law enforcement agency. The character of Damon Dark has been portrayed by various actors and has appeared in a TV series, a novel, and a long-running web series. He's known for his black attire, extensive knowledge of aliens, intelligence, idealistic morals, and witty humor. The series also features Damon's loyal friend Gary Sutton, played by actor Robert Trott. Starting in 1999, Damon Dark began as a weekly show on Melbourne's Community TV 31, with roots dating back to 1990. It later transitioned into a web series on YouTube, inspiring spin-offs like "The Young Damon Dark Adventures" and "Vincent Kosmos," created by Chris Heaven, an Italian actor and musician, focusing on a rebellious alien friend of Damon's.

Santa's Little Helper is a character in The Simpsons, the family's pet greyhound. He first appears in the show's debut episode, the 1989 Christmas special "Simpsons Roasting on an Open Fire." In this episode, his owner leaves him after he loses a race. Homer and Bart Simpson, hoping to earn some Christmas present money at the racetrack, see this and choose to take the dog home with them.

Ned Flanders, Jr. is a character on The Simpsons, voiced by Harry Shearer. He debuted in the first episode, "Simpsons Roasting on an Open Fire." Ned lives next door to the Simpsons and is known for his upbeat attitude, which annoys Homer. He's a devout Christian with a seemingly perfect family and is one of the nicest and most caring people in Springfield, making him a respected member of the community.

"Do the Bartman" is a song featured on The Simpsons album "The Simpsons Sing the Blues" released in 1990. Nancy Cartwright, who voices Bart Simpson, sings the lead vocals, with backing vocals by Michael Jackson and additional vocals by Dan Castellaneta, who voices Homer Simpson. The song was produced and written by Bryan Loren and was released as a single on November 20, 1990.

Abraham Jedediah Simpson II, also known as Grampa, is a fictional character from the TV show The Simpsons. He first showed up in an episode called "Grampa and the Kids" on The Tracey Ullman Show. Voiced by Dan Castellaneta, he's Homer Simpson's dad and Bart, Lisa, and Maggie's grandpa. In Entertainment Weekly's 1000th issue, Grampa was picked as the ideal grandpa for the perfect TV family.

"Homer to the Max" is the thirteenth episode of the tenth season of The Simpsons, which first aired on February 7, 1999, on Fox. In this episode, Homer finds out that a TV show called Police Cops features a character with the same name as him. Initially, he enjoys the fame but becomes upset when the character becomes a joke. To avoid the ridicule, Homer changes his name to Max Power, leading to new experiences and friendships. Eventually, he reverts to being Homer Simpson.

Patty and Selma Bouvier are characters from "The Simpsons," the animated TV show. They're identical twins, voiced by Julie Kavner, and they're Marge Simpson's older sisters. They both work at the Springfield Department of Motor Vehicles and aren't big fans of their brother-in-law, Homer Simpson. Selma is the older twin by two minutes and wants a boyfriend, while Patty is a lesbian. Kavner voices them as characters who drain the energy from situations. They first appeared in the very first episode of "The Simpsons," which aired on December 17, 1989.

Hubert Gagnon is an actor from Quebec, Canada, known for several roles. He's most famous for voicing Homer Simpson in the Quebec version of The Simpsons, as well as providing the voice for Mel Gibson in numerous movies. Additionally, he played the character Picabo on the Québécois TV show Les Oraliens. Gagnon also dubbed Vernon Dursley in the Harry Potter films and voiced Optimus Prime in the original Transformers cartoon, although he was replaced by Guy Nadon for the 2007 film. Interestingly, Nadon had previously portrayed Sideshow Bob alongside Gagnon in the Québécois version of The Simpsons.

question: What studio album did Kanye West record with Roc-A-Fella Records and soul singer Dwele?
pos: Kanye West's fifth studio album, "My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy," was released on November 22, 2010, by Roc-A-Fella Records. Before its release, West had faced public and legal issues, leading him to retreat to Hawaii in 2009 for a self-imposed exile, where he worked on the album. The recording process involved many musicians and producers in a collaborative environment. The album includes guest appearances from artists such as Bon Iver, Jay-Z, Pusha T, Rick Ross, Kid Cudi, Nicki Minaj, and John Legend.

"Power" is a hip hop song by Kanye West, released as the main track from his album "My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy" in 2010. The song includes vocals from Dwele and was co-produced by West and Symbolyc One. It samples songs like "21st Century Schizoid Man" by King Crimson, "Afromerica" by Continent Number 6, and "It's Your Thing" by Cold Grits. West mentioned spending 5000 hours composing it in Hawaii. The lyrics touch on themes related to the United States and criticism, with a distinctive vocal riff in the chorus.
neg: Hip Hop Since 1978 (HHS78) was a company based in New York City that managed artists and helped produce music. It was founded by Gee Roberson and Kyambo Hip-Hop Joshua. They played a big role in running Roc-A-Fella Records since it started in the early '90s. They first signed Kanye West in 1998 and helped him join Roc-A-Fella Records. Their first major project was West's album "The College Dropout" in 2004. In 2007, they teamed up with Bryant Entertainment and started managing Lil Wayne, Drake, and Nicki Minaj. Kyambo Joshua left in 2009. Later, they signed Young Jeezy. The company closed in 2014. Kyambo Joshua joined Def Jam Recordings, and Gee Roberson started his own management agencies.

Kanye West's third studio album, "Graduation," came out on September 11, 2007, under Roc-A-Fella Records. Recording for the album happened from 2005 to 2007 in studios like Chung King Studios and Sony Music Studios in New York City, and Chalice Studios and The Record Plant in Los Angeles. Kanye West mainly handled the production, with help from DJ Toomp and others like Mike Dean, Nottz, Brian All Day Miller, Eric Hudson, Warryn Campbell, Gee Roberson, Plain Pat, and Jon Brion. The album features guest appearances from artists like Mos Def, Dwele, T-Pain, Lil Wayne, DJ Premier, and Chris Martin of Coldplay. The cover art was created by Japanese artist Takashi Murakami.

Kanye West's first album, "The College Dropout," came out on February 10, 2004, under Roc-A-Fella Records. He worked on it for four years, starting in 1999. Before this album, West was known for producing music for artists like Jay-Z and Talib Kweli. However, he struggled to establish himself as a solo artist in the music industry. Despite facing rejection, he persisted and eventually landed a record deal with Roc-A-Fella Records.

PRhyme is the first album by the American hip hop duo PRhyme, made up of Royce da 5'9 and DJ Premier. It came out on December 9, 2014, under their record label, PRhyme Records. The album includes guest appearances by rappers like Killer Mike, Jay Electronica, Common, Ab-Soul, Schoolboy Q, Slaughterhouse, Mac Miller, and soul singer Dwele. DJ Premier handled the production, and the album samples music from Adrian Younge, a psychedelic soul composer and producer. The single "Courtesy" was used to promote the album.

Late Registration, Kanye West's second album, came out on August 30, 2005, under Roc-A-Fella Records. It took about a year to make, with recording sessions in New York City and Hollywood, where Kanye worked with Jon Brion, a record producer and composer. The album has guest appearances from artists like Adam Levine, Lupe Fiasco, Jamie Foxx, Common, Jay-Z, Brandy, and Nas. Compared to his first album, The College Dropout, Late Registration has more complex production, with West and Brion using detailed sampling and orchestration. The lyrics cover personal and political topics such as poverty, drugs, racism, healthcare, and the diamond trade.

"The People" is a song by Common, an American rapper, which was released as the second single from his album Finding Forever. It first appeared on Kanye West's mixtape, "Can't Tell Me Nothing." The song, produced by Kanye West, features background vocals by Dwele. Initially, Common sang the hook himself, but later it was replaced by Dwele. The song samples Gil Scott-Heron's "We Almost Lost Detroit" and includes vocal samples from Mountain's "Long Red," which was also used in another song featuring Kanye West, "Wouldn't Get Far." This was part of Kanye West's tribute to J Dilla through the album's production style.

Watch the Throne is a music album made by Jay-Z and Kanye West, two American rappers. It was released on August 8, 2011, through Roc-A-Fella Records, Roc Nation, and Def Jam Recordings. Before this album, Jay-Z and West had worked together on their own songs and with West producing for Jay-Z. Being close friends, they initially planned to make a short EP with five songs but ended up creating a full album. They started recording in November 2010 at different places. West was the main producer of the album, with help from other well-known producers like Mike Dean, Swizz Beatz, Sak Pase, Jeff Bhasker, The Neptunes, and Q-Tip.

"Flashing Lights" is a song by Kanye West, a hip-hop artist from the United States. It includes vocals by Detroit R&B singer Dwele and background vocals by Australian singer Connie Mitchell. West worked with Eric Hudson to write and produce the song. It was released on November 22, 2007, as the fourth single from his album "Graduation." The cover art for the single was created by Japanese pop artist Takashi Murakami. Music critics praised the song, considering it one of the standout tracks on the album "Graduation."

question: Were Enrique Carreras and Lionel Ngakane both filmakers during the 20th century?
pos: Lionel Ngakane (17 July 1928 – 26 November 2003) was a filmmaker and actor from South Africa.

Enrique Carreras (January 6, 1925 - August 29, 1995) was a filmmaker from Peru who later became an Argentine citizen. He directed, wrote scripts, and produced films. He was known for making a lot of movies and is considered one of the busiest directors in Argentine cinema history.
neg: Concepció Badia Millàs, also known as Conchita Badía or Conxita Badia, was a Spanish soprano and pianist. She was famous for her natural expression, emotional depth, and clear singing. People thought she was one of the best performers of Catalan, Spanish, and Latin American art songs in the 20th century. She sang in many premieres, like pieces by Enrique Granados, Manuel de Falla, Frederic Mompou, Alberto Ginastera, and Enric Morera, some of which were made just for her. Most of her recordings, music scores, letters, and photos are kept in the Biblioteca de Catalunya. In one letter, Pablo Casals said that everything he composed for a soprano, he did it with her in mind, so they all belonged to her.

Enrique Echeverría Vázquez (1923-1972) was a Mexican painter known for breaking away from traditional painting styles in Mexico during the mid-20th century. He was part of a group called the Generación de la Ruptura and was an early member of the Salón de la Plástica Mexicana. Instead of sticking to the usual figurative style, he, along with other painters, started experimenting with abstract and modern European painting styles. Despite his influence on other artists and critics, he passed away in the early 1970s before receiving widespread recognition for his work. Although he had two major exhibits at the Palacio de Bellas Artes in Mexico City, one shortly after his death and a retrospective thirty years later in 2003, his name and art aren't well known among younger Mexican painters.

The Carreras Cigarette Factory is a big, fancy building in Camden, London, UK. It's known for its unique style that mixes ancient Egyptian design with the trendy art deco style of the early 1900s. Built between 1926 and 1928 by the Carreras Tobacco Company, it was the brainchild of Bernhard Baron, a Russian-Jewish inventor and philanthropist. The architects M.E. and O.H. Collins and A.G. Porri designed it. The building stretches 550 feet (168 meters) and is mostly white.

Enrique Grau, born on December 18, 1920, and passed away on April 1, 2004, was a famous Colombian artist known for his paintings of indigenous and Afro-Colombian people. He was part of a group of three important Colombian artists in the 20th century, along with Fernando Botero and Alejandro Obregón.

Lionel S. Reiss was a Polish-American Jewish painter, born in Poland in 1894 but moved to New York City's Lower East Side when he was four. His family immigrated to the US like many Eastern European Jews at the time. Reiss grew up in New York City and studied commercial art there. He worked as a commercial artist for various companies, including Paramount Studios, where he eventually became the art director. He's famous for creating the Leo the Lion logo for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios.

Enrique Banchs was an Argentine poet who only published his work during a short period in the early 20th century, spanning four years. He released four works: "Las barcas" (1907), "El libro de los elogios" (1908), "El cascabel del halcón" (1909), and "La urna" (1911). Banchs wrote in a style inspired by the Siglo de Oro, focusing on classic themes. His last work was a collection of sonnets, a form that was uncommon by then. Despite not publishing anything in the last fifty years of his life, Banchs remained involved in the Argentine literary community and was a member of the Argentine Academy of Letters. He was also friends with Carlos Alberto Leumann.

Manuel Quiroga, a talented violinist from Galicia, lived from April 15, 1892, to April 19, 1961. His promising career in the early 20th century was tragically cut short by a traffic accident in New York in 1937. Many music critics praised him as the finest successor to Pablo de Sarasate, even calling him Sarasate's spiritual heir. He received dedications from composers like Enrique Granados and Eugène Ysaÿe. Quiroga earned admiration from the greatest violinists of his time, including Ysaÿe, Fritz Kreisler, George Enescu, Mischa Elman, and Jascha Heifetz, as well as composers like Igor Stravinsky and Jean Sibelius. Guilhermina Suggia, a renowned Portuguese cellist and once companion of Pablo Casals, described Quiroga's performance of Tartini's Devil's Trill Sonata as marvelous and flawless.
John Lionel Darby was the Dean of Chester during the late 1800s and early 1900s.

question: The city that contains the Yunnan Provincial Museum is also known by what nickname?
pos: The Yunnan Provincial Museum is in Kunming, on Guangfu Road. It showcases exhibits about Yunnan's ethnic groups and displays artifacts from tombs found in Jinning, near Lake Dian's southern edge.

Kunming, located in Southwest China, is the capital and largest city of Yunnan Province. Formerly known as Yunnan-Fu, it serves as the political, economic, and cultural hub of the province. Renowned for its pleasant climate, Kunming is often called the "Spring City." It played a significant role during World War II as a Chinese military center, American air base, and key transport point for the Burma Road. Situated on the Yunnan–Guizhou Plateau, Kunming sits at an altitude of 1900 meters and just north of the Tropic of Cancer. With a population of around 6.6 million as of 2014, Kunming is bordered by Lake Dian, featuring a scenic landscape dotted with temples and limestone hills.
neg: Yangzonghai Lake, also known as Yangzong Sea on some maps, is a freshwater lake situated between Yiliang County, Chenggong District, and Chengjiang County. It's about 45 kilometers east of Kunming City in Yunnan Province, China. Approximately 30,000 people rely on this lake for their drinking water. Yangzonghai Lake is famous for its underwater springs and is one of the many beautiful areas in Yunnan province, known for its rich biodiversity. It's a popular destination for tourists from Kunming, the nearby provincial capital. Kunming is also close to Dianchi Lake, one of China's largest freshwater lakes, although it's heavily polluted.

Dianchi Lake, also called Lake Dian and Kunming Lake, is a big lake found on the Yunnan-Guizhou Plateau near Kunming, Yunnan, in southern China. It's often called the "Sparkling Pearl Embedded in a Highland" and served as the inspiration for Kunming Lake in the Summer Palace in Beijing. The name "Dian" is where the Chinese abbreviation 滇 for Yunnan comes from.

The Dali–Ruili Railway, also known as the Darui Railway, is a new train track being built in Yunnan Province, Southwest China. This railway will stretch for 336.39 kilometers, starting from Dali in the center of Yunnan and ending in Ruili in the southwest, near Myanmar's border. The railway route goes through challenging terrain, with bridges and tunnels making up 75% of its length. Notably, there will be a 36-kilometer-long tunnel through the Gaoligong Mountains. Construction began in May 2011 and is expected to take six years to complete. The railway will pass through several cities and towns including Dali, Yangbi Yi Autonomous County, Yongping County, Baoshan, Mang City (also known as Mangshi or Dehong), and finally Ruili.

Flores Island Marine Provincial Park, also called Flores Island Provincial Park, is a park in British Columbia, Canada. It's on Flores Island in Clayoquot Sound, on the West Coast of Vancouver Island. The park is 7113 hectares and was established on July 13, 1995, as part of the Clayoqout Land-Use Decision. It's next to Gibson Marine Provincial Park, created in 1967, and Sulphur Passage Provincial Park, which surrounds Obstruction Island off the northeast coast of Flores Island.

Xin Zhui, also called Lady Dai or Marquise of Dai, was the wife of Li Cang, the Marquis of Dai, during the Han dynasty in China. Her tomb was found over 2,000 years later in a hill called Mawangdui in Changsha, Hunan. Inside, workers found her body remarkably well-preserved, along with many valuable items and documents. Her remains and possessions are now looked after by the Hunan Provincial Museum and are sometimes displayed in international exhibitions.

Kunming City Museum is a history museum located in Kunming City, Yunnan, China. While it's smaller compared to the Yunnan Provincial Museum, its main focus is showcasing the history of the city. Visitors can also explore exhibits on dinosaurs and enjoy a rotating display area that hosts various exhibitions ranging from history to art.

Luang Namtha Museum, also known as Louang Namtha Provincial Museum, is located in Luang Namtha, Laos. It mainly focuses on the culture and history of the local people, showcasing various items like traditional clothing, bronze drums from the Khamu ethnic group, textiles, ceramics, tools, household items, handmade weapons, and objects related to Buddhism.

Karel Dežman, who also went by Dragotin Dežman and Karl Deschmann, lived from January 3, 1821, to March 11, 1889. He was a politician and scientist from Carniola, a region in what is now Slovenia, during the 19th century. Dežman played a significant role in politics, culture, and science in Carniola at that time. He is known as one of the founders of modern archaeology in Slovenia. Additionally, he made important discoveries and advancements in botany, zoology, mineralogy, geology, and archaeology. Dežman was the first director of the Provincial Museum of Carniola, which is now known as the National Museum of Slovenia. Despite initially supporting Slovenian liberal nationalism, he later shifted towards Austrian centralism and adopted pro-German cultural views. This change in stance made him a controversial figure, seen by some as betraying his national roots.

question: Where is the singer of "B Boy" raised?
pos: "B Boy" is a hip hop song by Meek Mill, an American artist. It came out as the third single from his album "Dreams Worth More Than Money" on March 3, 2015, under Maybach Music Group and Atlantic Records. The track, produced by Sap, includes guest verses from Big Sean and ASAP Ferg.

Robert Rihmeek Williams, known as Meek Mill, is an American hip hop artist born on May 6, 1987. He grew up in Philadelphia and began his music career as a battle rapper before forming a brief rap group called The Bloodhoundz. In 2008, he signed his first record deal with rapper T.I. After leaving Grand Hustle Records in February 2011, Mill joined Miami-based rapper Rick Ross's Maybach Music Group (MMG). His debut album, "Dreams and Nightmares," was released in 2012 under MMG and Warner Bros. Records. It included the single "Young & Gettin' It" and debuted at number two on the U.S. Billboard 200 chart.
neg: Revised: "Under the Blue Moon" is New Edition's fifth studio album, released by MCA on November 24, 1986. This album marked a transition for the group as it was their first without member Bobby Brown, who had left the group. It's also their only album as a quartet. The album peaked at number 43 on the Billboard 200 and number 18 on the R&B albums chart. It later received a gold certification from the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA).

Immature's fourth album, "The Journey," was released on September 23, 1997, under MCA Records. It reached #92 on The Billboard 200 chart and #20 on the Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums chart. This marked their final album under the name Immature before transitioning to their fifth album in 1999 under the name IMx.

"B Boy Baby" is a song from Mutya Buena's first album, Real Girl. It was written by Phil Spector, Ellie Greenwich, Jeff Barry, Craig Klepto Tucker, Peter Celik, and Angela Hunte. The song includes vocals by Amy Winehouse, although she isn't credited. It was produced by Salaam Remi and served as the last single from the album.

Imajin is a popular American R&B boy band known for their hit song "Shorty (You Keep Playing With My Mind)" featuring Keith Murray. They also released a version of this song with Mr. Cheeks from The Lost Boyz. This single reached number 25 on the Billboard Hot 100, number 20 on Billboard's Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart, and number 22 on the UK Singles Chart in 1998. The band was formed by record producer Bert Price and was influenced by past boy bands like Jackson 5, New Edition, Hi-Five, Immature, and Mint Condition. The original members included Jamal Hampton (later replaced by Tony Royster, Jr.), Talib Kareem, Olamide Faison, and John Fitch. Faison is the younger brother of Donald Faison from the TV show Scrubs. Imajin prided themselves on being a true boy band with each member playing an instrument: Jamal Hampton and Tony Royster on drums, Talib Kareem on keyboard, Olamide Faison on guitar, and John Fitch on bass guitar. After their first album, the group split, and John and Olamide formed a duo called JizLams. During the break, Talib continued producing songs for artists like Solange Knowles, while Jamal pursued a solo career under the name J Star. Despite the hiatus, the group reunited and continues to create music together as Imajin.
De'Mario Monte Thornton, also known as Raz-B, was born on June 13, 1985. He's an American singer and actor, well-known for being one of the original members of the R&B boy band B2K.

Omarion, born Omari Ishmael Grandberry on November 12, 1984, is an American singer, songwriter, rapper, actor, and dancer. He first gained fame as the lead singer of the R&B boy band B2K, known for hits like "Bump, Bump, Bump," "Uh Huh," and "Girlfriend." After B2K disbanded, Omarion released his debut solo album "O" in 2005, which topped the Billboard 200 chart and earned him a Grammy nomination for Best Contemporary R&B Album. His second album, "21," was released in 2006 and included the hit single "Ice Box." In 2010, he released "Ollusion," followed by "Sex Playlist" in 2014, which featured the hit single "Post to Be." This song went 3x platinum and became his highest-charting single, reaching number 13 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart in May 2015.

B2K was a popular American R&B boy band that formed in 1998 and broke up in 2004. They were put together by American record producer Chris Stokes. Their first album, "B2K," came out on March 12, 2002, and it did really well, hitting #2 on the Billboard 200 chart and #1 on the U.S. Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs albums chart.

Elliot Straite, who goes by the name Dr. Freeze, is a multi-talented artist known for singing, writing songs, and producing records. His music is mainly in the new jack swing genre. Some of his notable works include writing and producing the popular song "I Wanna Sex You Up" for the R&B boy band Color Me Badd, and co-writing and co-producing "Break of Dawn" for Michael Jackson's chart-topping album, Invincible.

question: The Column of Saint Zanobi  is a monumental marble column located just north of religious building with the status of what?
pos: The Saint Zanobi Column, also known as Colonna di San Zanobi in Italian, is a large marble column with a cross on top and a crown of fire above it. It stands to the north of the San Giovanni Baptistery in Florence, Italy.

The Florence Baptistery, also called the Baptistery of Saint John, is a religious building located in Florence, Italy. It's shaped like an octagon and is situated in two main squares: Piazza del Duomo and Piazza San Giovanni. You can find it opposite Florence Cathedral and the Campanile di Giotto.
neg: The Column of Phocas is a tall Roman monument located in the Roman Forum of Rome, Italy. It was put up in honor of the Eastern Roman Emperor Phocas on August 1, 608. This column is the last addition to the Forum Romanum. It stands at 13.6 meters tall and has a fluted Corinthian style. Originally, it seems like the column was created in the 2nd century for a different building, then reused for this monument. Similarly, the base of the column was repurposed from supporting a statue of Diocletian. The old inscription was removed to make space for the new one honoring Phocas.
The Colonna dell'Abbondanza is a big column in Florence, Italy, standing in the Piazza della Repubblica.

The Vicariate Column, also known as Colonna della Vicaria, was a plain white marble column placed on a pedestal. It used to be located outside Castel Capuano along Via dei Tribunali in Naples, Italy. Initially, it served as a spot where the government punished debtors.

Piazza Colonna is a square in the Colonna district in central Rome, Italy. It's known for the Column of Marcus Aurelius, a marble pillar dating back to AD 193. On top of the column sits a bronze statue of Saint Paul, added in 1589 by Pope Sixtus V. The Via del Corso, once known as the Roman Via Lata, cuts through the eastern part of the square, running from south to north.

The San Jacinto Monument is a really tall column standing at 567.31 feet. It's in Harris County, Texas, close to Houston, right by the Houston Ship Channel. At the very top, there's a huge 220-ton star. This star marks where the Battle of San Jacinto happened, a really important battle during the Texas Revolution. They built the monument from 1936 to 1939, and it officially opened on April 21, 1939. It's the tallest column made of bricks and stones in the whole world. It's part of the San Jacinto Battleground State Historic Site. Just to compare, the Washington Monument is a bit shorter at 554.612 feet, but it's still the tallest stone monument globally. The column is shaped like an eight-sided pole, and it's got a big Lone Star on top, which is the symbol of Texas. If you visit, you can take an elevator up to the top deck and see a great view of Houston and even the Battleship Texas.

The Pestsäule, also known as the Plague Column or Trinity Column, is a monument dedicated to the Holy Trinity. It stands in Vienna, Austria, on a street called the Graben in the city center. This Baroque memorial was built in 1679 following a major plague outbreak and is famous for its intricate sculptures, making it one of Vienna's most recognizable and important artworks.

The Peace Column, known as Friedenssäule in German, stands tall in Mehringplatz, Berlin, Germany. It was designed by Christian Gottlieb Cantian and built in 1843. At the top of the 19-meter column is a brass statue of Victoria, the goddess of victory, crafted by Christian Daniel Rauch. In 1876, allegorical figures representing the four victorious allies of the Battle of Waterloo were added, and in 1879, two more sculptures were included: The Peace by Albert Wolff and Clio, who writes the history of the Wars of Liberation.

The Alexander II Column, also called Alexander's column or the Monument to Alexander II of Russia, is a tall column in Shevchenko Park, Odessa. It was built to honor the visit of Russian Emperor Alexander II to the city in 1875.

question: The Ingerophrynus gollum is named after a character in a book that sold how many copies?
pos: Ingerophrynus gollum, also known as Gollum's toad, is a type of true toad. It's been found only in Endau-Rompin National Park, Johor, living in dense forests with lots of trees, typically seen in the early evening after it's rained in the afternoon. The name "gollum" comes from the character in J.R.R. Tolkien's The Lord of the Rings.

The Lord of the Rings is a famous fantasy book by J. R. R. Tolkien, a British writer and scholar. It started as a follow-up to his earlier book, The Hobbit, but grew into a bigger story. Tolkien worked on it from 1937 to 1949. It's hugely popular, selling over 150 million copies worldwide.
neg: "Suanfa tongzong" is a math book written by Cheng Dawei, a Chinese mathematician in the 16th century. It was published in 1592 and contains 595 problems in 17 chapters, focusing on arithmetic for the abacus. It was a key resource for scholars studying Chinese mathematics. Six years later, Cheng Dawei published "Suanfa Zuanyao," which mostly reused content from four chapters of the first book. Due to its popularity, pirated copies with errors emerged, leading the author to release a condensed version.

Gollum is a made-up character created by J. R. R. Tolkien. He first appeared in the 1937 book The Hobbit and later played a significant role in The Lord of the Rings. Originally, Gollum was a kind of Hobbit called a Stoor who lived by a river called the Gladden Fields. His real name was Sméagol, but he changed it to Gollum because of a weird noise he made in his throat. He got messed up by the One Ring, which caused all sorts of problems for him.

The cosmological interpretation of quantum mechanics, proposed by Anthony Aguirre and Max Tegmark, suggests that in a universe with eternal inflation, there could be countless planets and copies of any quantum system. In this view, the wavefunction of a quantum system represents the real spatial arrangement of identical copies of that system in our infinite universe, rather than just possibilities. This interpretation suggests that the collapse of the wavefunction might not happen. Additionally, the uncertainty in quantum mechanics may be due to our inability to determine which copy of ourselves we are in the vastness of space.

Gollum explains how what was initially a three-week job for Andy Serkis to voice Gollum turned into a five-year dedication to bringing the character to life in The Lord of the Rings. Serkis covers different topics in the book, like how he came up with Gollum's characteristics (even basing his cough on his cat's hairball cough) and the challenges of acting out Gollum and integrating CGI. He also talks about the debate over whether he should have been considered for an Academy Award for his portrayal of Gollum.

The Burning Red, Machine Head's third album, is their second best-selling in the US. It sold as many copies in three years as their debut album Burn My Eyes did in almost eight years (1994–2002). In the US, it has sold over 134,000 copies and earned a silver certification from the BPI in 2011 for selling 60,000 copies in the UK.

Gollum sharks are a type of shark found in the southwestern Pacific Ocean. Biologist Leonard Compagno discovered and named this genus in 1973, inspired by J. R. R. Tolkien's character Gollum because one of the species, Gollum attenuatus (also known as the slender smooth-hound), shares similarities in appearance and behavior.

Ingerophrynus is a type of true toad that includes 12 different species. These toads are found in various regions, from southern Yunnan and Indochina to places like peninsular Thailand, Malaya, Sumatra, Borneo, Java, Sulawesi, and the Philippines. The creation of this genus came after a big scientific review of frogs. Before, ten of the species in this group were thought to be part of the Bufo genus. In 2007, a new species named Ingerophrynus gollum was discovered and named after J. R. R. Tolkien's character, Gollum.

"From Unknown Worlds" is a collection of fantasy fiction short stories edited by John W. Campbell, Jr. and illustrated by Edd Cartier. It was first published in 1948 by Street & Smith, with the aim of testing the market for a revival of the classic magazine "Unknown" from the 1930s-40s. Despite selling better than expected, too many copies were returned, leading the publisher to decide against reviving the magazine. The first British edition was released by Atlas Publishing in 1952, with a portion of the print run issued in hardcover. This edition excluded the story "One Man's Harp."

question: What Danish eurodance group had a single called "Barbie Girl" which resulted in a lawsuit in 2002?
pos: Aqua, a Danish eurodance band, became famous with their hit single "Barbie Girl" in 1997. They formed in 1989 and gained massive popularity worldwide in the late '90s and early 2000s. They released three albums: "Aquarium" in 1997, "Aquarius" in 2000, and "Megalomania" in 2011. Selling approximately 33 million albums and singles, they're considered the most successful Danish band to date.
Mattel v. MCA Records was a legal battle between Mattel and MCA Records over the 1997 song "Barbie Girl" by Aqua. The case was eventually dropped or dismissed by the court.
neg: Daze is a Danish band known for their catchy Eurodance tunes. Their first album, "Super Heroes," released in 1997, was a huge success, going double platinum internationally. The band consists of Lucas Sieber, Jesper Tønnov, and Trine Bix. Their music style is often likened to the Danish pop group Aqua. "Super Heroes" sold 31,000 copies on its release day in Scandinavia, later hitting the shelves in the US and other global markets. Popular tracks from the album include "Superhero," "Tamogotchi," and "Toy Boy." In 1998, Daze won the Danish Grammy Award for Best Dance Album, and their single "Superhero" was nominated as the Danish hit of the year by G.A.F.F.A. magazine. The band gained significant popularity in Argentina during the same period.

"Lollipop (Candyman)" is a song by Aqua, a Danish dance-pop group. It was their fourth single from the album "Aquarium," following their hit "Barbie Girl." While popular in Australasia, North America, and Mainland Europe, it wasn't released in the UK. Despite being a favorite of the group, "Lollipop (Candyman)" didn't achieve the same success as their previous singles like "Barbie Girl," "Doctor Jones," and "My Oh My."

Søren Nystrøm Rasted, born Søren Rasted on June 13, 1969, in Blovstrød, Denmark, is a Danish musician, singer, songwriter, and record producer. He's known for playing keyboard, guitar, and singing backing vocals. Søren is part of the Danish eurodance group Aqua and was once married to Lene Nystrøm, the vocalist of Aqua.
Lene Nystrøm Rasted, born on October 2, 1973, commonly known as Lene, is a Norwegian singer and songwriter. She's best known as the main singer of the Danish eurodance band Aqua.

René Dif, born on October 17, 1967, in Copenhagen, Denmark, is a Danish artist who sings, writes songs, DJs, and acts. He's most famous for being the main male singer in the Danish eurodance band Aqua.

The album "Perfect Day" is Cascada's second studio release, produced entirely by Yanou and DJ Manian. It's packed with upbeat Eurodance tunes, many of which are covers of rock and country songs from the early 2000s, with one exception: "Because the Night," originally by Patti Smith from 1978. It also includes edited versions of two tracks previously recorded under the name Siria. The music is classic Eurodance with energetic trance-style synths, fast drum beats, and catchy Europop lyrics focused on love, parties, and romance.

Doctor Jones is a song by the Danish dance-pop group Aqua. It came out after their big hit Barbie Girl and was their fifth single. While Barbie Girl was a huge success, Doctor Jones also did really well worldwide, showing that Aqua wasn't just a one-hit wonder. However, in America, they were still mostly known for Barbie Girl until they released Lollipop (Candyman), which also became popular, making it into the top 40 on the Hot 100 chart.

The first album by the Danish-Norwegian band Aqua is called "Aquarium." It came out on March 26, 1997, in Scandinavia and on September 9, 1997, in the United States. Before Aqua, the group was known as Joyspeed, but they only released one single called "Itzy Bitsy Spider." "Aquarium" became popular mainly because of its hit singles "Barbie Girl," "Doctor Jones," and "Turn Back Time," with "Barbie Girl" being a massive global success. Before the album, they released two singles, "Roses Are Red" and "My Oh My," which was re-released in 1998.

question: Which case was decided first, Selle v. Gibb or Reynolds v. Sims?
pos: Reynolds v. Sims, a 1964 U.S. Supreme Court case, established that state legislative districts must have roughly equal populations. This decision overturned the traditional role of state Senates, which previously allowed rural areas to offset urban population centers. The case originated from Alabama but impacted other states like Colorado, New York, Maryland, Virginia, and Delaware, where legislative reapportionment hadn't kept pace with population changes.

In the case of Selle v. Gibb (1984), the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals made a significant decision regarding the concept of striking similarities. They stated that to prove copying, one usually needs evidence of access to the original work and substantial similarity between the two works. However, if there's no evidence of access, striking similarities between the works can suggest copying. But it's important to note that merely having striking similarities isn't sufficient to infer access; these similarities must be so strong that they couldn't have arisen independently.
neg: The case West v. Barnes, decided in 1791, marked the first Supreme Court decision and the earliest one to involve oral arguments. Another case, Van Staphorst v. Maryland, was actually docketed before West v. Barnes but was settled before reaching oral argument. West v. Barnes was argued on August 2, 1791, and decided on August 3, 1791. Additionally, Collet v. Collet was the first appellate case docketed with the Court, but it was dropped before being heard. Alexander Dallas, the Supreme Court Reporter, didn't publish the full opinions of the justices in West v. Barnes; instead, he provided a condensed summary of the decisions, while the full opinions were published in various newspapers across the country at that time.
Reynolds v Times Newspapers Ltd was a legal case in English defamation law about when newspapers can publish harmful statements if it's in the public interest.

George Reynolds (January 1, 1842 – August 9, 1909) held important roles within The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church). He served as a general authority and was the secretary to the First Presidency for a considerable period. He was also involved in the historic 1878 United States Supreme Court case known as Reynolds v. United States, which marked the court's first ruling on freedom of religion.

Jameel v Wall Street Journal Europe was a ruling by the House of Lords regarding English defamation law. It basically supported the previous Reynolds v Times Newspapers Ltd decision and reinforced the idea of a public interest defense in libel cases.

Reynolds v. United States, a case decided by the Supreme Court in 1878, ruled that claiming religious duty couldn't excuse someone from criminal charges. This case was significant because it was the first time the Supreme Court discussed certain aspects of the Sixth Amendment related to jury impartiality and confrontation rights.

During Morrison Waite's time as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States from March 4, 1874, to March 23, 1888, the court dealt with an unusually high number of criminal cases. In just fourteen years, they handled 106 criminal cases, which was almost as many as they had dealt with from the court's inception until Waite became Chief Justice. Some notable cases during this period include United States v. Cruikshank (1875), United States v. Reese (1875), Reynolds v. United States (1878), Wilkerson v. Utah (1879), and several others.

Reynolds v. Pegler, a famous case from 1955, involved Quentin Reynolds suing Westbrook Pegler, a conservative columnist, for defamation. Reynolds won the case and was awarded a large sum of $175,001 in damages, setting a legal precedent.

Chuck Morgan Jr. (1930–2009) was a civil rights lawyer from Alabama. He helped establish the principle of one person, one vote in the 1964 Supreme Court case Reynolds v. Sims. He also represented Julian Bond and Muhammad Ali in their legal cases.

question: Mamie Gummer played the role of Nancy Crozier on the TV series airing on what network?
pos: "The Good Wife" is a TV series about Alicia Florrick, who goes back to her law career after her husband's scandal. It aired on CBS from 2009 to 2016. Created by Robert and Michelle King, it stars Julianna Margulies and features several other actors. The show mixes ongoing storylines with individual cases, standing out for its serialized approach, notably in the fifth season, which is unusual for CBS, known for procedural shows.

Mary Willa Mamie Gummer, born on August 3, 1983, is an American actress. She starred as Emily Owens in the TV series "Emily Owens, M.D." from 2012 to 2013, and had a recurring role as Nancy Crozier in "The Good Wife" from 2010 to 2015. Her film credits include "Evening" (2007), "Side Effects" (2013), "Cake" (2014), and "Ricki and the Flash" (2015). Gummer was nominated for a 2016 Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actress in a Play for her performance in the original production of "Ugly Lies the Bone."
neg: "Hank Zipzer's Christmas Catastrophe" is a British Christmas movie from 2016, inspired by the Hank Zipzer book series by Henry Winkler and Lin Oliver, and the CBBC TV show. It premiered on CBBC on December 12, 2016, written by Joe Williams and directed by Matt Bloom. Produced by Kindle Entertainment with Walker Productions and DHX Media, it received support from Screen Yorkshire’s Yorkshire Content Fund. Notably, it's the fourth CBBC-based movie and the second one exclusively for TV, following "Shaun the Sheep Movie."

Kamen Rider Battle: Ganbaride is an arcade and collectible item game celebrating the 10th anniversary of the Heisei run Kamen Rider Series. It features characters from the series and ties in heavily with Kamen Rider Decade. Players use special Data Cardass cards, similar to those used in Sega's Dinosaur King games. The game's controls evolve with each new Kamen Rider series. For example, during Kamen Rider OOO's airing, the arcade systems included an OOO Driver interface for toy Core Medals. As the series progressed, features like slots for Astro Switches and Wizard Rings were added. The game's name changed to Kamen Rider Battle: Ganbarizing during Kamen Rider Gaim's TV series and onwards.

"The Voice Kids: Ahla Sawt (meaning Best Voice) is a TV show in Arabic that airs on MBC 1. It started on January 2, 2016. In the first season, the judges were Tamer Hosny, Nancy Ajram, and Kadhim Al-Sahir. The competition has four stages, beginning with the Blind Auditions, where contestants sing without the judges seeing them. If a judge likes a performance, they turn their chair. Each judge can have up to 15 contestants on their team. The finale of season 1 was on March 5, 2016, and the winner was Lynn Hayek from Lebanon, who was on Team Kadim Al-Sahir."

Burt Gummer, played by actor Michael Gross, is a fictional character in the Tremors film series and its short-lived TV show on the SciFi Channel. He's a gun enthusiast and survivalist who's very paranoid. Alongside his ex-wife Heather Gummer (played by Reba McEntire), they were the first in the series to kill a Graboid directly. Burt takes his approach to problems to the extreme and is very serious about it. Although he's only the main character in Tremors 3 and the TV series, fans love his quirky personality, making him a standout in the franchise. In Tremors 5, he discovers he has a son named Travis B. Welker from a previous relationship before Heather.

Love It or List It Vancouver is a Canadian reality TV show about home design that airs on the W Network. It's a spin-off from Love It or List It and is produced by Big Coat Productions. The show, set in the Greater Vancouver area, premiered in January 2013 and stars Jillian Harris from The Bachelor and The Bachelorette, along with real estate agent Todd Talbot. In the US, it's called Love It or List It, Too, and airs on HGTV. New episodes in Canada started airing on July 6, 2015, and in the US on July 24, 2015.

"The Lightkeepers" is a romantic comedy movie from 2009, written and directed by Daniel Adams. It features actors like Richard Dreyfuss, Blythe Danner, Mamie Gummer, Tom Wisdom, and Julie Harris in her last film role. The theme song for the movie was written by Zana Messia.

Pakdam Pakdai, also called Rat-A-Tat worldwide, is an Indian cartoon comedy show. It used to be on Nickelodeon India and now airs on Sonic Nickelodeon. The show is similar to Oggy and the Cockroaches, a French cartoon about a cat, Oggy, and three pesky cockroaches. Pakdam Pakdai started in April 2013.

Cool Center is a Filipino comedy talk show that aired on GMA Network from March 14, 2009. It was hosted by Eugene Domingo and Anjo Yllana, taking over from Nuts Entertainment. However, Anjo Yllana left the show due to his vice-mayoral run for local elections. Eugene Domingo then moved on to host a new project called Comedy Bar with Allan K. and Fabio Ide, ending Cool Center on April 17, 2010.

question: What country do both Adnan Akmal and Kamran Akmal represent in cricket?
pos: Adnan Akmal, born on March 13, 1985, is a Pakistani cricketer known for his batting and wicket-keeping skills. He plays for the Zarai Taraqiati Bank Ltd Cricket Team and has represented Pakistan at the under-17 level. Recently, he was called up to join Pakistan's tour against South Africa in the UAE, filling in for the main keeper, Zulqarnain Haider. Adnan's brothers, Kamran Akmal and Umar Akmal, also play for Pakistan and have central contracts with the Pakistan Cricket Board. Adnan made his Test debut against South Africa on November 12, 2010.

Kamran Akmal is a Pakistani cricketer born on January 13, 1982. His brothers, Adnan and Umar Akmal, are also professional cricketers. Adnan is a keeper-batsman, while Umar is a specialist batsman and part-time wicket-keeper. Kamran got married in 2006 and lives with his wife, Aiza, and their children, Laiba and Ayyan. He graduated from Beaconhouse School System Garden Town, Lahore. Kamran is a right-handed wicket-keeper-batsman who has played Tests, ODIs, and T20Is for Pakistan. He debuted internationally in November 2002 with a Test match in which Pakistan won at Harare Sports Club. He has impressive stats, with 2648 runs in 53 Test matches, 2924 runs in 137 ODIs, and 704 runs in T20Is. Additionally, as a wicket-keeper, he has dismissed 206, 169, and 52 batsmen in Tests, ODIs, and T20Is respectively.
neg: Mohammad Salman, born on August 7, 1981, in Karachi, is a professional cricketer from Pakistan. He bats with his right hand and also serves as a wicketkeeper. He joined the team as a substitute for Kamran Akmal.

999 is a Malaysian TV series similar to COPS in the United States. It investigates crimes in the country and has been airing on TV3 since 2004. Initially, it aired on Thursdays at 9:00 pm but switched to Tuesdays at the same time in January 2014. Hazlin Hussain has been the host since 2014, succeeding former hosts Zakiah Anas, Mazidul Akmal Sidek, Halim Din, and Omar Abdullah. In its debut year, it was among Malaysia's most-watched TV shows, with over 3 million viewers.

Umar Akmal is a Pakistani cricketer born on May 26, 1990. He started playing One Day Internationals (ODIs) on August 1, 2009, against Sri Lanka and played his first Test match against New Zealand on November 23, 2009. Umar bats right-handed and also bowls as a part-time spinner. Similar to his brothers Adnan and Kamran, Umar has also served as a wicketkeeper for the national team in numerous ODIs. His wife's name is Noor Fatima.

Imran Ali, born on August 14, 1985, is a Pakistani cricketer. He only played one List A match for the Multan Tigers during the 2012–13 season. Not much is known about his life apart from the fact that he hails from Sahiwal, Punjab. Imran, a fast bowler, participated in the 2012–13 Faysal Bank One-Day Cup, where he represented Multan against the Lahore Eagles. During this match, held at the Multan Cricket Stadium in March 2013, Imran managed to take the wicket of the Eagles' captain, Adnan Akmal. He ended the match with figures of 1/28 from his nine overs, which included two maidens.

The Lahore Qalandars are a cricket team in the Pakistan Super League, representing Lahore. They were one of five teams in the 2016 competition, captained by Azhar Ali. Despite winning only two out of eight matches, they ranked fifth and were eliminated in the group stage. Umar Akmal was the top scorer with 335 runs in seven matches.

Kamran Rasheed Khan, born in 1949, is a Pakistani American cricketer and cricket administrator. He played for the United States national cricket team from 1979 to 1990 and also competed in domestic cricket for teams like Lahore, Pakistan Railways, and Punjab University from 1964/65 to 1970/71 as a wicket-keeper. Additionally, he served as the President of the United States of America Cricket Association briefly from 1999 to 2000.

Zulqarnain Haider, born on April 23, 1986, in Lahore, is a Pakistani cricketer who has played for the national team. He began his career in the Pakistan Under-19s and was brought into the senior national team in 2010 as a backup for wicket-keeper Kamran Akmal during their tour of England. Although he made his Test debut during that tour, a broken finger limited him to just one match. He later made his One Day International (ODI) debut against South Africa and has played four ODIs so far, all against them. After the fourth match, Haider left for London due to concerns for his safety. As a right-handed batsman, he has represented Lahore Blues and Pakistan Telecommunication Company Limited in Pakistani domestic cricket, and currently plays for Zarai Taraqiati Bank Ltd.

The 2013 East Africa Premier League was the third time Cricket Kenya organized this competition. It happened from August 7th to 11th, 2013, at the Nairobi Club Ground and Simba Union Club Ground. There were big changes this time, like new names for the Kenyan teams and famous Pakistani players like Kamran Akmal and Imran Nazir joining. Rising Stars Chuis won the tournament by beating Ruwenzori Warriors in the final by 9 wickets.

question: Did Franki Valli sing with Hellogoodbye or The Four Seasons?
pos: The Four Seasons, an American band, rocked the charts in the 1960s and 1970s. They were even called the top rock band before the Beatles by the Vocal Group Hall of Fame. Sometimes they're referred to as Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons since 1970. The group started as the Four Lovers but transformed into the Four Seasons in 1960. It consisted of Frankie Valli as the lead singer, Bob Gaudio on keyboards and tenor vocals, Tommy DeVito on lead guitar and baritone vocals, and Nick Massi on electric bass and bass vocals.

Hellogoodbye is a pop rock band from Huntington Beach, California, formed in 2001 by singer Forrest Kline. They signed with Drive-Thru Records and dropped their debut full-length album "Zombies! Aliens! Vampires! Dinosaurs!" in 2006, following their earlier EP "Hellogoodbye" and DVD "OMG HGB DVD ROTFL." Their second album, "Would It Kill You?," was self-released on their label Wasted Summer Records in 2010, later distributed in the UK and Europe by LAB Records in March 2011. Their third album, "Everything is Debatable," came out on October 29, 2013, while they were on tour as the opening act for Paramore's The Self-Titled Tour.
neg: Roy Roman is a skilled trumpet player known for hitting high notes. He has played alongside famous musicians like Lionel Hampton, Benny Goodman, Count Basie, Duke Ellington, Bob Hope, Sammy Davis Jr., and Franki Valli. Roman started playing the trumpet when he was 19 years old. After injuring one of his front teeth, he met Roy Stevens, who taught him a scientific method of improving his embouchure, which is how the mouth muscles are used when playing brass instruments. Today, Roman is recognized as the top authority on the Stevens/Costello Method, a technique that helps trumpet players enhance their range, endurance, and control.

"Can't Take My Eyes Off You" is a popular song from 1967 by Frankie Valli. It was a big success, earning a gold record and reaching No. 2 on the Billboard Hot 100 for a week, only behind "Windy" by The Association. The song was co-written by Bob Gaudio, who was in The Four Seasons with Valli. This song remained Valli's biggest solo hit until 1974 when he reached #1 with "My Eyes Adored You."

Valli, Frankie Valli's sixth solo album with The Four Seasons, came out in 1976 on Private Stock as a stereo recording. It got reissued on CD in 2008 along with his first solo album, Close Up, by Collector's Choice.

Bobby Fox, an actor from Ireland who now resides in Australia, gained fame for portraying Franki Valli in the Australian version of Jersey Boys. Before his acting career, Fox was a four-time World Irish Dance Champion and toured with various dance productions such as Riverdance and Dancing on Dangerous Ground. He also starred in the Australian musical Hot Shoe Shuffle and appeared in several other productions including Ladies in Black, Blood Brothers, Mamma Mia!, and Spamalot.

Dean Valli, born on October 5, 1983, in North Vancouver, British Columbia, is a Canadian Football League (CFL) player for the British Columbia Lions as an offensive lineman. He attended Simon Fraser University, where he played football for the Simon Fraser Clan for four seasons, from 2002 to 2005, and graduated with a bachelor of arts degree in 2006. In 2005, he earned a spot on the Canada West Universities Athletic Association all-star team and represented SFU at the 2005 East West Bowl in Waterloo, Ontario. Valli was drafted by the Lions in the 1st round, 6th overall, in the 2006 CFL draft, marking the beginning of his professional football career.

The Jersey Boys: Original Broadway Cast Recording won a Grammy for the musical about Frankie Valli and The Four Seasons. Produced by Bob Gaudio, a member of the original Four Seasons, it features Christian Hoff as Tommy DeVito, Daniel Reichard as Bob Gaudio, J. Robert Spencer as Nick Massi, and John Lloyd Young as Frankie Valli. Released on November 1, 2005, by Rhino Entertainment, it reached number eighty-five on the Billboard 200 chart. In February 2008, it was certified Gold by the RIAA, and by December 2014, it had sold 1.4 million copies in the US.

"My Eyes Adored You" is a song from 1974 written by Bob Crewe and Kenny Nolan. Originally, The Four Seasons recorded it early that year. However, when Motown declined to release it, lead singer Frankie Valli bought the recording for $4000. Despite rejections from Capitol and Atlantic Records, Valli managed to have it released by Private Stock Records, albeit with only his name on the label. The single hit the US market in November 1974, reaching the top spot on the Billboard Hot 100 in March 1975.
