Wassail is a hot mulled cider drink that was part of a Medieval English tradition called wassailing. The purpose of wassailing was to guarantee a good harvest of cider apples in the coming year.

Om Records is a record label from the United States that started in 1995. They mainly release electronic, dance, and hip hop music. It was founded in San Francisco by Chris Smith. Om Records releases albums by artists and also puts out compilations. Some well-known compilations they've released are Om Lounge and the Mushroom Jazz series. The label currently represents artists like Groove Armada, Underworld, Dirty Vegas, Bassnectar, Indiana Taurus, J Boogie, People Under The Stairs, Samantha James, Amp Live, Greenskeepers, Hot Toddy, Wagon Cookin, among others. In the past, they've had artists like Kaskade, Wolfgang Gartner, Ladybug Mecca, Juan Atkins, and Naked Music NYC.

question: What year was the film "Mom" released, starring the voice of Shashaa Tirupati?
pos: Shashaa Tirupati is a singer and songwriter from Canada, whose family is originally from Kashmir. She mainly sings for Bollywood and South Indian movies. You might recognize her voice from popular Bollywood songs like "The Humma Song" from the movie OK Jaanu, "Phir Bhi Tumko Chahunga" from Half Girlfriend (sung with Arijit Singh), "Baarish" also from Half Girlfriend, "Kanha" from Shubh Mangal Saavdhan, and "O Sona Tere Liye" (with A.R. Rahman) and "Chal Kahin Door," both from the movie MOM, starring Sridevi.

Mom is a thriller movie from 2017 directed by Ravi Udyawar. It's about a mother, played by Sridevi, seeking revenge for her daughter, portrayed by Sajal Ali. Other actors include Adnan Siddiqui, Akshaye Khanna, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui in supporting roles. The music is by A. R. Rahman. The film was released on July 7, 2017, in four languages and got good reviews from critics. It was also a commercial success and marked Sridevi's 300th film.
neg: Garfield Gets Real, also known as Garfield 3D in some places, is a CGI movie from 2007 featuring the famous cat Garfield. It was made by Paws, Inc., in partnership with Davis Entertainment and The Animation Picture Company, and was distributed by 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment. Jim Davis, the creator of Garfield, wrote the script starting in 1996. This film marked the return of fully animated Garfield since the last TV episode aired in 1995 and was the first one written by Davis since a TV special in 1991. It hit theaters on August 9, 2007, and came out on DVD on November 20, 2007. Gregg Berger, who acted in the original series, voiced Odie again, but Garfield's voice was done by Frank Welker due to the original actor Lorenzo Music's passing in 2001. Wally Wingert voiced Jon as Thom Huge retired the same year. The movie's success led to two sequels: Garfield's Fun Fest (2008) and Garfield's Pet Force (2009).
"Eleventh Mom" is a South Korean movie from 2007, starring Kim Hye-soo, Kim Young-chan, and Ryu Seung-ryong. It came out on November 29, 2007, and was seen by 350,204 people.

Chinatown Nights, also known as Tong War, is a 1929 film featuring Wallace Beery. Originally made as a silent film, it was later turned into a talkie by adding sound through dubbing. Directed by William A. Wellman and released by Paramount Pictures, the movie also stars Florence Vidor, who didn't provide her own voice and left acting afterward. Her role's voice was dubbed by actress Nella Walker. The cast includes Warner Oland as a Chinese gangster and Jack Oakie as a reporter with a stutter. It's based on the story "Tong War" by Samuel Ornitz.

"Gidget Goes to Rome" is a 1963 movie produced by Columbia Pictures in Eastmancolor. It features Cindy Carol as the main character, a high school surfer girl named Gidget, originally portrayed by Sandra Dee in the 1959 film "Gidget." Directed by Paul Wendkos, this film is the third installment in the Gidget series and delves deeper into Gidget's romantic relationship with Moondoggie. The screenplay, penned by Ruth Brooks Flippen, is based on characters created by Frederick Kohner. Notable actors from previous Gidget films, such as James Darren as Moondoggie, Joby Baker, and Jean Jeff Donnell as Gidget's mom, Mrs. Lawrence, make appearances in this movie. "Gidget Goes to Rome" has been made available on VHS and DVD formats.

The song "Phir Bhi Tumko Chaahunga" from the Indian movie "Half Girlfriend" features Shraddha Kapoor and Arjun Kapoor. Arijit Singh and Shashaa Tirupati sing it, with music by Mithoon and lyrics by Manoj Muntashir. Arijit Singh also sings a reprise version called "Pal Bhar (Chaahunga Reprise)," and Shraddha Kapoor performs another version titled "Phir Bhi Tumko Chaahungi" along with the instrumental "Half Girlfriend (Love Theme)."

British actor Christian Bale has been in many movies, ads, and even a video game. He started acting in 1986 on TV, then moved to films in 1987 with "Empire of the Sun," where he played a boy held captive in China during wartime. Critics liked his performance. He had a small role in "Henry V" in 1989, a well-regarded adaptation of Shakespeare. In 1992, he was in "Newsies," which flopped but gained a devoted fanbase. "Little Women" in 1994 got good reviews. Bale voiced a character in "Pocahontas" in 1995, which did okay at the box office but had mixed reviews. In 1998, he starred in "Velvet Goldmine," which had mixed reviews, but people were excited about his role. In 1999, he was in "A Midsummer Night's Dream" and played Demetrius, receiving praise. The same year, he played Jesus in a TV movie called "Mary, Mother of Jesus."

"Trading Mom," also called "The Mommy Market," is a fantasy/comedy movie from 1994. It was written and directed by Tia Brelis, inspired by a book of the same name written by her mother, Nancy Brelis. The film stars Sissy Spacek and Anna Chlumsky, and it's notable for being André the Giant's last acting role before he passed away a year before the movie's release.

Valentina is a romantic-comedy movie from Argentina, made in 2008 with traditional animation. It was shown in theaters in Argentina, Mexico, and Uruguay starting from July 24, 2008. It also had a small release in the United States later that year. However, it didn't do well at the box office outside Argentina, making it a commercial failure. The main characters are voiced by Florencia Otero (Valentina) and Sebastián Francini (Fede). Notably, it's the first full-length film produced by Illusion Studios.

question: For One Night Only was hosted by the man most well-known for hosting what show from 1962 until 1999?
pos: Gabriel Mary Gay Byrne, affectionately called Uncle Gay, Gaybo, or Uncle Gaybo, is an Irish radio and television presenter. He is best known for hosting The Late Late Show for 37 years, from 1962 to 1999, making it the world's second longest-running chat show. During his time at Granada Television in Britain, he also became the first person to introduce the Beatles on screen.

"For One Night Only" is a fun Irish TV show hosted by Gay Byrne. Each episode includes music and conversation with a special guest musician. It first aired on Friday nights during the summer of 2011 and came back for another season in 2012.
neg: WWE Extreme Rules is an annual wrestling event put on by WWE, a company based in Connecticut. It's only available to watch through pay-per-view or the WWE Network. "You and Me" is a song by One Night Only, from their album "Started a Fire" released in 2008. It was their first single, coming out on October 29, 2007, in both 7-inch vinyl and CD formats. "One Night Stand" is a video game made by Kinmoku. One Night Only is a British show that highlights the best of British music. It kicked off in December 2008, hosted by Myleene Klass alongside singer Tom Jones. Elton John's "One Night Only – The Greatest Hits" is a live album he released in 2000, recorded over two nights at Madison Square Garden. The album's title refers to a technical issue: most of the audio from the first night wasn't captured due to equipment failure, so only the second night was used for the album. WWE One Night Stand used to happen every June as a wrestling pay-per-view event by WWE, which is based in Connecticut. ELO Part II's live album, "One Night," was recorded during a concert at the Sydney Entertainment Centre in Australia on March 18-19, 1995, during the band's tour. question: What company did Roscoe Channing form with the owner of a leading stable of thoroughbred racehorses?
answer: Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company
pos: Roscoe H. Channing, Jr. was born in 1868 and passed away in 1961. He was known for being a star football player at Princeton University, earning recognition as an All-American halfback in 1889. During the Spanish–American War in 1898, he joined Theodore Roosevelt's Rough Riders, a unit Roosevelt took pride in for its inclusion of Ivy League football players. After his military service, Channing entered the mining industry, eventually teaming up with Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney in the 1920s to establish the Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company in Canada. Channing served as the company's President until his death.

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, also known as Sonny Whitney, was an accomplished American who dabbled in various fields including business, film production, writing, charity work, polo, and public service. He was also famous for owning a top-notch stable of racehorses.

The 2009 World Thoroughbred Rankings, released in January 2010 by the International Federation of Horseracing Authorities (IFHA), evaluated Thoroughbred racehorses aged three or older that participated in flat races throughout 2009. Opening in November 2002, this 304-acre center is considered one of the largest and most modern in the US horse racing industry.

The 2011 World Thoroughbred Rankings, issued by the International Federation of Horseracing Authorities (IFHA) in January 2011, assessed Thoroughbred racehorses aged three or older who participated in flat races during that year. It considered horses from any location or training background.

Night Raid, born in 1918 in England, was a prominent sire in Australia known for producing top-quality Thoroughbred racehorses. Among his notable offspring are Phar Lap and Nightmarch, both renowned racehorses in their own right.

The list of top Thoroughbred racehorses includes undefeated ones and those with outstanding records in specific categories. question: Jens Risom introduced what type of design, characterized by minimalism and functionality?
pos: Jens Risom, born on May 8, 1916, and passed away on December 9, 2016, was a Danish American furniture designer. He's known for his contributions to Mid-Century modern design and for being among the first to bring Scandinavian design to the United States.

Scandinavian design, which started in the 1950s in Finland, Norway, Sweden, Iceland, and Denmark, is known for its simple, minimalistic, and functional approach. Although "Scandinavia" technically refers to only Denmark, Sweden, and Norway, people often use it to include all five countries.
neg: Workflow Resource Planning, a term coined by Charles Lim Chee Pang in 2003, refers to a new type of Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) Software. Unlike traditional ERP systems that focus on data entry and processing, Lim introduced a new approach with the first WRP software, Radix ERP. While workflow functionality wasn't novel, having been pioneered by Lotus Notes until its decline in the early 2000s, Lim innovatively integrated it into ERP systems, resulting in Radix WRP, a unique ERP system with enhanced workflow management capabilities.

An NTFS symbolic link, also known as a symlink, is a type of file in the NTFS filesystem that acts as a shortcut to another file or directory. The file or directory it points to is called the target. When you use a symbolic link, it appears like a regular file or directory, and you can interact with it just like any other file. In NTFS 3.0 (which came with Windows 2000), symbolic links to directories or volumes were introduced as junction points and mount points. Starting from NTFS 3.1 (with Windows XP), you could create symbolic links for any type of file system object. Although NTFS 3.1 was launched with Windows XP, its functionality wasn't directly accessible to user mode applications without additional software like Masatoshi Kimura's opensource codice_1 driver. However, with the release of ntfs.sys in Windows Vista, symbolic link functionality became available to user mode applications by default.

Jens Ritter Instruments, founded by Jens Ritter in the mid-1990s, initially specialized in crafting high-end electric bass guitars under the name Ritter Bass Guitars until 2010. Jens later expanded his offerings to include guitars. Operating from a workshop in Deidesheim, Germany, Jens handcrafts around 50 to 60 instruments annually. Renowned bassists like Phil Lesh, Josh Dunham, and Doug Wimbish favor Ritter Basses. The instruments are celebrated for their innovative design, meticulous craftsmanship, unique aesthetic, and limited availability. Additionally, Jens Ritter Instruments produces strings and other accessories.

Bio-inspired robotic locomotion is a new area of design that takes inspiration from nature to create robots. Instead of directly mimicking biological systems, it focuses on understanding them and then making simpler and more effective mechanisms for engineering purposes. This approach differs from biomimicry, which involves directly copying nature. Bio-inspired robotics explores how biological systems solve problems and aims to simplify and improve those solutions for specific tasks. Researchers in this field are interested in studying biological mechanisms like sensors, actuators, and materials, and applying them to robot design, particularly for locomotion. This article introduces various modes of animal locomotion and provides examples of bio-inspired robots inspired by them.

In US trademark law, the functionality doctrine stops manufacturers from trademarking specific product features. There are two parts to this doctrine: utilitarian functionality and aesthetic functionality. It's based on the idea that competition in product markets would suffer if newcomers couldn't add features that consumers want. Utilitarian functionality denies federal trademark protection to features that serve a useful purpose. Patent law, not trademark law, protects useful processes and inventions. Designs covered by patents are assumed to be functional unless proven otherwise. Aesthetic functionality denies trademark protection to design features added to enhance the product's appeal. These features are covered by copyright law, which protects creative works.

Jacqueline "Jackie" Winsor, born on October 20, 1941, in St. John's, Newfoundland, is a sculptor from Canada and the United States. Her artistic style emerged in the early 1970s as a response to minimalism, leading to classifications like post-minimalism, anti-form, and process art. Influenced by her personal experiences, Winsor's sculptures blend aspects of Minimalism and feminism. They emphasize basic geometric shapes and symmetrical structures but diverge from Minimalism by using handmade, natural materials like wood and hemp instead of industrial ones.

Extensibility in software engineering and system design is about planning for future growth. It's like making sure that adding new stuff or changing existing stuff won't mess up everything else. So, when you want to make your system do more things or change how it works, you can do it without causing big problems. It's important because software is always getting updated and improved, and extensibility makes it easier to add new features or use parts of the software in different ways. Ways to do this include letting users add their own program bits and creating new types of data or formatting tags.

In simple terms, an HTML attribute changes how an HTML element works. It either alters how a specific element behaves by default or adds features to elements that need them to work properly. In HTML, you include attributes within the opening tag of an element.

"What's So Different?" is a song by R&B artist Ginuwine from his second album, "100% Ginuwine." It didn't quite make it into the Top 20 R&B charts but did crack the Top 50 on the pop charts. The Hunger Games movie series is made up of four films set in a dystopian future. They're based on Suzanne Collins' trilogy of novels. "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1" is a movie released in 2014. It's a dystopian science fiction adventure directed by Francis Lawrence. "Rhythm Divine" is a song by Enrique Iglesias from his album "Enrique" in 1999. It was released as the second single on October 9, 1999, by Interscope Records. question: What criteria subjectively qualifies the Houston Astrodome to be called the Eighth Wonder of the World?
answer: comparable to the seven Wonders of the World
pos: The NRG Astrodome, also called the Houston Astrodome or simply The Astrodome, is a famous sports stadium in Houston, Texas. It was the first dome stadium for various sports. Construction started in 1962, and it officially opened in 1965. It was the home of the Houston Astros baseball team from 1965 to 1999, the Houston Oilers football team from 1968 to 1996, and part-time home to the Houston Rockets basketball team from 1971 to 1975. It was also the main venue for the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo from 1966 to 2002. It was originally named the Harris County Domed Stadium and was nicknamed the Eighth Wonder of the World.
The "Eighth Wonder of the World" is a term used to describe new buildings, structures, projects, or designs that are considered as impressive as the original Seven Wonders of the World.
neg: "For the Last Time: Live From the Astrodome" is George Strait's inaugural live album, dropped in 2003. The title signifies that the concert captured on the album marked the end of events held at the Houston Astrodome.

Selena's "Live! The Last Concert" is a recording of her final live performance at the Houston Astrodome on February 26, 1995. The concert, also aired live on Univision, drew a crowd of 66,994 people, breaking the venue's attendance record. Released posthumously by EMI Latin on March 27, 2001, the album features Selena sharing the stage with Tejano singer Emilio Navaira. Critics praised the concert for outselling performances by country music stars like Vince Gill, Reba McEntire, and George Strait. Tragically, this performance marked Selena's final televised concert before her untimely death on March 31, 1995.

The 1973 Astro-Bluebonnet Bowl was held on December 29, 1973, at the Houston Astrodome in Texas. The teams playing were Tulane Green Wave and Houston Cougars, both independent football teams. Houston ended up winning the game with a score of 47–7.

Fearless is the first album by the British pop group Eighth Wonder, released in 1988. It's the only album they released in the UK and features entirely upbeat songs. The album includes six singles released in the UK, starting with "Stay With Me" in 1985, and notably includes their most popular track, "I'm Not Scared," produced and written by the Pet Shop Boys, which reached #7 on the charts, along with "Cross My Heart" reaching #13. Fearless reached #47 on the UK Albums Chart. Eighth Wonder disbanded in 1989, and lead singer Patsy Kensit pursued her acting career thereafter.

The Shreveport Steamer used to be a pro American football team in the World Football League. They started the 1974 season in Houston, Texas, as the Houston Texans (not the current NFL team with that name), playing home games at the Houston Astrodome. Later that season, they moved to Shreveport, Louisiana, and changed their name to the Shreveport Steamer. Their home stadium was the 30,000-seat State Fair Stadium, which is now called Independence Stadium.

In 1965, the Houston Astros played their first season at the Houston Astrodome and changed their name from the Colt .45s. They ended the season in ninth place in the National League with a record of 65 wins and 97 losses, trailing behind the Los Angeles Dodgers, who went on to win the World Series. Walt Suggs was both a college and professional American football player. He also participated in the first professional football game held at the Houston Astrodome in 1967 and was selected as an All-Star in 1967 and 1968 while playing in the American Football League.

"Brewster McCloud" is a 1970 experimental film directed by Robert Altman. The story revolves around a young recluse named Brewster McCloud, played by Bud Cort, who lives in a fallout shelter within the Houston Astrodome. He's working on building wings to fly and receives assistance from his fairy godmother, played by Sally Kellerman. However, Brewster becomes a suspect in a series of murders. The film was shot on location in Houston, Texas, showcasing landmarks like the downtown skyline, the Houston Astrodome, Astrohall, and the emerging Texas Medical Center. Notably, it was the first film to be shot inside the Astrodome.

question: Who was born first, José Echegaray y Eizaguirre or P. J. O'Rourke?

Mencken Research Fellow at the libertarian Cato Institute and writes for publications like The Atlantic Monthly, The American Spectator, and The Weekly Standard. You might also catch him on National Public Radio's game show Wait Wait... Don't Tell Me! Since 2011, he's been a columnist at The Daily Beast.

José Echegaray y Eizaguirre (1832–1916) was a versatile Spanish figure known for his work in engineering, mathematics, politics, and literature. Professor Wale Adebanwi, born in 1969 in Nigeria, is the first Black African Rhodes Professor at Oxford University.

Augustine of Canterbury, born around the early 6th century and likely passing away on May 26, 604, was a Benedictine monk. He later became the first Archbishop of Canterbury in 597, known for spreading Catholicism in England and being instrumental in establishing the Catholic Church in the country.

In Greek mythology, Despoina, also known as Despoena, was the daughter of Demeter and Poseidon. She was the sister of Arion and was worshipped as the goddess of mysteries in Arcadian cults. Alongside her mother Demeter, she was honored with the title "Despoina," which means mistress. She was also associated with the Eleusinian mysteries. Only those initiated into her mysteries were allowed to know her real name. Pausanias, a Greek traveler and geographer, mentioned Demeter's two daughters: Kore (also known as Persephone), who was born first, and Despoina, who was born later. Kore's father was Zeus, while Despoina's father was Poseidon. Pausanias didn't reveal Despoina's true name.

Patricio Echegaray, born on October 17, 1946, in San José de Jáchal, Argentina, was a prominent Argentine politician. Prior to this role, Echegaray served as the 26th General Secretary of the Juvenile Communist Federation from 1980 to 1985. Additionally, he was a member of the Buenos Aires City Legislature from 2000 to 2003.

The match took place on April 24th at Glanford Park in Scunthorpe, featuring Doncaster Belles and Knowsley United Women. Knowsley United made their debut in the final after losing in the previous season's FA Women's Premier League Cup final at Wembley. 2016年的英格兰足球协会女子足总杯决赛是英格兰女子足球队的主要杯赛的第46届决赛。这一盛大赛事是在英格兰足球协会（FA）直接主持下举行的第23届，由于赞助原因被称为SSE女子足总杯决赛。决赛于2016年5月14日在伦敦的温布利体育场举行，由阿森纳女足和切尔西女足对决。这场比赛是第二次在温布利举行的英格兰足球协会女子足总杯决赛。

In 2017, the FA Women's Cup Final was the 47th edition of England's main women's football cup competition. It was officially called the SSE Women's FA Cup Final due to sponsorship. It took place on May 6, 2002, at Selhurst Park in London, with Doncaster Belles facing Fulham Ladies. Fulham was making its second final appearance, having lost in 2001, while Doncaster Belles were in their record 13th final, having won the trophy six times before.

The 2000 FA Women's Cup Final was the 30th championship match of England's main cup competition for women's football teams. It was the seventh final organized directly by the Football Association (FA). The game took place between Doncaster Belles and Croydon Women at Bramall Lane in Sheffield on May 1, 2000. This was Croydon's third time in the final, having won in 1996 but lost in 1998. Doncaster Belles set a record by reaching their 12th final, having won the trophy six times before.

The 1997 FA Women's Cup Final was the 27th edition of England's primary women's football cup competition. It was the fourth final organized directly by the Football Association (FA) and was called the UK Living FA Women's Cup Final due to sponsorship. The match was played between Millwall Lionesses and Wembley at West Ham United's Upton Park in London on 4 May 1997. Millwall Lionesses had previously won the cup in 1991, while Wembley was making their first final appearance after winning the FA Women's Premier League Cup the previous season.

question: What act for Innocent Records achieved Platinum sales and shares its name with a primary color in the RGB color model?
pos: Blue sits between violet and green in the rainbow of colors we can see. When light falls within a range of 450 to 495 nanometers, our eyes perceive it as blue. If the light's wavelength is shorter, it looks more violet, and if it's longer, it seems more green. Pure blue falls right in the middle, with a wavelength of 470 nanometers. In art, blue is considered one of the main colors, along with red and yellow, which can be mixed to produce various shades. For instance, combining red and blue makes violet, while blue and yellow create green. Blue is also a key color in the RGB model, which is used to display colors on screens like TVs and computers.

Innocent Records was a pop record label created by EMI's Virgin Records to focus on pop music. After the success of the Spice Girls, Virgin Records wanted to enter the pop market and hired Hugh Goldsmith from RCA Records, known for turning Take That into a multi-platinum success. Goldsmith launched Innocent Records and signed artists like Billie Piper, Martine McCutcheon, and dance acts like Todd Terry. The label remained successful until the mid-2000s, with artists like Atomic Kitten and Blue achieving platinum sales.
neg: The ProPhoto RGB color space, also called ROMM RGB, was made by Kodak for photos. It has a big range of colors, covering more than 90% of possible colors you can see and 100% of common real-world colors. It's even bigger than Wide-gamut RGB. They picked the colors carefully to avoid changing hues when adjusting brightness. However, about 13% of the colors it can show aren't real or visible.

The YCoCg color model is created by changing an RGB color space into three parts: brightness (Y), green chrominance (Cg), and orange chrominance (Co). It's commonly used in video and image compression technologies like H.264/MPEG-4 AVC, HEVC, JPEG XR, and Dirac. It's popular because it's easy to calculate, provides good compression, and can convert to and from RGB using fewer bits than other color models.

A color space is how colors are organized, making it possible to accurately represent colors both in real life and on devices like screens. It can be set up in different ways: either by assigning specific colors to physical samples, like with Pantone, or by using mathematical formulas, like with Adobe RGB or sRGB. A color model, on the other hand, is a mathematical concept describing how colors are represented by numbers, like RGB or CMYK. However, if a color model isn't linked to a specific color space, it's just a random system with no universal meaning. By connecting a color model to a particular color space, you establish a defined range of colors, called a gamut. For instance, Adobe RGB and sRGB are two different color spaces based on the RGB model. Typically, color spaces are compared using standards like CIELAB or CIEXYZ, which cover all the colors humans can see.

HCL combines features from both cylindrical translations of RGB color space, like HSL and HSV, and the L*a*b* color space. While HSL and HSV are good at translating RGB colors consistently, they don't always match how humans see color variations in brightness. However, they can perform better than RGB in noisy environments. On the other hand, L*a*b* corresponds better to how humans perceive colors, but it struggles with maintaining consistent hue, particularly in the blue range.

RGBA represents red, green, blue, and alpha. It's often confused as a color space, but it's actually just an extension of the RGB color model, adding an alpha channel for transparency. The color itself is still based on RGB, and can be from any RGB color space. The alpha value, introduced by Catmull and Smith in the early 1970s, allows for alpha compositing, and it's named after the Greek letter used in the formula for linear interpolation: α A + (1 − α) B.

Brown is a mixture of colors. In printing or painting, you can create brown by blending red, black, and yellow, or red, yellow, and blue. On screens and monitors, like TVs and computers, brown comes from combining red and green in specific amounts. You can find brown in many natural things like wood, soil, human hair, eye color, and skin tone. It's often associated with dark wood or fertile soil. Interestingly, surveys in Europe and the US suggest that brown is generally disliked and connected with simplicity, rural life, waste, and being poor.
The RGB color model combines red, green, and blue light to create different colors. It's called RGB because it uses the initials of these three primary colors.

An RGB color space is a way to represent colors using the RGB color model. It's defined by three main colors: red, green, and blue. With these colors, you can create any other color within the range they define. To fully describe an RGB color space, you also need to know the white point (like the color of pure white) and a way to adjust how colors appear (gamma correction). The most widely used RGB color space is sRGB, which has been the standard since 2007.

question: What national historic district is located near a village in the town of Philipstown, New York?
pos: Valhalla Highlands Historic District, also known as Lake Valhalla, is a special place in Putnam County, New York, near Cold Spring. It's a national historic area with 57 important buildings, 11 sites, 10 structures, and 7 objects, along with a 900-acre forest. Originally, it was a getaway spot for people from New York City, mostly Germans, Austrians, and Norwegians. It started growing in the 1930s and 1940s, featuring lodges made of stone or logs, with cozy chimneys and terraces. There are also recreational spots like a boat lodge with ping-pong, a swimming dock, a tea pavilion, and more, all nestled within the beautiful forest.

Cold Spring, a village in Philipstown, Putnam County, New York, United States, had a population of 1,983 as of the 2010 census. It borders Nelsonville and Garrison. The village's central area is part of the National Register of Historic Places as the Cold Spring Historic District, known for its well-preserved 19th-century buildings built for workers at the nearby West Point Foundry, also a Registered Historic Place. General Gouverneur K. Warren, a key figure in the Union Army during the Civil War, was born in Cold Spring. Situated in the Hudson Highlands, the village is at the Hudson River's deepest point, across from West Point, and is a popular weekend retreat for many New York City residents.
neg: Arrow Rock is a village in Missouri, USA, close to the Missouri River, and it's super important historically. It's linked to stuff like moving west, the Santa Fe Trail, and a famous 19th-century artist named George Caleb Bingham. It's got the state's first-ever historic site, and the whole village is part of the National Historic Landmark Arrow Rock Historic District, recognized by the National Park Service in 1963. Loads of buildings here are also separately listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Plus, some spots are certified as part of the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail and the Santa Fe National Historic Trail.

The Greater Newport Rural Historic District in Giles County, Virginia, is a national historic area that includes 737 buildings and 25 structures. It's situated near the village of Newport and covers the previously listed Newport Historic District. This area features mainly farmsteads and complexes from the 19th and early 20th centuries. Some notable buildings include the Camper Cabin from the late 18th century, the Albert Meredith Cabin from around 1840, the E. L. Lucas House from around 1850, the Moses Atkins House from 1837, the William Lafon House from 1855, the Doak Lucas House from 1860, the Leonard Kessinger House from 1871, the Martin Farrier House from 1905, the Steve and Lori Taylor House from 1938, the Upper Spruce Run School from 1890, the Clover Hollow Christian Church from 1921, the Sherry Memorial Church, the Old Cook Mill from around 1910, three diminutive Burr covered bridges, a smelting furnace from 1871, the Mountain Lake Hotel Resort, and the Biological Station of the University of Virginia from 1934.

The Gilbert Town Historic District in North Carolina includes three archaeological sites and is a recognized national historic area. It was a significant trading hub from 1776 to 1783 and hosted both Patriot and Loyalist forces during the American Revolutionary War. Gilbert Town featured various establishments like the William Gilbert House, a store, tavern, mill, and blacksmith shop. It also served as the location for the Rutherford County Courthouse between 1781 and 1783. These sites are situated near Rock Road, which is part of the Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail.

Elmwood Historic District–West is a special area in Buffalo, New York, recognized for its historical significance. It includes nearly 2,000 buildings, along with some structures and objects, in the Elmwood Village neighborhood. This district is closely tied to Buffalo's Parks and Parkways system and is bordered by Delaware Park, Forest Lawn Cemetery, the former Buffalo State Asylum to the north, the Allentown Historic District to the south, and the Elmwood Historic District–East to the east. Most of the buildings here were constructed between 1867 and 1941, showcasing various architectural styles like Queen Anne, Shingle Style, Colonial Revival, Tudor Revival, and American Craftsman. It's considered one of the best-preserved collections of early 20th-century architecture in Buffalo and western New York State. Some notable landmarks include the Richmond Avenue Methodist-Episcopal Church and the Buffalo Tennis and Squash Club. There are also other significant buildings like the H.C. Gerber House, the Fred Dullard House, and St. John’s-Grace Episcopal Church, among others.

The Calumet Downtown Historic District, also called the Red Jacket Downtown Historic District, is situated in Calumet, Michigan, specifically on 5th and 6th Streets, between Scott and Pine Streets. This area is part of the larger Calumet Historic District and the Keweenaw National Historical Park. Recognized as a Michigan State Historic Site since 1973, it was officially listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1974.

The Glimmerglass Historic District in Otsego County, New York, near Cooperstown, is a nationally recognized area covering 15,000 acres. It includes parts of Otsego, Springfield, and Middlefield towns, as well as Cooperstown village, focusing on the area around Otsego Lake. The district contains 1,475 significant features, such as the Cooperstown Historic District, the U.S. Post Office in Cooperstown, and Hyde Hall in Glimmerglass State Park, which were previously listed as historic sites.

Elmwood Historic District–East is a special area in Buffalo, New York, recognized for its historical significance. It includes over 2,400 buildings, 31 structures, and 14 objects, all part of the Elmwood Village neighborhood. The district is bordered by Delaware Park, Forest Lawn Cemetery, and the former Buffalo State Asylum to the north, the Allentown Historic District to the south, and the Elmwood Historic District–West to the west. It's mainly residential and was developed between 1867 and 1965, showcasing various architectural styles like Queen Anne, Shingle, Colonial Revival, Tudor Revival, and American Craftsman. It's known for preserving the essence of the early 20th century in Buffalo and western New York, with notable landmarks like the Buffalo Seminary, Garret Club, and the William R. Heath House designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.

Cromwell's Run Rural Historic District is a special area recognized for its historical significance, found near Rectortown in Fauquier County, Virginia. This district contains 384 buildings, 20 sites, and 36 structures that have contributed to its historical importance. Notably, it also includes the Atoka Historic District and Rectortown Historic District, which are listed separately.

question: Which American writer wrote both The Ganymede Takeover (1967) and The Man in the High Castle (1962)?
pos: The Ganymede Takeover, written in 1967 by American authors Philip K. Dick and Ray Nelson, is a sci-fi story about aliens invading Earth. It's like Dick's earlier book, The Game-Players of Titan. Interestingly, Dick initially planned for it to be a sequel to his book The Man in the High Castle, where the Japanese occupied the United States instead of Ganymede.

"The Man in the High Castle" (1962) is a book by Philip K. Dick that imagines a different outcome to World War II. It's set in 1962, where the Axis Powers, mainly Japan and Germany, won the war and now control the former United States. The story explores the power struggles and life under their rule. The book won the Hugo Award for Best Novel in 1963, and it was later turned into a TV series starting in 2015.
neg: Nobuteru Yūki, a Japanese manga artist, illustrator, and animator, was born on December 24, 1962, in Tokyo. Starting out as a doujinshi artist using the names "The Man in the High Castle" and "Ubik," inspired by the writings of American science fiction author Philip K. Dick, Yūki has contributed to various manga, anime, and video game projects. He's best known for his collaboration with director Kazuki Akane, notably on "The Vision of Escaflowne," where he designed characters.

The Man in the High Castle is a TV show made by Amazon Studios, Scott Free Productions, Headline Pictures, Electric Shepherd Productions, and Big Light Productions. It's inspired by a book written by Philip K. Dick in 1962. The show portrays an alternate version of America in 1962 where the Axis powers won World War II, splitting the US into the Greater Nazi Reich and the Japanese Pacific States. The story revolves around characters who encounter propaganda films depicting a different history than their own, leading their lives to intersect in unexpected ways.

"Vulcan's Hammer" is a sci-fi book written by Philip K. Dick in 1960. It was first published as part of an Ace Double. This book marked the end of Dick's earlier, more pulp-style sci-fi writing from the 1950s, just before he gained more recognition for his acclaimed work like "Man in the High Castle," which won a Hugo Award and was published the following year.
Tzi Ma, born on June 10, 1962, is an actor from Hong Kong who has appeared in many American movies and TV shows like Dante's Peak, Rush Hour, 24, and The Man in the High Castle.

hartbeat! was a German music magazine that ran from 1984 to 1998. It covered various music genres like punk rock, power pop, garage rock, beat music, rock, and psychedelic music, spanning from the 1960s to the late 1990s. The magazine was published in English but not on a regular schedule. It was edited by Hans-Jürgen Klitsch, who also authored two books about the German Beatscene of the 1960s: "Shakin' All Over - Die Beatmusik in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland 1963 - 1967" (High Castle 2000; revised 2001) and "Otto & die Beatlejungs - Die Beatszene der 60er Jahre zwischen Oldenburg, Emden und Wilhelmshaven" (Isensee 2008).

"Aye, and Gomorrah, and other stories" is a book by American writer Samuel R. Delany, published by Vintage Books in 2003. It's a collection of stories organized by theme, similar to books like James Joyce’s "Dubliners," Sherwood Anderson’s "Winesburg, Ohio," and Willa Cather’s "Youth and the Bright Medusa." This book is closely based on an earlier collection called "Driftglass," which came out in 1971. The dedication for both books is similar, honoring Delany’s immediate family: his maternal grandmother, mother, sister, and father. "Aye, and Gomorrah" contains all ten tales from "Driftglass," plus five additional stories. The stories include ten science fiction tales, followed by five fantasies, presented in the order the author wrote them.

Eric Ellis Overmyer, born on September 25, 1951, is an American writer and producer known for his work on several TV shows. He has been involved in the writing and production of various series such as St. Elsewhere, Law & Order, The Wire, New Amsterdam, Bosch, Treme, and The Man in the High Castle.

In 1909, a British writer noted that the Kanakkan people, who are from a scheduled caste community, were wearing a sacred thread typically reserved for high caste Brahmins. This observation is peculiar because it goes against the usual practice.

question: Curt Menefee is the host of the Fox network's NFL show with co-host Michael Anthony Strahan who spent his entire 15-year career with what team?
pos: Michael Strahan is a retired American football player who spent his whole career with the New York Giants. He's known for setting a record for the most sacks in a season in 2001 and winning Super Bowl XLII in 2007. After retiring, he became a TV personality, working as a football analyst on Fox NFL Sunday and co-hosting Live! with Kelly and Michael from 2012 to 2016. He's also been a regular contributor on Good Morning America since 2014. He's been inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame and hosts The $100,000 Pyramid.

Curt Menefee, born on July 22, 1965, is an American sportscaster known for hosting the Fox network's NFL show, Fox NFL Sunday. He shares the spotlight with co-hosts Jimmy Johnson, Terry Bradshaw, Howie Long, and Michael Strahan.
neg: Ray Nitschke, born on December 29, 1936, and passed away on March 8, 1998, was a skilled middle linebacker in American football. He played for the Green Bay Packers for his entire 15-year career in the NFL. Nitschke was an essential part of the team's defense during the 1960s under coach Vince Lombardi. He helped the Packers secure five NFL championships and win the first two Super Bowls. He's now honored in the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

Al Dirt Wilson, born on April 6, 1950, played professional Canadian football for the BC Lions in the Canadian Football League (CFL). He spent his entire 15-year career as an offensive lineman for the Lions. Before that, he played college football at Montana State University. Wilson is highly regarded in the football community, being inducted into the Canadian Football Hall of Fame, the B.C. Sports Hall of Fame, and the B.C. Lions Wall of Fame. He even has a street named after him in his hometown of Duncan, called Al Wilson Grove. Additionally, his jersey number, #52, is one of the eight numbers retired by the B.C. Lions. He was also honored as a member of the B.C. Lions All-Time Dream Team in 2003 and was recognized in 2006 by TSN as one of the top 50 players in the CFL's modern era.

Charissa Jean Thompson, born on May 4, 1982, is an American TV host and sports broadcaster known for her work on Fox Sports 1 and NBC. Before that, she was with ESPN, Versus, GSN, and the Big Ten Network. She co-hosted SportsNation with Marcellus Wiley until leaving ESPN for Fox Sports in June 2013. Thompson then hosted Fox Sports Live when Fox Sports 1 launched on August 17, 2013. She also co-hosted Ultimate Beastmaster and was on Extra from 2014 to 2017.

Tamika Devonne Catchings Smith, born on July 21, 1979, is a retired American professional basketball player. She spent her entire 15-year career with the Indiana Fever in the WNBA. Throughout her career, Catchings achieved numerous accolades including a WNBA championship in 2012, the WNBA Most Valuable Player Award in 2011, and the WNBA Finals MVP Award in 2012. She also earned five WNBA Defensive Player of the Year Awards, four Olympic gold medals, and the WNBA Rookie of the Year Award in 2002. Additionally, she was chosen for ten WNBA All-Star teams, 12 All-WNBA teams, and 12 All-Defensive teams, while leading the league in steals eight times. She's part of a select group of nine women who have won an Olympic Gold Medal, an NCAA Championship, and a WNBA Championship. In 2011, Catchings was named one of the WNBA's Top 15 Players of All Time by fan vote.

Michael Peter Hjälm, born on March 23, 1963, was a Swedish ice hockey player. He represented Sweden in the Winter Olympics of 1984 and 1988, winning bronze medals in both. Although he was picked by the Philadelphia Flyers in the 1982 NHL Entry Draft, he chose to play his entire 15-season career in Sweden.

Fiona Forbes, a Canadian TV host, used to host the entertainment talk show Urban Rush on Shaw Cable and worked on CityTV's Breakfast Television. Currently, she hosts The Rush in Vancouver. In 2002, she and her co-host Michael Eckford won a Leo Award for best variety show hosts.

Merlin Jay Olsen was an American football player, announcer, and actor. He spent his entire 15-year professional football career in the NFL as a defensive tackle for the Los Angeles Rams. Olsen was chosen for the Pro Bowl a record 14 times in a row, missing selection only in the final year of his career. This achievement is shared with Bruce Matthews, Tony Gonzalez, and Peyton Manning. Olsen won the 1961 Outland Trophy as the best lineman in college football and is a member of both the Pro Football Hall of Fame and the College Football Hall of Fame. As an actor, he is known for his role as farmer Jonathan Garvey on Little House on the Prairie and later starred in his own NBC drama, Father Murphy.

William Ashley Freehan, born on November 29, 1941, was a catcher for the Detroit Tigers throughout his 15-year career in Major League Baseball. He was one of the top catchers in the American League during the 1960s and early 1970s, earning All-Star honors in eleven seasons when he caught at least 75 games. Freehan played a crucial role in the success of the 1968 Tigers, who won the championship, particularly for his management of star pitchers like Mickey Lolich and Denny McLain. He won the Gold Glove Award five times and held records for career fielding percentage, putouts, and total chances for a significant period. Freehan retired with impressive stats, including 200 home runs and 2,502 total bases, placing him among the best AL catchers of his time, only trailing Yogi Berra and Bill Dickey.

question: Francisco Jose Hernandez was a participant in an invasion that took place in what year?
pos: The Bay of Pigs Invasion, also known as Invasión de Playa Girón or Invasión de Bahía de Cochinos or Batalla de Girón in Spanish, was a failed attempt by a group called Brigade 2506 to invade Cuba with the support of the CIA on April 17, 1961. This group was made up of Cuban exiles who had left Cuba after Fidel Castro took power, and they were trained and funded by the CIA. Their goal was to overthrow Castro's government, which was becoming more communist. The invasion started from Guatemala and Nicaragua but was quickly defeated by the Cuban Revolutionary Armed Forces led by Castro within three days.

Pepe, born Francisco José Hernández on September 1, 1936, in Havana, is a Cuban exile from the 1960s. He's known for being anti-Castro and taking part in the Bay of Pigs Invasion. He co-founded and serves as president of the Cuban American National Foundation. They say they're now adopting a less direct stance against the Cuban government.
neg: Mikhail Sergeyevich Lunin, also known as Mikhaïl Lounine, was a Russian thinker and activist born on December 29, 1787, who played various roles during his lifetime. He served in the military during the Napoleonic invasion and later became involved in several liberal secret societies in the early 19th century, like the Union of Salvation and the Union of Welfare. Following his participation in the Decembrist Revolt of 1825, Lunin was arrested due to his associations with the rebels and was sent to a labor camp in Siberia. Despite enduring time in Finnish jails, multiple Siberian prisons, and government-monitored farm life as an exile, Lunin remained resilient and critical of autocratic rule. He was later imprisoned again for his oppositional writings against the Russian government and spent the remainder of his life in confinement.

Theodore Rodger Kubiak, born on May 12, 1942, used to play baseball for several teams including the Kansas City Athletics, the Oakland Athletics, the Milwaukee Brewers, the St. Louis Cardinals, the Texas Rangers, and the San Diego Padres. He was part of the Oakland Athletics when they won three consecutive World Series from 1972 to 1974. Kubiak's notable achievement is holding the Brewers' record for the most RBIs (Runs Batted In) in a single game, which is seven. He achieved this on July 18, 1970, during the team's inaugural year in Milwaukee. This achievement is particularly impressive because Kubiak wasn't known for his batting skills.

Invasion, a wrestling event by the World Wrestling Federation (now WWE) and sponsored by PlayStation, happened on July 22, 2001, at the Gund Arena in Cleveland, Ohio. Originally meant to be called Fully Loaded, it became the first pay-per-view to dive into the Invasion storyline, pitting WWF wrestlers against a mix of WCW and ECW wrestlers, forming The Alliance.

The 2003 MLS Cup, the eighth championship match of Major League Soccer, saw the Chicago Fire face off against the San Jose Earthquakes to determine the season's champion. Played on November 23, 2003, at The Home Depot Center in Carson, California, San Jose clinched victory with a 4–2 win over Chicago, thanks to Richard Mulrooney's goal in the 50th minute. This marked San Jose's second MLS Cup win in three years. Notably, it was the first MLS Cup where both teams wore their usual uniforms and the first final between two previous MLS Cup winners. Additionally, it set a record for the highest-scoring final, with a total of 6 goals scored.

Francisco Jose Frank Martin, born on March 23, 1966, is a basketball coach from the United States. He's currently in charge of coaching the men's basketball team at the University of South Carolina. Before his current role, Martin spent five seasons as the head coach at Kansas State University. Earlier in his career, he worked as an assistant coach at colleges and as the head basketball coach at three high schools in Miami. Martin's teams have made it to the NCAA Tournament five times under his leadership, and he earned the title of Big 12 Conference Men's Basketball Coach of the Year in 2010.

The Allied invasion of Italy happened on September 3, 1943, during World War II. General Sir Harold Alexander led the operation with the 15th Army Group, which included General Mark W. Clark and General Bernard Montgomery's British Eighth Army. It came after the Allies had taken Sicily. The main landing was near Salerno on September 9, with supporting operations in Calabria (Operation Baytown) and Taranto (Operation Slapstick).

The Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty, also known as the Treaty of Taipei, was signed in Taipei, Taiwan on April 28, 1952, officially ending the Second Sino-Japanese War. This agreement was necessary because the Republic of China (ROC) and the People's Republic of China were not invited to sign the Treaty of San Francisco, which ended World War II, due to disagreements about which Chinese government was legitimate. Under pressure from the United States, Japan signed a separate peace treaty with the ROC to formally end the conflict, even though the ROC wasn't part of the San Francisco Peace Conference because the Chinese Civil War had resumed. Despite this, the terms of the Treaty of Taipei were largely similar to those of the San Francisco Treaty, and notably, the ROC waived reparations from Japan as stated in Article 14(a) of the San Francisco Treaty.

The Battle of Clitheroe happened on June 10, 1138, during a chaotic time called The Anarchy. It was a fight between Scottish and English soldiers near Clitheroe, Lancashire. King David I of Scotland led an invasion into England and split his army into two groups. One group, led by William fitz Duncan, attacked Lancashire, causing trouble in Furness and Craven. On June 10, they clashed with English knights and soldiers. The English lost, setting the stage for the Battle of the Standard later that summer, where the outcome was different.

question: Dead but Rising was a song by the Danish band fomed in what city in 2001?
pos: "Dead but Rising" is a song by the Danish heavy metal band Volbeat. It was released as the seventh single from their fifth studio album, "Outlaw Gentlemen & Shady Ladies."

Volbeat is a heavy metal band from Denmark, formed in Copenhagen in 2001. They mix rock and roll, heavy metal, and rockabilly in their music. Their influences range from classic rock and roll icons like Elvis Presley and Johnny Cash to modern hard rock, thrash metal, heavy metal, alternative rock, and hardcore punk bands. The band's current members are vocalist and guitarist Michael Poulsen, guitarist Rob Caggiano, drummer Jon Larsen, and bassist Kaspar Boye Larsen. They're signed to Mascot Records in the Netherlands and have put out six studio albums and one DVD. All of their studio albums have achieved gold status in Denmark. Their second album, "Rock the Rebel/Metal the Devil," went platinum, while their 2010 release, "Beyond Hell/Above Heaven," earned widespread international acclaim, going double platinum in Denmark, platinum in Finland and Germany, and gold in the United States, Sweden, and Austria. Their sixth album, "Seal the Deal & Let's Boogie," was released worldwide on June 3, 2016.
neg: "Better Than Yourself (Criminal Mind Pt 2)" is a song by the Danish band Lukas Graham. It was released on October 22, 2012, as a digital download in Denmark and reached number one on the Danish Singles Chart. The song was written by Lukas Forchhammer, Rasmus Hedegaard, and Brandon Beal. The opening piano part of the song is directly taken from Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata.

"Dancin' (on a Saturday Night)" is a song written by Lynsey de Paul and Barry Blue. It was first recorded by Barry Blue and released as a single in 1973 on Bell Records. The song performed well, reaching number 2 on the UK Singles Chart, number 2 on the Australian Kent Music chart, number 9 on the German singles chart, and number 11 on the Dutch singles chart. Other artists like Flash Cadillac & the Continental Kids and bond released their versions as singles in subsequent years, with varying degrees of success on charts like Cashbox, Billboard Hot 100, and the CHUM Chart in Canada. Additionally, a Danish band called Clear Sound recorded a version with Danish lyrics by Finn Reiner, which reached number 17 on the Danish Hitlister. Junior Janson also released a version of the song as a single in 1975.

Claess and Willumsen is a Danish band formed by Claess Sorensen and Pelle Willumsen. Their debut album, "No Receipt," was released in 2007. They recorded and produced the album themselves, using equipment bought from garage sales and a single microphone purchased from a Danish composer who was moving to Hollywood. Despite facing challenges, some of their songs made their way onto US television and Danish radio. The album was released online in most parts of the world, and some of the songs have been sold in Canada, Germany, and the USA. One of their songs, "Someday" (also known as "I'll Find My Way Someday"), was featured in the American television series "Army Wives" on Lifetime Television. In 2007, Claess & Willumsen signed a contract with NOMA Music.

The Danish band Blue Foundation released their album "Life of a Ghost" first in Scandinavia in 2007 and later in the USA in 2009. One of the album's tracks, "Eyes on Fire," gained popularity after being included in the soundtrack of the 2008 film Twilight. Additionally, the group Zeds Dead remixed "Eyes on Fire."

Home Dead is a short album released in 2001 by the Danish band Kashmir. It came out after their successful album The Good Life but before they found their new sound with Zitilites. The music on this EP reflects the struggles shown in Rocket Brothers, a documentary about the band.

"The Danish Way to Rock" is a Danish song created for the 2010 FIFA World Cup, performed by the Danish band Nephew with the national team, known as Landsholdet. It quickly rose to the top spot on the Danish Singles Chart.

"Søndagsbarn" is a song by the Danish hip hop group Suspekt, featuring vocals from the Danish band Lukas Graham. It was released as a digital download in Denmark on May 22, 2015, under Tabu Records. The song reached number three on the Danish Singles Chart.

"Re-Sepp-Ten" is a Danish football anthem from 1986, released by Replay Records as the battle cry for Denmark's national football team during the 1986 FIFA World Cup in Mexico. It's credited to VM Holdet, the nickname for the Danish national team, also known as Landsholdet. The song was recorded at the Werner studio by members of the Danish team, along with contributions from Dodo Gad, Jens Rud, and Steen Christiansen of the Danish band Dodo and the Dodos, as well as Poul Halberg and Henrik Stanley Møller. The music was composed by Michael Bruun and arranged and produced by him.

question: The man, who the award in which "Summer of the Monkeys" won, was a spokesman for white sector of America?
pos: "Summer of the Monkeys" is a kids' book from 1976 by Wilson Rawls. It won the William Allen White Book Award and the California Young Reader Medal. It was first published by Doubleday and later by Yearling Books.

William Allen White (February 10, 1868 – January 29, 1944) was an American newspaper editor, politician, author, and leader of the Progressive movement. From 1896 until he passed away, White spoke up for the concerns of average Americans.
neg: Mike Smith began his career at MCA Publishing in 1988 as a scout, where he discovered and signed bands like Blur and Levitation, as well as scouted The Smashing Pumpkins. Later, he joined EMI Publishing in 1992 and continued to sign notable acts such as PJ Harvey, Elastica, and Supergrass, eventually becoming Head of A&R. Moving to Columbia Records UK in 2006 as Managing Director, he signed artists like Mark Ronson and Calvin Harris. Over the years, he also brought on board talents like The Ting Tings, MGMT, and Glasvegas. His tenure saw signings like Miike Snow, Lissie, and Magnetic Man, among others, contributing to the label's diverse roster. Throughout his career, he also managed artists like Kings of Leon, Bruce Springsteen, and Foo Fighters.

Vance Powell is an accomplished American record producer, engineer, and mixer who has won four Grammy Awards. He has worked with a diverse range of artists, including Chris Stapleton, Jack White, Tyler Bryant & The Shakedown, and many more.

Hätteberget is a Swedish lighthouse located in the sea to the west of Marstrand and south of Tjörn. It was constructed in 1977 to replace the old Pater Noster Lighthouse. This lighthouse stands 26 meters tall, made of concrete, and includes a helipad. Its design features a red belt around the tower and a gray cap on its peak. The light emitted from the white sector can be seen from a distance of 21.5 nautical miles.

Søren Solkær, born on September 3, 1969, previously known as Søren Solkær Starbird, is a Danish photographer famous for taking portraits of musicians. He's well-known for capturing iconic images of artists like Björk, The White Stripes, Franz Ferdinand, David Lynch, Arctic Monkeys, R.E.M., and U2.

The Australian Ecology Research Award (AERA) is given out by the Ecological Society of Australia to recognize the excellent work of mid-career researchers in the field of ecology. It started in 2008, partly inspired by a similar award from the Ecological Society of America. The AERA isn't limited to one area and seeks to honor exceptional ecological research from various sectors, including academia, public agencies, and private organizations. Nominations for deserving researchers are accepted every year.

The Holden-Keating Gang, led by Thomas James Holden and Francis Keating, robbed banks in the Midwest of the United States between 1925 and 1939. Holden was labeled by an FBI representative as a significant danger to everyone in America and became the first fugitive listed on the FBI's Top Ten Most Wanted List in 1950.

Curtis Jack Glencross, born on December 28, 1982, is a former Canadian professional ice hockey player. He wasn't chosen by any team initially but joined the Anaheim Mighty Ducks in 2004 as a free agent and started playing in the NHL with them in 2007. Throughout his career, he played for various teams including the Columbus Blue Jackets, Edmonton Oilers, Calgary Flames, and Washington Capitals. In Calgary, he was known for scoring goals and being involved in community activities, earning him the Ralph T. Scurfield Humanitarian Award in 2012. After playing for both Calgary and Washington in the 2014–15 season, he couldn't secure a contract with any NHL team and decided to retire. Glencross also supported the Special Olympics during his career and competed with Rae Croteau Jr.'s chuckwagon racing team in the summer.

Horace Bumstead (born in September 1841, died in January 1919) was a minister and educator who worked hard to improve education for African Americans. He served as the second president of Atlanta University from 1888 to 1907. Bumstead was unusual because he was one of the earliest white Americans to advocate for African American education. Despite facing criticism for his efforts, many African Americans supported him and saw him as their advocate.

question: Which lead actor/actress in War Chhod Na Yaar has also acted in Bengali and English-language films?
pos: The movie "War Chhod Na Yaar" is a Hindi Indian war comedy film released in 2013. It's directed and written by Faraz Haider, with dialogues by Deepak Kingrani. The film was announced on March 30, 2013, during a launch party at Novotel Hotel. Lead actors Sharman Joshi, Soha Ali Khan, Javed Jaffery, Sanjai Mishra, Dalip Tahil, and Mukul Dev were present at the event.
Soha Ali Khan Khemu, born on October 4, 1978, is an Indian actress famous for her roles in Hindi movies. She has also appeared in Bengali and English films.

Gita Dey, born on August 5, 1931, and passed away on January 17, 2011, was a well-known actress in Bengali Tollywood films, theater, and Bengali folk theater. She began her career as a stage artist at the age of 6 and entered the film industry in 1943, with her first film release being "Ahuti" (1941), where she appeared as a child actress. Throughout her career, she acted in over two hundred Bengali language films and performed in over two thousand stage shows. Some of her notable roles include appearances in movies like "Teen Kanya" directed by Satyajit Ray and Ritwik Ghatak's "Meghe Dhaka Tara," "Subarnarekha," "Komal Gandhar," and "Kato Ajanare." She also ventured into Hindi cinema, starring in films like "Parineeta" (2005) alongside Vidya Balan and Sanjay Dutt. Apart from her work in film and theater, she had a long association with All India Radio, where she performed in Shruti Natok. Over her lifetime, she received various awards, including the Presidential Award for Lifetime Achievement from Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam.

Debashree Roy, an Indian actress, has starred in over a hundred films, winning a National Award for her work in Bengali cinema. She gained prominence in the 1980s and 1990s as a leading actress, starting her career as a child artist in the 1966 Bengali film "Pagal Thakur." Her transition to adult roles came in 1978 with "Nadi Theke Sagare." She rose to stardom with roles in films like "Dadar Kirti" (1980) and "36 Chowringhee Lane" (1981). While she ventured into Hindi cinema with films like "Jiyo To Aise Jiyo" (1981) and "Kabhi Ajnabi The" (1985), her Bollywood career faced setbacks, notably with the latter being a box office flop. However, her pairing with Tapas Paul in films like "Bhalobasa Bhalobasa" (1985) established them as a popular on-screen couple. They went on to deliver several successful films together throughout the 1980s and 1990s.

Anil Chatterjee was a Bengali actor known for his work in Bengali cinema from the early 1950s to the mid-1990s. He appeared in around 150 movies, including a few in Hindi. He was versatile, playing various roles, mainly as a character actor, but also as a lead or antagonist. Despite limited opportunities, he made a lasting impression on audiences and critics alike. He even starred in a TV serial called "Naqab" on Doordarshan. He's one of the rare actors to have worked with directors like Satyajit Ray, Ritwik Ghatak, Tapan Sinha, and Mrinal Sen, collaborating with the first three on multiple occasions. His portrayal of the title character in "Deshbandhu Chittaranjan," a biopic about the freedom fighter Chittaranjan Das, earned him praise from Basanti Devi, Das's wife, who reportedly blessed him personally.

Siddhartha Ramchandra Jadhav, an Indian actor and comedian, is well-known for his work in both Marathi and Hindi entertainment industries. He's starred in numerous Bollywood films such as "Golmaal" and "Golmaal Returns," but he expresses a strong preference for Marathi film, television, and stage productions. Additionally, he appeared in a Bengali film called "Ami Subhah Bolchi," featuring Mithun Chakraborty. Currently, he's teamed up with Bharti Singh on the TV show "Comedy Circus Ke Ajoobe," collaborating for three consecutive seasons.

Maharshi Raghava, originally named Raghava Gogineni, is an actor from Andhra Pradesh, India. He gained popularity by starring in over 170 films, playing different characters. His debut film, "Maharshi," catapulted him to fame and also led to him being called Maharshi. Additionally, he has appeared in television serials.

Utpal Dutta was an influential Indian actor, director, and writer-playwright known for his work in Bengali theatre. He started the Little Theater Group in 1949, staging various English, Shakespearean, and Brecht plays. Later, the group shifted towards highly political and radical theatre, reflecting Dutta's Marxist beliefs. His notable socio-political plays include "Kallol" (1965) and "Louha Manob" (1964). Dutta also had a prolific film career spanning 40 years, appearing in over 100 Bengali and Hindi films. He is best remembered for his roles in films like "Bhuvan Shome" (1969), "Agantuk" (1991), and popular Hindi comedies like "Gol Maal" (1979) and "Rang Birangi" (1983).

Farida Jalal, born in 1949, is an Indian actress famous for her roles in over two hundred Bollywood movies. While she's best known for her work in Hindi cinema, she's also appeared in Telugu, Tamil, and English-language films.

question: What type of movie are Wishing Stairs and Voice?
pos: "Wishing Stairs," also known as "Whispering Corridors 3: Wishing Stairs," is a South Korean horror film from 2003. It's part of the Whispering Corridors series, which is all about eerie events in girls' high schools. Each movie in the series stands alone, but in "Wishing Stairs," there's a song sung in one scene that plays a crucial role in the plot of "Voice."

Voice, also known as Whispering Corridors 4: Voice and Voice Letter, is a 2005 South Korean horror film. It's the fourth movie in the Whispering Corridors series. This film marked the debut of three young actresses and director Choi Ik-Hwan, who was an assistant director on the series' first film.
neg: Rimstone, also known as gours, is a type of cave formation that looks like a stone dam. It forms when minerals like calcite build up in pools inside caves. The resulting structure often resembles stairs and can connect with flowstone above or below it. On flat surfaces, you might find tiny structures called micro-gours covering the rimstone. Sometimes, rimstone can create terraces stretching over long distances, with individual basins reaching lengths of up to 200 feet, as seen in Tham Xe Biang Fai cave in Laos.

A voice type refers to a specific singing voice with distinct qualities like vocal range, weight, tessitura, timbre, and transition points (passaggio). Factors like physical attributes, speech level, scientific tests, and vocal register also play a role. Voice classification categorizes voices into types, a process used in classical music, particularly opera, to match roles with suitable voices. Different systems, like the German Fach system and choral music system, exist for voice classification, but there's no universal standard.

Ninnu Kori, which translates to "Wishing For You" in English, is a romantic Telugu film directed by newcomer Shiva Nirvana and produced by DVV Danayya under DVV Entertainments. It stars Nani and Nivetha Thomas in the lead roles, with Aadhi Pinisetty playing an important character. The music for the film was composed by Gopi Sunder. Prawin Pudi served as the editor, and Karthik Ghattamaneni worked as the cinematographer. Filming began in February 2017 in the United States after the movie's launch in November 2016. It was eventually released on July 7, 2017.

The Highland Inn, operating from 1908 to 1957, was a resort hotel managed by the Grand Trunk Railway in Algonquin Provincial Park, Ontario. Situated close to the park offices on Cache Lake's northern edge, it was a central feature of the park for a long time. In 1957, the Ontario Government bought the inn to restore the park to its natural state and removed it. Today, only remnants of the concrete stairs and platform that connected to the CNR line remain, as the railway was dismantled after the last train departed in 1959.
