"The list includes ancient spiral stairs built during ancient Greek and Roman times. Spiral stairs, which have a twisting structure, were not common in architecture until later. Even though the oldest one dates back to the 5th century BC, they became popular in Roman architecture after the design of Trajan's Column."

Callington Mill, a tower mill constructed in 1837 by John Vincent in Oatlands, Tasmania, has been recently restored and is now fully operational. It stands as the only working mill of its kind in the Southern Hemisphere and ranks as Australia's third oldest windmill. Alan Scott, a traditional baker and blacksmith, played a significant role at the mill. Today, it serves as a prominent tourist attraction in Oatlands, offering visitors the opportunity to ascend internal stairs for panoramic views of the town and its surroundings. The mill site includes various structures such as the windmill itself, a granary, stable, miller’s cottage, and the mill owner’s house.

Cheon Soo-yeon, also known as Song Ji-hyo, is a South Korean actress and model. She began her acting career in 2003 with the horror film Wishing Stairs. Since then, she has gained fame for her roles in various genres, including romantic comedy, historical drama, crime, and family melodrama. Notable works include Princess Hours (2006), Jumong (2006), A Frozen Flower (2008), New World (2013), Emergency Couple (2014), and My Wife's Having an Affair this Week (2016).

The Exchange Ilford is the main shopping mall in the town center of Ilford, London. It used to be owned by The Mall Fund but has now been sold and is called The Exchange Mall again. It has three levels of shops, but the layout means the bottom level is split into two parts, so customers have to go through the middle level to access both sections. There's also an upper level with more shops and a food court, which you can reach from the middle level. You can move between the levels using lifts, stairs, and escalators inside the mall. Some stores have shops on multiple levels.

question: Which cast member of Alice Upside Down also stars in the ABC Family/Freeform drama "Switched at Birth?"
pos: "Alice Upside Down" is a movie from 2007, based on the Alice book series by Phyllis Reynolds Naylor. It was filmed at Bishop DuBourg High School in St. Louis, Missouri, USA. Initially, it had a limited release in theaters in 2007 before being widely released on DVD on July 29, 2008. In North America, it's shown on Starz Kids & Family, but it used to be available on demand. The story follows Alice, an 11-year-old starting sixth grade at a new school. The cast includes Alyson Stoner, Lucas Grabeel, Bridgit Mendler, Luke Perry, Penny Marshall, and Ashley Eckstein.

Lucas Stephen Grabeel, born on November 23, 1984, is an American actor, director, producer, singer, and songwriter. He's famous for playing Ryan Evans in the High School Musical movies, Ezra Chase in The Adventures of Food Boy (2008), and Ethan Dalloway in Halloweentown High (2004) and Return to Halloweentown (2006). Additionally, he portrayed a young Lex Luthor and Conner Kent in Smallville. On the TV drama Switched at Birth, he portrayed Toby Kennish. He's also known for voicing Deputy Peck in Sheriff Callie's Wild West on Disney Junior.
neg: The TV show Switched at Birth's second season was approved on August 17, 2012. It started airing on January 7, 2013, in the US, and had 21 episodes. The season was made by ABC Family, Pirates' Cove Entertainment, and Suzy B Productions, with Paul Stupin, Becky Hartman Edwards, John Ziffren, and the show's creator Lizzy Weiss as executive producers.

Lea Katherine Thompson, born on May 31, 1961, is an American actress, TV director, and producer. You might recognize her as Lorraine Baines in the Back to the Future movies or as the lead in the '90s show Caroline in the City. She's also been in other films like All the Right Moves, Red Dawn, Howard the Duck, Some Kind of Wonderful, and The Beverly Hillbillies. Additionally, she was part of the cast of the series Switched at Birth from 2011 to 2017.

"Switched at Birth" is a TV show that started airing on ABC Family in 2011. It's about two teenagers who were accidentally swapped at birth and raised in different backgrounds: one in a rich area, the other in a poorer one around Kansas City. What's unique about it is that it's the first show to feature multiple deaf or hard-of-hearing actors as regulars and has scenes where they use American Sign Language (ASL).

Switched at Birth is a TV drama that started on ABC Family in 2011. It's about two girls who find out they were swapped as babies. The show got renewed for multiple seasons, with each episode named after artwork. It aired on ABC Family until it became Freeform in 2016. The final season aired in 2017.

The third season of the TV show Switched at Birth started on January 13, 2014, and will have 22 episodes. It's made by ABC Family, Pirates' Cove Entertainment, and Suzy B Productions, with Paul Stupin and the creator Lizzy Weiss as executive producers.

On August 13, 2014, ABC Family said they were making another season of the popular show Switched at Birth. It would start on January 6, 2015. The new season would be made by ABC Family, Pirates' Cove Entertainment, and Suzy B Productions. Paul Stupin and Lizzy Weiss would be in charge.

General Hospital, airing on ABC, holds the title of the longest-running American TV drama. It began on April 1, 1963, created by Frank and Doris Hursley. Leslie Charleson, who has played Dr. Monica Quartermaine since August 17, 1977, holds the record for the longest-serving cast member. Rachel Ames previously held the title, playing Audrey Hardy from 1964 to 2007, with guest appearances in 2009 and 2013. Genie Francis and Kin Shriner, portraying Laura Spencer and Scott Baldwin, rank second and third for longevity, joining in February and August 1977. Jacklyn Zeman, who plays Bobbie Spencer, is the fourth longest-serving, starting in December 1977. Jane Elliot, joining as Tracy Quartermaine in June 1978, ranks fifth until her departure in May 2017. Anthony Geary, known for portraying Luke Spencer, joined in November 1978. The list below features current cast members, including main, recurring, debutants, departures, and returnees.

Constance Marie Lopez, also known as Constance Marie, is an American actress born on September 9, 1965. You might recognize her as Angie Lopez from the TV show "George Lopez" (2002–2007) or as Marcela Quintanilla, Selena's mother, in the 1997 movie "Selena." She also played Regina Vasquez in the ABC Family/Freeform drama "Switched at Birth" (2011–2017).

question: What kind of movie directed by F. Javier gutierrez did an Italian model and actress star in?
pos: Matilda Anna Ingrid Lutz, born on January 28, 1991, is an Italian model and actress known for her role in the 2017 horror movie Rings.

"Rings" is a horror movie made in 2017 in America. It's about supernatural stuff and psychology. F. Javier Gutiérrez directed it, and David Loucka, Jacob Aaron Estes, and Akiva Goldsman wrote it. The main actors are Matilda Lutz, Alex Roe, Johnny Galecki, Aimee Teegarden, Bonnie Morgan, and Vincent D'Onofrio. It's the third movie in The Ring series, and it happens thirteen years after the events of the 2002 film.
neg: Philip Sidney's Astrophil and Stella, likely written in the 1580s, is an English collection of 108 sonnets and 11 songs. The title combines Greek and Latin, with "Astrophil" meaning "star lover" and "Stella" meaning "star." The work follows the tradition of Italian poet Petrarch, incorporating themes like love, desire, and the art of poetry. Sidney uses Petrarch's rhyme scheme but with fifteen different variations.

Eleonora Pedron, born on July 13, 1982, is an Italian model and actress. She won the title of Miss Italia in 2002. Afterward, she worked shortly as a weather presenter on Italy's Rete 4 channel. Recently, she appeared in the TV series Donna Detective as an actress.

Marta Ribera, a Spanish actress born in 1971, gained fame for her performances in musicals like Jekyll & Hyde, where she played Lucy Harris, and Spamalot, where she portrayed The Lady of the Lake. She's also been seen as Sally Bowles in Cabaret and has taken on various other roles.

Margareth Madè, born Margareth Tamara Maccarrone on June 22, 1982, in Paternò, Italy, is an Italian model and actress. She goes by her stage name because her original surname, Maccarrone, is too closely associated with pasta.

The Basaglia Law, also known as Law 180, was passed in Italy in 1978 to overhaul the country's psychiatric system. It called for shutting down psychiatric hospitals and replacing them with community-based services, including places for short-term care. This law, named after psychiatrist Franco Basaglia who championed it, served as the foundation of Italian mental health regulations. It was enacted by the Italian Parliament on May 13, 1978, leading to the gradual closure of psychiatric hospitals by 1998. This reform had a global impact, influencing mental health policies in other countries. It was driven by the principles of Democratic Psychiatry.

Alex Belli, born on December 22, 1982, in Parma, is an Italian model, actor, and TV personality. He's most famous for playing Jacopo Castelli on the soap opera "CentoVetrine" from 2010 to 2015. He started his modeling career in 2005, working in cities like London, Paris, New York City, and Milan. In January 2012, he appeared on the Italian reality show "Ballando con le Stelle" alongside other celebrities. In 2013, he married Katarina Raniakova, a Slovakian model, but they divorced in 2017.
Eva Riccobono, born on February 7, 1983, is an Italian who works as a model, actress, and television presenter.

Janine Gutierrez, born on October 2, 1989, in Quezon City, is a Filipino actress, TV host, and commercial model. She graduated from Ateneo de Manila University with a degree in European Studies and is now signed with GMA Network as a contract artist.

question: In which county is the English king Harold Godwinson buried?
pos: Edith Walks, a documentary from 2017 directed by Andrew Kötting, follows the imagined journey of Edith the Fair, wife of English king Harold Godwinson. The film takes her from Waltham Abbey, where Harold is buried, to the area near the Battle of Hastings site, where William the Conqueror invaded England in 1066. It features insights from writers Alan Moore and Iain Sinclair, along with performances by torch singer Claudia Barton and musician Jem Finer.

The Abbey Church of Waltham Holy Cross and St Lawrence in Waltham Abbey, Essex, England, has been a place of worship since the 7th century. The current building mostly dates back to the early 12th century and showcases Norman architecture. An expansion project began in 1177, but only traces of it remain today. During the Late Middle Ages, Waltham was one of England's largest church buildings and a popular pilgrimage site. It was the last religious community closed during the Dissolution of the Monasteries in 1540. Today, it continues to serve as an active parish church for the town.
neg: Tostig Godwinson (1026 – 25 September 1066) was an Anglo-Saxon Earl of Northumbria and the brother of King Harold Godwinson. He was exiled by his brother, and later supported the Norwegian king Harald Hardrada's invasion of England. Tostig died in battle at Stamford Bridge.

Edith the Fair, also known as Edith Swanneck, was King Harold Godwinson's first wife. The nickname "Swanneck" likely originated from the Old English term "swann hnesce," meaning "Gentle Swan," although some mistakenly thought it referred to "swann hnecca," meaning "swan neck." She's occasionally mixed up with another woman named Ealdgyth, who was Earl Ælfgar of Mercia's daughter and queen during Harold's rule.

Several stories inspired by Harold Godwinson's time as king of England exist. Notably, Alfred, Lord Tennyson wrote a play called "Harold" in 1876, and Edward Bulwer-Lytton penned the novel "Last of the Saxon Kings" in 1848. Additionally, Rudyard Kipling included a short story in his 1910 collection "Rewards and Fairies," where an elderly King Harold encounters Henry I and passes away while being comforted by a Saxon knight.

In "The Last English King" (1997), a historical novel by Julian Rathbone, we follow Walt Edwinson, a soldier loyal to Harold Godwinson, the last Anglo-Saxon king of England, during the time of the Battle of Hastings. The story begins with Walt returning home to Iwerne in Dorset after four years, having fled England following the Anglo-Saxon defeat. During his travels across Europe and Asia Minor, including stops in Constantinople, Nicomedia, Nicaea, and Side, we learn about his experiences and memories, including his involvement in events leading up to the battle, such as accompanying Harold to William of Normandy's attack on Dinan.
Leofwine Godwinson, born around 1035 and died on October 14, 1066, was the younger brother of King Harold Godwinson. He was the fifth son of Earl Godwin.

The Battle of Stamford Bridge happened in a village called Stamford Bridge in England on September 25, 1066. It was between the English army led by King Harold Godwinson and a Norwegian force led by King Harald Hardrada and King Harold's brother, Tostig Godwinson. Both Hardrada and Tostig, along with most of the Norwegians, were killed in the battle. Despite repelling the Norwegian invaders, King Harold's army was later defeated by the Normans at Hastings, less than three weeks later. This battle is often seen as marking the end of the Viking Age, although there were still significant Scandinavian campaigns in Britain and Ireland in the years following, led by figures such as King Sweyn Estrithson of Denmark and King Magnus Barefoot of Norway.

Gytha Thorkelsdóttir, also known as Githa, was a Danish noblewoman born around 997 and likely died around 1069. She was the mother of King Harold Godwinson and Queen Edith of Wessex, who was married to King Edward the Confessor of England.

Godwin of Wessex (Old English: Godƿin; 1001 – 15 April 1053) was a powerful earl in England during the reign of the Danish king Cnut the Great and his successors. Cnut appointed him as the first Earl of Wessex. Godwin was the father of King Harold Godwinson and Edith of Wessex, who was married to King Edward the Confessor.

question: Who wrote The Devils, and was an eninent English theater, opera and film director?
pos: "The Devils" is a play written by British dramatist John Whiting, commissioned by Sir Peter Hall for the Royal Shakespeare Company. It's based on Aldous Huxley's book "The Devils of Loudun."

Sir Peter Reginald Frederick Hall CBE, born on November 22, 1930, and passed away on September 11, 2017, was a highly respected British director in theatre, opera, and film. His obituary in The Times hailed him as the most significant figure in British theatre for fifty years, while the Royal National Theatre stated that his impact on British artistic life in the 20th century was unmatched.
neg: "Bum Phillips" is a two-act opera composed by Peter Stopschinski, with the libretto written in English by Kirk Lynn. The story is based on Bum Phillips' memoirs, titled "Bum Phillips: Coach, Cowboy, Christian." The opera was the idea of theater director Luke Leonard and was commissioned by Monk Parrots, Inc., as discussed in a 2014 Sports on Earth article called "A Night at the Bum Phillips Opera."
"4 Devils," also called "Four Devils," is a silent drama movie from 1928. It was directed by F. W. Murnau, a German filmmaker, and it features Janet Gaynor as one of the stars.

David Alden, born in 1949 in New York City, is a director in theater and film. He's famous for his modern takes on opera. His twin brother, Christopher Alden, is also an opera director, but with a different style. While both brothers have tackled similar works, Christopher focuses more on characters' emotions, while David's productions often have exaggerated characters and strong political messages. David has spent a lot of time working in Europe, especially with Sir Peter Jonas, collaborating for over 20 years at the English National Opera and the Bavarian State Opera.

Phillip Boykin, also known as Phillip Lamar Boykin, is a versatile American performer. He's known for his talents in singing various genres like Broadway, gospel, jazz, and opera, as well as his acting in both film and stage productions. Notably, in 2017, he made Broadway history as the first African-American Boatman/Lee Randolph in the revival of "Sunday in the Park with George" at The Hudson Theater in New York City. He's set to portray Tonton Julian in the revival of "Once On This Island." Boykin has received nominations for prestigious awards like the Tony Award, Drama Desk, and Outer Critic Circle Award for his role in the Broadway revival of "Porgy and Bess" as Crown. Additionally, he's the founder and director of The NYGospel Brothers, a Gospel Quartet. Boykin, one of ten children, hails from Greenville, South Carolina. He began his studies in Opera Performance at South Carolina State College before transferring to the North Carolina School of the Arts and later completing his Bachelor of Music in Vocal Performance at the Hartt School of the University of Hartford. He also pursued further studies in Opera and Jazz Vocals at Howard University. On the big screen, he's been featured in films like "Freedom," "Top Five," and "Easter Mysteries."

Julien Nitzberg, born in 1965, is an American writer and director. He's famous for directing the documentary film "The Wild and Wonderful Whites of West Virginia." In theater, he's known for his musical "The Beastly Bombing," which he wrote and directed in both Los Angeles and New York. The musical won the LA Weekly Theater Award for Best Musical of the Year.

Lord Byron is a three-act opera composed by Virgil Thomson with a libretto in English by Jack Larson. It's based on the historical figure Lord Byron. It was Thomson's last opera and was commissioned by the Ford Foundation for the Metropolitan Opera (Met), but the Met never staged it. Instead, the first performance was at Lincoln Center, New York City, on April 20, 1972, presented by the music department of the Juilliard School. John Houseman directed the stage, Gerhard Samuel conducted, and Alvin Ailey choreographed. A revised version was performed in 1985 by the New York Opera Repertory Theater, with the composer involved.

Alexis Soriano is a conductor and composer from Spain and Lithuania. He learned from Ilya Musin and Valery Gergiev, and has been conducting The Hermitage Orchestra for ten years while also overseeing the Spanish Evenings Festival in Saint Petersburg. He conducted Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro at the Mariinsky Theater after Gergiev invited him. Soriano has been directing Opera Incognita since 2009, leading their first staged opera, The Letters of Van Gogh by Grigory Frid, at the Hermitage Theatre, which was nominated for the Golden Mask Award. He enjoys conducting contemporary and lesser-known Spanish music, and was the chief conductor of the INSO Lviv Symphony Orchestra from 2010 to 2012. He recorded the first performance of José Lidón's 1792 opera, Glaura y Cariolano. Since 2012, he has directed the New York Opera Society. In 2014, he was recognized as one of the top 100 Spaniards excelling internationally in their field. He has conducted orchestras like the Mariinsky Theatre, Teatro Colón, Teatro Real in Madrid, Lithuanian National Orchestra, Saint Petersburg Symphony, Prague Symphony, English Chamber Orchestra, and Taipei Symphony.

Brett C. Leonard is an American writer and producer known for his work in theater, television, and film. He is a member of the LAByrinth Theater Company in New York City. One of his notable works is the tragic drama "The Long Red Road," directed by Philip Seymour Hoffman and starring Tom Hardy, which premiered at the Goodman Theatre in Chicago. Leonard also wrote "Guinea Pig Solo," produced by LAByrinth and New York's Public Theater, starring John Ortiz. He has worked on TV series like HBO's "Hung" and AMC's "Low Winter Sun," served as a writer and Co-Executive Producer for Amazon's "Mad Dogs," and contributed as a Consulting Producer on AMC's "Fear the Walking Dead" and a Creative Consultant on BBC/FX drama "Taboo." His plays "Ninth and Joanie," "Roger and Vanessa," and "Unconditional" have been produced in various cities and received critical acclaim. Additionally, his film "Jailbait," based on one of his plays, premiered at the Tribeca Film Festival and received recognition at the Lake Placid Film Festival.

question: Which Grand Slam singles tournament have Francesca Schiavone and Olga Morozova both been finalists in?
pos: Francesca Schiavone, born on June 23, 1980, in Milan, is an Italian tennis player. She started playing professionally in 1998. In 2010, she made history by winning the French Open singles title, making her the first Italian woman to achieve this in singles. She was also a finalist in the 2011 French Open. Her highest ranking was world No. 4, reached on January 31, 2011. Notably, she is the most recent female player with a one-handed backhand to win a Grand Slam title.

Olga Vasilyevna Morozova, born on February 22, 1949, is a former tennis player from the Soviet Union. She came second in the singles category at both the 1974 French Open and the 1974 Wimbledon Championships.
neg: The Williams sisters, Venus (born 1980) and Serena (born 1981), are renowned American tennis players. They were coached by their parents, Richard Williams and Oracene Price, from a young age. Between 2001 and 2017, they competed in nine Grand Slam singles finals, showcasing a notable professional rivalry. In 2002-2003, they made history by playing in four consecutive grand slam singles finals, with Serena winning all four for her first Serena Slam. Over 17 years (2000-2016), they collectively won 12 Wimbledon singles titles. They also achieved the Career Doubles Golden Slam in 2001 and added Olympic gold medals in 2008 and 2012. Their doubles success continued with four consecutive grand slam titles in 2009-2010, leading to both being ranked No. 1 in doubles in June 2010. They have remained supportive of each other throughout their careers, maintaining a close bond even after exiting tournaments.

The 1968 US Open, once called the U.S. National Championships, was a tennis event held on grass courts at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, New York. It lasted from August 29 to September 8, marking the 88th time this tournament happened and the fourth major event of 1968. This was the first time the tournament was held in the Open Era of tennis, meaning it allowed professional players to compete and offered a total prize money of $100,000. Arthur Ashe and Virginia Wade were the singles champions. Ashe, still considered an amateur, couldn't claim the $14,000 winner's purse, which went to the runner-up, Tom Okker, while Wade received $6,000. Notably, Frank Parker, aged 52, lost to Ashe in the second round, setting a record as the oldest man to compete in a Grand Slam singles event.

In the 2012 US Open Men's Singles final, Andy Murray beat Novak Djokovic with a score of 7–6, 7–5, 2–6, 3–6, 6–2. The match lasted nearly five hours, making it one of the longest in US Open history. Murray's victory was a big deal because he became the first British man since 1936 to win a Grand Slam singles title, and the first British man in the Open Era to achieve this feat. This match was a significant moment in the ongoing rivalry between Murray and Djokovic, and it also marked Murray's 100th win in a grand slam tournament.

Li Na, born on February 26, 1982, is a former professional tennis player from China. She reached a career-high ranking of world No. 2 in the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) on February 17, 2014. During her career, Li won seven WTA singles titles and two Grand Slam singles titles: the French Open in 2011 and the Australian Open in 2014. These victories made her the first and only Grand Slam singles champion from East Asia and Asia overall. Before these wins, she was already the first player from East Asia to reach a Grand Slam singles final, which she did at the Australian Open in 2011. Li was also a finalist at the Australian Open and the WTA Tour Championships in 2013, a Wimbledon quarterfinalist three times, and reached the semifinals at the 2008 Beijing Olympics and the 2013 US Open. Among her notable achievements, she was the first Chinese player to win a WTA tour title in 2004, the first to reach a Grand Slam singles quarterfinal in 2006, and the first to break into the world's top 10. Her success has inspired a surge in tennis participation in East Asia, earning her recognition as a pioneer and leader in the region's tennis scene.

Francesca Schiavone was the title holder, but she was beaten in the final by Li Na with a score of 6–4, 7–6. This victory made Li Na the first person from Asia and China to win a Grand Slam singles title.

Sandra Reynolds Price, born on March 4, 1934, is a retired tennis player from South Africa. She achieved notable success, winning four Grand Slam women's doubles championships and one Grand Slam mixed doubles championship. Her most significant singles achievement was reaching the Wimbledon final in 1960, where she lost to Maria Bueno. Reynolds is the only South African female player to reach the Wimbledon singles final and one of only three from her country to reach a singles final in any Grand Slam event. Additionally, in 1961, she became the first South African player, male or female, to be seeded first in a Grand Slam singles event at Wimbledon. She also had successes at other tournaments, winning the German Championships in 1960, 1961, and 1962, and reaching the final of the Italian Championships in 1959.

In 1973, the Queen's Club Championships took place on grass courts in London, UK. The men's matches were part of the 1973 Commercial Union Assurance Grand Prix circuit, and the women's matches were part of the 1973 Women's Grand Prix tour. This tournament, the 74th edition, ran from June 17 to June 23, 1973. Ilie Năstase and Olga Morozova were the winners in the singles events.

In the 2017 Australian Open Men's Singles final, Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal faced off. Federer, ranked 17th, defeated Nadal, ranked 9th, in five sets. This marked their ninth meeting in a Grand Slam final and their first since the 2011 French Open. Federer's victory was significant as it was his first win against Nadal in a Grand Slam since the 2007 Wimbledon final. Despite trailing 3–1 in the final set, Federer won five consecutive games to clinch the title, ending a six-match losing streak against Nadal in Grand Slam events. This win also marked Federer's first victory over Nadal at the Australian Open and his first Grand Slam win over Nadal outside of Wimbledon's grass courts. With this victory, Federer extended his record of Grand Slam men's singles titles to 18, breaking his own all-time record for the third time, previously held by Pete Sampras.

question: "Kapitän zur See" Ernst Lindemann was the commander of which one of two battleships built for Nazi Germany's "Kriegsmarine"?
pos: Ernst Heinrich Lindemann, born on January 25, 1833, in Kirchlengern, Germany, and passed away on May 8, 1900, in Düsseldorf, was a German politician who served as mayor in Essen, Dortmund, and Düsseldorf. His grandson, Kapitän zur See Ernst Lindemann, commanded the famous battleship Bismarck.

Bismarck was the first of two battleships called the Bismarck-class, made for Nazi Germany's navy, the Kriegsmarine. It was named after Otto von Bismarck, who played a key role in uniting Germany in 1871. Construction started in July 1936 at the Blohm & Voss shipyard in Hamburg, and the ship was launched in February 1939. It was fully completed in August 1940 and became part of the German fleet. Bismarck and its sister ship Tirpitz were the biggest battleships ever built by Germany and among the largest in Europe.
neg: Hans-Jürgen Reinicke, born on August 10, 1902, and passed away on January 29, 1978, was a naval officer in Nazi Germany during World War II. He commanded the heavy cruiser Prinz Eugen and received the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross for his service.

Widder (HSK 3) was a ship used by Nazi Germany in World War II. It was originally meant for merchant raids. The Germans called it Schiff 21, while the Royal Navy referred to it as Raider D. The name "Widder" means "Ram" in German, which symbolizes the Aries constellation. It was named after the ship's captain, Kapitän zur See Helmuth von Ruckteschell, who was born under the sign of Aries.

Z43 was a Type 1936B destroyer of Nazi Germany's Kriegsmarine. She was built at Deschimag in Bremen, starting on 1 May 1942, launched on 22 September 1943, and commissioned on 24 March 1944. During her service, she was part of the 6th Destroyer Flotilla in the Baltic Sea under the command of Kapitän zur See Wenniger, later succeeded by Fregattenkapitän Lampe. Her duties mainly involved escorting ships, including the Heavy Cruiser Admiral Scheer. Additionally, she took part in a minelaying operation in December 1944, during which her sister ships Z35 and Z36 were sunk. Z43 suffered significant damage from a mine on 10 April 1945, leading to her scuttling on 3 May of the same year.

Ernst Kals (August 2, 1905 – November 2, 1979) was a high-ranking officer in the German navy, known as the Kriegsmarine, during World War II. He led a submarine called the Type IXC U-boat U-130 on five missions, where he successfully sank twenty enemy ships, totaling 145,656 tons of Allied cargo. For his exceptional bravery and military skill, he received the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross, a prestigious honor given for outstanding courage or effective leadership in combat.
The 21st U-boat Flotilla, part of Nazi Germany's navy during World War II, began in 1935 as a training unit stationed in Kiel. It was led by Captain Kurt Slevogt.
Otto Ernst Lindemann (March 28, 1894 – May 27, 1941) was a German naval captain who led the battleship Bismarck during its eight-month service in World War II.

Wolf Junge was a German naval officer in World War II. He became the second-in-command of the battleship Tirpitz in August 1943, but took over temporarily in April 1944 when the captain got injured. He was officially made captain in May. However, the crew didn't like him much because they thought he didn't have enough experience. He gave control of Tirpitz to another captain in November 1944.

Hans Jenisch (1913–1982) was a naval officer in Germany during World War II and later in West Germany. He led the U-32 submarine, sinking seventeen enemy ships in seven missions, making him one of the top-scoring U-Boat commanders of the war.

question: Which football team does Lewis Young's older brother, Ashley Young, play for?
answer: Premier League club Manchester United and the England national team
pos: Ashley Simon Young, born on July 9, 1985, is a professional football player from England. He plays as a winger for the Premier League team Manchester United and also represents the England national team.

Lewis Jack Young, born on September 27, 1989, is an English pro footballer for Crawley Town. He's versatile, adept at playing as a striker, right winger, and more recently, as a right back. He's also the younger sibling of Manchester United's Ashley Young.
neg: George Lewis Young (October 27, 1922 – January 10, 1997) was a Scottish footballer known for playing with Rangers and for being the first player to earn over 50 caps for the Scotland national team.

Yasuhito Endō, born on January 28, 1980, in Sakurajima, Kagoshima Prefecture, is a Japanese footballer currently playing for the J. League team Gamba Osaka. His older brother Akihiro, also a former pro footballer, retired in 2008 after representing Japan in the under-23 national team at the 1996 Olympics. Endō is highly regarded at Gamba Osaka and in the Japan National Football Team due to his exceptional passing, leadership, and goal-scoring abilities. He's renowned for his accuracy in free kicks and is considered one of Japan's most creative midfielders and talented footballers of his generation, despite only playing domestically in Japan.

Scott Lewis Young, born on July 15, 1981, used to play professional American football as a guard. He got drafted by the Philadelphia Eagles in the fifth round of the 2005 NFL Draft after playing college football at Brigham Young University.

Vanda & Young, consisting of Harry Vanda and George Young, were a songwriting and producing duo. They were both part of the Australian rock band The Easybeats in the 1960s, with Vanda as the lead guitarist and backing singer, and Young as the rhythm guitarist and backing singer. They co-wrote many of The Easybeats' later hits, including the widely known "Friday on My Mind," and also served as the group's record producers starting from 1967. Additionally, George Young was the older brother of Malcolm and Angus Young from the hard rock band AC/DC, and he produced several of the band's major albums, such as "Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap" released in 1976.

Lewis Young, born on December 20, 1998, is a pro Aussie rules footballer for the Western Bulldogs in the AFL. He joined the Bulldogs as the 49th pick in the 2016 draft. Young played his first game in the 2017 season's seventeenth round, helping the team win by twenty points against Carlton at Etihad Stadium.

Richard James Clausen, born on June 29, 1982, currently works as the offensive coordinator and quarterbacks coach at Calabasas High School. He used to play college football for Louisiana State University and the University of Tennessee. While at LSU, he played in three games over two years, including starting in one game against Ole Miss in 2002. After the 2002 season, he moved to Tennessee, where he joined the football team as a backup quarterback after sitting out the 2003 season due to NCAA transfer rules. His older brother, Casey, also played football for Tennessee from 2000 to 2003 and is now the head football coach at Calabasas High School. His younger brother, Jimmy, previously played quarterback for the Baltimore Ravens in the NFL.

William Travis Bully Van de Graaff was an American football player, coach, and college sports leader. He went to Tuscaloosa High School and played football at the University of Alabama, where he became an All-American in 1915. He was also part of an Associated Press Southeast Area All-Time football team from 1869 to 1919. Van de Graaff later coached football at Colorado College from 1926 to 1939, with a record of 49–47–6. He passed away in Colorado Springs in 1977 at 81. He was the older sibling of physicist Robert J. Van de Graaff, known for inventing the Van de Graaff generator. Additionally, Bully's two older brothers, Hargrove and Adrian, were also Alabama football players.

Robert Allen Young, born on September 3, 1942, and passed away on June 17, 1995, was a professional American football player. He spent most of his 16-season career in the National Football League (NFL) playing as an offensive guard for the St. Louis Cardinals. Young and his fellow Cardinal offensive linemen are recognized for introducing modern weightlifting and powerlifting techniques into NFL training. He achieved notable recognition, including two Pro Bowl selections in 1978 and 1979, as well as being named a first-team All-Pro in 1979. Young attended Howard Payne University and was also the older brother of Doug Young, a three-time world powerlifting champion.

question: Snowdrop is a proprietary game engine first revealed with an online-only action role-playing video game developed by who?
pos: Tom Clancy's The Division is an online video game where players take on the role of agents in a group called The Division, set in a post-pandemic New York City. Developed by Massive Entertainment and published by Ubisoft, the game was released in 2016 for various platforms. Players help rebuild operations in Manhattan, investigate the outbreak, and fight crime. It combines role-playing elements with multiplayer modes.

Snowdrop is a special game engine made by Ubisoft. It's used for games on Microsoft Windows, Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 4, and Xbox One. The first game to use it was Tom Clancy's The Division, which was shown off at E3 2013.
neg: Zero is a game engine made by Pandemic Studios. It was first used in a game and later featured in various Star Wars games like the Battlefront series. Games like Battlezone II: Combat Commander and Dark Reign 2 have an in-game editor accessible via commands. The engine was upgraded to work on consoles and support third-person gameplay. Later, it was adjusted again, separating the level editor from the game engine. Modding tools like ZeroEdit and a new level creation tool were released for Star Wars: Battlefront on December 23, 2004, with updates released on February 2, 2006. Pandemic primarily used Zero for many games developed in their Los Angeles studio, including a modified version in Mercenaries 2: World in Flames.

Amen: The Awakening was a story-focused video game that mixed shooting and role-playing elements, with a bit of stealth thrown in. It was being developed by Cavedog Entertainment as their first-person shooter game. Unfortunately, despite being 60% completed, it got canceled in 2000. One of the main reasons was that its plans were too ambitious for the technology available at the time, especially its complex game engine.

Charlie Murder is a video game where you fight enemies in an action-packed adventure. It was made by Ska Studios and released for Xbox 360 and PC. Originally, it was announced in 2010 for Xbox Live Indie Games, but then it got a major upgrade and was released in 2012 for Xbox Live Arcade. It finally came out on August 14, 2013, and people liked it, especially the music and the hand-drawn graphics. Later, it became available on Steam for Windows, Linux, and macOS on May 12, 2017.

Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare is a video game where you shoot from a first-person perspective. It was made by Infinity Ward and sold by Activision. This is the fourth game in the Call of Duty series and came out in 2007 for PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, and Windows computers. Unlike earlier games in the series, which were set in World War II, this one is set in modern times. It took more than two years to make, and it uses its own special game engine.

Project I.G.I.: I'm Going In, also known as Project I.G.I. in Europe, is a tactical first-person shooter game developed by Innerloop Studios and published by Eidos Interactive on December 15, 2000. When it came out, opinions on the game were mixed because it had some problems. These included bad artificial intelligence, not being able to save the game in the middle, and not having multiplayer. However, people liked its great sound and graphics, which were made possible by using a special game engine that Innerloop had used before in another game called Joint Strike Fighter.

ParaEngine Corporation, often shortened to P.E., is a tech company based in Shenzhen, China, founded by LiXizhi. They specialize in 3D virtual world technologies. In 2009, they released their first public product, Haqi Town, a creative social MMO designed for kids. In Haqi Town, users can create their own avatars and virtual lands to build their dream worlds easily. The company also focuses on developing a distributed computer game engine called ParaEngine. They use their proprietary game engine technologies to create various applications and collaborate with clients who integrate ParaEngine into their projects. They believe that advancements in game technology will lead to the emergence of a new 3D internet or Web3D.

The id Tech 5 game engine, created by id Software, is a proprietary software that succeeded id Tech 1, 2, 3, and 4. Unlike its predecessors, which were later released under the GNU General Public License, id Tech 5 remained proprietary. It was considered a significant improvement over id Tech 4. The engine's debut was at WWDC 2007, showcased by John D. Carmack on an eight-core computer, although the demonstration utilized only a single core with single-threaded OpenGL implementation on a 512 MB 7000 class Quadro video card. id Tech 5 made its debut in the video game Rage, and later in The Evil Within.

The Rockstar Advanced Game Engine (RAGE) is a special game engine made by the RAGE Technology Group at Rockstar San Diego, with help from other Rockstar Games teams. It's been used on various platforms like Microsoft Windows, PlayStation, Wii, and Xbox. Originally, the Angel Game Engine was created by Angel Studios for games like Midtown Madness and later used in the Midnight Club series and other Angel Studios games on consoles like the PlayStation and Xbox.

question: Wendy Ayche was featured in 2016 in an annual production created by Youtube and what other organization?
pos: Wendy Ayche, also known as Wengie, is a popular Australian YouTube personality and vlogger, born on January 9, 1986, in Guangzhou, China. She earned her nickname, Wengie, during a dance class where classmates were inspired by her Chinese name, Wén Jié. Since starting her YouTube channel on February 11, 2013, she has gained over 281 million views and amassed more than 11 million followers. In January 2016, ElleGirl Japan recognized her as a noteworthy channel. By August 2016, she ranked as the 5th fastest-growing channel globally. Google has also acknowledged her as one of the top beauty creators in Asia. In January 2017, she reached 5 million YouTube subscribers and her channel is currently the 12th most subscribed How-To & Style Channel on YouTube. Additionally, she serves as a board member of the Internet Creators Guild, which supports online creators. Recently, her YouTube channel won Best Channel and Overall Winner at the Australian Online Video Awards.

YouTube Rewind is a yearly video series made by YouTube and Portal A Interactive. It's like a big summary of all the popular videos, events, memes, and music from that year. Each year, they include more YouTube stars and make the videos fancier. The most recent one came out on December 8, 2016.
neg: The Svartisen Power Station is a big hydroelectric plant in Meløy, Nordland, Norway. It can generate up to 600 megawatts of power and produces around 2,200 gigawatt-hours of electricity every year, making it Norway's top producer. Statkraft owns the station.

The Sima Power Station is a hydroelectric power station in Eidfjord, Hordaland, Norway. Lang-Sima operates at 500 MW with an average annual production of 1,212 GWh, while Sy-Sima has a 620 MW capacity and produces around 1,640 GWh annually. Statkraft is the operator.

"Return to Eden" is an Australian TV show that started as a three-part mini-series in 1983 on Network Ten. It starred Rebecca Gilling, James Reyne, Wendy Hughes, and James Smillie. Later, in 1986, it became a 22-part weekly series with Gilling, Smillie, and Peta Toppano reprising their roles. Created by Michael Laurence, the show was a hit internationally, especially in France, where it has been aired 13 times.

Tubular Bells for Two is a music-theatre show performed by two Australian musicians, Aidan Roberts and Daniel Holdsworth. They play over twenty instruments live to recreate Mike Oldfield's 1973 album Tubular Bells. The show won 'Best Musical Moment' at The Sydney Fringe in 2010 and has been featured at major arts festivals in Australia and the Pacific, like the Sydney Festival and NZ International Arts Festival. It debuted in Europe at the 2012 Edinburgh Festival Fringe, winning two awards, and later toured Europe in 2013 for the 40th anniversary of the original album by Oldfield.

The Brazilian automotive industry was competitive within Latin America, alongside Mexico and Argentina, until around 1960. After that, there were two significant advancements that propelled Brazil to become a regional leader initially, and later, one of the world's leaders. Towards the late 1970s, new production capacities were established with investments from the US and Germany. This led to Brazil's annual production surpassing one million vehicles, securing its position as the world's 10th largest producer. Despite a slight decline around 1990, Brazil experienced renewed and robust growth with assistance from the same foreign players, as well as Japan and France. This growth enabled Brazil to surpass traditional automakers like Belgium, the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada, Russia, Spain, and France. By 2013, Brazil's annual production exceeded 3.7 million vehicles, making it the seventh-largest producer globally, although there has been a recent substantial decline in production.

"Blast!" is a Broadway show produced by James Mason for Cook Group Incorporated. Mason was previously involved with the Star of Indiana Drum and Bugle Corps. The production won the Tony Award for Best Special Theatrical Event in 2001 and also scooped the Emmy Award for Best Choreography that same year.

The Nore Power Station is a hydroelectric plant in Buskerud, Norway. The first part, Nore I, can produce up to 206 megawatts of power each year, generating around 1,110 gigawatt-hours. The second part, Nore II, has a capacity of 52 megawatts and produces about 314 gigawatt-hours annually.

The Rana Power Station, also known as Rana kraftverk, is a hydroelectric power station situated in Rana, Nordland, Norway. It has an installed capacity of 500 MW and produces around 2,100 GWh annually. The station is owned by Statkraft and is the second-largest producer in Norway, trailing only the Svartisen Hydroelectric Power Station in annual production.

question: John MacGregor, Baron MacGregor of Pulham Market was educated at the University of St Andrews and another university established by what monach?
pos: John Roddick Russell MacGregor, known as Baron MacGregor of Pulham Market, is a British politician. He went to Merchiston Castle School and then studied economics and history at the University of St Andrews, graduating in 1959. Later, he completed his LLB at King's College London in 1962. Before the 1979 general election, he was employed at Hill Samuel, a merchant bank.

King's College London, often called King's or KCL, is a public university in London, UK. It was established in 1829 by King George IV and the Duke of Wellington. It claims to be the fourth oldest university in England. In 1836, King's became one of the founding colleges of the University of London. Over time, it grew through mergers, including with Queen Elizabeth College, Chelsea College of Science and Technology, the Institute of Psychiatry, and the United Medical and Dental Schools of Guy's and St Thomas' Hospitals, among others.
neg: Pulham Market and Pulham St Mary are two villages about 9 miles north of Diss in Norfolk, England. Together, they cover an area of about 12.08 square kilometers. In 2001, the population was 999 people living in 443 households, but by 2011, it dropped to 977 people.

John MacGregor was a brave Scottish-Canadian soldier who served in both world wars. He received the Victoria Cross, the highest honor for bravery given to British and Commonwealth soldiers, for his courageous actions in battle.

The University of St Andrews Boat Club, established in 1965, is the rowing team connected to the University of St Andrews. They compete in races and regattas in Scotland and England, such as the Head of the River Race in London, the British University Championships 'BUCS' Regatta, and the Henley Royal Regatta. They are part of the University of St Andrews Athletic Union and are governed by Scottish Rowing with the registration code 'SAU'.

The Prior of St. Andrews led the Augustinian canons community at St. Andrews Cathedral Priory in Fife, Scotland. King David I established it in 1140, bringing canons from Nostell Priory, West Yorkshire. Initially, the prior might have been under the bishop's authority as an abbot, but by the 13th century, the canons gained the right to elect their prior independently. By the late 13th century, the native canons' abbacy no longer posed a challenge to the priory's authority, and they had formed into a collegiate church.

St Andrews Links, located in St Andrews, Fife, Scotland, is famously known as the Home of Golf. It boasts some of the world's oldest golf courses, dating back to the 15th century. Presently, there are seven public golf courses available: Balgove, Eden, Jubilee, Strathtyrum, New Course, the renowned Old Course (considered one of the finest and most traditional worldwide), and The Castle Course, positioned on the cliffs a mile east of St Andrews, designed by architect David McLay Kidd and opened in June 2008. These courses are managed by the local authorities through the St Andrews Links Trust, a charitable organization. Additionally, St Andrews is home to the prestigious Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews, historically one of the rulemaking authorities of golf until 2004, when it transferred its authority to The R&A, its offshoot organization.

The University of St Andrews, also called St Andrews University, is a well-known British public research university located in St Andrews, Fife, Scotland. It's the oldest of Scotland's four ancient universities and the third oldest university in the English-speaking world, after Oxford and Cambridge. St Andrews was established between 1410 and 1413, with a papal bull issued by Avignon Antipope Benedict XIII to a small group of Augustinian clergy.

The Archdeaconry of St Andrews was part of the larger St Andrews diocese, one of two such divisions within it. It was led by the Archdeacon of St Andrews, who answered to the Bishop of St Andrews. Back in medieval times, it included five areas, each called a deanery, with a total of 124 parish churches. These deaneries were named Mearns (with 14 churches), Angus (with 38 churches), Gowrie (with 20 churches), Fife (with 28 churches), and Fothriff (with 24 churches).
