question: Which game was released first, Icehouse pieces or Kill Doctor Lucky?
pos: Kill Doctor Lucky is a funny board game created by James Ernest and published in 1996 by Cheapass Games. It won the Origins Award for Best Abstract Board Game of 1997.

Icehouse pieces, also known as Icehouse Pyramids or Looney Pyramids, are pyramid-shaped gaming pieces that can nest and stack. They were created by Andrew Looney and John Cooper in 1987 for use in the game Icehouse.
neg: "Boxes" is a soundtrack album by the Australian band Icehouse, which was released in November 1985 by Festival Records / Chrysalis Records. Originally, the idea for the album came from Iva Davies and Robert Kretschmer, who worked with choreographer Graeme Murphy from the Sydney Dance Company to create a ballet performance also called "Boxes." The first live performance of "Boxes" took place at the Sydney Opera House on November 7, 1985, featuring the Sydney Dance Company, Davies, Kretschmer, and guest percussionist Masaki Tanazawa. In the US, the album was released under the name "Sydney Dance Company." The single "No Promises" was released in November as a 12-inch record and later as a cassingle in December for the Australian and New Zealand markets. It included other tracks from "Boxes," and two tracks from the album were later included in Icehouse's next studio album, "Measure for Measure," in April 1986.

"Can't Help Myself" is the debut single by the Australian synthpop/rock band Flowers, who later changed their name to Icehouse. It came out in May 1980 on a 7-inch vinyl through the indie label Regular Records, five months before their first album, "Icehouse," dropped. A larger 10-inch version of the single was released in July, featuring a cover with separate pictures of band members arranged diagonally above the band's name and song title. The song reached number 10 on the Australian Singles Charts.

"Icehouse" is a song by the Australian rock band Flowers. It was released as a single in Europe in 1982 by Chrysalis Records, from the band's debut album, also titled "Icehouse," after the band changed its name to Icehouse. In the United States, the song reached number 28 on the Billboard Top Tracks chart in 1981.

The Nameless One is a demon with two heads who first showed up in Sub-Mariner #22 (February 1970), created by Roy Thomas and Marie Severin. He led the Undying Ones and took over Earth a long time ago. After their power faded, they went back to their own world. Even after they were kicked out of Earth, the Nameless One still ruled them and tried to conquer Earth again multiple times. Later, another demon took over as the leader of the Undying Ones. This new leader tried to manipulate Wolverine into killing Doctor Strange. However, Wolverine, powered by demonic magic, killed this new Nameless One and many others from the Undying Ones.

Love in Motion marked the debut of new music from the Australian rock synthpop band Icehouse. It was released exclusively as a 7-inch vinyl single in October 1981 in Australia by Regular Records. Prior to this, the band was known as Flowers until June 27, 1981, when they changed their name to Icehouse. Following this shift, they signed with Chrysalis Records, and most of Flowers' previous material was rebranded under the Icehouse name for European, UK, and US audiences. Love in Motion achieved success, reaching #10 on the Australian singles charts. The B-side of the single, titled "Goodnight, Mr. Matthews," later appeared on their 1982 album "Primitive Man." In the US and European versions of the album released by Chrysalis Records, "Love in Motion" was also included, while the UK version of the album, released in 1983, was renamed "Love in Motion."

The song "No Promises" was the first single by the Australian band Icehouse from their album "Measure for Measure" in 1986. It came out in November 1985 on Regular Records, both as a 7-inch and a 12-inch vinyl single. It was also released in the UK and Europe by Chrysalis Records in the same formats but with different songs. Later, it was released in the US by Chrysalis with different track listings as well. The song reached #30 on the Australian singles charts. A remix by [love] tatto appeared on Icehouse's album "Meltdown" in 2002.

"We Can Get Together" is the second song released by the Australian rock band Flowers, which later became known as Icehouse. It came out in October 1980, on the independent label Regular Records, from their debut album, Icehouse. The single reached #16 on the Australian Kent Music Report Singles Charts, two weeks before the album's release.

Treehouse is a game where players aim to align their Icehouse pieces with a central configuration that's the same for everyone. The Treehouse Die determines the type of move a player should make to adjust their own setup or the central one, and they make these moves strategically to progress toward the goal.

question: American Blues included the drummer from which American rock band?
pos: Frank Lee Beard, born on June 11, 1949, drums for the American rock band ZZ Top. Before ZZ Top, he played with bands like The Cellar Dwellers, The Hustlers, The Warlocks, and American Blues.

American Blues was a band from Texas in the 1960s. They played a mix of blues and psychedelic rock, inspired by the 13th Floor Elevators. Two of their members, Dusty Hill and Frank Beard, later joined ZZ Top. From 1966 to 1968, they performed in various clubs across Dallas, Fort Worth, and Houston, including The Cellar and The Walrus in Dallas, and Love Street Light Circus Feel Good Machine in Houston.
neg: Mabel Greer's Toyshop is an English band that started out playing psychedelic rock before transitioning to progressive rock. They were active in London from 1966 to 1968 and served as the precursor to the famous band Yes. Their music blended psychedelic sounds with American blues and classical influences, featuring poetic lyrics. The band's lineup included notable musicians such as Chris Squire, Peter Banks, Tony Kaye, Bill Bruford, and Jon Anderson. In 2014, the band reunited with original members Clive Bayley and Robert Hagger, along with new additions Hugo Barré, Tony Kaye, and Billy Sherwood.

Slash's Blues Ball was a blues rock band from Los Angeles, California, that started in 1996. The band featured Slash on lead guitar, Teddy Big Bag Zig Zag Andreadis on vocals, Johnny Griparic on bass, Alvino Bennet on drums, Bobby Schneck on rhythm guitar, and Dave McLaurin on saxophone. After Slash left Guns N' Roses, they toured as a cover band for two years but didn't put out any albums.

The Muggs, a blues rock band from Detroit, Michigan, started in February 2000 with guitarist Danny Methric, bassist Tony DeNardo, and drummer Matt Rost. They gained recognition, making it onto Music Connection's 100 Hot Unsigned Band list in December 2008. Additionally, they won awards like Best Blues Artist and Best Rock Band in 2007.

Double Trouble is a blues rock band from Austin, Texas, led by guitarist and singer Stevie Ray Vaughan starting in 1978. They were active throughout the 1980s and played a significant role in revitalizing the blues genre, influencing many later musicians in blues and rock. The band, originally formed in Austin, Texas, included members such as Chris Layton on drums, Tommy Shannon on bass, and later Reese Wynans on keyboards. When performing with Stevie Ray Vaughan, they were known as Stevie Ray Vaughan and Double Trouble. Their music blended blues and rock, exploring various styles from ballads to soul and occasionally incorporating jazz and other musical elements.

Five Horse Johnson is a blues rock band from Toledo, Ohio, founded in 1995. They've toured with popular bands like Clutch and Halfway to Gone. Mixing hard rock, blues, and other styles, they've crafted a unique blend they call stoner rock/blues. Their second-to-last album, "The Mystery Spot," boasted guest appearances, including drummer Jean-Paul Gaster from Clutch. They've also embarked on a global tour with Clutch and Dub Trio.

Stevie Ray Vaughan and Double Trouble's ninth album, "Live at Carnegie Hall," was released in July 1997 by Epic Records. It features live recordings from their October 4, 1984 concert at Carnegie Hall, which was a sold-out benefit for the T.J. Martell Foundation. Vaughan, who had just turned thirty, considered it his best birthday celebration ever. The band's performance, backed by a ten-piece big band for the second half of the concert, received mostly positive reviews and included blues and R&B classics.

Here's a simpler version:

Here's a breakdown of musicians who've been part of the American blues rock band Canned Heat over the years. Since they started in 1965, the band has had 43 different members. The current lineup includes bassist Larry "The Mole" Taylor, who joined in 1967, drummer Adolfo "Fito" de la Parra, who's been there since 1967, guitarist Harvey "The Snake" Mandel, who joined in 1969, and vocalist Dale Spalding, who became a member in 2008.

Chris Robinson Brotherhood is a blues rock band from the USA, started in 2011 by Chris Robinson, the singer of Black Crowes, during a break from The Black Crowes. They've put out four albums: "Big Moon Ritual," "The Magic Door," "Phosphorescent Harvest," and "Any Way You Love, We Know How You Feel." The group includes Robinson, guitarist Neal Casal, keyboardist Adam MacDougall, bassist Jeff Hill (who joined in 2016, replacing Mark Dutton), and drummer Tony Leone (who took over from George Sluppick in January 2015).

question: The Indian actor and philanthropist, who starred in "Mera Damad," entered the film industry in what year?
pos: Farooq Sheikh, born on March 25, 1948, and passed away on December 27, 2013, was a well-known Indian actor, philanthropist, and TV host. He gained fame for his roles in Hindi movies from 1977 to 1989 and on TV from 1988 to 2002. After a break, he resumed acting in films in 2008 until his death. He made significant contributions to Parallel Cinema or the New Indian Cinema, collaborating with directors such as Satyajit Ray, Muzaffar Ali, Hrishikesh Mukherjee, and Ketan Mehta.

"Mera Damad" is a Hindi film from 1985 about a family's drama. It was directed by Partho Ghosh and produced by Shipra Biswas and Tushar Mazumdar. The cast includes Utpal Dutt, Ashok Kumar, Farooq Sheikh, Zarina Wahab, Rakesh Bedi, Prema Narayan, and Jankidas. The music was composed by Salil Choudhury and Babul Bose.
neg: Doddanna, born on November 11, 1949, is an Indian actor known for his work in Kannada films. He has appeared in around 500 movies, beginning his career in theater before transitioning to character roles in the Kannada film industry.

Fayyaz Hashmi was a poet and dialogue writer from Pakistan who contributed to both Indian and Pakistani cinema. He wrote notable songs like the popular ghazal "Aaj Jaane Ki Zid Na Karo" and "Tasveer teri dil mera behela nah sake gi." The latter song, released in 1941, helped make the singer Talat Mahmood well-known in India and played a key role in his introduction to the Calcutta film industry.

Krishnabhaskar Mangalasserri is an Indian actor, model, academic, novelist, and screenwriter known for his work in Malayalam films. He started his acting career in 2012 with the movie "Puthiya Theerangal," directed by Sathyan Anthikad. He later appeared in films like "Asha Black," where he not only co-wrote the screenplay but also played a prominent role alongside Sarath Kumar.

Tariq Hussain Khan was an Indian actor famous for his roles in Hindi movies. He started his career with his dad Nasir Hussain's film "Yaadon Ki Baraat" in 1973, which was a hit. He also starred in Nasir Hussain's next popular film "Hum Kisise Kum Nahin" in 1977. Despite these successes, Tariq didn't achieve lasting fame in the industry. He acted in a few more movies but eventually stopped after his last film "Mera Damad" in 1995.

Sunil Rawal, born on May 23, 1983, is both a film producer and actor in the Nepali film scene since 2012. His debut film, "Saayad," made under Durgish Films Pvt. Ltd. and directed by Suraj Subba, marked his entry into both producing and acting. Managing Director of Durgish Films Pvt. Ltd., Rawal has been a focal point in the industry since then, gaining attention from filmmakers and audiences alike. His first film, "Saayad," released in 2011, broke trends and earned him numerous awards, recognized by the Nepal Film Producer Association. Following its success, he produced another hit, "Hostel," in 2012, which resonated with Nepali youth and received national recognition. Rawal continued his streak with the sequel, "Hostel Returns," in 2015, maintaining a record of no flops in his productions. He serves as an inspiration for aspiring filmmakers and is actively involved in social initiatives, such as establishing libraries and aiding earthquake and flood victims across Nepal. Currently, Rawal is working on his upcoming projects, "Laaure" and "Woolen Marry," which are in the pre-production phase.

Tulu cinema, also known as Coastalwood, is a part of Indian cinema, producing around 5 to 7 films every year. The first Tulu film, "Enna Thangadi," was released in 1971. Initially, these movies were primarily shown in theaters within the Tulu Nadu region. However, the industry has expanded, with films now simultaneously released in Mangalore, Udupi, Mumbai, Bangalore, and Gulf countries. "Suddha," a highly acclaimed Tulu film, won Best Indian Film at the Osian's Cinefan Festival of Asian and Arab Cinema in 2006. In 2011, the industry experienced a resurgence with the release of "Oriyardori Asal," which became the biggest hit in Tulu film history. "Chaali Polilu" holds the record for the longest running and highest-grossing film in the Tulu film industry, completing 470 days at PVR Cinemas in Mangalore.

Vijay, also known as Duniya Vijay, is an Indian actor known for his work in Kannada films. He began his career as a junior artist, taking on minor roles until he gained recognition with his role in the movie "Duniya" in 2007. He has been praised for his acting in films like "Chanda" (2007), "Junglee" (2009), "Johny Mera Naam Preethi Mera Kaam" (2011), and "Jayammana Maga" (2013).

Komal Kumar is an Indian actor known for his comedic roles in Kannada films. He's also a film producer and distributor. He started his acting career in 1992 with a supporting role in "Super nan Maga," produced by his brother-in-law N. Srinivas. Since then, he's appeared in over 100 films, transitioning from comedic roles to lead roles, notably in "Chamkaisi chindi Udaisi." He's the younger brother of actor Jaggesh, and they often work together in the industry.

question: The Jeep Cherokee was originally sold as a variant of a Jeep model produced during what years?
pos: The Jeep Cherokee is a type of vehicle made by Jeep that belongs to different vehicle categories. It started as a version of the Jeep Wagoneer, but over time, it changed from a big SUV to one of the earliest small SUVs, and now it's a crossover SUV. The name has been used since 1974 and led to Jeep's most popular vehicle, the Jeep Grand Cherokee. The Cherokee name comes from the Cherokee Native American tribe.

The Jeep Wagoneer, produced from 1963 to 1991, was the first luxury 4x4 vehicle. It was considered a sport utility vehicle (SUV) long before that term became popular. Throughout its 28-year production, it underwent only minor mechanical changes, making it one of the longest-running models in U.S. automotive history.
neg: Richard A. Teague, known as Dick Teague, was an American industrial designer in the car industry. He worked at companies like General Motors, Packard, and Chrysler before becoming Vice President of Design at American Motors Corporation (AMC). Teague designed famous cars like the AMC Pacer, Gremlin, and Hornet, as well as the Jeep Cherokee XJ. He also contributed to designing cars for Chrysler, like the Jeep Grand Cherokee and Neon, after AMC was bought by Chrysler.
The SJ series Jeep Cherokee, a full-size SUV, was manufactured by Jeep from 1974 to 1983. It was built on the Wagoneer platform, which was first designed by Brooks Stevens in 1963.

The Jeep Liberty, also known as the Jeep Cherokee outside North America, is a small SUV made by Jeep. It came out in 2008 to replace the first-gen Liberty. This model was built with a single body structure and was made in various countries, including the US, Egypt, and Venezuela. In 2010, Jeep estimated that 70% of Liberty buyers were new to the brand. Production of the second-gen Liberty ended in 2012. The next model dropped the Liberty name and brought back Cherokee. As of early 2016, the model was still being sold in Venezuela until it was replaced by the KL model Cherokee by FCA Venezuela.

The Jeep Cherokee (KL) is a mid-size SUV made by Jeep. It was revealed in 2013 and sales began later that year. This Cherokee is special because it's the first Jeep built on a platform developed by Chrysler and Fiat. It's manufactured at the Belvidere Assembly Plant in Illinois.

The Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK2) launched in Spring 2010 is a mid-size luxury SUV from Jeep. It made its debut at the 2009 New York Auto Show. This generation keeps the iconic Jeep look but with a more modern design. Inside, it boasts luxury with leather and wood details, and high-tech electronics. The 2011 model received numerous awards for its off-road capability, luxury, value, safety, and being the most awarded SUV. Some of these accolades include being named a Top Safety Pick by the IIHS in 2011, recognized as a Consumers Digest Best Buy in the same year, hailed as the Safest SUV in America by MSN Autos, and awarded Truck of the Year for 2011 by The Detroit News.

The Jeep Liberty, known as the Jeep Cherokee (KJ/KK) outside North America, was a compact SUV produced by Jeep from 2002 to 2012. It replaced the Cherokee (XJ) and was priced between the Wrangler and Grand Cherokee. The Liberty was the smallest 4-door Jeep SUV until the arrival of the car-based 4-door Compass and Patriot in 2007. It featured unibody construction and was assembled in the United States, as well as in other countries like Egypt and Venezuela. Production of the Liberty ended on August 16, 2012, and the next generation reverted to the previous nameplate of Jeep Cherokee for markets outside North America.

The Jeep Cherokee (XJ) was a sport utility vehicle made by Jeep from 1983 to 2001. Unlike the original full-size SJ model, it didn't have a traditional body-on-frame chassis. Instead, it had a lighter unibody design. Initially called Sportwagons, these models paved the way for what we now know as modern SUVs, even though the term wasn't used back then.

The Jeep Liberty, also known as the Jeep Cherokee outside North America, is a small SUV that was made by Jeep. It was designed by Bob Boniface and first introduced in May 2001 for the 2002 model year. The Liberty replaced the Cherokee (XJ) and was priced between the Wrangler and Grand Cherokee. It was the smallest 4-door Jeep SUV until the Compass and Patriot were introduced in 2007. The Liberty had a unibody construction and was built at the Toledo North Assembly Plant in the US, as well as in other countries like Egypt and Venezuela.

question: Where was the person born who was recognized by MIAL and is an American soprano?
pos: Mary Violet Leontyne Price, born on February 10, 1927, is a famous American soprano singer. Originally from Laurel, Mississippi, she gained worldwide recognition during the 1950s and 1960s. Notably, she was among the first African Americans to achieve a prominent position as a leading artist at the Metropolitan Opera.

The Mississippi Institute of Arts and Letters (MIAL) is a foundation that privately funds awards for outstanding achievements in art, music, literature, and photography by Mississippi residents. It was founded in 1978 by former Mississippi Governor William Winter, Dr. Cora Norman, Dr. Aubrey Lucas, and Dr. Noel Polk, with the first awards given in 1980. Only registered members of the Institute can nominate candidates for these awards. Winners are selected by expert panels in seven categories: Fiction, Non-fiction, Visual Art, Concert Musical Composition, Popular Musical Composition, Photography, and Poetry. The awards ceremony takes place in a different Mississippi city each year. Past winners include notable figures like Walker Percy, Ellen Douglas, and Morgan Freeman, with lifetime achievement awards given to individuals like Walter Anderson, Eudora Welty, and Morgan Freeman.
neg: A mamzer is a person in Jewish law who is born from relationships that are considered forbidden. This could mean they are born from adultery involving a married Jewish woman and a man who is not her husband, from incest as defined by Jewish law, or they have a parent who is a mamzer. It's important to note that being a mamzer doesn't necessarily mean being illegitimate, as it doesn't include children born to unmarried mothers.

Leslie Herbert Les Irwin, CBE (1 May 1898 – 28 January 1985) was an Australian politician. He was born in Newcastle, New South Wales, and attended state schools. He served in the military from 1916 to 1930 and then worked as a bank manager. In 1963, he ran as the Liberal candidate for the seat of Mitchell in the Australian House of Representatives. He was notable for being the last person born in the 19th century, the last person born before Federation, and the last World War I veteran elected to the House. He held the seat until he was defeated in 1972 and passed away in 1985.

Nabi Tajima, born on August 4, 1900, is a Japanese woman who has lived for over a century. At 123 years old, she holds the title of the world's oldest known living person and is the only remaining individual born in the 1800s. She also holds the record for being the oldest verified person from Japan and Asia.

Myrna Docia Sharlow (July 19, 1893 – after 1935) was an American soprano who sang in operas and concerts from the 1910s to the 1930s. She started singing in 1912 with the Boston Opera Company and was quite active in Chicago from 1915 to 1920, then again in 1923–1924 and 1926–1927. She also performed with other important American opera companies, including one season at the Metropolitan Opera. Although she didn't perform much in Europe, she notably sang in the English premiere of Riccardo Zandonai's Francesca da Rimini at Covent Garden in 1914. Sharlow sang a variety of soprano roles, from dramatic to lighter ones, and even took on a few traditionally mezzo-soprano or contralto parts.

Camille Amy Zamora, born on December 14, 1970, is an American soprano known for singing opera, zarzuela, oratorio, art songs, and American classics. She sings a wide range of music, from early Baroque pieces to modern works by composers like Grammy winners Robert Aldridge and Herschel Garfein, and Prix de Rome winner Christopher Theofanidis.

The "Apprentice Adept" series, written by Piers Anthony, consists of seven fantasy and science fiction novels. It's set in two worlds, Phaze and Proton, which exist in the same space but different dimensions. Phaze is magical and lush, while Proton is a barren mining planet focused on science. At the start of the series, every person born on either world has a counterpart on the other. However, if someone doesn't have a duplicate (like a Proton citizen who migrated from another planet or if their counterpart died), they can travel between worlds using energy curtains that surround each dimension.

Frederick Fred Harold Hale Sr. was an American man who lived to be very old. When John Ingram McMorran died in February 2003 at 112 years old, Hale became the oldest living man in the United States. Then, in March 2004, at the age of 113, he became the oldest living man in the world after the death of Joan Riudavets from Spain. Hale is one of the ten oldest men ever recorded, and he holds the record for being the oldest person born in Maine.

Edwin Leard Mechem (July 2, 1912 - November 27, 2002) was a notable Republican figure in New Mexico politics. He held the positions of the 15th, 17th, and 19th Governor of New Mexico and also represented the state in the United States Senate. Mechem was the first governor born in the 20th century and the first New Mexico native to hold the office after statehood. Later, he became a Federal Judge.

question: Which magazine is older, Gallery or Dime Magazine?
answer: arose on the "Playboy" magazine pattern in the 1970s.
pos: Gallery is a popular men's magazine published by Magna Publishing Group. It follows the style of Playboy magazine and became well-known in the 1970s.

Dime Magazine, an American basketball publication since 2001, releases six editions annually for its global audience. Additionally, it offers Dime China, a version in Chinese with both translated content from the English edition and original material from Chinese editorial staff. The magazine is featured as an endorsement in NBA 2K12 and NBA 2K13 and is owned by Uproxx, a brand under Woven Digital.
neg: The Little Review Gallery was a small Modern Art gallery linked to the American literary magazine The Little Review. It was run by Jane Heap, who was the acting editor of The Little Review from 1924 to 1927. The gallery focused mainly on Constructivism, Dadaism, and art inspired by machines.

The dime novel was a type of cheap paperback fiction popular in the late 19th and early 20th centuries in the U.S. It came in various forms, including story papers, weekly publications costing five or ten cents, and thicker book reprints. Sometimes it even included early pulp magazines. The term "dime novel" was still used as late as 1940, notably in the magazine Western Dime Novels. Dime novels laid the groundwork for today's mass-market paperbacks, comic books, and media adaptations. Nowadays, "dime novel" often refers to hastily written, sensationalized stories, typically seen as low-quality literature.

C24 Gallery, established in 2011 by Emre & Maide Kurttepeli and Mel Dogan, is located in Chelsea, New York City. The gallery spans two levels and 5000 square feet, showcasing exhibitions by both local and international artists. Recognized as one of the top 500 galleries worldwide by Modern Painters magazine in 2013 & 2015, C24 Gallery participates in annual art fairs in New York, Miami, and Europe. It represents a diverse range of artists including Carole Feuerman, Katja Loher, Irfan Önürmen, and others.

Henry James O'Brien Bedford-Jones (1887–1949) was a Canadian writer known for his work in various genres such as historical fiction, adventure, fantasy, science fiction, crime, and Westerns. He became a naturalized United States citizen in 1908. Encouraged by his friend William Wallace Cook, a writer, Bedford-Jones started writing dime novels and stories for pulp magazines. He was incredibly prolific, with one pulp editor recalling an instance in Paris where Bedford-Jones was simultaneously working on two novels, each on its own typewriter. He considered Alexandre Dumas his main influence and even wrote a sequel to Dumas' famous work "The Three Musketeers," titled "D'Artagnan" (1928). Bedford-Jones authored over 100 novels, earning him the title "King of the Pulps." His works were featured in numerous pulp magazines, with Blue Book magazine being his primary publisher. Additionally, his stories appeared in Adventure, All-Story Weekly, Argosy, Short Stories, Top-Notch Magazine, The Magic Carpet, Golden Fleece, Ace-High Magazine, People's Story Magazine, Hutchinson's Adventure-Story Magazine, Detective Fiction Weekly, Western Story Magazine, and Weird Tales.

Linda Duvall is a Canadian artist and educator who splits her time between Saskatchewan and Toronto. Her art focuses on social projects, exhibitions, and research that delve into topics like morality, truth, and how people interact with each other through conversation. She uses various mediums like photography, video, installations, and performance art, often involving communities in her work, including online archiving. Duvall's projects often invite participation from individuals or groups to engage in specific conversations or expressions. Her work explores themes such as speech acts (like confessions or gossip), truth, grieving, intimacy, and vulnerability. She has had solo exhibitions in several galleries worldwide, and she has been involved with various artist-run organizations' boards.

Jessica Todd Harper is a portrait photographer who studied art history at Bryn Mawr College and earned a master's degree in photography from the Rochester Institute of Technology. Her work has been featured in various publications like Photo District News, Newsweek, and O, The Oprah Magazine. She has exhibited her photographs at prestigious venues such as The International Museum of Photography, the Houston Museum of Fine Arts, and the Allentown Art Museum. Harper has also won awards, including a project competition at Center and being selected as one of PDN's 30 Emerging Photographers to Watch. She is represented by Cohen Amador Gallery in New York and teaches at Swarthmore College. Harper was also a finalist for the Smithsonian Institution's National Portrait Gallery 2016 Outwin Boochever Portrait Competition.

Vanguard was a magazine that started in Vancouver, Canada, from 1972 to 1989. It talked about Canadian art and artists, and it came after another magazine called the Vancouver Art Gallery Bulletin, which was around from 1933 to 1971. Vanguard was first published by the Vancouver Art Gallery monthly from 1972 to 1984. It began in January 1972. Then, in February 1979, it changed its look to a glossy magazine and started covering art events across Canada. From 1985 to 1989, it was published by the Vancouver Society for Critical Arts Publications before it stopped being published. You can find all the issues at the Vancouver Art Gallery library.

"Pluck and Luck: Complete Stories of Adventure" was a popular American dime novel, first published by Frank Tousey. It ran for a long time, from January 12, 1898, to March 5, 1929, with a total of 1605 issues. At first, it was a 32-page magazine published twice a month, then it became a weekly publication. The magazine started at 8 x 11 inches in size but later switched to 6 x 9 inches, featuring colorful covers. Harry Wolff published issues No. 1002-1464, and the rest were published by Westbury.

question: which writer has the highest number of skill  Langston Hughes or  Ian McEwan
pos: James Mercer Langston Hughes (1902–1967) was a writer and activist from Joplin, Missouri, known for his poetry, novels, plays, and columns.

Ian Russell McEwan, an English writer born on June 21, 1948, is known for his novels and screenplays. He was recognized by The Times in 2008 as one of the top 50 British writers since 1945, and The Daily Telegraph ranked him 19th among the 100 most influential figures in British culture in the same year.
neg: The Langston Hughes Medal is given out every year starting from 1978 to honor a notable writer linked with the African diaspora. This award acknowledges their impactful contributions in various literary genres such as poetry, fiction, drama, autobiography, and critical essays, all of which contribute to preserving the legacy of Langston Hughes.

Le Conversazioni is a literary festival held in Capri, organized by Italian film personalities Antonio Monda and Davide Azzolini. It started in 2006 and receives funding from the Italian government and various corporations. The festival attracts many famous writers such as Martin Amis, Paul Auster, and others.

Black Nativity is a play that tells the Nativity story using an all-black cast. They sing traditional Christmas songs in a gospel style, and some new songs were made just for this show. Langston Hughes wrote it, and it first played Off-Broadway on December 11, 1961. This was a big deal because it was one of the first plays by a black writer to be shown there. It went on a successful tour of Europe in 1962, including a performance at the Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds in Italy. Since 1969, Black Nativity has been performed every year in Boston, Massachusetts, at different places like the Elma Lewis School of Fine Arts, Boston Opera House, Tremont Temple, Roxbury Community College, Northeastern's Blackman Auditorium, and currently at Emerson College's Paramount Theater. It's the longest-running production of Langston Hughes' Black Nativity. The cast includes 160 singers of all ages and voice types, with soloists, a narrator, and Mary and Joseph, who don't speak. There are also musicians and American Sign Language interpreters.

The Langston Hughes House in Harlem, Manhattan, New York City, is a historic home. Built in 1869, it's an Italianate style building with three stories plus a basement. It's made of brownstone, measures 20 feet wide and 45 feet deep. Langston Hughes, a well-known African American poet and author, used the top floor as his workspace from 1947 to 1967.

The Langston Hughes Performing Arts Institute (LHPAI) is a cultural venue located in Seattle, Washington, USA. It's managed by the City of Seattle Office of Arts and Culture and is named after the African-American writer Langston Hughes. Originally built in 1915 as a synagogue for the Orthodox Jewish congregation Chevra Bikur Cholim, it's now designated as a Seattle landmark. In 2009, plans were made for a $2.5 million renovation, which includes strengthening the building against earthquakes for the second time.

Robert Earl Jones (February 3, 1910 – September 7, 2006) was an American actor and boxer, sometimes known as Earl Jones. He was one of the earliest well-known African-American actors in movies, and he was closely connected to the artistic and cultural movement known as the Harlem Renaissance of the 1920s and 1930s. Jones collaborated with Langston Hughes, a prominent figure of that era, at the start of his career. In the 1930s in New York City, he mentored young people as part of the Works Progress Administration, a big government program. Through this work, he met Langston Hughes, who then cast him in his play "Don't You Want to Be Free?" (1938). Jones gained recognition for starring roles in films like "Lying Lips" (1939) and later in his career, he became known for supporting roles in movies like "The Sting" (1973), "Trading Places" (1983), "The Cotton Club" (1984), and "Witness" (1985). He was also the father of actor James Earl Jones.

"I, Too" is a poem by Langston Hughes. It shows a desire for equality and challenges the notion that patriotism is only for certain races. It was published in 1926 in Hughes's first poetry collection. Along with his other works, it played a significant role in the Harlem Renaissance, a cultural movement in the 1920s and 30s where African Americans found strength in literature, art, music, and poetry to express themselves and advocate for civil rights.

The Langston Hughes Society is a group in the United States that focuses on the writing of African American poet Langston Hughes. It was the first national organization dedicated to the work of a Black writer. It started after Hughes passed away and after the Langston Hughes Study conference in 1981, organized by Hughes' literary assistant George Houston Bass. The society's main publication is the Langston Hughes Review, released by the Institute for African American Studies at The University of Georgia. They also give out the Langston Hughes Award every year.

question: How large is the shopping mall where KGOT radio station has its studios ?
pos: The Dimond Center in Anchorage, Alaska, is a big shopping mall covering 728,000 square feet (67,000 square meters). It sits at the southwest corner of East Dimond Boulevard and the Old Seward Highway in south Anchorage. It's the biggest indoor mall in Alaska, even though the Tikahtnu Commons, an open-air mall on the other side of town, has more total retail space.

KGOT (101.3 FM) is a popular radio station in Anchorage, Alaska that plays the latest hits. It's owned by iHeartMedia, Inc. and operates from studios located in the Dimond Center, along with its sister stations.
neg: Bedok Mall is a big shopping center in Bedok, Singapore. It's part of a mixed-use area with stores, homes, and a bus station all together. Situated in the center of Bedok, it has a 3-story mall for shopping and family activities, along with eight residential towers named Bedok Residences, each 15 stories tall. This mall was the first large shopping center in Bedok, replacing the old bus station.

The Mall of Georgia is a big shopping center in Gwinnett County, Georgia, close to Buford, which is about 30 miles northeast of Atlanta. It was built in 1999 and is currently the biggest mall in Georgia, with over 200 stores on three floors. Some of its main stores are Belk, Dillard's, JCPenney, Macy's, and Von Maur. Other popular stores include Barnes & Noble, Dick's Sporting Goods, and Haverty's. There are also stores like Best Buy, Nordstrom Rack, T.J. Maxx, and Target nearby in the Mall of Georgia Crossing. The mall has a village area with lifestyle shops and outdoor restaurants, plus a big amphitheater with 500 seats. It's known for attracting high-end stores like Coach, Swarovski, Clarks, J.Crew, and Aveda. The Mall of Georgia is managed by the Simon Property Group.

Kentucky Oaks Mall, located in Paducah, Kentucky, USA, is a large indoor shopping center managed by Cafaro Company. It features over 90 stores, including popular brands like JCPenney, Best Buy, Elder-Beerman, Dillard's (split into two stores), and Dick's Sporting Goods. The mall also hosts the regional radio station Rock 98.3 WJLI. Initially the biggest mall in Kentucky by space for lease, it now ranks as the third-largest in the state, following Fayette Mall in Lexington and Mall St. Matthews in Louisville.

The Mall of New Hampshire is a big shopping center in Manchester, New Hampshire. It's got Macy's, Old Navy, JCPenney, Sears, and Best Buy as its main stores. With over 120 other stores, plus a big food court, it's 930,000 square feet in size. It's the third biggest mall in New Hampshire, after the Mall at Rockingham Park in Salem and the Pheasant Lane Mall in Nashua. The Mall of New Hampshire was the first large shopping mall in the state. It was first built in August 1977, but it's been added to a lot since then.

Park City Center is a big shopping mall in Lancaster, Pennsylvania. It's the largest one in Lancaster County and sits where U.S. Route 30 meets Harrisburg Pike. The mall looks like a snowflake, with stores along 8 corridors that spread out from the middle. The center of the mall has a big white tent for a roof, covering an area called Center Court. In 2008, the mall got a major makeover that lasted 18 months and updated everything. When it first opened, people also called it the Mall of Four Seasons because each of the four main corridors leading to big stores had a seasonal name: Winter had JC Penney, Spring had Sears, Summer had Gimbel's (later Pomeroy's/Boscov's), and Autumn had Watt & Shand (later Bon-Ton). This fancy mall, right in Amish country, was one of the first to have its own TV system. Down in the Winter area, there were studios for Park City Communications and the local CBS station, WLYH-TV 15, along with an ice skating rink.

Tower City Rapid Station is a transit hub in Cleveland, Ohio, USA. It's the main stop for the RTA Red Line and a key stop for the RTA Green and Blue Lines. You'll find it right under Prospect Avenue in Tower City Center mall. You can only get to the station through the mall, so it's open whenever the RTA trains are running.

Pavilion Mall is a big shopping center situated in Biñan City, Laguna, Philippines. It was the first major mall to open in Biñan City, starting its operations in October 1999. Currently, it is under the management of Ayala Malls, which is the third-largest mall chain in the Philippines. The mall is easily reachable by the National Highway or through the Mamplasan Exit on the South Luzon Expressway.

Here's a simpler version of the paragraph:

SM City Cebu, or SM Cebu, is a big shopping mall in Cebu City, Philippines. It's the fourth mall made by SM Prime Holdings, which is the biggest mall owner and developer in the country. This mall is the first one they made outside of Metro Manila and is the sixth largest in the Philippines. It covers 11.8 hectares of land and has a total floor space of 268,611 square meters.

question: What are the names of the members of the Detroit-based hip hop duo who has worked with Jason Gilbert?
pos: Jason Gilbert, also called JG, is a record producer and songwriter from the Cayman Islands. He has worked with famous artists like Eminem, Bad Meets Evil, Akon, Christina Aguilera, and Taio Cruz.

Bad Meets Evil is a hip hop duo from Detroit, made up of Royce da 5'9 (Bad) and Eminem (Evil). They started in 1997 with the help of their friend Proof. They've released one EP and four singles. Their first release in 1999 was a double non-album single, "Nuttin' to Do" and "Scary Movies." "Nuttin' to Do" reached 36 on the Hot Rap Songs chart, while "Scary Movies" reached 63 on the UK Singles Chart and was featured in the movie Scary Movie.

Islam has two main branches: Sunni and Shia. In Saudi Arabia, particularly in the Eastern Province, there's a significant Shia population, despite official figures suggesting otherwise. Saudi Arabia follows Wahhabism, with limited religious freedom among sects. Smaller Shia communities exist in Egypt and Jordan. Throughout history, Shia Muslims have faced discrimination, including genocidal attacks under Saddam Hussein's regime. The topic of Shia Islam is sensitive in the Arab world, especially among Sunni elites. This article explores the history and current situation of Shia Muslims in the Arabic-speaking world.

question: Which band is from England, Fireflight or Dirty Pretty Things?
pos: Fireflight is a Christian rock band from Eustis, Florida, formed in 1999 and signed by Flicker Records. Dirty Pretty Things were a band from England led by Carl Barât, who was also in The Libertines. The band formed in September 2005 after The Libertines broke up due to a disagreement between Barât and Pete Doherty in 2004. Barât had previously mentioned that his new project would be with Vertigo Records. Didz Hammond left the Cooper Temple Clause to join the band, along with Libertines drummer Gary Powell and guitarist Anthony Rossomando, who had filled in for Doherty after he left The Libertines. Their first performances were in October 2005 in Italy and Paris, France. They announced their breakup on October 1, 2008, and played their final shows in November of that year.

question: The Bart the Fink episode of The Simpsons aired in February of 1996, and involves the host of which kiddie show?

In this episode, Bart unintentionally reveals Krusty the Clown's tax evasion, causing Krusty's downfall. Krusty pretends to commit suicide to escape his troubles but ultimately decides to return to his career as a television clown with Bart's encouragement.

"Postcards from the Wedge" is the fourteenth episode of The Simpsons' twenty-first season, first aired on March 14, 2010, on Fox in the United States. Bart tries to manipulate Homer's strictness and Marge's sympathy but fails when they see through his plan and decide to ignore him. These themes were introduced in the previous season and would eventually lead to Bart's first true punishment in the series, setting a precedent for future episodes. This episode marks the last instance of Bart being grounded until "The Marge-ian Chronicles" in Season 27, six years later, also written by Brian Kelley.

The Itchy & Scratchy Show is a fictional animated series within The Simpsons. It's part of The Krusty the Clown Show, which Bart and Lisa Simpson watch. The cartoon features a cruel blue mouse, Itchy, who constantly harms and kills Scratchy, a helpless black cat. It first appeared in The Tracey Ullman Show in 1988 and later in The Simpsons in 1990. Characters from The Simpsons are sometimes involved in its production, like Roger Meyers Jr., who runs the studio.

This short introduced the Simpson family: Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa, and Maggie. Eventually, these shorts became the basis for the animated series "The Simpsons" after three seasons on The Tracey Ullman Show. It was written by Al Jean, Mike Reiss, Sam Simon, and Matt Groening, and directed by Rich Moore. In this episode, Bart chops off the head of the statue of Jebediah Springfield to impress three older kids he looks up to. However, when he realizes his mistake and confesses to his family, they go to town where an angry mob awaits. Bart apologizes, and the town forgives him as he puts the head back on the statue. Hutz and Dr. Nick inflate Bart's injuries to win sympathy during the trial. Marge opposes the lawsuit and becomes worried when Homer asks Bart to lie.

In the episode, the Simpson family's picnic is disrupted by mosquitoes, so they visit an Indian casino. Bart tries to sneak in but gets caught and is shown a glimpse of his future by the casino manager, where he's a failed musician living with Ralph Wiggum. Meanwhile, Lisa is portrayed as the President of the United States, trying to solve financial issues. This episode, like "Lisa's Wedding," gives a glimpse into the future of the characters.

The show was designed for local children's programs, where producers could mix it with other cartoons and live-action shows to make their own unique variety program.

question: Which mall, Wilton Mall or Viaport Rotterdam, has had more owners?
pos: Wilton Mall at Saratoga, also known as The Wilton Mall, is a big shopping center near Saratoga Springs, New York. It's off Interstate 87 exit 15 in Wilton. The mall is quite large, covering 763,270 square feet. Some of its main stores include Bon-Ton, Dick's Sporting Goods, JCPenney, HomeGoods, and Sears. You'll also find a food court and a movie theater there. Macerich owns the mall now; they bought it from Wilmorite Properties in 2004.

Viaport Rotterdam, previously known as Rotterdam Square, is a shopping mall in Rotterdam, New York, USA. Originally owned by Wilmorite Properties, it was renamed when The Macerich Company took over Wilmorite in 2005. The mall spans 900,000 sqft with 80+ stores, a 450-seat food court, eateries, and a seven-screen Sony-Loews Cineplex (now run by Zurich Cinemas). Kohan Retail Investment Group bought the mall in 2014, then Via Properties acquired it in 2015, renaming it Via Port Rotterdam in 2016.
neg: The Original Outlet Mall was an indoor shopping center in Kenosha, Wisconsin. It opened in 1982 as Wisconsin's first outlet mall. In 2005, its new owners, Tucker Development from Highland Park, Illinois, demolished the mall. Now, part of the land where the mall used to be is home to an Ashley Furniture store.

ViaPort Florida, previously called Lake Square Mall, is a shopping mall located in Leesburg, Florida. It opened its doors on September 24, 1980, and is currently managed by Lake Square Mall Realty Management and Via Properties. The mall features major stores like Belk, Sears, and Via Entertainment.

Saratoga Mall, once located near Saratoga Springs, New York, was a shopping center enclosed within a building. It got torn down in 1999 and was originally called Pyramid Mall Saratoga. Positioned off Exit 15 on I-87, it was on Route 50. After it was demolished, it got replaced by a large retail area called Wilton Square.

Birchwood Mall is a shopping center situated in Fort Gratiot Township, near Port Huron, Michigan, USA. It's managed by Rouse Properties, a major mall owner. With over 100 stores, a ten-screen AMC movie theater, and a food court, it's a bustling hub. Major stores like Carson's, JCPenney, Macy's, and Target draw shoppers, although Sears, the former fifth anchor, shut down in 2016. You can find the mall on Pine Grove Avenue (M-25), just north of Interstate 69 (I-69) and I-94.

Hubertus Huib Wilton, born on March 12, 1921, in Rotterdam, was a Dutch tennis player. He played for the Netherlands Davis Cup team in 1953, alongside players like Hans van Swol (his men's doubles partner), Boebi van Meegeren, and Ivo Rinkel. At Wimbledon in 1950, Wilton made it to the second round but lost to Henry Billington of Great Britain with a score of 6–1, 7–5, 11–9.

Pierre Bossier Mall is a shopping center located in Bossier City, Louisiana, right where Interstate 20 and Airline Drive meet. The mall, just like the city it's in, is named after Pierre Bossier, one of the early settlers. It was bought by General Growth Properties in the 1980s for $26 million and later sold. Nowadays, it's owned and managed by Rouse Properties, a big mall company in the US. Some of its main stores include J. C. Penney, Sears, Dillard's, Virginia College, and Forever 21 (formerly Stage). The mall used to have a theater called The Bossier 6, which opened in 1982 but closed down in 2000.

Eastland Mall, located in Charlotte, North Carolina, opened its doors in 1975 as the largest mall in the state at the time. It boasted three major department stores: Belk, J.C. Penney, and Ivey's, with a Sears store joining them four years later. However, over time, the mall faced challenges. Burlington Coat Factory, its last major anchor store, closed down, leaving the mall with no anchor tenants. Glimcher Realty Trust and the City of Charlotte owned the mall, but due to significant debts, Glimcher requested that the mall be placed under receivership. There were even reports of the mall facing foreclosure. Eventually, the interior space of the mall was sold to Boxer Properties of Houston for $2 million. The mall ceased operations on June 30, 2010. Subsequently, the city of Charlotte purchased the mall from Boxer Properties along with the owners of the vacant anchor stores, hoping to find a developer willing to revitalize the area.

Karcher Mall, situated in Nampa, Idaho, USA, is a shopping complex that first opened its doors in August 1965. Initially, it boasted anchor stores like Buttrey Food & Drug, Rasco-Tempo, and Skaggs Drug Centers. It held the title of the largest shopping center in the Treasure Valley until 1988 when the Boise Towne Square Mall opened up in Boise, diverting traffic away from Karcher Mall. Consequently, some retailers, including the 20-year-old anchor JCPenney, left Karcher Mall for Boise. Over the years, the mall changed hands multiple times, with various owners attempting to breathe new life into it, albeit with mixed success. Presently, the mall houses 28 stores, with anchor stores like Burlington Coat Factory, Discount Furniture, Jo-Ann Fabrics, Ross Dress for Less, and Mor Furniture. Milan Properties, Inc. currently owns the mall.

question: Which close friend of an American former basketball player was signed for to play for the Timberwolves?
pos: The Timberwolves had their 12th season in the NBA during 2000–01. They faced challenges after Malik Sealy's death, signing Chauncey Billups and LaPhonso Ellis to fill the gap. However, a secret deal with Joe Smith was canceled by the NBA, resulting in penalties like losing draft picks and a fine. Despite the setbacks, they managed an 11-game winning streak and ended fourth in their division with a 47–35 record. Kevin Garnett made it to the 2001 NBA All-Star Game amidst the turmoil.

Kevin Maurice Garnett, born on May 19, 1976, is a retired American basketball player. He spent 21 seasons in the NBA, playing as a power forward and center. Garnett stood out in high school, earning honors like the 1995 McDonald's All-American and a national player of the year award. He entered the NBA draft in the same year, getting picked as the fifth overall selection by the Minnesota Timberwolves, marking the first time in 20 years that a player was drafted straight out of high school.
neg: Eduardo Portela Marín, born in 1934 in Barcelona, Spain, is a retired basketball player, coach, and executive. He previously led the ACB, the organization overseeing Spain's premier basketball league, and ULEB, the Union of European Leagues of Basketball.

Richard Richie Garner, born in Mount Vernon, New York, is a former American basketball player famous for his time playing college basketball at Manhattan College. He played for the Jaspers from 1968 to 1972. Throughout his four years, he scored more than 1,000 points, maintained a shooting percentage of over .500, and set a record of 121 assists in the 1970-71 season, which has since been broken. Garner was the first player from Manhattan College to win the Haggerty Award, given annually to the best male collegiate basketball player in the greater New York City area since 1935-36. He received the award during his senior year, sharing it with Fordham's Tom Sullivan.

Delray Brooks, born on October 24, 1965, is an American basketball coach and former player. He gained fame as a high school basketball star in Indiana, winning awards like the 1984 Co-Indiana Mr. Basketball and 1984 USA Today Player of the Year. Despite initially playing for Bobby Knight at Indiana University, he later transferred to Providence College under Rick Pitino's coaching, where he experienced success. Transitioning to professional play, Brooks faced challenges in different leagues before becoming an assistant coach for Pitino at the University of Kentucky, where they reached the NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship final four. Later, he became the head coach at the University of Texas-Pan American but was fired due to a scandal. Now, he coaches high school basketball, currently leading the men's team at Clay High School.

Mike Edwards, born in the early 1950s, is a former American basketball player. He's most famous for his time playing basketball in high school and college in the United States, rather than his professional career in Mexico. Edwards attended the University of Tennessee from 1970 to 1973, where he excelled in basketball and was even named the 1972 co-Southeastern Conference Men's Basketball Player of the Year. In 2003, he was honored by being inducted into the Indiana Basketball Hall of Fame, and in February 2009, he was selected for the Tennessee All-Century Team, recognizing him as one of the top 20 players in the program's history.

Ricard Rubio i Vives, born on October 21, 1990, is a professional basketball player from Spain who currently plays for the Utah Jazz in the NBA. He made his debut in the Spanish ACB League at just 14 years old, becoming the youngest player in league history on October 15, 2005. At 16, he played his first EuroLeague game, making him the first player born in the 1990s to do so. Rubio was drafted by the Minnesota Timberwolves as the fifth overall pick in the 2009 NBA draft, making him the first player from the 1990s to be drafted. Despite an initial agreement, he ended up joining FC Barcelona before later joining the Timberwolves in 2011. After six seasons with the Timberwolves, he was traded to the Utah Jazz in June 2017.

Von McDade, an ex-basketball player from the USA, was born on June 7, 1967. During his college years, he played for the Oklahoma State Cowboys and Milwaukee Panthers. McDade stood out in 1991 when he ranked third in the country for scoring, averaging 29.6 points per game. Despite being drafted by the New Jersey Nets in the second round of the 1991 NBA draft, he never played in the NBA.

Jerry Ray Lucas, born on March 30, 1940, is a retired American basketball player known for his exceptional memory skills. He achieved national recognition as a standout high school player and later as a star player for Ohio State University. Lucas won a gold medal in the 1960 Olympics and had a successful international career before transitioning to the NBA. In college, he led the Ohio State Buckeyes to the 1960 national championship and was a three-time Big Ten Player of the Year and a two-time NCAA Player of the Year. In the NBA, Lucas was a three-time All-NBA First Team selection, a seven-time NBA All-Star, and won the Rookie of the Year award in 1964. He also earned accolades such as Most Valuable Player of the 1965 NBA All-Star Game. Lucas was inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 1980.

Curt Trouble Smith, born in 1971, is a retired American basketball player famous for his streetball skills in Washington, D.C. and Maryland. He attended Compton College and later Drake University, where he earned recognition as the Missouri Valley Conference Men's Basketball Player of the Year during his junior year in 1992–93.

question: What is the 2010 population of the city 2.1 miles southwest of Marietta Air Force Station?
pos: Smyrna, located northwest of Atlanta, is part of the inner ring of the Atlanta Metropolitan Area. In 2010, its population was 51,271, increasing to 53,438 by 2013 according to the U.S. Census Bureau. It's part of the Atlanta-Sandy Springs-Roswell MSA, within the Atlanta—Athens-Clarke—Sandy Springs CSA. Between 2000 and 2012, Smyrna saw a 28% population growth, making it one of Georgia's fastest-growing and most densely populated cities in the metro area.

Marietta Air Force Station, also known as ADC ID: M-111 and NORAD ID: Z-111, used to be a radar station for the United States Air Force. It sat about 2.1 miles northeast of Smyrna, Georgia, but it shut down in 1968.
neg: RAF Warmwell, a previous Royal Air Force base in Dorset, England, operated from 1937 to 1946. It was situated around 5 miles east-southeast of Dorchester and approximately 100 miles southwest of London.

Camp Pedricktown Air Defense Base was a Cold War site equipped with Army Air Defense facilities, including radars for detecting and identifying aircraft. Later, the radars were relocated to Gibbsboro Air Force Station. The old Martin AN/FSG-1 Antiaircraft Defense System, a vacuum tube computer from 1957, was taken out when command of the defense area shifted to Highlands Air Force Station near New York City, which oversaw the New York-Philadelphia Defense Area.

The 410th Bombardment Squadron used to be part of the United States Air Force but is no longer active. Its final assignment was with the 94th Bombardment Group. The squadron was shut down at Marietta Air Force Base in Georgia on March 20, 1951.

Royal Air Force Station Cottesmore, also known as RAF Cottesmore, used to be an air force base in Rutland, England, located between Cottesmore and Market Overton. It was where all the Harrier GR9 squadrons of the Royal Air Force and No. 122 Expeditionary Air Wing were based. The station shut down in 2011, earlier than initially planned, due to budget cuts in the defense sector. The closure was part of a broader decision that included retiring the Harrier GR9 aircraft and disbanding Joint Force Harrier. After its formal closing ceremony in March 2011, the airfield was managed as a satellite site to RAF Wittering until March 2012.

Stramshall is a village in Staffordshire, England, part of Uttoxeter Rural parish. It's about 2.1 miles north of Uttoxeter town, around 16.3 miles northeast of Stafford, and roughly 143 miles northwest of London. The village is also close to the A50 road, which connects Warrington and Leicester, approximately 0.8 miles to the north. The closest railway station is in Uttoxeter, serving the Crewe to Derby line, and the nearest airport is East Midlands Airport.
Topsham Air Force Station used to be a United States Air Force base near Brunswick, Maine, about 2.1 miles to the north. However, it was shut down in 1969.

The 302d Air Division used to be a part of the United States Air Force but is not active anymore. Its final location was at Marietta Air Force Base in Georgia, where it stopped operating on June 27, 1949.

Eldorado Air Force Station, situated 35 miles south of San Angelo, Texas, was home to one of four special radar systems called AN/FPS-115 PAVE PAWS, which provided early-warning capabilities. The station was operated by the 8th Space Warning Squadron, part of the 21st Space Wing under Air Force Space Command.

question: Are Buried Country and South of the Border both films turned into stage performances?
pos: Buried Country is a respected documentary film, book, and soundtrack album, and it's now also a stage show. Created by acclaimed writer Clinton Walker, it's a detailed account of Australian country music within the Aboriginal community, highlighting the genre's key stars.

South of the Border is a documentary directed by Oliver Stone in 2009. It first premiered at the 2009 Venice Film Festival. Tariq Ali, the writer for the project, describes it as a political road movie. Stone's goal with the film is to change people's perception of a leader who is often unfairly portrayed as a strongman or a clown.
neg: Clinton Walker, born in 1957, is an Australian writer primarily known for his writings on popular music. However, he also has a broader interest in social and cultural history and theory. The Sun-Herald in Sydney has praised him as the top chronicler of Australian grass-roots culture. He's often been ahead of his time, as noted by Rhythms magazine in 2015 regarding his project "Buried Country," which was seen as pioneering a decade ahead. Walker's influence extends beyond just writing; his critical insights have actively shaped Australian music development. His books like "Inner City Sound" (1981) and "Buried Country" (2000) have not only informed but also inspired generations of musicians. Despite achieving best-selling success with biographies such as that of Bon Scott, Walker's non-music works like "Football Life" (1998) and "Golden Miles" (2005) have offered fresh perspectives on subjects often overlooked in serious discourse.

Margaretha Murray, also known as Milan Murray, is a South African actress born on October 30, 1974. She's famous in South Africa for her roles in soap operas, feature films, and stage productions. Additionally, she co-hosts a weekly breakfast show called Ontbytsake on kykNET, an Afrikaans channel on DStv. She resides in Johannesburg with her husband, Schalk van der Merwe, and their two children, Steph and Lua. Murray grew up in the Cape Province of South Africa.

Araby Lockhart, born on December 4, 1926, is a Canadian actress famous for her roles in movies like Capote and Police Academy, as well as her stage work with Hart House Theatre and the Straw Hat Players. She's also been the President of the Actors' Fund of Canada.

Edward John Carroll, also known as E.J. Carroll (1874-1931), was an Australian businessperson in the entertainment industry. He made movies featuring actors like Snowy Baker and Raymond Longford, and played a role in founding Birch, Carroll and Coyle. Facing challenges in getting his films shown globally, he shifted focus from making movies to showing them in theaters.

Leah Flanagan, a singer-songwriter hailing from Sydney, New South Wales, has made notable appearances on Australian TV shows like Spicks & Specks and RockQuiz. With two albums under her belt, she's toured extensively across Australia, both solo and as part of festival ensembles. Leah takes pride in her identity as an Indigenous musician, contributing significantly to the music scene. Notably, she's been involved in important projects like the reissue of Archie Roach’s Charcoal Lane and Buried Country 1.5, The Story of Aboriginal Country Music. Her latest album, Saudades, was recorded at Midnight Oil's Jim Moginie's studio and mixed by Paul McKercher, known for his work with bands like You Am I and Augie March.

Gopishantha, known as Manorama or Aachi, was an Indian actress and comedian. She appeared in over 1,500 films, 5,000 stage performances, and numerous TV series until her passing in 2015. She set a Guinness World Record for acting in over 1,000 films in 1985, and by 2015, she had acted in over 1,500 films. She received several awards, including the Kalaimamani award, Padma Shri in 2002, the National Film Award for Best Supporting Actress for her role in the film "Pudhiya Padhai" in 1989, and the Filmfare Lifetime Achievement Award – South in 1995.
Sine Novela is a Philippine daytime soap opera broadcasted on GMA Network. It features old classic movies from Viva Films transformed into mini-series. The show stars an ensemble cast.

The Woody Guthrie Folk Festival happens every year around mid-July to celebrate Woody Guthrie's life and music. It takes place in Okemah, Oklahoma, where Guthrie was born, usually on the weekend closest to July 14th, his birthday. During the day, you can catch main stage performances indoors at the Brick Street Cafe and the Crystal Theater, while in the evening, they move outdoors to the Pastures of Plenty. The festival is organized by the Woody Guthrie Coalition, a non-profit group dedicated to preserving Guthrie's musical legacy.

question: "A Summer in the Cage" and "American Hardcore" are both what kind of film?
pos: "American Hardcore: The History of American Punk Rock 1980-1986" is a documentary directed by Paul Rachman and written by Steven Blush, who also authored the book it's based on. The film, released on September 22, 2006, focuses on the early days of hardcore punk, showcasing bands like Bad Brains, Black Flag, D.O.A., Minor Threat, Minutemen, and SSD. It hit DVD shelves courtesy of Sony Pictures Home Entertainment on February 20, 2007.

"A Summer in the Cage" is a documentary from 2007 that explores a man's life with bipolar disorder. The film focuses on the filmmaker's friend, Sam, and includes an interview with mental health expert Kay Redfield Jamison. It was directed by Benjamin Selkow and first aired on the Sundance Channel in 2007.
neg: The album "I Against I" by Bad Brains, released in November 1986 through SST Records (catalog number SST 065), is their third studio album and their best-selling one. It's praised for blending American hardcore punk with funk, soul, reggae, and heavy metal. The album is so acclaimed that it's listed in the book "1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die." Additionally, it includes an MTV video for the title track, directed by Paul Rachman, who later directed the documentary feature film "American Hardcore."

Hellfest was an American hardcore punk festival known for its hot summer weather. It started out featuring hardcore bands but later expanded to include various genres. The festival was praised for its friendly atmosphere, with no barriers allowing easy access to the stage for stage diving. It also had a strong focus on social causes like animal rights, with many attendees embracing straight edge or vegan lifestyles. Despite its popularity, Hellfest was abruptly canceled in 2005, leading to some fans filing lawsuits due to refund issues.

The documentary "All Ages: The Boston Hardcore Film," directed by Drew Stone, premiered at the Independent Film Festival of Boston on April 27, 2012. It showcases interviews, old footage, and music from early hardcore bands in Boston like Deep Wound, DYS, Gang Green, Impact Unit, Jerry's Kids, Negative FX, SS Decontrol, The Freeze, and The F.U.'s. The film also includes interviews with well-known figures like author Michael Patrick MacDonald, actress Christine Elise McCarthy, advertising executive Jonathan Anastas, Thrasher Magazine editor Jake Phelps, American Hardcore director Paul Rachman, and Newbury Comics owner Michael Dreese. You can find the DVD release of "All Ages" with additional content and commentary from the director.

"Punk's Not Dead," a documentary directed by Susan Dynner in 2007, explores the vibrant scene of hardcore punk and pop punk music in America. The film takes viewers inside clubs, malls, and recording studios to showcase the thriving culture. It features performances by 1980s hardcore bands and MTV skate punk and pop punk/rock acts, along with interviews and behind-the-scenes footage of bands, labels, and fans.

The Suicide File was a hardcore punk band from Boston, Massachusetts, formed in April 2001. They wrote songs with mainly political themes, but also tackled social and personal issues. Their music was mostly released by the label Indecision Records. They reunited in June 2006 for their first European Tour. Band members have ties to other bands like The Hope Conspiracy, Death By Stereo, and When Tigers Fight. Despite their short career, they left a lasting impact on the Boston hardcore scene and are still respected within the community. Since 2006, they've played a few successful reunion shows.

Deadfall, a crime drama movie from 1993, was directed by Christopher Coppola, who also co-wrote the script with Nick Vallelonga. The film features a star-studded cast including Michael Biehn, Nicolas Cage, Charlie Sheen, James Coburn, and Peter Fonda. It's worth noting that the film also inspired the song "Deadfall" by the American hardcore punk band Snot. Additionally, a movie called Arsenal, released in 2017, serves as both a prequel and sequel, with Nicolas Cage reprising his role as Eddie King.

Combat Zone Wrestling (CZW) is a wrestling organization in the U.S. It started in 1999 by John Zandig and some of his students, including Ric Blade, T.C.K, Lobo, Nick Gage, and Justice Pain, along with trainer Jon Dahmer. They held wrestling events in New Jersey and Delaware, focusing on a style known as ultraviolent wrestling, which involves using items like ladders, tables, chairs, thumbtacks, barbed wire, and even fire. CZW filled a gap left by the closure of Extreme Championship Wrestling (ECW), catering to fans who enjoyed intense, hardcore matches. CZW gained prominence in 2001 with their Cage of Death 3 event at the ECW Arena, becoming a top hardcore wrestling promotion after ECW ceased operations.

Blacklisted, an American hardcore punk band, released their fourth studio album, "When People Grow, People Go," on February 10, 2015, through Deathwish Inc. It's their first release since the 2012 EP "So, You Are A Magician?" and their first full-length album since 2009's "No One Deserves to Be Here More Than Me." They started working on the album in late 2013, blending their experimental and hardcore styles. Before its release, they teased fans with the tracks "Deeper Kind," streamed online in December 2014, followed by "Burnt Palms" and a music video for "Turn in the Pike" in January 2015.

question: How many novels are there in the series of novels of which Shadows in Flight is the tenth novel ?
pos: "Shadows in Flight" by Orson Scott Card, released in 2012, is the tenth novel in the Ender's Game series. The story picks up where the original four Shadow series books left off, following Bean and his children as they discover an ancient Formic ark during their space journey. A sample chapter was released on November 28, 2011, with the hardcover version following on January 17, 2012, and the paperback on January 29, 2013. The book was nominated for the Goodreads Choice Award for science fiction.

The Ender's Game series, also known as the Ender saga or Enderverse, is a collection of science fiction books by Orson Scott Card. It all began with the novelette "Ender's Game," which was later turned into a full novel. As of now, the series includes fifteen novels, thirteen short stories, 47 comic issues, an audioplay, and a film adaptation. The first two novels, "Ender's Game" and "Speaker for the Dead," won both the Hugo and Nebula Awards and were highly influential in 1980s science fiction.
neg: Castle Richmond is the third of five novels that Anthony Trollope wrote about Ireland. He penned it from August 4, 1859, to March 31, 1860, and it hit the shelves in three volumes on May 10, 1860. This was his tenth novel, and he signed the contract for it on August 2, 1859. Trollope received £600 for Castle Richmond, which was £200 more than what he got for his last novel, The Bertrams, showing that he was becoming more popular.

Amelia Atwater-Rhodes wrote "Persistence of Memory," which is the fifth book in her Den of Shadows series and was published on December 9, 2008. The story revolves around Erin Misrahe, who grapples with her alter-ego Shevaun, revealed to be a vampire with a connection to Erin. The book also includes a character named Alexander from Atwater-Rhodes's earlier novel, "In the Forests of the Night" (1999), who is the brother of the protagonist, Risika. Additionally, the novel features the poem "A Dream Within a Dream" by Edgar Allan Poe.

Eve Unsell (1887 – July 6, 1937) was an American screenwriter from Chicago, Illinois, who wrote for 96 films between 1914 and 1933. She also used the pseudonyms Oliver W. Geoffreys and E.M. Unsell. She married Lester Blankfield in 1911 and remained married until her death. Despite limited information about her personal life, she had a prolific career, writing and editing numerous films and plays. Some of her notable works include "Shadows" (1922), "The Ancient Mariner" (1925), "The Plastic Age" (1925), and "The Spirit of Youth" (1929). In addition to her writing, she was involved in various roles within the entertainment industry, such as adapting, directing, acting, and editing.

"Generosity: An Enhancement" is the tenth book by American writer Richard Powers. Similar to his other works, it delves into big ideas, particularly about feeling disconnected from society and advancements in science. The story uses metafiction, where the narrator interrupts the plot to place it in an alternate version of Chicago.

"Shadows on the Stars" is a fiction book by T. A. Barron, released by Penguin Young Readers Group. It's the tenth book in the series called Merlin Saga, which has 12 books in total. Initially named "The Great Tree of Avalon: Shadows on the Stars," it's the second book in "The Great Tree of Avalon" trilogy. The story unfolds in a world centered around a giant tree with seven roots, home to various creatures.

Walter Sorrells is a successful writer known for his mystery and suspense novels for both adults and teenagers. He's received awards for his work, including "Fake I.D." which was recognized as one of the top ten mysteries by Booklist magazine in 2005. Sorrells has also penned novels inspired by the TV show Flight 29 Down. Additionally, he writes using the pen names Lynn Abercrombie and Ruth Birmingham. He graduated from Haverford College in 1985, majoring in History.

"J Is for Judgment" is the tenth book in Sue Grafton's Alphabet mystery series. It follows Kinsey Millhone, a private detective in Santa Teresa, California. In this novel, Kinsey learns something important about her family: she finds out she has relatives in the Lompoc area.

Here's a simplified version of the paragraph:

The Diamond Chariot is a historical mystery novel by Boris Akunin, a famous Russian detective story writer. It was first published in 2003 as the tenth book in Akunin's Erast Fandorin series. Like the other Fandorin novels, The Diamond Chariot became very popular in Russia, selling 200,000 copies in its first week.

question: One of the coaches of Southern Methodist University also played what role at the Arizona State Sun Devils?
pos: Phil Bennett, born on December 3, 1955, is an American football coach and former player. Currently, he works as the defensive coordinator for the Arizona State Sun Devils. Before this role, he was the defensive coordinator for the Baylor Bears from 2011 to 2016. Additionally, he served as the interim head coach for the Pittsburgh Panthers during their 2011 BBVA Compass Bowl victory over Kentucky, after being their defensive coordinator for three seasons. Prior to coaching the Panthers, he was the head football coach at Southern Methodist University (SMU) from 2002 to 2007. Before his time at SMU, he worked as an assistant coach at seven different colleges.
Mike Cavan coached the Southern Methodist University football team from 1997 to 2001. During his time, the team won 22 games and lost 34. After him, Phil Bennett took over as coach.
neg: In 1952, the Arizona State Sun Devils football team played in the Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association (BIAA). Coached by Clyde B. Smith, they had a good season, winning 6 out of 9 games, including all 4 BIAA matches. They scored a total of 247 points while their opponents managed 121. Assistant coaches were Harold Brown and Bob White. They played their home games at Goodwin Stadium in Tempe, Arizona, where they had a 4-3 record, and they went 2-0 when playing away. Arizona State finished first in the Border Conference that year, led by team captain C Virgil Savage.

The 1951 Arizona State Sun Devils football team played American football for Arizona State College, now Arizona State University. They were part of the Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association (BIAA) during the 1951 college football season. Coached by Larry Siemering, they had a record of 6 wins, 3 losses, and 1 tie, scoring a total of 308 points while allowing 176. They won 4 games at home and 2 on the road. Assistant coaches were Harold Brown and Bob White. They played all home games at Goodwin Stadium in Tempe, Arizona, with quarterback Harold Self as team captain.

The Arizona State Sun Devils football team plays American football for Arizona State University. They compete in the Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS) of the NCAA and the South Division of the Pac-12 Conference. Since 1897, they've had a football team, with an overall record of 600 wins, 382 losses, and 24 ties, giving them a winning percentage of .608. Todd Graham is their current head coach, and they play their home games at Sun Devil Stadium in Tempe, Arizona. They've won seventeen conference titles, including three Pac-12 titles.

The 1956 Arizona State Sun Devils football team, from what's now Arizona State University, played in the Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association. Coached by Dan Devine, they had a great season, winning 9 out of 10 games and scoring 306 points while allowing only 83. Their assistant coaches were Tom Fletcher, Frank Kush, Al Onofrio, and Gordon Serr. Charlie Mackey led the team as captain, and they were strong both at home (5 wins, 1 loss) and away (4 wins, 0 losses), playing their home games at Goodwin Stadium in Tempe, Arizona.

The 1961 Arizona State Sun Devils football team, coached by Frank Kush, had a successful season. They played in the Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association (BIAA) and won the championship with a 7–3 record, scoring 287 points and allowing 163. Assistant coaches included Chuck Fairbanks, Gene Felker, Bill Kajikawa, Paul Kemp, and Dick Tamburo. Team captains were LG Dick Locke and C Fred Rhoades. They won four games at home and three on the road, playing all home games at Sun Devil Stadium in Tempe, Arizona.

The 1954 Arizona State Sun Devils football team played American football for Arizona State College, later renamed Arizona State University, in the Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association (BIAA) during the 1954 college football season. Coached by Clyde B. Smith for the third and final season, the Sun Devils had a 5-5 record (winning 3 out of 4 against BIAA opponents), scoring 178 points but allowing 228. Assistant Coaches were Gene Fetter, Tom Fletcher, and Bob White, and the team captain was QB Dick Mackey. They finished with a 3-3 record at home and 2-2 on the road, playing all home games at Goodwin Stadium in Tempe, Arizona.

The 1958 Arizona State Sun Devils football team, coached by Frank Kush, played in the Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association (BIAA) during the 1958 college football season. They had a good season, winning 7 games and losing 3. Overall, they scored 271 points while their opponents scored 131 points. The team captains were QB John Hangartner and RT Tom Ford. They played 5 games at home, winning 5 out of 7, and 3 games away, winning 2 out of 3. One home game was at Goodwin Stadium, and six were at Sun Devil Stadium in Tempe, Arizona.
