The 1955 Arizona State Sun Devils football team, representing Arizona State College (later renamed Arizona State University), played in the Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association (BIAA) during the 1955 college football season. question: What is the height of the player who won the 2015 AFL Rising Star award?
pos: Jesse Hogan, born on February 12, 1995, is a professional Australian rules football player for the Melbourne Football Club in the Australian Football League (AFL). Standing at 1.95 meters tall and weighing 100 kilograms, Hogan primarily plays as a key forward. He excelled in basketball and football from a young age, representing Western Australia in both sports. He played in the colts competition of the West Australian Football League with the Claremont Football Club. Hogan received recognition as a junior with All-Australian selection in the 2012 AFL Under 18 Championships. He was drafted by Melbourne with the second selection in the 2012 mini-draft, which meant he couldn't play in the 2013 AFL season. Despite a back injury sidelining him in 2014, he debuted in the AFL in 2015 and was awarded the Ron Evans Medal as the AFL Rising Star. Hogan led Melbourne in goals in his first two seasons with the club.

The NAB AFL Rising Star award is given every year to a talented young player in the Australian Football League. Jesse Hogan from Melbourne won the award this year with 49 votes, surpassing Patrick Cripps from Carlton, who got 41 votes.
neg: Clayton Oliver, born on July 22, 1997, is a professional Australian rules football player for the Melbourne Football Club in the Australian Football League (AFL). He's a midfielder, standing at 1.87 meters tall and weighing 88 kilograms. Oliver is recognized for his skills in handball and clearance work on the field. Despite facing challenges in his early career, including struggling in the TAC Cup in 2014 and missing out on selection for the 2015 AFL Under 18 Championships, he later excelled with the Murray Bushrangers in 2015. His achievements there, including winning best and fairest awards for both the league and the Murray Bushrangers, led to Melbourne selecting him as the fourth pick in the 2015 AFL draft. Oliver debuted in the 2016 season and earned a Rising Star nomination. Following his second AFL season, he was named the best young player by AFL coaches.

Stephen J. Coniglio, born on December 15, 1993, is a professional Australian rules football player. He currently plays for the Greater Western Sydney Giants in the Australian Football League (AFL). Before joining the Giants, he played for Swan Districts in the West Australian Football League (WAFL). Coniglio also represented Western Australia in the 2010 and 2011 National Under 18 Championships, where he won the Larke Medal as the best player in 2011. He was selected as the second pick in the 2011 AFL National Draft and made his debut for Greater Western Sydney in the first round of the 2012 season. Coniglio was also nominated for the 2012 AFL Rising Star award.

The Rising Star Award, also known as the EE Rising Star Award since 2013, used to be called the Orange Rising Star Award. It's a category at the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) that recognizes new talents in acting. It was established in 2004 after the death of Mary Selway, a respected casting director known for helping many new actors and actresses gain recognition. The nominees, regardless of gender or nationality, are chosen for their breakthrough performances in television, film, or both. The winner, selected solely by public votes via text, internet, or phone, is decided independently from the BAFTA juries. The award was sponsored by Orange UK until 2012 and has been sponsored by EE since 2013. James McAvoy was the first winner in 2006.

The NAB AFL Rising Star award is given every year to a talented young player in the Australian Football League (AFL). It started in 1993, and from 2007 onwards, the winner receives the Ron Evans Medal. Initially, it was called the Norwich Rising Star award until 1999 when Ansett sponsored it in 2000 and 2001. Since 2002, the National Australia Bank (NAB) has been the main sponsor.

Kevin Vincent Sheehan, born on August 1, 1953, used to play Australian rules football for Geelong. Now, he works as the Australian Football League's (AFL) National Talent and International Manager. Nick Holland, born on July 29, 1974, used to play Australian rules football professionally. Holland won the AFL Rising Star Award, was the best and fairest player, and leading goal kicker at Hawthorn. He also represented Australia in International Rules. Nowadays, he works as a lawyer and is known in the media.

Marcus Bontempelli, born on November 24, 1995, plays Australian rules football for the Western Bulldogs in the AFL. He joined the Bulldogs in 2013 as the fourth overall pick in the AFL Draft. In his first season, he impressed, winning the Best First-Year Player award in 2014 and narrowly missing out on the AFL Rising Star award, coming second to Lewis Taylor by just one vote.

Daniel Talia, born on October 2, 1991, is a professional Australian rules football player for the Adelaide Football Club in the Australian Football League (AFL). He joined the club as the 13th pick in the 2009 National Draft from the Calder Cannons. Talia earned recognition in 2012 by winning the AFL Rising Star award for being the best young player in the league. He comes from a football family; his great-grandfather is Arthur Stevens, a former Footscray player, and his grandfather, Harvey Stevens, was part of Footscray's 1954 VFL Grand Final victory. His younger brother, Michael Talia, initially played for the Western Bulldogs before moving to the Sydney Swans after the 2015 season.

question: Las Vegas Festival Grounds is north of the hotel that is owned by which company?
pos: The Las Vegas Festival Grounds, previously known as the MGM Resorts Festival Grounds, is a large outdoor area spanning 33 acres. It sits on the Las Vegas Strip, just north of the Circus Circus Hotel and Casino, which is owned by MGM. It's in Winchester, Nevada.

The Trump International Hotel Las Vegas is a tall, fancy hotel on Fashion Show Drive near the Las Vegas Strip. Rock in Rio USA was a music festival that took place in Las Vegas, Nevada, in 2015. It was inspired by the original Rock in Rio festival held in Rio de Janeiro. The Las Vegas area has several sports teams, but most games happen outside the city. The Vegas Golden Knights are the main professional team, starting in 2017. The Westgate Las Vegas Resort & Casino, located in Winchester, Nevada, is a hotel and casino owned by Westgate Resorts and managed by Navegante Group. The intersection of Tropicana Avenue and Las Vegas Boulevard, also known as the Tropicana – Las Vegas Boulevard intersection on the Las Vegas Strip, is notable for a few reasons. Downtown Las Vegas, often called DTLV, is the main business hub and historic heart of Las Vegas, Nevada. The Boots and Hearts Music Festival is a big country music and camping event run by Republic Live Inc. and owned by Stan and Eva Dunford. question: Which musical fantasy film is older, Bedknobs and Broomsticks or The Muppet Christmas Carol?

Bedknobs and Broomsticks is a movie made in 1971 by Walt Disney Productions and released in North America by Buena Vista Distribution Company on December 13, 1971. A Christmas Carol, written by Charles Dickens in 1843 and illustrated by John Leech, is a story about Ebenezer Scrooge, a grumpy old man who gets visited by ghosts from his past, present, and future. "This is a list of shows and movies about The Muppets. The main show is The Muppet Show, which aired from 1976 to 1981. There are also eight movies, like The Muppet Movie and The Muppets. Other series include Muppets Tonight and The Muppets."

Rizzo the Rat is a Muppet character brought to life by Steve Whitmire. He's a make-believe rat featured in The Muppet Show and several movies, including a prominent role in the 1992 film The Muppet Christmas Carol.

Kalanta Xristougenon, also known as Kalanta or Kalanda, is a Greek Christmas carol often called "Christmas Carol" in English. It's also referred to as Kalin Iméran and Christos Genate. Sam Eagle is a character from The Muppet Show, performed by Frank Oz. William Paul "Bill" Barretta, born on June 19, 1964, is an American puppeteer and producer known for his work with The Muppets since 1991. Barretta has taken on roles originally performed by Jim Henson, such as Dr. Teeth and Swedish Chef, and briefly filled in for Jerry Nelson's Lew Zealand. question: Which river system in Chilhowie, Virginia was the starting place for most Longhunters?
pos: The Holston River is a 136-mile-long river starting from Kingsport, Tennessee, and ending in Knoxville, Tennessee. It has three main branches: the North Fork, Middle Fork, and South Fork. These branches, along with the main river, form a significant river system that drains a large area including parts of northeastern Tennessee, southwestern Virginia, and northwestern North Carolina. When it meets the French Broad River in Knoxville, it becomes the Tennessee River.

A longhunter, typical of 18th-century America, was an explorer and hunter venturing into the wild frontiers for up to six months. Historian Emory Hamilton suggests that this practice was specific to Southwest Virginia, though the term has been loosely applied to explorers across America during that time. Most long hunts began in the Holston River Valley near Chilhowie, Virginia, with hunters originating from there or the nearby Clinch River Valley. These small groups of two or three men typically embarked on their hunts in October, wrapping up by late March or early April.
neg: The Thái Bình river, also known as Sông Thái Bình in Vietnamese, is the main river in Northern Vietnam within the Thái Bình river system. When this river system combines with the Red River system, it brings sediment that forms the Red River Delta.

The blackback barb, also called Enteromius barnardi, is a small fish found in Africa. It lives in shallow, plant-filled areas of rivers like the Zambezi, Cunene, and the Zambian part of the Congo River systems. It grows up to 7 cm long.

The Red River system in North Vietnam is a network of rivers that flow into or connect with the main river, the Red River. These rivers, along with the Thái Bình river system in the northeast, form the Red River Delta, which is the second largest delta in Vietnam. Together, these two systems are commonly referred to as the Red and Thai Binh rivers system. The sediment from the Red River system builds up the central and south Red River Delta, and both riverbanks are safeguarded by an extensive dyke system.

The Cotter River System (CRS) is in the Australian Capital Territory and was built in 1912. It's part of Namadgi National Park and provides water for the Australian Capital Territory, along with the Queanbeyan River in New South Wales. However, the Cotter River System is bigger and more reliable, especially during recent droughts, making the Queanbeyan River less important for water supply.

The Zambezi River System Action Plan (ZACPLAN) is a multinational effort led by the United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) to better manage the Zambezi River and its resources. It involves eight countries: Angola, Botswana, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Tanzania, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. The goal is to collectively manage water resources to meet both national and international objectives. Due to the large size of the Zambezi river basin and its importance to all these countries, the plan addresses concerns about increasing demand for water resources. Currently, competition for these resources leads to inefficient use and negative impacts on all involved countries' economies.

The Pearl River, also known as Zhujiang in Chinese, is a big river system in southern China. It's made up of several rivers like the Xi, Bei, and Dong rivers in Guangdong, which all flow into the Pearl River Delta. This delta is where they meet and form the Pearl River. It's the third-longest river in China, stretching about 2400 kilometers from the farthest point of the Xi River. The Pearl River Basin covers a vast area, draining parts of Guangdong, Guangxi, Yunnan, Guizhou, Hunan, and Jiangxi provinces in China, as well as some areas in northern Vietnam.

The Thái Bình river system is one of the two main river systems in the Red River Delta, Vietnam. It includes 8 rivers in northern Vietnam. When combined with the Red River system, it forms the Red River Delta.

Eastern freshwater cod, also called eastern cod or Clarence River cod, are big predatory fish found in the coastal Clarence River system in northeastern New South Wales. They're similar to Murray cod from the Murray-Darling River system and are important in the Clarence River area.

question: What party does the House of Commons representative for Congleton belong to?
pos: Congleton is an area in Cheshire that has a representative in the UK Parliament since 2010. Fiona Bruce, from the Conservative Party, is the current representative.

Fiona Claire Bruce, born on March 26, 1957, is a British politician from the Conservative Party. She represents the Congleton constituency in the Parliament, first elected in 2010 and re-elected in 2015.
neg: Baron Dunalley is a title in Ireland, created in 1800 for Henry Prittie, who was involved in Irish politics. His son, the second Baron, was also in politics and succeeded him. The title passed down through generations, with the seventh Baron inheriting it in 1992.

Earl Belmore is a title in County Fermanagh, Northern Ireland, granted in 1797 to Armar Lowry-Corry, who previously served in the Irish House of Commons for County Tyrone. He was initially made Baron Belmore in 1781 and Viscount Belmore in 1789. Born Armar Lowry, he later adopted the surname Corry by Royal license in 1774. His eldest son succeeded him as the second Earl. The second Earl also represented County Tyrone in both the Irish and British House of Commons, sat in the House of Lords as an Irish Representative Peer from 1819 to 1841, and served as Governor of Jamaica from 1828 to 1832.

In 2009, there was a special election in Glasgow North East for a seat in the UK Parliament. It happened because Michael Martin resigned as a Member of Parliament and Speaker of the House of Commons due to a scandal about MPs' expenses. This was a big deal because Martin was the first Speaker forced out of office since 1695. Willie Bain, who ran for the Scottish Labour Party, won the election with 59% of the votes. Surprisingly, only 33% of eligible voters actually participated, making it the lowest turnout ever for a Scottish by-election to the House of Commons.

Jean-Marie Boisvert, born on September 20, 1939, is a retired Canadian politician and teacher. He entered the Canadian House of Commons after winning the 1972 election as a member of the Social Credit Party, representing the Drummond district. Throughout his time in politics, he served on several parliamentary committees, including those focused on justice, legal affairs, food prices, and the Library of Parliament.

The Earl of Lanesborough was a noble title in Ireland, starting in 1756 with Humphrey Butler, 2nd Viscount Lanesborough. The family's lineage traces back to Theophilus Butler, who served in the Irish House of Commons. He became Baron Newtown-Butler in 1715 and was succeeded by his brother, Brinsley, who later became Viscount Lanesborough. Humphrey, Brinsley's son, was then made an earl. The title passed through generations until it ended with the death of the ninth Earl in 1998.

The Canadian federal election of 1926 happened on September 14th to choose members of the Canadian House of Commons for the 16th Parliament of Canada. It happened because of a situation called the King-Byng Affair. In the previous election in 1925, Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King's Liberal Party of Canada got fewer seats than the Liberal-Conservatives led by Arthur Meighen. But Mackenzie King wanted to stay in power with the help of the Progressive Party. Together, the Liberals and Progressives had more seats than any other party, so Mackenzie King could keep leading the government, even though it was a minority government.

Prosper Boulanger (November 17, 1918 - December 5, 2002) was a Canadian politician and businessman. He served as a Member of the Canadian House of Commons representing the Mercier district from 1962 to 1974 as part of the Liberal Party. During his time in politics, he held several roles, including Chair of the Standing Committee on Veterans Affairs and membership in committees related to fisheries, forestry, and parliamentary procedures. Additionally, Boulanger had prior service in the Royal Canadian Air Force from 1939 to 1946 and also worked as a councillor on the Montreal City Council.

In Canada, the Dean of the House is the Member of the House of Commons who has served the longest without any breaks and isn't a Cabinet Minister, party Leader, House Leader, or Whip. Their main duty is to oversee the election of the Speaker of the House of Commons at the start of each new Parliament. This role is similar to the Father of the House in the British House of Commons.

question: Season 2 of Rick and Morty began with the episode directed by whom?
pos: "A Rickle in Time" is the opening episode of the second season of the show "Rick and Morty," an American animated sitcom. It's the twelfth episode of the entire series. Matt Roller wrote it, and Wes Archer directed it. It premiered on Adult Swim in the United States on July 26, 2015.

The second season of Rick and Morty premiered on July 26, 2015, and ended on October 4. It aired on Adult Swim, which is Cartoon Network's late-night programming. This season had ten episodes in total.

Rixty Minutes is the eighth episode of the first season of Rick and Morty, which first aired on Adult Swim on March 17, 2014. "The Ricks Must Be Crazy" is the sixth episode of season two of the animated TV show "Rick and Morty." It's also the seventeenth episode overall. "Rick Potion #9" is the sixth episode of the animated series Rick and Morty, first aired on Adult Swim on January 27, 2014. It was written by Justin Roiland and directed by Stephen Sandoval. "Pilot" is the debut episode of the TV show "Rick and Morty," which aired on Adult Swim on December 2, 2013. It was written by Dan Harmon and Justin Roiland, the creators of the series, and directed by Roiland. The episode introduces the main characters, Rick Sanchez, a scientist with a drinking problem, and his grandson Morty Smith, who's still innocent. Together, they go on a risky journey across different dimensions to get Mega tree seeds. The pilot received mixed to positive reviews and was watched by around 1.1 million viewers during its airing.

"Gangland Undercover" is a TV series based on the real-life experiences of Charles Falco, a former ATF informant who infiltrated a biker gang. It's adapted from Falco's book and first aired in 2015 on the History Channel. Season 2 premiered in Canada in 2016 and in the US in 2017.

Angry Birds Stella is a TV series based on the game of the same name, created by Rovio Entertainment. It follows Stella and her friends—Luca, Willow, Poppy, and Dahlia—as they oppose Gale, Stella's former friend who leads the pigs on Golden Island. In the first season, Gale tries to find the Golden Egg but fails. In the second season, she returns and succeeds, but the birds realize the egg's danger when it turns things to gold, causing chaos. The gang works to save Golden Island, ultimately launching the egg away. Gale, frightened by the egg's power, retreats to her castle.

"Meeseeks and Destroy" is the fifth episode of the first season of Rick and Morty, which aired on Adult Swim on January 20, 2014. It was written by Ryan Ridley and directed by Bryan Newton. In this episode, Rick offers a solution to the family's issues, allowing him to join Morty on an adventure. The episode was popular, drawing in around 1.6 million viewers during its initial broadcast on Adult Swim.

question: What team did the recipient of the 2007 Brownlow Medal play for?

neg: In 2014, Matt Priddis from the West Coast Eagles won the 87th Brownlow Medal for being the fairest and best player during the AFL home and away season. In 2006, Adam Goodes from the Sydney Swans won his second Brownlow Medal for being the fairest and best player in the Australian Football League (AFL) season. He received 26 votes during the season, which was his second win after also winning in 2003.

question: Were both the Battle of Stones River and the Battle of the Ch'ongch'on River fought in the 19th century?
pos: The Battle of Stones River, also known as the Second Battle of Murfreesboro, took place from December 31, 1862, to January 2, 1863, in Middle Tennessee. It was part of the Stones River Campaign during the American Civil War. This battle had the highest casualties on both sides compared to other major battles of the Civil War. While the battle itself didn't have a clear winner, the Union Army successfully fended off two Confederate attacks and forced them to retreat. This victory was crucial for Union morale, especially after their defeat at the Battle of Fredericksburg. It also prevented the Confederates from gaining control of Middle Tennessee.

The Battle of the Ch'ongch'on River was a big fight during the Korean War from November 25 to December 2, 1950. It happened along the Ch'ongch'on River Valley in North Korea. After the Chinese did well in their first attacks against the UN forces, General Douglas MacArthur wanted to kick them out of Korea and end the war quickly. But the Chinese Commander Peng Dehuai expected this and planned a counterattack called the Second Phase Campaign.
neg: The Battle of Glendale happened on the Scottish island of Skye between two clans, the MacDonalds and the MacLeods. It's believed to have occurred around 1490 or later, maybe after 1513. According to MacLeod tradition, it was a significant battle, and although they won, they suffered heavy losses. The MacLeods turned the tide using their sacred Fairy Flag.

The Battle of Berestechko was a major conflict between Ukrainian Cossacks, led by Hetman Bohdan Khmelnytsky, along with their Crimean Tatar allies, and a Polish army commanded by King John II Casimir. It was part of a Cossack uprising in Ukraine that occurred from 1648 to 1657, following a two-year truce. Happening from June 28 to 30, 1651, the battle unfolded in the Volhynia region, specifically on a hilly plain south of the Styr River. The Polish camp was positioned across the river from Berestechko, facing south towards the Cossack army, which was about two kilometers away. The Cossacks had their right flank against the River Pliashivka, while the Tatar army occupied their left flank. This battle is believed to be one of the largest land battles in 17th-century Europe.

Register Cliff is a sandstone cliff that served as a crucial landmark for travelers on the Oregon Trail in the 19th century. Many emigrants engraved their family names on its soft stones as they journeyed westward along the Platte River valley near Fort John, Wyoming. It helped them confirm they were heading in the right direction towards South Pass and not veering into impassable mountain areas. Geographically, it's located on the eastern slope of the Continental Divide, marking the transition from the plains to the mountains in Wyoming. This cliff is significant for recording the names of countless emigrants who traveled along the Oregon Trail and other routes like the California Trail and Mormon Trail during the 1800s. Around 500,000 people used these trails from 1843 to 1869, but sadly, up to one-tenth of them died along the journey, mostly due to illness.

The Umba River is in northeastern Tanzania's Tanga Region, starting from Schageiuforest (Shagayu) in the West Usambara Mountains at 2,000 m altitude. It flows east along the north side of the mountain range. At Lelwa, it meets the Mbalamu River from the extreme north of the Usambara Mountains and the Mglumi River, then crosses into Kenya before flowing into the Indian Ocean. This spot marks the most eastern point on the Tanzania-Kenya border, which was mostly straightened in the 19th Century toward Lake Victoria. In the mid-1960s, precious stones like sapphires and Spessartine were found in the river's upper reaches. The Umba River Game Reserve, part of about 2,600 km² of protected wildlife areas, is also located along the river.

Joseph Leonard Follett (February 16, 1843 – April 1, 1907) was a brave American soldier in the Civil War. He earned the Medal of Honor, the highest honor for bravery in battle, for his actions at the Battle of Island Number Ten in Missouri on March 3, 1862, and at the Battle of Stones River in Tennessee on December 31, 1862. He received this honor on September 19, 1890.

Savage's Station, during the American Civil War's Peninsula Campaign, served as a crucial hub for supplies, medical care, and command for the Army of the Potomac. It was situated in Henrico County, Virginia, along the Richmond and York River Railroad. While the Norfolk Southern Railroad now owns the track, they have no records of an actual train station at that site. Instead, there was a farmhouse in a wooded area on a small hill next to the railroad, visible in period drawings and photos. This farmhouse became a major field hospital during the Seven Days Battles, and it also served as General George B. McClellan's headquarters during the Battle of Savage's Station in 1862. Although the house survived that battle, it was later burned down by Federal cavalry in 1864 and was never rebuilt. A smokehouse from the 1800s was documented on the property until the 1930s when it collapsed. Nearby, there's a brick-walled cemetery dating back to the 1700s, close to where the house once stood.

The Collins Ferry Historic District in rural northern Halifax County, Virginia, includes two historic farmsteads, a mill, and a ferry site along the Staunton River. It spans 768 acres, stretching from the river to Bull Creek Road and from Buffalo Creek to roughly the center of the district. The Collins Farm, situated at the end of McKeever's Trail, boasts a well-preserved Federal style plantation house from around 1810, overlooking the creek. This farm also features 19th-century outbuildings, a family cemetery, a mill site by the river, and a quarry where mill construction and grinding stones were sourced. The Hubbard Farm, located southeast of the Collins Farm, can be reached via a private drive connected to the historic road leading to Collins Ferry. It showcases a Greek Revival farmhouse constructed in 1856, along with 19th-century outbuildings, a family cemetery, and remnants of slave quarters.

The military history of Mexico spans thousands of years, starting with conflicts among indigenous peoples before the Spanish arrived. After the Spanish conquest in the 16th century, Mexico was under Spanish rule for three centuries. Mexico fought for independence in the 19th century, facing internal conflicts after gaining independence from Spain in 1821. The mid-19th century saw Mexico lose a significant portion of its territory to the United States in the Mexican–American War. Throughout the rest of the 19th century, Mexico experienced various conflicts, including the War of the Reform and resistance against French intervention.

question: Who has more scope of profession, Phil Rosen or  Delmer Daves?
pos: Delmer Lawrence Daves (July 24, 1904 – August 17, 1977) was an American who wrote, directed, and produced movies.
Phil Rosen, born on May 8, 1888, and passed away on October 22, 1951, was an American filmmaker who directed 142 movies from 1915 to 1949.
neg: Dark Passage (1947) is a black-and-white movie made by Warner Bros. It's a classic film noir directed by Delmer Daves and featuring famous actors Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall. The story is adapted from a novel by David Goodis, also called "Dark Passage." This movie marked the third collaboration between the real-life couple Bacall and Bogart out of the four films they worked on together.

The Petrified Forest is a movie made in 1936 in America, directed by Archie Mayo and featuring actors like Leslie Howard, Bette Davis, and Humphrey Bogart. It's considered one of the early examples of film noir and was based on a play by Robert E. Sherwood. The script was written by Delmer Daves and Charles Kenyon, and the story was later adapted for radio and TV too.

The Hanging Tree is a colorful Western movie from 1959 directed by Delmer Daves. When Daves got sick, Karl Malden stepped in to direct for a few days. The film features Gary Cooper, Maria Schell, George C. Scott, and Malden. It's set in Montana's gold fields during the 1860s and '70s gold rush. The plot revolves around a doctor who rescues a criminal from a mob wanting to hang him. As the story unfolds, the doctor discovers the man's background and attempts to influence him.

Shipmates Forever, a musical film from 1935, directed by Frank Borzage and written by Delmer Daves, is set at the United States Naval Academy. The movie features actors like Dick Powell, Ruby Keeler, Lewis Stone, Ross Alexander, John Arledge, Eddie Acuff, and Dick Foran. It was released by Warner Bros. on October 12, 1935.

Destination Tokyo is a black-and-white movie from 1943 about a submarine at war. It was directed by Delmer Daves in his first time directing a film. The screenplay was written by Daves and Albert Maltz, based on a story by Steve Fisher, who used to serve on submarines. The main actors are Cary Grant and John Garfield, supported by Dane Clark, Robert Hutton, and Warner Anderson, among others. Production started on June 21, 1943, and finished on September 4 of the same year. The movie first showed in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania on December 15, 1943, as a charity event for disabled children, and then was released nationwide on December 31, 1943.

"Broken Arrow," a colorful western movie from 1950, directed by Delmer Daves, features James Stewart as Tom Jeffords and Jeff Chandler as Cochise. While inspired by real historical figures, the film takes liberties with their story for dramatic effect. It received three Academy Award nominations and won a Golden Globe for promoting international understanding. Notably, it's considered one of the first post-World War II Westerns to portray Native Americans in a sympathetic light, according to film experts.

Drum Beat is a Western movie from 1954, filmed in CinemaScope and WarnerColor. It was written and directed by Delmer Daves and co-produced by Daves and Alan Ladd for Ladd's company, Jaguar Productions. The movie features Alan Ladd, Audrey Dalton, Charles Bronson as Captain Jack, and Hayden Rorke as President Ulysses S. Grant.

"Parrish" is a drama movie from 1961 by Warner Bros. It was written, produced, and directed by Delmer Daves, inspired by Mildred Savage's novel from 1958 with the same title. Max Steiner composed the music, Harry Stradling Sr. handled the Technicolor cinematography, Leo K. Kuter managed the art direction, and Howard Shoup did the costume design.

question: Which band has more members, Test Icicles or X Ambassadors?
pos: Test Icicles were a brief dance-punk band from England. They mixed indie rock with elements from different genres like hip hop, crossover thrash, and punk. The band started in 2004 with Rory Attwell and Sam Mehran, who were joined by Devonte Hynes later on. Hynes and Mehran were both 18 when the band started. Now, the band is known because its members found success later on.

X Ambassadors, also known as XA, is a rock band from Ithaca, New York. The band includes lead vocalist Sam Harris, keyboardist Casey Harris, lead guitarist Noah Feldshuh, and drummer Adam Levin. Some of their popular songs are "Jungle," "Renegades," and "Unsteady." Their first full-length album, "VHS," came out on June 30, 2015.
neg: "Boa vs. Python" is a song by Test Icicles, released as the first single from their debut album "For Screening Purposes Only" on August 1, 2005. The song reached #46 on the UK Singles Chart.

"Jungle" is a song by the American rock band X Ambassadors, featuring British blues rock singer Jamie N Commons. It was released as a single on December 18, 2013, by KIDinaKORNER and Interscope. The song was included in X Ambassadors' 2014 EP "The Reason" and their 2015 studio album "VHS."

Rory Attwell, an English musician, gained prominence as a member of the UK punk band Test Icicles. The band formed in 2004, played a few concerts, and disbanded on April 22, 2006, after a successful final show at London's Astoria. During their brief stint, they released the album "For Screening Purposes Only" and had UK Top 40 singles with "What's Your Damage" and "Circle. Square. Triangle."

David Joseph Michael Hynes, also known as Devonté Dev Hynes or Blood Orange, is a British artist known for his work as a singer, songwriter, composer, producer, and author. He was born on December 23, 1985. Hynes was part of the band Test Icicles from 2004 to 2006, where he played guitar, synth, and occasionally sang. The band released one album in 2005. Afterward, he pursued a solo career, releasing two albums under the name Lightspeed Champion and three more under Blood Orange from 2008 to 2016. Some of his musical influences include Prince, Hercules & The Love Affair, and Gary Utteridge.

"Circle, Square, Triangle" is a song by Test Icicles from their debut album "For Screening Purposes Only," released on October 24, 2005. It's their most successful track, reaching #25 on the UK Singles Chart.

Skylar Grey released a song called "Cannonball," which features the band X Ambassadors. It was written by Skylar Grey, Sam Harris, Noah Feldshuh, Casey Harris, Adam Levin, and Alex da Kid, and produced by Alex da Kid. The song is included in the FIFA 16 soundtrack and was officially released digitally on September 25, 2015. It was announced by The Independent. "Cannonball" sold about 25,000 digital copies in the United States and will be part of the US collaborative tour between Skylar Grey and X Ambassadors.

"Dig Your Own Grave" was a CD/DVD EP launched by Test Icicles on April 23, 2006. It featured remixes and new material on the CD, along with music videos and live footage from a London gig in November 2005 on the DVD. Initially, it was sold during the band's last 5-show tour, and later it hit record stores a week after that.

Test Icicles' first album, "For Screening Purposes Only," was released in 2005. It received positive reviews for its distinctiveness in the indie music world. Sadly, the band broke up in February 2006, making this album their only full-length release.

question: The movies The Boatniks and The Great Locomotive Chase were both made by which production company?
pos: "The Boatniks" is a funny movie from 1970 in America. It features actors like Robert Morse, Stefanie Powers, Don Ameche, and Phil Silvers. Walt Disney Productions made it, it was distributed by Buena Vista, and Norman Tokar directed it.

"The Great Locomotive Chase" is a movie made by Walt Disney in 1956. It's about a real event that happened during the American Civil War in 1862. The main character, played by Fess Parker, leads a group of Union soldiers disguised as civilians. They sneak into Confederate territory, steal a train near Atlanta, and drive it back to Union territory in Tennessee. Along the way, they cause damage by tearing up railroad tracks, destroying bridges, and cutting telegraph lines.
neg: The Great Locomotive Chase Festival is a three-day event held to remember the Great Locomotive Chase that happened on April 12, 1862. It takes place on the first weekend of October in downtown Adairsville, GA. The festival offers arts and crafts booths, historical exhibits, concerts, entertainment, carnival rides, and more than 40 food booths. There are also activities like the Grand Parade, pageants, street dances, and Gospel singing on Sunday afternoon. The festival was started by Marion Lacey, the principal of the town. It began after the school's fall festival was canceled due to funding problems. Lacey organized the festival to bring local businesses together and provide entertainment for students each fall.
The Yonah was a steam train with a specific design called a "4-4-0". It was involved in a famous event called the Great Locomotive Chase during the American Civil War.

Western & Atlantic Railroad #49, known as the Texas, is an old steam train built in 1856 by Danforth, Cooke & Co. It played a crucial role in the Great Locomotive Chase during the American Civil War. The Texas chased after the General, another train stolen by Union saboteurs to disrupt the Confederate rail system. Today, you can see the Texas at the Atlanta Cyclorama building in Grant Park, Atlanta, Georgia. It's also officially recognized as a historic landmark.

Henry P. Haney (1846-1923) was the last surviving American involved in The Great Locomotive Chase during the Civil War. At the time, he was just 15 years old and worked as a fireman on the Texas locomotive. This train was part of the pursuit crew chasing the General, which had been stolen by the Andrews Raiders.

The General is a 1926 American silent comedy movie distributed by United Artists. It's based on a real event from the American Civil War called the Great Locomotive Chase. The movie's story comes from a book called The Great Locomotive Chase, written by William Pittenger. Buster Keaton stars in the film and also helped direct it alongside Clyde Bruckman.

The Western & Atlantic Railroad #3 General is an old steam locomotive made in 1855 by the Rogers, Ketchum & Grosvenor company in Paterson, New Jersey. It was originally used by the Western & Atlantic Railroad. This locomotive gained fame during the American Civil War when Union spies stole it as part of a plan to disrupt the Confederate rail system. Nowadays, you can see it at the Southern Museum of Civil War and Locomotive History in Kennesaw, Georgia. It's considered an important historical artifact and is even listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

Rogers Locomotive and Machine Works was a company in the 1800s that made steam trains in Paterson, New Jersey. They made over six thousand trains for railroads worldwide, and many American railroads had at least one of their trains. Their most well-known train was called The General, made in December 1855, which played a big role in the Great Locomotive Chase during the American Civil War.

Cornelia, located in Habersham County, Georgia, USA, had a population of 4,160 in 2010, up from 3,674 in 2000. One notable feature is a large apple sculpture atop an obelisk-shaped monument. Additionally, it was the retirement home of baseball icon Ty Cobb and served as a filming location for the 1956 Disney movie "The Great Locomotive Chase," which was shot along the Tallulah Falls Railway running from Cornelia to Franklin, North Carolina.

question: How long is the river for which Frenchmans Creek is a tributary?
pos: The Darling River is Australia's third longest river, stretching 1472 km from its start in northern New South Wales to where it meets the Murray River at Wentworth, New South Wales. When you add its longest tributaries, it becomes a 2844 km long river system, making it the longest in Australia.

Frenchmans Creek is a small river that flows into the Darling River in western New South Wales. It stretches for 7.51 km from where it starts south of Pooncarie, New South Wales, at a height of 54.4 m, until it joins the Darling River at a height of 48 m.
neg: Cow Creek, a 35-mile-long tributary of the Missouri River, flows through north central Montana. It starts in the southern foothills of the Bear Paw Mountains in western Blaine County, then heads east and south before joining the Missouri River around 25 miles northeast of Winifred, Montana. The creek passes through a canyon in the Missouri Breaks, which are heavily eroded badlands on either side of the Missouri River. This canyon provided a travel route from the northern plains of Montana to the central and southern plains. Over time, it was used by migrating buffalo and Native Americans. During the steamboat era, when low water levels blocked riverboats from reaching Fort Benton, the mouth of Cow Creek served as a landing and freight depot. The Nez Perce Tribe had conflicts along Cow Creek in 1877 while fleeing to Canada. Today, modern highways bypass Cow Creek, and the buffalo and nomadic tribes are no longer present. Cow Creek remains largely untouched in the remote Montana Missouri Breaks area.

Lithia Springs Creek, also called Johnsons Run or Lithia Spring Creek, is a small river in Northumberland County, Pennsylvania, USA. It runs for about 3.2 miles through Point Township and covers an area of 8.96 square miles. One of its branches is known as Johnson Creek. Unfortunately, various types of waste are dumped into the creek from different places. There's at least one bridge spanning the creek that's over 20 feet long. It's classified as a Coldwater Fishery and a Migratory Fishery, home to wild trout and possibly some other fish species.
Locks Creek is a stream that stretches 1.9 miles in San Mateo County, California. It's the biggest smaller stream that flows into Frenchmans Creek.

The East Branch South Fork Eel River, which feeds into the South Fork Eel River, starts where Cruso Cabin Creek and Elkhorn Creek meet in Mendocino County, California. It's about 25 miles long and winds its way west until it joins the South Fork Eel at Benbow Lake State Recreation Area. Important streams that join the East Branch include Buck Mountain Creek, Squaw Creek, Rays Creek, and Tom Long Creek. The river flows west, then turns north, and west again, passing through rough terrain in the Coast Range of California. It's the biggest tributary of the South Fork Eel River.

The Red Rock River is a river in southwestern Montana that stretches about 70 miles. Its basin covers over 1548 square miles. Its farthest tributary, Hell Roaring Creek, starts in the Beaverhead National Forest near the Montana-Idaho border at an elevation of around 9100 feet. Brower's Spring, near Hell Roaring Creek, is close to the Missouri River's source. The river flows north and west, changing its name to Red Rock Creek as it passes through the Red Rock Lakes in a grassy valley. It continues west, gathering tributaries like Peet Creek and Long Creek, expanding into the Lima Reservoir, and then flowing through a canyon near Lima, Montana. It then heads northwest through a valley, passing Kidd and Red Rock, before reaching Clark Canyon Reservoir. Once, beneath the lake's waters, the Red Rock and Horse Prairie Creek met, forming the Beaverhead River, which feeds into the Jefferson River, a major tributary of the Missouri River.
Frenchmans Creek is a 4.4-mile stream located in San Mateo County, California. Its largest tributary is Locks Creek.

The Jemez River in New Mexico is a part of the Rio Grande system. It's formed by two smaller rivers, the East Fork Jemez River and San Antonio Creek, which gather water from various smaller streams in the Jemez Mountains and Santa Fe National Forest. The main stretch of the Jemez River is about 50 miles long, but if you count its longest source, San Antonio Creek, it's around 80 miles long. The East Fork Jemez River is about 22 miles long. Both San Antonio Creek and the East Fork Jemez River wind through bends and curves along their paths. The East Fork Jemez River is designated as a National Wild and Scenic River.

Tomichi Creek, a tributary of the Gunnison River in Gunnison County, Colorado, stretches for 71.8 miles. It starts northwest of Monarch Pass, flows southwest along Monarch Mountain's base, and gathers water from Congress Creek and Agape Creek before heading south toward Sargents. Near Sargents, it receives water from Marshall Creek and Long Branch Creek, then turns westward, receiving water from Needle Creek Reservoir and Hot Springs Reservoir. The Tomichi Valley, where the creek meanders, is mostly private ranch lands and ideal for livestock. Quartz Creek joins Tomichi Creek at Parlin, and further west, Cochetopa Creek merges with it before it finally flows into the Gunnison River near Gunnison. For a visual reference, check the BLM Colorado website.

question: Where is the school that Tyler Kalinoski went to located?
pos: Olathe East High School in Olathe, Kansas, is a big public high school for students in grades 9-12. It's one of four public high schools in the area. The school has sports teams called the Hawks, and they play in the 6A division. Besides sports, students can join clubs and participate in performing arts and school publications. The school's colors are orange and navy blue, and its mascot is the Hawk. In 1998, the U.S. Department of Education recognized Olathe East as a National School of Excellence.

Tyler Kalinoski, born on December 19, 1992, is an American basketball player who currently plays for the Antwerp Giants in Belgium. He gained recognition as a standout player during his high school days at Olathe East High School in Kansas, earning a nomination for the McDonald’s All-American team. Kalinoski then went on to play college basketball for the Davidson Wildcats. In 2015, he was honored as the Atlantic 10 Conference Men's Basketball Player of the Year.
neg: Harvest Time Christian Academy is a private school in Tyler, Texas, where boys and girls learn together. It started in 2010 as part of the Harvest Time Church of Tyler. They take students from Pre-K all the way up to 12th grade.

East Haven High School is in East Haven, Connecticut, at 35 Wheelbarrow Lane (previously at 200 Tyler Street until September 1997). It's a public school for both boys and girls from grades nine to twelve. The school's colors are blue and gold, and its mascot is the yellow jacket. It participates in the Southern Connecticut Conference for sports and is recognized for its marching band.

Calvin Tyler Scott, a Canadian basketball player, plays for the UPEI Panthers. He hails from Halifax, Nova Scotia, where he attended Halifax West High School and was the top scorer for the Halifax West Warriors. After high school, he went to Lee Academy in Maine before joining Acadia University in New Minas. However, he didn't feel entirely comfortable there and transferred to UPEI with Tim Kendrick. At UPEI, Tyler Scott excelled, averaging 23 points per game in his first year and earning recognition as a first-team All-Canadian. Throughout his time at UPEI, he consistently ranked among the top scorers in the AUS conference. In 2017, he entered the top 5 AUS scoring of all time and surpassed 1700 career points during his fifth year.

The Middlebourne Historic District in West Virginia is a special area recognized for its historical significance. It contains 88 important buildings, representing the heart of Middlebourne with its mix of government, business, and residential structures. Most of these buildings were constructed between the late 1800s and early 1900s, showcasing popular architectural styles like Queen Anne and Classical Revival. Among the district's treasures are the oldest buildings: the Quinif House (built in 1805) and the Gorrell-Wetzel House (built in 1807) in Federal-style design. Notable landmarks include Tyler County High School (built in 1907), First National Bank (built in 1902), and Smith's Drug Store (circa 1890). The district also boasts architectural gems like the Powell-Shore House, a prime example of Queen Anne style (built circa 1898-99). Additionally, it's home to the Tyler County Courthouse and Jail, separately listed for their historical significance (built in 1854, 1874, and 1922).

Kevin Eugene Lockett, born on September 4, 1974, used to play professional American football as a wide receiver and punt returner in the NFL. He was part of teams like the Kansas City Chiefs, Washington Redskins, Jacksonville Jaguars, and New York Jets. Before his NFL career, he played college football at Kansas State University, where he was both a football and Academic All-American. He attended Booker T. Washington High School in Tulsa. His younger brother Aaron and his son Tyler also played football at Kansas State, with Tyler eventually getting drafted by the Seattle Seahawks.

Tyler Consolidated High School (TCHS) is a public high school in Sistersville, West Virginia, USA. It's part of the Tyler County Schools district and can be found at 1993 Silver Knight Drive. The school came together in 1993 when students from Sistersville High School and Tyler County High School joined forces to create a single county high school.

The Stella Elkins Tyler School of Art, also called Tyler School of Art, is part of Temple University. It was founded by Stella Elkins Tyler and Boris Blai, both sculptors, on a 14-acre estate in Elkins Park. In 2009, Tyler moved to a new building on Temple's Main Campus, funded in part by $61.5 million from Pennsylvania. The new 255,000 square foot building was designed by architect Carlos Jimenez.

Woodville High School is a public high school in Woodville, Texas, part of the Woodville Independent School District. It's classified as a 3A school by the UIL. The Texas Education Agency rated it "Met Standard" in 2015.

question: Ambrose Mendy has managed and/or advised a British professional boxer that as of July 2017 is ranked the world's seventh best super middleweight by who?
pos: Ambrose Mendy, born in August 1954, is a British boxing manager, advisor, and sports agent. His career in boxing began in the late 1970s, and he has since managed and/or advised notable fighters such as Nigel Benn, James DeGale, Chris Eubank Junior, Lloyd Honeyghan, and Errol Christie, among others.

Chris Eubank Jr., born on September 18, 1989, is a British boxer. He's held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017 and previously held the WBA interim and British middleweight titles from 2015 to 2016. In July 2017, Eubank Jr. was ranked as the world's second-best super middleweight by BoxRec, sixth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board, and seventh by The Ring magazine. He's the son of Chris Eubank, a former two-weight world boxing champion.
neg: Super Scott Dixon, born in 1976 in Hamilton, is a Scottish boxer who competed in various weight divisions throughout the 1990s, 2000s, and 2010s. He won titles such as the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) Scottish Area welterweight title, World Boxing Board (WBB) welterweight title, and Commonwealth welterweight title. Dixon also challenged for other titles like the World Athletic Association (WAA) welterweight title. Throughout his career, his fighting weight ranged from 125 pounds (featherweight) to 167.5 pounds (super middleweight).

Dean Star Francis (born in 1974) is an English boxer who competed professionally in the super middleweight, light heavyweight, and cruiserweight divisions from the 1990s to the 2010s. Throughout his career, he achieved numerous titles including the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) British super middleweight, BBBofC English cruiserweight, European Boxing Union (EBU) super middleweight, World Boxing Organization (WBO) Inter-Continental super middleweight, International Boxing Organization (IBO) Inter-Continental light heavyweight, BBBofC British light heavyweight, British Masters light-heavy, and Commonwealth super middleweight titles. He also fought for the World Boxing Council (WBC) International super middleweight title against Jaffa Ballogou and the BBBofC British super middleweight title against Matthew Barney. Francis' weight during his fights ranged from 167 lbs as a super middleweight to 181 lbs as a cruiserweight.

Henry Wharton (born 23 November 1967 in Leeds) is an English boxer who competed professionally in the 1980s and '90s. He held titles such as the British Boxing Board of Control (BBBofC) British super middleweight, European Boxing Union (EBU) super middleweight, and Commonwealth super middleweight titles. Wharton also challenged for the World Boxing Council (WBC) super middleweight title against Nigel Benn and Robin Reid, as well as the World Boxing Organization (WBO) super middleweight title against Chris Eubank. Throughout his career, he fought in weight classes ranging from middleweight (162 lb) to cruiserweight (179 lb).

Rod Carr, born in 1968, is an Australian boxer who competed in various weight classes during the 1980s and '90s. He won several titles including the Oriental and Pacific Boxing Federation (OPBF) super middleweight, Trans-Tasman super middleweight, Australian super middleweight, and Commonwealth super middleweight titles. He also fought for the International Boxing Organization (IBO) super middleweight title against Rick Thornberry and the Pan Asian Boxing Association (PABA) light heavyweight title against Anthony Bigeni. Carr's weight during his career ranged from 164 pounds (super middleweight) to 180.5 pounds (cruiserweight).

Andre Thysse, born in Germiston in 1968, is a South African boxer who competed professionally in the 1990s and 2000s. Throughout his career, he won several titles including the Gauteng super middleweight Title, South African super middleweight title, and Commonwealth super middleweight title. He also challenged for various other titles such as the International Boxing Organization (IBO) super middleweight title against Brian Magee, World Boxing Council (WBC) super middleweight title against Markus Beyer, and others. Thysse's weight during fights ranged from super middleweight, around 163+3/4 lb, to light heavyweight, approximately 175 lb.

Jermain "Choo Choo" Mackey, born in Nassau in 1979, is a boxer from the Bahamas. He competed in the middle, super middle, and light heavyweight divisions during the 2000s and 2010s. Throughout his career, he won various titles including the Bahamas super middleweight, WBC Caribbean Boxing Federation super middleweight, WBA Fedecaribe super middleweight, and Commonwealth super middleweight titles. He also challenged for other titles, like the WBO NABO super middleweight against Jean Pascal and the WBC International super middleweight against Adonis Stevenson. Mackey's weight in fights ranged from welterweight to light heavyweight. He also represented the Bahamas in boxing at the 2002 Commonwealth Games.

Natascha Ragosina, also known as Natalia Yurievna Ragozina, is a retired professional boxer who never lost a match. She was considered the best female super middleweight boxer worldwide for much of her career. Born in Kazakhstan when it was part of the Soviet Union, she now lives in Moscow and represented Russia in her boxing career. Ragosina held the titles of the longest-reigning WBA female super middleweight champion and WBC female super middleweight champion. When she retired, she was the holder of all the major female super middleweight titles as well as two heavyweight belts.

Luke Blackledge, also known as "Robbo," is an English boxer born in Clitheroe in 1990. He has competed in the super middleweight and light heavyweight divisions, winning titles such as the British Masters light-heavyweight title, the WBC International Silver super middleweight title, and the Commonwealth super middleweight title. He has also challenged for other titles like the WBC Youth World light heavyweight title and the WBO Youth Intercontinental light heavyweight title. Additionally, he has had matches for the BBBofC Central (England) Area super middleweight title and the Commonwealth (British Empire) super middleweight title, but experienced defeats and draws in those bouts.

question: Rejuvelac is kind of grain water invented and promoted by a "holistic health" practitioner born in which year ?
pos: Ann Wigmore (1909–1994) was a holistic health expert and supporter of raw food diets who was originally from Lithuania but later became an American citizen. She authored numerous books explaining her ideas and traveled extensively to spread awareness about her health practices.
Rejuvelac is a fermented drink made from grains, originally introduced and popularized by Ann Wigmore.
neg: Holistic dentistry, also known as biological or alternative dentistry, takes a broader view of dental care by considering the patient's overall physical and sometimes emotional or spiritual health. It often involves avoiding amalgam fillings, opting for non-surgical gum disease treatments, and questioning the safety of root canals due to potential bacterial spread. Many holistic dentists are also critical of water fluoridation.

Elizabeth A. Betty Neilson, EDD (October 13, 1911 – October 4, 2001), was well-known in health education and played a significant role in promoting wellness and holistic health in public health initiatives.
Viktoras Peter Kulvinskas, born on February 23, 1939, is a holistic health expert from Lithuania. He's known for his work as a nutritionist, promoter of raw foods, and author.

Dr. Susan Lark, a medical doctor educated at Northwestern Medical School, has taught in the family and community medicine department at Stanford University. She specializes in women's health and preventive medicine, founding the Menopause Self Help Center in Los Altos, California. Known for her innovative approaches to menopause and hormone management, she emphasizes holistic women's health, focusing on hormone balance to prevent various health conditions. Dr. Lark has developed natural supplements to achieve hormone balance without conventional therapies and has authored 13 best-selling books on women's health topics. Her work has been featured in numerous publications, including Real Simple, Reader's Digest, and The New York Times.

Crystal Dawn Bright, born on April 9, 1981, hails from Greensboro, North Carolina. She's not only a talented musician but also an artist involved in various multimedia endeavors. She's garnered recognition locally and internationally, winning awards for her music and being praised for her unique blend of carnival folk, fairytale pop, and gypsy jazz, which the BBC described as delightfully eccentric.

The Guelph Community Health Centre (Guelph CHC, GCHC) is a public, non-profit organization in Guelph, Ontario, Canada. They offer primary health care and various programs focusing on overall well-being and community growth. Part of the Association of Ontario Health Centres (AOHC), they're among over 300 similar centers across Canada. Mickey Mehta, born on August 29, 1962, is an influential figure in India known for promoting holistic health, wellness, and fitness. His approach emphasizes holistic health and equipment-free workouts, which he promotes through his Mickey Mehta Wellness Temples in Mumbai. Referred to as 'India's Leading Holistic Health Guru' by the media, Mehta aims to expand his social media presence across various platforms to connect with a wider audience.

The Kripalu Center for Yoga & Health is a non-profit organization in Stockbridge, Massachusetts. It's housed in a large building that used to be a Jesuit school. They offer yoga and health programs and claim to be the biggest place of its kind in North America. In 2013, they made $34.7 million and had about 626 employees. They can host over 650 guests at once.

question: What town host an annual media finance conference that has featured an Australian-born American media mogul?
pos: Keith Rupert Murdoch, born on March 11, 1931, is an Australian-born American media tycoon. His father, Sir Keith Murdoch, was heavily involved in the Herald and Weekly Times newspaper publishing company across Australia, except New South Wales. Instead of joining his father's company after his death in 1952, Murdoch formed his own private company, News Limited. This decision gave him complete control as Chairman and CEO of the global media holding company, which later split into News Corp and 21st Century Fox in 2013, becoming the world's second-largest media conglomerate.

The Allen & Company Sun Valley Conference is an annual event about media finance. It's held in Sun Valley, Idaho, every July since 1983. The conference brings together business leaders, politicians, and influential figures from philanthropy and culture. Past attendees include Bill and Melinda Gates, Warren Buffett, Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin, and many others from various fields.

Marion Gordon Pat Robertson, born on March 22, 1930, is an American media mogul, executive chairman, and former Southern Baptist minister known for promoting conservative Christian beliefs. Caroline Spencer is a made-up character from the CBS soap opera The Bold and the Beautiful, invented by producer Bradley Bell. She's played by actress Linsey Godfrey. In the show, she's the daughter of Karen Spencer, who's a big deal in the media, and the niece of another media big shot, Bill Spencer, Jr. She's also named after her aunt, Caroline Spencer Forrester.

Merv Griffin Entertainment is a company started by Merv Griffin, a big name in American media, back in 1996. It's the successor to Merv Griffin Enterprises. They've produced shows like Dance Fever, which they brought back in 2003 for the Freeform channel. The company is part of The Griffin Group and owns rights to shows like The Merv Griffin Show and Dance Fever, although Sony Pictures Television handles distributing them on TV. From 2005 to 2008, Yani-Brune Entertainment ran the TV division, chosen personally by Griffin. Then in 2008, ShineReveille International struck a deal to distribute all of Merv Griffin Entertainment's shows internationally.

"A Girl like Me" is a short documentary made in 2005 by Kiri Davis. It talks about how color, hair, and facial features are significant for young African American women. It won the Diversity Award at the 6th Annual Media That Matters film festival in New York City and got featured on American media outlets like CNN, ABC, and NPR. Additionally, HBO aired the documentary, which was created as part of the Reel Works Teen Filmmaking program.

A media mogul is a successful businessperson who owns or controls a big chunk of media that many people use. They could be the owner or have a major role in a media company. People who have a lot of power and influence over a big media company might also be called a tycoon, baron, or business magnate. Even creators and founders of social media platforms can be seen as media moguls because they provide media to lots of people.

Elisabeth Murdoch, born on August 22, 1968, is a media executive from Australia who now lives in the United Kingdom. She's the second daughter of Rupert Murdoch, a very wealthy media owner. Elisabeth founded Shine Group, a British TV production company, in 2001 and was its non-executive chairperson. However, on January 1, 2015, her father's company, 21st Century Fox, merged Shine with other production companies like Endemol and Core Media, known for reality TV shows.

question: Ronald Reagan and George H. W. Bush both held which position in office?
pos: Ronald Reagan became the 40th President of the United States on January 20, 1981, after winning a big victory over Jimmy Carter in the 1980 election. He served until January 20, 1989, when he was followed by his vice president, George H. W. Bush, who won the 1988 election with Reagan's backing.

George Herbert Walker Bush, born on June 12, 1924, served as the 41st President of the United States from 1989 to 1993 and as the 43rd Vice President from 1981 to 1989. He belonged to the Republican Party and had roles as a congressman, ambassador, and Director of Central Intelligence. As of now, he is the oldest living former President and Vice President. To distinguish him from his son, George W. Bush, who also served as President, he's often called George H. W. Bush, Bush 41, Bush the Elder, or George Bush Senior since 2001.
neg: Otto Juan Reich, born on October 16, 1945, is a former high-ranking official in the administrations of Presidents Ronald Reagan, George H. W. Bush, and George W. Bush. Throughout his career, he held various important roles such as being the President's Special Envoy for the Western Hemisphere, Assistant Secretary of State for Western Hemisphere Affairs, United States Ambassador to Venezuela, and Assistant Administrator of the US Agency for International Development (appointed during a recess). In 2003, Bush appointed him as the US Special Envoy to the Western Hemisphere. Since leaving the White House in 2004, he has run his own international consulting firm, Otto Reich Associates, LLC, based in Washington, D.C.

Ronald Reagan became the 40th President of the United States on January 20, 1981, with his inauguration taking place on the West Front of the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C. It was the first time an inauguration was held on the building's west side. This event marked the start of Reagan's first term as President and George H. W. Bush's term as Vice President. Reagan took the presidential oath from Chief Justice Warren E. Burger using a family Bible given to him by his mother. Meanwhile, Vice President Bush was sworn in by Associate Justice Potter Stewart.

Ronald Reagan's second presidential inauguration happened in two parts: first, a private ceremony on January 20, 1985, at the White House, and then a public one the next day, January 21, 1985, at the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C. This marked the beginning of Reagan's second term as President and George H. W. Bush's term as Vice President.

A Reagan Democrat is a term used to describe a voter in the United States who traditionally supported the Democratic Party, particularly referring to white working-class residents in the Rust Belt. These voters shifted their support to Republican candidates, including Ronald Reagan in the 1980 and 1984 elections, George H. W. Bush in the 1988 election, and George W. Bush in the 2000 and 2004 elections. Some of these voters also supported Donald Trump, the Republican candidate in 2016, particularly in states like Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan, Wisconsin, and Iowa, which had previously voted for Reagan but had gone Democratic in the 2008 and 2012 elections.

Lawrence Sidney Eagleburger (1930–2011) was an American diplomat. He briefly served as the Secretary of State under President George H. W. Bush. Before that, he held various positions in the administrations of Presidents Nixon, Carter, and Reagan, and also served as Deputy Secretary of State under George H. W. Bush.

During Ronald Reagan's presidency, he nominated at least twelve people for various federal appellate judgeships who weren't approved. Some nominations weren't processed by the Democratic-controlled Senate Judiciary Committee before Reagan's presidency ended. Others were rejected by the committee or blocked by unfriendly Republican Party members. Three nominees were later renominated by Reagan's successor, George H. W. Bush. Ferdinand Francis Fernandez and Guy G. Hurlbutt were nominated after July 1, 1988, which is when the unofficial Thurmond Rule typically starts during a presidential election year. Eventually, eight of the twelve seats were filled by George H. W. Bush's appointees.

William Flynn Martin, born on October 4, 1950, is an American energy economist, educator, and international diplomat. He has held various significant roles throughout his career. For instance, during the Ronald Reagan administration, he served as the Special Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs, Executive Secretary of the National Security Council in the West Wing of the White House, and Deputy Secretary of the Department of Energy. Additionally, he was appointed by Secretary General of the United Nations Kofi Annan to serve on the Council of the University for Peace and later became its President. Furthermore, he served as the Executive Director of the Republican Platform Committee during George H.W. Bush's re-election bid. Over the years, he has held senior appointments and advisory positions under Presidents Ronald Reagan, George H.W. Bush, and George W. Bush.

Elliott Abrams, born on January 24, 1948, is a former American diplomat, lawyer, and political scientist. He worked in foreign policy roles for Presidents Ronald Reagan and George W. Bush. Abrams faced legal trouble for not sharing information with Congress during the Iran–Contra affair under Reagan's administration. However, he was pardoned by President George H. W. Bush.

question: In between The Bears and I and Oceans which was released on July 31, 1974, by Buena Vista Distribution?
pos: "The Bears and I" is a drama movie from 1974 directed by Bernard McEveety and written by John Whedon. It features actors like Patrick Wayne, Chief Dan George, Andrew Duggan, Michael Ansara, and Robert Pine. The film came out on July 31, 1974, distributed by Buena Vista.

The movie "Oceans" (originally in French as "Océans") was released in 2009. It's a nature documentary directed, produced, and co-written by Jacques Perrin, who also narrates it. Jacques Cluzaud is the co-director. The film takes a close look at the diverse marine life found in Earth's five oceans and discusses how human activities are harming the environment. In the English version, Pierce Brosnan provides the narration.
neg: Buena Vista is a small town in Elizabeth Township, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, near Pittsburgh and along the Youghiogheny River. It's known for having the Great Allegheny Passage rail trail passing through it. The town's ZIP code is 15018. At one point, Buena Vista was a mining community. Its name, like many other places in the USA, comes from the 1847 Battle of Buena Vista during the Mexican-American War.

Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures, previously known as Buena Vista Pictures Distribution, is an American film distributor owned by The Walt Disney Company. Established in 1953, it handles the distribution, marketing, and promotion of films from various Disney-owned studios, like Walt Disney Pictures, Pixar Animation Studios, and Marvel Studios. It changed its name to Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures in 2007, after being called Buena Vista Pictures Distribution since 1987.

The Buena Vista Downtown Historic District, situated in Buena Vista, Virginia, is a special area recognized for its historical significance. It includes 38 buildings and 1 structure located in the main business zone. These buildings, mostly made of brick and spanning one or two stories, date back as early as 1889-1890. Some notable structures within the district are the Buena Vista Post Office (1930), Buena Vista War Memorial Building (1954), Peoples Bank of Buena Vista (1907), Dickinson Building (around 1907), Royer’s Restaurant (around 1940), the Advocate Building (1889), Buena Vista Masonic Building (circa 1910), and the Valley Steam Laundry Building (circa 1905). Additionally, the Buena Vista Company Building (1890) is recognized separately as the Old Courthouse.

This list includes movies released by Walt Disney Pictures since 1983 and movies released before that under its previous name, Walt Disney Productions (1929–1983). Many of these movies were distributed in the United States by Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures, previously known as Buena Vista Distribution Company (1953–1987) and Buena Vista Pictures Distribution (1987–2007). Before 1953, Disney movies were distributed by RKO Radio Pictures, but they are now distributed by Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures.

Buena Vista High School, situated at 3945 East Holland in Buena Vista Charter Township, Michigan, was a public high school that belonged to the now-defunct Buena Vista School District. It shut down along with the district in July 2013. The school's symbol was the Knights, represented by blue and white colors. Its sports teams participated in the Greater Thumb Conference initially as a Class C school, and later in the Highland Conference as a Class D school.

Buena Vista is a brand linked to The Walt Disney Company, often used for its divisions and subsidiaries. It's based at the Walt Disney Studios on Buena Vista Street in Burbank, California, which also houses the company's corporate headquarters. The logos of these brands usually combine the words "Buena Vista" with the Disney Castle image, indicating their connection to Disney. "Buena Vista" translates to "good view" in Spanish.

The Best Western Lake Buena Vista Resort Hotel is a 325-room resort located within Walt Disney World Resort in Lake Buena Vista, Florida, near Disney Springs. It originally opened in November 1972 as the Travelodge at Lake Buena Vista, then changed names to Viscount Hotel from 1984 to 1988 before returning to Travelodge ownership in 1989. In 2000, it became the Best Western Lake Buena Vista Resort Hotel. Renovated in 2004, it now boasts two outdoor pools.

Buena Vista Park, located in San Francisco's Haight-Ashbury and Buena Vista Heights neighborhoods, is the city's oldest official park, dating back to 1867 when it was known as Hill Park before being renamed Buena Vista. It sits on a steep hill, reaching a height of 575 feet, covering 37 acres, with its boundaries marked by Haight Street to the north, Buena Vista Avenue West, and Buena Vista Avenue East. The park's lowest section is found at the north end along Haight Street.

question: What book provided the foundation for Masters and Johnson's research team?
pos: "Patterns of Sexual Behavior," written by Clellan S. Ford and Frank A. Beach in 1951, is a significant scientific book. It gathers data on human sexual behavior from 191 diverse cultures and compares it with observations from various animal species, focusing on primates. Regarded as a classic in its field, this book laid the groundwork for the research of Masters and Johnson. A revised edition titled "Human Sexuality in Four Perspectives" was released in 1977.

The Masters and Johnson research duo, William H. Masters and Virginia E. Johnson, were the first to study how people respond sexually and how to diagnose and treat sexual issues from the late 1950s to the 1990s.
neg: Berlin Diary (1934–1941) is a firsthand account by American journalist William L. Shirer about Nazi Germany's rise and path to war. Shirer, who worked as a radio reporter for CBS, covered Germany until Nazi censorship made it impossible for him to report objectively to his American audience. Feeling uneasy, he left the country. To protect his German sources from Gestapo retaliation, Shirer disguised their identities. His experiences detailed in this diary greatly contributed to his famous book, The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich.

Fukomys vandewoestijneae, also known as Caroline’s mole rat, was discovered in 2002 by a research team from the University of Ghent. This new species has a unique skull shape, and Paul Van Daele and his team officially described it in the journal Zootaxa. DNA and chromosome tests confirmed its status as a new species. The mole rat was named in honor of Van Daele's late wife, Caroline Van De Woestijne, who was part of the research team and tragically passed away from malaria during their time in Africa.

Virginia E. Johnson, originally named Mary Virginia Eshelman (1925–2013), was an American sex researcher famous for her work with the Masters and Johnson team. Together with William H. Masters, she studied how people respond sexually and helped develop ways to diagnose and treat sexual problems from the late 1950s to the 1990s.

Dana L. Shires, Jr. (born November 22, 1932) is an American doctor, researcher, and inventor. He helped develop Gatorade and co-founded the LifeLink Foundation, which helps with organ and tissue transplants.

"Sheep" is a scary book written by British author Simon Maginn. It first came out in 1994 and was printed again in 1997, but now you can't find it in stores. The 2005 movie "The Dark" was inspired by this book, although the story changed a lot when they made the film.

Alphapets is a collection of kids' books created by Ruth Lerner Perle, Deborah Colvin Borgo, Judy Blankenship, and Richard Max Kolding. It's like Sweet Pickles books where each book focuses on a letter of the alphabet, featuring animals for each letter. The stories are packed with words and items starting with the featured letter. Plus, at the end of each book, there's a special page to help practice identifying letters and words. This series first came out in the early 1990s.

Josef Peukert was a German Bohemian anarchist famous for his book "Memoirs from the proletarian revolutionary labour movement." In this book, he talks about the early days of the radical labor movement in Austria, the beginning of the anarchist movement in Germany, and the exile of anarchists in London and America during Socialist Law (1878-1890). However, fellow anarchist and historian Max Nettlau doubted the accuracy of Peukert's account and viewed it skeptically.

William Howell Masters, born in 1915 and passing away in 2001, was an American gynecologist. He's famous for being the leading figure in the Masters and Johnson sexuality research team, working closely with his wife, Virginia E. Johnson. Together, they delved into understanding human sexual response and finding ways to diagnose and treat sexual dysfunctions and disorders starting from 1957 until the 1990s.

question: What star of "Attack of the Gryphon" was also a voice artist in Johnny Bravo?
pos: "Gryphon," also called "Attack of the Gryphon," is a TV movie from 2007. Directed by Andrew Prowse, it features Amber Benson, Jonathan LaPaglia, and Larry Drake. The movie first aired on the Sci-Fi Channel on January 27, 2007.

Larry Richard Drake (February 21, 1950 – March 17, 2016) was an American actor, voice artist, and comedian. He was most famous for his roles as Benny Stulwicz in L.A. Law, Robert G. Durant in both Darkman, and as the voice of Pops in Johnny Bravo.
neg: Brian A. Miller, an American television producer, currently holds the position of Senior Vice President and General Manager at Cartoon Network Studios in Burbank, California, since 2000. The Festival of New Songs (FENS), previously known as Festival Nova scena, showcases emerging musicians from Slovenia and beyond. Held annually in July in Izola and Koper, the festival is broadcasted on major Slovenian television and radio channels.
