Some notable participants include Kingston, Tinkara Kovač, Siddharta, and Alya. The festival aims to promote Slovenian music and foster international collaboration with other European countries.
Van Partible, born Efrem Giovanni Bravo Partible on December 13, 1971, is a Filipino-American animator, writer, and producer famous for making the cartoon show Johnny Bravo.

Rumen Petkov, a Bulgarian animator and comic creator born on January 26, 1948, has had a significant impact on the Bulgarian comic book scene. He mentored a new wave of Bulgarian comic artists like Vladimir Nedialkov, Koko Sarkisian, and Ivan Kirjakov. Petkov's work, especially in the comic magazine DUGA (Rainbow), was beloved by several generations of Bulgarian children. His most famous creation, "The Adventures of Choko the Stork and Boko the Frog," gained popularity in Bulgaria during the 1970s and 1980s. Petkov also directed well-known animated films like "Friends of Gosho the Elephant" and "Treasure Planet," winning prestigious awards such as the Grand Prize at the Ottawa Animation Festival and the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival. More recently, Petkov has contributed to various animated series like "Johnny Bravo," "Dexter's Laboratory," and "Cow and Chicken" as a writer, storyboard artist, animation director, and director. He once expressed his belief that animation will endure because, like music, it's free-flowing and enjoyable.

Jeff Bennett, born on October 2, 1962, is an American voice actor and singer known for his roles in various TV shows, films, and video games. Some of his notable voice roles include Johnny Bravo, Petrie in Land Before Time, Mr. Smee and Bones in Jake and the Never Land Pirates, The Man With the Yellow Hat in Curious George, Raj in Camp Lazlo, and Kowalski in The Penguins of Madagascar series, among others.

Sherry Gunther, an American producer, is well-known for her work in animation. During her time at Klasky Csupo, she contributed to shows like Duckman, Rugrats, and early seasons of The Simpsons, earning a Primetime Emmy Award in 1991. Later, she became the senior vice president of production at Hanna-Barbera Cartoons, overseeing the creation of shows like Dexter's Laboratory and Johnny Bravo. She also produced Family Guy and established Twentieth Television's first in-house Prime-Time animation studio. Additionally, she produced Looney Tunes theatrical shorts for Warner Bros. Throughout her career, she has received numerous awards and nominations, including four Primetime Emmy nominations, Festival Awards, a Humanitas Award, a Daytime Emmy Award, two CableACE Award nominations, and a Humanitas Prize.

Steve Nallon, born on November 8, 1960, is a versatile British entertainer known for his acting, writing, voice work, and impressions. He started out in the 1970s as a stand-up comedian on the northern club scene. Nallon gained recognition for his voice work on the comedy puppet show Spitting Image, where he famously impersonated Margaret Thatcher during her tenure as UK Prime Minister from 1979 to 1990. Throughout his career, Nallon has portrayed various roles and characters across theatre, film, television, and radio.

Johnny Bravo is an animated TV series created by Van Partible for Cartoon Network. It premiered on July 14, 1997, and ended on August 27, 2004. The show is a spin-off of World Premiere Toons, also known as the What a Cartoon! Show.

question: Which fantasy film from 1971 featured the song "The Age of Not Believing"?
pos: Bedknobs and Broomsticks is a movie made in 1971 by Disney and released in North America on December 13th of that year. It's a mix of real acting and animation and stars Angela Lansbury and David Tomlinson. The story comes from books written by Mary Norton, a British author of children's stories.

"The Age of Not Believing" is a song from the 1971 Disney film Bedknobs and Broomsticks, sung by Angela Lansbury's character, Eglantine. In the song, Eglantine reflects on how children lose their belief in magic as they grow up and start doubting themselves. The song's message resonates both on a personal level and as a theme throughout the film: amidst wartime cynicism, Britain must rediscover its magical past to overcome challenges, paralleling the characters' journey to trust in Eglantine's magic to defeat the Nazis and save their country.
neg: Stark Electric Jesus is a short film from 2014 based on the poem "Stark Electric Jesus" by Malay Roy Choudhury. The film has been selected in 27 official selections across 20 countries and has won awards such as 'Best Video Art' in Poland, 'Most Promising Artist' at Madatac,06 in Spain, and 'Best Fantasy Film' at the Hrizantema International Horror & Fantasy Film Festival in Serbia.

Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV is a Japanese animated movie released in 2016. It's directed by Takeshi Nozue and written by Takashi Hasegawa, based on a story by Kazushige Nojima and Saori Itamuro. The movie premiered in Japan in July 2016 and later had a limited run in North America in August the same year. It was released on digital and physical formats in October 2016, sometimes bundled with different versions of the game Final Fantasy XV.

"Once Upon a Time in Vietnam" is a Vietnamese action fantasy film from 2013, directed by and starring Dustin Nguyen alongside Roger Yuan. It came out on August 22, 2013, marking the debut of Vietnamese action fantasy cinema.

The 1971 Baseball Hall of Fame elections introduced a fresh committee focusing on the Negro Leagues. In February, they chose Satchel Paige. The museum intended to celebrate Paige and future inductees with a special permanent exhibit. However, debates over the nature of this recognition stirred up during the announcement event on February 9 and persisted until the induction ceremonies six months later. During the induction, Paige was admitted to the Hall of Fame alongside major league players.

Sianoa Smit-McPhee, born on February 21, 1992, is an Australian singer, songwriter, and actress. You might recognize her from her time on the Australian soap opera Neighbours as Bree Timmins or from the children's TV show As the Bell Rings on the Disney Channel. In 2007, she played Desma in the short fantasy film Hugo. She also had a role on the HBO series Hung as Darby Drecker from 2009 to 2011. Later, in 2012, she appeared in the TV movie ABC Firelight and the series It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia. The next year, she starred in All Cheerleaders Die. Sianoa and her husband John Rush, who is a music producer, wrote and produced the song "Take a Bite of My Heart," which was featured in a film and performed by Sianoa.

They Say I am a Womanizer is a 1949 Mexican comedy-drama movie directed by Roberto Rodríguez, a gem from the Golden Age of Mexican cinema. The film stars Pedro Infante, Sara Garcia, Silvia Derbez, and child star María Eugenia Llamas. Pedro Infante plays the role of a womanizing grandson of Sara Garcia's character, Dona Rosa, a respected rancher who cares deeply for him. Despite Dona Rosa's efforts to guide him, Pedro's eye is set on Flor, the niece of a neighboring rancher, who flirts with him while he competes for her affection against the town mayor, Pablo. A plot twist arises when Pablo convinces orphan Tucita that Pedro is her father to sabotage his relationship with Flor. Eventually, the truth comes out, and Pedro and Flor tie the knot.

"The Golden Voyage of Sinbad," a fantasy film from 1973, directed by Gordon Hessler, showcases stunning stop-motion effects by Ray Harryhausen. It's the second installment in Colombia Pictures' Sinbad trilogy, following "The 7th Voyage of Sinbad" in 1958 and preceding "Sinbad and the Eye of the Tiger" in 1977. The movie features actors like John Phillip Law, Tom Baker, Takis Emmanuel, and Caroline Munro. Notably, it clinched the inaugural Saturn Award for Best Fantasy Film.

Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children is a 2005 Japanese animated film directed by Tetsuya Nomura and written by Kazushige Nojima. It was produced by Yoshinori Kitase and Shinji Hashimoto, developed by Visual Works and Square Enix, and is part of the Compilation of Final Fantasy VII series. The film is set in the world of the 1997 video game Final Fantasy VII. It was initially released in Japan on September 14, 2005, with Japanese voice acting, and later on April 25, 2006, with English voice acting in North America and Europe.

question: Mick Carter is the landlord of a public house located at what address?
pos: Michael "Mick" Carter is a character on the BBC soap opera EastEnders, played by Danny Dyer. He first appeared on the show on December 25, 2013. Dyer's role was announced on October 1, 2013, alongside Kellie Bright, who plays his on-screen partner Linda Carter. Mick is the son of Shirley Carter (played by Linda Henry) and is part of the Carter family. When he arrives, he becomes the new owner of The Queen Victoria pub, also known as The Vic, along with Linda, their son Johnny, and their dog Lady Di. Later, their daughter Nancy, son Lee, and other relatives join them.
The Queen Victoria, commonly known as The Queen Vic or The Vic, is a pub from the BBC soap opera, EastEnders. It's located at 46 Albert Square, Walford, London E20.
neg: The Fat Cat Brewery is situated at the Fat Cat Brewery Tap on Lawson Road in Norwich, Norfolk, England. It's owned by Colin Keatley, who also runs the Fat Cat pub, which has won the CAMRA National Pub of the Year award twice.

The Gatehouse, also called The Gate House, is a pub near Monnow Bridge in Monmouth, Wales. It used to be called the Barley Mow until 1993. It's the only pub in Monmouth next to a river. The pub has a restaurant, balcony seating, and a function room.

The Shakespeare Public House, located at 66-70 Prince Street in Bristol, England, is a historic building constructed in 1725 by the Bristol builder John Strahan. Originally, it was two attached Georgian-style houses. In 1777, it was turned into a pub, providing drinks and food to dock workers at the nearby port. It's been recognized as a grade II* listed building since 1959.

The Square and Compass is an old pub located in Worth Matravers, Dorset, known for its history and unique features. It used to be two cottages back in the 18th century before being turned into a pub. Its name comes from a former landlord who was once a stonemason, which explains the symbol. Inside, you'll find a museum displaying fossils and other local treasures. This pub is also quite special, being one of only nine across the country to consistently make it into CAMRA's good pub guide.

Linda Bernadette Carter is a character in the BBC soap opera EastEnders, played by Kellie Bright. She joined the show on December 19, 2013, alongside her on-screen partner, Mick Carter (played by Danny Dyer). Linda was introduced by the executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins as part of the Carter family. She became the landlady of The Queen Victoria pub and moved there with her family from her mother's pub in Watford. Although not explicitly named, she was occasionally referred to as Linda Peacock. Bright announced her pregnancy in May 2016 and took maternity leave, temporarily leaving the show on December 25, 2016. However, she made two guest appearances on March 16 and June 30, 2017, before returning full-time on August 7.

Whitney Carter, played by Shona McGarty, is a character on the BBC soap opera EastEnders. She's introduced as the adoptive daughter of Bianca Jackson, portrayed by Patsy Palmer, in April. Whitney's described as a younger version of Bianca and is the oldest of Bianca's four kids. Her storylines include dealing with family issues, surviving sexual abuse, exploitation, marriage, miscarriage, a bus crash, and complicated romantic relationships. McGarty faced temporary and extended breaks from the show due to various reasons.
The Adam & Eve used to be a pub at the corner of Bradford Street and Warner Street in Deritend, Birmingham, England. It had been there for over 200 years.

Nancy Carter is a character in the BBC soap opera EastEnders, portrayed by Maddy Hill. She first appeared on the show in episodes aired on 1 January 2014. Nancy is part of the Carter family, being the daughter of Mick Carter (played by Danny Dyer) and Linda Carter (played by Kellie Bright). Throughout her time on the show, Nancy's storylines involved romantic relationships with characters like Wayne Ladlow, Dexter Hartman, and Tamwar Masood. She also dealt with challenges such as coping with her mother's rape, managing epilepsy, and having conflicts with her older brother Lee Carter. Hill announced her departure from the show on 12 March 2016, and Nancy made her final appearance on 22 April 2016, alongside Tamwar.

question: What television thriller anthology did the winner of one Golden Globe, two tony Awards and six Primetime Emmy Awards appear on?
pos: Darkroom was a TV series on ABC from November 27, 1981, to January 15, 1982, made by Universal Television. It's like Rod Serling's Night Gallery, with each episode having a few different scary or thrilling stories. The show had a new story and cast in each episode, but James Coburn hosted the beginning and end parts. Lots of famous actors appeared in the episodes, like Steve Allen, Esther Rolle, Helen Hunt, and many more.

Brian Manion Dennehy, born on July 9, 1938, is an American actor known for his work in movies, theater, and TV. He's won a Golden Globe and two Tony Awards, and has been nominated for six Primetime Emmy Awards. He first gained fame for playing Sheriff Will Teasle in "First Blood" (1982). Dennehy has appeared in many other films, including "Gorky Park," "Silverado," "Cocoon," "F/X," "Romeo + Juliet," and "Knight of Cups."
neg: Al Pacino, an American actor and director in both film and stage productions, has won numerous awards including an Academy Award, a BAFTA Award, two Primetime Emmy Awards, two Tony Awards, and four Golden Globe Awards.

Elisabeth Moss, born on July 24, 1982, is an American actor in movies, plays, and TV shows. You might recognize her as Zoey Bartlet from "The West Wing," Peggy Olson from "Mad Men," Det. Robin Griffin in "Top of the Lake," and Offred in "The Handmaid's Tale." She's received several award nominations and wins for her roles.

"Lost" is a TV show that aired on ABC from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010. It received many award nominations and wins, including 11 Primetime Emmy Awards out of 54 nominations, 13 Saturn Awards out of 48 nominations, and others like Teen Choice Awards, Television Critics Association Awards, and Golden Globe Awards. Notable wins include Outstanding Drama Series at the Primetime Emmy Awards, Best Television Series – Drama at the Golden Globe Awards, and Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Drama Series at the Screen Actors Guild Awards.

Beatriz "Betty" Suarez is the main character in the TV show Ugly Betty, played by America Ferrera. Ferrera won several awards for her portrayal, including a Golden Globe and a SAG award in 2007. She also received recognition at the Primetime Emmy Awards. AOL listed Betty as one of the 100 Most Memorable Female TV Characters.

Laura Linney, born on February 5, 1964, is an American actress and singer who has won two Golden Globe Awards and four Primetime Emmy Awards. She's also been nominated for three Academy Awards and four Tony Awards.

Al Pacino, born April 25, 1940, is an American actor, filmmaker, and screenwriter. He has been active in the entertainment industry for over five decades and has received numerous awards and honors, including an Academy Award, two Tony Awards, two Primetime Emmy Awards, a British Academy Film Award, and four Golden Globe Awards. He has also received the Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Film Institute, the Golden Globe Cecil B. DeMille Award, and the National Medal of Arts. Pacino is one of the few actors to have won the "Triple Crown of Acting," which includes a competitive Oscar, Emmy, and Tony Award for acting.

John Arthur Lithgow, born on October 19, 1945, is an American actor, musician, singer, comedian, voice actor, and author. He's won numerous awards, including two Tony Awards, six Emmy Awards, two Golden Globe Awards, and three Screen Actors Guild Awards. He's also received accolades like an American Comedy Award, four Drama Desk Awards, and nominations for two Academy Awards and four Grammy Awards. Lithgow has a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame and is part of the American Theater Hall of Fame.

Blythe Katherine Danner, born on February 3, 1943, is an American actress. She's known for winning two Primetime Emmy Awards for Best Supporting Actress in a Drama Series for her role as Izzy Huffstodt on Huff (2004–2006), and a Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Play for her performance in Butterflies Are Free (1969–1972). Danner was also nominated for two Primetime Emmy Awards for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Comedy Series for playing Marilyn Truman on Will & Grace (2001–2006), and for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Miniseries or a Movie for her roles in We Were the Mulvaneys (2002) and Back When We Were Grownups (2004). She was additionally nominated for a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Miniseries or Television Film for the latter role.

question: What Cayman Islands registered Mandarin and Cantonese-language television broadcaster launched Phoenix Hong Kong Channel on 28 March 2011?
pos: Phoenix Hong Kong Channel, one of Phoenix Television's six channels, started on March 28, 2011, to cater to viewers in Hong Kong who speak Yue Chinese. It's the first Yue Chinese-language channel from Phoenix Television available across Hong Kong, airing on cable and satellite TV. While most programs are in Yue Chinese, some still air in Mandarin Chinese.

Phoenix Television, headquartered in Hong Kong and registered in the Cayman Islands, is a Mandarin and Cantonese-language broadcaster serving audiences in mainland China, Hong Kong, and other regions with large Chinese viewerships. The network offers six TV channels, such as Phoenix InfoNews, Phoenix Chinese, Phoenix Movies, and Phoenix Hong Kong, delivering a mix of news, information, and entertainment content.
neg: Carey Olsen is a top offshore law firm with offices in various locations like the British Virgin Islands, Cape Town, Cayman Islands, Guernsey, Hong Kong, Jersey, London, and Singapore. They specialize in advising on laws from regions such as the British Virgin Islands, Cayman Islands, Guernsey, and Jersey.

The ".ky" is the internet domain for the Cayman Islands. Initially, only residents and registered companies in the Cayman Islands could register, needing a local address. However, since September 2, 2015, anyone worldwide can register it on a first-come, first-served basis. Additionally, the Cayman Islands also use the international code "CYM" and are set to receive the ".cym" domain in a future expansion of domain names.

The Cayman Islands are participating in the 2011 Pan American Games in Guadalajara, Mexico, from October 14 to 30, 2011. They're sending twelve athletes across four sports, which matches their participation level from the 2007 Pan American Games in Rio de Janeiro. Bruce Blake, the general secretary of the Cayman Islands Football Association, will be leading the team as the Chef de Mission.

Anthony Travers, OBE, served as the Chairman of the Board of Cayman Finance from 2009 to 2011. He's also the Chairman of the Cayman Islands Stock Exchange and previously held senior roles at the international law firm Maples and Calder. With over thirty years of experience in Cayman Islands law, he specializes in areas like mutual funds, structured finance, insurance, and private client matters. Travers has also provided guidance to the government on developing legislation in the Cayman Islands.

The Cayman Islands rugby sevens team is a smaller team that competes internationally. They've participated in events like the Commonwealth Sevens and made their first appearance at the Hong Kong Sevens in 2016, becoming the 60th team to play in that tournament.

The Cayman Islands Open 2011 was a women's tournament held as part of the 2011 Cayman Islands Open. It was a WSA World Series event with a Gold level, offering a prize of $68,500. The tournament occurred in Grand Cayman, Cayman Islands, from April 3rd to April 9th. Nicol David emerged as the winner, securing her third Cayman Islands Open title by defeating Jenny Duncalf in the final match.

Cayman Enterprise City is a special area in the Cayman Islands where businesses get special treatment. It's run by a private company, not the government, even though it was the government's idea. To make these special areas possible, the government made laws in 2011 and 2012. They also created a group called the Special Economic Zone Authority (SEZA) to handle licenses and rules.

Walkers is a law firm headquartered in the Cayman Islands. While it has expanded to other locations, more than half of its employees still work in the Cayman Islands. Additionally, Walkers has established a branch office in 15/F, Alexandra House, Hong Kong.

question: What is the name of the film starring Rose McGowan and features the character Earl McGraw's daughter?
pos: Earl McGraw and his son Edgar, played by Michael Parks and James Parks, are fictional characters who appear in several films by Robert Rodriguez and Quentin Tarantino, including the From Dusk till Dawn franchise and various works from the Grindhouse project. Despite Earl being killed off in his first appearance, other characters named Earl and Edgar have appeared in later films by Rodriguez and Tarantino. Earl, known for his heavy Texas accent and profanity-laden dialogue, often provides comic relief. Both characters are consistently depicted as Texas Rangers. Edgar, played by James Parks, is portrayed as Earl's son. Earl also has a daughter named Dakota, played by Marley Shelton, who plays a significant role in Planet Terror, another film from the Grindhouse project. Dakota is also portrayed by Nicky Whelan.

Planet Terror, a 2007 American zombie film by Robert Rodriguez, follows a group fighting zombie-like creatures while clashing with a military unit. The movie stars Rose McGowan, Freddy Rodriguez, Josh Brolin, Marley Shelton, Naveen Andrews, Michael Biehn, Jeff Fahey, Stacy Ferguson, and Bruce Willis. It was released alongside Quentin Tarantino's Death Proof as a double feature called Grindhouse, aiming to recreate the grindhouse theater experience. Rodriguez not only directed but also wrote the script, handled cinematography, composed the music, co-edited, and produced the film.
neg: Emotional Technology is the fourth album by electronica artist BT. It has a more pop-like sound compared to his previous work. The album includes popular songs like "Somnambulist," also known as "Simply Being Loved," which holds the Guinness World Record for the most vocal edits in a single track. It features vocals from JC Chasez, Rose McGowan, and BT himself, among others.
The TV movie "The Pastor's Wife" aired in 2011 on the Lifetime Network. It stars Rose McGowan as Mary Winkler and is based on the true crime book of the same name by Diane Fanning.
Here's a simpler version

Devil in the Flesh is a thriller movie from 1998 with Rose McGowan as the lead. It's also known as "Dearly Devoted." While Kelly Carlin-McCall helped write the script, the movie itself isn't based on Raymond Radiguet's novel "Le Diable au corps" (The Devil in the Flesh), which has been made into a movie twice before.

In 1996, "Scream" hit theaters. It's a slasher movie made in America, written by Kevin Williamson and directed by Wes Craven. The cast includes David Arquette, Neve Campbell, Courteney Cox, Matthew Lillard, Rose McGowan, Skeet Ulrich, and Drew Barrymore. The story revolves around Sidney Prescott, played by Neve Campbell, who lives in Woodsboro, California, and is hunted by a killer called Ghostface. "Scream" is unique because it blends comedy, mystery, and violence to poke fun at horror movie clichés from films like "Halloween" and "Friday the 13th." It stands out for having characters who are aware of horror movie tropes and openly talk about them.

Paige Matthews, played by Rose McGowan, is a character in the TV show Charmed. She joined the series in season four after actress Shannen Doherty left. Paige is the younger half-sister of Piper and Phoebe Halliwell, who are also witches. Like them, she's one of the Charmed Ones, the most powerful witches. Paige's backstory reveals she's the secret daughter of Patty Halliwell and her whitelighter, Sam Wilder, and was adopted after birth.
Dead Awake is a mystery movie from 2010 featuring actors like Nick Stahl, Rose McGowan, and Amy Smart. Before its release, the film was known as Dylan's Wake.

Conan the Barbarian, released in 2011, is an American fantasy film inspired by the character created by Robert E. Howard. It presents a fresh take on the Conan story and isn't connected to the older movies with Arnold Schwarzenegger. The movie features Jason Momoa as Conan, along with Rachel Nichols, Rose McGowan, Stephen Lang, Ron Perlman, and Bob Sapp, and it was directed by Marcus Nispel.

question: Chimaja Appawas the younger brother of a general of the Maratha Empire in India, who served as what to the fifth Maratha Chhatrapati Shahu from 1720 until his death?
pos: Shreemant Chimaji Ballal Peshwa, also known as Chimaji Appa, was born in 1707 and was the son of Balaji Vishwanath Bhat. He was the younger brother of Bajirao Peshwa of the Maratha Empire. He was a skilled military leader who freed the western coast of India from Portuguese control. His most significant achievement was capturing the Vasai fort from the Portuguese after a tough battle.

Baji Rao (18 August 1700 – 28 April 1740) was a military leader in the Maratha Empire in India. He held the position of Peshwa (Prime Minister) under the fifth Maratha Emperor, Shahu, from 1720 until he passed away. He is also referred to as Bajirao Ballal.
neg: Balaji Vishwanath (Bhatt) was born into a Konkanastha Brahmin family in the coastal Konkan region of present-day Maharashtra. His family held the position of Deshmukh for Shrivardhan under the rule of the Siddi of Janjira. He sought employment in the western ghats and worked as a mercenary under various Maratha generals. According to Kincaid & Parasnis, he entered Maratha administration during the reign of Chhatrapati Sambhaji or his brother Rajaram's regency. He later served as an accountant for the Maratha general Dhanaji Jadhav at Janjira. From 1699 to 1702, he was the head-administrator at Pune and from 1704 to 1707, he served as the Sarsubedar of Daulatabad. After proving himself as a capable officer, he had a falling out with Dhanaji's son and successor, Chandrarao Jadhav, and aligned with the newly released Maratha ruler Chhatrapati Shahu, who appointed him as his assistant around 1708.

The New Palace in Kolhapur, Maharashtra, India, was built between 1877 and 1884. Made of black polished stone, it's known for its impressive architecture and attracts many tourists. The palace grounds include a garden, fountain, and wrestling area. The building itself is eight-sided with a central tower and clocks installed in 1877. Paintings depicting events from Shivaji's life adorn the glass windows. There's also a zoo and a lake on the grounds. Today, it still serves as the residence of Chhatrapati Shahu, a direct descendant of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, who founded the Maratha Empire.

Rajaram II Bhonsle, also known as Ramaraja, was the sixth ruler of the Maratha Empire. He was adopted by Chhattrapati Shahu, who was tricked into believing he was Tarabai's grandson. Tarabai used Rajaram II's presence to gain power after Shahu's death, but later she claimed he was not the legitimate heir. Despite this, Peshwa Balaji Baji Rao kept him as the symbolic ruler. However, the real power rested with the Peshwa and other chiefs, while Rajaram II was more of a symbolic leader without much authority.

Maynak Bhandari was an important leader in the early Maratha Navy during the time of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. He played a key role in establishing and protecting the Maratha Empire's coastline. Bhandari, along with Daria Sarang, commanded a fleet of 200 ships. Their titles, Mai Nayak Bhandari and Daria Sarang, mean Water Leader and Sea Captain. The Maratha Navy laid the foundation for the modern Indian Coast Guard. Today, a memorial stands in Bhatye Village, near Ratnagiri town, dedicated to Ram Nayak Bhandari.

The Maratha Navy was the naval branch of the Maratha Empire's military in India, active from the mid-17th to the mid-18th century. Chhatrapati Shivaji, the founder of the Maratha Empire, is known as the Father of the Indian Navy.

Baloji Kunjar, also known as Kunjir, was a prominent figure in the Maratha Empire during the late 1700s to early 1800s. He served as both a Sardar and Minister of Affairs under Peshwa Baji Rao II. He was highly regarded by Peshwa Baji Rao II and played a key role during a period of succession debates following the death of Peshwa Sawai Madhavrao. Kunjar successfully mediated between Baji Rao II and Nana Phadanvis, securing Baji Rao II's appointment as Peshwa. In recognition of his efforts, he was granted land in the form of Jagir, consisting of 14 villages near Purandhar fort. Kunjar, along with his son Pandoji Kunjar and Narayan, held positions of authority as Sur-Patils in Pune Punch Mahals under Peshwa Baji Rao II. Their family enjoyed privileges as sar-patils of 360 villages and towns in the Subha of Poona for a considerable period.

The Maratha emperors ruled over the Maratha Empire in the Indian subcontinent from the early 17th to the early 18th century. This empire covered what are now Bangladesh, India, and Pakistan. However, their power declined rapidly in the 18th century, and the British Raj took over after the last emperor was removed in 1818. At its peak in the late 17th and early 18th centuries, the Marathas controlled a large part of the Indian subcontinent, stretching from Bengal in the east to Atak and Sindh in the west, and from Kashmir in the north to the Kaveri basin in the south. Initially, the Peshwas served under the Maratha king (Chhatrapati), but later they became the leaders themselves, while the king's role became largely symbolic. Towards the end of the Maratha Empire, the Peshwas played a significant role in its expansion.

Shahu Bhonsle (1682–1749 CE) was the fifth ruler of the Maratha Empire, which was established by his grandfather, Shivaji. Shahu and his mother were captured by Mughal General Nusrat Jang in 1689. He later escaped Mughal captivity and, in 1708, defeated his aunt Tarabai in a family conflict to become the ruler. Following the death of Aurangzeb, influential Mughal officials released Shahu with a small group of men, believing that having a friendly Maratha leader as an ally would be beneficial.

question: What is the name of the oldest child that attended the Trump campaign-Russian meeting?
pos: On June 9, 2016, at Trump Tower in New York City, three top members of Donald Trump's presidential campaign—Donald Trump Jr., Jared Kushner, and Paul Manafort—met with at least five others, including Russian lawyer Natalia Veselnitskaya. The meeting was set up by Rob Goldstone, a publicist who has known Trump for a long time, acting on behalf of his client, singer-songwriter Emin Agalarov. Kushner revealed the meeting to U.S. officials when he updated his security clearance form.

Donald John Trump Jr., born on December 31, 1977, is an American businessman who used to be on reality TV. He's the oldest child of Donald Trump, who was the 45th President of the United States, and his first wife, Ivana.
neg: The Child Welfare League of America (CWLA) is the oldest organization in the United States focused on child welfare. Its main goal is to prioritize children on a national level. The CWLA is respected by professionals who work with children and is the only national organization that includes members from both public and private agencies, giving it special access and influence across all areas of children's services.

Domitia, also known as Domitia the Elder, was born around 8 BC and died in June 59 AD. She was the oldest child of Antonia Major and Lucius Domitius Ahenobarbus, who served as consul in 16 BC. Domitia was the granddaughter of Triumvir Mark Antony through her mother, Antonia Major, and Octavia Minor. She was also related to the Roman Emperor Augustus, Emperor Caligula, Emperor Claudius, Empress Valeria Messalina, and Emperor Nero. Domitia had two younger siblings, Domitia Lepida and Cn. Domitius Ahenobarbus, who served as consul in AD 32. The exact date of her birth is not known, but it was estimated to be no later than 7 BC, possibly even earlier if there was a significant gap between her birth and that of her siblings.

Mary Elizabeth Day Nursery, also known as Mary Elizabeth Day Care Center, is a historic building in Sioux City, Iowa, USA. It is the oldest child day care facility in Iowa and the state's second-oldest preschool. Established in 1914 by the Wall Street Mission, a local settlement house operated by the Methodist Episcopal Church, it moved to its current location in 1926, becoming Iowa's first purpose-built day nursery. Designed by local architect Jurgen A. Raven and constructed by The Lytle Company, a Sioux City construction firm, the two-story brick Renaissance Revival building reflects its historical significance. Parents contributed to their children's care costs, supplemented by subsidies from religious institutions, private associations, and individuals. During the Great Depression, government funding and licensing of child care began, with the Works Progress Administration's involvement in the 1930s. In 1940, a garage and playhouse designed by Sioux City architect Knute E. Westerlind were added. The facility was renamed the Mary Elizabeth Day Care Center in 1990 and was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1997.

Jessica Mulroney, previously known as Jessica Brownstein, is a Canadian fashion stylist. She married Ben Mulroney on October 30, 2008. Ben is the oldest son and second oldest child of Mila and Brian Mulroney, who served as a former Prime Minister of Canada. Jessica Mulroney follows the Jewish faith, and the couple has three children.

Clayton Anthony Fountain (September 12, 1955 – July 12, 2004) was a convicted murderer who spent time in federal prison. He was born in Fort Benning, Georgia, and grew up as the oldest of six children in a family that moved frequently due to his father's military service. Clayton took on a lot of responsibilities at a young age, helping care for his siblings while his parents were busy. Despite being trained by his father in traditional male roles, he ended up in the Marines and was convicted of murdering his staff sergeant in 1974 while stationed in the Philippines. This led to a life sentence in the United States Penitentiary, Marion, where he used his military skills to commit further acts of violence, earning him the reputation as the Most Dangerous Prisoner in the federal system.

The Clear Creek Meeting House is a Quaker meeting place situated at 14365 N. 350th Ave., near McNabb, in Magnolia Township, Putnam County, Illinois. It was constructed in 1875 for the Illinois Yearly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends, also known as the Quakers. This gathering was the furthest west for the Hicksite Friends and drew attendees from various states. Additionally, the meeting house hosted the Clear Creek Monthly Meeting for local Quakers. The building's design is typical of American Friends meeting houses, with two square rooms both inside and out, reflecting simplicity, a key Quaker principle. It stands as one of the few remaining western Quaker meeting houses exemplifying this architectural tradition.

John Ingram McMorran, born in 1889 and passing away in 2003 at the remarkable age of 113, was one of the world's oldest people. He hailed from Goodland Township, Michigan, and was the eldest child in his family. Interestingly, he was related to Representative Henry Gordon McMorran. Despite a fortune teller predicting he'd live to 111, McMorran surpassed expectations, defying the odds. He had a sister who lived to 103. Despite his habits of smoking, drinking, and indulging in greasy food, he lived a long life.

Zeresenay Alemseged, born on June 4, 1969, is an Ethiopian paleoanthropologist known for his work at the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco and now at the University of Chicago. He gained fame for discovering "Selam," also known as "Lucy's child," on December 10, 2000. Selam, a nearly complete fossilized remains of a 3.3 million-year-old child belonging to the species Australopithecus afarensis, is considered the oldest child ever found and provides valuable insights into human evolution, especially regarding childhood development. Alemseged found Selam while leading the Dikika Research Project (DRP), a multinational effort he initiated in 1999. The DRP continues to make significant discoveries in paleoanthropology, with Alemseged focusing on understanding hominin fossil remains and their environments through fieldwork aimed at gathering new data on early hominin skeletal biology, environmental context, and behavior.

question: The 1st Virginia Regiment saw action at a battle that led to the departure of what Royal Governor?
pos: The 1st Virginia Regiment was formed in Williamsburg, Virginia, on July 17, 1775, initially as a state militia group before joining the (U.S.) Continental Army later. Its roots trace back to the Charles City-Henrico County Regiment of Militia, which was established in 1652. Led by Colonel George Washington during the French and Indian War, the regiment participated in various battles, including Great Bridge, New York Campaign, Trenton, Princeton, Brandywine, Germantown, Monmouth, Stony Point, and the Siege of Charleston. After most of the regiment was captured by the British in Charleston, South Carolina, on May 12, 1780, it was officially disbanded on November 15, 1783. The 276th Engineer Battalion carries on the legacy of the 1st Virginia Regiment.

The Battle of Great Bridge happened on December 9, 1775, near Great Bridge, Virginia, at the start of the American Revolutionary War. The colonial Virginia militia won, which made the British Governor Lord Dunmore leave and removed British control from Virginia in the early days of the war.
neg: The 5th Virginia Regiment was formed on December 28, 1775, in Richmond, Virginia, to serve in the U.S. Continental Army. They fought in battles like Trenton, Princeton, Brandywine, Germantown, Monmouth, and the Siege of Charleston. On May 12, 1779, they merged with the 3rd Virginia Regiment. Notable leaders included General William Russell and Col. Josiah Parker.

The 9th Virginia Regiment started in 1776 as part of Virginia's troops. It was officially formed between February and March of that year with troops from eastern Virginia. Later, it joined the Continental Army in May. During battles like Brandywine and Germantown, the regiment was involved. At Germantown, led by Colonel George Mathews, they got separated and many were captured by the British. They advanced so far into enemy lines that they were surrounded. Attacked from different directions, they eventually surrendered. In 1779, they merged with the 1st Virginia Regiment and were eventually captured by the British in 1780 during the Siege of Charleston. They disbanded in 1783.

The 1st Virginia State Regiment was a group of soldiers from Virginia who fought in the American Revolutionary War. They were approved by Virginia's government in December 1776 to defend the state. Facing a shortage in the Continental Army, Virginia sent the regiment, led by Colonel George Gibson, to help in July 1777. They stayed with the Continental Army through winter camps and battles like Monmouth until late 1779 when they returned to Virginia. Unlike other regiments, they had ten companies instead of eight, including one for light infantry.

The 7th Virginia Regiment was formed on January 11, 1776, in Gloucester, Virginia, to serve in the Continental Army. They fought in battles like Brandywine, Germantown (where they stayed at Valley Forge during winter), Monmouth, and Charleston. Many members were captured in Charleston by the British on May 12, 1780, and the regiment officially ended on January 1, 1783. A part of this regiment, known as the 3rd Virginia Detachment, was involved in the Waxhaw Massacre in 1780.

The 6th Connecticut Regiment was formed on May 1, 1775, in New Haven, Connecticut, initially for the Continental Army. It later became part of the Continental Line on January 1, 1776, known as the 10th Continental Regiment. Then, on January 1, 1777, it joined the Connecticut Line as the 6th Connecticut Regiment again. The regiment participated in various battles including the siege of Boston, the Battle of Long Island, and the New York Campaign. Additionally, its colonel and a company of light infantry fought in the Corps of Light Infantry during the Battle of Stony Point. Finally, the regiment was combined with the 1st Connecticut Regiment on January 1, 1783, at West Point, New York, and was disbanded on November 16, 1783.

The 3rd Virginia Regiment was formed in December 1775 in Alexandria, Virginia, to join the Continental Army. It was led by Colonel Hugh Mercer at first, who was soon promoted. Then George Weedon took over, also getting a promotion shortly after. Colonel Thomas Marshall, who was the father of Supreme Court Chief Justice John Marshall, became the next commander. During their time at Valley Forge, Colonel William Heth led them. The regiment fought in various battles including Trenton, Princeton, and Charleston. Unfortunately, most of the soldiers were captured by the British in Charleston in 1780, leading to the regiment being officially disbanded in 1783. Some notable lieutenants in the regiment included James Monroe, Thomas Helm, John Francis Mercer, and James Markham Marshall.

The 4th Virginia Regiment was formed on December 28, 1775, in Suffolk Court House, Virginia, to join the Continental Army. They fought in battles like Trenton, Princeton, Brandywine, Germantown, Monmouth, and Charleston's siege. Unfortunately, in May 1780, most of the regiment was captured by the British in Charleston, South Carolina. The regiment officially disbanded on January 1, 1783.

The 12th Virginia Regiment was formed on September 16, 1776, in Williamsburg, Virginia, to serve in the Continental Army of the United States. They fought in battles like Brandywine, Germantown, Monmouth, and took part in the Siege of Charleston. Unfortunately, the majority of the regiment was captured by the British in Charlestown, South Carolina, on May 12, 1780. As a result, the regiment was officially disbanded on January 1, 1783.

question: Which Argentine telenovela broadcast by Telefe from March 12 to December 19, 2012 starred Isabel Macedo as Jimena Benitez?
pos: "Graduados" is an Argentine soap opera from 2012 aired on Telefe from March 12 to December 19. It follows a group of high school graduates from 1989 who reunite twenty years later. The story revolves around Andrés Goddzer, played by Daniel Hendler, who learns that María Laura Falsini, portrayed by Nancy Dupláa, was pregnant in 1989 and married Pablo Catáneo, played by Luciano Cáceres, who believed he was the father. This leads to a parental dispute, a love triangle, and 1980s nostalgia. The show also tackles themes like school bullying and LGBT rights, with flashbacks featuring the same actors as teenagers.

Patricia Longo, or Jimena Benítez, is a made-up character in the Argentine TV series Graduados from 2012. Isabel Macedo plays her role, depicting her as an adult and also as a teenager in flashback scenes.
neg: Montecristo: Love and Revenge is an Argentine soap opera that first aired on Telefe on April 25, 2006. It's loosely inspired by Alexandre Dumas' 1844 novel, The Count of Monte Cristo. This show became Telefe's top soap opera and was labeled Argentina's most talked-about soap opera by Variety in 2007.

"Guapas," a telenovela from Argentina, aired in 2014. Produced by Pol-ka, it was broadcasted on El Trece. The show stars Araceli Gonzalez, Isabel Macedo, Mercedes Morán, Carla Peterson, and Florencia Bertotti.

"Amar, después de amar" is a 2017 Argentine soap opera aired on Telefe, starting from January 23, 2017. The show features Mariano Martínez, Isabel Macedo, Eleonora Wexler, Federico Amador, Michel Noher, Manuela Pal, Delfina Chaves, Franco Masini, Camila Mateos, Manuel Ramos, and Virginia Lago in the main roles.

Verano del '98 (Endless Summer) is an Argentine soap opera created by Cris Morena. It aired on Telefe television from January 12, 1998, to November 17, 2000. The show had three seasons and featured multiple cast changes. Additionally, Cris Morena contributed songs to the soundtrack of Verano del '98.

Alma Pirata is an Argentine soap opera from 2006, made by Cris Morena. It stars Benjamín Rojas, Fabián Mazzei, Luisana Lopilato, Mariano Martinez, Nicolás Vázquez, Isabel Macedo, Elsa Pinilla, and Julia Calvo.

Niní was a popular Argentine children's TV series that aired on Telefe starting in 2009. It starred Florencia Bertotti and Federico Amador, and was created by Gabriela Fiore and Jorge Chernov. Florencia Bertotti, along with her former husband Guido Kaczka, who was a TV host, produced the show in collaboration with Endemol. The main antagonists were played by Maida Andrenacci and Paula Morales. The show debuted with a high rating of 19.1 points, according to Argentina's TV popularity rating system (IBOPE), surpassing its competition by 13 points. Throughout its airing, Niní consistently maintained high ratings, becoming one of Telefe's most popular afternoon shows. However, its momentum gradually declined after the first two weeks, resulting in an average rating of 10 points by the end of its run.

Lali Espósito, an Argentine singer and actress, started her music journey in 2003 by lending her vocals to the soundtrack album for the Argentine telenovela, Rincón de Luz. From 2007 to 2012, she was part of the pop group Teen Angels, which spun off from the TV series Casi Ángeles, where she also acted from 2007 to 2010. In 2013, Espósito ventured into her solo career while still working with Teen Angels. That year, she released four songs for the Argentine telenovela Solamente Vos, in which she starred, and also dropped her debut single "A Bailar."

Botineras (WAGs: Love for the Game) is an Argentine soap opera created by Endemol and Underground. It aired on Telefe from November 24, 2009, to August 25, 2010. The storyline focuses on the romantic lives of football players and also involves various police investigations. Initially a comedy, the show later transitioned into a police drama. The original leads were Florencia Peña and Nicolás Cabré, portraying Giselle López and Cristian Chiqui Flores. Peña left the show due to her character losing significance after the genre change and her overall dissatisfaction with it. Consequently, characters played by Romina Gaetani and Isabel Macedo gained more prominence.

question: What was position of the man who served Prince Andrew from 1990-2001?
pos: Prince Andrew, also known as the Duke of York, was born on February 19, 1960. He is the second son and third child of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh. When he was born, he was second in line to the British throne, but as of 2017, he is now sixth in line.
Captain Robert Neil Blair CVO RN served as Private Secretary and Treasurer to The Duke of York from 1990 to 2001.
neg: Joe Gilmore, born in Belfast on May 19, 1922, and passing away on December 18, 2015, held the prestigious role of Head Barman at The Savoy Hotel's American Bar for many years. He began his career as a trainee barman there in 1940, eventually becoming the Head Barman in 1955 until his retirement in 1976. During his tenure, Gilmore created numerous cocktails to celebrate special occasions and notable guests, a tradition at the American Bar. Among those honored with custom cocktails were members of royalty, politicians, and celebrities such as The Prince of Wales, Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother, and American Presidents Harry S. Truman and Richard Nixon. He also crafted cocktails to mark historic events like the moon landing in 1969 and the American-Russian space link-up in 1975.

Sarah Ferguson wore a fancy dress made of ivory satin with lots of beadwork for her wedding to Prince Andrew, Duke of York, on July 23, 1986, at Westminster Abbey. The dress, designed by Lindka Cierach, had beads with symbols like hearts for romance, anchors and waves for Prince Andrew's sailing hobby, and bumblebees and thistles from Sarah Ferguson's family crest. Copies of the dress, with all these special symbols, were sold in stores right after the wedding. Inspired by Princess Diana's wedding dress, Sarah's dress had a 17-foot-long train with their initials, A and S, sewn in silver beads. The headpiece and bouquet were adorned with fabric rosettes or silk flowers to match the gown. Sarah Ferguson loved the dress, saying in her memoir that she had to lose weight to fit into it. She praised Lindka's skill in making such a flattering gown, which felt like a corset because it was so well-structured. Hairstylist Denise McAdam and makeup artist Teresa Fairminer took care of Sarah's look, while florist Jane Packer designed the bouquet. This ivory silk wedding dress became the most popular style of the season.

Krajmir, a Serbian nobleman under Prince Lazar's rule from 1373 to 1389, held the title of vojvoda, or general. He's remembered in Konstantin Mihailović's memoirs for his role in the Battle of Kosovo in 1389, where he, along with Lazar, was captured and killed by the Ottomans in front of Bayezid. He hailed from Toplica and might be associated with Krajko, the son of magnate Jovan Oliver, or possibly identified with Milan Toplica from folklore.

The Royal Marriages Act 1772 was a law in Great Britain that set rules for who in the British Royal Family could marry to prevent marriages that might lower the royal family's status. This law gave the king or queen the power to say no to a royal marriage, which upset a lot of people when it was first made. It was canceled on March 26, 2015, because of an agreement made in 2011. Now, there are still rules about who the first six people in line to the throne can marry.

In the 21st century, Canadian royal tours continue a tradition that spans over 300 years. These tours can serve different purposes, such as official visits, working trips, vacations, or periods of military service for a member of the Royal Family. Originally, these tours were mainly for Canadians to see and possibly meet their royal family members, accompanied by patriotic ceremonies. However, in the late 20th century, they took on additional themes. For example, Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip's 2005 tour of Saskatchewan and Alberta aimed to honor "The Spirit of Nation Builders." Junior members of the Royal Family also started undertaking unofficial working tours in Canada. During these visits, they are invited by provinces, municipalities, and organizations, with funding provided independently, without federal assistance. Prince Charles, Princess Anne, Prince Andrew, Prince Edward, and Sophie, Countess of Wessex, have all made several of these smaller tours.

John Hartmann, born in Auleben on October 24, 1830, and passed away in Liverpool, England in 1897, was a famous brass composer from Prussia. He gained recognition for his role as the bandmaster for Prince George, Duke of Cambridge, in the British 4th Regiment, 12th Lancers.

Armand Douglas Hammer, born on August 28, 1986, is an American actor known for several roles. You might recognize him as one of the Winklevoss twins in "The Social Network" (2010), Prince Andrew Alcott in "Mirror Mirror" (2012), the main character in "The Lone Ranger" (2013), and as the voice of Jackson Storm in "Cars 3" (2017). He also played Illya Kuryakin in "The Man from U.N.C.L.E." (2015) and starred as Oliver in "Call Me by Your Name" (2017). Additionally, his portrayal of Clyde Tolson in "J. Edgar" (2011) earned him a nomination for a Screen Actors Guild Award.

Princess Henriëtte van Nassau-Weilburg, born in 1780 and passed away in 1857, was the daughter of Prince Charles Christian, Duke of Nassau-Weilburg, and Carolina of Orange-Nassau, who was the daughter of William IV, Prince of Orange. Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom is her descendant through Henriette's grandson Francis, Duke of Teck. Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, is her descendant through her granddaughter Princess Alexandra of Saxe-Altenburg, who is the grandmother of Prince Andrew of Greece and Denmark. Juan Carlos I of Spain is a descendant of Henriette through her granddaughter Archduchess Elisabeth Franziska of Austria, who was the grandmother of Alfonso XIII of Spain.

question: Are Agee and To Shoot an Elephant both documentaries about war?
pos: "Agee" is a documentary film made in 1980 by director Ross Spears. It explores the life of writer James Agee and was considered for an Academy Award in the Best Documentary Feature category.
"To Shoot an Elephant" is a documentary made in 2009 about the Gaza War that happened from 2008 to 2009. It was directed by Alberto Arce and Mohammad Rujailahk.
neg: The North African elephant, also known as the Carthaginian elephant, was a type of elephant that lived in North Africa above the Sahara desert. It was closely related to the African bush elephant, or it might have been its own separate species. These elephants were famous for being used in wars by Carthage against the Roman Republic. Even though scientists have described this elephant as a subspecies, many haven't accepted it as such. They were also called the North African forest elephant and Atlas elephant. Originally, they likely lived across North Africa, extending down to what is now Sudan and Eritrea.

"Khan Kluay" is a Thai animated film from 2006 set in ancient Siam. It follows the story of a young elephant who gets separated from his mother and eventually becomes a war elephant for King Naresuan. The movie is based on a book called "Chao Praya Prab Hongsawadee" by Ariya Jintapanichkarn. In India, it was called "Jumbo," and in the US, it was titled "The Blue Elephant." There's also a sequel called "Khan Kluay 2," which continues the story of Khan Kluay's offspring facing another threat from the Burmese while struggling with personal conflicts.

Marcel Trillat, born on April 4, 1940, is a French journalist and documentary filmmaker. He's known for his work shedding light on the living conditions of workers, women, and immigrants in France, as well as documenting the French government's actions during events like the Algerian War and the Gulf War. More recently, he's explored topics such as religious cults and public hospitals. Collaborating with Maurice Failevic, he co-directed three documentaries, including one on the history of communism in France. Trillat also served as a director at France Télévisions, the country's public television broadcaster, for five years.

James Howard Williams, nicknamed Elephant Bill, was a British soldier and elephant specialist in Burma. He gained fame for his efforts with the Fourteenth Army during World War II's Burma Campaign. His 1950 book, "Elephant Bill," further highlighted his experiences. Williams achieved the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel, received recognition in dispatches three times, and was honored with the OBE in 1945.

Surus, known as the Syrian elephant, was likely the final war elephant in Hannibal Barca's army during his time in Italy. Various Roman writers described Surus, suggesting it was probably a large Asian elephant with one tusk. Despite a Carthaginian coin from Hannibal's era showing an African elephant, historians think Surus was actually an Indian elephant, possibly descended from those captured by the Ptolemies of Egypt, who were successors to Alexander the Great, during their campaigns in Syria. According to some stories, Surus was the last survivor of the 37 war elephants that Hannibal brought along during his famous crossing of the Alps in 218 B.C. amidst the Second Punic War.

"Hannibal Brooks," a 1969 British war comedy film, directed by Michael Winner and written by Ian La Frenais and Dick Clement, tells the story of a prisoner of war attempting to escape from Nazi Germany to Switzerland during World War II, with the help of an Asian elephant. The movie stars Oliver Reed, Michael J. Pollard, and Wolfgang Preiss. The story is inspired by the real-life experiences of writer Tom Wright, who cared for an elephant named Lucy while working at Munich Zoo as a prisoner of war. It is also linked to the true story of Olga, an elephant rescued from Vienna Zoo in 1944. The title pays homage to Hannibal, the Carthaginian military commander who famously led an army, including war elephants, over the Alps.

Carlos Rendón Zipagauta, born on September 29, 1955, in Cali, is a Colombian-Belgian documentary filmmaker. He learned about filmmaking and screenwriting while living in Belgium for 16 years. Starting as an assistant, he later became a co-director with Jean Christophe Lamy. Afterward, he went back to Colombia to create documentaries. One of his notable works is the 1993 film "Nukak Makú," which focuses on the indigenous Nukak peoples. This film received awards at festivals in France and Belgium, which also helped him secure grants from the EU for making more documentaries.

Elephant Pass railway station is located in northern Sri Lanka. It's owned by Sri Lanka Railways and is part of the Northern Line connecting the north to Colombo. The station was closed from 1990 to 2014 because of the civil war but reopened on March 4, 2014.

question: What shallow water table aquifer is located near the county seat of Keith County, Nebraska?
pos: The Ogallala Aquifer is a big underground water source found beneath the Great Plains in the United States. It's made up of sand, silt, clay, and gravel and sits fairly close to the surface. Covering about 174,000 square miles across parts of eight states, it's one of the largest aquifers globally. Geologist N.H. Darton gave it its name in 1898 after finding it near Ogallala, Nebraska. This aquifer is a crucial part of the High Plains Aquifer System and lies on top of the Ogallala Formation, which is the main geological layer supporting much of the High Plains area.

Ogallala is a town in Keith County, Nebraska, USA. It has around 4,737 people as of the 2010 census and serves as the county's main administrative center. Back when Nebraska was just a territory, Ogallala was a Pony Express stop and later became a significant spot along the transcontinental railroad. The Ogallala Aquifer got its name from this town.
neg: Keystone is a small area in central Keith County, Nebraska, USA. It's situated close to the North Platte River, northeast of Ogallala, which is the main city in Keith County. Keystone is at an elevation of 3,100 feet (945 m). Even though it's not officially incorporated, there's a post office there with the ZIP code 69144.

Souris Beach Provincial Park is a park you can visit for the day, found near Souris town in eastern Prince Edward Island, Canada. The beach there is special because it's shallow, letting you walk quite far from the shore on sandy ground. This shallowness also makes the water warmer than in other Island beaches where it gets deep faster, because the sun heats it up more.

Dune Dam is a long sand dune found at the western tip of Chaco Canyon, New Mexico, close to where the Chaco and Escavada Washs meet. It formed when winds carried sand from the Chaco River, gradually building up the dune until it blocked the Chaco Wash, creating a small, shallow lake near the Ancestral Puebloan great house, Penasco Blanco. Around 900 CE, evidence suggests the dune broke, but the Chacoans repaired it with masonry in the early 11th century, creating a stone-lined reservoir that was visible until 1920. This dam helped maintain the water table in the canyon, supporting Chacoan agriculture. However, geologist Stephen A. Hall questioned this interpretation due to the absence of a lakebed behind the dam.

Kingsley Dam stands on the eastern side of Lake McConaughy in central Keith County, Nebraska. It's the world's second largest hydraulic fill dam, built as part of the New Deal project. The dam is massive, stretching 3.1 miles long, 162 feet tall, and 1100 feet wide at its base. Lake Ogallala sits to the east of the dam, while the Kingsley Hydroelectricity Plant is to the south. In this area, you'll also find the Nebraska Game and Parks Commission and Central Nebraska Public Power and Irrigation District. Kingsley Dam, the Kingsley Hydroelectricity Plant, the Morning Glory Spillway, and the Outlet Tower (a structure for releasing water from the lake) are the main landmarks around Lake McConaughy.

Lemoyne is a small town in northern Keith County, Nebraska, USA. It's located along Nebraska Highway 92, next to Lake C.W. McConaughy, and north of Ogallala, the county's main city. Lemoyne sits at an elevation of 3,333 feet (1,016 meters). Even though it's not formally incorporated, it still has a post office with the ZIP code 69146.
Keith County is a part of Nebraska in the United States. According to the 2010 census, it had a population of 8,368 people. Ogallala is its county seat.

Flatwood is a type of soil found in the southeastern United States. It has poor drainage and is formed from marine sediments. The soil formation is influenced by a shallow water table, which is usually only a few feet deep and changes throughout the year. In the USDA soil taxonomy, Flatwood soils are classified as fine, mixed, semiactive, mesic Aquic Hapludults.

Ingram–Schipper Farm, situated near Boonsboro in Washington County, Maryland, USA, is an old farmstead with significant historical value. The main house is a two-story brick building with white accents and a slate roof, showcasing Victorian architecture with a flat-roofed porch. Surrounding the house are several original structures, like a brick kitchen and wash house, three log buildings (one of which may have been a residence with a fireplace), and a sizable stone barn.

question: Who was born first Mahbub ul Haq or Ibn Arabi?
pos: Abū ʿAbd Allāh Muḥammad ibn ʿAlī ibn Muḥammad ibnʿArabī al-Ḥātimī aṭ-Ṭāʾī (Arabic: أبو عبد الله محمد بن علي بن محمد بن عربي الحاتمي الطائي‎) (26 July 1165 – 16 November 1240), known as Shaykh Al-Akbar, was an Arab Andalusian Sunni scholar of Islam. He was a Sufi mystic, poet, and philosopher, renowned among Sufis as the greatest master and a genuine saint.

Mahbub ul Haq, born on February 24, 1934, and passed away on July 16, 1998, was a Pakistani economist known for his work in game theory and international development. He also held the position of Finance Minister of Pakistan from April 10, 1985, to January 28, 1988.
neg: Idrees Ul Haq, also known as Mirza Mohammad Idrees ul Haq Beigh, is a Kashmiri innovator and activist. He gained recognition for his innovative ideas and social initiatives. In 2005, he received an honor from the Governor of Jammu and Kashmir for his contributions to society. However, he later gave up this award in 2011 to protest the Ramban firing incident. He made history as the first young person from Jammu and Kashmir to participate in Israel's Technology Transfer program.

Inge Kaul is a professor at the Hertie School of Governance in Berlin, Germany. She advises governments, international organizations, and nonprofits on ways to address global issues. Her expertise lies in global public goods, focusing on topics like financing international cooperation, partnerships between public and private sectors, global governance, diplomacy on global issues, and reforming the UN system. Previously, she directed the UNDP's Human Development Report Office and later its Office of Development Studies. She has authored many publications on global economics and finance and has edited books on managing globalization and responding to global challenges.

Akbariyya is a type of Sufi philosophy that comes from the teachings of Ibn Arabi, an Andalusian Sufi scholar. Ibn Arabi was nicknamed Shaykh al-Akbar, meaning the greatest shaykh. Unlike a specific Sufi group, Al Akbariyya refers to all the thinkers and Sufis who follow Ibn Arabi's teachings about Wahdat al-Wujud, a concept in Sufi doctrine. It's important to note that this is different from another group called Al Akbariyya, which was a secret Sufi society founded by a Swedish Sufi named 'Abdu l-Hadi Aguéli.

The Journal of Human Development and Capabilities is an academic journal reviewed by experts. It focuses on human development and capabilities from a people-centered perspective. Routledge publishes it for the Human Development and Capability Association. It started in 2000 as the Journal of Human Development and changed its name to the current one in 2009. The initial editors-in-chief were Khadija Haq, Richard Jolly, and Sakiko Fukuda-Parr.

The Human Development Index (HDI) is a measure that combines life expectancy, education, and income to rank countries into different levels of development. A higher HDI score indicates longer life expectancy, better education, and higher income per person. It was created by economists Amartya Sen and Mahbub ul Haq and is used by the United Nations Development Programme to assess whether people can achieve desirable outcomes in their lives.

Chak 86/6-R, also known as Rasool Abad, is located in Sahiwal, Punjab, Pakistan. It's one of the largest villages in the area, initially planned during British rule before 1900. Over time, it has transformed into an urban area with various amenities. Notably, it's renowned for housing Asia's largest Wood Market called Lakkar Mandi and for being associated with the religious figure Baba Mast. Doctor Fazal Din Sehgal, a prominent figure, owned significant portions of the village. Initially managed by Maher Khar din in the 1930s, who encouraged families to settle there, the village expanded, with land divided into blocks for agriculture. Maher Amir U Din further developed the area from 1958 onwards. Today, it comprises several sub-areas such as the main village 86, Shad-man Town, Baba Must Colony, and Bashir Colony. It gained status as a union council during General Pervez Musharraf's tenure, with Mehar Riaz Ul Haq serving as its first elected Nazim, eventually becoming the only person in Pakistan's history to be elected Nazim thrice.

Maulana Sami ul Haq, born on December 18, 1937, is a Pakistani religious scholar, politician, and influential figure known as the "Father of the Taliban." He has close connections to Taliban leader Mullah Mohammed Omar and currently holds the position of chancellor at Darul Uloom Haqqania, a Deobandi Islamic seminary. This institution has educated many key Taliban figures. Additionally, Haq chairs the Difa-e-Pakistan Council and leads his own faction of the Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam political party, called JUI-S. He is also a founding member of Muttahida Majlis-e-Amal.

Sir Fazle Hasan Abed, born on April 27, 1936, is a Bangladeshi social worker. He founded and chairs BRAC, the world's largest non-governmental organization, employing over 120,000 people. He has been honored with several awards for his significant contributions to social improvement, including the Ramon Magsaysay Award, the UNDP Mahbub Ul Haq Award, the Clinton Global Citizen Award, and the WISE Prize for Education. In 2015, he was awarded the World Food Prize for his exceptional efforts in reducing poverty in Bangladesh and ten other countries.

question: What does the goddess associated with the goddess frigg  consists of what tales?
pos: In Norse mythology, Hlín is a goddess linked to Frigg, another goddess. She's mentioned in old poems and writings like the Poetic Edda and the Prose Edda, which were compiled in the 13th century. Some scholars think Hlín might actually be another name for Frigg.

Norse mythology is the stories and beliefs of the ancient North Germanic people. It started with their pagan religion and continued even after Christianity spread in Scandinavia. These myths include stories about gods, creatures, and brave heroes. They come from different sources, like old writings, archaeological findings, and stories passed down through generations.
neg: The Frigg gas field is a natural gas field located in the North Sea, right on the border between the United Kingdom and Norway. It's named after the goddess Frigg. Production started on May 8, 1978, with King Olav V of Norway officially opening it. However, production ceased on October 26, 2004. The field is about 230 km northwest of Stavanger. It was operated by the French oil company Elf Aquitaine, which later merged and became Total S.A.

In Norse mythology, Eir, which means "help" or "mercy" in Old Norse, is a goddess or valkyrie known for her medical skills. She is mentioned in several ancient sources, including the Poetic Edda, the Prose Edda by Snorri Sturluson, and in skaldic poetry. Scholars have debated whether these sources describe the same figure and whether Eir was originally a goddess of healing or a valkyrie. Some suggest she may be connected to the goddess Frigg and compare her to the Greek goddess Hygieia.

In Norse mythology, Sága is a goddess linked to wisdom and associated with a place called Sökkvabekkr, which could mean "sunken bank" or "treasure bank." In stories, Sága and Odin enjoy drinking together at Sökkvabekkr while waves flow around them. These details come from ancient texts like the Poetic Edda and the Prose Edda. Scholars have suggested different ideas about what Sága and her place might symbolize, like connections to other goddesses and locations in Norse mythology. Some even think Sága could be another name for the goddess Frigg.

In Norse mythology, Nanna, also known as Nanna Nepsdóttir, is linked with the god Baldr. Different stories describe Nanna differently. According to the Prose Edda by Snorri Sturluson from the 13th century, Nanna is Baldr's wife, and they have a son named Forseti. When Baldr dies, Nanna is so upset that she dies too. They are placed together on Baldr's ship, which is set on fire and sent out to sea. In the realm of Hel, Baldr and Nanna are reunited. In another tale, when the god Hermóðr tries to bring Baldr back to life, Nanna gives him gifts to deliver to other gods, like Frigg and Fulla. Skaldic poetry often mentions Nanna, and she's also briefly mentioned in the Poetic Edda.

In Norse mythology, Gná is a goddess who runs errands for Frigg, riding a flying horse named Hófvarpnir, which means "hoof-thrower." This story is found in the Prose Edda written by Snorri Sturluson in the 13th century. Scholars suggest Gná might represent abundance and could be connected to Fama from Roman mythology. Hófvarpnir and Sleipnir, an eight-legged horse, are both seen as extraordinary horses in Norse mythology.

In Norse mythology, Fensalir, also known as Fen Halls, is where the goddess Frigg lives. This place is mentioned in ancient texts like the Poetic Edda and the Prose Edda. Scholars think it might have something to do with Norse religious rituals linked to springs, bogs, or swamps. Some even suggest a connection to another watery place called Sökkvabekkr, associated with the goddess Sága.

Marzanna, also known as Марена, Morė, Morana, Morena, or Mara, among others, is a Baltic and Slavic goddess linked to seasonal rituals centered around the cycle of death and renewal in nature. She's an ancient deity associated with the transition from winter to spring and the realm of dreams. In Slavic traditions, the demise of Marzanna marks the onset of spring, symbolizing the rebirth embodied by goddesses like Kostroma, Lada, and Vesna.

In Germanic mythology, there's a goddess named Fulla or Volla. Fulla, mentioned in Norse mythology, wears a golden band and takes care of Frigg's belongings, like a box and shoes. Frigg also trusts Fulla with her secrets. Fulla appears in various old texts like the Poetic Edda and the Prose Edda. Volla, mentioned in the Horse Cure Merseburg Incantation, helps heal a wounded foal and is said to be Frigg's sister. Scholars have different ideas about what this goddess represents.

question: What competition held in Kathmandu, Nepal did Julian Bolling compete in 1984?
pos: The first South Asian Games, also known as the 1984 South Asian Games or 1st SAF Games, took place in Kathmandu, Nepal, from September 17 to 23, 1984.

Julian Bolling, born on June 19, 1966, is a successful swimmer from Sri Lanka. He's earned 15 gold medals for his country at the South Asian Games from 1984 to 1991 and competed in three Olympic games: Los Angeles 1984, Seoul 1988, and Barcelona 1992. His parents are Tara Bolling, and he's the cousin of Dipika Chanmugam, who also represented Sri Lanka internationally. Bolling's standout performance was at the Colombo South Asian Games, where he secured six gold medals. However, his record was surpassed in 2016 by Mathew Abeysinghe, who won seven golds in India.
neg: The Mr Nepal competition, sponsored by Expose Nepal, is a male beauty pageant established in 2002. Contestants engage in activities like swimming, mountain climbing, and marathon running. Sandeep Pokharel from Morang is the reigning Mr Nepal since April 5, 2015, when he was crowned in Kathmandu. Typically, the titleholder resides in Kathmandu during their reign.

The 16th Miss Nepal pageant, called "Hidden Treasures Miss Nepal 2010," took place on September 1, 2010, at the Tribhuvan Army Club in Kathmandu. Eighteen women aged 19 and older competed in the final. Zenisha Moktan, the winner of Miss Nepal 2009, crowned Sadichha Shrestha as her successor during the event. Sadichha Shrestha went on to represent Nepal at Miss World 2010, while the first runner-up, Sahana Bajracharya, represented Nepal at Miss Earth 2010, and the second runner-up, Sanyukta Timsina, represented Nepal at Miss International 2010.

The 20th annual Miss Nepal beauty pageant, called Hidden Treasures Fanta Miss Nepal 2015, took place on April 18 at Hotel Annapurna in Kathmandu. Evana Manandhar won the title of Miss Nepal World 2015, succeeding Subin Limbu, the 2014 winner. Dibyata Vaidya became the first runner-up and represented Nepal at Miss Earth 2015, while Medha Koirala became the second runner-up and went on to compete at Miss International 2015.

In 2014, the 19th Miss Nepal beauty pageant, called Hidden Treasures Fanta Miss Nepal 2014, took place on May 2nd at the Nepal Academy Hall in Kathmandu. The winner, Miss Nepal World 2014, would go on to compete in Miss World 2014. The first runner-up would represent Nepal in Miss Earth 2014, and the second runner-up would participate in Miss International 2014. Ishani Shrestha, Miss Nepal 2013, crowned the new winner.

The 2015 Nepal Premier League, also called the Everest Premier League, was meant to be the league's second edition. Originally planned for March 26 to April 4, 2015, in Kathmandu, it faced opposition from the Cricket Association of Nepal due to its name. However, the association eventually backed the league, which was renamed the Everest Premier League. It was rescheduled to take place from September 24 to October 3, 2016.

In 2013, the Fanta Miss Nepal 2013 beauty pageant took place on March 20th at the Nepal Academy Hall in Kathmandu. Ishani Shrestha was crowned Miss Nepal World 2013, representing Nepal at Miss World 2013. Rojisha Shahi became Miss Nepal Earth 2013 and competed in Miss Earth 2013, while Shritima Shah was crowned Miss Nepal International 2013 and went on to compete in Miss International 2013.

In 2012, the 18th Miss Nepal beauty pageant, named Hidden Treasures Miss Nepal 2012, took place on May 6 at the Hotel Del Annapurna in Kathmandu. Malina Joshi, Miss Nepal 2011, crowned Shristi Shrestha as Miss Nepal World 2012. Shristi represented Nepal at Miss World 2012. Nagma Shrestha and Subekshya Khadka were crowned as Miss Nepal Earth 2012 and Miss Nepal International 2012 respectively. They participated in Miss Earth 2012 and Miss International 2012.

Bhadrabas is a village in central Nepal, about 15 km northeast of Kathmandu. It had a population of 2,388 people and 503 houses according to the 2011 Nepal census. The village is home to Adarsh Uchha Madhayamik Vidhalaya, the oldest high school in the eastern Kathmandu Valley. The Nepal Red Cross Society operates there, providing health services through a notable health center. In 1984, the World Health Organization conducted a survey on smoking habits among the residents of Bhadrabas using a tobacco smoking questionnaire.

question: William Pery served as Captain of the Yeomen of the Guard under the lord who served in what position from 1865 to 1868?
pos: Robert Arthur Talbot Gascoyne-Cecil, known as the 3rd Marquess of Salisbury, was a British Conservative statesman who served as prime minister three times, totaling over 13 years in office. Before becoming the Marquess, he was titled Lord Robert Cecil and Viscount Cranborne. Notably, he was the final prime minister to lead entirely from the House of Lords.

William Hale John Charles Pery, the 3rd Earl of Limerick, was an Irish nobleman and Conservative politician. He held various titles and positions, including Captain of the Yeomen of the Guard under Lord Salisbury from 1889 to 1892, and again from 1895 until his death in 1896. He was also appointed a Knight of the Order of St Patrick in 1892.
neg: The Queen's Body Guard of the Yeomen of the Guard is a group that protects the British Monarch. It's actually the oldest British military group, dating back to 1485. They still wear uniforms from the Tudor period, which are red and gold. There are 60 Yeomen plus six officers, who used to be from the Army, Marines, and Air Force, but now can also be from the Navy. In 2011, the ban on Navy personnel joining was lifted, and two sailors joined. The Captain of the Yeomen is always a political appointee, specifically the government Deputy Chief Whip in the House of Lords.

George Percy, who later became the 5th Duke of Northumberland, was born on June 22, 1778, and passed away on August 22, 1867. He was also known as Lord Lovaine from 1790 to 1830 and as The Earl of Beverley from 1830 to 1865. A member of the British Tory party, he held the position of Captain of the Yeomen of the Guard during Sir Robert Peel's term as Prime Minister from 1842 to 1846. He inherited the title of Duke of Northumberland on February 12, 1865, following the death of Algernon Percy, the 4th Duke of Northumberland, who had no children with his wife, Eleanor Percy, Duchess of Northumberland.

Henry Charles Cadogan, the 4th Earl Cadogan, was a British diplomat and Conservative politician. He held the title of Viscount Chelsea from 1820 to 1864. Additionally, he served as Captain of the Yeomen of the Guard from 1866 to 1868.

Henry Stephen Fox-Strangways, the 3rd Earl of Ilchester, was a British politician who belonged to the Whig party. He held the position of Captain of the Yeomen of the Guard during Lord Melbourne's tenure from 1835 to 1841.

William John Monson, 1st Viscount Oxenbridge PC, was a British Liberal politician. He was also known as The Lord Monson. He held the position of Captain of the Yeomen of the Guard from 1880 to 1885, and again in 1886 under William Ewart Gladstone.
