Baron Berkeley of Stratton was a title in England's nobility, given in 1658 to John Berkeley, who supported the Royalists during the English Civil War. He came from the Bruton branch of the Berkeley family and was descended from Sir Maurice de Berkeley in the 14th century. John's brother was Charles Berkeley, 2nd Viscount Fitzhardinge, and his nephew was Charles Berkeley, 1st Earl of Falmouth. The third Baron, John's second son, was a Royal Navy Admiral. When he died without children, his younger brother, the fourth Baron, took over. He was a politician and served as First Lord of Trade. When he passed away, the title went to his eldest son, the fifth Baron, who also held political positions. Unfortunately, he didn't have any children, and the title ended when he died in 1775.

The Earl of Aylesford is a British title that was established in 1714. It was given to a lawyer and politician named Heneage Finch, who was already a Baron in England. He was the son of another Earl and a descendant of an earlier countess. The second Earl, who was the eldest son, represented areas like Maidstone and Surrey in Parliament. He married Mary Fisher, and their family gained Packington Hall in Warwickshire through this marriage. The third Earl also served in Parliament. The fourth Earl held positions in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords, including roles like Captain of the Yeomen of the Guard and Lord Steward of the Household.

William Street is a major road in central Limerick City, Ireland, beginning at a junction with O'Connell Street and running southeast. It's named after William Pery, 1st Baron Glentworth, who was related to Edmund Sexton Pery, known for developing the present-day Newtown Pery area of Limerick City Center.

question: William Cammisano was part of which Mafia family?
pos: William "Willie" Rat Dominick Cammisano Sr. (April 26, 1914 – January 26, 1995) was a member of the Kansas City, Missouri mafia and worked as an enforcer for Nicholas Civella's crime syndicate in Kansas City.
The Kansas City Crime Family, also called the Civella crime family, is a Mafia group located in Kansas City, Missouri.
neg: Calcedonio Di Pisa, also called Doruccio, was a Sicilian Mafia member born on October 11, 1931, in Palermo, and died on December 26, 1962, in the same city. He was the leader of the Mafia group in the Noce area of Palermo and was part of the initial Sicilian Mafia Commission, which was the main organizing body of Cosa Nostra in Sicily.

Antonino "Nino" Rotolo, born on January 3, 1946, is an Italian Mafia boss from the Pagliarelli area in Palermo. This area was historically controlled by the Motisi Mafia family. Rotolo served as the underboss of Matteo Motisi, but some informants claim he was essentially the top leader representing the area on the Sicilian Mafia Commission. By 2006, police identified Rotolo as a significant figure in Cosa Nostra's hierarchy, ranking as number 25 in the Mafia boss Bernardo Provenzano's coded list.

Rosario Naimo, also known as Saro or Saruzzo, was born on August 18, 1945, in Palermo. He's part of the Sicilian Mafia and is recognized as a key connection between the Sicilian and American Mafia, especially with the Gambino crime family. He hails from the Tommaso Natale-Cardillo Mafia clan, which later merged into the San Lorenzo family, and is considered a man of honor within these circles.

Antonio Cottone, sometimes called U Patre Nostru (Our Heavenly Father), was part of the Sicilian Mafia in Villabate, Sicily. He was known for being generous. The Cottone family was a well-known Mafia group in the area, as mentioned by Melchiorre Allegra, a former Mafia member turned informant, in 1937.

Salvatore La Barbera, born in Palermo on April 20, 1922, and passing away on January 17, 1963, was a Sicilian mobster. He, alongside his brother Angelo La Barbera, was in charge of the Mafia family based in Palermo Centro. Salvatore La Barbera held a prominent position on the inaugural Sicilian Mafia Commission formed in 1958, overseeing Mafia operations in Borgo Vecchio, Porta Nuova, and Palermo Centro. He vanished during the First Mafia War, presumably abducted and murdered, his whereabouts remaining unknown thereafter.

The Greco Mafia family has been a significant force in Sicily and Calabria since the late 19th century. They controlled territories in Ciaculli and Croceverde Giardini near Palermo, as well as rural areas in Calabria, dominating the citrus and olive oil markets, respectively. Members of the family held key positions in both the Sicilian Cosa Nostra and the Calabrian 'Ndrangheta. Salvatore Ciaschiteddu Greco was the first leader of the Sicilian Mafia Commission, succeeded by Michele Greco, also known as "The Pope."

Angelo La Barbera, born on July 3, 1924, and his brother Salvatore La Barbera, born on April 20, 1922, were influential figures in the Sicilian Mafia. They jointly controlled the Mafia family based in Palermo Centro. Salvatore La Barbera served as a leader in the first Sicilian Mafia Commission established in 1958, overseeing Mafia groups in Borgo Vecchio, Porta Nuova, and Palermo Centro.

Gaspare Spatuzza, born on April 8, 1964, in Palermo, Sicily, was involved with the Mafia in the Brancaccio area of the city. He worked as a hitman for the Graviano brothers, who led the Mafia family in Brancaccio. When the Graviano brothers were arrested in January 1994, Spatuzza took over leadership of the Mafia family. He was later arrested in 1997 and began cooperating with the authorities in 2008. During his testimony, he alleged that media mogul and former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi struck a deal with the Sicilian Mafia in 1993, effectively giving the Mafia significant influence over the country.

question: 1956 Night Series Cup games were played at what inner suburb of Melbourne that is 3km south of Melbourne's central business district?
pos: Albert Park is a neighborhood in Melbourne, Australia, located 3 km south of the city's downtown area. It's governed by the City of Port Phillip. In 2011, the population of Albert Park was 5,955 according to the census.

In 1956, the Victorian Football League introduced the VFL Night Premiership Cup, a tournament held in August and September after the regular season. It was the league's first night series, featuring a knockout format with eight teams that didn't qualify for the final four. Games took place at the Lake Oval in Albert Park, South Melbourne's home ground, as it was the only one suitable for night matches. Despite not all teams participating, the average attendance for the seven matches was 20,000, with a crowd of 32,450 turning up for the Grand Final on the first night.
neg: The 1965 VFL Golden Fleece Night Premiership was a football competition held after the regular season. It involved eight teams that didn't qualify for the finals. The games were played at Lake Oval because it was the only ground with lights. It was sponsored by Golden Fleece. North Melbourne won the tournament by beating Carlton in the final.

The 1958 VFL Night Premiership Cup was a football competition held at the end of the 1958 VFL Premiership Season. It was the third year of the event. Unlike the previous year, where both day finalists were defeated upon entering, causing a complex fixture, this year returned to the original format used in 1956. The tournament was a knockout style, involving the eight VFL teams that didn't qualify for the finals. All games took place at the Lake Oval, Albert Park, which was the only ground suitable for night matches at the time. St Kilda won the cup by defeating Carlton in the final by 8 points.

In September of the 1966 VFL Premiership Season, the VFL Golden Fleece Night Premiership took place. It was a cup competition at the end of the season, where eight VFL teams that didn't make it to the finals competed. The games were played at the Lake Oval in Albert Park, the only ground with night game facilities at the time. North Melbourne won the tournament by defeating Hawthorn in the final with a 53-point lead, securing their second consecutive night series cup.

In 1967, the VFL Golden Fleece Night Premiership was a football tournament held in August and September. It involved eight VFL teams that didn't qualify for the finals. The games were played at the Lake Oval, Albert Park, South Melbourne's home ground, as it was the only venue with night game facilities. Footscray won the tournament by defeating South Melbourne in the final by 45 points, securing their third night series cup win.

The 1961 VFL Night Premiership Cup was a competition held at the end of the Victorian Football League season, specifically in August and September. It was part of the VFL Night Series, which was in its sixth season. The tournament involved eight VFL teams that hadn't made it to the finals. Games took place at the Lake Oval, Albert Park, South Melbourne's home ground, as it was the only venue with night game facilities. Geelong won the cup for the first time by defeating North Melbourne in the final, with a margin of 12 points.

In 1957, the Victorian Football League (VFL) held its Night Premiership Cup tournament, which took place from August to October as part of the VFL Premiership Season. It was the second year of this tournament, featuring all twelve VFL teams in a knockout format across four rounds. Matches were held at the Lake Oval in Albert Park, South Melbourne's home ground, which was the only venue equipped for night games at the time. South Melbourne emerged as the champions, securing their second consecutive night series cup by defeating Geelong in the final with a 51-point lead.

In September of the 1971 VFL Premiership Season, the VFL H.J. Heinz Night Premiership took place as an end-of-season cup competition. It involved the eight VFL teams that didn't make it to the finals. Games were held at the Lake Oval, Albert Park, because it was the only ground with night game facilities. This was the last of the VFL Night Series competitions, ending due to decreased interest and the new final five format in the premiership. Melbourne won the cup, beating Fitzroy by 16 points in the final, marking their first victory in the night series.

In September of the 1960 Victorian Football League (VFL) season, the VFL Night Premiership Cup took place. It was a tournament held at night, involving eight VFL teams that didn't qualify for the finals. The games were held at the Lake Oval in Albert Park, South Melbourne's home ground, since it was the only venue with night game facilities. South Melbourne won the cup for the third time, beating Hawthorn by 13 points in the final.

question: When did the game which held three times in  in East Asia first held
pos: The Summer Olympic Games, also known as the Games of the Olympiad, started back in 1896 and happen every four years in a different city. Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, hosted the most recent Olympics. The International Olympic Committee is in charge of organizing the games and making sure the host city is ready. Winners in each event get gold for first place, silver for second, and bronze for third, a tradition that began in 1904. The Winter Olympics came about because of the Summer Olympics' popularity.

The 2008 Summer Olympics, also called Beijing 2008, were held in Beijing, China, from August 7 to August 24, 2008. Athletes from 204 countries competed in 28 sports and 302 events, making it slightly larger than the 2004 Games. This was China's first time hosting the Summer Olympics and the third time they were held in East Asia, following Tokyo in 1964 and Seoul in 1988.
neg: Memorabilia is a fan convention happening in the UK since 1994. It's for fans and collectors of movie, TV, and sports memorabilia. It happens twice a year, usually in March and November, at the NEC Birmingham. It brings in over 30,000 visitors and around 250 traders. In the past, it was held three times a year and had extra events in places like London, Manchester, and Glasgow.

The International Teen Princess contest started in Chicago, Illinois, in 1966 and ran for four years. It was then renamed the World Teen Princess in 1970 and held three times in Europe. In 1973, it split into two separate contests: one called Teen Princess, which continued twice but seems to have ended after the 1974 pageant in Venezuela, and the other called Miss Teenage Peace International in Oranjestad, Aruba. In 1974, the latter was renamed Miss Teenage Intercontinental.

The EAFF E-1 Football Championship, once called the East Asian Football Championship, is a soccer tournament for countries in East Asia that are part of the East Asian Football Federation (EAFF). It started in 2003 under the name East Asian Football Championship and later changed to EAFF East Asian Cup in 2013 and 2015. Before the EAFF was created in 2002, there was the Dynasty Cup, which was like an unofficial championship for the top four teams in East Asia. Both men and women have separate competitions, with the men's starting in 2003 and the women's in 2005. In 2005, they even had a combined points competition where they added up the results of both the men's and women's teams, excluding qualifiers.

The Australian Correspondence Chess Championship is run by the Correspondence Chess League of Australia (CCLA). It was held three times before 1937, with O Ludlow winning once and F M Hallman winning twice. After that, regular championships have been held since 1937, except for a break during World War II from 1939 to 1945.

The Fruit Bowl was a college football game that happened after the regular season in December. It took place at Kezar Stadium in San Francisco, California, and occurred three times after the 1947-1949 seasons. The first two games had college teams playing, while the last game involved club teams.

The Toronto Marathon happens every May, starting from Mel Lastman Square and ending at Ontario Place. It began in 1995 as the Canadian International Marathon and changed its name to the Toronto Marathon in 2003. GoodLife Fitness became its primary sponsor in 2008. Initially held in October, it moved to May in 2011 due to concerns about road closures from another marathon. Since 2012, it's been held on the first Sunday of May each year.

Moonpark is a popular music festival in Argentina that happens three times a year starting from 2003. Located in the Northeast part of Buenos Aires city, it's known for showcasing top-notch dance and electronic music acts, making it a significant event in the country's music scene.

The 6 Hours of Mexico is a sports car race that takes place at Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez in Mexico City. It started in 1974 during the IMSA GT Championship. In 1989, it came back as a 480 km race during the World Sportscar Championship and ran three times before the championship ended. Then, it returned in 2016 as part of the FIA World Endurance Championship.

question: Blinding Edge Pictures produced which 2000 film starring Bruce Willis?
pos: Blinding Edge Pictures is a company in the U.S. that makes movies. It started in 2000 by M. Night Shyamalan. They're famous for making movies written and directed by Shyamalan, such as Unbreakable (2000), Signs (2002), The Village (2004), The Happening (2008), After Earth (2013), The Visit (2015), and Split (2017). They also released their first TV series, Wayward Pines, in 2015.

"Unbreakable," a movie released in 2000, is an American superhero thriller film. It was written, produced, and directed by M. Night Shyamalan and stars Bruce Willis, Samuel L. Jackson, Robin Wright, and Spencer Treat Clark. The film is the first part of a trilogy. It follows the story of David Dunn, a security guard who survives a train crash. After the accident, he discovers he has superhuman abilities with the help of Elijah Price, a comic book shop owner who is disabled. As Dunn grapples with his powers and his family life, he starts fighting crime and uncovers the true identity of Elijah Price.
neg: "Last Man Standing" is a 1996 action thriller movie in the United States. It was written and directed by Walter Hill and features Bruce Willis, Christopher Walken, and Bruce Dern. The film is a recognized remake of Akira Kurosawa's "Yojimbo."

The movie "The Whole Nine Yards" came out in 2000. It's a crime comedy directed by Jonathan Lynn and features actors like Bruce Willis, Matthew Perry, Amanda Peet, Michael Clarke Duncan, and Natasha Henstridge. The title of the movie comes from a common saying, and there's a sequel called "The Whole Ten Yards," which came out in 2004.

"Striking Distance" is a 1993 action thriller featuring Bruce Willis as Detective Thomas Hardy of the Pittsburgh Police. The movie also stars Sarah Jessica Parker, Dennis Farina, and Tom Sizemore. Directed by Rowdy Herrington and written by Herrington along with Marty Kaplan, it was filmed in various spots across Pittsburgh, initially named "Three Rivers."

"Signs" is a 2002 American science fiction horror movie written and directed by M. Night Shyamalan. It was produced by Blinding Edge Pictures and The Kennedy/Marshall Company. The film follows the story of Graham Hess, a former priest played by Mel Gibson, who finds crop circles in his cornfield and later realizes they're caused by aliens. The movie also features Joaquin Phoenix, Rory Culkin, and Abigail Breslin, and delves into themes of faith, family, and encounters with extraterrestrial beings.

Mercury Rising is a 1998 American thriller movie with Bruce Willis and Alec Baldwin. It's directed by Harold Becker and based on Ryne Douglas Pearson's novel "Simple Simon." Willis stars as Art Jeffries, an FBI agent who goes undercover to safeguard a 9-year-old autistic boy. The boy unknowingly deciphers a secret government code, making him a target for government assassins.

"Lay the Favorite" is a movie from 2012 that mixes comedy and drama. It features Bruce Willis, Rebecca Hall, Catherine Zeta-Jones, and Joshua Jackson. The story, based on Beth Raymer's memoir, revolves around a carefree young woman exploring both legal and illegal sports gambling. The movie was directed by Stephen Frears.

"In Country" is a drama movie from 1989, made in the USA and directed by Norman Jewison. It features Bruce Willis and Emily Lloyd. The script was written by Frank Pierson and Cynthia Cidre, based on Bobbie Ann Mason's novel. James Horner composed the music. Willis got nominated for a Golden Globe for his supporting role.

Cop Out is a 2010 American movie directed by Kevin Smith. It's an action-comedy about two veteran NYPD partners, played by Bruce Willis and Tracy Morgan, who are chasing a stolen rare baseball card. They face off against a ruthless gangster who's obsessed with memorabilia. Unlike Smith's other films, he didn't write this one. Despite getting bad reviews and not doing well at the box office, it's Kevin Smith's most financially successful film.

question: What kind of dinosaur does Raymond Ochoa voice in the Pixar film "The Good Dinosaur"?
pos: Raymond Ochoa, born on October 12, 2001, is an American actor known for his roles in commercials, TV shows like "10 Items or Less" and "Merry Christmas, Drake & Josh," and as the voice of Arlo in Pixar's movie "The Good Dinosaur."

"The Good Dinosaur" is a movie made by Pixar Animation Studios and released by Walt Disney Pictures in 2015. Directed by Peter Sohn, it tells the story of a young Apatosaurus named Arlo who befriends a human in a world where dinosaurs never went extinct. The movie stars Raymond Ochoa, Jack Bright, Sam Elliott, Anna Paquin, A.J. Buckley, Steve Zahn, Jeffrey Wright, and Frances McDormand.
neg: Adrian Molina, born on August 23, 1985, is an American screenwriter and storyboard artist known for his work at Pixar since 2007. He began his journey as a 2D animator on Ratatouille before transitioning to storyboard artist roles for films like Toy Story 3 and Monsters University. After contributing to The Good Dinosaur, he took on his first screenplay writing job for Coco, eventually co-directing the movie. Additionally, Molina illustrated the Little Golden Book for Toy Story 3.

The Golden Globe Award for Best Animated Feature Film was first given out at the 2007 Golden Globe Awards. It marked the first time the Golden Globe Awards had a category specifically for animated films. Nominations are announced in January, with the awards ceremony held later in the month. Initially, only three films were nominated, compared to five for most other awards. The Pixar movie Cars was the inaugural winner. Since then, Pixar has won the award for six other films: Ratatouille in 2008, WALL-E in 2009, Up in 2010, Toy Story 3 in 2011, Brave in 2013, and Inside Out in 2016. However, in 2012, Cars 2 lost to The Adventures of Tintin, and in 2014, Monsters University didn't receive a nomination. Additionally, in 2016, The Good Dinosaur lost to Inside Out, and in 2017, Finding Dory wasn't nominated. The Hollywood Foreign Press Association has been giving out Golden Globe Awards since 1944.

Richard Bruce Kind, born on November 22, 1956, is an American actor recognized for his performances in TV sitcoms like Mad About You, where he played Dr. Mark Devanow, and Spin City, where he portrayed Paul Lassiter. In 2015, he voiced the character Bing Bong in the Pixar movie Inside Out. Additionally, he lends his voice to the character Harvey Timbers in the Nickelodeon animated series Welcome to the Wayne, which debuted in 2017.

Harley Jessup, born in 1954, is an American production designer and visual effects art director. He's received two Academy Award nominations for visual effects, winning once. Presently, he works at Pixar Animation Studios and has served as a production designer for various films including Monsters, Inc., Ratatouille, and Cars 2. Before joining Pixar, Jessup worked as a production designer on James and the Giant Peach for Walt Disney Pictures.

Studying dinosaur behavior is tough for paleontologists because they mainly rely on physical remains. However, they can gain insight from trace fossils and paleopathology. To understand dinosaur behavior, scientists look at the poses of fossilized bodies, their habitats, use computer simulations for biomechanics, and compare them with modern animals. This understanding is speculative and likely controversial. Yet, there's agreement that some behaviors seen in crocodiles and birds, dinosaurs' closest living relatives, were also present in dinosaurs. Many species gathered in herds for defense, migration, or to protect their young. Different types of dinosaurs formed groups of young individuals, and evidence suggests they communicated with their offspring, similar to modern birds and crocodiles. Certain features like crests and frills were likely used for displays rather than defense. Most dinosaurs moved on land, and biomechanical studies help understand their locomotion and behaviors like running speed or tail snapping.

Sanjay's Super Team is a short animated film made by Pixar Animation Studios. It was written and directed by Sanjay Patel, inspired by his own childhood. The film debuted on June 15, 2015, at the Annecy International Animated Film Festival in France. It was later shown in theaters alongside Pixar's The Good Dinosaur, starting on November 25, 2015.

Xtractaurs, created by Mattel in 2009, is a toy line that combines action figures with an online game. The toys are dinosaurs, both popular ones and lesser-known species. Players extract DNA samples from these dinosaurs and analyze them on a computer, similar to Jurassic Park. By collecting samples from multiple dinosaurs, players can create genetically engineered hybrids on their computer to battle Megavores, ancient dinosaurs with similar qualities. Each dinosaur toy has a unique ability, and combining them enhances their fighting prowess. For example, the first dinosaur, Tyrannosaurus Rex, has the ability to chomp. This encourages players to collect more samples and create stronger hybrids.

Enrico Casarosa, an Italian storyboard artist and director at Pixar, received an Academy Award nomination in 2012 for his work on the animated short film La Luna. From 2011 onwards, he served as the head of story for Bob Peterson's movie, The Good Dinosaur.

question: Which American Space Western animated series did Celebrity Home Entertainment released
pos: Celebrity Home Entertainment, also called Celebrity Video, was started by Noel C. Bloom in 1985. They focused on distributing home videos, mostly featuring lesser-known content from various countries, along with B-grade action movies and adult films. They also put out a few well-known titles like BraveStarr and Filmation's Ghostbusters.

BraveStarr is a 1980s American animated series set in space with a Western theme. It originally aired from September 1987 to February 1988. The show was created alongside a line of action figures. It was the final animated series produced by Filmation and Group W Productions before Filmation ceased operations in 1989. A spin-off series called Bravo! (originally named Quest of the Prairie People) was in production when the studio closed. Reruns of BraveStarr aired on Qubo Night Owl from 2010 to 2013 and on the Retro Television Network from 2010 to 2015.
neg: "The Fairies" is an Australian TV show featuring two fairies named Harmony and Rainbow Rhapsody (later known simply as Rhapsody). They have friends like Elf, who bakes fairycakes, Barnaby the Bizzy Buzzy Bee, and Wizzy the Wizard. The show, which includes songs and dance routines in each episode, started as a direct-to-video series in 2000 by Carlton Home Entertainment UK, then became a full-fledged TV series in 2005. Later series were released on DVD by Contender Home Entertainment in 2007, and merchandise was available in Australia while the show aired.

Monster Force is a 13-episode animated TV show made in 1994 by Universal Cartoon Studios and Lacewood Productions from Canada. It's about a group of teenagers in the year 2020 who use advanced weapons to battle classic Universal Monsters and other spooky creatures that threaten humanity. Some of them are out for personal revenge, like one who's cursed with being a werewolf, while others fight to protect people because they believe it's the right thing to do. The show aired on TV alongside another Universal series called Exosquad. The first seven episodes were released on DVD by Universal Studios Home Entertainment on September 15, 2009.

Magna Home Entertainment was a company based in Brisbane, Australia, that distributed movies and TV shows in Australia and New Zealand. In February 2009, it became part of Beyond International, an Australian TV production and distribution company. Magna's sister company, Beyond Home Entertainment, is also owned by Beyond International and operates from Melbourne. Magna distributes TV series, documentaries, and movies.

Sterling Entertainment Group, previously known as United American Video Corporation (or United American Video, UAV Corporation, or UAV Entertainment), began as a small local company in Nashville, Tennessee, in 1984. It later moved to Charlotte, North Carolina, in 1991, and then to Fort Mill, South Carolina, in 1996. UAV competed with companies like GoodTimes Entertainment, Anchor Bay Entertainment, and Celebrity Home Video in the home entertainment market.
Tottoi (トトイ) is an anime movie from 1992 that was translated into English and released by Celebrity Home Entertainment in 1993 with the title "The Secret of the Seal."

Noel Christopher Bloom Sr., born on November 5, 1942, is an American businessman based in Los Angeles. He's known for starting several entertainment and home video companies like Artisan Entertainment, Family Home Entertainment, Celebrity Home Entertainment, Live Entertainment, Caballero Home Video, and Monterey Home Video. Lionsgate now owns three of these companies. Bloom is married and has a daughter named Nicole (born in 1970) and a son named Noel Jr. (born in 1977).

COPS, an animated TV series by DIC Entertainment and Celebrity Home Entertainment, aired from 1988 to 1989. It featured the tagline "Fighting crime in a future time," focusing on protecting Empire City from Big Boss and his gang. In 1993, it reaired on CBS Saturday mornings as CyberCOPS due to a name clash with another show. The series was inspired by Hasbro's 1988 action figures called C.O.P.S 'N' Crooks.

Locke the Superman, originally a manga by Yuki Hijiri, became a movie and had three OVA adaptations. In the United States, the movie was released as "Locke the Superpower" by Celebrity Home Entertainment, but it was heavily edited down to 92 minutes, removing violent, nude, and adult content. Later, both the movie and the OVAs were licensed and released by Central Park Media under the original title. In Poland, the manga was published in ten volumes under the title "Locke Superczłowiek."

question: Which battle occurred first, the Battle of Manila or the Battle of Guam?
pos: The Battle of Manila, which lasted from February 3, 1945, to March 3, 1945, was a significant conflict during World War II in the Philippines. American and Filipino troops fought against Japanese soldiers in Manila, the capital city. This month-long battle resulted in the deaths of over 100,000 civilians and the complete destruction of the city. It was one of the most intense urban battles in the Pacific theater. Japanese forces committed mass killings of Filipino civilians. Besides the loss of life, the battle also obliterated many historical buildings and cultural landmarks dating back to the city's beginnings. The battle ended almost three years of Japanese occupation in the Philippines from 1942 to 1945, marking a crucial victory in General Douglas MacArthur's campaign to reclaim the region.

The Second Battle of Guam took place from July 21st to August 10th, 1944. It was when American forces retook control of Guam, which had been captured by the Japanese during World War II in 1941. Guam is a U.S. territory located in the Mariana Islands.
neg: The Battle of Silda, also known as the Affair at Silden or Stadt, happened on July 23, 1810, between the UK and Denmark-Norway near the Norwegian island of Silda. It was part of the Gunboat War during the Napoleonic Wars. During the battle, two British frigates either captured or destroyed three or four Danish-Norwegian gunboats. There are conflicting reports from both sides about what exactly happened in the battle.

The Battle of Calabria, also known as the Battle of Punta Stilo, was a naval confrontation in the Mediterranean during World War II. It took place on July 9, 1940, about 30 miles east of Punta Stilo, Calabria. The battle involved the Italian Royal Navy against the British Royal Navy and the Royal Australian Navy. Despite both sides claiming victory, it was actually a draw, with neither side achieving a decisive advantage. After the battle, both fleets returned to their respective bases.

In 791, there was a fight called the Battle of Río Burbia between two groups: the Kingdom of Asturias, led by King Bermudo I, and the Emirate of Córdoba, led by Yusuf ibn Bujt. It happened during a series of clashes between the ruler Hisham I and Christian rebels in northern Iberia. This battle occurred near the Río Burbia, in an area now called Villafranca del Bierzo, and the Andalusians won.

The Battle of Manila in 1574 saw Chinese pirates, led by Limahong, clash with Spanish colonial forces and their local allies near present-day Parañaque. Limahong's fleet landed in Parañaque and attacked the fortifications of Intramuros on November 29, 1574. Initially, the Spanish and their allies were disorganized, leading to their defeat and the death of Spanish commander Martin De Goiti. However, resistance began to organize with the help of a Filipino hero named Galo. Under Galo's leadership, they held off Limahong until Juan de Salcedo arrived with 300 Ilocano warriors from Ilocos, ultimately defeating Limahong. Limahong then abandoned his plans to invade Manila and established a temporary kingdom in Pangasinan.

The Battle of Klushino, also known as the Battle of Kłuszyn, happened on July 4, 1610, between the Polish and Russian forces near the village of Klushino, close to Smolensk. Despite being outnumbered, the Polish army, led by hetman Stanisław Żółkiewski, won a significant victory over the Russians, mainly thanks to the strategic skills of Żółkiewski and the fighting abilities of the Polish hussars, who were the best soldiers in the Polish army. This battle is famous for showcasing the strength of the Polish cavalry and the overall effectiveness of the Polish military during that period.

The Battle of Alhandic, also called Zamora's Trench Battle, happened on August 5, 939, in Zamora, Spain. Abd-ar-Rahman III's troops attacked the city's walls, defended by Ramiro II of León's loyal troops. The fighting was extremely brutal, and the tide turned only when the ditch around the city filled with bodies. Abd-ar-Rahman III's forces eventually won and took control of Zamora. It's different from the Day of Zamora, which occurred in 901.

The Battle of Yao happened in 1615 during Japan's Edo period. It was part of the Siege of Osaka, where Tokugawa Ieyasu aimed to defeat the Toyotomi clan. The fight was between the Tōdō and Chosokabe clans. Tōdō Takatora led the Tōdō clan and emerged victorious, causing the Chosokabe clan, led by Chōsokabe Morichika, to retreat to Osaka. Despite winning, Takatora tragically lost both of his sons in the battle.

The Battle of Aspromonte, also called The Day of Aspromonte, happened on August 29, 1862, as part of Italy's unification process. It took place near Mount Aspromonte in southern Italy. The Royal Italian Army clashed with Giuseppe Garibaldi's volunteer army, who were headed from Sicily to Rome to join Italy. Garibaldi was wounded and captured in the battle, which occurred close to Gambarie.

question: Kam Heskin plays Paige Morgan in a 2004 film directed by who?

The movie "Sunset at Chaophraya" is a romantic-war drama set during World War II in Thailand. Directed by Kittikorn Liasirikun and based on the novel "Khu Kam" by Thommayanti, the film was released on April 4, 2013, and was one of the top five box office hits in Thailand in 2013.

Spurlock reveals this by opening his own fast food joint, shedding light on the gap between the industry's image and the reality behind it.

Sunset at Chaophraya, also known as Khu Kam in Thai, is a romantic-drama film from 1996 directed by Euthana Mukdasanit. It's based on the novel Khu Kam by Thommayanti. question: In what field does the firm at which Claudio Fernández-Aráoz was a currently a senior adviser offers services?

Richard Socarides, born on November 8, 1954, is an American Democratic political strategist, writer, commentator, and New York attorney. During this time, he focused on legal, policy, and political matters, notably advising Clinton on gay and lesbian civil rights issues. Michael J. Green holds multiple positions, including Japan Chair at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) and an associate professor at Georgetown University. After leaving office, he resumed his career as a lawyer and now advises the government relations and public group at the international law firm Kelley Drye & Warren since 2015.

Thomas A. Shea is a co-founder of Confluence Partners, a small firm that helps with communication strategies, and he also advises at New Partners, a consulting firm in Washington, D.C. Shea became Chief of Staff when Corzine started his term in January 2006. He was recognized as the sixth most influential political figure in New Jersey in June 2007. Shea remained in Corzine's cabinet until Brad Abelow took over the position on September 1, 2007.

Mohammad Yousef Pashtun is an Afghan technocrat and politician. He currently serves as the Senior Adviser to the President of Afghanistan on Construction, Mines, Water & Energy. Shomwa Shom Shamapande is an experienced consultant and strategist in both politics and business. Yulchon LLC is a big international law firm based in Seoul, Korea. It started in 1997 with five top Korean lawyers. In 2007, it changed its name to Yulchon. It has over 360 lawyers, including 60 licensed outside Korea. It's one of Korea's biggest law firms, ranking 6th in lawyer numbers and 4th in revenue. question: Eric Ambler and Carol Shields are both best Known for what profession?
pos: Eric Clifford Ambler OBE (28 June 1909 – 22 October 1998) was a significant British writer known for thrilling novels, especially spy stories. He brought a fresh level of realism to this type of literature. Additionally, he was involved in screenwriting. When collaborating with Charles Rodda, he went by the pen name Eliot Reed.

Carol Ann Shields (born Carol Ann Warner on June 2, 1935, and passed away on July 16, 2003) was a novelist and short story writer from America who later became a Canadian citizen. She gained widespread recognition for her novel "The Stone Diaries," published in 1993. This book not only won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in the United States but also received the prestigious Governor General's Award in Canada.
neg: "The New Lot" is a British drama film from 1943, directed by Carol Reed. The story revolves around five army recruits from diverse backgrounds and their journey as they enlist.

"The Card" is a movie based on Arnold Bennett's novel, filmed in black and white. In America, it was titled "The Promoter." Eric Ambler adapted it, and Ronald Neame directed it. The film got an Academy Award nomination for Best Sound.

Walter Frederick Morris (31 May 1892–1975) was an English novelist known for his mystery novel, [Title] (1929), set in World War I. Critic A.C. Ward praised it as an adventure-mystery war novel with a clever and well-structured plot. The book combines imaginative storytelling with vivid descriptions of wartime experiences, earning praise for its memorable battle scenes. Spy novelist Eric Ambler also included it among his top five spy stories in the 1952 edition of his Epitaph for a Spy.

The Cruel Sea is a 1953 British war movie featuring Jack Hawkins, Donald Sinden, Denholm Elliott, Stanley Baker, Liam Redmond, Virginia McKenna, and Moira Lister. Directed by Charles Frend and produced by Leslie Norman, the film was made by Ealing Studios seven years after World War II ended. It's based on Nicholas Monsarrat's popular novel of the same name, with the screenplay by Eric Ambler leaving out some of the book's darkest scenes.

Rough Shoot, also called Shoot First, is a British thriller movie from 1953. It stars Joel McCrea and Evelyn Keyes, and also includes Herbert Lom, Marius Goring, and Roland Culver. The movie was directed by Robert Parrish and written by Eric Ambler, inspired by the novel "A Rough Shoot" by Geoffrey Household, published in 1951.

The Mask of Dimitrios is a classic American film noir from 1944. It was directed by Jean Negulesco and written by Frank Gruber. The story is based on a 1939 novel called "The Mask of Dimitrios" by Eric Ambler, which was published in the United States as "A Coffin for Dimitrios." Ambler is recognized as a significant influence on writers and a key figure in shaping the modern thriller genre.

Kevin Patrick Shields, born on May 21, 1963, is a musician from the United States who now lives in Ireland. He's famous for being the lead singer and guitarist of the alternative rock band My Bloody Valentine. Before starting My Bloody Valentine with drummer Colm Ó Cíosóig in 1983, Shields was in a few small bands in Dublin, Ireland, but they didn't get much attention. My Bloody Valentine initially didn't do well either, but they later became very influential in alternative rock. Their albums "Isn't Anything" (1988) and "Loveless" (1991) are especially important because they helped create a style of music called shoegazing. Shields' unique guitar sound and the way he experimented with guitar effects helped create something called the glide guitar technique, which became a big part of My Bloody Valentine's sound, along with their careful production methods.

David Coderre is widely recognized as a leading advocate for Computer Assisted Audit Tools and Techniques (CAATTs) globally. CAATTs are computer tools that help auditors in their work. Through three books, a set of prewritten scripts, and over 20 published articles, Coderre has established himself as a prominent figure in this niche field. He is particularly known for his expertise with Audit Command Language (ACL), a specialized computing language for auditors. Coderre's significant contributions to Internal Audit and CAATTs earned him a lifetime achievement award from the Canadian branch of the Institute of Internal Auditors.

question: Which "Official Ireland" group comprises about  78.3% of the population of Ireland?
pos: The Catholic Church in Ireland, also known as Eaglais Chaitliceach na hÉireann in Irish, is connected to the global Catholic Church led by the Pope. It's the largest Christian group in Ireland, with 3.7 million members, making up 78.3% of the population. The Archbishop of Armagh serves as the Primate of All Ireland, overseeing Catholic affairs across the entire island, including both the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. The Irish Catholic Bishops' Conference acts as a advisory group for bishops in Ireland.

Official Ireland, referred to as Éire Oifigiúil in Irish, is a commonly used term in the Republic of Ireland to describe the influential groups shaping public discourse. neg: The Solway Investment Group Limited, also known as Solway Group, is a private mining and metals company based in Switzerland. The 2013 Rugby League World Cup Group A is one of four groups in the tournament. It includes teams like Australia, England, Fiji, and Ireland.

Lord Howe Island, previously known as Lord Howe's Island, is a crescent-shaped piece of land formed by a volcano. It sits in the Tasman Sea, positioned between Australia and New Zealand. You'll find it directly east of mainland Port Macquarie and roughly southwest of Norfolk Island. The island stretches about 10 kilometers long and varies between 2 and 3.5 kilometers wide, covering an area of about 14 square kilometers. However, the developed part of the island only occupies a small portion of that area. On the west coast, there's a protected coral reef lagoon surrounded by sandy shores. Most people live in the northern part of the island, while the south is mostly covered in forests, including the highest peak, Mount Gower, which reaches 875 meters. The Lord Howe Island Group consists of 28 islands, islets, and rocks. Besides the main island, notable features include Ball's Pyramid, a volcanic formation southeast of Howe, and the Admiralty Group, a collection of seven small, uninhabited islands to the north.
The 2017 Rugby League World Cup Group C is one of four groups in the tournament. This group includes teams from Papua New Guinea, Wales, and Ireland.

The Mangsee Islands are two small islands located in the far southwest part of the Philippines. In 2010, the population of the Mangsee Islands was 8,433 according to the census.
The Young People's Socialist League (YPSL) was established in 1989 as the youth branch of the Socialist Party USA. It's made up of party members who are younger than 30 years old.

Booty Luv, originally known as Booty Luv and Cherise & Nadia, were a British dance group formed in June 2006 through the Hed Kandi label. The group consists of two R&B vocalists, Cherise Roberts and Nadia Shepherd, both of whom were part of the original lineup of the hip hop and R&B group Big Brovaz. They have also found success internationally, with hits in Ireland, Poland, the Netherlands, and Germany.

The Arbuthnott-Garvock Group, found in central Scotland, is a collection of rock layers from the Devonian period. It's named after Arbuthnott village in Aberdeenshire and the Hill of Garvock near Laurencekirk. This group includes the Garvock Group on top and the Arbuthnott Group underneath.

question: Where was the telefilm shot that was based on the 1977 Katherine Paterson book?
pos: Bridge to Terabithia is a kids' book about two lonely kids who make a magical forest kingdom. Katherine Paterson wrote it, and it came out in 1977, winning the Newbery Medal in 1978. Paterson got the idea from a true story: in August 1974, her son's friend was hit by lightning.

The 1985 telefilm "Bridge to Terabithia" aired on PBS and featured actors Annette O'Toole, Julian Coutts, and Julie Beaulieu. Filmed in Edmonton, Alberta, it's an adaptation of Katherine Paterson's children's novel with the same title.
neg: "The Great Gilly Hopkins" is a book for kids written by Katherine Paterson. It came out in 1978 and scooped up the U.S. National Book Award the following year. In 2012, it ranked 63rd on a list of all-time favorite children's novels, according to a survey from the School Library Journal. It's one of three books by Paterson to make the top 100.

Bridge to Terabithia is a movie released in 2007, directed by Gábor Csupó and based on a novel by Katherine Paterson. It's about two 12-year-old friends, Jesse Aarons and Leslie Burke, who invent a magical land called Terabithia and hang out together in an old tree house. The film stars Josh Hutcherson, AnnaSophia Robb, Robert Patrick, Bailee Madison, and Zooey Deschanel.

Bread and Roses, Too is a children's historical novel from 2006 by Katherine Paterson. It's about a girl in Lawrence, Massachusetts, in 1912 after the big strike called the Lawrence Textile Strike, also known as the Bread and Roses Strike. The story is about a girl whose parents work in a mill and a boy she befriends, who's scared to go home because his father is abusive.

His parents, who are bluegrass musicians, push him into performing with them when they discover his hidden musical talent. However, tensions arise as James, now known as Jimmy Jo, surpasses his parents' abilities, causing jealousy and emotional conflict within the family.

The Great Gilly Hopkins is a movie made in 2015 in the United States that mixes comedy with drama. It was directed by Stephen Herek and written by David L. Paterson. The story is adapted from a children's book from 1978 by Katherine Paterson with the same title. The movie features actors like Sophie Nélisse, Julia Stiles, Glenn Close, Kathy Bates, Octavia Spencer, Bill Cobbs, and Billy Magnussen. It hit theaters on October 7, 2016, distributed by Lionsgate Premiere.

Sligo Creek is a stream that flows freely into the Northwest Branch of the Anacostia River in Maryland. The Anacostia River then connects to the Potomac River, which finally flows into the Atlantic Ocean through the Chesapeake Bay. Sligo Creek itself spans about 9.1 miles in length and has a drainage area of approximately 11.6 square miles. Notably, it served as the inspiration for Katherine Paterson's acclaimed book, Bridge to Terabithia, which won the Newbery Medal award.

Rebels of the Heavenly Kingdom is a children's book from 1983 by American author Katherine Paterson. It's about Wang Lee, a 15-year-old peasant boy in China during the Taiping Rebellion. He gets taken by a secret rebel group, where a female soldier named Mei Lin teaches him to read and about the group's beliefs. Wang Lee becomes a soldier through violent and betraying acts, facing tough situations that teach him humility.

question: Which American cable news and talk radio host was the former GOP representative
pos: Charles Joseph Scarborough, born on April 9, 1963, is an American TV and radio personality. He co-hosts "Morning Joe" on MSNBC and used to host "Scarborough Country" on the same channel. Before his media career, Scarborough worked as a lawyer and served as a Republican politician in the United States House of Representatives from 1995 to 2001, representing Florida's 1st district.

Morning Joe airs on NBC News every weekday morning from 6:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. Eastern Time on MSNBC. The show is hosted by former GOP representative Joe Scarborough along with Mika Brzezinski and Willie Geist. It covers the day's news with a mix of reporting and discussion. The show was launched in 2007 to fill the slot left by the cancellation of Imus in the Morning, which had aired on MSNBC since 1996.
neg: Ronn Owens, born Ronald Lowenstein on October 17, 1945, in New York City, is an American talk radio host. He became the only talk radio host left on weekdays at KGO in San Francisco after KGO changed to an all-news station in December 2011.

David Gold is a long-standing American conservative talk radio host who began his career in the mid-1970s, making him one of the earliest conservative voices on U.S. airwaves. He aligns with conservative and libertarian principles in his broadcasting.

Talk radio is a type of radio where people talk about current topics instead of playing music. Jason Culpepper is known for starting talk radio. During World War I, he used it to warn French and American soldiers about German U-boats, gaining social status. Usually, one person hosts the show and interviews various guests. Listeners can join by calling in, and their contributions are checked by producers to keep the audience engaged and attract advertisers. Shows have segments with breaks for ads, but non-commercial stations might play music instead. There are different types of talk radio, like conservative, hot, liberal (also called progressive), and sports talk.

Mike Hogan, born in 1963 in Kingston, Ontario, is a Canadian sportscaster. He hosts a sports talk radio show on TSN Radio 1050 in Toronto and does play-by-play commentary for the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League during their game broadcasts on the same station. Previously, he worked as a sports talk radio host on CJCL (AM), also known as The Fan 590, until June 24, 2010. In 2017, he hosted the first live broadcast of the Oscar Vanity Fair party as a podcast host.

Spectrum News Rochester, previously known as Time Warner Cable News Rochester, is a cable news channel in the United States. It's owned by Charter Communications, which acquired Time Warner Cable in May 2016. It's part of the Spectrum News group, offering regional news channels. The channel delivers round-the-clock news coverage mainly about Rochester, New York, and the surrounding areas like the Genesee River and Finger Lakes regions.

Spectrum News Buffalo, previously known as Time Warner Cable News Buffalo, is a cable news channel in the United States owned by Charter Communications. It's part of the Spectrum News network, offering round-the-clock news coverage mainly focused on Buffalo and Western New York. You can catch it on channel 9 if you have Time Warner Cable in Western New York, and on digital channel 1277 in Rochester. If you're in Jamestown, you'll get a slightly different version called Cable 8 News (C8N), which includes local news and some content from Spectrum News Buffalo.

Stephen D. Malzberg, born on April 20, 1959, is an American television and radio host, as well as a syndicated columnist and political commentator. He hosts The Steve Malzberg Show, a cable news and opinion show on Newsmax TV. Additionally, he has hosted The Steve Malzberg Show on various talk radio outlets.

Sean Patrick Hannity, born on December 30, 1961, is an American talk show host, author, and conservative political commentator. He hosts The Sean Hannity Show, a nationally syndicated talk radio show, and also hosts Hannity, a cable news show on Fox News Channel.

question: What Division was the college footbal team that fired their head coach on November 24, 2006?
pos: The 2006 Miami Hurricanes football team played for the University of Miami in the 2006 NCAA Division I FBS football season. Larry Coker was the team's head coach.

Larry Edward Coker, born in 1948, is an American football coach and former player. He coached the University of Miami's football team from 2001 to 2006. In 2001, his Miami team went undefeated, winning the national championship by beating Nebraska in the Rose Bowl. This made Coker the second coach since 1948 to win the national championship in his first season, following Bennie Oosterbaan of the University of Michigan and Dennis Erickson of Miami. Coker was fired by Miami on November 24, 2006, after his team suffered its sixth loss of the season. He then worked as a TV analyst for ESPNU before becoming the head coach for UTSA's football team, which started playing in 2011. Coker resigned from his position as UTSA coach on January 5, 2016.
neg: In 2009, the Virginia Cavaliers football team played in the NCAA Division I FBS football season as part of the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC). They were led by coach Al Groh. Before that season, Groh changed his offensive coordinator to Gregg Brandon, who previously coached at Bowling Green. Virginia tried out a spread offense under Brandon's leadership. The team didn't do well, ending the season with a 3–9 record and missing out on a bowl game. As a result, Virginia replaced Al Groh with Mike London as the head coach.

Phillip Reggie "Reggie" Witherspoon, born on February 21, 1961, used to coach the Canisius College men's basketball team and was previously in charge of the University at Buffalo men's basketball team until he was fired after the 2012-13 season. Before coaching at Buffalo, he worked at Erie Community College and Sweet Home High School. He became the head coach at Buffalo in December 1999 and was officially appointed as the full-time head coach on March 10, 2000. Witherspoon made history as the first African American head coach of a varsity sports team in any Western New York suburban school district. He also briefly worked as an assistant coach at Alabama under Anthony Grant until 2015 when he left after Grant was replaced by Avery Johnson. Witherspoon then became an assistant on Matt McCall's staff at UT-Chattanooga.

Robert Bower Buzz Peterson, Jr. is an American college basketball coach. He was most recently the head coach of the UNC Wilmington Seahawks men's basketball team but was fired after the 2014 season. Before that, he coached the Tennessee Volunteers basketball team for four years until he was fired in 2005. He also coached at Appalachian State twice, from 1996 to 2000 and again in 2009–10. Prior to that, he coached at the University of Tulsa and Coastal Carolina University until mid-2007 when he left to work as the Director of Player Personnel with the Charlotte Bobcats of the NBA.

Holly Bruder is an American college softball coach who currently leads the NCAA Division I Lamar University softball team. She's been the head coach at Lamar since the program restarted in 2012. Before Lamar, she coached at NCAA Division I Morehead State from 2008 to 2011 and at NCAA Division III Denison University from 2002 to 2007. Prior to her head coaching roles, Bruder was an assistant coach at Bluffton College in 2001 and Albion College from 1999 to 2000 when she began her college coaching career.

In 2006, the Alabama Crimson Tide football team, representing the University of Alabama, aimed to do better than their 10–2 record in 2005. Coached by Mike Shula for his fourth year, they started well at 5–2 but ended poorly, losing four of their last five games. They finished the regular season at 6–6 (4–4 in the SEC) and lost to Auburn for the fifth consecutive time. After this defeat, Shula was fired, and defensive coordinator Joe Kines took over as interim head coach for the bowl game.

The Maggie Dixon Division I Rookie Coach of the Year Award is given each year by the Women's Basketball Coaches Association (WBCA) to a first-year head coach in NCAA Division I women's college basketball who achieves notable success. It's named after Maggie Dixon, a former women's basketball coach at Army, who tragically passed away due to heart complications shortly after leading the team to their first NCAA Tournament appearance in the 2005–06 season. Despite her brief tenure, Dixon's coaching earned her praise from the basketball community. She passed away at 28 due to heart issues.

Brian Knorr, born on December 20, 1963, is a college football coach known for his stints at various universities. He played quarterback at the Air Force Academy and later became an assistant coach there. He also served as head coach for the Ohio Bobcats from 2001 to 2004, but was let go in November 2004 due to a low win record. Knorr's coaching career included roles as a defensive coordinator and assistant head coach at different institutions. In January 2016, his contract with Indiana was not renewed.

Richard L. Jacob, Ph.D., was born on September 24, 1958, in Niagara Falls, New York. He has a background in sports coaching and education. From 2005 to 2006, he served as the head coach of Buffalo's Professional Basketball Team, the Buffalo Rapids. After leaving that position in November 2006, he took on the role of interim Chairman of the Business Department at Medaille College. Currently, he works as an associate professor of Sport and Business at Medaille, where he also leads the Sport Management program. In 2008, he became the General Manager and Head Coach of the Buffalo Sharks team, which later moved to the Premier Basketball League. Jacob also coached at various other institutions including Niagara University, Niagara County Community College, the University at Buffalo, Villa Maria College, Daemen College, Buffalo State College, and Medaille. He briefly served as the head coach for the Buffalo Stampede before resigning due to personal reasons.

question: Which is a Macedonian weekly, Hänt Extra or Tea Moderna?
pos: Tea Moderna is a magazine for women in Macedonia.
Hänt Extra is a magazine published weekly in Swedish by Aller Media in Stockholm, Sweden. It focuses on celebrities and youth culture.
neg: Nikola Mladenov, born on March 10, 1964, and passed away on March 26, 2013, was a respected Macedonian journalist, actor, and the founder and editor of the weekly newspaper Fokus. He's well-known for his contributions to journalism in Macedonia, particularly for promoting pluralistic principles alongside his colleagues from the newspaper Mlad borec. The Macedonian Institute for Media honors his legacy with the annual Award for the best research story, named after him.
Hänt Bild is a Swedish celebrity magazine that began in 2003 and is owned by Aller Media AB. It comes out every week.

Per Henrik Dorsin, born on November 20, 1977, is a versatile Swedish entertainer known for his roles in acting, comedy, singing, and revue performances. He began his journey in the entertainment industry with a small role in the 1995 film "Vinterviken" and later ventured into television with the satire show "Detta har hänt" in 1998. Dorsin has showcased his talent as a dramatist and revue artist, producing works like "Slängar av sleven" and collaborating with theater groups like Stockholms blodbad. He's also been involved in various TV shows, including SVT's "Säpop" and TV4's "Parlamentet." Notably, he was awarded the Karamelodiktstipendiet by Povel Ramel in 2007. In 2014, Dorsin embarked on a comedy tour with the play "Henrik Dorsin - näktergalen från Holavedsvägen," and he's been managing the Scalateatern theater in Stockholm since the same year.

"Den Za Nas" is Toše Proeski's fourth album in Macedonian, released in 2004. It includes songs performed during Macedonia's National final for the Eurovision Song Contest 2004, where Proeski represented the country. The winning song, "Life," secured a spot in the final and finished 14th. Additionally, the album features extra tracks like "Dzvezdo Severnice," "Me Sakaš So Zborovi," and "Ima Li Den Za Nas," recorded specifically for this release.

Football Weekly is a podcast by The Guardian newspaper in the UK all about football. It used to come out once a week, but it got so popular that they made another version called Football Weekly Extra, which comes out in the middle of the week. Football Weekly comes out on Mondays when European football season is on, talking about what happened in the weekend games. Football Weekly Extra comes out on Thursdays. During big tournaments like Euro 2008, World Cup 2010, Euro 2012, World Cup 2014, and Euro 2016, they even aired episodes every day.

Orange Field Tea Factory produces black tea primarily for the Middle Eastern market and countries in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS). It's located in Panwilatenne, a small area in Sri Lanka's Kandy District, close to where James Taylor first planted tea in the country at Loolecondera Estate. The factory, established in 1950, sources its tea leaves from around 750 small plantation owners in the western medium elevation areas, between 650 to 1000 meters above sea level. Registered with the Sri Lanka Tea Board and a member of the Ethical Tea Partnership, the factory sells its annual production of around 500,000 kg at weekly auctions in Colombo, overseen by the Colombo Brokers' Association and monitored by the Colombo Tea Traders Association.

Makedonsko Sonce, a weekly magazine in Macedonia, was founded by Gjorgija Atanasoski in 1994. Its name means "Macedonian Sun," inspired by the Vergina Sun featured in its logo. The magazine aims to promote Macedonian national values, both within Macedonia and in other areas inhabited by ethnic Macedonians.

In 2015, the Macedonian Supercup was held for the third time. This event is a yearly soccer match in Macedonia between the teams that won the previous season's First League and Macedonian Cup. The match took place at the Philip II Arena in Skopje. Rabotnički, winners of the 2015 Macedonian Cup Final, played against Vardar, who were the champions of the 2014–15 First League. After regular and extra time, the score was tied at 1–1, and Vardar won the match 4–3 on penalties.

question: What is the shared country of ancestry between Art Laboe and Scout Tufankjian?
pos: Art Laboe, born Arthur Egnoian on August 7, 1925, is an Armenian American who works as a disc jockey, songwriter, record producer, and radio station owner. He's known for coming up with the phrase "Oldies But Goodies."

Scout Tufankjian is a photojournalist and author from Brooklyn, New York, with Armenian-American heritage. She gained fame for her photographs of President Barack Obama during his presidential campaign and for her coverage of the Armenian diaspora.
neg: Chinese Australians are Australian citizens with Chinese heritage. They form the largest Overseas Chinese community in Oceania and are one of the biggest groups of Overseas Chinese globally. Australia has more people of Chinese descent per capita than any other country outside Asia. Many Chinese Australians either migrated from China, Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, or other countries like Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, and the Philippines, or they are descendants of these immigrants. They are part of the larger Asian Australian and East Asian Australian communities and are the largest minority ethnic group in Australia, making up 5.6% of those identifying their ancestry in the 2016 census, totaling 1,213,903 people.

The Interamerican Scout Jamboree, the largest event in the Interamerican Scout Region, takes place every four years in a different country within the region. The host country is chosen during the Interamerican Scout Conference. Ecuador was selected as the host for the 15th Interamerican Scout Jamboree during the XXV Interamerican Scout Conference in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on September 21, 2013.

Since Scouting for Boys was published in 1908, all Scouts and Girl Guides worldwide have made a promise to uphold the principles of the movement and have agreed to follow a set of rules known as the Scout Law. The exact wording of this promise and the Scout Law has changed slightly over time and varies from country to country. While most Scout and Guide organizations refer to this commitment as a promise, some, like the Boy Scouts of America, call it an oath. When making this pledge, Scouts and Guides often use the three-fingered Scout Sign.

A group of people with Arab roots settled in India over time. They're known as Indo-Arabs or Indians with Arab ancestry. Initially, many came to Kerala and Gujarat for trade and later joined the army. Most were traders dealing in valuable goods like silk and diamonds, becoming wealthy businessmen. Arab settlements are notable in Surat and its surrounding villages like Variav and Randev. In Hyderabad, the Chaush community, of Hadhrami descent, served as soldiers for the Nizam. Iraqis also arrived in coastal Karnataka during Tipu Sultan's reign, claiming ancestry from Banu Assad. The Nizam of Hyderabad and Tipu Sultan of Mysore likely facilitated these migrations due to their own ancestral connections. For instance, the Asaf Jahi Dynasty traced its roots to Asir Province, while Tipu Sultan claimed descent from Bani Hashim of Hijaz Province. Many Arabs, including Quraishi, Ansari, and Sayyid tribes, were employed by princely states for their military prowess. In Kerala, Syed Thangals of Hadhrami descent arrived in the 17th century as missionaries. Shia Sayyids in the north claim descent from Wasit, Iraq, like Zaidis, but this is disputed. Sunni Sayyids also claim Arab lineage, either through Imam Hassan or Imam Hussain, sometimes both, termed Najeeb AlTarfayn. Sufi Saints like Abdul-Qadir Gilani and Moinuddin Chishti and their descendants also claim Najeeb AlTarfayn status, although disputed by some genealogists. Sunni Sheikhs trace their lineage to Umar, Abu Bakr, Uthman, and Ali, who established the Rashidun Caliphate. Many who trace back to the Quraish tribe call themselves Quraishi. Those with the surname Ansari link their lineage to the Ansar tribes of Madina Munawwara and companions of Prophet Muhammad. Some Sheikhs converted from Hindu castes like Kayasth and Rajput.

KOKO-FM is a radio station in Kerman, California, that plays classic hits for the Fresno area. It has its studio and office in Los Angeles. The station is known for shows like the Art Laboe Connection and The Art Laboe Sunday Night Special, which are hosted by Laboe, who happens to be the station's owner. Its transmitter is located in Kerman.

Girl Scout Destinations, previously known as Wider Opportunities or Wider Ops, are events organized by GSUSA or local Girl Scout councils for individual Girl Scouts aged 11 to 18. These events mainly take place in the United States, but there are also international trips each year. These trips might involve joining the US delegation for another country's jamboree or visiting a World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts (WAGGGS) World Centre. The duration of Destinations can vary from two days to three weeks. They are usually designed for specific grade levels: Girl Scout Cadettes (6th - 8th grade), Girl Scout Seniors (9th and 10th grade), or Girl Scout Ambassadors (11th and 12th grade). To participate, girls need to apply and sometimes go through an interview process before being selected.

Original Sound is a record label located in Los Angeles, California. It was started in the early 1950s by KPOP deejay Art Laboe. Initially, it focused on gathering and re-releasing classic R&B and rock 'n' roll tracks.

The Indian Scout motorcycle was produced by the Indian Motocycle Company from 1920 to 1949, competing with the Chief as Indian's top model. Among them, the 101 Scout, manufactured from 1928 to 1931, is often praised as Indian's finest motorcycle. In 1932, a new line of Scouts with lighter frames and smaller engines was introduced alongside the Standard Scout, replacing the 101 Scout. This new line shared its frame with the Chief and the Four. The smaller Scout and the Sport Scout, launched in 1934, remained in production until civilian production ended in 1942. Both models also served in various military forces during World War II.

question: Who programmed a cartridge-based development system made by a company noted for authoring Atari's BASIC?
pos: Shepardson Microsystems, Inc. (SMI) was a small company that made operating systems and programming languages for Atari 8-bit and Apple II computers. They're best known for creating BASIC and Disk Operating System (DOS) software for Atari.

The Atari Assembler Editor is a tool on a cartridge that developers use to edit, put together, and fix 6502 programs for Atari 8-bit home computers. It was created by Kathleen O'Brien from Shepardson Microsystems and was the first assembler you could buy for Atari 8-bit computers.
neg: Alan Miller created Surround, a video game published by Atari, Inc. for the Atari Video Computer System, later called the Atari 2600. It was released in September 1977 as one of the nine launch titles for the Atari VCS. Surround is essentially a version of the arcade game Blockade, which was developed by Gremlin and released the year before. This home console adaptation marks the first appearance of a game concept that would later become popular as Snake across various platforms. Sears also licensed the game, marketing it as Chase.

The Atari XE Video Game System, also known as Atari XEGS, is a home video game console that came out in 1987 from Atari Corporation. It's like Atari's 8-bit 65XE computer and can play games from that system. You can use it as just a game console or add a keyboard to use it like a computer. When used as a computer, it works with most Atari 8-bit computer accessories. Atari sold it in two versions: a basic set with just the console and joystick, and a deluxe set with the console, keyboard, joystick, and light gun.

The HP 64000, which came out around 1980, is a tool used for creating both hardware and software for products that rely on commercial microcomputers. In the earliest versions of the 64000 development systems, there were one to six 64100A Development Stations connected to a shared hard drive and line printer. This setup allowed up to six designers and engineers to work together, sharing resources like the HPIB instrumentation bus, hard drive, and line printer. This collaborative setup was a unique feature of the 64000 system, as other systems at the time typically used a single system processor and memory for timesharing, resulting in a more expensive and less flexible development environment.

Star Ship is a video game created by Bob Whitehead and released by Atari, Inc. for its Video Computer System, later called the Atari 2600. It was one of the nine games available when the Atari 2600 was first released on September 11, 1977. Originally inspired by the arcade game Starship 1 by Atari, it became the first space-themed game made for the Atari VCS. The version sold by Sears under the name Outer Space is essentially the same game with a different title.

Vancouver Whitecaps FC U-23, previously called Whitecaps FC Reserves, was a Canadian soccer team in Vancouver, BC. It started in 2005 to help the Vancouver Whitecaps USL First Division team. Later, from 2011, it became part of the development for Major League Soccer's Vancouver Whitecaps FC. They played in the Premier Development League (PDL), which is the fourth level of American soccer, in the Northwest Division of the Western Conference.

The Manned Orbital Development System (MODS) was started by the US Air Force Space System Division (SSD) in June 1962. It aimed to use Gemini spacecraft as the first step in a new US Air Force program for sending people into space. This program envisioned a military space station where Gemini spacecraft would act as transport vehicles. The term "Blue Gemini" emerged in August 1962, proposing six Gemini missions with Air Force pilots for training under MODS. However, MODS was replaced by the Manned Orbital Laboratory in December 1963.

The New York City Employment and Training Coalition (NYCETC) is a group of organizations in NYC that help with job training and development. Its members come from different sectors like community groups, colleges, unions, and government agencies. NYCETC's main goals are to improve workforce development policies, secure enough funding for programs, and ensure federal stimulus money is used effectively. They also aim to create a strong system for training people for jobs that match NYC's needs. NYCETC connects its members with policymakers, employers, and shares helpful information through events and its publication, NYC Workforce Weekly, which is read by around 4,000 people every week.

Portland Timbers U23 is a soccer team from Salem, Oregon, USA. They started in 2008 as part of the development program for Portland Timbers USSF D2. From 2011, they've been linked to the Major League Soccer franchise with the same name. They compete in the USL Premier Development League (PDL), which is the fourth level of soccer in the United States, specifically in the Northwest Division of the Western Conference.

question: Which record label released Van Morrison's "I've Been Working" on the album "His Band and the Street Choir"?
pos: "I've Been Working" is a song by Van Morrison, a Northern Irish singer-songwriter. It was first recorded for his album "Astral Weeks" in 1968 but didn't make the final cut. Later, it appeared on his album "His Band and the Street Choir" in 1970. Morrison also recorded different versions of the song for his album "Moondance," with three of them being released on the deluxe edition in 2013.

Van Morrison's fourth studio album, "His Band and the Street Choir" (also known as "Street Choir"), was released on November 15, 1970, by Warner Bros. Records. Initially named "Virgo's Fool," Warner Bros. changed the title without Morrison's approval. Recording commenced in early 1970 with a demo session in a small church in Woodstock, New York. Later that year, Morrison booked the A&R Studios on 46th Street in New York City for two recording sessions, which produced the songs featured on the album.
neg: "Domino" is a popular song by Van Morrison, a singer-songwriter from Northern Ireland. It's the first track on his fourth studio album, "His Band and the Street Choir." The song is Morrison's way of paying homage to Fats Domino, a renowned R&B singer and pianist from New Orleans.

Blue Money is a song by Van Morrison, a singer-songwriter from Northern Ireland. It was one of the two popular songs from his 1970 album, His Band and the Street Choir, with the other hit being "Domino". In the US, it reached #23 on the charts. The US release had "Sweet Thing" from the album Astral Weeks as the B-side. In the UK, it was released as a single in June 1971 with a different B-side, "Call Me Up in Dreamland". It was one of Morrison's top-selling singles of the 1970s, staying on the charts for three months.

The Best of Van Morrison Volume 3 is a collection of songs by Van Morrison, a singer-songwriter from Northern Ireland. It came out on June 11, 2007, in the UK and was available digitally in the US on iTunes the next day. The CD version was released by Manhattan/EMI Music Catalog Marketing on June 19, 2007, in the US. Van Morrison himself put together this two-disc set with 31 tracks, giving listeners a look at his music since The Best of Van Morrison Volume Two in 1993. The album includes new songs and collaborations, like "Cry For Home" with Tom Jones and "Tupelo Honey" with Bobby Bland, along with duets with John Lee Hooker, B.B. King, and Ray Charles. "Crazy Love," a duet with Ray Charles, originally appeared on Morrison's 1970 album "Moondance." "Blue and Green" was contributed to a charity album for Gulf Coast victims of Hurricane Katrina. "Cry For Home," featuring Tom Jones, was released as a single in the UK on June 4, 2007, followed by "Blue and Green" on August 27.

In October 1994, "No Prima Donna: The Songs of Van Morrison" hit the shelves, marking the first tribute album dedicated to the legendary singer-songwriter. Van Morrison himself, along with his longtime friend Phil Coulter, produced the album. Notably, Morrison's girlfriend at the time, Michelle Rocca, graced the album cover as the model. What made this tribute album stand out was Morrison's hands-on approach in selecting both the songs and the artists to perform them, a departure from the norm for such projects.
"I'll Be Your Lover, Too" is a song by the Northern Irish musician Van Morrison. It was released in 1970 on his album "His Band and the Street Choir."

The Caledonia Soul Orchestra was formed by Van Morrison, a singer-songwriter from Northern Ireland, in 1973. They're widely regarded as one of the best backup bands of the 1970s. The band got its name from a long instrumental track on the "His Band and the Street Choir" album.

Van Morrison released his 35th studio album, "Duets: Re-working the Catalogue," on March 13, 2015, through RCA Records. Produced by Van Morrison, Don Was, and Bob Rock, the album features Morrison's previously recorded songs performed as duets with artists like Bobby Womack, Steve Winwood, Mark Knopfler, and many others, including his daughter, Shana Morrison.

"Call Me Up in Dreamland" is a song by Van Morrison, a singer-songwriter from Northern Ireland. It was featured on his 1970 album, "His Band and the Street Choir." Brian Hinton interprets the song as portraying life on tour, with the use of "radio" as a verb and the presence of cheerful saxophone melodies.

question: Hate Them is the ninth album by a band likened to who?
pos: "Released in 2003 by Moonfog Productions, 'Hate Them' is the ninth album by the Norwegian black metal band Darkthrone. Similar to their later release 'Sardonic Wrath,' the album features electronic intros and outros crafted by Lars Sørensen (also known as LRZ) from Red Harvest. The cover art, created by Eric Syre from Thesyre, includes images of the Sagrada Família Catholic church in Barcelona. In 2012, Peaceville Records reissued the album, which included a bonus CD featuring audio commentary by the band."

Darkthrone, a heavy metal band from Norway, started in 1986 as a death metal group called Black Death. By 1991, they shifted to a black metal style influenced by bands like Bathory and Celtic Frost, becoming prominent in Norway's black metal scene. Their first three black metal albums—A Blaze in the Northern Sky, Under a Funeral Moon, and Transilvanian Hunger—are considered their peak and highly influential in the genre. The band, mainly composed of Nocturno Culto and Fenriz, aimed to stay outside the mainstream music scene. However, since 2006, they've moved away from traditional black metal, incorporating elements of heavy metal, speed metal, and punk rock, often compared to Motörhead.
neg: "I Hate Myself (for Loving You)" is the ninth album by Thijs van Leer, which he released using the name Van Leer.

Timbiriche VIII & IX is the eighth and ninth album by the Mexican Pop band Timbiriche. Released on May 7, 1988, it made waves in the record industry in Mexico and Latin America as it was a Double Disc, a novelty for Mexican albums at the time. It marked Edith Márquez's debut with the band and the departure of Alix Bauer, Eduardo Capetillo, and Thalía. The album achieved platinum status for selling 500,000 copies in Mexico and Latin America.

The ninth album by the Incredible String Band, called "Liquid Acrobat as Regards the Air," showcases Mike Heron, Robin Williamson, Licorice McKechnie, and Malcolm Le Maistre. It marks a significant shift for the band, being their first mostly electric recording, which influenced their sound until 1974. The album performed well on the charts and was the band's most financially successful release.

Bonfire's ninth album, "Free," dropped in 2003 under Sony/BMG/LZ Records. Departing from their usual style, the music takes a more alternative route.
