The album sported two covers: one for Germany and another for global release, with the German cover featuring a brown wall backdrop and the global one in white. Despite anticipation, both loyal fans and critics weren't thrilled with the material, leading to an overall negative reaction. Notably, the track "September On My Mind" reflects on the 9/11 attacks. The extended length of "Friends" is attributed to extra band member recordings after the song. Nonetheless, the album found success, making its mark on the Official German Media Control Top 100 Album Charts.

Lonestar is a country music band from America that started in 1992 with members Richie McDonald, John Rich, Keech Rainwater, Michael Britt, and Dean Sams. They've made 12 studio albums, including two Christmas albums, and released seven greatest hits collections along with 37 singles. Their first five albums with BNA Records have all been certified gold or higher by the RIAA, and their greatest hits album is certified platinum. The band's most successful album is 1999's Lonely Grill, which went 3× Platinum. In April 2010, they released their ninth album, Party Heard Around the World, which introduced Cody Collins as the new lead singer, taking over from McDonald in 2007.

Osc-Dis, short for Oscillator in Distortion, stands as the ninth album by the Japanese band The Mad Capsule Markets. Initially released in Japan in 1999, it later reached international audiences in 2001. This album marked a significant turning point for the band, propelling them into the spotlight beyond Japan, largely due to the success of the single "Pulse." 

Musically, Osc-Dis blends industrial metal, industrial rock, and punk rock with various electronic music styles. It notably embraced a more melodic approach compared to its predecessor, incorporating elements of pop punk. The album features guest vocal contributions from Hirosuke from Balzac, Yamada from Geronimo, and Katsya from NND. Additionally, Osc-Dis introduced the band's mascots, The White Crusher and The Cyborn, adding a visual dimension to their artistic identity.

"Still Restless" is the ninth album by the American country band Restless Heart, released in 2004. It marked their reunion after not releasing any music since 1998's "Greatest Hits" and was their first album with all five original members since 1990's "Fast Movin' Train." It was released under Koch Records Nashville and included the single "Feel My Way to You," which reached #29 on the Billboard Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in late 2004.

Jeremy Camp's ninth studio album, "Reckless," was produced by Camp himself and Andy Dodd. It came out on February 12, 2013, under the BEC Recordings label, making it his eighth release with the label. The first single, also titled "Reckless," was released on November 16, 2012, and did well on the charts. This album is significant as it's Camp's ninth overall, including his first independent release. In the week of March 2, 2013, "Reckless" ranked as the 31st best-selling album nationwide on the Billboard 200 chart, and it was the 10th most popular rock album and the top-selling Christian album of that week.

question: How did Emilie du Chatelet, Voltaire's love, contribute to the basic laws of physics?
pos: "Voltaire in Love" is a well-liked book that tells the story of the sixteen-year romance between Voltaire and Émilie, the Marquise du Châtelet. It was written by Nancy Mitford and first came out in 1957. The book also delves into the French Enlightenment period.

Gabrielle Émilie Le Tonnelier de Breteuil, Marquise Du Châtelet, was a French thinker who lived in the early 1700s. She was known for her work in natural philosophy, mathematics, and physics. Unfortunately, she passed away in 1749 due to complications from childbirth. One of her most famous accomplishments was translating and adding commentary to Isaac Newton's book Principia, which outlines fundamental laws of physics. This translation, published after her death in 1759, is still regarded as the standard French version. In her commentary, she made a significant contribution to Newtonian mechanics by proposing an additional conservation law for total energy, including kinetic energy.
neg: Katherine Kath, born Lily Faess on August 11, 1920, in Berck, Pas-de-Calais, France, was a renowned French ballerina at the Theatre du Chatelet in Paris. After an injury ended her ballet career, she transitioned to acting. She passed away at the age of 92 in 2012 in Berck, France, the exact cause of her death remains undisclosed.

The Ethiopian Legal Information Website is a digital database of Ethiopian laws. Its goal is to give the public, researchers, professors, law firms, and legal professionals easy access to basic laws online. Developed by Mekelle University Law Faculty in Ethiopia and the Non-Western Law Department of Ghent University in Belgium, it currently hosts federal laws, with future plans to include state, regional, and other laws.

The main rules of how our minds connect ideas are: things that happen close together, repeating experiences, paying attention, feeling good or bad about something, and finding things similar. These ideas were first explained by Aristotle around 300 B.C. and later by John Locke in the 17th century. They both believed that when we're born, our minds are like blank pages, and we have to learn everything. These rules they talked about are still really important in how we understand learning today.

Jean du Chatelet, who also went by the names Baron de Beausoleil and Auffembach, lived from around 1578 in Brabant to about 1645 in The Bastille, Paris. He was a specialist in minerals, mining engineering, and dowsing.

Disney's Twelve Basic Principles of Animation were created by Ollie Johnston and Frank Thomas, Disney animators, in their book published in 1981. They built upon the techniques of earlier Disney animators from the 1930s onwards, aiming to make animations look more lifelike. These principles aimed to make characters in animations seem like they followed the rules of physics while also addressing emotional timing and character appeal.

The Basic Laws of Israel are like the country's constitution. They talk about how the government works and protects people's rights. They're supposed to be part of a formal constitution, but that's been delayed since 1950. For now, they act as the closest thing Israel has to a constitution. Israel operates under a mix of these Basic Laws, court decisions, and regular laws. Not all constitutional issues are covered, and there's no set deadline for finishing the constitution. Sometimes it's not clear if the Basic Laws or regular laws are more important, and courts decide on a case-by-case basis.

Israel does not have a formal written constitution; instead, it relies on a set of Basic Laws established through the Harari Decision of 1950. These laws cover government structure and human rights. Aharon Barak, the former President of the Israeli Supreme Court, argued that these Basic Laws effectively function as the country's constitution, a view widely accepted during his tenure from 1995 to 2006. However, not everyone agrees with this perspective, including Barak's colleague, Supreme Court Judge Mishael Cheshin.

"The Physics of Superheroes" by James Kakalios, a physics professor and avid comic-book enthusiast, delves into the fundamental principles of physics through the lens of comic book scenes. Rather than pointing out where superheroes defy scientific laws, Kakalios highlights instances where comic book scenarios provide unique perspectives on physics concepts. For example, he analyzes events like Gwen Stacy's demise and Ant-Man's ability to escape a paper bag through the principles of physics such as levers and torque. This approach allows him to cover a wide range of topics, from mechanics to quantum physics, making complex concepts more accessible through familiar superhero narratives.

question: Were Goo Goo Dolls and Echosmith formed in the same city?
pos: Echosmith is a pop band from California that formed in 2009. Originally, it was made up of four siblings, but now it's down to three: Sydney, Noah, and Graham Sierota, since their oldest sibling, Jamie, left in 2016. They used to be called Ready Set Go! before signing with Warner Bros. Records in 2012. Their most famous song is "Cool Kids," which reached number 13 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and was certified double platinum by the RIAA in the US and ARIA in Australia, selling over 1.2 million copies. It was one of Warner Bros. Records' top-selling digital songs in 2014, with 1.3 million downloads. Their first album, "Talking Dreams," came out on October 8, 2013.

The Goo Goo Dolls, a rock band from Buffalo, New York, started in 1985 with John Rzeznik, Robby Takac, and George Tutuska. Mike Malinin joined as drummer in 1995 but became official in 1998. Their hit song "Iris" in 1998 was a big success, but they've had other popular singles like "Name" and "Naked" from their album "A Boy Named Goo" in 1995, and "Slide," "Black Balloon," "Dizzy," and "Broadway" from "Dizzy Up the Girl" in 1998, among others. With 19 top ten singles and over 12 million albums sold worldwide, they've made quite a mark in the music industry.
neg: The song "All That You Are" by the Goo Goo Dolls is part of the soundtrack for a movie. It came out on June 14, 2011, alongside the movie's release. This song, along with singles from Linkin Park and Paramore, was released on iTunes the same day as the soundtrack. It's the second time the Goo Goo Dolls have contributed to a Transformers movie soundtrack, following their first song "Before It's Too Late (Sam and Mikaela's Theme)" for the movie "Transformers."

Check out "Live in Buffalo: July 4th, 2004," a live album by the Goo Goo Dolls, an American rock band. This album features a CD and a DVD showcasing their concert in Buffalo, New York, on July 4, 2004. The DVD includes nineteen songs performed live, and the CD includes a studio version of their cover of Supertramp's "Give A Little Bit." The concert took place downtown at Niagara Square, in front of Buffalo City Hall, and attracted over 60,000 fans despite heavy rain. The performance has been praised for its energy, with some comparing it to Talking Heads' "Stop Making Sense." Despite the rain interruption, the band persevered, briefly pausing for safety concerns and skipping three songs from the original setlist.

The first album by the American rock band Goo Goo Dolls is called "Goo Goo Dolls." All the songs on it are sung by bassist Robby Takac, who used to be the lead vocalist. It's quite hard to find compared to the band's other albums because it's only available as an LP, not in wide circulation, and out of print. The song "I'm Addicted" was the only one from this album included on the band's 2001 compilation album called "What I Learned About Ego, Opinion, Art & Commerce." Another song, "Torn Apart," was also on a compilation album called "Volume Two," which had other album tracks, b-sides, and rarities.

"Notbroken" is a song by the Goo Goo Dolls, released as the second single from their ninth studio album, "Something for the Rest of Us," which came out on August 31, 2010. The band's official website announced that "Notbroken" would be the album's second single.

The ninth album by the American rock band Goo Goo Dolls, "Something for the Rest of Us," came out on August 28, 2010, in Australia and August 31 in North America through Warner Bros. Records. They recorded it from spring to fall 2009 in Buffalo and Los Angeles, with producer Tim Palmer. Initially, they planned to release a single in November 2009 and the album in February 2010, but they went back to the studio in January 2010 to make improvements. Lead singer John Rzeznik wanted to dig deeper into the songs and also took time off for personal reasons, like spending time with his girlfriend. They worked with several producers, including Butch Vig and Rob Cavallo, who also produced their previous albums. The album has twelve songs, with "Home" being the first single released on June 8, 2010.

The Goo Goo Dolls released an EP called "Waiting for the Rest of It" in 2010 through Warner Bros. Records. It was given to everyone who bought tickets for the Something for the Rest of Us Tour starting from July 17. The EP was meant to hype up the Goo Goo Dolls' upcoming album, "Something for the Rest of Us."
The iTunes Originals – Goo Goo Dolls album, released digitally on August 1, 2006, features interviews and new versions of their songs that you can't find on any other CD.

"Hold Me Up" is the third album by the American rock band Goo Goo Dolls, released in 1990 by Metal Blade Records. It's seen as their first big debut with a major label, unlike their earlier self-organized albums. The album includes their first single, "There You Are," which also became their first music video. Some see this album as the band's final authentic garage rock work, and it's where John Rzeznik starts to take the lead as the band's main vocalist.

question: The Detroit mayoral elections of 2009 took place to fill the vacancy created by a politician who was sentenced to what?
pos: Kwame Malik Kilpatrick, born on June 8, 1970, is an ex-American politician. He was a Democratic Michigan state representative and also held the position of mayor in Detroit from 2002 to 2008. He stepped down from his role as mayor in September 2008 after being found guilty of lying under oath and interfering with legal proceedings. Kilpatrick was given a jail term of four months and was let out on probation after spending 99 days behind bars.
The Detroit mayoral elections of 2009 happened on May 5th, 2009. There was a primary held on February 24th, 2009 to choose a candidate to replace Kwame Kilpatrick, who had stepped down as mayor.
neg: Jane Marum Roush, a lawyer from Virginia, served temporarily as a Justice on the Supreme Court of Virginia. She was appointed by Governor Terry McAuliffe on July 27, 2015, to fill a vacancy until the next session of the Virginia General Assembly. However, the Assembly failed to elect her to a full twelve-year term, leading to uncertainty about her status. Despite legal debates, the governor reappointed her for a second temporary term, which ended on February 12, 2016, when the Assembly did not elect her for a full term during its regular session.

This is a timeline of municipal elections in Calgary, Alberta, Canada. Initially, mayoral elections were held annually until 1923 when they switched to every two years. In 1971, the mayoral term became three years. Similarly, council elections were yearly until 1914, then shifted to two-year terms, with half the council elected each year. In 1971, council elections synchronized with mayoral ones and also became three-year terms. In 1976, wards increased to 14, each represented by an alderman for three years. On December 14, 2010, council changed the title to councillor, effective in the October 2013 election. Additionally, in 2012, the Local Authorities Election Act extended the mayor and councillors' terms to four years.

Joseph F. Vitale, born on November 10, 1954, is an American Democratic Party politician. He's been a member of the New Jersey State Senate since 1998, representing the 19th Legislative District. Previously, he served as the Mayor of Woodbridge Township, New Jersey. He was appointed by the Township Council in July 2006 to temporarily fill the position after the death of Mayor Frank Pelzman. Vitale initially joined the Senate in 1998, filling a vacancy left by Jim McGreevey when he resigned to run for Governor of New Jersey in 1997, a bid that was ultimately unsuccessful.

In the 2010 United States Senate elections in Illinois on November 2, 2010, there were two opportunities to vote for the same Senate seat. One was for the regular term starting in January 2011, and the other was a special election to finish the term left by Roland Burris, who temporarily filled the seat after Barack Obama became president.

In 2013, local elections were held in the United Kingdom on May 2nd. This included voting in 35 English councils, which consisted of 27 non-metropolitan county councils, eight unitary authorities, and one Welsh unitary authority. Direct mayoral elections were also held in Doncaster and North Tyneside. The previous elections were in June 2009, except for County Durham, Northumberland, and Anglesey, where they occurred in 2008.

Brian DelGrosso, born around 1973, used to be a state representative in Colorado. He became a state representative when Don Marostica resigned in August 2009, and he was chosen by the Republican Party vacancy committee. DelGrosso represented House District 51, which includes Loveland. He won elections in 2010, 2012, and 2014 but didn't run for re-election in 2016 due to term limits. He left office in January 2016.

The Charlotte mayoral election of 2015 happened on November 3, 2015, to choose the Mayor of Charlotte, North Carolina. These elections occur every two years, and the newly elected mayor takes office in December.

Jon M. Bramnick, born on February 24, 1953, is an American politician from the Republican Party. He's been a member of the New Jersey General Assembly representing the 21st legislative district since 2003. Since January 2012, he's been the leader of the Republican members in the Assembly. He first joined the Assembly in 2003 to finish the term of Thomas Kean, Jr., who moved to the New Jersey Senate. After that, he won full two-year terms in 2003, 2005, 2007, 2009, 2011, 2013, and 2015.

question: In what year was the team that Luke Clark plays either right back or central midfielder for founded?
pos: Luke Stephen Clark, born on May 24, 1994, is an English football player currently on the roster of Curzon Ashton. He is versatile, capable of playing both as a right back and a central midfielder.

Curzon Ashton Football Club, known as the Nash, is a semi-professional football club from Ashton-under-Lyne, Greater Manchester, England. Founded in 1963, the club plays in the National League North, which is the sixth tier of the English football league system. They are affiliated with the Manchester County Football Association and have been based at the Tameside Stadium since 2005.
neg: Martin Linnes, born on September 20, 1991, is a Norwegian pro soccer player. He's known for his flexibility on the field, often switching between positions like right back, left back, central midfielder, right midfielder, and right winger. Currently, he's playing for Galatasaray in Turkey.

Leigh Michael Broxham, born on January 13, 1988, is an Australian soccer player. He mainly plays in midfield for Melbourne Victory in the A-League. Broxham is versatile, often playing defensively, but he can also fill in as an attacker or in various defensive positions like center back, left back, or right back.

Ibrahim Tall, born on June 23, 1981, in Aubervilliers, Paris, is a Senegalese football player. He currently plays for FC Stade Nyonnais. Tall is known for his ability to play in multiple defensive positions, including right back and center back.

Jorge Nicolás Pandiani Quaglia, also called Nicolás or Nico Pandiani, is a Uruguayan soccer player. He currently plays for the Canadian Soccer Club in the Uruguayan Segunda División. He can be found on the field either as a right back or as a central defender.
Michalis Bakakis, born on March 18, 1991, is a professional football player for AEK Athens. He's versatile, capable of playing as either a right back or a right midfielder.

Bjørn Helge Semundseth Riise, born on June 21, 1983, in Ålesund, is a Norwegian soccer player. He's currently on the team Aalesund, and he usually plays in the midfield or as a right winger. Riise has played 35 times for the Norwegian national team. From July 2009 to August 2012, he played for Fulham in the Premier League. He's the younger brother of John Arne Riise, who used to play for Liverpool and Fulham, and also represented Norway internationally.

Luke Anthony Hubbins, an English footballer born on September 11, 1991, started his career with Birmingham City. However, he made his professional debut in August 2010 while on loan to Notts County for the Football League Cup. He also had a short stint with Tamworth, a Conference National club. Despite being with Birmingham City, he never got a chance to play for their first team. He was released by the club at the end of the 2011–12 season. Later, he joined AFC Telford United in the Conference, where he played as either a winger or right back. Hubbins left AFC Telford United on May 2, 2013.

Atiqur Rahman Meshu, born on August 26, 1988, is a Bangladeshi football player. He currently plays defense for Brothers Union and the Bangladesh national football team. Meshu is versatile, often playing as a center back or right back. Notably, during the 2010 AFC Challenge Cup, his impressive diving header secured Bangladesh's victory over Tajikistan, marking their first-ever defeat against Bangladesh in history.

question: What genre of music was played by both Tappi Tíkarrass and INXS?
pos: Tappi Tíkarrass was a punk band from Iceland that blended funk, rock, and jazz into their music, setting them apart from other bands of their era. It's also recognized as the earliest significant music endeavor of the now-famous singer Björk Guðmundsdóttir.

INXS was an Australian rock band that started in 1977 in Sydney, New South Wales, initially known as The Farriss Brothers. They began by playing cover songs in pubs and clubs in Western Australia and occasionally performed their own music. The band's core members were Andrew Farriss (main composer and keyboardist), Jon Farriss (drummer), Tim Farriss and Kirk Pengilly (guitarists), Garry Gary Beers (bassist), and Michael Hutchence (main lyricist and vocalist). Hutchence, with his charismatic stage presence and striking appearance, led the band for twenty years. While they started with a new wave/pop sound, they later adopted a harder pub rock style infused with funk and dance elements.
neg: "Bitið fast í vitið," which translates to "Bite Hard In Your Mind" in English, is the first EP by the Icelandic punk/pop band Tappi Tíkarrass. It came out in late 1982 on the Spor label, shortly after the band formed in September 1981, led by vocalists Björk and Eyþór Arnalds. This EP leans heavily into punk music and includes five tracks, including one titled "London" in English.

Steeltown was a band from Brisbane, Australia, active in the 1990s. They played a mix of synth, rock, and pop music, and their biggest hit was 'Hero,' which came out in September 1991 and made it to the top forty charts. They were particularly successful in Queensland, outselling other bands from the region at that time. You can find their music video and live performances on YouTube. The band members included Andy Richmond on vocals, Peter Howard on keyboards, Terry Gidman on drums, Kate Richmond on vocals and percussion, and Reece Speceis on lead guitar. Steeltown was formed by former members of a Scottish band called the Technicians, who moved to Australia in the 1980s. The Technicians also had several top 40 hits with songs like 'Hot for Love,' 'Clockwork Clown,' and 'Soldier of Fortune,' released through record labels like Powderworks, EMI, and BMG. Their music was published by MMA, which was associated with the famous rock band INXS.

"Nýtt Líf" (English: New Life) is an Icelandic comedy film released in 1983, directed by Þráinn Bertelsson. It was filmed in the Westman Islands and features actors like Eggert Þorleifsson and Karl Ágúst Úlfsson. The soundtrack includes songs by various musicians, including the band Tappi Tíkarrass, in which Björk was a member. They contributed songs like "Sperglar" and "Kukl" (also known as "Seiður").

Disco polo is a type of dance music that originated in Poland in the late 1980s. Initially called sidewalks music, it became popular in the mid to late 1990s, peaking around 1995–1997. However, its popularity declined in the early 2000s before experiencing a resurgence in late 2007. The Polish Dictionary from Publishing PWN describes disco polo as a Polish version of disco music, featuring simple melodies. It's a blend of disco, Euro disco, contemporary folk music, influenced by Italo disco and Polish folk songs. Often played at weddings and celebrations, it has elements of city folklore music.

Kidandali is a type of music style unique to Uganda, along with Kadongo Kamu. It comes from the Ganda language and translates to "local party" or "celebration." Think of it as the music you'd hear at traditional weddings or community gatherings. Some people also call it Band music or Afrobeat.

Rave music originally emerged in the late 1980s and early 1990s, featuring genres like house, breakbeat, acid house, techno, and hardcore techno. It was the staple music at rave parties. Over time, the term expanded to include any electronic dance music (EDM) played at raves. Originating from the UK acid movement, rave, also known as hardcore, started in underground venues like warehouse parties and pirate radio stations. It evolved into oldschool hardcore and gave rise to newer styles like drum and bass, 2-step, and hardcore techno genres such as gabber, hardstyle, and happy hardcore. Rave music is typically heard in DJ mix sets, although live performances are also common.

Folk rock is a music style that blends folk music with rock. It started in the mid-1960s in the US and UK. Bands like the Beatles and Bob Dylan mixed traditional folk tunes with rock instruments. The term "folk rock" was coined by the US music press in June 1965 to describe the Byrds' music when they released their first album.
Miranda is the debut album by the Icelandic punk band Tappi Tíkarrass. It came out on December 23, 1983, under the Gramm label.

question: A puzzle-platform video game developed by the Valve Corporation is part of what 2012 action-adventure game?
pos: Gateways is a video game made by the British indie studio Smudged Cat Games in 2012. It combines gameplay ideas from the Portal and Metroid series, blending action, adventure, and platforming elements.

Portal is a game where you solve puzzles and navigate platforms. It was made by Valve Corporation and first came out in 2007 as part of a bundle called The Orange Box for PC, Xbox 360, and PlayStation 3. Since then, it's been adapted for other platforms like OS X, Linux, and Android.
neg: Fez, stylized as FEZ, is a puzzle-platform video game made by Polytron Corporation and published by Trapdoor. In the game, you play as Gomez, who gets a fez that lets him see his flat, 2D world as just one side of a 3D world with four sides. You switch between these four 2D views to move platforms and solve puzzles. The goal is to gather cubes and cube fragments to bring order back to the universe.

"Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time" is a video game made by Ubisoft. It came out in November 2003 for several platforms like Game Boy Advance, PlayStation 2, GameCube, Xbox, and Microsoft Windows. It's part of the Prince of Persia series, which got a fresh start with this game. Jordan Mechner, the creator of the series, helped out as a creative consultant, designer, and writer for "The Sands of Time."

Team Fortress 2 (TF2) is a multiplayer video game made by Valve Corporation. It's a first-person shooter game where players work in teams. TF2 is the follow-up to a mod from 1996 called Team Fortress for Quake, and its remake in 1999 called Team Fortress Classic. The game first came out in 2007 as part of a bundle called The Orange Box for Windows and Xbox 360. A version for PlayStation 3 came out later in 2007. It became available as a standalone game for Windows in 2008, and later on for Mac OS X in 2010 and Linux in 2013. You can get the game online through Valve's Steam platform, or buy a physical copy from Electronic Arts.

Half-Life 2: Lost Coast is an extra level for the 2004 game Half-Life 2. It was made by Valve Corporation and came out on October 27, 2005, for free on Steam for people who had the Windows version of Half-Life 2. Lost Coast is like a demo showing off the high-dynamic-range graphics in the Source engine. The level has different areas to show these effects well. Also, it was Valve's first game where developers could talk about the design while players go through the level.

The Lost Vikings is a video game where you solve puzzles and jump around platforms. It was made by a company that's now called Blizzard Entertainment and first came out for the Super NES in 1992. Later on, it was also released for other systems like the Amiga, MS-DOS, and Mega Drive/Genesis. The Mega Drive/Genesis version has extra stages that aren't in any other version. Blizzard put out a version for the Game Boy Advance in 2003, and in 2014, they made it available for free on Battle.net, which you can play using DOSBox.

Summary: Aperture Tag: The Paint Gun Testing Initiative is a video game created by the Aperture Tag Team in 2014. It started as a modification of Valve Corporation's Portal series but was later approved by Valve for sale on Steam. Unlike the original Portal games, it doesn't have the portal gun. Instead, it introduces a paint gun that shoots two types of gel. The game includes new characters, voice acting, 27 levels, and a co-op mode with a level editor.

Portal 2, a video game made by Valve Corporation in 2011, is a follow-up to the game Portal from 2007. It came out on April 19, 2011, for computers (Microsoft Windows, OS X, Linux), PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360. You can buy the physical copies of the game from Electronic Arts, or get it online for Windows, Mac, and Linux through Valve's service called Steam. The announcement for Portal 2 was made on March 5, 2010, after a week of a special game connected to the original Portal. Before the official release on Steam, they did another special event called the Potato Sack, with 13 small games. This ended with a funny event to launch Portal 2 a few hours early.

Portal is a video game series where you solve puzzles by creating portals between surfaces. You play as Chell, who is trapped in a testing facility controlled by a mean computer named GLaDOS. Using a device called the portal gun, you create openings that let you or objects move between different areas. You use these portals to solve puzzles, like crossing gaps or avoiding obstacles, to reach the end of each level. Along the way, you encounter various obstacles like lasers, turrets, and other gadgets that either help or hinder your progress.

question: What produces the hormone that promotes sodium retention in the distal nephron?
pos: Angiotensin is a hormone that narrows blood vessels, leading to higher blood pressure. It's part of the renin-angiotensin system, a key target for drugs that raise blood pressure. Angiotensin also triggers the adrenal cortex to release aldosterone, another hormone. Aldosterone makes the kidneys hold onto sodium, further increasing blood pressure.

Aldosterone is a hormone made in the adrenal gland that helps regulate sodium levels in the body. It mainly acts on the kidneys, controlling how much sodium is kept and how much potassium is released in the urine. This affects blood pressure and volume. When aldosterone levels are off, it can lead to heart and kidney problems. It works opposite to another hormone called atrial natriuretic hormone, which is made by the heart.
neg: The sodium-chloride symporter, also called Na-Cl cotransporter or NCC, is a protein in the kidney that helps absorb sodium and chloride ions from the tubular fluid into cells in a part of the kidney called the distal convoluted tubule. It belongs to a group of proteins called SLC12 cotransporters, which move ions without creating an electric charge. In humans, the gene responsible for this protein is called SLC12A3 and is found on chromosome 16.

In the kidney, the loop of Henle, also known as Henle's loop or nephron loop, is a part of the nephron that connects the proximal convoluted tubule to the distal convoluted tubule. Named after its discoverer, Friedrich Gustav Jakob Henle, its main job is to help the kidney create a concentration gradient in the medulla.

Low pressure receptors, also known as volume receptors, are sensors found in the venae cavae, pulmonary arteries, and atria. They detect changes in the tension of the vessel walls, which corresponds to how full the low-pressure part of the circulatory system is (below 60mmHg). These receptors send signals that control the release of hormones like antidiuretic hormone (ADH/Vasopressin), renin, and aldosterone. When atrial pressure rises, it leads to a decrease in ADH and aldosterone release, causing more urine to be produced and thus lowering blood pressure. Additionally, when atrial receptors stretch, they prompt the secretion of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), which encourages the kidneys to excrete more water and sodium through urine.

Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is a condition where acid builds up in the body because the kidneys can't properly make urine acidic. In the kidneys, blood is filtered, and the filtered fluid passes through tubules where salts, acids, and other substances are exchanged before becoming urine. RTA can happen because the kidneys either don't reabsorb enough bicarbonate ions (which are alkaline) in the early part of the tubules or don't release enough hydrogen ions (which are acidic) later on. Unlike kidney problems where the kidneys don't work well, RTA specifically refers to poor urine acidification in kidneys that are otherwise healthy. There are different types of RTA with different symptoms and causes.

In the kidney's nephron, the ascending limb of the loop of Henle comes after the descending limb and the loop's sharp bend. This part of the kidney's tube is split into a thin and thick ascending limb. The thick part is also called the distal straight tubule, which is different from the distal convoluted tubule that comes next.

In the kidney's physiology, tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) is a system that helps the kidneys regulate the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Each nephron, a functional unit in the kidney, has this feedback mechanism. It works by sending information from the renal tubules (where the tubular fluid is) to the glomerulus (where filtration begins). When the concentration of sodium chloride increases in the distal tubules, it triggers the release of adenosine from specific cells called macula densa cells. This release of adenosine sets off a series of events that adjust the GFR to an appropriate level.

Sylvia Agnes Sophia Tait, born in 1917 and passing away in 2003, was an English scientist who specialized in biochemistry and endocrinology. She collaborated closely with her second husband, James Francis Tait, from 1948 until her death. Together, they discovered a hormone called aldosterone, which plays a crucial role in regulating blood pressure by controlling sodium levels, potassium secretion, water retention, and increasing blood pressure. This discovery was significant as aldosterone was the last of a group of important steroid hormones to be identified during the mid-20th century. It's estimated that aldosterone is involved in about 15% of cases of high blood pressure.

Distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA), also known as Type 1 renal tubular acidosis (RTA), is the earliest recognized form of RTA. It happens when a specific type of cells in the kidney's collecting ducts can't properly release acid. This can be caused by various factors and results in the urine not becoming acidic enough, usually staying above a pH of 5.3.

question: How many Senate seats will be contested during the midterm elections that Nancy Soderberg has filed to run for Congress in?
pos: The 2018 US elections are happening on Tuesday, November 6, 2018. These are midterm elections, which means they're taking place halfway through President Donald Trump's term as a Republican president. In these elections, all 435 seats in the US House of Representatives and 33 out of the 100 seats in the US Senate will be up for grabs. Additionally, there will be contests for 39 state and territorial governorships, as well as many other state and local elections.

Nancy Elisabet Soderberg, born in 1958, is an American expert in foreign policy. She worked for President Bill Clinton as Deputy National Security Advisor and as a United Nations Ambassador. Currently, she heads Soderberg Global Solutions, teaches at the University of North Florida, and chaired the Public Interest Declassification Board under President Obama. She has held various positions, including president of Connect U.S. Fund, vice president of the International Crisis Group, and board member of the Jacksonville Port Authority. She's advised Senator Edward M. Kennedy and contributed to four presidential campaigns. Soderberg is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and frequently appears on TV and radio. She's authored many articles and two books on American foreign policy. Soderberg earned a Master's from Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service in 1984 and a Bachelor's from Vanderbilt University in 1980. She also ran for Congress in Florida's 6th Congressional District in 2018 as a Democrat.
neg: The Wisconsin general elections in 2016 took place on November 8, 2016. During these elections, Wisconsin residents voted for one of the state's U.S. Senate seats, all eight seats in the United States House of Representatives, half of the Wisconsin Senate seats, and all of the Wisconsin Assembly seats. Primary elections occurred on August 9, 2016.

Midterm elections in the United States happen every two years, halfway through the president's four-year term. During these elections, people vote for members of Congress, such as all 435 seats in the House of Representatives, and about a third of the seats in the Senate.

In the United States Senate, there are three groups of senators, with either 33 or 34 seats in each group. These groups, called classes, help decide which seats are open for election every two years. This setup means that not all 100 seats are up for election at the same time. For instance, Class 1 senators, consisting of 33 seats, were elected in 2012, Class 2 senators, also 33 seats, were elected in 2014, and Class 3 senators, with 34 seats, were elected in 2016.

The TEAM Unity (Together Everybody Achieves More) Unity was a political alliance formed for the 2007 Philippine Midterm Elections. It included supporters and former critics of ex-President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo. The goal of Team Unity was to win Senate seats to prevent President Arroyo from facing impeachment attempts by the opposition after the elections.

The Eightieth United States Congress was a period when the government's lawmakers, the Senate and the House of Representatives, gathered in Washington, DC from January 3, 1947, to January 3, 1949, while Harry Truman was president. Republicans gained control of both chambers during this time by winning more Senate and House seats. Despite passing many bills, Truman called it the Do Nothing Congress and campaigned against it in the 1948 election. They passed some pro-business laws like the Taft–Hartley Act but opposed many of Truman's ideas. Truman's strategy worked, and the Democrats gained more seats in the next Congress.

The 2002 United States elections took place on November 5, during Republican President George W. Bush's first term. In an uncommon outcome for midterm elections, the president's party, the Republicans, won more seats in both the Senate and the House of Representatives. Specifically, they gained 2 Senate seats and 8 House seats.

In the 2008 United States Senate elections, 35 out of 100 seats were up for grabs. Of these, 33 were for regular six-year terms starting from January 3, 2009. These senators would belong to Class 2. Additionally, there were two special elections in Mississippi and Wyoming for Class 1 Senate seats. The winners of these special elections would serve the remaining term until January 3, 2013.

The 2002 United States Senate elections were intense battles where the Republican Party won, gaining two seats. This gave them a slight edge over the Democratic Party in the Senate. These elections were for class 2 Senate seats, last contested in 1996. They took place on November 5, 2002, about fourteen months after the September 11, 2001 attacks.

question: In between Berghuis v. Thompkins and Mississippi University for Women v. Hogan which one was a  case decided 5-4 by the Supreme Court of the United States?
pos: In the case of Mississippi University for Women v. Hogan, decided in 1982 by a 5-4 vote, the Supreme Court ruled that the university's policy of admitting only one gender violated the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause.

Berghuis v. Thompkins, a 2010 ruling by the U.S. Supreme Court (case number 08-1470), tackled the scenario of a suspect who knows about their right to stay silent under Miranda v. Arizona but doesn't clearly say if they want to use that right or not.
neg: In 1973, the Supreme Court of Florida made a significant decision in the case Hoffman v. Jones. This case marked the first time a court, rather than a legislature, introduced the idea of comparative negligence in negligence law. It involved the death of William Harrison Jones Jr. caused by a Pav-A-Way Corporation truck driven by Philip Francis Hoffman Jr. This ruling was groundbreaking because it ended the long-standing contributory negligence doctrine, allowing victims to recover damages even if they were partially at fault. Florida adopted "pure" comparative negligence, meaning victims can receive compensation based on the percentage of harm caused by the responsible party. Hoffman v. Jones is a landmark case often referenced in legal education materials, and comparative negligence is now widely accepted in legal practice.

Van Staphorst v. Maryland, 2 U.S. (2 Dall.) 401 (1791), was the first case officially recorded in the United States Supreme Court. Even though the court was ready to hear and rule on the case, it got resolved before any arguments were made. Collet v. Collet was the first appeal case documented with the court, while West v. Barnes was the first case where the court delivered a decision.

In the 2016 case of Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt, the U.S. Supreme Court made an important decision on June 27, 2016. They voted 5-3 to say that Texas couldn't make rules about abortion that made it too hard for women to get one. The next day, on June 28, the Supreme Court said no to challenges from Wisconsin and Mississippi, where lower courts had already said similar rules were not okay. This decision could affect other states with similar rules too.

In the case of Hirabayashi v. United States in 1943, the Supreme Court ruled that it was okay to impose curfews on people from a specific minority group during wartime, as long as the country was at war with the group's country of origin. This case came about after President Roosevelt issued Executive Order 9066 in response to the Pearl Harbor attack, leading to restrictions on Japanese Americans, including curfews and internment camps. Gordon Hirabayashi, the plaintiff, challenged his conviction for breaking the curfew, which was eventually overturned in the 1980s, along with a similar case called Yasui v. United States.

In the Banks v. Commissioner case of 2005, the Supreme Court decided whether the money a taxpayer pays to their attorney from a judgment or settlement should be counted as income for federal tax purposes. They ruled that if the taxpayer receives income from a recovery, the part paid to the attorney as a contingent fee is also considered income for the taxpayer. However, there's a special rule for employment cases due to the Civil Rights Tax Relief in the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004. This law lets taxpayers subtract attorney’s fees from their gross income when calculating their adjusted gross income.

In the Summers v. Earth Island Institute case in 2009, several environmental groups sued the US Forest Service. They wanted to stop the agency from selling timber from 238 acres of fire-damaged federal land without following the proper process of notifying the public, allowing comments, and providing a way to appeal, as required by the Forest Service Decision-making and Appeals Reform Act.

United States v. Quiver, 241 U.S. 602 (1916), is a case where the United States Supreme Court ruled on adultery between two Oglala Sioux Tribe members on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota. The case started in a district court in South Dakota. Initially, the district court said the adultery wasn't punishable under the 1887 law because it happened on an Indian reservation, which wasn't under its jurisdiction. The Supreme Court agreed, saying that adultery between Native Americans on a reservation wasn't punishable under federal law.

In the case of V.L. v. E.L. (2016), the Supreme Court addressed adoption rights for same-sex couples. Initially, a Georgia court granted V.L., the partner of E.L., adoption rights to their three children. When the couple split and moved to Alabama, E.L. tried to prevent V.L. from seeing the children. The Alabama Supreme Court refused to recognize the Georgia adoption judgment, prompting V.L. to appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court. Ultimately, on March 7, 2016, the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Alabama's decision, allowing V.L. to maintain parental rights.

question: Which jazz singer has a 2003 album entitled The Boy Next Door?
pos: Stacey Kent, an American jazz singer, is married to saxophonist Jim Tomlinson.
"The Boy Next Door" is a jazz album released in 2003 by singer Stacey Kent. She picked songs for the album that were originally performed by male singers she admires.
neg: "Hold Me in Your Arms" is Rick Astley's second album, which came out in November 1988, following his debut, "Whenever You Need Somebody." Half of the songs were written and produced by Stock Aitken & Waterman, while the other half were Astley's own creations produced by PWL associates Phil Harding, Ian Curnow, and Daize Washbourn. The album's release was delayed due to a fire at PWL Studios, which damaged some of Astley's recorded material. This marked Astley's final collaboration with Stock, Aitken & Waterman, as he wanted to move away from their dance-pop style, change his image, and focus more on his original compositions, as seen in his 1991 release, "Free."

The song "Boy Next Door" is the fifth single by British R&B artist Jamelia and the last one from her first album, Drama. It didn't do as well as her other songs, not making it into the top 40 in the UK. It reached number 42 and stayed in the top 75 for just two weeks. The single version is a bit different from the album version, with a slight remix and a shorter length.
"Not the Boy Next Door" is an album by Australian singer and songwriter Peter Allen, released in 1983. It marked his debut with Arista Records.
The boy next door is a common character in stories, often representing a wholesome, average guy. He's typically seen as a love interest for a girl who lives nearby.

American jazz singer Stacey Kent recorded it for her album "The Boy Next Door" in 2003. Other artists who have covered the song include Stan Getz, Bruce Eskovitz, Carmen McRae, Lee Konitz, Spike Robinson, Eddie Higgins, and Bennie Wallace.

"Superstar – The Hits" is a compilation of Jamelia's best songs, released by Parlophone Records on September 24, 2007. It includes ten of her UK Top 40 singles, excluding her debut single "So High," her first top forty hit "I Do," the single "Boy Next Door," and her collaboration with Tiziano Ferro, "Universal Prayer," which was not released in the UK. However, the album does include her version of "Stop," marking its first appearance on a Jamelia album.

Fire! is a manga series by Hideko Mizuno that tells the story of an American rock star named Aaron. Serialized in Seventeen from 1969 to 1971, it won the 1970 Shogakukan Manga Award. Aaron, the main character, is not your typical "boy next door" or "shining prince." Sandra Buckley points out that fans were drawn to his unconventional and rebellious behavior. This series was groundbreaking for shōjo manga, featuring the first sexually explicit scenes in post-World War II manga and a male protagonist. While some view the story as a conservative lesson, Buckley notes that fans avidly followed Aaron's adventures for two years, with reports of teenage girls eagerly awaiting each new issue.

Boy Meets Girl is a chick lit novel written by American author Meg Cabot in 2004. It was first published under the name Meggin Cabot in January 2004 by HarperCollins Publishers. Later editions of Boy Meets Girl were released under Meg Cabot's actual name. This book is part of the Boy series, but it's only loosely linked to the previous book, The Boy Next Door.

question: The actor who appeared on Charlotte's Shorts and Weeds was born in what year?
pos: Charlotte's Shorts is a 90-minute live performance showcasing short stories written by Charlotte Dean. The cast typically includes current and former members of the Groundlings, like Tim Bagley, Jim Rash, Jillian Bell, and others. In 2014, the show was staged at different theaters in Los Angeles, including two performances at The Groundlings Theater. It's also a highlight at events like SF Sketchfest and The Hollywood Fringe Festival.

Gary Anthony Williams, born on March 14, 1966, is an American actor and comedian known for his roles such as Uncle Ruckus in The Boondocks, Yancy Westridge in the video game Alpha Protocol, and Horace Warfield in . He has appeared in various TV shows including Weeds, Boston Legal, Blue Collar TV, and Malcolm in the Middle as Abe Kenarban. Williams is also the co-founder and Artistic Director of the L.A. Comedy Shorts film festival in Hollywood, California. Additionally, he starred alongside Cedric the Entertainer in the popular TV Land sitcom The Soul Man, and he's a regular on Whose Line is it Anyway?.
neg: "A Story of Floating Weeds" is a silent film from 1934 by Yasujirō Ozu. He remade it in color as "Floating Weeds" in 1959. The film won the Kinema Junpo Award for best film, marking the third year in a row that an Ozu film received this honor, following "I Was Born, But..." and "Passing Fancy."

Milton, a series of animated shorts by Mike Judge from 1991, aired on Saturday Night Live and MTV's Liquid Television in the 1990s. The 1999 movie Office Space was inspired by these cartoons, with actor Stephen Root playing Milton Waddams. Mike Judge voiced all characters in the shorts. While Milton was the main character in the shorts, he played a supporting role in Office Space alongside his boss, Bill Lumbergh (played by Gary Cole). Despite always being late, Milton managed to travel to various places in the shorts.

Andy Milder, born on August 16, 1969, is an American actor known for his roles in movies like Apollo 13, Armageddon, Rumor Has It…, Frost/Nixon, Transformers, and Domino. He's been a regular on TV series like Fame L.A. and Weeds, and made appearances on shows such as The West Wing, Six Feet Under, Ugly Betty, Boston Legal, Parks and Recreation, Married... with Children, The Wonder Years, Private Practice, and Criminal Minds. Milder has also provided narration for several programs like Ballroom Bootcamp, 101 Most Starlicious Make-Overs, and Wrecks to Riches. He voiced characters in the video game and animated series Legion of Super Heroes. From 2005 to 2009, he played Dean Hodes in Weeds, and since 2011, he's been recurring on the Disney Channel sitcom Austin & Ally as Lester Dawson. Additionally, he made an appearance on the show Royal Pains on the USA Network.

Harry Bowen was an American actor who worked in both silent and sound films. He was born on October 4, 1888, in Brooklyn, New York. He started his career in short films during the silent era and continued into talking pictures. In 1929, he had a small role in his first full-length feature film, "Red Hot Rhythm," directed by Leo McCarey. Over his 20-year career, Bowen appeared in more than 150 films, mostly shorts. Some of his notable appearances include "King Kong" (1933), "Flying Down to Rio" (1933) which starred Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, John Ford's comedy "The Whole Town's Talking" (1935), and "Next Time We Love" (1936) with Margaret Sullavan, James Stewart, and Ray Milland. His last known film performance was in the 1939 film "The Day the Bookies Wept."

Spencer Bell was a famous American actor who worked in both stage and film. He's most remembered for his roles alongside Larry Semon in silent comedy shorts from the late 1910s to 1928. Bell was among the earliest African American comedic actors in silent films and was the first to get a film contract. During his fifteen-year career in films, he starred in over seventy comedy shorts.

Billy Sullivan, also known as W. A. Sullivan, William A. Sullivan, and Arthur Sullivan, was an American actor who worked in silent and early sound films. He was born on Long Island, New York, on July 18, 1891. Sullivan began his film career in the 1910s with short films. His first movie was part of a serial called "The Million Dollar Mystery" in 1914, which later became a full-length film in 1918. He had his first major role as King Arthur in "Over the Hill" in 1917. In the early 1920s, he mostly worked in short films before transitioning to feature films in 1925. From 1924 to 1927, he starred in around 20 films for Rayart Pictures, including titles like "The Slanderers" (1924), "Goat Getter" (1925), "The Winner" (1926), and "When Seconds Count" (1927). Throughout his career, he appeared in over 80 productions, including more than 50 feature films.

Charles Eldridge (1854–1922) was an American actor who worked on both stage and screen during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He acted in over 100 films, mostly short ones, and began his career on stage in the 1870s. His first film role was in a 1910 short called "The Legacy," and he later appeared in his first feature film, "The Strange Story of Sylvia Gray." Alongside his many short film appearances, Eldridge also acted in 27 feature films between 1914 and 1922. While he usually played supporting roles in full-length films, he occasionally took on lead roles, such as in "Polly of the Circus" (1917), "Broken Hearts" (1920), and "Ashamed of Parents" (1922). "Polly of the Circus" was particularly noteworthy as it was the debut film of Goldwyn Pictures and was filmed in Fort Lee, New Jersey, mostly at Universal Studios' rented space.

Andy Umberger is an American actor who began his career in New York City, mostly acting on stage. He appeared in three Broadway productions: "City Of Angels," "Passion," and "Company." After relocating to Los Angeles in the late 90s, he transitioned to film and television. He's been in over 15 films in supporting roles and has appeared as a guest on more than 60 TV shows. He's had recurring roles on 10 different series, including popular ones like "Mad Men," "Weeds," "Boston Legal," "The West Wing," "Desperate Housewives," and "ER." He also played D'Hoffryn on "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" and is one of only five actors to appear in three series created by Joss Whedon: "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," "Angel," and "Firefly."

question: After he was contracted by the team that is headquartered in Affalterbach, Baden-Württemberg, Germany, Dario Franchitti competed in what series?
pos: AMG, short for Mercedes-AMG GmbH, is the part of Mercedes-Benz that makes really fast cars. They work separately from Mercedes-Benz, hiring their own engineers and building and customizing their own cars. Their main office is in Germany. AMG used to be its own company, focused on making Mercedes-Benz cars faster, but Mercedes-Benz took control of it in 1999 and now owns it completely. So, now AMG is like a little brother to Mercedes-Benz, part of the same big family company.

Dario Franchitti, born on May 19, 1973, and also known as George Dario Marino Franchitti, is a retired racing driver from Scotland. He achieved significant success in the IndyCar Series, winning the championship four times (in 2007, 2009, 2010, and 2011) and the Indianapolis 500 three times (in 2007, 2010, and 2012). Additionally, he won the 24 Hours of Daytona in 2008. Franchitti began his racing career in the UK during the early 1990s, competing in Formula Vauxhall and Formula Three. He won the McLaren Autosport BRDC Award in 1992. After struggling to find a single-seater racing opportunity in 1995, he joined the AMG team to race in touring cars in the DTM and later in the International Touring Car Championship. Although he had some success, the series ended after the 1996 season, leaving Franchitti without a drive again. Mercedes then placed him in CART in 1997, driving for the Hogan Racing team.
neg: The 2007 Firestone Indy 400 took place at Michigan International Speedway as part of the 2007 IRL IndyCar Series on August 3–5, 2007. It was the thirteenth race out of seventeen for the season and marked the series' last event at the track, at least for the time being. Notably, only seven cars completed the race due to a major accident on lap 144 involving Dario Franchitti flipping upside-down after colliding with Dan Wheldon. Fortunately, Franchitti emerged from the incident uninjured.

Johnny Mowlem, born on February 12, 1969, is a British professional racing driver known for his skill in sports car racing. He's won various championships, including the 2013 European Le Mans Series GT championship and the British Porsche Cup championship in 1996 and 1997. Throughout his career, he's achieved victories and podium finishes in prestigious races like the 24 Hours of Daytona, the 12 Hours of Sebring, and the Le Mans 24 hours. Mowlem transitioned from single-seater racing to sports cars in 1996, gaining international recognition. He's also known for driving the hybrid-powered Ginetta Zytek prototype racer and for his involvement with Lotus Racing. Besides racing, Mowlem runs his own driving academy, catering to corporate clients and aspiring racers.

Marino Alessandro Cesare Franchitti, born on July 7, 1978, is a British racing driver. He's also the younger brother of Dario Franchitti. Marino has mainly raced sports cars and grand tourers throughout his career. One of his biggest achievements was winning the 2014 12 Hours of Sebring race.

The 2011 Indy Grand Prix of Sonoma was the seventh race in Sonoma for the IndyCar Series in 2011. It happened on August 28th at the Infineon Raceway in Sonoma, California. Will Power led most of the race, with Team Penske taking the top three spots on the podium. This was the first time Penske had achieved this since 1994. With this win, Power narrowed the gap in the championship standings with Dario Franchitti. Also, he closed in on Franchitti's lead for the Mario Andretti Road Course Trophy. Simon Pagenaud filled in for Simona de Silvestro, who couldn't race due to visa issues.

In July 10, 2011, the 2011 Honda Indy Toronto race happened at the Exhibition Place temporary street circuit in Toronto, Canada. Dario Franchitti came in first, followed by his teammate Scott Dixon in second place, and Ryan Hunter-Reay in third. Despite winning pole position and leading the most laps, Will Power ended up finishing 24th due to a collision with Dario Franchitti and Alex Tagliani, who were also competing for the championship.

In July 2009, the 2009 Honda Indy Toronto race took place in Toronto, Canada, at a temporary street circuit called Exhibition Place. Dario Franchitti won the race, making it his third win of the season and joining his teammate Scott Dixon as the only drivers with three wins that year. Franchitti also took back the lead in the championship from Dixon, leading by two points as they headed to the next race in Edmonton. Ryan Briscoe came in second, marking his fifth second-place finish in the last six races, while Will Power, returning to the series, finished third for Penske Racing.

The 1998 Molson Indy Vancouver was the fifteenth race in the 1998 CART FedEx Champ Car World Series season. It happened on September 6, 1998, at Concord Pacific Place in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. Dario Franchitti won the race for the second time in a row by overtaking Michael Andretti for the lead with seven laps remaining. This victory made Franchitti the first driver in over a year to win a race from the pole position.

The 2002 Gran Premio Telmex-Gigante marked the final race of the 2002 CART FedEx Champ Car World Series season, held on November 17, 2002, at the Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez in Mexico City, Mexico. This event was significant as it was the first Champ Car race at this track since 1981. It also saw many drivers and teams participating in their last Champ Car event before moving to the rival Indy Racing League (IRL). Drivers like Michael Andretti, Kenny Brack, Scott Dixon, Dario Franchitti, Tony Kanaan, and Tora Takagi chose to leave CART for the IRL, while teams such as Chip Ganassi Racing, Team KOOL Green, and Mo Nunn Racing made permanent switches to the IRL. Additionally, major automotive companies like Honda and Toyota also shifted their support from CART to the IRL. Season champion Cristiano da Matta planned to leave CART for Formula One, and Christian Fittipaldi explored a career in stock car racing.

question: In which year did this division, where Cleveland Browns placed fourth in 2009, adopt its current name?
pos: In 2009, the Cleveland Browns had their 61st season playing pro football and their 57th in the NFL. They finished fourth in the AFC North with a 5–11 record, better than the previous year's 4–12. It was the first season for George Kokinis as the general manager and Eric Mangini as the head coach, but Kokinis got fired on November 2. They played all their home games at Cleveland Browns Stadium in Cleveland, Ohio.

The AFC North is a division within the NFL's American Football Conference (AFC). It started in 1970 as the AFC Central after the NFL and AFL merged. The Cleveland Browns and the Pittsburgh Steelers joined the AFC from the old NFL to balance the number of teams in each conference. In 2002, the division was renamed the AFC North when the league expanded to 32 teams and realigned divisions.
neg: In 2008, the Cleveland Browns had their 60th season as a pro sports team and their 56th in the NFL. They ended with a 4–12 record and missed the playoffs. Romeo Crennel coached for the last time that year. They played their home games at Cleveland Browns Stadium. During the season, they didn't score a touchdown for 24 quarters straight. Since 2008, the Browns haven't had a winning record or made the playoffs for seven years in a row.

In 2010, the Cleveland Browns had their 62nd season as a pro sports team and their 58th season in the NFL. They didn't make it to the playoffs for the eighth year in a row, which is their longest drought ever. They ended the season with 5 wins and 11 losses, the same as in 2009, and came in third in the AFC North. This was the first season with Mike Holmgren as team president and Tom Heckert as general manager, and the second season with Eric Mangini as head coach. They played all their home games at Cleveland Browns Stadium in Ohio.

The Cleveland Browns had their 63rd season in pro sports and 59th in the NFL. They aimed to do better than their 2010 record of 5-11, but were out of playoff contention by Week 14. This was their second season led by president Mike Holmgren and general manager Tom Heckert, and the first with head coach Pat Shurmur. They played all home games at Cleveland Browns Stadium in Cleveland, Ohio.

Freddie S. Summers, born on February 16, 1947, used to play professional American football as a defensive back for the Cleveland Browns in the NFL for three seasons. He started his football journey after being drafted by the Cleveland Browns in 1969. Summers initially went to McCook Community College before heading to Wake Forest University, where he played as a quarterback. He went to Dorchester High School in Dorchester, Boston, Massachusetts. Later, on June 15, 1972, he was traded to the New York Giants in exchange for a draft pick. Unfortunately, he got injured and was put on waivers on August 30, 1972.

Lamar A. Chapman, born on November 6, 1976, used to play as a cornerback in American football. He spent two seasons with the Cleveland Browns in the NFL. He got picked by the Browns in the fifth round of the 2000 NFL Draft after playing college football at Kansas State University. Chapman went to Liberal High School in Liberal, Kansas. Unfortunately, he got put on the waived/injured list by the Browns on August 5, 2002.

Ronald Wayne Snidow, born in 1941 and passing away in 2009, was a defensive tackle in the NFL, playing for the Washington Redskins and the Cleveland Browns. He went to high school in California and played college football at the University of Oregon. He was drafted by the Redskins in 1963, later traded to the Browns in 1968. Snidow achieved All-Pro status in 1969 but retired in 1972 due to a broken leg. After football, he worked in real estate until his retirement. He battled Lou Gehrig's disease and passed away in 2009 while on vacation in Italy.

The Cleveland Browns had their 64th season as a pro sports franchise and 60th in the NFL in 2012. They improved from 4–12 in 2011 to 5–11 but still ended fourth in the AFC North. Their playoff drought extended to 9 years, the longest in their history. It was the third season with Mike Holmgren as president and Tom Heckert as GM, and the second with Pat Shurmur as head coach. Jimmy Haslam took over as owner from Randy Lerner. They played all home games at Cleveland Browns Stadium in Ohio.

In 2007, the Cleveland Browns were in their 59th season as a pro sports team and their 55th in the NFL. They wanted to do better than their 4–12 record from 2006 and deal with injuries that hurt them last year. They were led by head coach Romeo Crennel and played home games at Cleveland Browns Stadium in Ohio.

question: How many restaurants comprise the quick service restaurant chain that Ron Joyce helped found?
pos: Tim Hortons, also called Timmy's or Tim's, is a Canadian fast-food chain famous for its coffee and doughnuts. It's the biggest quick-service restaurant in Canada, with 4,613 locations across nine countries as of December 31, 2016.

Ronald Vaughan Ron Joyce, born on October 19, 1930, is a Canadian billionaire businessman known for co-founding the Tim Hortons doughnut chain alongside Tim Horton, serving as his partner and the first franchisee.
neg: Toddle House was a popular restaurant chain across the US known for its quick breakfast options and round-the-clock service. They mainly focused on takeout orders.

Lion's Choice is a fast-food chain from Missouri known for its roast beef sandwiches. They use lean, top-round roast beef that's slow-roasted fresh every day in their kitchens. The beef is thinly sliced and served on a toasted and steamed bun with their special seasoning.

Shawarmer is a popular Middle Eastern fast-food chain known for its delicious Shawarma. It started in Riyadh in 1999 and has since expanded to 13 cities in Saudi Arabia, boasting over 70 branches. Shawarmer focuses on modernizing the traditional shawarma while ensuring high-quality standards, making it a major player in Saudi Arabia's food industry.

A fast food restaurant, also called a quick service restaurant (QSR), is a type of eatery where you can quickly grab food without much table service. They usually offer a limited menu of ready-made meals that are kept hot and packaged for takeout. Fast food places are often part of a chain or franchise, which means they use the same ingredients and supplies in all their locations. The term "fast food" was added to the Merriam–Webster dictionary in 1951.

Hero Certified Burgers is a Canadian restaurant chain that specializes in hamburgers and other fast food items. Founded in 2004 and headquartered in Toronto, Ontario, it had nearly 60 locations by March 2017. In 2015, it expanded to the United States, opening its first store in Elmwood Village, Buffalo, New York. Unfortunately, the Buffalo location closed its doors by the end of 2016. The company is known for using sustainably-sourced beef.

Noodle Box Pty Ltd is a fast-food chain in Australia known for its stir-fried noodles. It was started by Josh James and David Milne in 1996, with its main office located in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia.

Leeann Chin is an Asian fast-food chain based in Bloomington, Minnesota, with more than 50 locations in the Midwest, mainly in the Minneapolis-Saint Paul area. The chain was started by Leeann Chin herself, with funding from Carl Pohlad (a banker and former owner of the Minnesota Twins) and actor Sean Connery. In 2011, it won awards for Best Chinese Food and Best Takeout Food and ranked 80th on a list of the country's top 100 fast-casual restaurants by FastCasual.com. Currently, it's owned by Lorne Goldberg, a financier from Los Angeles who also owns other popular Asian chains like Pick Up Stix and Mandarin Express.

Arcos Dorados Holdings Inc. is the biggest franchisee of McDonald’s worldwide, both in terms of sales and the number of restaurants. By the end of 2010, it accounted for 6.7% of all McDonald’s franchises worldwide. With over 94,000 employees, it's the top employer for young people entering the workforce in Latin America and the Caribbean. Every day, it serves more than 4.3 million customers, making it the largest fast-food chain in the region.

question: Anthony Avent played basketball fo a High School that is located in a city approcimately 8 mi west of where?
pos: Anthony Avent, born on October 18, 1969, is a former American professional basketball player. He was chosen by the Atlanta Hawks as the 15th overall pick in the 1991 NBA Draft. Originally from Rocky Mount, North Carolina, Avent played for several NBA teams including the Milwaukee Bucks, Orlando Magic, Vancouver Grizzlies, Utah Jazz, and Los Angeles Clippers during his six-year career. He attended Seton Hall University, where he participated in the 1989 NCAA championship game. Before that, he played basketball at Malcolm X Shabazz High School in Newark, New Jersey.

Newark, also known locally, is the biggest city in the state of New Jersey and is the county seat of Essex County. It's a major hub for air travel, shipping, and rail transportation. In 2010, it had a population of 277,140, ranking it as the 67th most populous city in the US, down from 63rd place in 2000. By 2015, its population had grown to 281,944, making it the 70th largest city in the nation. Newark is the second largest city in the New York metropolitan area and is about 8 miles west of lower Manhattan.
neg: James Blackmon Sr. is an American basketball coach and former standout college and high school player. He led two teams to win the class 2A high school basketball championship in Indiana in 2008 and 2009. Blackmon also played basketball for the University of Kentucky Wildcats during college. He was recognized for his skills in high school, being named a McDonald's All-American and Parade All-American, and was a runner-up for the Indiana Mr. Basketball award in his senior year at Marion High School.

Finchampstead is a village in Berkshire, England, located in the Wokingham Borough. It's about 2 miles south of Wokingham, 5 miles west of Bracknell, 8 miles southeast of Reading, and 33 miles west of Central London. It's known for being an affluent area, ranking as the 31st wealthiest village in Britain. With its high standard of living, it's considered one of the most desirable places to live in the UK.

Presley Askew (1909–1994) was an American coach in basketball and baseball. He achieved 169 wins at New Mexico State and Arkansas, with a total record of 509–312 in high school and college coaching. Born in Red Oak, Oklahoma, he played basketball at Red Oak High School, then graduated from Eastern Oklahoma State College and Oklahoma State University. He started coaching at Fanshawe Public School in 1932 and later moved to Red Oak High School until 1942, when he shifted to Van Buren High School in Arkansas. At Van Buren, his teams were highly competitive and participated in state championship tournaments.

Weldon Drew, born on April 22, 1935, served as the head men's basketball coach at New Mexico State University from 1979 to 1985. He took over the role from Ken Hayes, who left for Oral Roberts University. Before that, Drew was an assistant coach at NMSU from 1975 to 1979. He came to NMSU after coaching basketball at Houston's Kashmere High School, where he had a remarkable record, including winning two Texas 4A state championships and a national championship in high school basketball. He earned national coach of the year honors in 1975. The NMSU job was Drew's first head coaching position at the college level. After a tough 1984-85 season, Drew was let go, and he then became an assistant coach at Oklahoma State for two seasons before taking over as head coach at Langston University in Oklahoma in 1987. Drew graduated from Fisk University in 1957, where he had an impressive basketball career, and he also played basketball at Wheatley High School in Houston.

Larry Haskell Friend (April 14, 1935 – February 27, 1998) was a basketball player in the American National Basketball Association (NBA). He was born in Chicago, Illinois, and initially played basketball at Marshall High School there. However, he later moved to Los Angeles, California, before his senior year and attended Fairfax High School. Friend began his college basketball career at Los Angeles City College, where he was recognized as an All-American Junior College player. Later, he transferred to the University of California, where he played for three years. During his senior season, he scored an average of 19.1 points per game and earned a spot on the AP All-American third team. Friend was selected as the fifth pick in the second round of the 1957 NBA Draft by the New York Knicks. He played one season with the Knicks, averaging 4.0 points, 2.4 rebounds, and 1.1 assists per game. Afterward, in the 1961-62 season, Friend returned to professional basketball to play for the Los Angeles Jets in the American Basketball League. He played in thirty-nine games and averaged 11.0 points and 3.7 rebounds per game, leading the league in three-point shooting (58-163). Unfortunately, due to financial issues, the Jets folded during their first season. Following his basketball career, Friend became involved in investment business. He passed away on February 27, 1998, in Newport, California, after battling prostate cancer.
