question: Walt Zeboski photographed which 40th President during his campaign in 1980?
pos: Walt Zeboski, an American photographer and photojournalist for the Associated Press, passed away on November 12, 2012. He worked for over thirty years and is best known for extensively photographing Ronald Reagan during his 1980 presidential campaign, capturing some of the most iconic images of the campaign. Zeboski's work often centered on California politics, and he covered the terms of four consecutive Governors of California from the 1960s to the 1980s: Pat Brown, Ronald Reagan, Jerry Brown, and George Deukmejian.

Ronald Wilson Reagan was an American leader and actor. He was the 40th President of the United States from 1981 to 1989. Before that, he served as the Governor of California from 1967 to 1975, after working as a Hollywood actor and a union leader.
neg: In 1960, John F. Kennedy, a Senator from Massachusetts, announced his bid for the presidency on January 2nd, aiming to replace Dwight D. Eisenhower. He clinched the Democratic Party's nomination at their convention in July and selected Lyndon B. Johnson as his running mate. Kennedy and Johnson won the election on November 8th, defeating Richard Nixon. They were inaugurated as President and Vice President on January 20, 1961. Kennedy served as President until his assassination in November 1963.

The 40th Battalion was an infantry group in the Australian Army. It was formed in 1916 during World War I and made up of soldiers from Tasmania. They fought on the Western Front and had two members who received the Victoria Cross. After the war, the battalion was dissolved but later reformed in 1921 as part of the Citizens Force, serving part-time in Tasmania. In World War II, it stayed in Australia until it joined with the 12th Battalion. After being disbanded in 1946, it was brought back in the 1950s and eventually became part of the Royal Tasmania Regiment in 1960. Finally, in 1987, it merged with the 12th Battalion to form the 12th/40th Battalion, Royal Tasmania Regiment.

Gerald Ford, originally named Leslie Lynch King Jr., was an American politician. He became the 38th President of the United States from August 1974 to January 1977 after Richard Nixon resigned. Before that, he served as the 40th Vice President for eight months, following Spiro Agnew's resignation. Ford was the first person appointed to the vice presidency under the 25th Amendment. He's also unique for being the only individual to serve as both Vice President and President without being elected to either position. Prior to his vice presidency, Ford spent 25 years as a U.S. Representative from Michigan's 5th congressional district, with the last nine years as the House Minority Leader.

Ronald Reagan, the 40th President of the United States, was known for his powerful speeches and debates. He started his career in Iowa as a radio broadcaster before moving to Los Angeles in 1937 to pursue acting, appearing in both movies and television shows. After giving a persuasive speech in support of Barry Goldwater's presidential campaign in 1964, he decided to run for Governor of California and won in 1966 and 1970. In 1980, Reagan ran for president as a Republican and defeated the incumbent, Jimmy Carter. He was reelected in 1984 with a large margin, famously declaring it was "Morning in America." Reagan served as president until 1989.

Wyman Park is a neighborhood that connects Hampden and Roland Park in Baltimore City. It became part of Baltimore City in 1888. The neighborhood stretches from 33rd Street to 40th Street from west to east, and from Keswick Road to Wyman Park from south to north. South of 40th Street, you'll find garden apartments, multi-story apartment buildings, and single-family homes. Residents often identify with areas north of 40th Street, including University Parkway and The Johns Hopkins University. Additionally, Wyman Park is home to the Union Soldiers and Sailors Monument, situated at 29th and Charles Street.

Bernhard Vogel, born on December 19, 1932, is a German politician affiliated with the CDU. He served as the Minister President of Rhineland-Palatinate from 1976 to 1988 and later as the Minister President of Thuringia from 1992 to 2003. Notably, he's the only person to have led two different German federal states and holds the record for being the longest-serving Minister President of Germany. Additionally, he held the position of President of the Bundesrat twice, in 1976/77 and 1987/88.

José Alberto Pepe Mujica Cordano, born on May 20, 1936, is a Uruguayan politician who served as the 40th President of Uruguay from 2010 to 2015. He was once involved with the Tupamaros, a group known for urban guerrilla warfare, and spent 13 years in prison during the military dictatorship of the 1970s and 1980s. Mujica, affiliated with the Broad Front coalition of left-wing parties, held the position of Minister of Livestock, Agriculture, and Fisheries from 2005 to 2008 before becoming a Senator. He won the 2009 presidential election as the Broad Front candidate and officially took office as President on March 1, 2010.

The 2/40th Battalion was a group of Australian soldiers formed in 1940, mainly recruited from Tasmania. They were part of the 8th Division's 23rd Brigade. Initially stationed in Darwin for defense as tensions with Japan rose in 1941, they later went to Timor with Sparrow Force when Japan entered the war. Despite being outnumbered and low on supplies, they fought the Japanese on the island. Most were captured and became prisoners of war, but some carried out guerrilla attacks before being withdrawn by the end of the year.

question: What type of film are both "500 Years Later" and "Manson"?
pos: "500 Years Later" is a documentary film made by Owen 'Alik Shahadah and written by M. K. Asante, Jr. It came out in 2005 and has won several awards at international film festivals, including Best Documentary at UNESCO Breaking the Chains Award, Pan African (Los Angeles), and Bridgetown (Barbados) Film Festivals. Additionally, it won Best Film at the International Black Cinema (Berlin) Film Festival and Best International Documentary at the Harlem (New York) International Film Festival.
"Manson" is a documentary from 1973 about Charles Manson and his followers. Robert Hendrickson and Laurence Merrick directed it.
neg: Idiocracy, released in 2006 and directed by Mike Judge, features Luke Wilson, Maya Rudolph, and Dax Shepard. It follows the journey of two individuals who join a secretive military experiment in human hibernation. They wake up 500 years later to find themselves in a chaotic society overwhelmed by advertising, consumerism, and a disdain for intelligence. This world lacks curiosity, social accountability, and clear ideas of justice and human rights.

Ife Piankhi is a talented artist from Uganda who works as a poet, singer, and educator. She's worked with various artists like Keko, Nneka, Mamoud Guinea, and more. For over 22 years, she's traveled around the world, including places like Canada, Ghana, and the USA. She was a regular host on Colourful Radio in London, and she's been featured in documentaries like "500 Years Later" and "Nubian Spirit," where her expertise in Nile Valley Civilisations was showcased. Additionally, she's the resident poet and MC for Poetry in Session, Kampala's longest-running poetry event.

Tukufu Zuberi, born on April 26, 1959, is an American sociologist, filmmaker, educator, and writer. He's known for his work in documentaries about Africa and its diaspora, like (2002) and 500 Years Later (2005). Zuberi is also a host on the PBS show History Detectives. He founded his production company and premiered the film African Independence at the San Diego Black Film Festival in January 2013. Currently, he holds the position of Lasry Family Professor of Race Relations, Professor and Chair of the Sociology Department, and professor of Africana Studies at the University of Pennsylvania.

Kyokusui-no-en is a modern Japanese event inspired by an old game played by nobles. Participants have to write a short poem next to a stream within a time frame determined by a cup of sake floating towards them. If the cup reaches them, they either drink to celebrate finishing their poem or take it as a penalty for not completing it in time. The tradition is believed to have started around 1,500 years ago, with some sources suggesting it began in the Heian period about 500 years later. There's also evidence of a similar game in China dating back to 353, where poems were recorded in Wang Xizhi's work, the Lantingji Xu.

Elizabeth Betita Martínez, born in 1925, is an American Chicana feminist known for her extensive involvement in community organizing, activism, writing, and teaching. She's authored many books and articles focusing on social movements in the Americas. One of her notable works is the bilingual "500 Years of Chicano History in Pictures," which later inspired the educational video "¡Viva la Causa! 500 Years of Chicano History." Angela Y. Davis has praised her work as one of the most significant records of progressive activism today, describing Martínez as unique, unstoppable, and tireless.

Ako Mitchell is an actor and filmmaker from Britain and America. He directed and co-wrote the short film "I'm in the Corner with the Bluebells," which was part of the international shorts competition at the 2014 Toronto International Film Festival. Recently, he played "Klook" in "Klook's Last Stand" at London's Park Theatre and was nominated for a Best Actor award at the Off West End Awards. He also portrayed Lenny Henry's brother in "Fences" in London's West End. Ako has worked at London's Donmar Warehouse and starred opposite Patina Miller in "Sister Act" at The London Palladium. His other credits include roles like Pilot in Nick Lloyd Webber's "The Little Prince," Mitch in "Spelling Bee" at Donmar Warehouse, Mufasa in "The Lion King" at Lyceum Theatre in the West End, Coalhouse Walker Jr. in "Ragtime" at Charing Cross Theatre, and Dennis in "Lake Placid: The Final Chapter" (Film). Additionally, he co-produced the documentary film "500 Years Later," which won awards at the Pan-African Film Festival, Black Berlin International Cinema, and Harlem International Film Festival.
Motherland, directed and written by Owen 'Alik Shahadah in 2010, is an independent documentary film. It serves as the sequel to the 2005 documentary titled 500 Years Later.

Ruakuri Cave, located in the Waitomo region of New Zealand, holds the title of being the longest underground cave in the area. Local Māori people stumbled upon it around 400 to 500 years ago. The cave got its name, "Ruakuri," meaning "den of dogs," when wild dogs were found living near its entrance about 300 years after its discovery.

Originally from Tokyo, Japan, he started at Waseda University but didn't finish his degree because he was part of a left-wing theater group. He joined P.C.L. The movie "Obsessed" (also known as "Human Addiction" or "Human Intoxication") is a South Korean erotic romance film from 2014. It tells the story of a couple who engage in a passionate affair while in a military camp under strict surveillance in 1969.

Bill Berry is the American Producing Director at The 5th Avenue Theatre in Seattle, Washington. Before that, he worked as associate producing artistic director and casting director from 2002 to 2009. This summer, he's set to make his Broadway directing debut with First Date the Musical at the Longacre Theatre. Berry's directing talent has been showcased in theaters across the US, with his recent work at New Jersey’s Paper Mill Playhouse earning critical acclaim for his production of On the Town.

"Juice," a 1992 American crime film, is about four young men growing up in Harlem. Directed by Ernest R. Dickerson and written by Dickerson and Gerard Brown, the movie stars Omar Epps, Jermaine Hopkins, Khalil Kain, and Tupac Shakur in his acting debut. It follows their daily lives, starting with harmless mischief but escalating to more serious situations over time. The film also explores the challenges they face, such as police harassment, rival gangs, and family issues. "Juice" marks Dickerson's debut as a writer and director.

question: Which city was the man who is known for a science humor story based on the tongue-in-cheek combination of two adages born in?

"Two Against Tyre" is a tale adapted from an unpublished story centered around Eithriall the Gaul, a character created by Robert E. Howard. The Ruins of Cawdor was the final graphical MUD out of three created for The Sierra Network, later known as The ImagiNation Network. It was designed by Richard Aronson, who wrote the popular RPG humor story "Eric and the Dread Gazebo," and was loosely inspired by Shakespeare's Macbeth.
"Knock," a science fiction tale by Fredric Brown, begins with a brief story inspired by a text by Thomas Bailey Aldrich.

The Circus Man is a silent film from 1914 made by Jesse Lasky and released by Paramount Pictures. Directed by Oscar Apfel and written by Cecil B. DeMille, it's based on the novel "The Rose in the Ring" by George Barr McCutcheon. You can find it preserved at the Library of Congress.

Mind Fields is a book that showcases paintings by Polish artist Jacek Yerka alongside short stories and prose poems by American writer Harlan Ellison. Yerka painted 34 artworks first, with each inspiring Ellison to write a short story, except for "Under the Landscape," which was based on two separate paintings.

Nord-Ost is a Russian musical play created by Aleksei Ivaschenko and Georgii Vasilyev. Battlefield Detectives was a TV series on the History Channel from 2003 to 2006. It delved into well-known battles, honing in on the actual battleground and recounting the events using up-to-date scientific findings. The show utilized modern science to uncover the strategies behind victories and defeats in historical conflicts.

question: What was the largest passenger capacity of the plane type used for BOAC Flight 911 ?
pos: BOAC Flight 911, also known as Speedbird 911, was a trip around the world flown by British Overseas Airways Corporation. Unfortunately, it crashed due to severe turbulence near Mount Fuji in Japan on March 5, 1966. The plane, a Boeing 707-436, was piloted by Captain Bernard Dobson, aged 45, from Dorset. He was a skilled pilot with experience flying 707s since November 1960.

The Boeing 707 is a medium-sized airplane with a long reach, designed by Boeing Commercial Airplanes and produced between 1958 and 1979. It's often referred to as the "seven oh seven." Different models of this plane can carry anywhere from 140 to 219 passengers and can fly distances ranging from 2500 to [insert missing range value here].
neg: BOAC Flight 712, also known as Speedbird 712, was a flight by British Overseas Airways Corporation using a Boeing 707-465 plane. It was flying from London Heathrow Airport to Sydney with stops in Zurich and Singapore. On April 8, 1968, during takeoff, one of its engines failed, causing a big fire. The engine actually detached from the plane while in the air. Although the plane managed to make an emergency landing, the situation was made worse by confusion over checklists and distractions from a check captain, leading to the tragic deaths of five out of the 127 people on board.

Silver Shadow, a cruise ship launched in 2000 and operated by Silversea Cruises, accommodates 382 passengers and employs 295 crew members. Its sister ship, the Silver Whisper, shares the same builder, the Mariotti Shipyard in Genoa, Italy. With a space-to-passenger ratio of 74, both ships offer more space per passenger compared to any other cruise ship. This ratio is determined by dividing a vessel's gross tonnage by its passenger capacity. Additionally, the passenger-to-crew ratio is 1.31 to 1, indicating ample staff for passenger assistance.

Silver Whisper, a cruise ship launched in 2000 and managed by Silversea Cruises, accommodates up to 382 passengers with a crew of 295. Its sister ship, the Silver Shadow, shares a similar design and was also constructed by the Mariotti Shipyard in Genoa, Italy. Both ships boast a high space-to-passenger ratio of 74, offering more room per passenger compared to other cruise liners. Additionally, the passenger-to-crew ratio stands at 1.31 to 1, indicating ample staff to attend to passenger needs.

Ball-bearing Run was the nickname for a flight during wartime that ran between Stockholm, Sweden, and Leuchers, Scotland. It was operated by the Royal Norwegian Air Force but appeared to be a regular BOAC (British Overseas Airways Corporation) flight for political reasons. The aircraft had civilian registration, and the Norwegian military crew wore BOAC uniforms and carried British passports.

BOAC Flight 777-A was a regular civilian flight operated by British Overseas Airways Corporation. It flew from Lisbon, Portugal, to Whitchurch Airport near Bristol, England, on June 1, 1943. During the journey, it was attacked by eight German Junkers Ju 88s and ultimately crashed into the Bay of Biscay, killing all 17 people on board. Among the passengers was the actor Leslie Howard.

The Freedom class consists of three cruise ships operated by Royal Caribbean International. The first ship in the class, Freedom of the Seas, held the title of the world's largest passenger ship and the largest ever built in terms of passenger capacity and gross tonnage when it was constructed in 2006. These records were held collectively by all three ships until the completion of the Oasis of the Seas in November 2009.

MV Caledonian Isles is a big ship owned by Caledonian Maritime Assets Limited and operated by Caledonian MacBrayne (CalMac). It ferries people and cars between the Hebridean and Clyde Islands of Scotland, particularly serving the route from Ardrossan to Brodick on the Isle of Arran. With a capacity for up to 1000 passengers and 110 cars, it's the biggest ship on one of CalMac's busiest routes. During the summer, it's especially popular for day trips to Arran, making the crossing in just 55 minutes.
Kenneth Stonehouse (1908–1943) was a British journalist who worked for Reuters in both the United States and Europe. He tragically died in the crash of BOAC Flight 777.

question: What is the birthday of this Anglo-Irish actress, courtean, and mistress, who was the mother to the illegitimate daughter of King William IV?
pos: Dorothea Jordan, born on November 22, 1761, and passing away on July 15, 1816, was an actress from Ireland and England. She was also known for her relationship with William IV, who would later become King of the United Kingdom. During his time as the Duke of Clarence, they were together for 20 years. They had ten children together, who all went by the last name FitzClarence, even though they were born out of wedlock.

Elizabeth Hay, also known as the Countess of Erroll, was born on January 17, 1801, and passed away on January 16, 1856. She was the illegitimate daughter of King William IV of the United Kingdom and Dorothea Jordan. At the age of 19, she married William Hay, who later became the 18th Earl of Erroll, thus becoming the Countess of Erroll on December 4, 1820. Due to her lineage, William Hay was appointed as the Lord Steward of the Household. Their wedding took place at St George's, Hanover Square. Elizabeth is depicted in a family portrait at the House of Dun, where she kept a stone thrown at her father, King William IV, and the gloves he wore during the opening of his first Parliament as souvenirs. She passed away in Edinburgh, Scotland.
neg: Amelia Cary, Viscountess Falkland (March 21, 1807 – July 2, 1858), was a British noblewoman. She was the fifth daughter of William IV of the United Kingdom (who was then the Duke of Clarence) and his longtime mistress, Dorothea Jordan. Amelia had four sisters and five brothers, all with the last name FitzClarence. When their father became king, the FitzClarence children were recognized as the younger children of a marquess. Amelia, who was a granddaughter of George III, was named after her aunt, Princess Amelia.

John Crichton-Stuart, the 5th Marquess of Bute, born on August 4, 1907, and passing away on August 14, 1956, was the son of John Crichton-Stuart, the 4th Marquess of Bute, and Augusta Bellingham. He was directly descended from Robert II of Scotland through his father's side and from William IV of the United Kingdom through his mother's side. This made him the first member of the Bute family to be descended from William IV.
Lady Mary Fox, born on December 19, 1798, was the illegitimate daughter of King William IV of the United Kingdom and his mistress, Dorothea Jordan. Later on, she pursued a career as a writer.

Lieutenant-General Lord Frederick FitzClarence, GCH (9 December 1799 – 30 October 1854), was a British Army officer and the third illegitimate son of King William IV and his mistress, Dorothea Jordan.

Lady Augusta Gordon, born on November 17, 1803, was a British noblewoman. She was the fourth daughter of William IV of the United Kingdom and his mistress Dorothea Jordan. They lived at Bushy House in Teddington. Augusta had four sisters and five brothers, all with the surname FitzClarence. When their father became king, they were given the status of younger children of a marquess.

Sophia Sidney, Baroness De L'Isle and Dudley, born on March 4, 1795, was the oldest daughter of King William IV of the United Kingdom and his mistress Dorothea Jordan. She married Philip Sidney, becoming the 1st Baroness De L'Isle and Dudley, and had four children who lived to adulthood. Before she passed away in 1837, she worked as the State Housekeeper at Kensington Palace.

The Regency Act of 1830, also known as 1 Will.4 c.2, was created by the UK Parliament in case King William IV died before his successor turned 18. It allowed for a regent to rule until the new monarch reached adulthood. Additionally, if King William IV had a child after his death, that child could have taken the throne instead of Queen Victoria. However, the Act was never put into effect because William did not have any legitimate children, and Queen Victoria became queen when she turned 18 in 1837.

Wilhelmina FitzClarence, also called Mina, was a British noblewoman and writer. Her mother, Lady Augusta FitzClarence, was the illegitimate daughter of William IV of the United Kingdom. Mina was born just after William became king. As a child, she traveled across Europe, visiting places like France and Hanover. In 1855, she married her first cousin, William FitzClarence, 2nd Earl of Munster, and they had nine children, including the 3rd and 4th Earls of Munster.
